S: Jeremy, a patient, reports a history of acute disc herniation, which occurred four months ago while moving boxes with his son. He reports pain when sitting, numbness and tingling in the lower back, accompanied by a sensation of tapple over the right toe, and a sensation of numbness and tingling in the right foot, which resolved within an hour. He also experiences pain in the lower back when he tries to support his upper body weight, and a sensation of numbness and tingling in the right foot, which has not improved since. He has a history of knee surgery two years ago, total knee replacement, and a total knee replacement in 2022. He denies any fever or chills. O: Vital signs in the office are good. Blood pressure is 117 over 506. Heart rate is slow at 64. Oxygenation is 99.5% on room air. Neck exam shows bony protuberance of the c5 c6. Lumbar spine x-ray shows decreased flexion and extension of the lower back, positive straight leg raise, and spasm of the paraspinal muscles of the lumbar spine. Musculoskeletal exam shows equal bilateral strength. Lumbar spine x-ray shows no acute bony abnormality. Lumbar spine x-ray shows no fracture of the back. A: The primary diagnosis is acute disc herniation, likely secondary to a traumatic event, given the patient's history of knee surgery and recent surgery. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of back pain and stiffness, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation. P: Order a lumbar spine MRI to assess the extent of herniation. Refer the patient to a physical therapist for further evaluation and management. Prescribe meloxicam 15 mg once a day for pain management. Discuss further treatment options such as an epidural steroid injection to reduce inflammation.

S: The patient reports feeling okay but recently experiences tarry stools. The patient denies any family history of cancer. O: Colonoscopy revealed a type 2 tumor in the transverse colon measuring 30  30 mm, marked with a black dye. Biopsy indicated poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma. Laboratory tests showed no remarkable abnormalities. CEA level was 3.1 ng/ml (normal range: 5.0-15.0 ng/ml) and CA19-9 level was 3.4 U/ml (normal range: 37-37 U/ml). CT scan showed wall thickening in the area of the tumor. CT scan indicated wall thickening in the tumor. Clinical diagnosis is T2N0M0, stage I, according to the TNM classification (UICC 8th edition). Post-colonoscopy, a laparoscopy-assisted colectomy was performed, revealing a 10-mm ulcer with a polypoid lesion of 8.5 mm in the center, but no type 2 tumor was found. Histological examination of the formalin-fixed specimen showed nonspecific granulation of tissue, indicating fibrillization under the mucous membrane and sloughing off of the epithelium. A: The primary diagnosis is poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma of the transverse colon, stage I, with no evidence of metastases. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of adenocarcinoma, but these are less likely given the imaging and histological findings. P: The patient underwent a laparoscopy-assisted colectomy to remove the tumor, which was performed 2 months post-colonoscopy. Post-operative management will include close monitoring of the patient's condition, including regular follow-ups to assess for any recurrence or new symptoms. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately.

S: The patient is a 39-year-old male presenting with a history of heroin and amphetamine abuse, presenting with a history of hallucination and a 0.5 mL of 24% paraquat injected into the right cephalic vein approximately 4 hours ago. He reports mild hypothermia with a body temperature of 35.8°C. He also experiences mild dyspnea, abdominal pain, and right wrist pain over the injection site. He also mentions tenderness in the abdomen around the epigastric area. O: Vital signs include a pulse rate of 63 beats/min, respiratory rate of 16 breaths/min, and blood pressure of 112/69 mm Hg. Laboratory findings include a positive urine paraquat test (4+), initial plasma paraquat concentration of 0.51 g/mL, and normal chest radiograph findings. Follow-up urine paraquat test was negative. A: The primary diagnosis is acute kidney injury secondary to paraquat ingestion, complicated by acute kidney injury, rapid serum creatinine augmentation, and intermittent postprandial abdominal pain and constipation. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of acute kidney injury, but these are less likely given the laboratory results and clinical presentation. P: Initiated charcoal hemoperfusion therapy to remove paraquat from the system, which was performed without methylprednisolone or cyclophosphamide therapy. The patient was admitted to the intensive care unit for further management, with charcoal hemoperfusion therapy performed. The patient will be monitored closely in the ICU, with appropriate fluid supplementation to maintain urine output and avoid nephrotoxic medications. The patient will be discharged 13 days post-admission, with instructions to continue follow-up with healthcare providers and maintain a healthy lifestyle.

S: The patient, with a history of hyperlipidemia, hypertension, and smoking, presented with an incidental pancreatic cyst discovered during a lung cancer screening helical CT. The patient reported no symptoms related to the incidental cyst. O: Initial examination revealed a 23 x 18 mm fluid density lesion in the distal pancreatic body, with no pancreatic ductal dilation. EUS-FNA revealed an anechoic and septated cyst. Cytology analysis showed an amylase level of 1532 and a CEA level of less than 200, consistent with a pseudocyst or benign cyst. Follow-up CT abdomen and pelvis with IV contrast in six months showed the cyst persisted. Repeat EUS-FNA using a 19G Boston Scientific needle and nCLE imaging confirmed the diagnosis of a cystic neuroendocrine tumor of the pancreas. Histopathology confirmed the diagnosis of a cystic neuroendocrine tumor. A: The primary diagnosis is a cystic neuroendocrine tumor of the pancreas, confirmed by histopathology. Differential diagnosis initially included a pseudocyst or benign cyst, but these were ruled out by imaging and histopathology. P: The patient underwent surgical evaluation to determine the best course of action for the cystic neuroendocrine tumor. Postoperative care will focus on monitoring the cyst's internal structures and managing any potential complications. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the cyst's progress and adjust treatment as necessary.

S: The patient, with a history of intestinal obstruction due to sigmoid volvulus, underwent laparotomy and detwisting sigmoidopexy, followed by elective sigmoidectomy 2 months ago. The patient reports experiencing abdominal distension, constipation, vomiting for 3 days, severe abdominal pain for one day, and recurrent constipation without seeking medical advice. The patient denies any significant family, drug, or social history. O: Physical examination revealed the patient to be ill but not pale, jaundiced, or febrile. Vital signs included a pulse rate of 104 bpm, blood pressure of 110/70 mmHg, respiratory rate of 22 cycles per minute, and temperature of 38.8°C. The abdomen was grossly distended with full flanks, a midline scar, visible dilated bowel loop, and peristalsis, with tenderness and no bowel sounds. Digital rectal examination showed a 3rd degree pile and an empty rectum. Blood tests showed Hb of 13 g/dl, WBCs of 14  109 per liter, and PLTs count of 305  109 per liter. Renal profile and serum electrolytes were within normal limits. Blood glucose was 193 mg/dl, and urine examination was unremarkable. Abdominal X-ray indicated a typically dilated omega-shaped colon. A: The primary diagnosis is strangulated bowel obstruction with adhesive type as the top differential. Differential diagnoses include other causes of abdominal distension and constipation, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The management plan includes NG tube suction and intravenous fluids resuscitation. The patient will be closely monitored for any changes in symptoms or condition. Further treatment options will be considered based on the patient's response to the treatment and potential complications. The patient is advised to maintain regular follow-ups and report any new symptoms or changes in condition.

S: The patient reports noticing a lump in the left breast, which has been bothersome. The patient has a history of a cough, which was not related to the previous diagnosis. O: Mammography and ultrasonography of the left breast revealed a lobulated mass in the upper quadrant at the 12 o'clock position, associated ipsilateral axillary lymphadenopathy, and several large cysts in both breasts. MR of the breasts showed a 25  23  27-mm mass in the left breast, and other smaller rim-enhancing lesions with rapid enhancement with a plateau and washout on the delayed phase. MR also showed a left lower lobe lung mass and associated atelectasis. Ultrasound-guided 14G core biopsy of the left breast mass indicated poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma of lung origin, with FNA positive for malignant cells. Staged CT scan confirmed a mass in the apical segment of the left lower lobe and widespread sclerotic bony metastasis involving the axial skeleton. A: The primary diagnosis is poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma of lung origin, likely of lung origin, with a secondary diagnosis of solitary brain metastasis in the left parietal lobe. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of breast cancer, but these are less likely given the imaging and biopsy results. P: The patient has been treated with chemotherapy but developed a solitary brain metastasis 13 months post-diagnosis. The disease remains well controlled 7 years post-diagnosis. The patient is advised to maintain regular follow-up appointments to monitor for any recurrence or complications.

S: The patient, a 5-year-old female, presented with a chief complaint of a mass and pain on her scalp for 8 days, followed by a fever for the past 2 days. The parent reports no improvement in the symptoms, with the fever peaking at 39 °C. The patient lives in the countryside and has been around dogs but is too young to remember any specific trauma or incident. O: Physical examination revealed a 10 by 12 cm tender erythematous boggy swelling on the scalp with significant loss of hair and yellowish-brown to hemorrhagic crusts. Removal of crusts revealed seropurulent discharge with stench and tenderness. Laboratory tests showed a white blood cell count of 12.41  109/L, 8.90  109/L neutrophils at 71.70%, and an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 43 mm/h. Urine, fecal, liver function, and renal function were normal. Bacteria culture from the lesion confirmed Staphylococcus aureus infection. Samples from the hair and ulcer were prepared using 10% potassium hydroxide solution for fluorescent brightening agents and Evans blue staining. A: The primary diagnosis is a bacterial infection with a fungal infection, likely a bacterial infection, given the culture results and culture results. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of scalp pain and fever, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and laboratory results. P: The management plan includes a combination of antibiotics for the bacterial infection and antifungal medications for the fungal infection. Close monitoring of the patient's response to treatment will be necessary, with adjustments to the treatment plan as necessary. The patient will be educated on the importance of adhering to the treatment regimen and adherence to the treatment plan. Referral to a dermatologist for further evaluation and management of the fungal infection is recommended.

S: The patient, a female with a history of an excisional biopsy for a benign right breast mass seven years ago, presents with a new mass in her left breast during the postpartum period. She denies breastfeeding and has no family history of breast or ovarian cancer. O: Clinical breast exam revealed a 3.6 cm mass at the 12 o'clock position of the left breast, approximately 4 cm from the nipple. axillary examination was normal. Ultrasound revealed a heterogenous 3.48 cm mass in the left breast. Core needle biopsy indicated benign breast tissue with focal secretary changes and chronic inflammation. Excisional biopsy identified a 3.2 cm malignant phyllodes tumor, extending to the inferior, medial, and posterior margins, with a 1.5 cm area of DCIS at the lateral margin, ER+ (90%) and PR- (negative) with a positive margin. Bilateral diagnostic mammogram showed a small cluster of punctate calcifications in the left upper outer quadrant, suggestive of malignancy. Genetic counseling and testing was negative for BRCA 1/2. A: The primary diagnosis is a malignant phyllodes tumor in the left breast, with differential diagnoses including benign breast tissue and malignant phyllodes tumor. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the aggressive nature of the tumor and the absence of malignancy. P: The patient underwent a left breast re-excision lumpectomy and wire localization excisional biopsy of the calcifications, followed by wire localization excisional biopsy of the calcifications. The patient has been placed on tamoxifen and is currently on adjuvant radiation therapy. Follow-up mammography, ultrasound, and clinical exam are stable. The patient is advised to maintain regular follow-up appointments to monitor her condition and manage any complications.

S: The patient is a 79-year-old male with a history of ischaemic heart disease and dyslipidemia. He was referred for further management of an incidental finding of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AA) in the aorta. He reported experiencing fever of 39°C, chills, loss of appetite, and back pain approximately 3 months post-surgery. O: Initial CT angiography showed an infrarenal AAA measuring 6.3 cm  7.0 cm  20.0 cm, extending to the right common iliac artery, with scattered wall calcifications. The thoracic aorta was normal. Full blood count showed a total white cell count of 15  109 l–1 with predominant neutrophilia. Repeat CT showed air surrounding the endovascular graft with inflammatory changes and aortic wall thickening, extending to the proximal common iliac artery. Blood cultures grew Staphylococcus aureus. A: The primary diagnosis is an infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm (AA) with associated inflammatory changes and aortic wall thickening. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of aortic aneurysms, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation. The prognosis is guarded due to the severity of the disease and the patient's severe symptoms. P: The patient underwent successful endovascular repair of the AAA using a bifurcated endovascular stent graft. Post-operative management included medical therapy and antibiotics, followed by surgical intervention. Blood cultures grew Staphylococcus aureus. The patient succumbed to sepsis after 1 week of medical therapy. The family has been informed, and support has been provided during this difficult time.

S: The patient, a male with a history of prostate cancer diagnosed 10 years ago and hepatic metastases detected a few months ago, presented with slowly progressive memory issues, mainly focusing on new names and appointments. He was diagnosed with prostate cancer 10 years ago and was treated with docetaxel. He also had a history of asthma and migraine, which have not been present for over 20 years. O: Neurological examination was unremarkable except for a mild tandem gait imbalance. Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MOCA) score was 22 out of 30, indicating mild cognitive impairment. ARHGAP26 antibodies were detected in serum with a CBA titer of 1:3,200. Immunohistochemistry indicated cerebellar staining and PCs with a dilution of 1:1,000, suggesting ARHGAP26. Rat hippocampal staining showed a fine granular-to-smooth pattern at 1:320. Immunohistochemistry remained highly indicative of ARHGAP26 at 1:3,200, and CBA titer increased to 1:10,000. A: The primary diagnosis is metastatic prostate cancer with associated hepatic metastases and hepatic metastases. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of metastatic cancers, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and immunohistochemistry results. P: The patient was treated with docetaxel for prostate cancer. The patient was treated with docetaxel for hepatic metastases. The family was informed of the patient's death and expressed their deepest condolences.

S: The patient, admitted to the hospital due to a hepatic disorder, reports feeling slightly off but did not expect any serious symptoms. O: Blood tests revealed aspartate aminotransferase at 48 U/L (normal range 13 to 33 U/L), alanine phosphatase at 66 U/L (normal range 8.0 to 42 U/L), and alkaline phosphatase, total bilirubin, carcinoembryonic antigen, and carbohydrate antigen 19-9 levels within normal limits. Abdominal ultrasonography identified an 8  7-mm solid mass at the gallbladder fundus and several stones in the gallbladder. Enhanced CT scan showed irregular wall thickening at the gallbladder fundus and an indistinct boundary between the tumor and liver. T2-weighted MRI indicated a high-intensity nodule in the thickened wall at the gallbladder fundus. Surgical findings included a 10 mm solid mass at the gallbladder fundus and a color change on the liver bed floor adjacent to the tumor. Histopathological findings indicated papillary tumors with cyst formation and mucin secretion. A: The primary diagnosis is suspected malignancy of the gallbladder fundus, likely a submucosal tumor. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of gallbladder malignancy, but these are less likely given the imaging and histopathological findings. P: The patient underwent a laparoscopic cholecystectomy and liver bed resection of the gallbladder fundus, which successfully removed the tumor and affected tissue. Regular follow-up appointments are scheduled to monitor for any recurrence. The patient is advised to maintain a healthy lifestyle and attend all follow-up appointments to ensure optimal health outcomes.

S: The patient, previously diagnosed with squamous cell carcinoma in the left maxillary gingiva, underwent a partial maxillectomy. Post-surgery, the patient had two dental implants placed in the anterior maxillary region and one zygomatic implant placed in the right side of the zygomatic bone. During a second-stage surgery, one of the dental implants in the anterior region was removed due to loss of osseointegration. The other implants and prosthesis have been stable, with no issues since 1 year and 6 months since functional loading. O: The patient underwent a partial maxillectomy for squamous cell carcinoma in the left maxillary gingiva. Post-surgery, two dental implants were placed in the anterior maxillary region, and one zygomatic implant was placed in the right side of the zygomatic bone. During the second-stage surgery, one of the dental implants in the anterior region was removed due to loss of osseointegration. The other dental implants and prosthesis have been stable, with no issues since 1 year and 6 months since functional loading. A: The primary diagnosis is squamous cell carcinoma in the left maxillary gingiva, with complications including loss of osseointegration and osseointegration. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of dental tumors, but these are less likely given the patient's history and current findings. P: Continue regular dental check-ups to monitor the stability of the dental implants and prosthesis. Encourage the patient to report any discomfort or changes in the prosthesis. Encourage the patient to report any new symptoms immediately.

S: The patient reports a history of leg edema for several years, worsening recently, primarily below the knee. O: The patient's LEL index is 179 on the right and 173 on the left, indicating lymphedema in both legs. Varicose veins are noted along the medial side in the edematous leg. Clinical disease severity is C3 using the revised CEAP classification. Duplex ultrasound scanning shows reflux longer than 2.0 seconds along the length of the great saphenous vein (GSV) in both thigh and lower leg regions, confirmed by manual compression of the calf. No venous thrombosis was detected. Varicose vein stripping is performed, removing affected veins from the ankle to the groin bilaterally. Clinical disease severity is stage 2 using the Campisi clinical staging system for lymphedema. A: The primary diagnosis is venous insufficiency, characterized by venous insufficiency. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of leg edema, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The management plan includes varicose vein stripping and indocyanine green (ICG) lymphography to confirm the status of lymphatic flow. The patient will be educated on the procedure and instructions to follow. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's condition and adjust treatment as necessary.

S: The patient, with a history of type I diabetes mellitus for over 20 years, Addison disease, and systemic lupus erythematosus, presents with increasing abdominal pain, poor oral intake, and episodes of nausea with blood-tinged emesis over the past six days. The patient denies any history of tobacco or alcohol use but uses marijuana daily. O: Vital signs include a temperature of 97.1° F, blood pressure 130/102 mmHg, heart rate 140 beats/minute, and respiratory rate 26 breaths/minute. Physical examination reveals abdominal guarding. Laboratory findings include blood glucose 763 mg/dL, CO2 8 mmol/L, -hydroxybutyrate 15.3 mmol/L with an anion gap 36 mmol/L, arterial blood gas pH 7.11, HCO3 4.1 mmol/L, urinary ketones 80 mg/dL, urine glucose  500 mg/dL, and hemoglobin A1C 15.3%. CT of the abdomen and pelvis shows extensive low-attenuation surrounding the distal esophagus with esophageal wall thickening. A: The primary diagnosis is diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), evidenced by imaging and clinical findings. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of abdominal pain, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: Initiate insulin drip and aggressive intravenous fluid resuscitation to manage DKA. Consult gastroenterology for further evaluation of the esophagus. Educate the patient on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and adherence to follow-up appointments. Schedule follow-up appointments to monitor the patient's condition and adjust treatment as necessary.

S: The patient reports chronic back pain worsening over the past three days, accompanied by diarrhea and numbness in the right thigh. The patient has a significant medical history including end-stage renal disease (ESRD), alpha-2-antiplasmin deficiency, chronic pancytopenia, prostate cancer, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia, treated with fluoroscopy-guided corticosteroid injections two weeks ago. The patient denies fevers, chills, night sweats, or antibiotic use. O: Physical examination revealed pain on deep palpation of the lower abdomen and light palpation over the lumbar spine and lumbar paraspinal muscles, with positive psoas signs. Muscle strength is preserved. Laboratory results showed pancytopenia with white blood cells at 3.66 K/cmm, red blood cells at 2.64 M/cmm, platelets at 127 K/cmm, neutropenia with a count of 1.38 K/cmm, elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 46 mm/hr, and a C-reactive protein level of 116 mg/L. MRI scan indicated discitis at the L2-L3 vertebral joint, vertebral osteomyelitis with phlegmon, and multiple bilateral psoas abscesses. Cultures from peripheral venous blood, hemodialysis line, and urine were taken. CT-guided fine-needle aspiration of the abscesses yielded purulent fluid with gram-positive cocci. A: The primary diagnosis is discitis at the L2-L3 vertebral joint, vertebral osteomyelitis with phlegmon, and multiple bilateral psoas abscesses. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of psoas abscesses, but these are less likely given the culture results and imaging results. P: The management plan will include close monitoring of the patient's condition and adjustment of the treatment plan as necessary. The patient will be educated on the importance of follow-up and adherence to the treatment plan to manage pain and address the underlying issues. Referral to a neurologist for further evaluation and management of the abs

S: The patient is a 54-year-old Caucasian male with a 30-year history of HIV infection treated with lamivudine, stavudine, and indinavir since 1997. He reports a 10-day history of asthenia, myalgia, and jaundice. He denies any recent trauma, prolonged immobilization, convulsions, or consumption of alcohol or illicit substances. He has a history of acute hepatitis A and active hepatitis C genotype 1a. O: On examination, the patient is slightly hypertensive with a blood pressure of 144/84 mmHg, mucocutaneous jaundice, unremarkable cardiopulmonary status, and no edema of the extremities. Abdominal examination revealed hepatomegaly 2 cm below the costal margin, severe muscle weakness, and elevated creatinine kinase (CK) at 185190 U/I, creatinine at 553 mol/l, phosphate at 3.03 mmol/l, and potassium at 7. Laboratory findings include elevated creatinine kinase (CK) at 185190 U/I, creatinine at 553 mol/l, phosphate at 3.03 mmol/l, and potassium at 7. A: The primary diagnosis is acute hepatitis A and active hepatitis C genotype 1a, complicated by hepatomegaly and muscle weakness. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of acute myalgia and asthenia, but these are less likely given the imaging and laboratory findings. P: Continue current HIV therapy with Genvoya® Genvoya®. Monitor liver enzymes and kidney function closely. Educate the patient on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and adherence to the treatment regimen. Schedule follow-up appointments to assess treatment efficacy and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Ensure patient understands the importance of compliance with the treatment regimen and follow-up appointments.

S: The patient, with a one-year history of pulsatile tinnitus in the right ear, reports no history of trauma, surgery, or other diseases related to the condition. O: Examination and laboratory tests were normal. Carotid Doppler sonography showed normal carotid intima-media thickness and no plaque formation. Increased peak systolic and end diastolic velocities were noted in the right common carotid artery with values of 75 cm/sec, 33 cm/sec, and 0.49 cm/sec. The left common carotid artery showed 63 cm/sec, 20 cm/sec, and 0.65 cm/sec. The right external carotid artery showed 760 ml/min, with a resistive index of 0.53. Subcutaneous vascular structure was noted in the right suboccipital-mastoid region with a high flow rate of 128 cm/sec and low resistance (RI = 0.48). CT angiography (CTA) revealed a Cognard type I DAVF in the right mastoid region. A: The primary diagnosis is a Cognard type I DAVF in the right mastoid region, likely secondary to vascular abnormalities. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of pulsatile tinnitus, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: Plan to perform a CT angiography (CTA) as soon as possible to assess the cause of the abnormalities and determine the best course of action. The patient will be closely monitored for any changes in the condition and advised to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's condition and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient reports experiencing blurred vision for the last 2 months, which is unclear. O: The patient's best corrected visual acuity is 20/100 in both eyes. The pupils are isochoric, and light reflexes are bilaterally present. Slit-lamp anterior segment examination is normal. Intraocular pressure values are within normal limits. Fundus examination shows RPE changes in the macula of both eyes. Fluorescein Fundus Angiography (FFA) and Indocyanine Green Angiography (ICGA) reveal irregular hyperfluorescent areas in both eyes in the early and late phases. Indocyanine Green Angiography (ICGA) indicates dilated choroidal vessels in the early phase and plaque CNV in the late phase. Fundus autofluorescence shows hyperautofluorescent spots in the central fovea and superonasal to the fovea in the right eye. Spectral domain OCT (Heidelberg) shows bilateral subretinal fluid, shallow irregular PED, and pachy-veins in both eyes. OCT-A (RTVue XR "Avanti", Optovue, Fremont, California, United States of America) imaging reveals a tangled hyperreflective neovascular network compatible with type 1 CNV in the choroid slab of both eyes. A: The primary diagnosis is type 1 CNV in the choroid slab of both eyes, evidenced by the presence of dilated choroidal vessels and plaque CNV in the late phase. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of blurred vision, but these are less likely given the imaging results and imaging findings. P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition with regular follow-up appointments to adjust the treatment plan as necessary. The patient will be educated on the importance of compliance with the treatment plan and expected outcomes. Referral to a neurologist for further evaluation and management of type 1 CNV is recommended.

S: The patient is a 24-year-old female in good health with a chief complaint of abnormal-looking upper front teeth since 10 years. She reports a chief complaint of abnormal-looking upper front teeth since 10 years. O: Physical examination reveals retained deciduous maxillary right lateral incisor and canine and deciduous left canine, along with a congenitally missing permanent maxillary left lateral incisor. Diagnostic impressions and casts are taken, along with preoperative orthopantomograph and RVGs. Phase 1 therapy includes 1 g of AugmentinTM, amoxicillin and clavulanate, and atraumatic extraction using luxators (SDI®) and periotomes (Medessa®). A: The primary diagnosis is an abnormal-looking upper front teeth with a congenitally missing permanent maxillary left lateral incisor. The patient's condition is complicated by a congenital missing permanent maxillary left lateral incisor. P: The management plan includes immediate implant placement following extraction with respect to the deciduous teeth (52, 53, and 63) and a fixed prosthesis following intentional endodontic therapy with respect to 23. The patient will be given 1 g of AugmentinTM as a prophylactic antibiotic therapy, and local anesthesia will be administered to prevent damage to the alveolar ridge. The extraction will be performed atraumatically using luxators (SDI®) and periotomes (Medessa®), with anterior forceps to minimize tissue damage, preserving the gingiva and socket. A: The primary diagnosis is an abnormal-looking upper front teeth with a congenital missing permanent maxillary left lateral incisor. The patient's condition is complicated by a congenital missing permanent maxillary left lateral incisor. The prognosis depends on the success of the surgical intervention and the patient's compliance with the treatment plan. P: The management plan includes immediate implant placement following extraction with respect to the deciduous teeth (52, 53, and 63) and a fixed prosthesis following intentional endodontic therapy with respect to 23. Postoperative care will include a detailed case history, treatment plan, and written informed

S: The patient is an 11-year-old boy with a history of blunt chest trauma post-driving by a truck. He reports difficulty breathing and difficulty breathing. He was previously healthy with no co-morbidities. O: On examination, the patient's Airway (A) was patent. Breathing (B) showed bilateral subcutaneous emphysema, right tension pneumothorax, and tachypnea with a respiratory rate of 42/min and oxygen saturation of 66% on 10 L of oxygen by non-rebreather mask. Circulation (C) was hemodynamically unstable with a pulse rate of 162/min, blood pressure of 112/94 mmHg, and Glasgow Coma Scale of 11/15. CT examination showed multiple injuries including bilateral hemopneumothorax, bilateral lung contusion, and left multiple rib fractures. The right chest tube had massive air leakage. A: The primary diagnosis is a right bronchus intermedius injury secondary to blunt chest trauma post-driving. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of chest trauma, but these are less likely given the CT findings. P: The patient underwent intubation with a single-lumen endotracheal tube and intercostal drains for emergency pneumothorax treatment. The patient was intubated with a single-lumen endotracheal tube and intercostal drains for emergency pneumothorax treatment. Blood gas analysis showed a pH of 6.897, PaCO2 of 96.4 mmHg, PaO2 of 96.8 mmHg, BE of -13.6 mmol/L, and lactate level of 74 mg/dL. CT imaging confirmed a right bronchus intermedius injury, necessitating emergency thoracotomy. A: The primary diagnosis is a right bronchus intermedius injury post-driving, complicated by bilateral lung contusion and multiple rib fractures. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of chest trauma, but these are less likely given the CT findings. P: The patient will require close monitoring and follow-up care to manage and manage the right bronchus intermedius injury. The patient will be educated on the importance of adherence to

S: The patient, a 9-month-old unvaccinated Amish female, presents with a chief complaint of fever, cough, and increased work of breathing. The parent reports no significant past medical history. O: Physical examination reveals significant respiratory distress and bilateral wheezing. Chest X-ray shows bilateral infra-hilar streaky opacities, worsening immediately following intubation. Complete blood count is unremarkable. Initial treatment with nebulized albuterol was ineffective. Chest X-ray showed bilateral infra-hilar streaky opacities, which worsened upon imaging. Despite aggressive bronchodilator therapy and airway clearance, the patient exhibits clinical signs of obstructive airway disease, positive tracheal aspirate culture for Streptococcus pneumoniae and Haemophilus influenzae. Initial chest X-ray showed acute left-sided lung collapse without choking episodes or foreign body aspiration. A: The primary diagnosis is obstructive airway disease with complications including respiratory distress, cough, and wheezing. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of respiratory distress and respiratory distress, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and imaging findings. P: Continue monitoring the patient's respiratory status and adjust the treatment plan as necessary based on the patient's response to treatment and response to bronchodilator therapy. Maintain current regimen of piperacillin/tazobactam (Zosyn) and adjust as necessary based on the patient's response to treatment. Educate the parents about the importance of adhering to the treatment regimen and adherence to the treatment plan.

S: The patient reports a one-month history of mouth ulcers, painful swallowing, and fever. The patient has a history of asthma, mild-moderate mitral regurgitation, and no recent travel history or new sexual partners. The patient denies any new medications, alcohol, recreational drugs, or smoking. O: On admission, the patient's temperature was 38.2°C. Laboratory tests showed mild anemia with a hemoglobin level of 119 g/L, platelet count of 227  109/L, white cell count of 9.0  109/L, and albumin of 33 g/L. ESR was elevated at 69 mm/hr, and CRP was 73 mg/L. ANCA test was negative, complement component C4 was elevated, and the rest of the autoimmune screen was negative. Blood and urine cultures showed no bacterial growth, viral throat swab, or coeliac serology. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy showed marked oropharyngeal ulceration without contact bleeding. CT scan of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis showed no abnormalities. A: The primary diagnosis is a cutaneous ulcer with a history of mild anemia and inflammatory processes, likely exacerbated by the patient's history of asthma and asymptomatic mild-moderate mitral regurgitation. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of anemia and inflammatory processes, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and laboratory findings. P: Continue monitoring the patient's condition closely with regular follow-ups to assess for any recurrence or worsening of symptoms. Educate the patient on the importance of reporting any new or worsening symptoms immediately. Consider referral to a rheumatologist for further evaluation and management. Ensure the patient understands the importance of reporting any new or worsening symptoms promptly.

S: The patient reports mild chronic diarrhea worsened by metformin but no other abdominal symptoms. The patient has a history of ischemic heart disease treated with clopidogrel, which is contraindicated to total optical colonoscopy. O: The patient was referred due to a positive fecal occult blood test. During the virtual colonoscopy, a complete cutoff of the inflated colon was noted on a CT topogram at the sigmoid and descending colonic junction. A conventional non-contrast-enhanced abdominal CT and secondary contrast-enhanced acquisition revealed a short contrast-enhancing "scar-like" structure infiltrating the posterior colonic wall at the level of the sigmoid and descending colonic junction, with multiple adherences with the retroperitoneum and the left iliac fossa. No obstruction, subocclusion, or fecal stasis upstream was noted. Ultrasound showed a perfectly empty descending colon with normal mucosal relief, but a thickening of the muscle layer at the junction of the sigmoid and descending colon. A: The primary diagnosis is retrograde and unidirectional functional stenosis of the colon, likely due to ischemic heart disease. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of colonic stenosis, but these are less likely given the imaging results and imaging findings. P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the colon's function and potential treatment options. The patient will be scheduled for a follow-up appointment to discuss potential treatment options. The patient is advised to reach out with any further questions or concerns.

S: The patient reports an urge to move legs, which worsens during rest and occurs before night sleep. A full-night diagnostic PSG recording was performed while on zolpidem (5 mg), revealing periodic leg movement (PLM) bursts. The patient experienced a comfortable warmth in the legs after 4W-acuinjections, but short PLM bursts reappeared 124 minutes later, indicating restorative sleep in the morning. A: The primary diagnosis is Restless Leg Syndrome (RLS), evidenced by the patient's symptoms and laboratory findings. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of leg discomfort, but these are less likely given the patient's history of hyperlipidemia and ischemic heart disease. P: Continue zolpidem (5 mg) and monitor the patient's sleep patterns closely. Continue hypnotic therapy and monitor the patient's sleep patterns closely. Educate the patient on the importance of adhering to the prescribed medication regimen and avoiding hypnotics if symptoms persist or worsen. Schedule a follow-up appointment in one week or sooner if symptoms persist or worsen.

S: Ben Doe, a 66-year-old male, presents with a four-day history of a severe headache, hotness, and a temperature of 10°C. S: The patient, with a history of hypertension and diabetes, presents with body weight loss. The patient has a history of hypertension and diabetes, which are well-controlled by medication. A: The primary diagnosis is ypT4b, ypN0, M0, ypStage IIC, stage IIIC, stage IIIC, stage IIIC, stage IIIC, stage IIIC, stage IIIC, stage IIIC, stage IIIC, stage IIIC, stage IIIC, stage IIIC, stage IIIC, stage IIIC, stage IIIC, stage IIIC, stage IIIC, stage IIIC, stage IIIC, stage IIIC, stage IIIC, stage IIIC, stage IIIC, stage IIIC, stage IIIC, stage IIIC, stage IIIC, stage IIIC, stage IIIC, stage IIIC, stage IIIC, stage IIIC, stage IIIC, stage IIIC, stage IIIC, stage IIIC, stage IIIC, stage IIIC, stage IIIC, stage IIIC, stage IIIC

S: The patient was a 47-year-old male with a 17 pack-year history of smoking, presenting with symptoms of weakness and difficulty breathing. He reported a history of smoking and was diagnosed with metastatic disease in the left upper lobe, presenting with a primary tumor in the left upper lobe measuring 4.7 cm in diameter, extensive thoracic lymphadenopathy, and multiple ring-enhancing brain metastases up to 4.5 cm in diameter, mostly in the right cerebral hemisphere. O: Physical examination revealed a primary tumor in the left upper lobe, 4.7 cm in diameter, extensive thoracic lymphadenopathy, and multiple ring-enhancing brain metastases up to 4.5 cm in diameter, mostly in the right cerebral hemisphere. Pathology from the lung mass indicated adenocarcinoma histology. Genetic analysis identified an EGFR exon 20 variant with an amino acid residual, indicating reduced sensitivity to EGFR-TKI. Chest CT imaging re-evaluation showed small (8 mm in size), innumerable, diffusely located bilateral lung nodular metastases. Treatment included whole-brain radiation therapy (WBRT), cisplatin and pemetrexed, docetaxel, nivolumab, and erlotinib, followed by docetaxel, nivolumab, and erlotinib. MRI of the head showed new tiny (3-8 mm in size), numerous, diffusely located, nodular brain metastases without significant peritumoral edema or dominant mass lesion. A: The primary diagnosis was metastatic adenocarcinoma of the left upper lobe, with multiple brain metastases. The patient's EGFR exon 20 mutation was identified, indicating reduced sensitivity to EGFR-TKI. Differential diagnoses were considered but ruled out based on genetic testing. P: The patient underwent whole-brain radiation therapy (WBRT) with a partial response to the left lung primary and near-complete resolution of the miliary lung metastases, followed by docetaxel, nivolumab, and erlotini

S: The patient, a female, reports a history of gastroenteritis, characterized by tummy pain and fever. She has been taking Paracetamols for five days and has not been on any regular medications. S: The patient, a male, presented with two episodes of loss of consciousness at rest over a fortnight, describing sudden collapse and shaking in all four limbs. He denies any recent alcohol or drug use. He denies any family history of blackouts, collapse, or unexplained sudden death. O: Physical examination revealed no cardiac failure, audible murmurs, tetany, or facial dysmorphia. ECG showed sinus rhythm with a prolonged corrected QT interval of 588 ms, with normal PR interval and QRS duration. Blood tests showed corrected calcium at less than 1.25 mmol/L (normal 2.2-2.5 mmol/L), phosphate at 2.88 mmol/L (normal 172 /L), and ALP at 172 /L (normal 2.2-2.5 mmol/L). Endocrine investigations showed parathyroid hormone (PTH) at less than 3 ng/mL, vitamin D at 24.1 nmol/L, and normal thyroid function tests. Echocardiography showed no structural abnormalities and preserved ventricular size and function. CT scan of the head was unremarkable. A: The primary diagnosis is sudden cardiac collapse secondary to a complication of cardiac failure. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of cardiac failure, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The patient was admitted to a monitored bed and started on intravenous calcium replacement therapy, including a 10 mL 10% calcium gluconate bolus over 30 minutes, followed by an infusion of 1% calcium gluconate in one litre of normal saline at a rate of 50 mL/hour. The treatment plan includes continued monitoring of cardiac activity and adjustment of the treatment as necessary. The patient will continue to be monitored on a cardiac monitor and will be monitored for any changes in cardiac function or deterioration.

S: Greg, who suffered intracranial hemorrhages in a Humvee rollover in 2014, was unresponsive and intubated. He returned to the United States for ongoing treatment. He was referred to music therapy for cognitive deficits due to severe traumatic brain injury. The initial music therapy assessment in January 2016 identified expressive speech issues, memory problems, and coordination deficits. He performed the song "We Didn't Start the Fire" by Billy Joel as a duet, which improved his speech and memory. O: Greg's initial music therapy assessment in January 2016 showed expressive speech issues, memory problems, and coordination deficits. The music therapy sessions involved therapeutic singing, rhythmic cueing, and vocal prosody exercises. The exercises addressed hypernasality, slurred speech, fluidity, intonation, and articulation, improving speech control and intonation. A: The primary diagnosis is severe traumatic brain injury with associated cognitive deficits and cognitive deficits. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of speech and memory deficits, but these are less likely given the specific findings. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the improvement in his speech and memory. P: Continue outpatient treatment with music therapy sessions to address cognitive deficits and improve speech and memory. Encourage active participation in therapy and engage with an audience to improve self-practice. Encourage regular follow-up appointments to monitor progress and adjust treatment plans as necessary. Educate Greg on the importance of adherence to the treatment plan and the importance of adherence to the treatment plan.

S: The patient, a 63-year-old with a history of large aortic valve (AVMs) diagnosed at age 63, reports a recent fall resulting in a right femoral shaft fracture. The patient has a history of bruising on the right thigh and limping since age 3. O: On admission, massive swelling and venous varicosities were noted in the right thigh. Plain radiography showed a fracture in the femoral shaft, bony erosion, and numerous phleboliths. Computed tomography showed enhanced AVMs and phleboliths in the quadriceps femoris and the hypotrophy of the femur. Three-dimensional computed tomography angiography indicated feeding by the branches of the deep and superficial femoral artery. Closed reduction of the fracture using the fracture table was difficult, leading to massive bleeding (1000 mL). Taylor Spatial Frame (TSF) was applied, and acute correction was performed, resulting in total blood loss of 2300 mL. The patient was transfused with 23 units of red cell concentrate, 10 units of fresh-frozen plasma, and 20 units of platelet concentrate. A: The primary diagnosis is a right femoral shaft fracture with associated phleboliths and fractures. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of bruising and limping, but these are less likely given the imaging and surgical findings. P: The patient underwent closed reduction and intramedullary nailing using elastic nails fixed to a monotube unilateral external fixator. Postoperative management included transfusion of 23 units of red cell concentrate, 10 units of fresh-frozen plasma, and 20 units of platelet concentrate. The patient was transferred to the ICU and received 8 units of red cell concentrate. Postoperative care includes close monitoring of residual displacement of the fracture, with close monitoring of the fracture's condition. Further consultations with a nephrologist and a cardiologist are recommended to manage the fracture and manage any complications.

S: The patient, with a history of peripheral artery disease and iron deficiency anemia, presented with worsening leg pain. He reported no hematochezia, melena, hematemesis, fatigue, or abdominal pain. He has been taking oral iron supplements for the last five years. O: Physical examination revealed pale conjunctivae. Vital signs were stable. Laboratory tests showed a hemoglobin level of 6.9 g/dL, mean corpuscular volume of 73.5, and hematocrit of 22.7% with normal white blood cell and platelet counts. Iron-deficiency anemia analysis showed ferritin at 6 ng/mL, serum iron at 25 g/dL, total iron-binding capacity at 535 g/dL, and transferrin saturation at 5%. Upper and lower endoscopy showed no active bleeding or suspicious lesions. Small bowel capsule endoscopy identified a suspicious lesion in the jejunum with fresh blood. Double balloon enteroscopy identified a 25mm proximal jejunal soft submucosal mass with mild superficial ulceration/erosions of the surface mucosa. Biopsy from the mass confirmed a cavernous hemangioma without malignancy. A: The primary diagnosis is cavernous hemangioma with no evidence of malignancy. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of gastrointestinal bleeding, but these are less likely given the imaging and biopsy results. P: The patient will be referred to the gastroenterology department for further evaluation of gastrointestinal bleeding. Follow-up with the gastroenterology department will be necessary to manage the hemangioma. The patient is advised to monitor symptoms and follow up with the surgeon for further management and surgical evaluation. Education on the importance of iron supplementation and adherence to iron supplementation will be provided.

S: The patient, a 5-year-old male, presented with a chief complaint of a generalized rash and fever, described as erythematous maculopapular and pruritic rash covering the face, trunk, back, and limbs, with a high-grade fever (40 °C) and weakness. The patient also reported enlarged cervical and inguinal lymph nodes, facial, neck, and scrotal edema. O: Laboratory findings include progressive leukocytosis (26,280/L), eosinophilia (5010/L), minimal liver function changes, elevated lactate dehydrogenase (805 U/L), and slightly elevated C-reactive protein (6 mg/dL). Liver function tests showed minimal alterations, lactate dehydrogenase levels at 805 U/L, and slightly elevated C-reactive protein at 6.10 mg/dL. Chest and renal function tests were normal. Virological examinations for Epstein-Barr virus, cytomegalovirus, herpes-simplex virus, hepatitis, and parvovirus were negative. Skin biopsy confirmed eosinophilic infiltration. A: The primary diagnosis is eosinophilic infiltration of the skin, likely exacerbated by current intravenous vancomycin. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of eosinophilic infiltration, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and laboratory findings. P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition and considering alternative treatments for osteomyelitis. The patient is advised to report any changes or worsening of symptoms immediately. Referral to a pediatric rheumatologist for further evaluation and management of eosinophilic infiltration is recommended. Education on the importance of reporting new or worsening symptoms will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient reports difficulty swallowing, pain when trying to swallow, shortness of breath, and chest pain. The patient has a history of a dental repair 16 years ago, where metallic dentures were fitted. O: Physical examination revealed swollen neck, face, and eyelids, and subcutaneous crepitus. Skull radiograph showed a missing partial denture from the right lower jaw, and chest radiographs revealed two metallic density objects in the retrocardiac area adjacent to the descending aorta with mild right-sided pleural effusion, pneumomediastinum, and subcutaneous emphysema. CT imaging of the neck and thorax confirmed a perforated oesophagus with two metallic density objects measuring approximately 17 mm in the middle one-third of the oesophagus, a suspected contained leak of orally ingested positive contrast media along the right posterolateral aspect of the oesophagus, pneumomediastinum with left pneumothorax, and subcutaneous emphysema of the neck and chest. Emergency thoracoscopic removal of the foreign body was performed, and the oesophageal tear was repaired. A: The primary diagnosis is a perforated oesophagus secondary to ingested dentures. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of oesophageal perforation, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The patient underwent emergency thoracoscopic removal of the foreign body and repaired the oesophageal tear. Post-operative care includes a follow-up oral gastrograffin study on post-operative day 7 to monitor for leaks. The patient will be started on a per oral diet and will be monitored for any leaks.

S: The patient reports noticing a 2 x 2 cm mass on the lateral side of the right elbow, which has been bothersome. The patient underwent a marginal resection of the mass, which revealed an atypical lipomatous tumor. Post-resection, MRI showed no remains of the tumor. The tumor recurred 10 months post-resection, and a wide resection was performed. The patient denies any targeted therapy or chemotherapy prior to resection or post-surgery. O: The resected specimen was yellow-white with a hard, elastic texture. Histological analysis confirmed an atypical lipomatous tumor with a negative tumor margin. Histological analysis of the resected specimen showed proliferation of atypical lipomatous cells and high-grade spindle cells, confirming dedifferentiated liposarcoma. A: The primary diagnosis is dedifferentiated liposarcoma of the right elbow. The patient's history of recurrence post-resection and subsequent surgical interventions are consistent with this diagnosis. The prognosis is good with no recurrence observed over the past two years. P: The management plan includes regular MRI imaging and follow-ups to monitor the patient's condition and detect any recurrence. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms or changes immediately. Further consultations with oncology and oncology are recommended to manage the condition and prevent further recurrence.

S: The patient reports irritation in the right eye, which started earlier today when working on a car using a hammer and chisel. The irritation has worsened since the last visit. O: Initial examination revealed congestion and laceration of the conjunctiva in the right eye. Seven days later, the patient woke up with decreased vision, redness, and minimal pain in the right eye. Computed tomography scan and biomicroscopic examination revealed a metallic intraocular foreign body in the right eye. Best-corrected visual acuity (BCVA) decimal decreased from 1.0 to 0.7. Biomicroscopic examination indicated intense conjunctival and ciliary injection, likely self-sealed conjunctival laceration, corneal oedema, 3+ anterior chamber cells with fibrin, and a thin layer of hypopyon in the anterior chamber and posterior synechiae. A layer of fibrin mesh was also covering the anterior surface of the lens. The left eye was unremarkable. A: The primary diagnosis is exogenous endophthalmitis secondary to penetrating eye injury with retained intraocular metallic foreign body. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of conjunctival and ciliary injections, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The patient will be referred to the Department of Ophthalmology at Oslo University Hospital for urgent surgical removal of the foreign body. Post-operative care will include continued use of chloramphenicol as prescribed, and the patient will be educated about the procedure and expected outcomes. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor recovery and manage any complications.

S: The patient, a 34-year-old male with a history of pure HSP, reports a history of unstable posture, abnormal posture, and pain in the lower limbs starting at age 22. He has no history of exposure to pesticides or toxins. He also mentions experiencing delusion of persecution, anxiety, and fear. O: Neurological examination revealed pyramidal signs, but muscle strength and sensation were normal. EMG indicated multiple peripheral nerve damage. MRI scans showed normal brain, cervical, thoracic, and lumbar regions. The patient's parents inherited the homozygous p.D597fs mutation. A: The primary diagnosis is a novel homozygous pathogenic SPG46/GBA2 mutation, specifically p.D597fs. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of psychiatric disorders such as delusion of persecution, anxiety, and fear. The prognosis depends on the management of the patient's symptoms and lifestyle adjustments. P: The management plan includes referral to a psychiatric specialist for further evaluation and management. The patient is advised to monitor his condition closely and make lifestyle adjustments to improve quality of life. Regular follow-ups with a neurologist and a psychiatric specialist are recommended to manage symptoms and adjust treatment as necessary. The patient is encouraged to reach out with any further questions or concerns.

S: The patient, with a history of malignant mucosal lentiginous melanoma of the left gingiva, stage III (pT3, N1, M0), presented with fatigue and worsening shortness of breath for the last two months. He has a history of chemotherapy and radiation for malignant mucosal lentiginous melanoma of the left gingiva, stage III (pT3, N1, M0). He has been on nivolumab 240 mg IV every two weeks since August 2019. He denies paroxysmal dyspnea and fever. He has a history of smoking 1 pack per day for 30 years. O: Recent chest CT in February 2020 showed multiple pulmonary nodules with interstitial/ground-glass changes in the upper lobes bilaterally, right middle lobe, and right lower lobes, worsening over the past two weeks. Laboratory tests showed a low TSH level of  0.07, normal free triiodothyronine (T3), free thyroxine (T4) of 4.6, and negative TPO antibody. Bronchoscopy with BAL showed erythematous bronchial mucosa of the right lower lobe. A: The primary diagnosis is nivolumab-induced pneumonitis secondary to nivolumab treatment. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of pulmonary nodules, but these are less likely given the imaging and lab results. The prognosis depends on the management of nivolumab-induced pneumonitis. P: Continue monitoring thyroid levels, liver function, and lung health closely. Schedule regular follow-up appointments to monitor the patient's symptoms and adjust treatment as necessary. Educate the patient on the importance of reporting worsening symptoms promptly. Consider referral to a pulmonologist for further evaluation and management of nivolumab-induced pneumonitis.

S: The patient, a male with no history of Kawasaki disease or thoracic trauma, presented with presyncope and back pain. He reported no history of Kawasaki disease or thoracic trauma. O: On examination, the patient's heart rate was 90 beats/min and systolic blood pressure was 60 mmHg. Laboratory tests showed elevated liver enzymes (glutamic oxaloacetic transaminase at 815 IU/L, glutamic pyruvic transaminase at 240 IU/L, lactate dehydrogenase at 924 IU/L). Transthoracic echocardiography revealed a 37  54-mm spherical mass adjacent to the right lateral atrioventricular groove and decompression of the right ventricle resulting from pericardial effusion. Transthoracic echocardiography showed a 37  54-mm spherical mass adjacent to the right lateral atrioventricular groove and decompression of the right ventricle resulting from pericardial effusion. CT and coronary angiography identified three coronary artery aneurysms with coronary arteriovenous fistula (CAVF). Emergency surgery was performed through a median sternotomy, containing blood and clots, and a rupture site was identified on the wall of the giant CAA, originating from the ostium of RCA. Cardiopulmonary bypass was established via an ascending aortic cannula and bicaval cannula. The patient passed away during the postoperative period due to complications. A: The primary diagnosis was cardiac tamponade secondary to ruptured coronary artery aneurysms and CAVF. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of cardiac tamponade, but these were less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation. P: The patient underwent emergency surgery for cardiac tamponade and CAVF repair. Postoperative complications included complications from cardiac tamponade and cardiac tamponade. The patient was cooled to moderate hypothermia, aorta cross-clam

S: The patient is a 64-year-old male presenting for heart valve surgery due to severe multi-valvular disease detected during preoperative evaluation for colon diverticulitis. He reports recurrent life-threatening diverticular bleeding and heart failure. O: Transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) revealed severe aortic regurgitation (cusp prolapse) and severe mitral regurgitation (severe mitral regurgitation caused by degenerative bi-leaflet prolapse with multiple eccentric regurgitant jets), exacerbated by secondary factors including mitral annular and left ventricular dilation. During the DVR, an extensive hematoma was noted surrounding the posterior atrioventricular groove, suspected to be a cut through the left ventricular wall. Post-dVR, the patient was re-instituted full CPB support and tapered off inotropic agents to weaken the force of muscular contractions. The re-weaning process was performed without hemodynamic instability. A: The primary diagnosis is severe aortic regurgitation with complications including degenerative bi-leaflet prolapse and mitral annular and left ventricular dilation. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of aortic regurgitation, but these are less likely given the imaging and surgical findings. P: The patient underwent successful double valve replacement (DVR) with minimal complications. He is advised to monitor for any signs of complications and report them promptly. Follow-up care will include regular check-ups and monitoring to ensure proper function of the heart valves. The patient will be educated on signs of complications and advised to report them promptly. Lifestyle adjustments will be recommended to manage his heart failure and prevent further complications.

S: The patient, a 68-year-old African-American male with a history of right posterior limb stroke, chronic kidney disease stage III, heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF), hypertension (HTN), gout, prediabetes, and hyperlipidemia, reports persistent nausea and vomiting for the past six weeks, initially treated with omeprazole and ondansetron four weeks ago. He reports cramping abdominal pain around dinner time, worsening when lying down, and brown diarrhea for the past three weeks, about two episodes per day. He denies any changes in medications, recent travel, sick friends, or changes in diet. O: Vital signs are within normal limits: temperature 97.9 degrees Fahrenheit, pulse 76, blood pressure 114/71, and respiratory rate 20. Computed blood count shows anemia with a hemoglobin of 9.9 g/dL (normal 11.9 g/dL two months ago), and hematocrit of 30.9% (normal 30.9%). A: The primary diagnosis is anemia secondary to chronic kidney disease stage III, heart failure with reduced ejection fraction, hypertension, gout, prediabetes, and hyperlipidemia. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of anemia, but these are less likely given the patient's history and current symptoms. P: Plan to conduct further diagnostic tests including a blood count, hematocrit, and possibly a nephrology consultation to determine the cause of the anemia and persistent symptoms. Continue current medications, including aspirin 81 mg and clopidogrel 75 mg, and monitor for any worsening or new symptoms. Educate the patient on the importance of reporting new or worsening symptoms immediately. Schedule follow-up appointments to assess the effectiveness of the treatment and adjust as necessary.

S: The patient is a 12-year-old boy presenting with a left knee injury sustained while playing soccer. He reports the pain is difficult to move the knee and expresses concern about the pain. He denies any history of chronic medication or Osgood-Schlatter disease. O: Radiographs and CT revealed small flecks of bone at the proximal tibial tuberosity. MRI showed swelling and loosening of the patellar tendon, with a Sugimoto index of 1.36. The patient's patella alta was noted compared to the right knee with a Sugimoto index of 1.36. A: The primary diagnosis is patellar tendon avulsion with a tibial tuberosity sleeve fragment. The patient is diagnosed with patellar tendon avulsion with a tibial tuberosity sleeve fragment. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of patellar tendon avulsions, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The management plan includes surgical repair of the avulsed patellar tendon using two suture anchors and a tibial tuberosity sleeve fragment. The patient will be immobilized with a slightly flexed knee position for 3 weeks, followed by rehabilitation for active and passive range of motion. The K-wire and soft wire will be removed 4 months postoperatively. At 6 months postoperatively, the active range of motion of the knee should be equal to that of the contralateral side without pain. A 1-year follow-up is planned to monitor recovery and manage any complications.

S: The patient, with a history of hypertension, coronary artery disease, non-melanoma skin cancer, and a recent CABG procedure five months ago, presents with a new skin problem on the left chest, which has been growing for two weeks without any pain. The patient has a history of hypertension, coronary artery disease, and non-melanoma skin cancer. O: Physical examination revealed a well-demarcated erythematous, indurated plaque overlying the previous harvest site of the left internal thoracic artery. Punch biopsy confirmed an uninvolved epidermis with diffuse dermal sclerosis and underlying panniculitis. Histopathologic evaluation confirmed an uninvolved epidermis with diffuse dermal sclerosis and underlying panniculitis. A: The primary diagnosis is a well-demarcated erythematous, indurated plaque overlying the left internal thoracic artery. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of sclerodermatous changes, but these are less likely given the biopsy results. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the asymptomatic nature of the plaque. P: The management plan includes observation during bi-annual skin examinations to monitor the plaque's progression or cause any changes. The patient is advised to contact healthcare providers if any concerns or changes arise before the next examination. Regular follow-ups are scheduled to monitor the plaque's progress and manage any potential complications.

S: The patient, referred to the Department of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery at Ayder Referral Hospital, reports a gingival mass in the mouth that has been present for approximately two years. The patient denies any significant medical or family history. O: Intra-oral examination revealed a solitary, well-defined, roughly oval-shaped gingival mass arising from the attached and free labial gingival margin covering two-thirds of the crown of teeth 33 and 34. The mass has gradually progressed to its current size of 2 x 2 cm. The overlying mucosa is intact and similar to adjacent mucosa. The swelling was non-tender with firm consistency and a smooth surface texture. Intraoral periapical radiograph of the right mandibular anterior region showed a minor arc-shaped bone loss in relation to teeth 33 and 34. Histopathological examination of the lesion showed a spheroidal shape measuring approximately 2  2 cm, covered by a capsule with soft to firm consistency, and a grayish-white appearance with minute hemorrhagic areas. Hematoxylin and eosin stained sections were microscopically examined, and the tumor mass was composed of spindle/polyhedral, cuboidal, and columnar cells arranged in multiform patterns with a few areas. A: The primary diagnosis is pyogenic granulomas, based on clinical and histopathological findings. Differential diagnoses considered included peripheral ossifying fibroma, peripheral giant cell granuloma, fibrous epulis, benign connective tissue tumors, and peripheral odontogenic neoplasms. P: The patient underwent surgical removal of the lesion in toto under local anesthesia. Histopathological examination confirmed the diagnosis of pyogenic granulomas. A follow-up appointment will be scheduled to discuss follow-up requirements and treatment plans. The patient is advised to maintain oral hygiene and report any new symptoms immediately.

S: Patient 3, currently unemployed, reports a history of severe alcohol use starting 12 years ago, which has led to significant changes in his social life and relationships over the last 10 years. He has experienced significant reduction in social contacts and general withdrawal from people. He has been experiencing depression and changes in his mood for a while. O: The patient meets the criteria for Major Depressive Disorder. The patient has been referred to a specialist for alcohol use and a mental health professional for treatment. A: The primary diagnosis is Major Depressive Disorder, evidenced by the patient's history of binge drinking and recent alcohol use. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of alcohol use, but these are less likely given the patient's history and current symptoms. P: Refer the patient to a specialist for alcohol use and a mental health professional for treatment. The treatment plan will include therapy and medication to manage withdrawal symptoms. The patient is advised to attend and fully participate in both treatments to improve overall quality of life. Regular follow-ups with the specialists are necessary to monitor progress and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient, a 12-year-old with a history of dwarfism, hormone replacement therapy since age 7, developmental dysplasia of the left hip, and a habitual patellar dislocation of the right knee, presents with a painful, swollen elbow. Post-operative care will include rehabilitation and follow-up care to regain normal function in the elbow. The patient is advised to report any further questions or concerns immediately.

S: The patient reports experiencing progressive headaches for two months and a fever for two weeks, blurred central vision, and restricted visual fields. S: The patient is a 25-year-old female with a long-standing history of psychiatric disorder on medical treatment, presenting with abdominal pain, abdominal distension, and failure to pass stool and flatus for one week. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of abdominal pain and distension, but these are less likely given the imaging and surgical findings. P: The patient underwent a Laparotomy and Gastrotomy, revealing distension, reaching the pelvis, and a Gastrotomy. Post-surgery, the patient was referred back to the psychiatric hospital for further treatment and management of her psychiatric disorder. The plan includes referral to a psychiatric hospital for further treatment and management of her psychiatric disorder. Post-operative care will include monitoring of the patient's progress and adjusting the treatment plan as necessary. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of gastrointestinal symptoms such as infection or inflammatory processes, but these are less likely given the imaging and laboratory findings.
