The patient is advised to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately. Further consultations with a nephrologist and a pulmonologist may be necessary depending on the patient's response to the treatment regimen.

S: The patient reported sudden onset of jerky movements in both upper limbs, accompanied by changes in the way the patient sits and walking, and a narrow and shuffling gait. The patient also experienced rapid progressive dysphasia, withdrawnness, and indifferent social behavior. The patient also experienced visual hallucinations and exaggerated startle responses, and severe jerking movements, loss of bladder control, and inability to move or speak. The patient's family history of neurodegenerative diseases was not confirmed. O: MRI and EEG revealed asymmetrical cortical ribboning with a left-sided emphasis and bilateral anterior basal ganglia diffusion restriction. EEG showed generalized periodic complexes. Cerebrospinal fluid cell count and routine biochemistry were normal, but no protein 14.3.3, S100B, or real-time quaking-induced conversion assay was available. A: The primary diagnosis is axial and gait apraxia with progressive dysphasia. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of jerking movements and dysphasia, but these are less likely given the imaging and biochemistry results. The prognosis is guarded due to the rapid progression of symptoms and the absence of family history of neurodegenerative diseases. P: The management plan includes continued monitoring and management of the patient's symptoms. Further testing for protein 14.3.3, S100B, or real-time quaking-induced conversion assay is necessary. The patient's family will be informed about the nature of the disease, its progression, and the importance of adherence to the treatment plan. Further consultations with neurology and a neurologist are recommended to address the patient's neurological symptoms.

S: The patient is a 61-year-old woman with a BRCA1 gene mutation, presenting for a prophylactic total laparoscopic hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy. She reports no history of cancer and has a history of Cesarean section and left ovarian cystectomy. O: During the procedure, a white nodule was found on the fimbriated end of the right fallopian tube, accompanied by adhesions between the omentum and right pelvic sidewall. The nodule was solid, firm, and measured 0.5 x 0.1 x 0.3 cm. The entire nodule was frozen, and sections showed small, tightly packed tubules and nests of epithelioid cells in a fibrous background with many psammoma bodies. Mucicarmine stain was negative. Immunohistochemical studies showed positivity for WT1, calretinin, PAX8, and D2-40, and negative for p53, estrogen, and progesterone receptors. Thread-like bridging was observed in several foci of the lesion. A: The primary diagnosis is adenomatoid tumor with psammoma bodies, evidenced by the negative Mucicarmine stain and absence of estrogen and progesterone receptors. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of adenomatoid tumors, but these are less likely given the negative Mucicarmine stain and absence of estrogen and progesterone receptors. P: The management plan includes continued monitoring of the lesion and follow-up with additional tests or treatments if necessary. The patient is advised to maintain a healthy lifestyle and monitor for any changes in her body. The patient is encouraged to report any unusual symptoms immediately.

S: The patient is a 62-year-old male presenting with melena for the past two days. He has a history of alcoholic liver cirrhosis complicated by hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), transcatheter arterial embolization, laparoscopic radiofrequency ablation, esophageal and gastric varices, and endoscopic variceal band ligation due to bleeding esophageal variceal bleeding. He has been smoking 20 cigarettes per day and drinking 100 g of alcohol daily for 40 years without quitting. O: On admission, the patient's blood pressure was 116/74 mmHg, pulse rate 80 beats/min, respiratory rate 20 breaths/min, and body temperature 35.9 °C. Hemoglobin was 8.3 g/dL, lower than the baseline of 9.2 g/dL. Abdominal CT scan showed cirrhosis and recurrent liver cirrhosis in S4, S6, and S7, with thrombosis in the right posterior branch of the portal vein. Emergent esophagogastrodudenoscopy and colonoscopy were inconclusive. Anterograde SBE (Olympus Medical systems, Tokyo, Japan) showed a large amount of fresh blood and 1 engorged cystic lesion with persistent bleeding from the central depression. Biopsy forceps indicated a soft sensation, not induration, indicating ectopic jejunal varices. A: The primary diagnosis is ectopic jejunal varices secondary to cirrhosis and recurrent liver cirrhosis. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of ectopic jejunal varices, but these are less likely given the imaging and biopsy results. P: The patient was transferred to the ICU due to hemorrhagic shock and was treated with a 3.5 mL glue mixture (3.0 mL of cyanoacrylate and 0.5 mL of lipiodol) and a second attempt of sclerotherapy with 2.0 mL of cyanoacrylate. The patient is advised to quit smoking and reduce alcohol intake to prevent further complications. Follow

S: The patient presented with sudden, intense substernal chest pain starting 30 minutes prior to arrival. The pain was described as sudden and intense. O: Initial ECG showed atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular response and a rate of 147 bpm, with minimal ST depression in the lateral leads but no ST-segment elevation. Point-of-care labs including a basic metabolic panel and troponin test were performed. Chest X-ray was non-diagnostic. Initial cardiac ultrasound indicated right heart strain secondary to pulmonary embolism. During the bedside cardiac ultrasound, the patient experienced ventricular fibrillation, which was managed with multiple rounds of epinephrine, 450 mg of amiodarone, and three conventional defibrillations with increasing joules at 150 J, 200 J, and 200 J. Double sequential defibrillation (DSD) was performed using a second set of pads in the anterior-posterior orientation. A: The primary diagnosis is atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular response and a life-threatening heart rhythm. Differential diagnoses initially included aortic dissection and pulmonary embolism, which were ruled out based on imaging and clinical presentation. P: The patient underwent multiple rounds of epinephrine, 450 mg of amiodarone, and three conventional defibrillations with increasing joules at 150 J, 200 J, and 200 J. Double sequential defibrillation was performed using a second set of pads in the anterior-posterior orientation. The patient was started on a Lidocaine drip after improvement in tachycardia and non-responsiveness to amiodarone. The patient is currently stable with a Lidocaine drip. Regular follow-ups are scheduled to monitor the patient's condition and manage any complications.

S: The patient, a resident of a rural area in Heilongjiang Province, reports a possible tonic-clonic seizure and a reduction in vision in the right eye since 2015. The patient has a history of a possible tonic-clonic seizure and a reduction in vision in the right eye since 2015. O: Brain MRI revealed multiple parietal cysts at the vesicular stage with edema in the frontal, parietal, and occipital white matter. Orbital MRI showed one well-defined ring-enhancing cystic lesion involving the right superior rectus. Chest X-ray showed multiple nodular calcifications. ELISA positive for anticysticercal IgG antibodies. CSF biochemical, cytological, and microbiological examinations showed normal WBCs, protein (23.52 mg/dL), normal glucose level in the CSF and blood, and a negative bacterial culture. A: The primary diagnosis is a parasitic infection affecting the brain and eyes, complicated by anticysticercal IgG antibodies. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of seizures and ocular cysts. The prognosis depends on the response to the treatment and response to the treatment. P: The patient underwent successful ophthalmic surgery and has been started on systemic oral albendazole and steroid therapy. The treatment plan includes three additional courses of albendazole with 3-month intervals, aiming to eradicate the neural cysts by four cycles. The patient is advised to follow the treatment regimen and report any new symptoms or concerns immediately. Regular follow-ups will be scheduled to monitor the patient's progress and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient, with a history of hypertension and erosive gastritis, presents with lightheadedness for the past 2 days, abdominal pain, and melena. The patient has a history of hypertension and erosive gastritis treated with transfusions two weeks ago. The patient has been on prednisone 20 mg twice daily, diltiazem, and tramadol. The patient denies any history of drug or alcohol abuse, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, or nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs. O: On examination, the patient is afebrile and not hypoxic with a blood pressure of 175/39 mm Hg, pulse 140, and respiratory rate 18. Physical examination reveals normoactive bowel sounds, soft abdomen without guarding or rigidity, significant epigastric tenderness, negative Castell sign, and tympanic Traub Space percussion. No jaundice on skin, sclera, or oral frenulum. Melena is present on rectal examination. Laboratory findings include a white blood cell count of 46,000/mL, hemoglobin 9.2 mg/dL (baseline 11), and platelets 96,000/mL. Metabolic panel shows creatinine at 1.8 mg/dL, AST 40 U/L, ALT 59 U/L, total bilirubin 0.7 mg/dL, serum glucose 300 mg/dL, and lipase 31 U/L. A: The primary diagnosis is acute pancreatitis (AIP) secondary to steroid therapy and gastrointestinal bleed. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of acute pancreatitis, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and lab results. P: The patient will be admitted to the hospital for further management and monitoring. The management plan will include close monitoring of vital signs and lab results, and consultation with specialists to determine the best course of treatment for AIP and gastrointestinal bleed. The patient will be educated on the importance of adhering to the treatment regimen and adherence to the treatment plan. Referral to a gastroenterologist for further evaluation and management of AIP and gastrointestinal bleed is recommended.

S: The patient reports experiencing back pain and ankle clonus in both ankles. The patient has a history of total nephrectomy for renal cell carcinoma (RCC) 10 years ago. O: Physical examination is within normal limits except for the ankle clonus. MRI and CT scans reveal spinal metastases involving the T1-T3 vertebrae, a pathological fracture of T2 causing spinal cord compression, and metastases in the right adrenal gland, sternum, left clavicle, and sacrum. CT-guided biopsy of the T2 vertebral lesion confirms metastatic renal cell carcinoma (mRCC). Spine Instability Neoplastic Score is 16, indicating instability. A: The primary diagnosis is metastatic renal cell carcinoma (mRCC) of the T1-T3 vertebrae, grade III, type 6 and zones 4 to 9, layers A to D, with a Spine Instability Neoplastic Score of 16, indicating instability. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of metastatic renal cell carcinoma, but imaging and clinical findings support the primary diagnosis. P: Initiate treatment with zoledronic acid 4 mg/month to manage metastases and perform a TES with reconstruction using a cryo-treated tumor-bearing bone graft. Plan for TES with reconstruction using a cryo-treated tumor-bearing bone graft. Monitor the patient's progress closely and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Schedule a follow-up appointment to review recovery and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient is a 32-year-old obese woman, gravida five, para 3104, with a history of preterm contractions and preeclampsia, presenting with persistent pelvic pain and a fever of 103.1 F since delivering her baby girl four days ago. She also reports fever and chills. O: Physical examination revealed normal foul-smelling lochia. Labs showed elevated white blood cell count and anemia. Pelvic x-ray showed diastases of the pubic symphysis measuring 3.75 cm. MRI scan of the pelvis and lumbar spine showed no pelvic abscess or hematoma. On hospital day three, the patient was febrile, tachypneic, tachycardic, hypoxic, and experiencing a productive cough. Blood cultures identified Streptococcus pyogenes (group A) and Proteus mirabilis. Urine culture grew 80,000 cfu/mL of Proteus mirabilis, susceptible to ampicillin, cefazolin, ceftriaxone, ciprofloxacin, gentamicin, levofloxacin, trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole, resistant to nitrofurantoin. Chest CT showed bilateral patchy opacities. A: The primary diagnosis is sepsis secondary to endometritis, likely secondary to endometritis. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of tachycardia and fever, but these are less likely given the culture results. P: The patient was started on intravenous ampicillin and clindamycin. Blood cultures confirmed Streptococcus pyogenes and Proteus mirabilis, resistant to nitrofurantoin. On hospital day three, the patient was febrile, tachypneic, tachycardic, and hypoxic. She also experienced expiratory wheezes in upper lung fields bilaterally. Chest CT showed bilateral patchy opacities. A: The primary diagnosis is sepsis secondary to endometritis, likely secondary to endometritis. Differenti

S: The patient is a 28-year-old right-handed woman presenting with a severe depressive episode starting 10 years ago, characterized by alternating phases of depression and sporadic episodes of elation. She reports a history of low alcohol consumption and sporadic use of cannabis during adolescence. She also experiences binging behaviors, which occur almost daily. She has a history of high-fat food consumption, causing physical and psychological distress. She has been on various pharmacological therapies including valproate, fluoxetine, citalopram, venlafaxine, and bupropione, currently on clomipramine (150 mg daily) and pregabalin (225 mg daily). O: The patient's current medications include clomipramine (150 mg daily) and pregabalin (225 mg daily). MADRS and HAMD assessments indicate severe depressive symptoms at baseline. A: The primary diagnosis is Bipolar Disorder-II, evidenced by the patient's history of binging behaviors and a history of high-fat food consumption. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of depressive symptoms, but these are less likely given the patient's history and current findings. P: Continue monitoring the patient's depressive symptoms and adjust medications as necessary based on MADRS and HAMD assessments. Adjust medications as necessary based on the patient's response to therapy. Educate the patient on the importance of reporting any new symptoms or changes in her condition. Consider referral to a neurologist for further evaluation and management.

S: The patient is an 81-year-old male presenting with bilateral groin and thigh pain following an accidental fall from a height of 5 meters. He reports inability to actively move his legs and pain on passive movement. O: Clinical examination revealed inability to actively move the legs and pain on passive movement. Radiographic studies indicated a bilateral fracture of the femoral shaft and a bilateral Robert Mathys (RM®) cementless total hip arthroplasty. Bone lesions were classified as Vancouver type-B2 periprosthetic femoral fracture. The patient's BMI is 33 kg/m2, indicating significant comorbidities. The patient has a history of RM® cementless total hip arthroplasty and Paprosky type II femoral osteolysis. A: The primary diagnosis is a bilateral fracture of the femoral shaft and a bilateral Robert Mathys (RM®) cementless total hip arthroplasty. Differential diagnoses could include other types of femoral fractures, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. The prognosis depends on the progression of the fractures and the patient's response to the rehabilitation program. P: The patient will be monitored closely for progress and adjustments to the rehabilitation program. He will be educated on the importance of adhering to the rehabilitation plan and attending all follow-up appointments. Referral to a neurologist for further evaluation and management of the fractures is recommended. Further consultations with a neurologist and a rheumatologist are recommended to manage his comorbidities.

S: The patient reports a retained foreign body in the left eye for approximately 8 months following a gunshot injury to the left eye. The patient has experienced pain in the left eye but denies sinonasal symptoms. O: Initial radiograph detected a round-shaped metallic foreign body in the left eye globe, diagnosed as a retained foreign body in the left orbit. Imaging revealed a round-shaped metallic foreign body in the left eye globe, diagnosed as a retained foreign body in the left orbit. CT scan of the left orbit showed a round-shaped metallic foreign body in the medial intraconal space and lateral attachment of the posterior ethmoid sinus, measuring 6 mm. A transnasal endoscopic approach with navigator assistance was performed to remove the foreign body. The bullet was dissected and delivered through the left nostril using probes. No intraorbital bleeding or damage to soft ocular structures was noted. A: The primary diagnosis is a retained foreign body in the left orbit following a gunshot injury to the left eye. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of orbital foreign bodies, but these are less likely given the imaging and surgical findings. P: The patient underwent a minimally invasive procedure for removal of the foreign body using an endoscopic transnasal approach. The procedure involved uncinectomy and anterior-posterior ethmoidectomy, which were performed with navigator assistance. The bullet was dissected and delivered through the left nostril using probes, and no intraorbital bleeding or damage to soft ocular structures was noted. The patient is advised to follow up and report any further symptoms or issues.

S: The patient is a 68-year-old male with a history of Parkinson's disease diagnosed in 2009, currently in Hoehn and Yahr Stage III, with a 10-year history of the disease. He reports experiencing cognitive problems a few years after diagnosis, including concentration and memory deficits. He has been active in his community and has been active in community development. He has been a community development volunteer for 28 years and raised 5 children. He has been playing Bridge game service StepBridge, which has been beneficial for his cognitive functions. O: The patient's current condition is Hoehn and Yahr Stage III, with a history of Parkinson's disease diagnosed in 2009. He has been playing Bridge game service StepBridge for approximately 10 years, with subjective benefits in concentration and memory. He has been playing regularly for almost 10 years. A: The primary diagnosis is Hoehn and Yahr Stage III, with a history of Parkinson's disease. The patient's cognitive challenges have been exacerbated by the use of a Dutch Web-based Bridge game service. The patient's compliance with the activity has been excellent, and his spouse has observed these improvements. P: The patient is advised to continue playing Bridge game service StepBridge to maintain cognitive health. Regular follow-ups with the healthcare team are recommended to monitor the patient's condition and adjust treatment as necessary. The patient is encouraged to maintain regular activities to maintain cognitive health. Further consultations with the healthcare team are recommended to discuss the effectiveness of the new activity and the importance of compliance.

S: The patient reports a persistent fever persisting for 20 days. The patient has a history of a pulmonary infection and cytopenia in the peripheral blood. O: Physical examination revealed a hemoglobin level of 74.0 g/L (normal range: 13.8-17.2 g/L for men, 15.1-17.2 g/L for women), and a ferritin increase of 3602.5 g/L (normal range: 0-60 g/L). Immunohistochemistry showed decreased white blood cells, red blood cells, and neutrophil granulocytes. Hemoglobin levels were 74.0 g/L (normal range: 0-60 g/L), and ferritin increased to 3602.5 g/L (normal range: 0-60 g/L). Autoimmune antibodies were negative. NK cell activity was measured using IFN- secretion and functional activity against target cells, specifically K562 cells. Bone marrow aspiration confirmed hemophagocytosis. A targeted next-generation sequencing panel was performed on the Ion Torrent Personal Genome Machine, revealing a mean depth of 315 folds and 98.44% of the target region covered by at least 20 folds. A: The primary diagnosis is HLH, evidenced by cytopenia and NK cell activity. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of HLH, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and laboratory results. P: The patient was diagnosed with HLH-2004 guidelines, based on the HLH-2004 guidelines. The treatment plan includes close monitoring of the patient's response to treatment and potential genetic testing. The patient will be educated on the importance of reporting any new symptoms or concerns immediately. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's response to treatment and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient, with a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and hypothyroidism, presents with increasing diplopia and nausea for the past six days, accompanied by unintentional weight loss of 10 pounds over the last two weeks. O: Physical examination revealed bony tenderness localized to the ribs and a right CN VI palsy causing impaired right eye abduction. Laboratory tests showed a white count of 10,700 k/L, absolute neutrophil count of 7.5 k/L, and absolute lymphocyte count of 2.42 k/L. Blood chemistry showed elevated serum Ca2+ at 15.8 mg/dL, ionized Ca2+ at 7.7 mg/dL, and glucose at 254 mg/dL. Parathyroid hormone levels were low at 10 pg/mL, and parathyroid hormone-related peptide was normal at 1.3. Urine analysis and urine protein electrophoresis were unremarkable. Total protein was 6.8 g/dL, serum globulin was 2.8 g/dL, and albumin/gamma globulin ratio was elevated at 2.4. Serum protein electrophoresis revealed a faint monoclonal immunoglobulin. Immune-quantification indicated IgG at 1150 mg/dL, IgA at 200 mg/dL, and IgM at 41. A: The primary diagnosis is a recurrent CN VI palsy, likely exacerbated by the patient's diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and hypothyroidism. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of CN VI palsy, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and laboratory findings. P: Plan to conduct further diagnostic tests including a urine analysis and protein electrophoresis to further investigate the cause of the CN VI palsy and the presence of Bence-Jones protein. Continue monitoring the patient's condition closely and consider additional testing or specialist consultations as necessary. Educate the patient on the importance of adherence to the treatment plan and follow-up appointments.

S: The patient, with a history of traditional herbal remedies for liver detoxification, reported using "lian-serpent" for detoxification. The patient experienced a fever and weakness for one week, followed by dark urine. The patient was admitted with acute hepatitis, cholestasis, cytolysis, jaundice, and normal vital signs. O: On admission, the patient was diagnosed with acute hepatitis with cholestasis, cytolysis, jaundice, and hepatocellular damage with ALT at 1923 U/L, AST at 873 U/L, and GT at 155 U/L. Abdominal ultrasonography was normal, showing no hepatomegaly or lithiasis. Laboratory tests for viral hepatitis were negative. The patient was discharged two weeks post-admission with regression of jaundice and a progressive decrease in liver function tests. A: The primary diagnosis is acute hepatitis with cholestasis, cytolysis, jaundice, and hepatocellular damage. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of hepatitis, but these are less likely given the negative results for viral hepatitis. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the improvement in liver function tests. P: The management plan includes continued monitoring of liver function tests and regular follow-ups with a hepatologist. The patient is advised to avoid consuming any more of the herbal remedy and consult a healthcare professional before starting any alternative treatments. Further consultations with a hepatologist are recommended to manage liver issues and prevent further complications.

S: The patient, a male, presented with severe pain and deformity in the left arm, forearm, and wrist, which was twisted and twisted. He reported the pain and deformity as a result of being on a waterslide at an amusement park. O: Physical examination revealed closed injuries, soft arm and forearm compartments, and intact neurovascularity. Radiographs of the humerus, forearm, and wrist showed a left distal third humeral shaft fracture and a left Galeazzi fracture, including a midshaft radius fracture and disruption of the distal radioulnar joint. The patient underwent open reduction and internal fixation of both humeral shaft and radial shaft fractures within 24 hours of admission. The humeral shaft fracture was amenable to reduction and fixation with an extraarticular locking plate. Post-operative care included a well-padded long arm posterior plaster splint extending from the posterior shoulder to the fingers, with an additional coaptation component to stabilize the humerus fracture. A: The primary diagnosis is a left distal third humeral shaft fracture and a left Galeazzi fracture, with complications including a midshaft radius fracture and disruption of the distal radioulnar joint. The patient underwent successful open reduction and internal fixation of both humeral shaft and radial shaft fractures. P: The patient underwent open reduction and internal fixation of both humeral shaft and radial shaft fractures within 24 hours of admission. Post-operative care includes monitoring recovery and healing, with instructions to maintain the affected area clean and avoid movements that may disrupt healing. The patient is advised to follow any instructions and report any concerns during recovery.

S: The patient is an 81-year-old woman with a history of solid tubular carcinoma, presenting with a chief complaint of fatigue and weakness. She reports noticing a lump in her breast and feeling tired and weak. O: Physical examination revealed a lump in the breast, with a thickness of 41 mm. The AGD was 1.29, and 15 projections were used to visualize the tumor. A: The primary diagnosis is solid tubular carcinoma of the breast, characterized by a lump in the breast, fatigue, and weakness. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of breast cancer, but these are less likely given the imaging results. The prognosis depends on the stage of the cancer and the patient's overall health. P: The management plan includes a comprehensive review of the patient's overall health, stage, and type of cancer, and potential side effects. The patient will be scheduled for a follow-up appointment to discuss the treatment options and begin the process. The patient is advised to maintain a healthy lifestyle, maintain active activities, and attend a support group or counselor to help with emotional aspects of cancer management.

S: The patient, admitted with a chief complaint of right upper pain and a palpable mass, presented with a chief complaint of right upper pain and a palpable mass in the right upper abdomen. The patient denies any significant medical or surgical history, family, or psychosocial history. O: Physical examination revealed slight tenderness and a semimobile mass in the right upper abdomen. Clinical examination showed no persistent weak abdominal pain and mass. Abdominal contrast-enhanced CT revealed a 130  100  90 mm massive cystic mass in the right upper peritoneal cavity with a thickened wall and many enhanced nodules. Gadolinium-enhanced MRI indicated intra-cystic fluid was bleeding or mucinous fluid, and a connection with the pancreatic head was noted. Post-operative findings included a hemorrhagic cyst, which was re-increased during surgery. A: The primary diagnosis is a hemorrhagic cyst in the right upper peritoneal cavity. Differential diagnoses initially included MCN, mucinous cystic adenocarcinoma, and hemorrhagic cyst. The prognosis is good post-operatively, with a successful partial pancreatectomy. P: The patient underwent a partial pancreatectomy, which was performed successfully. Post-operative recovery was good, and the patient was discharged on post-operative day 9. The plan includes continued monitoring of recovery and any changes in the patient's condition. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately.

S: The patient, initially diagnosed with an aneurysmal bone cyst in 2008, reports persistent pain and claudication in the left lower limb. The pain has been persistent since 2013, leading to a referral to the Emergency Unit of the Lomas Verdes High Specialty Medical Unit for traumatology and orthopedics. The patient has been under surveillance in the private sector since 2013. O: The patient was initially treated with bone biopsy and curettage with lyophilized cadaveric tricortical bone allograft, which was initially negative for infectious or inflammatory bone disease. Recent imaging including pelvic radiographs, computerized tomography with three-dimensional reconstruction, and a bone scan were negative for infectious or inflammatory bone disease. Magnetic resonance imaging indicated a neoplastic lesion of the pelvis with edema, suggestive of Ewing’s sarcoma. An incisional biopsy in December 2013 showed necrosis and reabsorption of spongy bone tissue, vascularized fibrous connective tissue, and osteoclastic giant cells. Follow-up in June 2014 showed slight improvement in symptoms. A: The primary diagnosis is Ewing’s sarcoma of the left lower limb, complicated by osteolysis of the pelvis. Differential diagnosis initially included an aneurysmal bone cyst, which was ruled out by imaging and histopathology. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic with regular follow-up appointments. P: The patient is advised to continue regular monitoring and follow-up appointments to monitor for any changes in pain or new symptoms. The patient is advised to report any new or worsening symptoms immediately. Further consultations with oncology and a nephrologist are recommended to manage the sarcoma effectively.

S: The patient is a 29-year-old South Asian male presenting with a 14-day history of high-grade fever, malaise, and anorexia, accompanied by a 10-pound weight loss. He denies recent medications, contact with sick people, or recent travel. O: Vital signs include a blood pressure of normotensive, resting sinus tachycardia of 110 bpm, pulse oximetry of 98% on room air, and mild pyrexia of 38.8°C. Physical examination reveals bilateral conjunctivitis with chemosis, strawberry tongue glossitis, palmar desquamation, and ichthyosis without lymphadenopathy or dermatologic manifestations. Laboratory tests indicate leukocytosis and notable thrombocytosis, with a normal comprehensive metabolic panel and elevated inflammatory markers including erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein. An extensive infectious disease diagnostic workup was negative. Immunological panel tests for various viruses, bacteria, and parasites were negative. A: The primary diagnosis is incomplete presentation of Kawasaki disease, evidenced by the patient's symptoms and laboratory findings. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of fever, malaise, and anorexia, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and laboratory findings. P: The patient has been started on high-dose enteric-coated aspirin as a treatment for Kawasaki disease. Close monitoring of the patient's condition will be necessary, and aspirin will be administered as needed to alleviate symptoms. The patient is advised to report any changes or worsening of symptoms immediately.

S: The patient reports edema in both lower extremities, abdominal fullness, shortness of breath upon exertion, swelling in the legs, stomach feeling full, and difficulty catching breath upon exertion. The patient has been on dasatinib 100 mg daily for CML, which has improved the size of the spleen and leg edema. O: Physical examination revealed a giant splenomegaly reaching the pelvic cavity and hepatomegaly. Blood tests showed an elevated white blood cell count of 480,000/L. Bone marrow examination confirmed CML. Post-discharge, the patient developed heavy proteinuria with a urinary protein-creatinine ratio of 8.93 g/g creatinine and a low serum albumin level of 2.3 g/dL. Two months post-discharge, dasatinib was transiently stopped due to pancytopenia. A: The primary diagnosis is CML with complications including heavy proteinuria and nephrotic syndrome. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of splenomegaly and hepatomegaly, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and laboratory findings. P: Continue monitoring the patient's condition with regular checkups and blood tests to assess the progression of CML, nephrotic syndrome, and overall health. Educate the patient on the importance of reporting new symptoms or changes in their condition immediately. Consider referral to a nephrologist for further evaluation and management of nephrotic syndrome.

S: The patient, a HIV and HCV positive for 11 years, presented with severe nonreducible exophthalmos, eyelid chemosis, decreased vision in the right eye at 1/10, mechanical proptosis, and optic disc swelling associated with venous congestion. The patient's history of drug and alcohol addiction and habitual marijuana smoking was noted. O: Clinical examination revealed severe nonreducible exophthalmos with dislocation of the right eye medially and inferiorly, eyelid chemosis, decreased vision at 1/10, and mechanical proptosis restricted optic disc swelling. Brain MRI indicated an intraorbital mass inhomogeneously hypointense on T2-weighted images and hypointense on T1-weighted images, with intense and inhomogeneous contrast enhancement. Histology confirmed monomorphic proliferation of plasmablastic cells, suggestive of plasmablastic lymphoma. A: The primary diagnosis was a monomorphic proliferation of plasmablastic cells in the orbital mass, likely a neoplastic disease, given the patient's history of HIV and HCV, and the presence of marijuana smoking. Differential diagnoses considered included neoplastic diseases, which were ruled out based on imaging and histology. P: The management plan included initiating treatment for the intraorbital mass, which was delayed due to a heart attack. The patient died within a week post-diagnosis due to a heart attack. The family was informed of the patient's death and expressed their deepest condolences.

S: The patient reports swelling and facial asymmetry on the left side of the face, first diagnosed with craniofacial monostotic FD at age 13 and treated under general anesthesia at age 18. The patient also mentions a swelling on the left side of the mid face region at age 18, which was noticed at age 18. O: Clinical extra-oral examination revealed significant facial asymmetry. A CT scan showed a dysplastic dense mass affecting the maxillary and zygomatic bones. Preoperative cephalometric analysis showed a canting of 5.5 mm downwards. The patient underwent a Le Fort I osteotomy at age 20 to correct the occlusal canting. A mandibular sagittal split ramus osteotomy (BSSRO) will be performed to correct the compensatory mandibular occlusal canting. A Triaca style mandibular wing osteotomy will be performed to adjust the mandibular chin and body contour. A: The primary diagnosis is craniofacial monostotic FD with complications including severe maxillary occlusal canting, compensatory mandibular occlusal canting, and a symmetrical mandible outline. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of facial asymmetry, but these are less likely given the imaging and surgical findings. P: The management plan includes continued presurgical orthodontic treatment for 14 months, followed by a Le Fort I osteotomy at age 20 to correct the occlusal canting and a mandibular sagittal split ramus osteotomy to correct the compensatory mandibular occlusal canting. Postoperative orthodontic treatment will start 4 weeks post-surgery, with close monitoring of the patient's progress and no evidence of skeletal relapse at the 2-year follow-up. The patient will be educated on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and regular follow-up appointments to monitor progress and manage any complications.

S: The patient, referred for further examination of a radiolucent finding on the left side of the mandible, reports feeling fine and no symptoms in the mouth, including the left mandible area. The patient has a history of uneventful medical and dental history. O: Initial extraoral examination showed unremarkable findings and no paresthesia. Intraoral examination confirmed no redness or tender swelling of the left mandibular mucosa. S: The patient reports progressive dyspnea on effort (DUO) following pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP) treatment. The patient has a history of HIV-1 infection confirmed by western blotting. O: Initial blood examination revealed a cluster of differentiation-4 counts of 45/L (7.3%) and HIV-RNA loads of 56,000 copies/mL. Bronchoscopy identified Pneumocystis jirovecii in the bronchoalveolar lavage fluid. -D glucan levels were increased at more than 300 pg/mL. Arterial blood oxygen pressure was normal at rest (93.5 mmHg), but decreased rapidly to 44.5 mmHg after 30 seconds of slow walking. Respiratory function tests showed severe restrictive ventilator impairment with vital capacity at 36.5% and forced expiratory volume in 1 second at 107.4%. Chest CT showed severe fibrotic changes at the bilateral basal parts and diffuse fibrotic changes. A: The primary diagnosis is HIV-related PCP with complications including severe restrictive ventilator impairment, severe restrictive ventilator impairment, and diffuse fibrotic changes. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of lung dyspnea, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The patient was started on trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX) with corticosteroids. The treatment plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition and adjustment of treatment as necessary. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess treatment efficacy and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Patient education regarding the nature of the disease, treatment expectations, and potential side effects will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient reports experiencing left hemiparesis and dysarthria for approximately 5 hours. The patient has a history of hypertension. O: Initial NIHSS score was 3, indicating a minor stroke. A PCT scan revealed severe stenosis in the right MCA territory, severe stenosis in the superior portion of the right minor branch, and moderate stenosis in the right main branch. The average right and left cerebral rSO2 values are 69.01% and 71.28%, respectively. A: The primary diagnosis is a minor stroke with severe stenosis in the right MCA territory and moderate stenosis in the right main branch. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of cerebral hemorrhage, but these are less likely given the imaging results and clinical presentation. P: The management plan includes treatment with EVT (Endovascular Therapy) to restore blood flow in the affected area. The patient will be closely monitored for any new or worsening symptoms. The patient is advised to follow up with their primary care physician and report any new or worsening symptoms immediately.

S: The patient reports a progressively growing mass in the back region, which has been causing multiple drainage attempts at referral sites for suspected abscess. Chest CT scan with contrast showed an undefined heterogeneous mass dependent on soft tissues in the posterior thorax wall with infiltration signs in the muscular plane and density alteration of subcutaneous cellular tissue and skin. Differential diagnoses could include other types of sarcomas, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. Referrals to oncology, surgical oncology, and radiation oncology services will be arranged to manage the patient's condition. S: The patient, admitted for anemia and thrombocytopenia three weeks ago, presented with a febrile erythematous rash, fever, fatigue, vomiting, and non-bloody diarrhea. The patient denies any family history of kidney or hematological disorders. O: Physical examination revealed paleness and bruises on the abdomen, back, and lower extremities. Laboratory findings included hemolytic anemia with marked reticulocytosis, presence of schistocytes, profound thrombocytopenia, and elevated uric acid. Serum creatinine levels were normal. Plasma haptoglobin was undetectable, lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) was elevated, direct Coombs test was negative, and anti-streptolysin titers were marginally elevated. D-dimers were elevated at 2.49 g/mL, fibrinogen-equivalent units were normal, prothrombin, INR, partial thromboplastin time, fibrinogen, and C3 and C4, but sC5b-9 was elevated at 653 ng/mL. Urinalysis showed microscopic erythrocyturia and mild proteinuria. On Day 2, hemoglobin dropped to 48 g/L, and platelet count dropped to 5  109/L within 2 days. A: The patient is diagnosed with atypical hemolytic uremic syndrome (aHUS) based on laboratory findings and clinical presentation. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of hemolytic anemia and thrombocytopenia, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and laboratory findings. P: The patient was administered a single dose of eculizumab (900 mg/m2) 2 days post-admission. The patient was vaccinated as a precaution. Continued monitoring of hemoglobin and platelet count is necessary, with adjustments to the treatment plan as necessary. Regular follow-ups with the healthcare team are essential to adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient reports severe pain in the right lower abdomen and vomiting. The patient denies any history of abdominal surgery or trauma. O: Physical examination revealed deep tenderness at McBurney's point without abdominal distension. Blood tests showed slight leukocytosis (9840/l) and no elevated C-reactive protein (0.01 mg/dl). Enhanced CT scan showed a slightly enhanced, thickened appendiceal wall, a slightly dilated ileum, and ascites at the recto-vesical pouch, but intestinal obstruction was not diagnosed. Laparoscopic surgery involved three trocars, a 12-mm camera trocar in the infra-umbilical position, and two 5-mm trocars in the left lower quadrant and lower median abdomen, identifying strangulated small bowel obstruction caused by trapping of ileal bowel loops by a band. No ischemic change was detected in the trapped ileum and slight inflammatory changes were noted in the appendix. A: The primary diagnosis is mild acute appendicitis with complications including strangulated small bowel obstruction and ileal bowel obstruction. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of abdominal pain and vomiting, but imaging and surgical findings support the primary diagnosis. P: The patient underwent laparoscopic surgery to remove the band, which was resected using laparoscopic coagulation shears. Post-operative care will include close monitoring of the patient's recovery and pain management. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor recovery and manage any complications. The patient is advised to report any discomfort or concerns immediately.

S: The patient is a 38-year-old woman, gravida 4, para 2, at 12 weeks of gestational age, presenting with mild vaginal bleeding and mild lower abdominal pain. She has a history of two previous Cesarean deliveries, the most recent six years ago, and other surgical procedures including appendectomy and partial gastrectomy. She reports minimal vaginal bleeding and mild lower abdominal pain. O: Vital signs were stable. Cervical os was closed during per vaginal (PV) examination. Post-procedure, severe bleeding occurred, with the os tip-of-finger. Bedside ultrasound showed a bulky uterus with retained products of conception and a uterine cavity filled with blood clots. Evacuation and curettage (E&C) were performed, but E&C failed to stop the bleeding. A laparotomy via Pfannenstiel incision was performed, revealing intact uterus without tear or perforation. A: The primary diagnosis is placenta accreta, a uterine accreta invading the old scar from her previous Cesarean delivery. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of vaginal bleeding and uterine scarring, but these are less likely given the imaging and surgical findings. P: The patient underwent a unilateral ligation of the uterine and ovarian arteries, and local resection of the uterine wall segment affected by the placenta accreta. Post-operative care includes regular follow-ups to monitor recovery and manage any complications. The patient is advised to report any unusual symptoms immediately. Further consultations with a nephrologist and a pulmonologist may be necessary depending on her recovery progress.

S: The patient, with a history of diabetes, hypertension, and dyslipidemia, presents with chief complaint of visual changes in the left eye since yesterday, resulting in sudden loss of vision in the left eye. The patient reports sharp pain in the left eye, rated 5/10, which has resolved. The patient denies any recent trauma to the eye, fever, headache, eye discharge, ear pain, nasal congestion, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, paresthesias, or focal weakness. The patient denies any past medical history of contact lens use, eye surgery, or glaucoma. O: Physical examination reveals normal extraocular motility in both eyes, equal, round, and reactive pupils bilaterally. Visual field testing shows decreased vision in the nasal visual field in the left eye, with visual acuity of 20/50 in the left eye and 20/20 in the right eye. Intraocular pressure is 19 mmHg in the left eye and 23 mmHg in the right eye. Fundoscopic examination shows a black spot at 5 o'clock in the left eye. Ultrasound examination of the left eye shows a hyperechoic smooth folded membrane within the vitreous, consistent with retinal detachment. A: The primary diagnosis is retinal detachment in the left eye, evidenced by the presence of a hyperechoic smooth folded membrane within the vitreous. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of retinal detachment, but these are less likely given the imaging findings and clinical presentation. P: The management plan includes discussing treatment options for retinal detachment and follow-up requirements to preserve vision in the affected eye. The patient will be educated on the signs of retinal detachment and the importance of adherence to follow-up appointments. Referral to a neurologist for further evaluation and management of retinal detachment is recommended.

S: The patient, a former farmer and husband-man, reports a history of cholecystectomy, presenting with vague, colicky epigastric pain starting 2 years ago, which has progressively worsened over the past 4 months. A: The primary diagnosis is cholecystectomy-related epigastric pain, likely exacerbated by the patient's lifestyle and lifestyle changes. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of epigastric pain, but these are less likely given the patient's history and clinical presentation. S: The patient, a male with a history of a foot fracture at age 8, presented with sudden onset of left leg pain and swelling. He reported a fever of 38°C a few days ago. He denies any chronic diseases, history of injuries, illnesses, or family history of foot fractures. O: Physical examination revealed swollen and painful left leg, reduced range of motion in the left hip, and bumps on the right tibia without signs of arthritis, intestinal inflammation, or skin changes. Blood pressure and urinary output were normal. Emergency ultrasound indicated femoral and pelvic deep vein thrombosis. Urinalysis showed haematuria and proteinuria, but blood and urine cultures were sterile. X-rays indicated hyperostosis and sclerosis in the metaphysis of the right tibia, with a periosteal reaction. CRP levels were not significantly elevated over the first few days. Abdominal ultrasound revealed a giant, homogenous pelvic mass and hydronephrosis of the left kidney, with a creatinine level of 185 mol/L and urinary protein excretion of 7g over 24 hours. A: The primary diagnosis is femoral and pelvic deep vein thrombosis, likely secondary to a traumatic foot fracture. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of acute thrombosis and inflammation, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The patient was admitted to the hospital for further evaluation and management of femoral and pelvic deep vein thrombosis. The treatment plan includes close monitoring of kidney function and thrombosis, with adjustments to antibiotic therapy as necessary based on the patient's response to treatment. Further consultations with a nephrologist and a nephrologist are recommended to address the thrombosis, inflammation, and kidney issues. Patient education regarding the nature of the condition, treatment options, and potential side effects will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient, referred to the maxillofacial department, reports a painless swelling in the mouth for approximately 2 years, which interferes with dental occlusion. O: Physical examination revealed a 1.5 cm soft lesion in the mouth, mainly soft on palpation. An excisional biopsy under local anesthesia was performed, revealing a capsulated lesion. Post-surgery, the lesion was completely removed, with adipose tissue and a thin capsule surrounding it. Pathologic examination confirmed an intraoral fibrolipoma. A: The primary diagnosis is intraoral fibrolipoma of the mouth, a benign tumor with no complications. The prognosis is good with no signs of recurrence after 12 months. P: The patient underwent successful excisional biopsy under local anesthesia. Post-surgery, the lesion was sent for laboratory examination to determine the cause of the swelling. The patient is advised to maintain regular follow-ups to monitor for any recurrence or complications. The patient is encouraged to reach out with any concerns or questions.

S: The patient, a 55-year-old entrepreneur with a history of smoking for 37 pack years, presents with sudden onset of pain in the middle of the left thigh, accompanied by swelling. He reports no other health issues. O: Physical examination revealed a slightly pale patient with a heart rate of 120 bpm and a blood pressure of 100 x 70 mmHg. Head and neck, thorax, and abdomen were normal. Lower limb examination showed ecchymosis and pulsatile swelling between the mid and distal thirds of the thigh in the anteromedial region, with signs of distal microembolization in the left foot, and absent popliteal and distal pulses. Ultrasonography of the left thigh revealed an aneurysmal dilatation of the SFA, measuring 5.8 x 5.3 cm, with associated thrombi and perivascular accumulations. A: The primary diagnosis is a ruptured SFA aneurysm in the anteromedial region, likely exacerbated by smoking. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of thigh pain and swelling, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The management plan includes emergency surgical intervention to address the ruptured SFA aneurysm. The procedure will involve removing the extensive hematoma, resecting the aneurysm, and revascularization using the contralateral great saphenous vein in reverse. Samples will be collected for anatomopathological and microbiological analyses. The patient will be educated on the procedure and the importance of follow-up appointments to monitor recovery and manage any complications.

O: Physical examination revealed moderate tenderness over the epigastrium, central abdomen, and right hypochondrium with a positive Murphy's sign. Laboratory tests including complete blood count, urine analysis, liver, and renal function tests were within normal limits. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of abdominal pain, but these are less likely given the patient's history of obstructive sleep apnea and family history. The prognosis depends on the management of the patient's symptoms and response to treatment. P: Continue monitoring the patient's condition closely with regular follow-ups to assess for any recurrence or new symptoms. Educate the patient on signs of worsening symptoms and encourage immediate reporting of any new symptoms. Consider referral to a gastroenterologist for further evaluation and management of obstructive sleep apnea. S: The patient, a female with a history of breast carcinoma, presented for a follow-up regarding breast carcinoma. She reported feeling okay but denied any symptoms from the tibia tumor. O: Whole-body CT and bone scintigraphy scan revealed a tumor in the entire right tibia. Plain X-ray and MRI confirmed an intraosseal tumor in the tibia, extending from 4 cm below the knee joint to about 4 cm from the ankle joint. Open biopsy confirmed adamantinoma histology. Treatment included a custom-made, silver-coated, modular endoprosthesis of the Modular Universal Tumor and Revision System, knee joint resection, metal-on-poly articulation, talar replacement, and a supplementary screw. The endoprosthesis was enveloped in a Trevira tube, and a microvascular latissimus dorsi musculocutaneous flap was anastomosed to the tibia artery and concomitant vein, and transposed a medial gastrocnemius muscle flap to cover the patellar tendon region. A: The primary diagnosis is adamantinoma in the right tibia, with a secondary diagnosis of adamantinoma. The prognosis is good with appropriate surgical intervention. P: The patient underwent successful surgical resection of the tumor and reconstruction of the affected area. Regular follow-ups are scheduled to monitor the healing process and ensure no complications arise. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms or unusual symptoms immediately.

S: The patient, diagnosed with B-ALL, reports a history of Philadelphia chromosome-positive leukemia (P-ALL) treated with a pediatric-inspired regimen and dasatinib 140 mg/day. The patient is currently in complete remission but has not yet achieved complete remission. O: The patient's FISH test showed 70% positive results. Molecular analysis of white blood cells revealed expression of P190BCR-ABL1, the most common isoform in Ph+ ALL. A second evaluation confirmed minimal residual disease (MRD) in the body. A point mutation in the ABL1 domain of the fusion transcript, c.1319A.G, was identified in 20% of BCR-ABL1-expressing cells at follow-up. A: The primary diagnosis is Ph+ ALL, characterized by Philadelphia chromosome-positive leukemia. The patient's complete remission and the presence of minimal residual disease (MRD) suggest a possible acquired resistance to dasatinib treatment. P: The patient will continue to be monitored closely for BCR-ABL1 mutations and will undergo a bone marrow transplant to address acquired resistance. The treatment plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition and reducing BCR-ABL1 expression before the allogeneic bone marrow transplant. The patient will be educated on the importance of adhering to the treatment regimen and adherence to the treatment plan.

She underwent an abdominal cerclage placed pre-pregnancy, prophylactic low molecular weight heparin for APLS, insulin for type two diabetes mellitus, and betamethasone for threatened preterm labor. The patient's history of multiple morbidities and the absence of symptoms during pregnancy suggest a high-risk pregnancy. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of euglycemic symptoms, but these are less likely given the patient's history of multiple morbidities. P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's health post-pregnancy. The patient will be educated on the importance of using condoms and avoiding intercourse with her husband. Regular follow-ups will be scheduled to monitor her health and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Referral to a

S: The patient reports experiencing shortness of breath and occasional chest pain. The patient's father passed away from ZZ-AATD disease. The patient has a history of targeted familial genotyping, which identified a single Z allele. O: The patient's AAT level is 64 mg/dL, indicating MZ heterozygotes. The patient's mother carries an S allele, indicating increased risk for maternal half-siblings. A: The primary diagnosis is MZ heterozygotes, evidenced by the presence of a single Z allele in the patient's mother. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of MZ heterozygotes, but these are less likely given the patient's genetic profile. P: The management plan includes monitoring the patient's symptoms closely and considering augmentation therapy if symptoms worsen. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately. Further consultations with a geneticist and a pulmonologist are recommended if symptoms worsen. The patient is encouraged to contact their mother and half-siblings if they experience any concerning symptoms.

S: The patient reports experiencing blurred vision for the past 2 weeks. The patient attempted suicide 2 weeks ago with 15 tablets of pregabalin, leading to unconsciousness and seizures. The patient has a history of attempted suicide 2 weeks ago with 15 tablets of Lyrica, which led to unconsciousness and seizures. O: The patient's discharge report shows a blood pressure of 100/60 mmHg, heart rate of 165/minute, respiration rate of 34/minute, and body temperature of 36.8 °C. Hemogram and biochemical values are within normal limits. An arterial blood gas analysis during intensive care showed pH 6.79, PaO2 of 45 mmHg, PaCO2 of 55 mmHg, HCO3 of 7.9 mmol/L, and BE of -33.6 mmol/L. The patient was treated with intravenous hydration, 20 ampules of NaHCO3, and 0.05 mg/kg midazolam. Post-treatment, arterial blood gas analysis improved with pH 7.41, PaO2 of 145 mmHg, PaCO2 of 31.8 mmHg, HCO3 of 18.8 mmol/L, and BE of -3.3 mmol/L. Best corrected visual acuity is 20/40 in the right eye and 20/50 in the left eye. Anterior segment examination is normal, and intraocular pressure is within normal limits. A: The primary diagnosis is bilateral serous exudative macular detachment in the right eye, likely related to the patient's recent suicide attempt. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of blurred vision, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: Continue monitoring the patient's vision closely and adjust the treatment plan as necessary based on further evaluations and imaging results. Educate the patient on the importance of reporting any new symptoms or changes in vision. Schedule follow-up appointments to reassess the patient's condition and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient, a 3-year-old intact female red corn snake, presented with swelling in the middle of her body and has not been eating for the past three weeks. The snake has a history of 2.5 years and has been healthy until now. The owner reports that the snake has been feeding a frozen-thawed adult mouse once a week. The patient has noticed a decrease in defecation habits over the past few weeks, with stools becoming smaller, drier, and less frequent over the past three to four weeks. O: Physical examination revealed the snake to be quiet, alert, and responsive, with a soft 6  4 cm ventral swelling at the midbody. Ultrasonography indicated a cylindrical structure lateral to the caudal liver near the stomach, markedly and focally fluid dilated. A: The primary diagnosis is a gastrointestinal obstruction, likely a gastrointestinal obstruction, given the dilated segment of the caudal liver. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of gastrointestinal obstruction, but these are less likely given the imaging results. P: The management plan includes scheduling additional diagnostic tests to determine the exact cause and appropriate treatment. The patient is advised to closely monitor the temperature and humidity closely and report any changes in behavior or condition. Further diagnostic tests will be scheduled to confirm the diagnosis and determine the exact cause of the obstruction.

S: The patient reports hitting his head hard but denies any significant neurological symptoms since the accident. The patient has severe dementia and has been placed in a temporary halo device before surgery. O: Neurological examination revealed a left nondisplaced impaction OCF with an occipital condyle-C1 interval of 2.5 mm and a 5 mm translation of C1-C2. The fracture pattern is Anderson and Montesano type 1 and Tuli type 1, classified as Anderson and Montesano type 1 and Tuli type 1. Craniocervical misalignment and C1-C2 translation were noted. A CT scan of the cervical spine showed a left nondisplaced impaction OCF with an occipital condyle-C1 interval of 2.5 mm and a 5 mm translation of C1-C2. A halo device was placed temporarily prior to surgery, and rotational traction force was adjusted. Post-surgery, internal segmental fixation was performed using an occipital bone plate and bilateral pedicle screws for C2, and an autologous iliac crest bone graft in an augmented posterior fusion. A: The primary diagnosis is a left nondisplaced impaction OCF with an occipital condyle-C1 interval of 2.5 mm and a 5 mm translation of C1-C2. The fracture pattern is stable with craniocervical misalignment and C1-C2 translation. The patient's neurological status has improved post-surgery. P: The patient was placed in a temporary halo device prior to surgery. Post-operative care included internal segmental fixation using an occipital bone plate and bilateral pedicle screws for C2, and an autologous iliac crest bone graft in an augmented posterior fusion. The halo vest was removed immediately post-surgery, and the patient is now ready to be discharged and transferred to a rehabilitation facility for further recovery.

S: The patient reports experiencing paroxysmal palpitation, described as sudden, racing, and pounding. The patient's sister and father have molecularly confirmed CFNS and a heterozygous missense mutation in exon 3 of the EFNB1 gene. The patient has a history of frontonasal dysplasia and a successful catheter ablation for the left lateral accessory pathway. O: The patient's 12-lead ECG showed a short PR interval and Delta waves, and widened QRS complexes. Transthoracic echocardiography was normal. The patient's sister and father have molecularly confirmed CFNS and a heterozygous missense mutation in exon 3 of the EFNB1 gene. A: The primary diagnosis is type-A WPW syndrome, characterized by rapid heartbeats and a heterozygous missense mutation in exon 3 of the EFNB1 gene. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of heart failure, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and genetic findings. P: The management plan includes referral to the electrophysiology department for an electrophysiological study and transcatheter ablation of the accessory pathway. The procedure will involve inserting a catheter into the heart to study electrical activity and delivering energy to destroy the accessory pathway causing the WPW syndrome. The patient will be educated on the procedure and the importance of follow-up appointments to monitor recovery and manage any complications.

S: The patient is a 15-year-old Han Chinese boy presenting with fever, weakness, pallor, edema, dyspnea, and a gradual increase in abdominal girth for the past 2 weeks. He reports feeling weak and tired, experiencing increased abdominal girth, and difficulty breathing. He has a history of consanguineous marriage, spleen resected at age 9, and multiple hospital admissions for pyrexia of unknown origin. O: On examination, the patient was unwell with a height of 135 cm, weight of 30 kg, and no secondary sex characters. He presented with a fever between 37.2 and 39.7 °C, pallor, wakefulness, distress, and clarity of mind. No jaundice, petechiae, fresh rash on skin, superficial lymph nodes in the inguinal region, eyelids swollen, no cyanosis, and no congestion in the pharynx. Physical examination revealed audible harsh breath sounds and crackles bilaterally, a distended abdomen with hepatomegaly, and a liver palpable 10 cm below the costal margin with firm consistency and free from tenderness. Murphy sign was negative, shifting dullness sign was positive, and marked pitting edema was noted in the lower extremities. Neurological assessment was normal, and systemic examinations were essentially normal. Laboratory tests and imaging showed a white blood cell count of 0/6. A: The primary diagnosis is a recurrent spleen resected due to unexplained enlargement, complicated by a severe abdominal hepatomegaly and hepatomegaly. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of abdominal girth and hepatomegaly, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: Continue monitoring the patient's vital signs and lab results closely. Consider surgical intervention if symptoms persist or worsen. Educate the patient on the importance of reporting new or worsening symptoms immediately. Schedule regular follow-up appointments to monitor the patient's progress and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient, with a history of coronary artery disease, heart failure, atrial fibrillation, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, and type-2 diabetes mellitus, was admitted after a seizure at a nursing rehabilitation facility. The patient reported feeling better after receiving 25 g of dextrose 50% (D50) and was transferred to the emergency department. O: Upon admission, the patient was hypoglycemic with a blood glucose level of 21 mg/dL. Initial laboratory results showed hypokalemia with a potassium level of 2.9 mmol/L, acute kidney injury with serum creatinine at 2.52 mg/dL, and hypoglycemia with a blood glucose level of 34 mg/dL. Liver function tests were within normal limits. The patient was prescribed levofloxacin 750 mg daily for pneumonia and other medications including aspirin 81 mg daily, atorvastatin 80 mg daily, glipizide 10 mg daily, losartan 25 mg daily, mometasone 220 mcg/inhalation three times daily, spironolactone 25 mg daily, torsemide 100 mg daily, and warfarin. A: The primary diagnosis is acute kidney injury secondary to a seizure at a nursing rehabilitation facility. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of hypoglycemia, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and laboratory findings. The prognosis is guarded due to the severity of the seizure and the patient's history of diabetes mellitus. P: The management plan includes close monitoring of blood glucose levels in the ICU and adjustment of medications as necessary. The patient will be closely monitored in the ICU and will be monitored in the ICU for any signs of worsening symptoms or complications. Regular follow-ups in the ICU will be scheduled to monitor the patient's condition and manage any complications.

S: The patient reports a discharging wound in the upper part of the abdomen for approximately a month. The wound started 6 months ago following an emergency exploratory laparotomy at another medical college for abdominal pain. Post-surgery, the patient developed a burst abdomen, managed conservatively with oral nutrition, and developed a burst abdomen on the fourth day post-surgery. Post-surgery, the patient developed a burst abdomen, managed conservatively with oral nutrition, and developed a burst abdomen. The wound was covered with a split thickness skin graft in the fourth month, but noticed a serous discharge from a small ulcer in the upper part of the grafted surface. O: Physical examination revealed a 12 cm  5 cm elliptical patch of skin graft over the middle of the abdomen, a small depressed ulcer of 1 cm  1 cm in its upper part covered with pale granulation, exuberant pale granulation, a scar at the previous drain site, and a deficient abdominal wall below the skin graft. Blood tests were normal with hemoglobin at 11.4 gm/dl, total WBC count at 11.6  103/mm3, total serum protein at 7.9 gm/dl, and serum albumin at 3.5 gm/dl. Ultrasound showed a left subphrenic collection of 8 cm  7 cm. A: The primary diagnosis is a discharging wound in the upper part of the abdomen, complicated by a peptic perforation post-surgery. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of abdominal pain, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The management plan includes consultation with a specialist to explore the cause of the persistent wound issues. The patient is advised to maintain the wound clean and change gauze as needed. Regular follow-ups will be scheduled to monitor the wound's healing and adjust the gauze as necessary. The patient is encouraged to report any new symptoms or changes in condition immediately.

S: The patient, a 152 kg male with a BMI of 45, presented with sudden onset of intense pain in the right upper quadrant, described as colicky sharp stabbing pain, worsening with coughing or deep breaths. The pain was initially described as colicky sharp stabbing but has progressed to a constant dull discomfort, worsening with coughing or deep breaths. The patient has a history of undifferentiated immunodeficiency, idiopathic thrombocytopaenia (ITP) with splenectomy, a possible previous stroke, and paroxysmal atrial fibrillation. He is on warfarin and has been on multiple antibiotic courses for recurrent lower limb cellulitis and respiratory tract infections post-splenectomy. O: Vital signs include a platelet count of 232  109 l1, mildly elevated white cell count of 13.8  109 l1, and C-reactive protein of 12.7 mg l1. Liver function tests are normal, but the INR is elevated at 3.8, and lactate level is elevated at 2.7 mmol l1. CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis revealed a well-defined ovoid mass of 37  27 mm with a Hounsfield Unit of 51 in both portal venous and delayed phases, suggesting an adrenal lesion. The left adrenal appears normal in a "Y" shape, with patchy consolidation in the right lower lobe. A: The primary diagnosis is an adrenal lesion in the right upper quadrant, likely exacerbated by splenectomy, given the elevated INR and lactate levels. Differential diagnoses could include acute cholecystitis or right lower lobe pneumonia with associated pleurisy. P: Initiate intravenous antibiotics to treat a lower respiratory tract infection. Monitor the patient's response to the treatment and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Educate the patient on the importance of adhering to the treatment regimen and adherence to the treatment plan. Schedule follow-up appointments to assess the effectiveness of the treatment and adjust as necessary.

S: The patient, a 20-year-old with a history of appendicitis, presented with upper abdominal pain and tenderness. The pain is predominantly in the left upper part of the abdomen. O: Physical examination revealed left hypochondriac pain and tenderness in the upper abdomen. Laboratory tests showed elevated inflammatory markers (WBC 13400/L, CRP 11.58 mg/dL), elevated biliary enzymes (lactate dehydrogenase 250 U/L, alkaline phosphatase 535 U/L, -glutamyltranspeptidase 76 U/L), elevated tumor markers (carcinoembryonic antigen 9.4 U/mL, cancer antigen 19-9 550 U/mL), elevated tumor markers (carcinoembryonic antigen 9.4 U/mL, cancer antigen 19-9 550 U/mL), and elevated pancreatic tumor markers (s-pancreas-1 antigen 20.0 U/mL, duke pancreatic monoclonal antigen type 2  25 U/mL). Contrast-enhanced CT scan revealed a markedly dilated main pancreatic duct (MPD) measuring 55 mm in length, thinning with atrophy, and gastropancreatic and splenopancreatic fistulas, suggesting penetration of a pancreatic tumor. MRI confirmed the dilatation of the MPD with low signal intensity on T1-weighted images and high signal intensity on T2-weighted images. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy identified four gastropancreatic fistulas on the posterior wall of the gastric body, discharging mucus from these fistulas. Cytological examination of the mucus did not reveal malignancy. A: The primary diagnosis is IPMN of main ductal type penetrating into the stomach and spleen. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of pancreatic tumors, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The patient has been pre-operatively diagnosed with IPMN of main ductal type penetrating into the stomach and spleen. Surgery is planned

S: The patient reports a painless mass in the right calf for the last 2 years, initially discovered 2 years ago, initially diagnosed as a lipoma.
