S: The patient, with a history of breast cancer diagnosed at age 68, underwent lumpectomy, radiotherapy, and chemotherapy. She reports no pain or discomfort in the right hypogastric area. O: Physical examination revealed a palpable mass in the right hypogastric area without tenderness. Tumor markers were within normal limits, with mild elevation of serum carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) at 5.3ng/ml (normal range: 4.7ng/ml) and serum cancer antigen 15-3 (CA 15-3) at 31.4U/ml (normal range: 4.7ng/ml). Abdominal ultrasound showed a hypoechoic formation sized 80.0 x 36.6 mm below the uterus and an intravaginal ultrasound revealing a mixed texture mass sized 8.7cm with a solid and cystic part in the right ovary. Abdominal MRI scan identified a 9 cm cystic mass in the right iliac fossa, in contact with the right ovary, uterus, and intestines, thin-walled without disturbance in molecular diffusion and low-grade heterogeneity. Exploratory laparotomy and formal appendectomy identified a cystadenoma of the appendix. Postoperative course was uneventful, and pathological examination of the surgical specimen confirmed a low-grade mucinous neoplasm of the appendix. A: The primary diagnosis is a low-grade mucinous neoplasm of the appendix, confirmed by imaging and biopsy. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of adnexal mass, but these are less likely given the imaging and biopsy results. P: The patient is asymptomatic after a year of follow-up. Regular check-ups and imaging tests are scheduled to monitor the patient's condition and detect any new symptoms or concerns. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately. Further consultations with oncology and ob-gyn are recommended to manage her breast cancer effectively.

S: The patient, a male with a history of HIV treated with Tenofovir, emtricitabine, efavirenz, and dolutegravir, presents with a 4-week history of constipation, painful defecation, and streaks of blood on toilet paper. He reports no significant weight loss in the last 3 months. O: Vital signs are within normal limits. Abdominal examination is soft, nontender, and non-distended. Bowel sounds are normoactive. Rectal exam is normal. Laboratory findings include hemoglobin 14.1 g/dL, leukocyte count 4.7 K cells/uL, platelet count 246 K cells/uL, mildly elevated alkaline phosphatase 142 U/L, RPR test negative, stool culture negative for Salmonella, Shigella, Aeromona, Plesiomona, Campylobacter antigen, Escherichia coli shigatoxins, and no isolated ova and parasites. Rectal swab for gonorrhea and chlamydia PCR negative. Colonoscopy revealed moderate inflammation, erythema, and friability of the rectal mucosa, with shallow ulcerations only in the rectum. Histopathology indicated mucosa with increased lymphoplasmacytic and neutrophilic infiltrate in the lamina propria, acute cryptitis, and focal crypt abscesses. A: The primary diagnosis is a recurrent infection with a recurrent infection in the rectum. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of recurrent infections, but these are less likely given the imaging and histopathological findings. P: The management plan includes referral to gastroenterology for endoscopic evaluation of the colon and rectum. The patient will be educated on the signs of infection and the importance of follow-up care. Referral to a gastroenterologist for further evaluation and management of recurrent infections is recommended. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's response to treatment and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient, with a psychiatric history of major depressive disorder, generalized anxiety disorder, posttraumatic stress disorder, borderline personality disorder, and pica, presented to the emergency department after intentionally ingesting objects including 50 paperclips, 50 screws, eight batteries, and seven razor blades covered in paper. The patient reported feeling anxious and unable to help with the ingestion behaviors. The patient has a history of multiple psychotropic medications including antidepressants, mood stabilizers, lithium, Depakote, olanzapine, haloperidol, aripiprazole, and benzodiazepines. O: The patient's abdominal radiograph confirmed multiple metallic objects in the stomach and small intestine. The gastroenterologist successfully removed the objects endoscopically. The patient was admitted to the adult inpatient psychiatric unit for further care. The patient's past medications include antidepressants, mood stabilizers, lithium, Depakote, olanzapine, haloperidol, aripiprazole, and benzodiazepines, but these have not been effective in controlling ingestion behaviors. A: The primary diagnosis is an ingestion behavior disorder with a history of multiple psychotropic medications, including antidepressants, mood stabilizers, lithium, Depakote, olanzapine, haloperidol, aripiprazole, clonazepam, and lorazepam. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of anxiety, but these are less likely given the patient's psychiatric history. The prognosis depends on the effectiveness of the treatment and the management of anxiety and ingestion behaviors. P: The patient has been restarted on alprazolam at 2 mg three times daily. Dialectical Behavior Therapy includes components of mindfulness, distress tolerance, emotion regulation, and stress management skills. The patient will continue to be monitored in the adult inpatient psychiatric unit, with adjustments to the treatment plan as necessary. The patient is advised to reach out with any concerns during his stay.

S: The patient, a six-month-old male infant with a significant past medical history including neonatal meningitis on the second day of life, presents with a chief complaint of disproportionate head enlarging over the past three months. The parent reports that the infant's head has been enlarging disproportionately for the past three months. O: Initial MRI revealed gross asymmetrical hydrocephalus with obstruction at the aqueduct level, and no signs of ependymal thickening. During a ventricular tap, CSF cultures were sterile, with no features of infection. A repeat MRI showed gross asymmetric dilatation of the left lateral ventricle and air-fluid level in the right periventricular region, suggestive of pneumocephalus. CSF samples showed features of infection and Gram-positive budding yeast, susceptible to all antifungals. Fluconazole (50 mg 24 hourly) was started, and daily CSF samples continued to grow C. parapsilosis. A: The primary diagnosis is pneumocephalus secondary to a multiloculated abscess in the left lateral ventricle and air-fluid level in the right periventricular region. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of enlarging, but these are less likely given the culture results and clinical presentation. P: The management plan included placement of an external ventricular drain and intraventricular vancomycin (10 mg 12 hourly) and parenteral vancomycin (120 mg 8 hourly) and meropenem (240 mg 8 hourly). The patient underwent a right temporoparietal craniotomy and excision of a multiloculated abscess, followed by removal of the right EVD and placement of a left EVD. Fluconazole (50 mg 24 hourly) was started, followed by placement of an Ommaya reservoir and a ventricular catheter for better intraventricular antibiotic administration. The patient is stable with no further complications reported. A: The primary diagnosis is pneumocephalus secondary to a multiloculated abscess in the right periventricular region. The prognosis is favorable with ongoing antifungal therapy

S: The patient reports a nonproductive cough, dyspnea at rest, dysuria, and urinary frequency for about a week. The patient was previously diagnosed with a UTI and a viral upper respiratory tract infection two days ago. The patient was treated with ciprofloxacin but did not improve symptoms. O: Vital signs show oxygen saturation at 90%, tachycardia, and low-grade fever. Physical examination reveals significant bibasilar crackles, a holosystolic apical murmur in the chest, 2+ lower extremity edema, and punctuate macular lesions on the feet. Laboratory studies indicate leukocytosis with neutrophilia (14.7 bil/L and 11.3 bil/L, respectively), acute kidney injury, bacteriuria, and leukocytes. Chest X-ray was unremarkable. Blood and urine cultures confirmed the infection. Transthoracic echocardiogram revealed a mobile mass on the posterior leaflet of the mitral valve, with an ejection fraction of 40%. Blood and urine cultures identified gram-positive cocci in pairs and clusters. On day 5, a transesophageal echocardiogram confirmed severe mitral regurgitation and posterior leaflet perforation. On day 8, the patient was acutely decompensated and required endotracheal intubation. A: The primary diagnosis is acute heart failure with aggressive diuresis, complicated by a vascular emboli phenomenon. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of vascular emboli, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: Initiated treatment with intravenous gentamicin and penicillin G for a 6-week course, followed by treatment for acute heart failure with aggressive diuresis. The patient is currently on intravenous gentamicin and penicillin G for a 6-week course, and is currently on aggressive diuresis treatment. On day 8, the patient was acutely decompensated and required endotracheal intubation. The family has been informed about the patient's condition and has been supportive during this time.

S: The patient reports experiencing discomfort and irregular bowel movements. O: Contrast CT examination revealed a wall thickness in the sigmoid colon. Colonoscopy revealed multiple polyps in the sigmoid colon, one of which was a 25 mm pedunculated polyp. Microscopically, 10% of the tumor cells were conventional tubular adenocarcinoma with hyperchromatic oval nuclei in the basal portion and eosinophilic cytoplasm. Other tumor cells showed dysplastic columnar epithelium with large epithelioid or polygonal nuclei randomly arranged and clear or vacuolated cytoplasm. cribriform or fused tubular structures and a desmoplastic reaction were noted. PAS, PAS-D, Alcian blue, and mucicarmine staining on the clear cell component were negative. Immunohistochemical staining for CK7, focally positive for CK20, and positive for CDX2 and MUC2 were negative for CK7, focally positive for CK20, and positive for CDX2 and MUC2. Differential staining for CEA and CD10 was negative for CEA and CD10. MUC5AC, MUC6, AFP, glypican 3, perilipin, and AR were negative. Ki67 LI was 80.0% for the conventional component and almost 100% for the clear cell component. A: The primary diagnosis is tubular adenocarcinoma with invasion into the submucosa of the pT1b submucosa. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of tubular adenocarcinoma, but these are less likely given the negative immunohistochemical and immunohistochemical staining results. P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition with regular follow-up appointments to assess treatment efficacy and manage any complications. The patient is advised to adhere strictly to the treatment plan and follow up appointments to ensure optimal outcomes. Further consultations with oncology and oncology are recommended to manage the invasive nature of the tumor.

S: The patient is a 27-year-old female presenting with a nine-month history of an abdominal lump. She reports feeling full after eating food and has lost weight. O: Clinical examination revealed a large, non-tender, soft cystic swelling occupying the upper abdomen. Radiological investigations including an ultrasonogram and CECT revealed a complex cystic mass with internal septation. Contrast-enhanced CT of the abdomen showed a large multiseptated cystic lesion adhered to the pancreas, causing mass effect. The lesion was well defined, lobulated, and hypodense, with dilation of the main pancreatic duct and portal vein thrombosis with portal cavernoma. USG-guided FNAC showed straw-colored aspirate with mature lymphocytes, with normal cyst amylase and CEA levels. Postoperative exploration revealed a large multiloculated cystic lesion extending through the gastrocolic omentum, pushing the stomach up and transverse colon downwards, with hundreds of cystic spaces containing lymphatic fluid. Histopathological examination showed unremarkable pancreatic tissue with an attached lesion consisting of dilated lymphatic spaces with lymphatic follicles, congested blood vessels, and fibrocollagenous tissue with chronic inflammatory infiltrate. A: The primary diagnosis is a multiloculated cystic lesion in the pancreas, with complications including dilation of the main pancreatic duct, portal vein thrombosis, and portal cavernoma. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of pancreatic lesions, but these are less likely given the imaging and histopathological findings. P: The patient underwent surgical exploration to excise the lesion, which was managed with an abdominal drain. Postoperatively, the patient was discharged with the drain in place, and histopathological examination revealed unremarkable pancreatic tissue with an attached lesion consisting of dilated lymphatic spaces with lymphatic follicles, congested blood vessels, and fibrocollagenous tissue with chronic inflammatory infiltrate. The patient is advised to continue regular follow-up appointments and report any changes in her

S: The patient, a 2-year-old male with a history of myoclonic seizures between 2 and 3 years of age, reports a history of unsupported sitting at 12 months and walking independently at twenty-two months. At 2 years, he can go upstairs with two-hand support and climb furniture, but his gait appears ataxic sometimes. He has a history of myoclonic seizures between 2 and 3 years of age, currently on anti-epileptic medications. He has a preference for pureed foods, occasional choking episodes, and a preference for specific textures and water exploration. His sleep is disrupted with frequent awakenings. O: Physical examination at 2 years, 3 months shows a weight of 12.1 kg (15-50th centile), height of 87.5 cm (15-50th centile), and head circumference of 48 cm (- 1 SD). He has deep-set eyes, down slanting palpebral fissures, and a prominent nasal root and tip. Echocardiogram, abdominal ultrasonography, brain MRI, and genetic testing for Angelman syndrome were normal. A: The primary diagnosis is myoclonic seizures, with differential diagnoses including other forms of epilepsy, but these are less likely given the patient's history and current findings. The prognosis is guarded due to the severity of the seizures and the presence of choking episodes. P: Continue anti-epileptic medications and monitor seizures closely. Regular follow-ups with the pediatrician are recommended to manage his seizure symptoms and prevent choking episodes. Educate the patient on the importance of medication adherence and regular monitoring of development. Consider referral to a sleep specialist if sleep issues persist or worsen.

S: The patient, with a history of osteopenia and a total hip arthroplasty on the left side three months ago, presents with leg pain and inability to walk. The patient reports tenderness and bruising around the left hip area. O: Vital signs are mildly hypertensive with a blood pressure of 137/92 mmHg and tachycardia with a heart rate of 105 beats per minute. Physical examination reveals a slightly shortened and externally rotated left leg. Pelvic radiograph shows medial displacement of the acetabulum and femoral head into the lesser pelvis. An angiography for vascular disruption was negative. A: The primary diagnosis is medial displacement of the acetabulum and femoral head into the lesser pelvis. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of pelvic pain and bruising, but these are less likely given the radiograph results and angiography results. P: The management plan includes urgent internal pelvic fixation to address the medial displacement of the acetabulum and femoral head into the lesser pelvis. The patient is hemodynamically stable post-surgery, and pre-operative instructions are provided. Post-operative care will focus on ensuring recovery and preventing complications. The patient is advised to follow pre-operative instructions and report any questions or concerns immediately.

S: The patient, a 6-year-old female, reports feeling worried about her growth and health. She started receiving rhGH treatment at age 6 and has experienced a dramatic increase in growth velocity, particularly during the first 2 years of treatment. She has remained prepubertal and has a retarded bone age by 1 year. She also mentions a 6-month period of decreased growth velocity, IGF-1, and IGFBP-3 levels during the fourth year of therapy. O: The patient's serum IGFBP-3 levels normalized after 1 month of rhGH treatment, and IGF-I levels normalized after 6 months. Serum IGF-I and IGFBP-3 levels normalized for up to 4.5 years, but decreased during the fourth year due to a lack of treatment adherence. The patient and siblings have mild hypercholesterolemia, with a positive paternal family history. A: The primary diagnosis is mild hypercholesterolemia with a history of rhGH treatment. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of hypercholesterolemia, but these are less likely given the patient's history and family history. P: Continue rhGH treatment and maintain proper adherence to the treatment regimen. Monitor growth and overall health closely. Educate the patient on the importance of adherence to the treatment regimen and the importance of regular follow-ups. Consider consultation with a nephrologist for further evaluation and management of hypercholesterolemia.

S: The patient, diagnosed with a middle esophageal diverticulum at age 30, presented with chest discomfort eight months ago. The patient denies any treatment for the diverticulum and has a history of pediatric asthma. O: Recent tests revealed a diverticulum diameter of 47 mm, with an accumulation of contrast medium in the diverticulum. Gastrointestinal endoscopy revealed a diverticulum in the right wall, 30 cm from the incisor row, partially covered by adherent white matter with iodine. narrowband imaging indicated type A. Pathological findings of the endoscopic biopsy indicated atypical epithelium and no malignant findings. The esophageal body peristaltic wave was normal. A: The primary diagnosis is atypical epithelium with atypical epithelium. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of esophageal diverticulum, but these are less likely given the biopsy results. P: The management plan includes scheduling a thoracoscopic diverticulectomy to address symptoms and the risk of malignancy. The patient will be placed in the prone position, and four trocars will be inserted into the right thoracic cavity. A pneumothorax will be created using CO2 gas at 6 mm. The thoracoscope will be inserted via the 12-mm port in the ninth intercostal space at the inferior scapular angle line and the assistant will use the 12-mm port in the fifth intercostal space on the posterior axillary line. The patient is advised to schedule the surgery at the earliest available date. Further questions or concerns will be addressed during the surgery.

S: The patient is a 13-year-old boy presenting with left groin pain and decreased range of movement in the left hip. He reports a history of an avulsion fracture of the AIIS during a rugby game six months ago, which he played without a warm-up. He reports sharp pain in the left groin while running with a ball while playing rugby. He has been doing well with conservative treatment and referred to a physiotherapist for mobilisation and muscle strengthening. O: Initial MRI revealed a bony fragment measuring 12 mm  4 mm  12 mm at the rectus femoris origin of the AIIS, retracted inferiorly 3 cm, anteriorly 1 cm, and laterally 0.5 cm. Post-injury, the patient experienced sharp pain in the left groin while running with a ball, restricted flexion to 70°, and decreased internal rotation. Abduction, adduction, extension, and external rotation were similar to the other side. Radiographs and CT scans showed hypertrophic calcification in the rectus femoris avulsion, normal hip joints, and well corticated heterotopic bone formation at the site, measuring 3.5 cm at maximum diameter. Three-dimensional CT data showed the impinging area in 70° of hip flexion. Post-operative arthroscopy confirmed a well-formed bone. A: The primary diagnosis is a rectus femoris avulsion fracture with complications including hypertrophic calcification, hip flexion restriction, and impinginging area. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of groin pain, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The patient underwent successful surgical intervention with a well-formed bone. Post-operative care includes regular follow-ups with physiotherapy and physiotherapists to monitor recovery and adjust treatment as necessary. The patient is advised to continue regular rehabilitation exercises to improve mobility and strength. Further consultations with a physiotherapist and a surgeon are recommended to manage pain and improve mobility.

S: The patient reports skin ecchymosis on the trunk and lower limbs for about 10 days. S: The patient, with a history of muscle disorders, reports a slowly progressing weakness in the upper and lower limbs for approximately 7-8 years, difficulty in walking up and downstairs, and shortness of breath, without difficulty swallowing or speaking. The patient has a history of mild hyperCKemia (CK level 468 UI/L). Neurological examination revealed lumbar hyperlordosis, abdominal breath, and a waddling gait. Manual muscle test (MRC) revealed bilateral and symmetric weakness in the deltoid, pectoralis, biceps brachii, triceps brachii, ileo-psoas, and quadriceps, with hypotrophy in the axial musculature with winged scapulae. Blood tests showed slightly elevated CK levels, normal serum protein electrophoresis, and moderate restrictive ventilatory deficit. Nerve conduction studies were unremarkable. The patient will be educated on the importance of follow-up appointments and adherence to the treatment plan. Referral to a neurologist for further evaluation and management of muscle weakness is recommended. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's progress and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient, a 56-year-old with a history of extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy for urinary calculus, endoscopic colon polypectomy for colon polyps, esophagectomy with gastric reconstruction for esophageal cancer, and chemoradiation therapy, presents with severe shortness of breath. She will continue to be monitored for any worsening symptoms or new symptoms. She is advised to report any new or worsening symptoms immediately. Further consultations with a neurologist and a psychiatric specialist are recommended to explore the possibility of a psychi

S: The patient, a smoker of Spice, presented with a two-day history of nosebleeds and painless gross hematuria, described as fruit punch, worsening to ketchup. The patient denies any dysuria, frequency, urgency, incomplete bladder emptying, clot formation, flank or abdominal pain, history of anticoagulation, hepatic dysfunction, or history of anticoagulation or hepatic dysfunction. S: The patient, who underwent a right hepatectomy due to trauma in August 2012, reports a history of abdominal pain and vomiting in May 2012. The patient also underwent a laparotomy in November 2012 to repair a right diaphragmatic hernia and strangulation of the ileus of the small intestine, which was repaired with an ileus tube. O: Physical examination revealed normal labs including complete blood count, erythrocyte sedimentation rate, and biochemical tests. Chest and abdominal radiographs revealed colon gas in the right intrathoracic space. Contrast imaging confirmed incarceration of the ileus tube in the transverse colon. CT of the chest and abdomen showed the transverse colon and small intestine anastomosis adherent to the right hemidiaphragm. A: The primary diagnosis is a diaphragmatic hernia with associated intestinal obstruction. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of abdominal pain and vomiting, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The management plan includes surgical repair of the diaphragmatic hernia using laparoscopic ports in the left half-lateral decubitus position. The surgical procedure will involve careful separation of the transverse colon and small intestine anastomosis from the right hemidiaphragm. Post-operative care will include monitoring for any complications or complications from the surgery. The patient will be educated on the procedure and expected outcomes, and a follow-up appointment will be scheduled to monitor recovery and manage any complications.

S: The patient, previously diagnosed with infectious cervical tuberculosis on C1, underwent posterior C1-2 screw-plate fixation surgery.
