The patient has a history of severe dysphagia and malnutrition, with a BMI of 19. Neurological examination revealed left dominant proximal arm muscle weakness with atrophy, dysesthesia in distal fingers, and hyperreflexia with bilateral extensor plantar reflex. Routine blood work showed slightly elevated CRP. Chest X-ray showed no specific abnormalities. lateral cervical X-ray showed an O-C2 angle of 17-degree kyphosis. CT and MRI showed a space-occupying lesion in the retropharyngeal space with heterogeneous signals on both T1- and T2-weighted images. MRI showed a space-occupying lesion in the retropharyngeal space, with heterogeneous signals on both T1- and T2-weighted images. A: The primary diagnosis is severe dysphagia and malnutrition, complicated by retropharyngeal space kyphosis, with complications including severe dysphagia, malnutrition, and neck pain. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of dysphagia and malnutrition, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: Continue monitoring the patient's condition with regular follow-ups to assess the progression of the lesion and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Educate the patient on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and adherence to the medication regimen. Encourage the patient to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately.

S: The patient, referred for a 5-month history of lower back pain, reports a history of cervical laminoplasty for ossification of the posterior longitudinal ligament and diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis 19 years ago. The patient has a history of hypertension, diabetes, and no history of BCG vaccination. The patient has undergone transurethral resection of a bladder tumor and intravesical mitomycin C for bladder cancer 1.5 years ago, TUR-Bt for bladder cancer, and intravesical MMC for recurrence of bladder cancer. Post-treatment with intravesical BCG therapy, the patient experienced systemic weakness, loss of appetite, and septic shock. The patient was diagnosed with hypercytokinemia caused by BCG therapy, which showed clinical improvement without antituberculosis drugs. O: Current vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows vertebral tenderness at the L2/3 level. Laboratory analysis shows a white blood cell count of 6300 /L, erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 53 mm/h, and a high C-reactive protein level of 2.7 mg/dL. No other abnormal lab findings related to anemic changes, kidney function, or liver function. A: The primary diagnosis is L2/3 spondylitis, likely secondary to BCG therapy, given the patient's history of bladder cancer and recent recurrence of bladder cancer. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of lower back pain, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and laboratory findings. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and management of the patient's chronic conditions. P: The management plan will include a referral to a neurologist for further evaluation and management of the patient's chronic conditions. The patient will be monitored in the ICU for any signs of recurrence or complications from BCG therapy. Regular follow-ups will be scheduled to assess treatment efficacy and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Patient education regarding the nature of the disease, treatment expectations, and potential complications will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: 49-year-old male presents with neck pain from a foreign object accidentally struck by a nail gun on a construction site. He reports difficulty swallowing and is neurologically intact. O: Initial evaluation shows no Horner's syndrome, active bleeding, or hemodynamic instability. CT angiography of the neck shows the nail traversing close to the left internal carotid artery near the skull base, preserved blood flow proximal and distal to the nail, and significant vessel narrowing at the level of the nail. Three-dimensional (3D) rotational angiography indicates small areas of contrast stagnation proximal and distal to the nail and a small dissection flap proximal to the nail, consistent with at least a partial vessel injury. Intracranial left anterior circulation image normalized without abnormal vessel dropout. A: The primary diagnosis is a partial vessel injury in the left internal carotid artery, likely secondary to a nail gun accident. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of neck pain and vascular injury, but imaging and clinical findings support the primary diagnosis. P: The patient will be managed with trauma surgery, oral and maxillofacial surgery, and neurointervention. The plan includes a discussion between trauma surgery, oral and maxillofacial surgery, and neurointervention to determine the best course of action to repair the injury and remove the nail. The patient will be educated on the importance of follow-up and recovery, and will be monitored closely for any complications.

S: The patient, a young adult, presents with a 3-day history of a throbbing headache in the left frontal area, moderate in severity but severe, affecting sleep. The patient denies any history of migraines, similar headaches, fever, photophobia, changes in behavior or personality, abnormal movements, loss of consciousness, weakness, loss of sensation, posture abnormalities, diplopia, vision loss, or difficulty swallowing. The patient has a positive family history of stroke at a young age. O: Physical examination reveals the patient to be tired, hypoactive, and in mild pain distress. Vital signs are within normal limits: temperature 37 °C, blood pressure 117/68 mm Hg, pulse rate 71 bpm, respiratory rate 18/min, and oxygen saturation 99% in room air. No neck rigidity or proptosis was noted. Glasgow Coma Scale is 15/15 with no focal neurological deficits and normal reflexes. A: The primary diagnosis is a throbbing headache in the left frontal area, likely triggered by a traumatic event, given the patient's history of venous thromboembolism and family history of stroke. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of headaches, but the Glasgow Coma Scale is 15/15 with no focal neurological deficits. P: The management plan includes referral to a neurologist for further evaluation of the throbbing headache. The patient is advised to monitor symptoms closely and return to the emergency department if symptoms worsen or new symptoms arise. Further diagnostic tests may be necessary to clarify the cause of the headache. The patient is advised to monitor symptoms and return to the emergency department if symptoms worsen or new symptoms arise.

S: The patient is a 40-year-old woman, gravida 2, and parity 1, referred at 23 weeks and 2 days of gestation due to placenta previa and severe FGR. She reports a history of normal vaginal delivery with manual removal of the placenta. She denies taking aspirin or other anticoagulants. O: Recent ultrasound showed no fetal anomaly, but the estimated fetal body weight (EFBW) was 258 g (-3.7 SD). Placenta previa and enlargement of the placenta (8  9  7 cm) were confirmed. Umbilical cord insertion was normal. Blood tests showed Hb (12.4 g/dL), platelet count (99,000/L), APTT 27 seconds (24.5-38.7 seconds), PT-INR (0.88 (0.90-1.10), and D-dimer levels (0.9 g/L 1.0 g/L). Pelvic MRI at 24 weeks and 3 days showed internal heterogeneity and enlargement, placenta previa, and a fluid-fluid level on the fetal side of the placenta with no blood flow. Recent ultrasound at 24 weeks and 4 days of gestation confirmed an MSH in a clear fluid-fluid level measuring 2.8  7. A: The primary diagnosis is idiopathic placentomegaly with severe FGR. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of placenta previa and enlargement, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition and development of the fetus. The patient is advised to attend all follow-up appointments and report any changes in symptoms. Further consultations with a nephrologist and a pulmonologist are recommended to manage her condition and prevent complications.

S: The patient reports several broken teeth and a lost permanent tooth. The patient has a history of an accidental fall from a tractor ten days ago, resulting in a chin injury. The patient denies any significant medical history. O: Intraoral examination revealed uncomplicated crown fractures in tooth numbers 15, 16, 25, 26, 35, 36, and 45, and clinically missing tooth number 34. Panoramic radiograph confirmed the avulsion of tooth number 34 and no evidence of fracture involving the maxilla or mandible. A functional space maintainer (band and loop with an acrylic pontic of tooth number 34) was used for temporary prosthesis and space maintainer. Tooth 35 was severely damaged on the lingual aspect. A: The primary diagnosis is uncomplicated crown fractures in tooth numbers 15, 25, 35, 36, and 45, with complications including avulsion of tooth number 34, and a complicated crown fracture in tooth 46. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of tooth loss, but these are less likely given the radiograph results. P: The treatment plan includes restoration of tooth numbers 15, 25, 35, and 45 with composite restorations, root canal treatment (RCT) in tooth 46, and restoration of stainless steel crowns in tooth 46. The functional space maintainer will be used for temporary prosthesis and space maintainer, with extensive tooth loss on the lingual aspect. The patient will be educated on the procedure and expected outcomes, and scheduled appointments will be scheduled to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient, a non-drinker and ex-smoker, reports feeling unwell and has a history of liver cirrhosis secondary to Hepatitis B infection diagnosed in April 2017. The patient has a history of smoking seven years ago and has a history of non-drinking and non-drinking. The patient was diagnosed with liver cirrhosis secondary to Hepatitis B infection in April 2017. O: The patient's upper endoscopy revealed hypertensive gastropathy and Grade II-III esophageal varices, banded uneventfully. Colonoscopy indicated colonic edema indicative of portal hypertension. Triphasic CT scan showed irregular nodular contour of the liver with left lobe hypertrophy, cirrhosis, splenic and gastric cardia varices, splenorenal shunt, and severe ascites. The gallbladder was also distended without biliary or duodenal/pyloric obstruction. A repeat CT scan in August 2017 showed a grossly dilated gallbladder and mildly prominent proximal small bowel loops with increased wall enhancement. MRCP in November 2017 showed a markedly distended, thin-walled gallbladder with a 1 cm gallstone lodged in the proximal cystic duct. A: The primary diagnosis is liver cirrhosis secondary to Hepatitis B infection, likely secondary to portal hypertension. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of liver dysfunction, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. The prognosis depends on the management of the gallbladder and the management of portal hypertension. P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition with regular follow-up appointments. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms immediately. Further treatment options may be considered based on the progression of the gallbladder's condition and response to treatment. The patient is encouraged to report any new symptoms immediately.

S: The mother reports persistent pain in the nipple throughout the entire breastfeeding session, accompanied by each episode of breastfeeding. The mother has a history of a tooth on the lower left gum and an ulcer under the tongue, which sometimes bleeds. The mother has been reluctant to continue breastfeeding, relying on infant formula milk instead. O: Physical examination reveals normal breast with no inflammation or engorgement, mild eczema around the nipple, and no infection. Cervical and axillary lymph nodes are not palpable. Oral cavity examination reveals a neonatal tooth over the left anterior region of the mandibular ridge, measuring 2 mm  1 mm, whitish opaque, Grade II mobility, and a whitish ulcer over the ventral aspect of the tongue measuring 1 mm  1 mm. A: The primary diagnosis is a neonatal tooth associated with Riga-Fede disease, causing difficulty in breastfeeding. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of nipple pain, but these are less likely given the examination results. P: The management plan includes referral to the pediatric dental surgery department for the extraction of the neonatal tooth under local anesthesia. Post-extraction, the baby will be able to resume breastfeeding successfully. Post-extraction, the wound will heal well within 2 days, and the wound will be able to resume breastfeeding successfully. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the healing of the wound and manage any complications.

S: The patient is a 72-year-old male with a history of moderately differentiated intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma diagnosed in October 2015, initially diagnosed with moderate weight loss, pain in the right hypochondrium, loss of appetite, and asthenia. He reports a history of chemotherapy, including Gemcitabine, Capecitabine, and Cisplatin, which was not effective. He has undergone four courses of chemotherapy, including Gemcitabine, Capecitabine, and Cisplatin, which was not effective. O: Initial Karnofsky scale index was 70%. MRI revealed increased tumor size, metastatic nodules in both the left and right lobes, spread to the bile duct, holedoch, and gallbladder, and increased serum gamma glutamyltranspeptidase (GGT) levels. Karnofsky scale index decreased to 60%. Advanced molecular analysis of the tumor was performed, revealing gene expression profiles in a formalin-fixed, paraffin-embedded (FFPE) biopsy sample, total RNA extracted using Ambion's RecoverAllTM Total Nucleic Acid Isolation, and complete Whole Transcriptome Amplification WTA2 Kit (Sigma) for reverse transcription and library amplification. Hybridization was conducted according to the CustomArray ElectraSenseTM Hybridization and Detection protocol. A: The primary diagnosis is moderately differentiated intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma with metastatic nodules and metastatic metastases. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of cholangiocarcinoma, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The management plan includes switching to TKI inhibitors to address GGT levels. The patient will be educated on the importance of adherence to the treatment regimen and the potential side effects of TKI inhibitors. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor treatment efficacy and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Patient education on the importance of adherence to the treatment regimen and follow-up appointments will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient reports worsening back pain for a week, tingling, numbness in lower limbs, and difficulty walking. The patient also mentions decreased sensation on the upper back. O: Physical examination revealed moderate muscle weakness in the lower limbs and superficial hypesthesia, a decreased sensitivity to touch below the T5 level, and a dorsal cord disorder. Laboratory tests and plain radiography showed no abnormalities. MRI revealed a dorsally located epidural lesion between the Th5 and Th8 vertebrae, a heterogeneous mass isointense on T1-weighted imaging and slightly hyperintense on T2-weighted imaging. The lesion is likely an epidural hematoma. Postoperative complications include intraoperative blood loss of up to 2000 mL, with potential adhesions between tumors and dura. Pathology confirmed nonfiltrating spinal angiolipoma. A: The primary diagnosis is nonfiltrating spinal angiolipoma of the Th5 and Th8 vertebrae. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of thoracic myelopathy, but these are less likely given the imaging and pathology results. P: The management plan includes an emergent surgical excision of the epidural lesion. The surgery will involve a Th5-8 laminectomy to access the posterior epidural space and a small mass of epidural fat at both the upper and lower ends of the lesion. Postoperative complications include intraoperative blood loss of up to 2000 mL, with electrocoagulation for hemostasis, and swollen compressive dura matter. Postoperative follow-up examinations will be scheduled to monitor the patient's progress and detect any recurrence within 1 year. The patient will be educated on the procedure and expected outcomes to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient reports experiencing unusual pain in the left carotid area for the past 24 hours, radiating to the ear. O: Colour Doppler ultrasound revealed an eccentric hypoechoic thickening in the proximal bulbar internal carotid area and partially in the carotid bifurcation, with a thin hyperechoic atheromatous fibrous plaque. Contrast-enhanced ultrasound showed normal capillary distribution of microbubbles in the hypoechoic thickening and avascular fibrous plaque. Unenhanced Axial T1-weighted MR imaging showed a hypointense tissue around the proximal internal carotid and intense enhancement of this tissue on fat-saturated contrast-enhanced T1-weighted images. A: The primary diagnosis is Carotidynia or TIPIC syndrome, characterized by hypointense tissue around the proximal internal carotid and intense enhancement of the perivascular inflammatory sheath. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of carotidynia and TIPIC syndrome, but these are less likely given the imaging results and imaging results. P: The treatment plan includes treatment with non-steroid anti-inflammatory drugs to manage inflammation and pain. A follow-up Doppler ultrasound after 14 days is scheduled to monitor the progress of the treatment. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately.

S: The patient, a male with a history of severe depression, reported feeling down and having thoughts of suicide for the past 4 weeks. He also experienced epileptic seizures after 7 days of treatment. O: Initial treatment with sertraline and olanzapine was ineffective, leading to worsening symptoms including slower thinking and epileptic seizures. CSF pressure was 240 cmH2O, leukocyte count was 10  106/L, and anti-NMDAR antibodies were found in CSF and serum at 1:32. EEG showed epileptic activity with sharp-slow waves in the right anterior frontotemporal region. B-ultrasound and CT scan of the chest and abdomen were performed to exclude tumors. Treatment included intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG, 25 g/day, 5 days), methylprednisolone (1,000 mg, 3 days + 500 mg, 3 days), prednisolone (0–60 mg, 12 weeks), levetiracetam (1,500 mg, bid) and valproic acid (500 mg, bid). Symptoms included severe heart and respiratory failure, persistent psychiatric symptoms, aggressive behaviors on olanzapine, muscle stiffness, and slurred speech. Clonazepam (2 mg, bid), midazolam (2–4 mg/h, 45 days), and midazolam (2–4 mg/h, 45 days). A: The primary diagnosis is severe depression with complications including severe heart and respiratory failure, severe psychiatric symptoms, and persistent psychiatric symptoms including visual hallucination, auditory hallucination, and delusion. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of psychiatric symptoms, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: Initiated treatment with intravenous immunoglobulin (25 g/day, 5 days), methylprednisolone (1,000 mg, 3 days + 500 mg, 3 days), prednisolone (0–60 mg, 12 weeks), levetiracetam (1,500 mg, bid), and valproic acid (500 mg, bid). Treatment included levetiracetam (1,500 mg, bid) and valproic acid.

S: The patient, with a history of monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS) treated for prostate cancer with external beam radiation therapy, reports experiencing weakness and tiredness and enlarged right testicle. O: Clinical examination revealed hypercalcaemia. CT scan of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis showed a large right-sided scrotal mass with soft tissue extending through the inguinal canal and along the right gonadal vein, with bilateral lung nodules measuring up to 14mm. Ultrasound revealed a heterogeneous mass replacing the right testicle with mass-like soft tissue infiltration of the right epididymis and spermatic cord, with increased Doppler vascularity. Ultrasound-guided biopsy confirmed diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, germinal centre subtype. A: The primary diagnosis is diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, germinal centre subtype, with differential diagnoses including sarcoma or lymphoma. The prognosis is favorable with a complete radiological response to chemotherapy. P: The patient underwent chemotherapy for diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, germinal centre subtype. Post-chemotherapy, the patient was referred to haematology for further management. Regular follow-ups are scheduled to monitor the patient's response to treatment and detect any recurrence. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately.

S: The patient, admitted to the emergency department with a 12-hour history of abdominal pain, distension, and bilious vomiting, reported no similar attacks before. O: Physical examination revealed dehydration and afebrileness with a pulse of 98 per minute and blood pressure of 130/80 mmHg. The abdomen was distended and tympanic on percussion, with tinkling bowel sounds. Abdominal X-ray confirmed multiple fluid levels without free air. Abdominal and pelvic CT scans showed a small bowel obstruction (SBO) with a transitional zone in the right lower abdomen and a saclike mass of clustered dilated bowel loops compressing the anterolateral wall of the bladder. Radiological findings confirmed an internal hernia. A laparoscopic approach was performed, using a three trocars technique (12mm trocar at the navel and two 5mm trocars at bilateral abdominal flank) to confirm the diagnosis of an obstructive supravesical hernia involving the terminal ileum. The incarcerated intestine was viable, and the hernia's ring was closed with a 2/0 Polydioxanone (PDS) running suture. A: The primary diagnosis is an internal hernia with a transitional zone in the right lower abdomen and a saclike mass compressing the anterolateral wall of the bladder. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of abdominal pain and bilious vomiting, but these are less likely given the imaging and surgical findings. P: The patient underwent a laparoscopic approach to repair the hernia. Post-operative management included monitoring for complications and ensuring informed consent. The patient was discharged on the fourth post-operative day and was discharged on the fourth post-operative day. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor recovery and manage any complications.

S: The patient is a 52-year-old male with a BMI of 37.7, asymptomatic and nonsmoker, with no comorbidities but class II obesity. He reports no unusual symptoms related to the nodule. O: The patient's high-resolution chest CT scan revealed a 1.5 cm mixed ground glass opacity with a larger solid component in the right middle lobe (RML). The nodule increased in size at the follow-up CT scan. General anesthesia was administered with double lumen endotracheal intubation and lateral decubitus at dorsal decubitus 40 degrees. A 5 cm oblique incision was made parallel to the costal arch, and subcutaneous tissue and rectus abdominis were dissected along the subcostal margin. A subcostal tunnel was bluntly dissected using a finger until the mediastinal pleura was opened at the cardiophrenic angle. A covidien wound protector was placed. A thoracoscopic lens with a 30° angle was used to examine the interlobar fissure. A lobectomy was performed using VATS instruments, curved tip stapler technology, and a 28 F chest tube was inserted through the subcostal wound. Routine venous thromboembolism prophylaxis (6000 i.u UFH) was administered 12 hours post-operatively. A: The primary diagnosis is a lobectomy of the right middle lobe with a larger solid component in the right middle lobe. The patient's BMI is 37.7. The successful lobectomy and successful venous thromboembolism prophylaxis are essential for recovery. P: The patient underwent a successful lobectomy and systemic mediastinal lymph nodes dissection. Post-operative care includes regular monitoring of recovery and follow-up appointments to assess recovery and manage any complications. The patient is advised to maintain a healthy lifestyle and maintain regular follow-up appointments.

S: The patient reports that vision in the left eye is not as clear as the one in the right eye. The patient has noticed changes in vision in the left eye. O: Visual acuity is 20/20 in the right eye but 20/25 in the left eye. Intraocular pressure is normal in both eyes. Closer examination revealed a circumscribed lesion measuring 0.6 mm in horizontal basal diameter and 0.5 mm in vertical basal diameter, with a dilated feeding retinal arteriole, splitting the mass into a bi-lobulated "butterfly" appearance. Near-infrared reflectance imaging showed intrinsic hyperreflectivity, short-wavelength autofluorescence, and red-free filter photography showed a blocked signal by the lesion. Fluorescein angiography (FA) showed mild ring-shaped fluorescence in the arteriovenous phase without leakage into the late phase. Indocyanine green angiography showed weak cyanescence on the superior boundary. A: The primary diagnosis is CSHRPE, a benign retinal lesion in the left eye. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of retinal lesions, but these are less likely given the imaging findings and imaging results. P: The management plan includes regular monitoring of the eye during routine evaluations. The patient is advised to report any changes in vision or concerns immediately. Further education on the nature of the condition and the importance of regular follow-up is crucial.

S: The patient reports persistent left-side chest pain for 2 months and hemoptysis for 1 month. The patient denies any medical comorbidities or familial history of malignancies. The patient is a nonsmoker but occasional drinker. O: Physical examination revealed two metabolically active soft tissue masses in the left suprahilar region and the left lower lobe, with enlarged prevascular and left hilar lymph nodes, a metastatic lesion in the left fourth rib, and moderate left pleural effusion. Biopsy from the lung mass indicated adenocarcinoma positive for ALK gene rearrangement and negative for epidermal growth factor receptor gene mutation. Pleural fluid cytology confirmed metastatic adenocarcinoma. Baseline hemogram, liver function tests, and kidney function tests were within normal limits. PET/CT imaging showed a partial response to palliative radiotherapy 20 Gy in five fractions over 5 days, with a reduction in the size of the primary tumor and pleural effusion, with a reduction in fluorodeoxyglucose uptake. A: The primary diagnosis is advanced NSCLC, stage IV, with a differential diagnosis of other forms of lung cancer. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the partial response to treatment and the absence of significant adverse effects. P: The patient was started on palliative radiotherapy 20 Gy in five fractions over 5 days, with a dose of crizotinib 250 mg twice daily and a liver function test once per week for monitoring liver toxicity. The patient is advised to return to the emergency department for further evaluation and management. Further evaluation and management of the patient's symptoms are necessary, and the patient is encouraged to report any new symptoms immediately.

S: The patient reports experiencing a fever of 38°C, weakness, lumbar pain, and small red spots on the skin. The patient has a history of Neisseria meningitidis infection. O: Blood cultures confirmed septic shock secondary to Neisseria meningitidis infection. Initial antibiotic therapy with meropenem and amikacin was discontinued. Blood cultures confirmed septic shock secondary to Neisseria meningitidis infection. The patient's PCT was elevated at 121.7 ng/ml. The patient's condition worsened, with severe bleeding from catheter insertion points, severe hypotension, and increased norepinephrine up to 0.75 g/kg/min. Oligoanuria was also noted, necessitating hemofiltration. Cytosorb treatments have shown hemodynamic improvement with norepinephrine and epinephrine tapering off after the third session. Lactate values and inflammation stabilized, with PCT decreasing to 16.52 ng/ml. Disseminated intravascular coagulopathy improved, and skin necrosis areas were demarcating. A: The primary diagnosis is septic shock secondary to Neisseria meningitidis infection. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of septic shock, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and laboratory results. P: The patient was transferred to the ICU for further evaluation and management of septic shock. He was started on empirical antibiotic therapy with meropenem and amikacin. He was started on norepinephrine infusion and epinephrine infusion. He has shown significant improvement in hemodynamic status with tapering off norepinephrine and epinephrine over 72 hours, with lactate values stabilizing to 16.52 ng/ml. The patient is expected to be extubated in about 10 days. Regular follow-ups will be scheduled to monitor recovery and manage any complications.

S: The patient is a 34-year-old primigravida, referred for suspicion of chorioangioma of the placenta or a placental teratoma. She reports no known comorbidities but has a history of pregnancy-induced hypertension. She was previously diagnosed with pregnancy-induced hypertension and was unaware of any family history of congenital anomalies or twin pregnancies. O: Ultrasonography revealed a single intrauterine fetus at 27 weeks and two days gestation, normal interval growth, and a multiloculated cystic mass with septations and calcifications, lacked vascularity. Color Doppler examination showed no vascularity. The mass was 104 x 53 mm and appeared from the anterior wall of the uterus. Repeat scans in the third trimester showed the same findings. At 36 weeks and five days of gestation, a second congenitally malformed fetus was delivered, with no cephalic end structures. A single placenta measuring 515 grams was delivered, with two umbilical cords. Histopathological examination of the placenta revealed placental discs measuring up to 19.5 x 14 x 4 cm, placental membrane measuring 30 x 16 cm, and gross malformation with the absence of the head and upper limbs but partially formed lower limbs. The heel to rump length was 18. A: The primary diagnosis is placental teratoma, complicated by a second congenitally malformed fetus with no cephalic end structures. Differential diagnoses considered included placental teratoma, chorioangioma, hemorrhagic placental degeneration, or degenerating fibroid. The patient's history of pregnancy-induced hypertension and the presence of a second congenitally malformed fetus complicate the diagnosis. P: The patient was discharged in a stable condition on the sixth day of admission. The patient is advised to report any further concerns or questions immediately. Further consultations with a nephrologist and a nephrologist are recommended to manage her condition and manage her hypertension.

S: The patient is a 32-year-old multiparous woman presenting for induction of labor due to abnormal antenatal testing. She reports a previous cesarean delivery at 7 cm dilation, which stopped at 7 cm dilation. She has a history of a previous cesarean delivery, which was postponed due to abnormal antenatal testing. O: Initial cervical exam showed 2 cm dilation and 50% effacement. Initial labor with oxytocin was performed, followed by an amniotomy at 5 cm dilation with clear fluid. The patient's progression from 2 cm to 5 cm was approximately 10 hours, followed by 3.5 hours to 6 cm. The patient delivered a male infant with a weight of 2659 g and Apgar scores of 9 at 1 minute and 9 at 5 minutes, respectively. The arterial cord pH was 7.26. Post-delivery, the patient's bladder was distended and edematous, despite the presence of a patent Foley catheter. A vaginal exam revealed spontaneous detachment of the anterior rim of the cervix from approximately 9 to 3 o'clock, necrotic, and no bleeding at the site of cervical detachment. The entire cervix was completely detached during the cesarean delivery. A: The primary diagnosis is spontaneous detachment of the anterior rim of the cervix, complicated by a spontaneous detachment of the cervix. Differential diagnoses could include uterine rupture or placental abruption, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The patient underwent a repeat cesarean delivery with no uterine rupture or dehiscence. Post-delivery, the patient will continue to be closely monitored during recovery. She will continue to be monitored for signs of uterine rupture or placental abruption, and she will be educated on signs of potential complications such as uterine rupture or placental abruption. Regular follow-ups will be scheduled to monitor her condition and manage any complications.

S: The patient reports multiple cords in the eye following phacoemulsification and intraocular lens (IOL) implantation yesterday. The patient denies any pain or discomfort. The patient has a history of diabetes, glaucoma, uveitis, trauma, and other intraocular surgeries. The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation, Raynaud's syndrome, and B-cell CLL treated with rituximab, chlorambucil, and ibrutinib for 6 months before cataract extraction. O: Visual presentation at presentation was 20/100, and intraocular pressure was 43 mmHg. No hypopyon, hyphema, significant corneal edema, or cellular reaction were noted. Dilated fundus examination was unremarkable. The patient's previous eye had 2-3+ nuclear sclerosis without pseudoexfoliation or phacodonesis. Preoperative findings included 2-3+ nuclear sclerosis without pseudoexfoliation or phacodonesis. Retrobulbar block of 2% lidocaine and 0.75% Marcaine was administered, and dexamethasone and cefazolin were applied to the ocular surface. A: The primary diagnosis is fibrinoid syndrome, likely secondary to IOL implantation. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of ocular cords, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation. P: Initiate topical prednisolone every 2-3 hours, brimonidine three times per day, timolol-dorzolamide two times per day, and oral acetazolamide. Monitor the patient's vision and intraocular pressure closely. Schedule follow-up appointments to assess the effectiveness of the treatment and adjust as necessary. Educate the patient on signs of worsening symptoms and encourage immediate reporting of any new symptoms.

S: The patient reports experiencing numbness and weakness in the right leg, which was initially diagnosed as a metastatic tumor. However, symptoms worsened, leading to dizziness and nausea. The patient has a history of hypertension, hyperthyroidism, mammary gland hyperplasia, and no history of diabetes, heart disease, hepatitis, tuberculosis, or drug allergy. O: Physical examination revealed decreased calculation capacity, instability, and decreased fibroproteinogen levels. Laboratory findings showed leukocytes at 13.52  109/L, glucose at 2.93 mmol/L, sodium at 124 mmol/L, chlorine at 87 mmol/L, and fibroproteinogen at 1.62 g/L. CSF examination showed cerebrospinal fluid with a yellow and clear appearance, CSF cells at 514/l, leukocytes at 14/l, high CSF protein at 82.54 mg/dl, increased 24-h IgG intrathecal synthesis rate at 13.54, negative IgG oligoclonal band, cytokine interleukinin-10 at 641.00 pg/ml, positive cytomegalovirus IgG, negative neuronal antigen spectrum antibody IgG, and female tumor markers. Autoimmune antibody tests and protein electrophoresis were conducted. A: The primary diagnosis is concentric sclerosis with complications including numbness and weakness in the right leg. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of numbness and weakness, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and laboratory findings. P: Continue monitoring the patient's condition closely with regular follow-ups to assess treatment efficacy and response to treatment. Educate the patient on signs of worsening symptoms and encourage immediate reporting of any new symptoms. Consider referral to a neurologist for further evaluation and management of concentric sclerosis. Encourage the patient to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately.

S: The patient reports a disseminated vesicular rash on the trunk and extremities, with around 40 to 50 lesions, which resolved within 10 days. The patient has a history of Splenomegaly, a sequela of infectious mononucleosis, and recurrent mild upper respiratory infections. The patient has a history of Splenomegaly diagnosed at age 5 and has a history of recurrent mild upper respiratory infections. O: Physical examination revealed persistent leucopenia, selective IgA deficiency, and CD4 lymphopenia (111-118 cells/L). Imaging confirmed splenomegaly with a 17 cm cranio-caudal length, modest mesenteric and retroperitoneal adenopathy. Flow cytometric analysis of T-cell subpopulations confirmed CD4 lymphopenia with CD4 at 189 cells/L, normal CD8 T cells (383 cells/L), and increased proportion and absolute number of CD3+TCR+CD4CD8 double negative T cells (DNT) at 4.3% or 33 cells/L. High proportion of cycling of CD4 T-cells and DNT (Ki67 12% and 42%, respectively) and increased PD-1 expression in CD4 T-cells (42%). Total IgG levels were moderately elevated at 1,716 mg/dL, and IgM levels were normal at 54 mg/dL. A: The primary diagnosis is Idiopathic CD4 lymphopenia (ICL), based on imaging and clinical findings. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of vesicular rash, but these are less likely given the imaging results and clinical presentation. P: The patient will continue to be monitored for any signs of infection or complications from the varicella zoster virus vaccine strain disseminated infection. Regular follow-ups will be scheduled to monitor the patient's condition and adjust treatment as necessary. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately.

S: The patient, a 5-year-old girl, presented with sudden loss of consciousness, abdominal pain, urge to cry, pallor, cyanosis, loss of muscle tone, and ocular revulsion. The parent reports frequent abdominal pain, short episodes of absence, frequent cough, and a reduction in exercise tolerance. O: Physical examination revealed a systolic regurgitant murmur. Lab tests showed slight metabolic acidosis, elevated Troponin T at 65 ng/l, liver transaminases with ASAT at 82U/l and ALAT at 48U/l, and elevated NT-Pro-BNP at 1,024 ng/l. ECG indicated an incomplete right bundle branch block, right ventricular hypertrophy, slight enlargement of the right ventricle and right atrium, and tricuspid regurgitation, leading to elevated systolic right ventricular pressure of more than 45 mmHg and pulmonary artery dilatation. Follow-up Echocardiography confirmed dilatation of the right cardiac cavities and tricuspid regurgitation III. A: The primary diagnosis is severe seizure equivalent with secondary pulmonary hypertension and myocardial cell damage due to hypoxemia and acidosis. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of seizure symptoms, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: Initiated treatment with valproic acid to address seizures. Follow-up Echocardiography confirmed dilatation of the right cardiac cavities and tricuspid regurgitation III. Continued monitoring and adjustment of treatment as necessary are recommended. The patient is advised to maintain close communication with the healthcare team and return for regular check-ups.

S: The patient, with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, prior stress cardiomyopathy with normal coronaries on left heart catheterization, and hypertension, was found down by a neighbor and brought to the emergency department. The patient reported feeling unwell and was found by a neighbor. O: Initial EKG showed sinus tachycardia with a heart rate of 104 bpm, premature atrial complexes, biatrial enlargement, right axis deviation, prolonged QT interval, and atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular rate and a heart rate of 147 bpm. Second electrocardiogram showed atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular rate and a heart rate of 147 bpm, and prolonged QT. Troponin I was elevated at 9 ng/ml on admission. Transthoracic echocardiogram showed a left ventricular ejection fraction of 55% and a left ventricle apical thrombus measuring 0.95 x 0.7 cm, with regional wall motion abnormalities including hypokinetic to akinetic basal myocardial segments, an akinetic apex, and hyperdynamic midventricular segments. A: The primary diagnosis is reverse midvariant takotsubo cardiomyopathy, evidenced by elevated troponin I levels and regional wall motion abnormalities. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of takotsubo cardiomyopathy, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation. P: The patient was admitted to the medical intensive care unit for further monitoring and treatment. The treatment plan included IV 5 mg metoprolol and amiodarone bolus, followed by a heparin drip. A transthoracic echocardiogram showed a left ventricular ejection fraction of 55% and a left ventricle apical thrombus measuring 0.95 x 0.7 cm, with regional wall motion abnormalities including hypokinetic to akinetic basal myocardial segments, an akinetic apex, and hyperdynamic midventricular segments. The patient was discharged with prescribed aspirin, atorvastatin, metoprolol, and apixaban. A: The primary diagnosis is reverse mid

S: The patient is a 77-year-old male with a history of NHL/SLL diagnosed almost 10 years ago. He presents with abdominal swelling, altered mental status, and difficulty urinating with blood in it. He denies recalling all the details of his oncologic history and treatment regimens. O: Physical examination revealed diffuse bulky lymphadenopathy in the cervical, axillary, and inguinal areas. Laboratory tests showed hypokalemia, hypophosphatemia, and elevated lactate dehydrogenase levels. CT scan on the head showed negative findings for acute events. Repeat CT scans showed diffuse bulky lymphadenopathy in the abdomen, bilateral iliac, inguinal, and retroperitoneal lymphadenopathy, and diffuse lymphadenopathy in the axillary and cervical regions. Bone marrow biopsy indicated a CD5 and CD23 positive B-cell population (37% of the lymphoid gate), lambda-restricted, immunophenotypic expression of CLL/SLL with lambda light chain restriction, and a kappa light chain restricted population of monoclonal plasma cells co-expressed with CD56. Urinary complaints of difficulty voiding and hematuria were noted. A: The primary diagnosis is NHL/SLL with differential diagnoses including toxic and metabolic encephalopathy. The patient's history of NHL/SLL and recent treatment discontinuation suggest a potential recurrence of the disease. P: The management plan includes a follow-up appointment with the oncologist to discuss the treatment options and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. The patient is advised to monitor symptoms and report any new symptoms immediately. Further consultations with urology and urology are planned to manage the patient's urinary issues.

S: The patient, a known case of renal cancer treated 5 years ago, presented for a laryngeal cancer screening. He reported no symptoms related to the tumor. O: The tumor was discovered at the posterior end of the nasal septal mucosa. Imaging analyses and a regional biopsy were performed under local anesthesia. Pathological findings resembled an inverted ductal papilloma of the salivary glands. MRI showed a 10 mm mass in the vault of the nasopharynx at the junction of the nasal septum and roof. positron emission tomography scan showed no abnormal uptake of 18F-fludeoxyglucose in the nasopharynx, thyroid gland, or other bodies. Surgery under general anesthesia was performed using an endoscopic endonasal approach. Hematoxylin-eosin staining showed a papillary structure lined by a columnar epithelium with a hyalinized fibrous core, and sheets of spindle cells. A: The primary diagnosis is an inverted ductal papilloma of the salivary glands, with a negative tumor margin. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of nasal tumors, but these are less likely given the imaging and biopsy results. P: The patient underwent surgical excision of the tumor with an endoscopic endonasal approach, using an electrocautery needle, suction curette, and suction probe. Post-operative care includes regular check-ups to monitor recovery and ensure no recurrence of the tumor. The patient is advised to reach out with any concerns or questions during recovery.

S: The patient is an 80-year-old male presenting with bilateral posterior uveitis and CME, which started 5 months after starting nivolumab for metastatic cancer treatment. He reports a best corrected visual acuity (BCVA) of 20/70 in the right eye and 20/40 in the left eye. He was started on oral prednisone, topical difluprednate (Durezol), and nepafenac, which resolved the CME and improved vision to 20/30 in both eyes. However, he developed foveal thinning and a full-thickness macular hole (FTMH), which reduced his BCVA to 20/60 in the left eye. He underwent macular hole surgery (MHS) but was canceled due to a closed macular hole with residual subretinal fluid. OCT showed a closed macular hole with residual subretinal fluid. The macular hole reopened three months later, and his vision improved to 20/80 in the left eye. A: The primary diagnosis is bilateral posterior uveitis with CME. The patient's condition has remained stable with a BCVA of 20/70. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of uveitis and CME, but these are less likely given the history and imaging results. P: Continue monitoring the patient's condition closely with regular follow-ups with the ophthalmologist. Educate the patient on the importance of reporting any new symptoms or changes in vision. Schedule regular follow-ups with the ophthalmologist to monitor for any changes in vision or new symptoms. Encourage the patient to report any decrease in vision or new symptoms immediately.

S: The patient reports experiencing hemoptysis for the past 30 days, coughing up blood and feeling very weak. The patient has a history of cardiac surgery for aortic coarctation at age 18 without complications post-operatively. O: Physical examination revealed severe anemia with a hemoglobin level of 6.9 g/dl and hemodynamic instability (shock index of 1.4). Chest X-ray showed no significant abnormalities. Digestive endoscopy indicated grade B esophagitis. Fiber bronchoscopy showed limited traces of blood in the bronchial tract afferent to the left upper lobe without signs of active bleeding. Contrast-enhanced CT scan of the chest revealed an aneurysmal dilatation of the descending thoracic aorta communicating with the left upper bronchus, with an upper posterior hemorrhagic leak indicating initial left upper lobe compression and ground-glass opacities with scissural delimitation. A: The primary diagnosis is severe anemia with a hemoglobin level of 6.9 g/dl and hemodynamic instability (shock index of 1.4). Differential diagnoses could include other causes of hemoptysis, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The patient underwent thoracic endovascular aortic repair (TEVAR) for the aortobronchial fistula, which was successfully treated with an endovascular stent-graft. The patient is advised to attend all scheduled appointments and report any new or concerning symptoms immediately. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor recovery and manage any complications.

S: The patient was an 81-year-old Caucasian male with a history of melanoma on the right anterior chest wall, initially treated with wide local excision. Four months post-diagnosis, a recurrence was noted in the right lung, leading to a switch to dabrafenib and trametinib. The patient experienced progressively weakening symptoms starting a month after the second cycle of pembrolizumab. He also experienced a generalized tonic-clonic seizure on Day 14 of hospitalization. O: Neurological examination revealed a strength of 2/5 in the UEs and 0/5 in the LEs, with areflexia and no bulbar muscle weakness. Lumbar puncture indicated albuminocytologic dissociation with elevated CSF protein (56 g/L). Electromyography indicated motor and sensory neuropathy. Infectious workup showed negative CSF cultures and VDRL. Antibodies to ganglioside GM1 for GBS were negative. Initial treatment included methylprednisolone and IVIG for five days, followed by plasmapheresis and a generalized tonic-clonic seizure on Day 14. A CT scan of the brain showed a hemorrhage within one of the metastatic lesions and associated vasogenic edema. A: The primary diagnosis was metastatic melanoma with complications including acute hypoxic respiratory failure, mechanical ventilation, and a generalized tonic-clonic seizure. Differential diagnoses initially included other forms of metastatic brain lesions, but these were ruled out based on imaging and clinical findings. P: The patient was started on methylprednisolone and IVIG for five days, followed by plasmapheresis and plasmapheresis. On Day 14 of hospitalization, he developed acute hypoxic respiratory failure, necessitating mechanical ventilation. On Day 14 of hospitalization, he developed a generalized tonic-clonic seizure, leading to a decision to withdraw care. The family was informed of the patient's condition and the nature of his condition.

S: The patient is a 19-year-old male presenting with a one-day history of left flank pain and dysuria. He reports mild low back pain from a recent car accident, which does not affect daily activities. He has a family history of cervical cancer but no significant family history of cancer. O: Physical examination revealed mild tenderness to palpation on the thoracic and lumbar spine, a slightly more prominent right orbital rim, and a dark skin mark on the right front thigh along the L1-2 distribution. Laboratory tests were negative for bacteriuria and vitamin D deficiency. Complete blood count, comprehensive metabolic panel, and alkaline phosphatase levels were within normal limits. Serum protein electrophoresis was negative for any M protein, and tumor markers like CEA and PSA were negative. Chest, abdominal, and pelvic CT scans with contrast showed additional similar thoracic spinal lesions but no primary tumor lesion. SPECT and whole-body nuclear scans identified ground-glass sclerotic lesions on the maxillofacial region and right calvarium, with increased nuclear signal uptake. A: The primary diagnosis is fibrous dysplasia, a benign disease process, likely secondary to a car accident. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of spinal pain and dysuria, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The management plan includes continued monitoring of the patient's condition and managing symptoms. Regular follow-ups are necessary to monitor for any changes in the condition. The patient is advised to maintain regular check-ups to ensure no significant changes in his condition. Further consultations with oncology and a nephrologist are recommended to manage his condition and prevent further complications.

S: The patient, a female with a history of incarcerated hernia and intra-abdominal hypertension, presented with concerns about her liver condition. She expressed concerns about the potential for surgical intervention, which she refused. She has a history of a double incarcerated hernia treated with open liver resection and a re-laparotomy for lavage due to hemorrhagic liquid causing acute abdominal pain. O: CT-Scan and MRI revealed a more aggressive disease in segments 2 to 8 of the liver, with only a portion of the caudate lobe with visible parenchyma. Physical examination confirmed a palpable mass involving almost all abdominal quadrants. Regular controls showed increasing weight loss, an abnormally low BMI, severe bilateral lower limb varicose veins, and edema due to IVC compression. A few months later, the patient was admitted to the emergency room due to double incarcerated hernia, treated urgently with a left open liver resection and multiple non-anatomic resections and fenestrations. A recent CT-Scan showed a huge hypertrophy of the remanent liver with small-sized remaining cysts. A: The primary diagnosis is remanent liver disease with complications including a large abdominal mass, nauseous symptoms, and gastric compression. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of abdominal mass, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation. P: The management plan included an open liver resection with multiple non-anatomic resections and fenestrations, followed by a left open liver resection and re-laparotomy for lavage due to hemorrhagic liquid causing acute abdominal pain. The patient has undergone successful liver surgery with no complications. Continuous monitoring of liver function and overall health is essential. The patient is advised to reach out with any concerns or questions.

S: The patient reports experiencing pain following a CT scan revealing a hypervascular mass lesion in the pancreas. The patient is unfamiliar with 68Ga DOTATATE PET/CT scans, which target somatostatin receptors (SSTRs) on neuroendocrine tumors (NETs). O: 68Ga DOTATATE PET/CT scan revealed a focus of uptake in the pancreas and moderate tracer uptake foci in several areas of the spine and right iliac wing. However, these areas show characteristic appearances of hemangiomas, not bone metastases. CT images showed a Corduroy sign on sagittal planes and a "polka-dot" appearance on axial slices, indicating sclerosis. The areas of tracer uptake are consistent with hemangiomas, not bone metastases. A: The primary diagnosis is hemangiomas, a benign non-cancerous growth in the pancreas, causing bone demineralization with vertical striation due to thickened trabeculae. Differential diagnoses could include bone metastases, but these are less likely given the imaging findings. P: The management plan includes continued monitoring of the pancreas mass and hemangiomas to ensure no changes. The patient is advised to follow up with their primary care physician and schedule regular check-ups. The patient is advised to report any new or worsening symptoms immediately.

S: The patient is a 63-year-old Japanese male presenting with right-sided pleuritic chest pain and a fever. He reports persistent fever of 39°C. O: Laboratory tests showed total leukocyte count at 7690/mm3, serum C-reactive protein at 17.8 mg/dL, normal liver and kidney function tests, and negative sputum culture. Chest CT revealed a right basilar peripheral opacity and an ipsilateral reactive pleural effusion. Contrast-enhanced CT indicated increased right pleural effusion and aggravated infiltration. A filling defect in the inferior lobar artery of the right lung was noted, indicating a pulmonary embolism with reactive pleural effusion. A second contrast-enhanced CT revealed residual infiltration at the pulmonary embolism site in the right inferior lobe, measuring 1.2 cm, with progressive necrosis in the peripheral parenchyma of the infarcted lung. A: The primary diagnosis is pulmonary embolism with reactive pleural effusion, complicated by a pulmonary embolism with a pulmonary parenchymal embolism. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of pulmonary embolism, but imaging and clinical findings support the primary diagnosis. P: The management plan includes a resection of the right lower lobe containing the embolism site. The patient will be monitored for any signs of infection or complications from the pulmonary embolism. Post-operative care will include monitoring for any signs of infection or complications, and supportive care will be provided to manage any complications. Education on signs of infection and when to seek immediate care will be provided.

S: The patient is a 90-year-old male presenting with lower abdominal pain, described as uncomfortable. He denies any other symptoms such as peritoneal irritation. He has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and hyperuricemia. He denies any history of surgery or trauma. O: Physical examination revealed tenderness in the lower abdomen. Laboratory findings include anemia and a low estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR). Hemoglobin level was 10.3 g/dL, and eGFR was 35 mL/min/1.73m2. Abdominal contrast-enhanced CT indicated a 120 mm mass adjacent to the stomach and transverse colon, with coexisting low- and high-density areas. Extravasation was observed in the arterial phase and spread in the portal phase. On the 2nd day of admission, hemoglobin volume dropped to 9.5 g/dL. Abdominal contrast-enhanced CT confirmed the mass as a mesenteric hematoma. Post-discharge, hemoglobin levels improved to 11.4 g/dL, and the patient was discharged on the third day with no anemia progress. A: The primary diagnosis is a mesenteric hematoma of the stomach and transverse colon, with complications including anemia and extravasation. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of abdominal pain and anemia, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The management plan includes conservative therapy for anemia and mild anemia. The patient will continue with conservative therapy and will be monitored for any signs of worsening anemia or complications. Regular follow-ups will be scheduled to assess the effectiveness of the treatment and adjust as necessary. The patient will be educated on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and adherence to follow-up appointments.

S: The patient reports experiencing casual headaches, which are not clear at this time. The patient has a history of functional endoscopic sinus surgery and septoplasty in 1998, and chronic sinus issues since then. O: Neurological examination and MRI revealed a mass on the left side of the clivus, incidentally identified. PET-CT was performed to exclude potential primary neoplasm. Post-surgery, the mass was successfully removed, isolated from the sellar and suprasellar area, with no connection to the pituitary gland or stalk. Histopathology confirmed the mass as an ectopic pituitary adenoma, null cell type. A: The primary diagnosis is an ectopic pituitary adenoma, null cell type, in the left clivus. Differential diagnosis initially included primary neoplasm, which was ruled out by PET-CT. P: The patient underwent successful biopsy and resection of the mass. Post-surgery, the patient will be discharged in three days with no neurological deficits. The patient is advised to monitor symptoms and contact healthcare providers if any concerns arise.

S: The patient is a 64-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 2, presenting with pelvic pain for four months. She has a history of ventro-suspension for uterine prolapse 25 years ago and a laparoscopy-assisted vaginal hysterectomy 3 years ago. She reports discomfort in her abdomen, which has been causing discomfort. O: Physical examination revealed a pelvic mass fixed to the left anterolateral abdominal wall. Abdominal magnetic resonance imaging showed a huge mass in the pelvic cavity, behind the bladder with irregular borders. Tumor markers showed elevated CA-125 levels at 269.7 kU/L (normal 0-35 kU/L). Debulking surgery included bilateral salpingoopherectomy, total omentectomy, bilateral pelvic and paraaortic lymph node dissection, appendectomy, and aspiration for cytologic evaluation. The left ovarian mass invaded the abdominal wall, necessitating resection of the fascia and part of the rectus abdominis muscle. Histology showed round cells with hyper-chromatic nuclei and pleomorphisms, eosinophilic cytoplasm, frequent mitosis, apoptosis, and focal necrosis. Histology showed diffuse, strong, cytoplasmic, and membranous CD56, nuclear Fli-1 positivity, and multifocal staining for NSE, mesothelin, and focal HMW and low molecular weight cytokeratin. A: The primary diagnosis is a recurrent ovarian tumor with associated uterine prolapse and uterine prolapse. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of pelvic pain and abdominal pain, but these are less likely given the imaging and histological findings. P: The patient underwent a debulking operation with bilateral salpingoopherectomy, total omentectomy, bilateral pelvic and paraaortic lymph node dissection, appendectomy, and aspiration. Post-operative management includes monitoring recovery and discussing further treatment options as needed. The patient will be kept informed of any new symptoms or concerns during recovery. Regular follow-up appointments will

S: The patient is a 15-year-old female who underwent surgery for concomitant exotropia under local anesthesia. She reports feeling a foreign body sensation in her eye six months post-surgery. She was initially fine initially but experienced a foreign body sensation six months postoperatively. O: Physical examination revealed a 5 x 5 mm conjunctival cyst at the right middle temporal side of the eye. The cyst was surgically excised and treated with surgical excisation. Post-surgery, the cyst wall was coated with stratified squamous epithelium and fibrous connective tissue. Post-surgery, the cyst was successfully removed. A: The primary diagnosis is a conjunctival cyst at the right middle temporal side of the eye, likely contributing to the patient's foreign body sensation. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of foreign body sensations, but these are less likely given the pathological findings. P: The patient underwent successful surgical removal of the conjunctival cyst. Post-operative care includes regular follow-ups to monitor the condition and ensure proper healing. The patient is advised to maintain a clean environment and attend regular check-ups to ensure proper healing. Further consultations with a neurologist or a pulmonologist may be necessary depending on the outcome of the surgery.

S: The patient, with a history of pigmentary changes at the macula in 1985, reports a best corrected visual acuity of 6/9 in the right eye and 6/6 in the left eye. The patient has a history of glaucoma diagnosed in 2001, hypertension diagnosed in 2001, cotton wool spots, and haemorrhages, and elevated serum urea and creatinine levels. The patient has undergone bilateral cataract surgery, left-sided trabeculectomy in 2005, and regular haemo-dialysis for end-stage renal failure. O: The patient's best corrected visual acuity was 6/9 in the right eye and 6/6 in the left eye. Retinal examination showed cotton wool spots and haemorrhages, consistent with hypertensive retinopathy. Serum urea and creatinine levels were elevated at 20.5 mmol/L (normal 2.8–7.2 mmol/L) and 474umol/L (normal 60-105umol/L). Differential diagnoses could include other causes of glaucoma, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. The prognosis is guarded due to the severity of the retinopathy and the patient's history of hypertension. P: Continue monitoring the patient's eye health and overall condition closely. Regular follow-up appointments are scheduled to monitor the patient's condition and adjust treatment as necessary. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately. Further consultations with a neurologist or a pulmonologist may be considered if symptoms persist or worsen.

S: The patient is a 28-year-old woman, gravida 3 para 1, who underwent a medical termination of a miscarriage at seven weeks in 2008 without dilation and curettage. She experienced progressive anemia and sudden increasing abdominal pain post-admission. O: Clinical examination revealed a body temperature of 36.7 °C, blood pressure of 102/65 mmHg, pulse rate of 100 bpm, and oxygen saturation of 100%. Blood tests showed mild leucocytosis (16.61  109/L), normal platelet count, normal coagulation test, and hemoglobin of 102 g/L. Ultrasonography indicated the foetal head above the uterine cavity, the foetal size consistent with the gestational age, placental position, and scar thickness of the previous caesarean section of approximately 0.2 cm. Ultrasonography showed the foetal head above the uterine cavity, the foetal size consistent with the gestational age, placental position, and scar thickness of the previous caesarean section of approximately 0.2 cm. Ultrasonography showed the foetal head above the uterine cavity, the foetal size consistent with the gestational age, placental position, and scar thickness of the previous caesarean section of approximately 0.2 cm. A laparotomy revealed a massive haemoperitoneum caused by the rupture of the uterine posterior wall, retrieved approximately 1 liter of blood from the abdomen. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of hemoperitoneum, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the successful delivery of a healthy boy. P: The patient is advised to follow up with her obstetrician for further care and monitoring.
