S: The patient reports a history of lymphadenopathy on the left side of the neck, which has been causing discomfort for the past few months. O: Physical examination revealed partial effacement of normal nodal architecture by a lymphoma with a marginal zone pattern, with no proliferation centers. FNA and excision specimens showed a B-cell clone expressing CD19, CD20, CD5, CD38, partial CD23, partial FMC7, and moderate kappa light chain, negative for CD10 and CD200. Immunohistochemical staining indicated neoplastic B-lymphocytes in the widened marginal zone regions were positive for CD20, CD79a, CD5 (weak), and bcl-2, negative for CD10, bcl-6, cyclin D1, SOX-11, and CD23. Molecular testing showed no evidence of a MYD88 L265P mutation. Conventional GTG-band karyotype analysis from both lymph node and bone marrow biopsy showed aberrant CD5 positivity. FISH studies were performed using the Vysis CLL probe set. A: The primary diagnosis is nodal MZL with aberrant CD5 positivity. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of lymphoma, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and immunophenotypic and molecular findings. P: The management plan includes discussing the diagnosis with a team of specialists and developing a treatment plan tailored to the lymphoma. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's response to treatment and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. The patient will be educated on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and adherence to follow-up appointments.

S: The patient, with a history of rhabdomyolysis, COPD, and occasional use of methamphetamine, presents with severe, constant, sharp pain in the right pectoral muscle starting 5 days ago. The pain is severe, constant, sharp, and radiates from the right pectoral muscle to the right shoulder. The patient also reports minor superficial abrasions on the right chest from steel, a fever the night before, a nonproductive chronic cough, and red, swollen skin changes on the right chest. No blunt trauma, intravenous drug use, recent travel, or weight loss was reported. O: On examination, the patient was febrile and tachycardic, but stable. Physical examination revealed erythematous, tenderness along the distal right pectoral insertion and right shoulder, sensitivity to light touch along the right arm, and a 3 times the size of the left chest. There was a nontender induration on the right flank, no discrete mass or abscess, and a fluid collection in the posterior scapula region on the right side. Lab results showed elevated procalcitonin, c-reactive protein, white blood cell count, and creatinine kinase level. Chest x-ray was unremarkable. Ultrasound of the right pectoral muscle showed skin induration with tiny anechoic areas, and CT scan showed fat stranding of the right pectoral without abscess. A: The primary diagnosis is cellulitis in the right pectoral area, likely secondary to rhabdomyolysis or a complication of rhabdomyolysis. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of muscle pain and inflammatory processes, but these are less likely given the imaging and lab results. P: Continue monitoring the patient's condition closely with regular follow-ups with a rheumatologist and possibly a neurologist. Consider referral to a rheumatologist for further evaluation and management. Educate the patient on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and adhering to follow-up appointments.

S: The patient reports a chief complaint of the esthetic appearance of their teeth, characterized by high and rotated maxillary canines for the past 4 months. The patient expresses concern about the esthetic appearance of their teeth and expresses concern about the malposition of their maxillary canines. O: Intraoral photographs reveal a complete Class II molar and canine relationship, a 4-mm overjet, a 3-mm overbite, a negative tooth-size discrepancy of 5 mm in the maxillary arch and 8.5 mm in the mandibular arch, a 2-mm deviation of the maxillary midline to the right side, and crossbite on the left side. Panoramic radiograph shows all of the teeth except for the third molars, significant horizontal bone loss at the premolar region, endodontic treatment of tooth 46, and significant dental health impairment due to large restorations in several teeth. Cephalometric analysis reveals a skeletal Class I relationship (ANB = 1o) and a hyperdivergent skeletal pattern, with maxillary incisors being buccally tipped and protruded (1-NA = 9 mm and 1.NA = 26o), and mandibular incisors well positioned (1-NB = 6 mm and 1.NB = 25o, IMPA = 90o). The upper lip is retruded by 4 mm and the lower lip is retruded by 2 mm in relation to the S line. A: The primary diagnosis is asymmetric maxillary canine malposition, complicated by significant horizontal bone loss at the premolar region, endodontic treatment of tooth 46, and significant dental health impairment due to large restorations. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of maxillary canine malposition, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The management plan includes exploring orthodontic treatment options to improve the esthetic appearance of the smile and correct the malposition of the maxillary canines. The patient will be scheduled for a follow-up appointment to discuss the treatment options and develop a personalized treatment plan. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor bone loss and dental health. The patient

S: The patient is a HIV-1-infected 41-year-old male farmer presenting with right hypochondriac abdominal pain for five days, decreased appetite, nausea, vomiting, and yellowish discolouration of the sclera for the last two days. He denies fever, diarrhoea, blurring of vision, odynophagia, or dysphagia. He was previously diagnosed with pneumocystis jiroveci pneumonitis (PJP) in September 2016, treated with co-trimoxazole and prednisolone. He reports no fever, diarrhoea, blurring of vision, odynophagia, or dysphagia. O: Physical examination revealed icterus and tender hepatomegaly, but fundoscopy did not reveal CMV retinitis. He has normocytic normochromic anemia with a hemoglobin level of 10.7 g/dl, normal total leucocyte and differential counts, and elevated liver enzymes including total bilirubin at 9.2 mg/dl, AST at 109 U/L, ALT at 41 U/L, and ALP at 90 U/L. A: The primary diagnosis is pneumocystis jiroveci pneumonitis (PJP), complicated by elevated liver enzymes and bilirubin levels. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of hepatomegaly and hepatomegaly, but these are less likely given the current findings. P: Continue current medications and report any new or worsening symptoms. Continue monitoring liver enzymes and bilirubin levels closely. Educate the patient on the importance of reporting new or worsening symptoms immediately. Consider referral to a hepatologist for further evaluation and management.

S: The patient, with a history of Crohn's disease and previously on tumor necrosis factor inhibitor therapy, presents with symptoms of weakness and sickness. The patient reports difficulty in completing daily activities. O: Laboratory findings include low fibrinogen at 43, elevated ferritin at 108,416 ng/mL, elevated liver enzymes, and hyperbilirubinemia. Viral testing for EBV and HIV was negative. HLH-94 protocol was initiated with etoposide and dexamethasone, achieving significant improvement in liver function panel, LDH, and ferritin levels. On hospital day 35, the patient developed a severe gastrointestinal bleed, necessitating multiple transfusions. Upper and lower endoscopies were inconclusive, leading to a poor surgical candidate. A: The primary diagnosis is HLH-94, complicated by hemophagocytic histiocytes. Differential diagnoses initially included EBV and HIV, which were ruled out by negative viral testing. The prognosis is guarded due to the severity of the gastrointestinal bleed and complications from hemorrhagic shock. P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition with supportive care and comfort measures. The patient will continue on HLH-94 protocol with etoposide and dexamethasone, which has shown significant improvement in liver function panel, LDH, and ferritin levels. The patient will be educated on the signs of complications and advised to seek immediate medical attention if symptoms worsen. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's condition and adjust treatment as necessary.

S: The patient, recently diagnosed with stage IIIB superficial spreading melanoma on the right distal thigh, reports feeling okay but experiencing weird sensations and weakness in legs and arms. He has undergone surgery, a right inguinal SLN biopsy, and right inguinal CLND. He reports no bladder or bowel incontinence or difficulties with speech. O: MRI of the brain and whole spine revealed abnormal enhancement involving bilateral 5th, 7th, and 8th cranial nerves, cauda equina nerve roots, and the conus surface and peripheral nerves at the thoracolumbar junction. CSF studies were negative for malignant cells but showed lymphocytic pleocytosis. CSF protein was elevated at 175 mg/dL (normal range 15-45 mg/dL). Laboratory studies indicated concomitant adrenal insufficiency. Electromyography indicated electrophysiologic evidence consistent with generalized, sensory and motor, length-dependent, predominantly axonal, peripheral polyneuropathy. A: The primary diagnosis is ipilimumab-related acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (AIDP). Differential diagnoses could include other causes of parasthesias, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The patient was started on Methylprednisolone 1.5 mg/kg twice daily, tapered to 1 mg/kg by 10 mg weekly over a 12-week period, and transitioned to physiologic doses of hydrocortisone to manage ipilimumab-related adrenal insufficiency. The patient is currently on Methylprednisolone 1.5 mg/kg twice daily, with gradual improvement in motor symptoms in the hands and lower extremities. A: The primary diagnosis is ipilimumab-related acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (AIDP), with differential diagnoses including autoimmune and paraneoplastic etiologies. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the rapid improvement in motor symptoms and minimal parasthesias in the upper and lower extremities. P: Continue monitoring the patient's symptoms and adjust the treatment

S: The patient, with a history of hypertension, type 2 diabetes, and hyperlipidemia, reports experiencing uncontrollable movements on the left side of the body for approximately 10 years. The movements involve the arm reaching around or flinging out, and the leg dancing on its own. The patient denies any movement issues on the right side or facial movements. O: Physical examination revealed episodic movements in the left hand, forearm, arm muscles, and leg, with quick and moderate-amplitude movements, worsening with distraction or anxiety. lateralizing movements of the head to the left were noted, but no facial or tongue movements were noted. CT scan of the head showed asymmetric calcification in the right caudate nucleus and anterior putamen. Lab work for parenchymal calcification was normal. MRI of the brain with contrast showed hypointense gradient echo (GRE) signal in the right caudate nucleus and putamen, and an underlying developmental venous anomaly (DVA). A: The primary diagnosis is asymmetric calcification of the right caudate nucleus and anterior putamen, likely secondary to a developmental venous anomaly. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of claustrophobic movements, but these are less likely given the imaging findings and normal lab work. P: The management plan will include referral to a neurologist for further evaluation and management of the DVA. The patient will be educated on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and ensuring compliance with the treatment plan. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor progress and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient, with a history of morbid obesity, diabetes mellitus, end stage renal disease, and osteomyelitis, presents with chief complaint of penile swelling starting nine days ago following a bite injury to the penis during oral intercourse. The patient reports worsening swelling, redness, penile discharge, pain, or difficulty retracting the foreskin since the injury. The patient has a history of suspected balanitis treated with Keflex and fluconazole. O: Initial treatment included suspected balanitis with Keflex and fluconazole. CT scan revealed subcutaneous emphysema involving the dorsal aspect of the penis. Surgical examination revealed phimosis with purulent drainage from the phimotic ring and induration of the penile shaft. Post-operative examination under anesthesia revealed necrotic, nonviable tissue involving the dorsal aspect of the glans and shaft of the penis. Post-operative care included dressing the penis with XeroformR gauze and Kerlix moistened in saline. A: The primary diagnosis is subcutaneous emphysema of the dorsal aspect of the penis, likely a necrotizing soft tissue infection. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of penile swelling, but these are less likely given the imaging and surgical findings. P: The patient underwent urgent penile exploration and debridement. Post-operative care includes close monitoring of the patient's progress and regular follow-ups to assess for any recurrence or complications. The patient is advised to maintain regular follow-up appointments and report any new symptoms or concerns immediately.

S: The patient is a 19-year-old female with a history of afebrile focal seizures, intractable generalized seizures, myotonic, tonic, and tonic-clonic, convulsive status epilepticus, and multiple episodes of convulsive status epilepticus. She has a history of afebrile focal seizures and intractable generalized seizures, both myotonic, tonic, and tonic-clonic, and multiple episodes of convulsive status epilepticus. She has a history of autistic traits, decelerated head growth from the 50th to the 10th percentile between one and 2 years of age. She reports intense eye contact, ongoing stereotypic hand movements with hand dyspraxia, broad-based gait with notable ataxia, breath-holding, and teeth grinding. She is 141 cm tall but has normal weight for height. O: Birth weight is 2890 g, length 47 cm, and head circumference 32 cm. Pre- and neonatal periods were normal. Clinical examination at 19 years revealed intense eye contact, ongoing stereotypic hand movements with hand dyspraxia, broad-based gait with notable ataxia, breath-holding, and teeth grinding. Musculature is generally hypotonic, and slight scoliosis. Current symptoms include daily seizures (focal, tonic, tonic-clonic), despite intense anti-epileptic treatment. A: The primary diagnosis is classic Retts syndrome (RTT), characterized by aggressive epilepsy with daily seizures (focal, tonic, and tonic-clonic). Differential diagnoses could include other causes of epilepsy, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and clinical findings. P: Continue monitoring the patient's condition with regular follow-ups to assess the effectiveness of the treatment and adjust as necessary. Educate the patient on the importance of reporting any new symptoms or changes in her condition. Consider referral to a pediatric neurologist for further evaluation and management of her condition.

S: The patient, diagnosed with stage I disease, reports recent symptoms of multiple small lung nodules, more than 15 in number. The patient underwent a left lower lobectomy for a T1bN0M0 stage, followed by a left lower lobectomy for a T1bN0M0 stage. The patient has a history of extensive mediastinal lymphadenopathy, a bone metastasis, and a left-sided malignant pleural effusion 12 months ago. Genetic analysis revealed an EGFR exon 20 variant with an amino acid residue, associated with reduced sensitivity to EGFR-TKIs. The patient has been on cisplatin, pemetrexed, maintenance pemetrexed, docetaxel, nivolumab, single-agent vinorelbine, and multiple small lung nodules over the past 12 months. O: The patient's pleural fluid cytology showed adenocarcinoma. Genetic analysis showed an EGFR exon 20 variant with an amino acid residue, associated with reduced sensitivity to EGFR-TKIs. No other mutations were found in EGFR exon 19 or 21, BRAF, KRAS, ALK, IDH 1/2, PTEN, or TP53. The patient has been on cisplatin, pemetrexed, maintenance pemetrexed, docetaxel, nivolumab, single-agent vinorelbine, and multiple small lung nodules over the past 12 months. A: The primary diagnosis is stage I adenocarcinoma with complications including mediastinal lymphadenopathy, bone metastasis, and left-sided malignant pleural effusion. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of adenocarcinoma, but the EGFR exon 20 mutation is associated with reduced sensitivity to EGFR-TKIs. The prognosis is guarded due to the progression of the disease and the presence of multiple small lung nodules. P: Continue monitoring the patient's condition with regular follow-ups to assess the progression of the disease and detect any new symptoms or changes in the patient's condition. Educate

S: The patient is a 75-year-old smoker with a history of hepatic transplantation 13 years ago for hepatocellular carcinoma. He presents with hemoptysis and dyspnea. He reports a history of wheezing and acute respiratory failure following a six-month history of chemotherapy for hepatocarcinoma. O: Initial chest CT scan showed a solid lesion in the apical segment of the right lower lobe, multiple confluent mediastinal adenopathies, and right paratracheal lymphadenopathy. Videobronchoscopy revealed two small sessile lesions approximately 4.5 cm from the carina on the right lateral wall of the trachea. Pathological findings suggestive of hepatocarcinoma metastases. Post-chemotherapy, the patient experienced wheezing and acute respiratory failure. A second videobronchoscopy revealed a vegetative neoformation obstructing the tracheal lumen about 6.5 cm far from the true vocal cords. A: The primary diagnosis is hepatocarcinoma metastases, confirmed by anatomicopathological findings. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of hepatocarcinoma, but these are less likely given the imaging and pathological findings. P: Continue monitoring the patient's condition closely with regular follow-ups to assess for any recurrence or complications. Consider surgical intervention if symptoms persist or worsen. Educate the patient on signs of worsening symptoms and encourage immediate reporting of any new symptoms.

S: The patient is a 38-year-old male with a history of schizophrenia, presenting after a second suicide attempt. He reports taking 48 tablets of burotizolam, 42 tablets of haloxazolam, and 14 tablets of levomepromazine. He was diagnosed with schizophrenia at age 23 and has a history of working part-time at a convenience store and nursery. He has a history of a father who committed suicide three years ago and a friend who died from a sickness three years ago. He has been stockpiling sleeping medications. O: Physical examinations and vital signs were normal. The patient's first overdose involved 76 tablets of brotizolam and 30 tablets of eszopiclone. The patient's mother found him unconscious and called an ambulance. A: The primary diagnosis is schizophrenia with a history of a suicide attempt, complicated by a history of pessimism and a family history of mental illness. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of schizophrenia, but the patient's symptoms and history strongly suggest schizophrenia. P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition, regular follow-ups with the healthcare team, and supportive care. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms or changes in his condition immediately. The patient is encouraged to reach out if he feels the urge to harm himself again.

S: The patient reports experiencing left hip and knee pain and limping for the past three weeks. The patient denies any fever or recent trauma. O: Physical examination revealed pain when flexing and rotating the hip in different directions. Point-of-care ultrasound (POCUS) was performed, comparing the ultrasound of the left hip with the right side. A pelvic radiograph confirmed the diagnosis. A: The primary diagnosis is left hip and knee pain with associated limping. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of hip and knee pain, but these are less likely given the imaging results. P: The management plan includes expedited immobilization and pain control. A pelvic radiograph confirmed the diagnosis. A: The primary diagnosis is left hip and knee pain with associated limping. The differential diagnosis initially included other causes of hip and knee pain, but the pelvic radiograph confirmed the diagnosis. P: The management plan includes expedited immobilization and pain control. The patient will be educated on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and adherence to follow-up appointments. Further consultations with a neurologist and a pulmonologist are planned to explore the causes of the hip and knee pain.

S: The patient, a male with a history of laparoscopic adjustable gastric band surgery and revision surgery for weight loss failure, presents with a painful mass in the left upper quadrant of the abdomen, which has been increasing in size over the last 2 years. He denies fever, diarrhea/constipation, nausea/vomiting, fever, lymphadenopathy, significant family history, or smoking. O: Physical examination revealed the patient to be afebrile, soft, non-distended, and healed surgical scars. A 4  4 cm, symmetric mass with normal overlying skin in the left upper quadrant was identified. Laboratory findings including complete blood count, liver function tests, and renal function tests were within normal limits. CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis with oral contrast revealed a subcutaneous spherical foreign body, likely the port, with a connected tube extending 10 cm into the abdominal cavity. A: The primary diagnosis is a port site hernia, likely a retained foreign body. Differential diagnosis initially included a port site hernia, which was ruled out based on imaging and laboratory findings. P: The patient underwent a minimally invasive removal of the port with a 10 cm connected tube. He was discharged on the same postoperative day. The patient is advised to report any further concerns or issues immediately.

S: The patient, a school teacher with a history of a 2.4 cm GIST diagnosed six months ago, presents with new-onset jaundice four days ago, weakness, fatigue, and itchy for the past several days. The patient denies any prior history of alcohol consumption, intravenous drug use, tattoos or non-sterile piercings, transfusions of blood or blood products, sexual promiscuity, or living in a developing country. The patient denies any family history of liver diseases. O: On examination, the patient appeared icteric with yellowish discoloration of the skin and sclera, afebrile with a temperature of 97.4 and hemodynamic stability with a heart rate of 72 bpm and blood pressure of 110/85 mm Hg. Physical examination revealed soft abdomen with no tenderness, guarding, or rigidity. Laboratory tests showed elevated transaminases (AST 1450 U/L) and ALT 1680 U/L. A: The primary diagnosis is a high-grade GIST with a mitotic rate of more than 5/50 per high-power field, positive for CD34, CD117, and DOG-1. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of liver dysfunction, but these are less likely given the imaging and laboratory findings. P: Plan to conduct further diagnostic tests to determine the cause of the elevated liver enzymes and jaundice. Continue monitoring liver function and ensure proper follow-up care. Educate the patient on the importance of adherence to follow-up appointments and medication adherence.

S: The patient reports significant pain and difficulty moving the elbow following a fall while walking down the stairs. The patient has a history of a previous case of a Regan-Morrey type 2 coronoid process fracture, which was successfully treated with arthroscopic osteosynthesis. O: Initial tests revealed a coronoid process fracture, specifically a Regan-Morrey type 2, with a high success rate. A: The primary diagnosis is a Regan-Morrey type 2 coronoid process fracture of the elbow, specifically a Regan-Morrey type 2. Differential diagnoses could include other types of coronoid process fractures, but these are less likely given the imaging results and clinical presentation. P: The treatment plan includes performing an arthroscopic osteosynthesis using two 3.5 mm CCSs to fix the fracture. The surgery will be scheduled for 5 days post-injury to ensure optimal healing conditions. The patient is advised to follow pre-operative instructions and attend all scheduled follow-up appointments. The patient is encouraged to reach out with any questions or concerns during recovery.

S: The patient, who underwent liver dysfunction treatment 3 years post-aortic valve replacement, reports recent fatigue. He has a history of duodenal ulcer perforation and is currently on warfarin, angiotensin receptor blocker, proton pump inhibitor, and ursodeoxycholic acid for an unknown liver function disorder. He denies any history of alcohol consumption or tobacco smoking. O: Vital signs include a body temperature of 36 °C, blood pressure of 164/65 mmHg, and pulse rate of 66/minute. Laboratory findings include mild anemia, liver-renal injury, hemoglobin 9.7 g/dL, platelet count 18.9  104/dL, CRP 0.29 mg/dL, ALP 1138 U/L, AST 40 U/L, ALT 37 U/L, -GTP 298 U/L, BUN 22.4 mg/dL, creatinine 1.14 mg/dL, APTT 45.6 seconds, and PT-INR 2.67. Plain radiograph showed no significant findings. CT scan revealed an enhanced tumor within the hilar bile duct and dilatation of the left hepatic duct. Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) indicated a tumor shadow in the bile duct. Cytology confirmed malignant cells in the bile. No lymph node or distant metastases were detected. A: The primary diagnosis is hilar cholangiocarcinoma of the bile duct. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of liver dysfunction and kidney injury, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. The prognosis depends on the extent of the disease and response to treatment. P: The patient has been readmitted for further evaluation and management. The surgery plan includes an extended left hepatectomy with resection of the bile duct. Post-operative care will include close monitoring of liver function and kidney function. The patient will be educated on the importance of adhering to the treatment regimen and adherence to follow-up appointments. Referral to a hepatologist for further evaluation and management of liver dysfunction is recommended.

S: The patient, a 23-month-old male, presented with four episodes of tonic seizures over 10 days at 16 months old, enamel hypoplasia, and hypotonia in the trunk and limb muscles. The patient's developmental quotient (DQ) and mental index (MI) scores were less than 70. Brain MRI revealed long T1 and long T2 signal changes in the white matter adjacent to the anterior and posterior horns of both lateral ventricles, indicating dysplasia in these regions. Video-electroencephalography (EEG) monitoring showed abnormal brain waves during sleep. Liver function tests showed increased plasma ALT at 117 IU/L and AST at 50 IU/L, with normal ranges for ALT and AST at 9–50 IU/L and 15–40 IU/L, respectively. Plasma bilirubin was normal, but plasma citrulline was elevated at 220.94 mol/L, with normal plasma arginine levels. Follow-up brain MRI showed ventricular dilation and cerebral atrophy of the left hemisphere with malacia, suggestive of serious irreversible brain injury. A: The primary diagnosis is severe brain injury, likely secondary to a genetic disorder, given the elevated plasma ALT, AST, and citrulline levels. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of cerebral atrophy and malacia, but these are less likely given the genetic findings. P: The patient was started on a restricted protein diet and arginine supplementation, which reduced plasma ammonia levels to 70 mol/L after two weeks of treatment. The family was informed about the genetic findings and the importance of compliance with the treatment plan. Further genetic counseling was provided to the family to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient, with a history of diverticulitis for 27 years, abdominal pain, sigmoid resection, appendectomy, and end colostomy with a mucous fistula, presents for a semiannual total body skin evaluation. The patient has a history of basal cell carcinoma on the right side of the neck removed five years ago, actinic keratoses on sun-exposed skin treated with cryotherapy, and psoriasis as an adult, limited to less than 5% of the body surface area. The patient has been using clobetasol propionate 0.05% cream or solution, followed by triamcinolone 0.1% cream twice daily for three to five days, allergic contact dermatitis to bandaid adhesive, and leukonychia since childhood. O: Physical examination reveals eight keratotic plaques on the face, arms, and legs, treated with liquid nitrogen cryotherapy, and small, red scaly psoriasis lesions on the chest, arms, and legs, with no nail plate changes. Fingernails and toenails show diffuse whitening, and thumbnails have alternating horizontal bands of white and red, indicating a nail flag sign. A: The primary diagnosis is actinic keratoses, with a history of basal cell carcinoma and psoriasis. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of psoriasis, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation. The prognosis depends on the response to cryotherapy and management of the keratotic plaques. P: Proceed with cryotherapy for actinic keratoses. Continue treatment of psoriasis as tolerated. Monitor the patient's response to treatment and adjust as necessary. Educate the patient on the importance of reporting any new symptoms or changes in the condition.

S: The patient reports a painless, firm, immobile mass on the right side of the scrotum for approximately a year, which has been slowly growing. O: CT scan revealed a right inguinal hernia with intraperitoneal fat extending inferiorly into the scrotal sac and a 14  10.5 cm membranous sac excised. The sac contained nine separate, lobulated masses ranging from 2 to 8 cm in size, tracing along the spermatic cord. Microscopically, the masses were predominantly composed of mature adipose tissue, but the dark red component showed fibrous tissue with myxoid areas and variable numbers of adipocytes with significant variations in size and shape. Arborizing capillaries, lipoblasts, and atypical nonlipogenic spindle cells were noted in the myxoid component. PET-scan revealed a nonhypermetabolic fatty mass along the distal anterior aspect of the right psoas. A: The primary diagnosis is a well-differentiated liposarcoma mixed type of inguinal hernia, grade 1, with a retroperitoneal component. Differential diagnoses could include other types of liposarcomas, but these are less likely given the imaging and imaging findings. P: The management plan includes referral to a specialist for further evaluation and management of the retroperitoneal component of the inguinal tumor. The patient will be educated on the nature of the disease, treatment options, and potential side effects. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the tumor's response to treatment and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient reports decreased vision in the right eye and pain around the eye for approximately one week. O: Ophthalmological examination revealed light perception/0.9 in decimals, a relative afferent pupillary defect of grade 3, diffuse disc swelling, and inferior disc hemorrhage. Neurological examination showed normal muscle strength in all extremities, normal sensory deficits, and normoactive deep tendon reflexes. Orbit MRI revealed T2 high signal intensities and diffuse contrast enhancement along the right anterior and posterior optic nerve, with perineural enhancement. Cerebrospinal fluid analysis showed a red blood cell count of 0/L, white blood cell count of 1/L, and protein level of 27 mg/dL. CSF oligoclonal band was negative, and IgG index was 0.64. Serum AQP4-IgG flow cytometry assay using AQP4-M23-expressing live cells was negative. A: The primary diagnosis is right optic neuritis, evidenced by the presence of T2 high signal intensities and diffuse contrast enhancement along the right anterior and posterior optic nerve, and perineural enhancement. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of optic neuritis, but these are less likely given the imaging findings and clinical presentation. P: Initiated intravenous methylprednisolone (1000 mg pulse therapy) for 5 days, followed by oral prednisolone (60 mg daily). The patient experienced a second right optic neuritis attack with a visual acuity of 0.15/1.0 4 months post-treatment, with azathioprine 50 mg twice per day in a remission state. The average thickness of the retinal nerve fiber layer has decreased in the right eye (51 m and left 105 m). A: The primary diagnosis is right optic neuritis, evidenced by the presence of T2 high signal intensities and diffuse contrast enhancement along the right anterior and posterior optic nerve, and perineural enhancement. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of optic neuritis, but these are less likely given the imaging findings and clinical presentation. P: Initiated azathioprine 50 mg twice per day in a remission state. Continued monitoring of the patient'

S: The patient, a 24-month-old female, presented with a 10-day history of fever, worsening symptoms including adynamia, pallor, inappetence, oliguria, and choluria. The parent reported that the child's health worsened significantly over the past 3 days. O: Physical examination revealed the patient to be lethargic, skin discolored (4+/4+), and hypoactive. Radiographic imaging indicated pneumonia. Complete blood count showed marked anemia, thrombocytopenia, and significant increase in hepatic enzymes. Abdominal ultrasonography showed pronounced hepatosplenomegaly. Diagnostic tests confirmed Visceral Leishmaniasis (VL). The patient was treated with liposomal amphotericin B (5 mg/kg/day) for 5 days, and serology screening was positive for cytomegalovirus antibodies IgG and IgM. At the end of VL treatment, the patient experienced severe liver injury, hyperbilirubinemia, hypoalbuminemia, and increased liver and canalicular enzymes: ALT 354 IU/mL, AST 354 IU/mL. A: The primary diagnosis is Visceral Leishmaniasis, confirmed by diagnostic tests and serology. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of liver injury, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and laboratory findings. P: The patient was treated with liposomal amphotericin B (5 mg/kg/day) for 5 days, and serology screening was positive for cytomegalovirus antibodies IgG and IgM. The treatment plan includes close monitoring of liver function and supportive care to manage symptoms. The management plan includes regular follow-ups in the pediatric ICU and the pediatric intensive care unit to assess recovery and manage any complications.

S: The patient, a 5-week-old boy, presented with jaundice and failure to thrive. He was delivered by Cesarean section at 38 weeks of gestation, with an Apgar score of 9/9. His birth weight was 2600 g, length 49 cm, and cranial circumference 32.5 cm. Urinary Cytomegalovirus test was negative. The patient has a healthy 8-year-old brother. He was discharged from another neonatal center on the 4th day of life. Physical examination revealed skin and scleral jaundice. Routine blood tests confirmed cholestatic jaundice with total bilirubin at 11.95 mg/dL, conjugated bilirubin at 6.69 mg/dL, and increased gamma-glutamyl transpeptidase at 221 U/L. Routine screenings for Alagille syndrome were negative, except for a minor pulmonary artery stenosis and a doubt of a thoracic butterfly hemivertebra. Abdominal ultrasound showed normal liver size and echogenicity, normal biliary intrahepatic and extrahepatic tree, regular liver vessel flow, hyperechogenic kidneys with multiple bilateral cortical cysts. Serum creatinine was 0.59 mg/dL, and glomerular filtration rate was 35 ml/min/1.73m2. He has Chronic Kidney Disease KDIGO stage 3, metabolic acidosis, tubular proteinuria, and polyuria. A: The primary diagnosis is cholestatic jaundice with complications including jaundice and failure to thrive. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of jaundice, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation. The prognosis depends on the management of jaundice and the progression of chronic kidney disease. P: The management plan includes continued monitoring of renal function and jaundice, supplementation with fat-soluble vitamins, and adjustment of milk feeding. Regular monitoring of renal function and jaundice will be necessary. The patient will be educated on the importance of adhering to the treatment regimen and regular follow-up appointments to assess progress and adjust treatment as necessary. Referral to a pediatric nephrologist and a ne

S: The patient is a 22-year-old unmarried South Asian female presenting with a four-month history of right eye issues. She reports a headache lasting one day, followed by metamorphopsia in the right eye. She has a history of refractive errors in both right and left eyes for three years. O: Ocular examination revealed best-corrected visual acuity (BCVA) in the right eye at 6/24, left eye at 6/18, and BCVA at 6/6. Fundus examination revealed 2+ vitreous cells and a slightly elevated area of yellow-white active retinitis of two to three disc diameters over the macula in the right eye. Fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA) showed a hyperfluorescent patch of increasing intensity of 2DD temporal to the optic disc in the right eye. axial optical coherence tomography (OCT) scan revealed an irregular, thickened surface of the retina with loss of foveal contour and pigment epithelial detachment in the right eye. OCTA showed abnormally dilated hyperfluorescent vessels at the outer retina in the right eye. A: The primary diagnosis is choroidal neovascular membrane in the right eye, likely secondary to a choroidal neovascular membrane. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of retinal inflammation and retinitis, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The management plan will include monitoring the patient's condition with regular follow-up appointments to assess treatment efficacy and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. The patient will be educated on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and adhering to follow-up appointments. Referral to a neurologist for further evaluation and management of the choroidal neovascular membrane is recommended.

S: The patient, with a history of kidney failure and multiple myeloma for 10 years, reports recent difficulty swallowing and breathing. He denies any signs of systemic amyloidosis or hypo- or hyper-thyroidism. O: Clinical examination revealed significant neck swelling. Ultrasound revealed an increased volume of the thyroid gland with a right lobe measuring 49  38  100 mm and the left lobe 41  34  51 mm, with mediastinum involvement but no lateral cervical lymphadenopathy. CT and MRI scans showed diffuse and multinodular enlargement of both lobes of the thyroid gland, with the right lobe reaching C2, and the left lobe reaching the brachio-cephalic trunk. Fine needle aspiration (FNA) on one of the nodules showed colloid and histiocytes. Post-operative course was unremarkable. Histological findings included diffuse stromal deposition of amorphous eosinophilic material, residual normal-sized or cystically dilated thyroid follicles, and a variably fatty stromal component characterized by mature adipocytes. PAS staining was negative or weakly positive in the amorphous eosinophilic stromal material, but a positive Rosso Congo stain showed apple-green birefringence under polarized light. A: The primary diagnosis is Amyloid goiter, a rare condition characterized by diffuse enlargement and histological findings. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of thyroid enlargement, but these are less likely given the imaging and histological findings. P: The patient underwent total thyroidectomy with no complications. Post-operative management included no complications, and the thyroid gland was surgically removed. The patient is advised to monitor symptoms closely and report any new symptoms immediately. Further consultations with a nephrologist and a pulmonologist are recommended to manage the condition effectively.

S: Mary Smith, a 20-year-old female, presents with a chief complaint of a headache starting yesterday. She reports a headache that started at mid-morning, initially intense and throbbing, which has progressively worsened over time. S: The patient reports feeling unwell, experiencing nausea, vomiting, and a weight loss of 7 kg over the past month. The patient has a history of Pica disorder since age 2 and a history of trichophagia. O: Physical examination revealed stable vital signs but paleness. A large, firm, hard mass was noted in the epigastric and left upper quadrant areas. Blood tests including complete blood count, electrolytes, BUN, creatinine, liver function tests, amylase, and lipase were unremarkable. CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis showed a large, multi-layered, heterogeneous, solid mass measuring 30  17  12 cm in the gastric lumen, extending from the gastric fundus to the pyloric canal, heterogeneously hyperdense, separated from the gastric walls by gastric fluid, and no abnormal gastric mural thickening. EGD indicated a large, hard hairball occupying the entire lumen of the stomach from the fundus through the pylorus, reaching the duodenum. A: The primary diagnosis is a large, hard, heterogeneous, solid mass in the gastric lumen, likely secondary to a gastric tumor, given the patient's history of Pica disorder and trichophagia. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of gastric masses, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The patient underwent successful surgical intervention with a 7 cm longitudinal gastrotomy on the anterior gastric wall, 6 cm from the pylorus, to remove the trichobezoar. Post-operative care will include close monitoring of the patient's recovery and adherence to follow-up appointments. The patient will be educated on signs of complications and advised to report any new symptoms immediately.

S: The patient is a 22-year-old female with a history of lower extremity CRPS type-I in the left ankle and foot, based on the IASP Budapest Criteria. She reports no history of psychological disorder, seizure disorder, or neurological abnormalities. She underwent a diagnostic left lumbar sympathetic block (LSB) procedure, followed by 5 additional LSBs using the same technique and medications. She recalls taking lorazepam 1.5 mg orally prior to each procedure. For the 6th block, she was also given DPH 50 mg IV prophylactically. O: Physical examination revealed the contracture of the left foot in a plantar-flexed position and a reproducible tremor of the ipsilateral quadriceps muscles when the left knee was fully extended. The needle entry point was marked on the skin at the level of L3, with 3 mL of Lidocaine 1% and 20-gauge 3.5-inch introducer and 25-gauge 6-inch spinal needles. The spinal needle was directed to the anterolateral aspect of the L3 vertebral body. Negative aspiration for blood and cerebrospinal fluid was noted, and 10 mL of Bupivacaine 0.5% was injected in 1 mL increments. A: The primary diagnosis is lower extremity CRPS type-I in the left ankle and foot. The patient underwent a diagnostic left lumbar sympathetic block (LSB) procedure, followed by 5 additional LSBs using the same technique and medications. The prognosis depends on the response to further treatment and the management of the CRPS. P: The patient is advised to continue monitoring symptoms and report any changes or concerns. A follow-up appointment is scheduled to assess progress and determine if further treatment is necessary. The patient is encouraged to report any changes or concerns during the follow-up.

S: The patient, admitted with complaints of shortness of breath, reports persistent difficulty breathing. He has a history of hypertension, hypothyroidism, GERD, VLUs, and ambulatory dysfunction. He has a history of back surgery, fracture surgery, hysterectomy, and partial thyroidectomy. O: Physical examination revealed a large ulcer on the distal aspect of the right lower extremity, covered in a fibrotic slough and pitting and woody edema. Skin assessment revealed a large ulcer on the distal aspect of the right lower extremity with a fibrotic slough and pitting and woody edema on the leg. The ulceration measured 10 x 16 x 1.5 cm with 20 percent brown tissue, 40 percent pink tissue, and 40 percent tan tissue in the base, with a malodor. Initial treatment included intravenous cefepime, clindamycin, and vancomycin, followed by a novel ROCT-CC on the wound base with NPWTi-d. A: The primary diagnosis is a large ulcer on the distal aspect of the right lower extremity with a fibrotic slough and pitting and woody edema. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of septic shock, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and surgical history. P: The patient was treated with intravenous cefepime, clindamycin, and vancomycin, pending wound culture results. A novel ROCT-CC was applied on the wound base with NPWTi-d, with a hypochlorite solution (Dakin's) 0. A: The primary diagnosis is a large ulcer on the distal aspect of the right lower extremity with a fibrotic slough and pitting and woody edema on the leg. The patient's current condition is not stable enough for discharge. The treatment plan includes continued monitoring and adjustments to the treatment regimen as necessary. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately. Further consultations with the WOCN team and plastic surgery are planned to manage the ulceration and manage any complications.

S: The patient is an 18-year-old boy presenting with seizures for the past 3 months, starting with blurring of vision, head deviating to the right side, right upper limp, generalized tonic-clonic seizures, suboccipital and frontal tension headache, and suboccipital and frontal tension headache. He reports loss of consciousness post-episodes, suboccipital and frontal tension headache, fever, loss of weight, trauma, sensory or motor issues, and no family history of similar issues or surgeries. O: Physical examinations were within normal limits. Brain MRI with contrast showed a right parieto-occipital cortical and subcortical mass lesion measuring 1.5 x 1.5 cm with low signal intensity on T1 and intermediate signal intensity on T2 and FLAIR, intense enhancement with small susceptibility artifacts on T2, significant vasogenic edema, and mass effect on adjacent sulci. Preoperative diagnosis was not clear, leading to surgical removal of the tumor. Post-surgery, the patient was discharged in stable condition. A: The primary diagnosis is a right parieto-occipital cortical and subcortical mass lesion, likely a granulomatous infection or metastasis, with differential diagnoses including schwannoma and meningioma. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the absence of new neurological deficits post-surgery. P: The patient underwent surgical removal of the tumor, which was successful. He is advised to continue taking phenytoin 100 mg orally three times a day and Paracetamol 6 as needed for pain or discomfort. Follow-up appointments are scheduled in 2 months to monitor for any recurrence or complications.

S: The patient, a 16-year-old with a history of bilateral juvenile open-angle glaucoma (JOAG) and high myopia ( 8.0D), reports worsening vision over the past few years. The patient has a history of poorly controlled intraocular pressure (IOP) at 25 mmHg with full medication. The patient has stopped anti-glaucoma treatment a few months ago. O: Physical examination revealed normal iridocorneal angle, pachymetric measurements of 611 m in the right eye and 614 m in the left eye, axial length of 27.56 mm in the right eye, and bilateral enlarged disc cupping of the optic nerves with sectorial excavation and reduction of the neural rim in the left eye. Optical coherence tomography angiography (OCTA) indicated retinal nerve fiber layer thinning in several areas of both eyes, vascularity of the peripapillary capillaries at 43.6% in the right eye and 49.15% in the left eye. Visual field test showed progressive central scotoma in both eyes. A: The primary diagnosis is bilateral progressive central scotoma in both eyes, likely secondary to a history of JOAG and high myopia. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of glaucoma, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: Continue current anti-glaucoma treatment with adjustments to medication as necessary. Schedule an ERG to monitor the patient's condition closely. Educate the patient on the importance of reporting any changes in vision or symptoms immediately. Schedule regular follow-up appointments to monitor the patient's condition and adjust treatment as necessary.

S: The patient reports severe abdominal pain and a blockage in the intestines leading to a small bowel resection. The patient underwent a surgical procedure to replace the affected part of the descending thoracic aorta (DTA), which was surgically removed. The patient has a history of diffuse metastatic liver disease, which has been detected within three weeks of the surgery. O: Physical examination revealed a floating mass involving the descending thoracic aorta (DTA). Postoperative findings included a poorly differentiated mucinous tumor in the aorta, characterized as high-grade myxoid intimal aortic sarcoma. Postoperative recovery was slow, but the patient experienced no cerebrovascular accidents. A: The primary diagnosis is high-grade myxoid intimal aortic sarcoma of the descending thoracic aorta. The patient underwent successful surgical replacement of the DTA with full cardiopulmonary bypass under deep hypothermic circulatory arrest. The patient's overall health status and rapid decline post-surgery suggest a need for transfer to hospice care. P: The management plan includes transfer to hospice care for the patient and family to receive appropriate supportive care. The patient will be educated on the importance of adherence to the treatment plan and the importance of follow-up appointments to monitor recovery and manage any complications. Referral to a hematologist for further evaluation and management of liver disease is recommended.

S: The patient, with a history of dilated ischemic cardiomyopathy and triple coronary artery bypass grafting in 1990, reports experiencing chest pain and shortness of breath. O: Coronary angiography revealed a baseline GFR of 45 ml/min/1.73 m2, Hs-Troponin T of 497 ng/l, and CK-MB of 211 U/l. The native coronary circulation was completely occluded at the proximal segments. Tandem calcified lesions of the saphenous vein graft (SVG) on the distal right coronary artery and an ostial stenosis of the SVG on the first obtuse marginal branch were noted. The left internal mammary artery was patent. An Ad Hoc PCI of the SVG on the right coronary artery was attempted, but the non-compliant balloon (2.5 x 15mm) was unable to break the hard and calcified plaque. An elective PCI with rotational atherectomy was performed, and a drug-eluting stent (3.5  38 mm) was placed in the affected area. A: The primary diagnosis is Non-ST segment elevation myocardial infarction secondary to saphenous vein graft ostial stenosis and ostial stenosis of the SVG. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of myocardial infarctions, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The patient underwent an elective PCI with rotational atherectomy to address the ostial stenosis. The stent was placed to improve blood flow and alleviate symptoms. A drug-eluting stent (3.5  38 mm) has been placed in the affected area to improve blood flow and alleviate symptoms. The patient is advised to follow a medication regimen to prevent further complications. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor recovery and manage any complications.

S: The patient is a 42-year-old African American male with a history of diabetes, hypertension, heart failure with reduced ejection fraction, coronary arterial disease, and atrial fibrillation. He reports new onset right-sided chest pain and a lump on his chest. O: Initial ultrasound and CT scan revealed an anterior right chest mass measuring 7.5  6.5  4.8 cm, 0.6 cm deep to the skin, and a 9x9x9cm necrotic mass arising from the pectoralis major. CT-guided core biopsy was positive for high-grade spindle cell neoplasm. Two months later, the mass increased in size to 21.4  17.8  13.7 cm without evidence of metastatic disease or invasion, and MRI confirmed a 23 cm mass within the right pectoralis major without vascular or bony invasion. A: The primary diagnosis is high-grade spindle cell neoplasm of the pectoralis major. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of spindle cell neoplasms, but these are less likely given the imaging and biopsy results. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the aggressive nature of the tumor and the patient's multiple comorbidities. P: Initiated neoadjuvant chemotherapy regimen of gemcitabine and docetaxel for 2 cycles, followed by radiation therapy (50Gy over 2 months to the tumor bed + 3 cm margins). Plan to proceed with wide local surgical resection to remove the tumor en bloc with resection to the intercostal fascia, including pectoralis major and minor. The patient will undergo a wide local surgical resection for definitive therapy. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the tumor's response to treatment and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient reports experiencing cough, rhinorrhea, sore throat, and a loss of appetite. The patient denies any family history of autoimmune thyroid diseases and is not currently taking any medications. O: Vital signs include a height of 145 cm, body weight of 40.0 kg, blood pressure of 137/81 mmHg, pulse rate of 116 beats/min, and body temperature of 37.0°C. Electrocardiogram shows sinus tachycardia. Laboratory findings include a normal white cell count of 8,290 cells/L, slightly elevated C-reactive protein at 3.94 mg/dL, and alkaline phosphatase at 460 U/L. Thyroid hormone levels are elevated: free triiodothyronine at 20.27 pg/mL, free thyroxine at 6.53 ng/dL, and thyroglobulin at 183 ng/mL. Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) is undetectable. Ultrasonography of the thyroid shows heterogeneous and hypoechoic areas, suggestive of subacute thyroiditis. A: The primary diagnosis is subacute thyroiditis, evidenced by elevated thyroid hormone levels, elevated C-reactive protein, and thyroid-stimulating hormone positivity. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of thyroid dysfunction, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: Initiated a combination of prednisolone (10 mg/day) and methimazole (10 mg/day) for four weeks, followed by a discontinuation of methimazole due to worsening liver function. Continued monitoring of thyroid hormone levels and liver function is necessary, with adjustments to treatment as necessary. Regular follow-up appointments are scheduled to assess progress and adjust treatment as necessary.

S: The patient, with a history of a solitary right kidney, presented with right lower quadrant pain, nausea, vomiting, decreased urination, and dysuria. The patient denies any history of kidney stones. O: Physical examination revealed right lower quadrant tenderness and right costovertebral angle tenderness. Vital signs showed hypotension (BP 77/46), tachycardia (117 bpm), and tachypnea (22 breaths per minute). The patient was afebrile with a high leukocyte count of 24,190/L, creatinine 3.90 mg/dL, and lactic acid 7.49 mg/dL. Urinalysis showed 30 WBCs and 6 RBCs per HPF, positive leukocyte esterase, and negative nitrites. Urine culture grew Klebsiella pneumoniae. CT scan showed an atrophic left kidney and a 4 mm stone in the right ureterovesical junction causing mild hydroureteronephrosis with findings suggestive of pyelonephritis. Emergent cystoscopy with right ureteral stent placement was performed. Postoperative complications included persistent hypotension and vasopressors, with blood cultures negative for Klebsiella. URS-LL and right ureteral stent placement with a string were performed. Laser lithotripsy was performed to remove the stone. A: The primary diagnosis is a solitary right kidney infection with a 4 mm stone in the right ureterovesical junction causing mild hydroureteronephrosis and pyelonephritis. Differential diagnoses initially included sepsis, which was ruled out by negative cultures. P: The patient underwent emergent cystoscopy with right ureteral stent placement, followed by piperacillin-tazobactam for the infection. Postoperative complications included persistent hypotension and vasopressors, which were managed with IV antibiotics. The patient underwent URS-LL and right ureteral stent placement with a string. Laser lithotripsy was performed to remove the stone. The patient

S: The patient, a 20-year-old female with a history of primary amenorrhoea, reports no history of period. She has been referred to the radiology department for further evaluation. O: Physical examination revealed well developed secondary sexual features. Abdominal sonography was normal with normal upper abdominal organs. Pelvic sonography revealed complete non-visualization of the uterus, cervix, and vagina, and bilateral ovaries in bilateral inguinal canals. Doppler study showed no significant vascular compromise in either ovary. CT urography and screening MRI of the pelvis confirmed complete agenesis of the uterus, cervix, and vagina, and location of ovaries in bilateral inguinal canals. Genetic karyotyping test showed a 46XX chromosome pattern. A: The primary diagnosis is Type I MRKH syndrome, associated with bilateral ovarian hernias. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of uterine agenesis, but these are less likely given the imaging and genetic findings. P: The patient will be referred to a geneticist for further evaluation and management of Type I MRKH syndrome. She will be educated on the importance of follow-up and adherence to the treatment plan. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor her condition and adjust treatment as necessary.

S: The patient is a 15-month-old boy with no significant medical history, presenting with a scald burn from hot milk spilled on his lips, chin, neck, chest, left arm, and left foot. He reports progressive stridor and laboured breathing, initially thought to be due to sputum stasis. O: Physical examination revealed mixed deep second-degree burns to the lips, chin, neck, chest, left arm, and left foot, covering 12% of the total body surface area. The burns are distributed as follows: neck (1%), chest (4%), face (3%), foot (1%), and left arm (3%). Helicopter Emergency Medical Services (HEMS) administered intravenous rehydration and analgesics, including fentanyl and paracetamol, to manage pain management. During transport, he was considered medically stable, but his oxygen saturation dropped to 80% despite maximal supplemental oxygen via a non-rebreathing mask. An inspection revealed blistering off the lower lip, with no intra-oral redness or swelling, and no compromised circulation. Airway opening maneuvers and sputum evacuation attempted, but the stridor persisted. A: The primary diagnosis is a scald burn from hot milk spilled on his lips, chin, neck, chest, left arm, and left foot, with complications including progressive stridor and laboured breathing. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of sputum stasis, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation. P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition with regular follow-ups to assess recovery and adjust treatment as necessary. The patient will be educated on the importance of hydration and pain management to prevent further burns. Referral to a pediatric pulmonologist for further evaluation and management of sputum stasis is recommended. Regular follow-ups will be scheduled to monitor recovery and adjust treatment as necessary.

S: The patient is a 72-year-old male presenting with dysphagia. He reports difficulty swallowing. O: Gastroscopy revealed a large submucous eminence lesion approximately 18-24 cm from the incisors. CT examination revealed a 1.8 cm  5.2 cm  2.9 cm soft tissue mass in the upper esophageal wall. Endoscopic ultrasonography indicated the lesion was hypoechoic and originated from the muscularis propria with a clear boundary. An arc incision was made along the longitudinal direction of the esophagus, and a full-thickness resection was performed to achieve en bloc resection. A 20-gauge needle was used to relieve subcutaneous emphysema and a gastroduodenal decompression tube was placed. Postoperative recovery was uneventful, and no esophageal stricture was observed 2 months later. A: The primary diagnosis is leiomyoma of the upper esophageal wall. The patient's refusal to undergo invasive surgical resection and subsequent endoscopic submucosal excavation led to a decision to opt for endoscopic submucosal excavation. P: The patient underwent a full-thickness resection of the esophageal wall, which was performed with a 20-gauge needle and a gastroduodenal decompression tube. Postoperative recovery was uneventful, and no esophageal stricture was observed 2 months later. The patient is advised to maintain regular follow-up appointments and report any new symptoms or concerns.

S: The patient reports recurrent chest pain, transient syncope, sweating, fatigue, and dizziness starting approximately nine months ago. The patient has a history of recurrent periorbital nodules and a submaxillary mass over the past 12 years, with multiple surgeries for these issues. The patient denies any history of hypertension, diabetes, hepatitis, or tuberculosis, and has no history of illicit drug use. O: The patient's blood pressure is 110/61 mmHg, and electrocardiogram is normal. Physical examination revealed anemia, scars, and yellowish nodules on the skin. Blood pressure was 110/61 mmHg, and electrocardiogram was normal. A: The primary diagnosis is recurrent chest pain, transient syncope, and anemia. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of chest pain and syncope, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. The patient's history of periorbital nodules and a submaxillary mass is noted, and the patient's history of inflammatory pseudotumor, dacryoadenitis, and reactive lymph node hyperplasia are noted. P: Continue monitoring the patient's blood pressure and electrocardiogram closely. Schedule a follow-up appointment in the ER of a local hospital for further evaluation and management of the chest pain, syncope, and anemia. Educate the patient on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and adherence to follow-up appointments. Consider referral to a pulmonologist for further evaluation and management of the periorbital nodules and submaxillary mass. Ensure compliance with the treatment regimen and follow-up appointments.

S: The patient, with a history of recurrent episodes of gonococcal urethritis, presented with sudden onset of diffuse abdominal pain, described as a constant pressure starting this morning, worsening throughout the day. O: Vital signs were stable. Lab results showed leukocytosis at 11,200 and positive urinalysis. CT scan showed mild telescoping of loops of the small bowel and mesenteric fat in the left mid abdomen. Diagnostic laparoscopy indicated intussusception of the mid jejunum. Pathology confirmed marked congestion and focal reactive lymphoid hyperplasia in the lamina propria of the invaginated bowel. A: The primary diagnosis is intussusception of the mid jejunum, evidenced by imaging findings and pathology. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of abdominal pain, but these are less likely given the imaging and pathology results. P: The patient underwent open exploration, segmental resection, and primary anastomosis of the jejunum. Postoperative care instructions were followed, and the patient was discharged on postop day 2. The patient is advised to follow postoperative care instructions and report any unusual symptoms or concerns.

S: The patient, referred for prehepatic portal hypertension due to portal vein thrombosis, reports feeling alright but expresses concern about his condition. He has experienced two episodes of acute pancreatitis, with the disease onset at 9.7 years. He denies any recent injuries or other health issues. O: Abdominal ultrasound revealed chronic pancreatitis, a heterogeneous pancreas, and a dilated pancreatic duct. Genetic testing identified a heterozygous c.568G>A (p.Glu190Lys) variant in the PRSS1 gene. No other pathogenic variants were found in the susceptibility genes. A: The primary diagnosis is chronic pancreatitis with a heterozygous c.568G>A (p.Glu190Lys) variant in the PRSS1 gene. Differential diagnoses include injury, anatomical anomalies, toxic-metabolic disorders, and biliary disease. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and management of the pancreatitis. P: The management plan includes regular monitoring of the pancreas and monitoring hypertension. The patient is advised to maintain a healthy lifestyle, avoid alcohol, and eat a low-fat diet to manage his pancreatitis. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the pancreas and hypertension. The patient is encouraged to report any new symptoms or worsening of his condition immediately.

S: The patient, previously diagnosed with IgG lambda MM in November 2007, reports a relapse post-treatment with lenalidomide and dexamethasone. The patient has undergone multiple rounds of chemotherapy, including multiple rounds of lenalidomide and dexamethasone. O: The patient's CD138+ cells were analyzed, and RNA analysis revealed activation of the HDAC pathway. The HDAC inhibitor vorinostat was identified through drug repurposing. The patient's IgG levels were elevated at 2,910 mg/dL and free lambda was at 141. Since starting the treatment, IgG levels have decreased to 785 mg/dL and free lambda light chains to 19.16 mg/dL. A: The primary diagnosis is IgG lambda MM with a relapse post-treatment. The patient's IgG and lambda levels have decreased significantly, with a decrease in IgG levels to 785 mg/dL and free lambda light chains to 19.16 mg/dL. P: The treatment plan includes administration of venetoclax 400 mg PO once daily, HDAC inhibitor panobinostat 20 mg Monday, Wednesday, and Friday, and pomalidomide 2 mg Monday to Friday, 3 weeks on, 1 week off. The patient is advised to adhere strictly to the treatment schedule and report any side effects or issues. Regular follow-ups are scheduled to monitor the patient's progress and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: Sharon is a patient with a history of right shoulder pain, which started three weeks ago following a fall on a ladder. She reports intermittent pain in the right shoulder, which has been exacerbated by ice and advil use. She has been able to move the right arm but reports pain lifting overhead and raising the arm overhead. She has been using ibuprofen for the pain. She has no numbness or tingling in her arm or hand. O: Vitals are good. Physical examination shows limited active and passive range of motion, tenderness to the greater tuberosity of the humerus, no tenderness at the sternoclavicular joint, good strong bilateral hand grips, and brisk capillary refill of less than three seconds. Neurovascular examination of the right arm shows brisk capillary refill of less than three seconds, equal and bilateral response to sensation and touch. X-ray of the right shoulder reveals no fracture or bony abnormality. A: The primary diagnosis is rotator cuff tendinopathy, likely secondary to rotator cuff tendinopathy. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of rotator cuff tendinopathy, but these are less likely given the x-ray findings. P: Order an MRI of the right shoulder to confirm the diagnosis. Refer the patient to physical therapy for six to eight weeks to monitor recovery and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Continue nsaid if tolerated. Schedule a follow-up in two weeks to evaluate the patient's progress and make additional treatment plans.

S: The patient, admitted with generalized body weakness and anorexia, reports a history of hypertension and chronic kidney disease. O: Physical examination revealed severe hyponatremia with a sodium concentration of 116 mmol/L, hypokalemia with a potassium level of 2.8 mmol/L, and hypomagnesemia with a magnesium level of 1.2 mg/dL. Ionized calcium was elevated at 1.82 mmol/L (normal range: 1.00–1.30 mmol/L). Serum PTH was significantly elevated at 3071.90 pg/mL, and serum vitamin D was 35.52 ng/mL. Parathyroid scintigraphy showed decreased tracer uptake in the inferior half of the right thyroid lobe, homogeneous tracer uptake in the left lobe, and increased tracer activity in the inferior pole of the right lobe. A fainter focus of tracer uptake in a soft tissue mass on the lateral aspect of the 7th right rib was noted. A: The primary diagnosis is primary hyperparathyroidism, likely secondary to a parathyroid adenoma. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of hypoparathyroidism, but these are less likely given the imaging results and imaging findings. P: The management plan includes discussing the case with a multidisciplinary team to determine the best course of action. The patient will be closely monitored for electrolyte levels and any potential complications. Further investigations will be conducted to determine the extent of the parathyroid adenoma. The patient will be educated on the importance of follow-up and compliance with the treatment plan.

S: The patient, a female with a history of sporadic abdominal pain for approximately 2 years, aggravated over the past week. She reports sharp, frequent abdominal pain, predominantly in the left lower abdomen, with no nausea and vomiting or history of abdominal trauma. She has a congenital anomaly of the kidneys and uterus and denies menstruation. She has a history of appendectomy. O: Physical examination revealed the patient to be afebrile. Physical examination revealed a 4  5 cm mass in the left lower quadrant, with no rebound tenderness or muscle rigidity. Laboratory tests showed a white blood cell count of 7.13  109/L, neutrophilic granulocytes of 76.8%, hemoglobin of 120 g/L, and platelet count of 322  109/L. CT and abdominal laparotomy identified an intestinal stromal tumor and pelvic kidneys. Digestive tract radiography indicated possible extraintestinal involvement. Abdominal laparotomy showed normal intestinal tract, but a mass in the sigmoid flexure was exophytic without infiltration, measuring 6.0  5.0  3.0 cm. Colon anastomosis confirmed a solitary fibrous tumor (SFT). A: The primary diagnosis is an ectopic ovary with corpora lutea bleeding. Differential diagnosis initially included other causes of abdominal pain, but these were ruled out based on imaging and laboratory findings. P: The patient underwent successful colon anastomosis, confirming the diagnosis of an ectopic ovary with corpora lutea bleeding. Post-operative management included regular follow-ups to monitor recovery and detect any recurrence. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms immediately. Further consultations with oncology and gastroenterology are recommended to manage her congenital anomalies.

S: The patient reports a month-long history of right lumbago. The patient underwent B mode ultrasonography, which revealed a lower echo mass in the lower pole of the right kidney. The tumor was 5.4  4.8 cm, with an irregular shape and no clear boundary, and uneven internal echo. A middle abdomen plain and enhanced CT scan showed a round tumor of 5.2  4.9 cm with a clear boundary and uneven density. A laparoscopic radical nephrectomy was performed to remove the tumor. Immunohistochemistry tests were positive for HMB45, Melan-A, S100, Ki67, and TFE3. A: The primary diagnosis is a translocation of XP11.2 tumor associated with pigment differentiation, with low malignant biological behavior. The tumor was successfully removed with no recurrence after 3 months. P: The patient underwent a laparoscopic radical nephrectomy to remove the tumor. Post-operative management includes regular follow-ups to monitor for any recurrence or new symptoms. The patient is advised to maintain a healthy lifestyle and adhere to follow-up schedules to ensure continued health.

S: The patient, a chef at an Indian restaurant, reports an accident involving the middle, ring, and little fingers on the left hand, which required amputation. The fingers were unable to be replanted, leading to amputations of the middle and ring fingers at the level of the proximal phalanx and of the little finger at the middle phalanx. Six months post-injury, the patient has been referred for hand reconstruction. O: The patient's preoperative visual analogue scale (VAS) score was 4/10, indicating phantom pain post-amputations, and Quick-DASH was 81.82/100.00. Foot vascularity examination with contrast-enhanced computed tomography indicated bilateral STT compatible for reconstruction of two fingers. A: The primary diagnosis is bilateral STT for hand reconstruction. The patient's history of a meat chopper injury and subsequent amputations are consistent with this diagnosis. P: The management plan includes transferring bilateral second toes to the middle and ring fingers. The procedure will involve a curved incision over the volar surface of the distal middle and ring fingers, identification of the digital artery, digital nerve, and flexor digitorum profundus on the volar side, and dissections on both the dorsal and plantar sides to identify key structures like the extensor digitorum longus, flexor digitorum longus, and proper palmer digital nerves. The second toe will be transferred to the middle and ring fingers, reconnecting the blood vessels, nerves, and tendons. Physical therapy will be conducted to manage pain and manage pain. The patient will be closely monitored for progress and any new symptoms.

S: The patient is a 19-year-old Japanese woman who underwent root canal treatment on tooth #47 in 2005, presenting with dull pain since the extraction of tooth #48 in August 2010. She reports no improvement post-extraction but concerns about the expansion of the right posterior mandibular bone. She has a low BMI of 17.0. O: Intraoral radiography revealed insufficient root canal filling in the distal root and a foreign body suspected to be extruded gutta-percha outside the apex of the mesial root of tooth #47, along with bone absorption around both roots. Post-extraction, the patient experienced purulent discharge from the pocket of tooth #47. Intraoral radiography showed insufficient root canal filling in the distal root and a foreign body suspected to be extruded gutta-percha outside the apex of the mesial root of tooth #47, along with bone absorption around both roots. Panoramic radiography showed new bone formation at the equivalent sites of teeth #48 and #47, a radiolucent region around the distal root of tooth #46, continuous absorption from the alveolar bone of the distal root of tooth #46 to the lingual cortical bone at the equivalent of tooth #47, and six granulated hard tissues. MRI showed low intensity in the right lower molar region. A: The primary diagnosis is a recurrent infection of the right posterior mandibular bone, likely secondary to the extraction of tooth #48. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of mandibular pain, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The management plan will include close monitoring of the patient's condition and symptom reporting. The patient will be educated on the importance of reporting any new symptoms or changes in her condition. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess the effectiveness of the treatment and adjust the plan as necessary. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms immediately.

S: The patient, a male with a history of sarcoidosis and respiratory tract infections, presented with a 2-day history of right-sided lower abdominal pain. He reported nausea, anorexia, nausea, and no vomiting, diarrhea, or rectal bleeding. He denies any urinary or gynecological symptoms. O: Vital signs on presentation showed a pulse rate of 76 bpm, blood pressure of 110/70 mmHg, and respiratory rate of 14 breaths per minute. Physical examination revealed marked tenderness in the RIF with rebound tenderness and localized guarding, with normal bowel sounds. Blood tests showed a WCC of 7.1 and CRP of 16.6. Renal and liver function tests were normal. Urinalysis was normal, and the pregnancy test was negative. CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis revealed an epiploic appendagitis of the caecum with mild surrounding pericaecal fat stranding. A: The primary diagnosis is acute appendicitis, likely exacerbated by sarcoidosis and respiratory tract infections. Differential diagnosis initially included acute appendicitis, which was ruled out based on imaging and clinical findings. P: The patient was admitted for observation and further testing. The management plan included conservative analgesia and antibiotics for 2 days, followed by a follow-up visit to assess recovery and manage any recurrence of symptoms. The patient was discharged from surgical care due to no recurrence of symptoms.

S: The patient, a second-born child, reports a history of neonatal respiratory distress syndrome, neonatal respiratory distress syndrome, micrognathia, glossoptosis, cleft palate, triphalangeal thumbs, congenital perimebranous ventricular defect, and a congenital perimebranous ventricular defect. The patient has a history of inherited hyporigenerative anemia, which required regular blood transfusion therapy. O: The patient was born at 38 weeks post-natural childbirth, weighing 2.1 kg, with typical PRS features including micrognathia, glossoptosis, cleft palate, triphalangeal thumbs, and a congenital perimebranous ventricular defect without haemodynamic effects. Neurodevelopmental delays were noted, including head control at 4-5 months, ability to sit at 11 months, standing unassisted at 13 months, and learning to walk precariously at 20 months. The patient's verbal language development was poor at that time. Genetic characterization of congenital anemia revealed a de novo chromosomal deletion involving RPS26, confirming DBA. Clinical examination at age 21 revealed a peculiar face, skeletal abnormalities in a complex malformation syndrome, and a mental deficiency.
