A: The primary diagnosis is inherited hyporigenerative anemia, evidenced by genetic findings and clinical presentation. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of congenital anomalies, but these are less likely given the genetic findings and clinical presentation. P: Continue regular monitoring of the patient's condition with regular blood transfusions. Educate the patient on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and reporting any new symptoms. Schedule regular follow-up appointments to monitor the patient's condition and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Ensure the patient understands the importance of compliance with the treatment regimen and follow-up schedules.

S: The patient, admitted in July 2018 with heaviness in the right hypochondrium, reports a history of curative surgery for endometrial cancer in 2010 with hysterosalpingooophorectomy and greater omentum resection. Post-surgery, the patient underwent radiation and chemotherapy with a total of 40 Gy for the pelvis, 20 Gy for the vaginal stump, and three courses of cyclophosphamide, adriamycin, and 5-fluorouracil. In May 2018, the patient experienced new dull pain in the right hypochondrium. O: Abdominal ultrasound revealed a liver lesion. Contrast-enhanced MDCT of the chest and abdomen showed a large, well-circumscribed tumor in the SVIII of the liver. positron emission tomography combined with computed tomography indicated a large, hypermetabolic lesion of the right hemidiaphragm measuring 11.4  13.5  10.7 cm. A: The primary diagnosis is a large, hypermetabolic lesion of the right hemidiaphragm, likely from the diaphragm, with associated liver invasion. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of heaviness, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The patient underwent video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery, which was converted to open right lateral thoracotomy due to the lesion's size and proximity to the right liver lobe. Post-operative management includes close monitoring of the patient's progress and discussing any concerns with the multidisciplinary team. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess the effectiveness of the treatment and manage any complications.

S: The patient reports chronic inflammation around teeth #24, #25, and #34, with endodontic treatments on tooth #16. The patient expresses concern about the pain and hopelessness of tooth #12, which is causing significant pain. O: The patient has a history of chronic inflammation around teeth #24, #25, and #34, and has undergone endodontic treatments on tooth #16. The patient has a preference for an implant fixed restoration in a single-staged approach, with bone augmentation, sinus floor elevation in the second quadrant, and implant placement in regions #12, #16, #18, #24, #26, #28, #35, #37, #46, and #48. Post-extraction, a 7-mm bone ring will be used to fix the graft with an Ankylos Implant. The posterior maxilla will be treated with immediate implant placement in tooth #24, a 7-mm bone ring fixed with a dental implant in tooth #26, and external sinus floor elevation, including implant placement in tooth #28. A: The primary diagnosis is advanced bone loss in the posterior maxilla, specifically tooth #12, with complications including palatal and buccal bone loss. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of bone loss, but these are less likely given the patient's history and surgical findings. P: The management plan includes a single-staged approach with bone augmentation, sinus floor elevation in the second quadrant, and implant placement in regions #12, #16, #18, #24, #28, #35, #37, #46, and #48. The patient will be educated on the procedure, post-procedure, and follow-up requirements. The patient is advised to have a discussion with their dentist and consent prior to the procedure to ensure proper preparation and follow-up.

S: The patient is a 73-year-old male with a history of significant asbestos exposure and recurrent diverticulitis. He presents with persistent left lower quadrant pain, which has not improved since previous hospitalization. O: Previous CT scan showed fluid near the sigmoid colon, suggesting nonspecific colitis. Repeat CT scan showed possible nodularity of the mesentery. PET scan showed multiple hypermetabolic mesenteric lesions in the left paracolic gutter and pelvis, favored by carcinomatosis. Colonoscopy showed no luminal lesions. Tumor marker serology was negative. Exploratory laparoscopy revealed extensive peritoneal carcinomatosis involving all mesenteric surfaces and partial involvement of the right diaphragm. Pathology confirmed malignant epithelial mesothelioma with peritoneal seeding. A: The primary diagnosis is malignant epithelial mesothelioma with peritoneal seeding. Differential diagnosis initially included nonspecific colitis, which was ruled out by imaging and biopsy. P: The patient underwent sigmoid colon resection with diverting colostomy for symptomatic relief. The treatment plan includes hyperthermic intraperitoneal chemotherapy (HIPEC) and cytoreductive surgery (CRS). The patient has been referred to oncology for further evaluation and management. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately.

S: The patient presented with a lack of defecation. The patient underwent a colonoscopy revealing a circumferential tumor in the lower rectum, 45 mm from the anal verge, diagnosed as stage IIIb rectal cancer, specifically cT4bN2M0. The tumor was treated with XELOX plus bevacizumab as neoadjuvant therapy (NAT) and a SEMS bridge to surgery (BTS). Postoperatively, the patient was discharged 20 days post-surgery, and XELOX was started as adjuvant chemotherapy 5 weeks post-surgery. The patient has been alive without recurrence for 17 months. O: Colonoscopy revealed a circumferential tumor in the lower rectum, 45 mm from the anal verge, diagnosed as stage IIIb rectal cancer, cT4bN2M0. Postoperative findings included circumferential luminal narrowing in the lower rectum, smooth and edematous stenosis, and successful Laparoscopic low anterior resection with diverting ileostomy. Histopathologically, the chemotherapeutic effect was grade 2, indicating a positive response. Postoperative course was uneventful, and the patient was discharged 20 days post-surgery. A: The primary diagnosis is stage IIIb rectal cancer of the lower rectum, cT4bN2M0. The patient underwent successful surgical intervention with XELOX and bevacizumab. The prognosis is favorable with a successful surgical approach. P: Continue monitoring the patient's response to XELOX and bevacizumab. Continue adjuvant chemotherapy 5 weeks post-surgery to reduce the risk of recurrence. Regular follow-up appointments are scheduled to assess the effectiveness of the treatment and adjust as necessary. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately.

S: The patient, a 20-day-old baby girl, presented to the neonatal intensive care unit with a chief complaint of poor oral intake. The patient has been unable to swallow 10-20 mL of formula for the past two days, and has been changing diapers 10 to 14 times per day. The parent reports no vomiting or diarrhea. The baby was born at 38+2 weeks of gestation with a weight of 3380 g via cesarean section. No abnormal findings during the prenatal and immediate postnatal periods were noted. O: On admission, the patient's weight was 3100 g, length 53 cm, head circumference 36 cm. Vital signs were normal for her age, with a heart rate of 150 beats/min, blood pressure 78/50 mmHg, respiratory rate 48 breaths/min, and body temperature 36.5 °C. Physical examination revealed dry lips, prolonged capillary refill time 5–6 seconds, both thumbs in palms, frontal bossing, prominent upper lip, high arched palate, sparse frontal scalp hair, and bilateral 5th finger clinodactyly. Capillary blood gas analysis showed severe metabolic acidosis with a pH of 7.16, pCO2 28.3 mmHg, pO2 42 mmHg, HCO3 17.3 mmol/L, and base excess 17.3 mmol/L. Laboratory tests showed serum sodium at 113.3 mEq/L and serum potassium at 8.79 mEq/L. A: The primary diagnosis is severe metabolic acidosis with complications including severe metabolic acidosis and dehydration. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of dehydration, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and laboratory findings. P: The patient was administered 20 mL/kg of normal saline intravenously for over 1 hour. The patient will continue to be monitored in the neonatal intensive care unit, with adjustments to the saline dosage as necessary based on the patient's response to the treatment. Regular follow-ups will be scheduled to monitor the baby's condition and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient, a male, presented with worsening left upper quadrant abdominal pain radiating to the left shoulder, which began the day after an outpatient colonoscopy. He reports no active extravasation. O: Initial CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis showed a grade III splenic injury without active extravasation. Initial hemoglobin was 9 grams per deciliter, decreased to 7.4 grams per deciliter over 24 hours. An angiography revealed a subcapsular blush, indicating a need for splenic artery embolization using interlocking coils. Post-angiography, hemoglobin levels stabilized. A: The primary diagnosis is a grade III splenic injury with no active extravasation. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of abdominal pain, but these are less likely given the imaging and angiography results. P: The patient was admitted to the intensive care unit for close monitoring and treatment. Post-operative care included splenic artery embolization using interlocking coils, which stabilized hemoglobin levels. The patient is expected to be discharged the following day with instructions to monitor for any complications.

S: The patient, a car electrician, presented to the emergency room following an accident on a hoverboard and falling on his right shoulder. He denies any routine medications or allergies. He was advised to return in 2 weeks for a standard follow-up examination to assess the fracture and the locking plate. He experienced a breaking sound when he picked up a grocery bag with two packs of sugar, 1 kg each, and felt his shoulder falling down. O: Initial X-ray showed a displaced comminuted right middle third clavicle fracture with clavicle shortening. Intraoperative and postoperative imaging were performed. Postoperative findings included a fixation clavicle plate with a displacement of the fracture. A second X-ray showed breakage of the fixation clavicle plate and displacement of the fracture. A: The primary diagnosis is a displaced comminuted right middle third clavicle fracture with clavicle shortening. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of clavicle fractures, but these are less likely given the imaging and surgical findings. P: The management plan includes surgical intervention with a right-sided Acumed Locking Clavicle Plate with superior approach to the clavicle. Postoperative care will include analgesia, immobilization in a sling, and physical therapy with restricted range of motion of  80° abduction. The patient will continue physical therapy with restricted range of motion of  80° abduction. A repeat X-ray will be performed to reassess the fracture and the locking plate. A cancellous bone graft will be used to refill the fracture site. The broken plate will be sent for inspection.

S: The patient, with a history of asthma, presented with severe respiratory distress and was initially managed in the ICU for status asthmaticus. However, complications included bilateral segmental pulmonary embolism (PE), mild RV dilatation, and normal RV function. The patient underwent a percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) tube placement and anticoagulation for one day. Post-PEG placement, the patient developed acute hypotension with systolic blood pressures between 70 and 80 mmHg. CPR was performed for 6 minutes and managed with CPR. Arterial blood gas showed a pH of 7.05 and pCO2 of 77 mmHg. Follow-up TTE showed severe decreased RV function with bulging of the interventricular septum into the left ventricle. Treatment included 10 mg of norepinephrine, 2.4 mL/hr of vasopressin, 300 mcg/min of phenylephrine, 5 mcg/kg/min of dobutamine, and 40 ppm inhaled nitric oxide. Follow-up TTE showed severe decreased RV function with bulging of the interventricular septum into the left ventricle. A: The primary diagnosis is bilateral segmental pulmonary embolism secondary to critical illness polymyoneuropathy. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of respiratory distress, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation. The prognosis is guarded due to the severity of the PE and severe RV strain. P: The patient was treated with low molecular weight heparin, tracheostomy, and anticoagulation for one day. Post-procedure, the patient was transferred back to the ICU for further evaluation and management. The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition with regular follow-ups to assess progress and adjust treatment as necessary. The patient is advised to adhere strictly to follow-up appointments and follow-up schedules.

S: The patient reports increasing asthenia, described as extremely weak and tired. O: Physical examination revealed severe anemia with a hemoglobin level of 7.3 g/dL, white blood cell count reduced to 2400/L, severe neutropenia with neutrophils at 600/L, and normal platelet count at 168,000/L. Diagnostic tests revealed B-ALL with normal karyotype, negative for BCR-ABL rearrangement, and immature B-cell origin. CT-scan revealed a 7.0 cm solid lesion on the inferior pole of the right kidney, confirmed as clear cell carcinoma. Post-chemotherapy, MRD negativity was maintained, but blasts were noted at the peripheral blood smear. PET-CT showed multiple lesions, including a large pancreatic one. Pancreatic endoscopic biopsy identified CD19+ and CD22+ lymphoid cells, characteristics of B-ALL. A: The primary diagnosis is B-ALL with EM-ALL localizations. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of renal cancer, but these are less likely given the imaging and biopsy results. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the positive CD22 positivity of the blast cells. P: The patient will continue with Inotuzumab ozogamicin (IO) weekly to manage B-ALL. The treatment plan includes regular follow-ups to monitor for any recurrence or complications. The patient will be educated on the importance of adherence to the treatment regimen and the importance of follow-up appointments.

S: The patient reports severe headaches and fatigue. The patient denies any history of smoking, alcohol, diabetes, or atherosclerosis. The patient has been on antihypertensive medication for the past 8 months, and has been referred for a renal angiogram due to uncontrolled hypertension. O: Physical examination was unremarkable. Neurological examination showed alertness, attentiveness, and oriented. Speech was clear and fluent with good repetition, comprehension, and naming. No pronator drift of outstretched arms was noted. Muscle bulk, tone, reflexes, and sensory were normal. Coordination and gait were normal. Laboratory tests showed a normal complete blood count, cholesterol, lipid profile, and renal function with a serum creatinine of 119 mol/L. The left kidney size was 9.6 cm by 4.8 cm. Renal Doppler ultrasound confirmed renal artery stenosis with a renal resistive index of 0.58. Initial imaging indicated left renal artery stenosis. A: The primary diagnosis is left renal artery stenosis, likely secondary to uncontrolled hypertension, given the patient's history of antihypertensive medication and imaging findings. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of hypertension, but these are less likely given the imaging results and clinical presentation. P: Continue current antihypertensive medications and attend follow-up appointments to monitor the patient's response to treatment and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Educate the patient on the importance of medication adherence and regular monitoring of blood pressure. Encourage the patient to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately.

S: The patient is a 74-year-old male with a history of hypertension, cystolitholapaxy for bilateral ureteral stones, and is currently on losartan and hydrochlorothiazide. He reports a mild productive cough. He denies any drug allergies. O: Pre-operative chest radiograph showed a normal picture. Echocardiogram indicated normal left ventricular function. Pre-operative vital signs were within normal limits with a heart rate of 74 bpm, blood pressure of 168/85 mmHg, respiration rate of 18 times per minute, and oxygen saturation of 94% on room air. General anesthesia was administered with remifentanil (3 ng/mL), lidocaine (20 mg), propofol 180 mg, and succinylcholine 80 mg. Oral tracheal intubation was performed using a 7.5 mm endotracheal tube with a video-assisted intubating stylet. Mechanical ventilation was controlled with a tidal volume of 500 mL, respiratory rate of 10 times per minute, and positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 4 cmH2O. Sevoflurane at an end-expiration concentration was 2%. An arterial line was established through a radial artery for continuous beat-to-beat monitoring. A: The primary diagnosis is mouth floor squamous cell carcinoma of the mouth. The patient's history of hypertension, cystolitholapaxy, and bilateral ureteral stones complicate the surgical process. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of squamous cell carcinoma, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation. P: The patient underwent a tumor-wide excision, mandibulotomy, tracheostomy, and free flap reconstruction due to mouth floor squamous cell carcinoma. Post-operative care will include close monitoring of vital signs, adjustment of anesthesia as necessary, and follow-up care to monitor recovery and manage any complications. The patient will be educated on the importance of adhering to post-operative care instructions and adherence to follow-up care instructions.

S: The patient, a 14-year-old female, reports a history of microscopic hematuria, proteinuria, and hypocomplementemia, which began at age 10 and continued to worsen. She denies any edema or hypertension at that time. She has a history of nephrotic syndrome and has no history of systemic lupus erythematosus, thrombotic microangiopathy, or malignancies. She has been diagnosed with MPGN type I, treated with Prednisolone 60 mg (2 mg/kg/day) for 4 weeks, gradually reduced to 15 mg on alternate days over a 1-year period, and decreased urinary protein excretion to 2+ by dipstick. She has been treated with Prednisolone and dipyridamole for MPGN type I. O: The patient's serum albumin level was 2.5 g/dL, urinary protein excretion was 3.4 g/day, and normal blood pressure and renal function. Renal biopsy at 11 years old showed increased mesangial cells and matrix with a lobular pattern of glomeruli and thick glomerular capillary walls with double contours. Masson trichrome stain showed subendothelial and mesangial deposits. Immune-enzyme method (PAP) showed lumpy C3 deposits along glomerular capillaries, weak staining of IgA, IgG, and IgM, but no glomeruli were included for electron microscopic studies. Anti-DNA antibody, hepatitis B virus antigen, hepatitis C virus antibody, and cryoglobulins were negative. The patient was diagnosed with MPGN type I, treated with Prednisolone 60 mg (2 mg/kg/day) for 4 weeks, gradually reduced to 15 mg on alternate days over a 1-year period, and decreased urinary protein excretion to 2+ by dipstick. A follow-up renal biopsy at 14 years of age showed 18 glomeruli. A: The primary diagnosis is MPGN type I, with differential diagnoses including systemic lupus erythematosus, thrombotic microangiopathy, and

S: The patient presented with a generalized tonic-clonic seizure and reported feeling weakness on the left side. The patient has a history of a benign breast lesion. O: Physical examination revealed mild left pyramidal hemiparesis and upper motor neuron signs. Brain MRI showed a 16-mm right parafalcine, extra-axial lesion with homogenous contrast enhancement, and surrounding vasogenic edema in adjacent parietal and posterior frontal white matter. CT scan showed pretracheal and precarinal lymphadenopathy, but no primary lesion elsewhere. Parasagittal craniotomy and Simpson grade-two excision of the tumor were performed, and a small component of residual tumor was left. Histological examination confirmed neoplastic cells with moderately pleomorphic nuclei, spindle in outline, occasional plump and polygonal forms, eosinophilic cytoplasm, low mitotic rate (4/10 HPFs), and a well-developed and prominent peripheral lymphoid cuff. Immunohistochemical analysis was positive for desmin, anaplastic lymphoma kinase 1 (ALK1), vimentin, and epithelial membrane antigen (EMA). A: The primary diagnosis is atypical meningioma with differential diagnoses including inflammatory myofibroblastic tumor (IMT). The lesion was referred for international consultation due to the difficulty in resolving the differential diagnosis. P: The patient underwent a parasagittal craniotomy and Simpson grade-two excision of the tumor. Post-surgery, the patient was monitored for neurological deficits and was advised to continue regular follow-up appointments. Further diagnostic workup may be necessary depending on the final diagnosis and response to treatment.

S: The patient, referred to the Department of Gynecology, reports experiencing abdominal pain for the past 2 weeks. No other symptoms were reported. O: Ultrasonography of the pelvis revealed a large mass extending from the right side of the uterine body to the adnexal region, with a solid, hypoechoic mass with sound attenuation. Serum levels of carcinoembryonic antigen, carbohydrate antigen 19-9, and carbohydrate antigen 125 were within normal limits. CT and MRI revealed a large solid mass with cystic areas. T1-weighted MRI showed high signal intensity relative to the myometrium, T2-weighted MRI showed low signal intensity, and diffusion-weighted imaging showed high signal intensity relative to the endometrium. Early-phase contrast-enhanced fat-saturated T1-weighted imaging showed marked high signal intensity, and delayed-phase contrast-enhanced 3D fat-saturated T1-weighted imaging showed slightly high signal intensity. Microscopy examination revealed multiple small cystic spaces containing mucinous fluid or hemorrhage, ovarian stromal intervening fibrous tissues, and multiple vascular spaces. Mucus-producing tumor cells with moderate atypia were noted in the papillary-structured architecture. A: The primary diagnosis is endometrioma with a related malignant tumor, possibly clear cell carcinoma or endometrioid carcinoma. Differential diagnoses could include other malignant tumors, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The patient underwent a right adnexectomy to remove the mass, measuring 12  9  7 cm, with a yellowish-white cut surface, cystic component containing dark yellow fluid, smooth internal surface, and almost solid component. Microscopy examination revealed multiple small cystic spaces containing mucinous fluid or hemorrhage, ovarian stromal intervening fibrous tissues, and multiple vascular spaces. Mucus-producing tumor cells with moderate atypia were noted in the papillary-structured architecture. A: The primary diagnosis is endometrioma with a related

S: The patient reports a painless mass on the head under the midline parietal-occipital scalp for approximately a year. The mass is under the midline parietal-occipital scalp. O: A plain radiograph revealed erosion of the skull bone underneath the mass. MRI revealed a large parasagittal tumor with homogenous contrast enhancement and a large parasagittal tumor with homogenous contrast enhancement. An angiography indicated dense stains with distorted vessels in the same location. Post-surgery, the tumor was dark-reddish in color and rubbery in texture, with invasion through the skull. Histopathology confirmed a plasmacytic type plasmacytoma with positive lambda stain. Systemic oncological evaluations showed no residual tumor, other skeletal involvement, or tumor cells in the bone marrow biopsy. The patient has no anemia, hypercalcaemia, or renal impairment due to plasma cell dyscrasia. A: The primary diagnosis is a plasmacytic type plasmacytoma of the head, a benign tumor with no residual tumor, other skeletal involvement, or tumor cells. Differential diagnoses could include other benign tumors or metastatic tumors, but histopathology and histopathology support the primary diagnosis. P: The patient underwent total tumor resection with no radiotherapy. The plan includes close monitoring of the patient's progress and no further radiotherapy. The patient is advised to maintain regular follow-up appointments to monitor for any recurrence or systemic progression.

S: The patient is a 75-year-old female with a 30 pack-year history of smoking, presenting with fatigue, cough, and weight loss. She reports a history of smoking and has a 30 pack-year history of smoking. O: Chest CT revealed an 8.6 cm right upper lobe lesion with mediastinal invasion, extensive cervical and mediastinal adenopathy, and a malignant pericardial effusion. Biopsy confirmed squamous cell carcinoma, stage IV cT3N3M1b. Treatment included palliative PT-DC with carboplatin and gemcitabine, maintenance gemcitabine, and palliative radiotherapy. Combination immunotherapy with PD-L1 and CTLA-4 antibody therapy was initiated, but histopathology did not reveal PD-L1 expression on tumor cells. Post-treatment oligo-progressive disease in a celiac lymph node was resected, followed by recurrence of disease. A: The primary diagnosis is poorly-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of the right upper lobe, stage IV cT3N3M1b. Differential diagnosis initially included other forms of lung cancer, but biopsy confirmed poorly-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma. The prognosis is guarded due to the aggressive nature of the disease and the patient's history of smoking. P: Continue close monitoring of the patient's lung cancer status and manage hypercalcemia. Continue combination immunotherapy with PD-L1 and CTLA-4 antibody therapy. Maintain image-guided locoregional therapy for the aortocaval lymph node. Regular follow-up appointments are necessary to monitor the patient's response to treatment and detect any recurrence. Educate the patient on the importance of reporting any new symptoms or changes in her condition.

S: The patient reports a burning sensation on the right side of the tongue for approximately a month. The patient has a 30-year history of chewing betel nuts, consuming 10 betel nuts daily. The patient has a family history of oral cancer, which his father passed away 15 years ago. O: Intraoral examination revealed a tender, firm, 2  2.5 cm ulcero-proliferative growth at the right lateral border of the tongue, normal tongue movements, and a single 1  1 cm tender, firm, ovoid lymph node in the right submandibular region. Contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CECT) confirmed infiltrating squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) involving the right lateral border of the tongue, stage III - T2 N1 M0. A: The primary diagnosis is infiltrating squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) of the right lateral border of the tongue, stage III - T2 N1 M0. Differential diagnosis initially included proliferative verrucous leukoplakia, which was ruled out based on imaging and biopsy results. P: The management plan includes discussing treatment options for infiltrating squamous cell carcinoma, stage III - T2 N1 M0, with no evidence of distant metastasis. The patient will be educated on the nature of the disease, treatment options, and expected outcomes. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's response to treatment and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient reports a fever starting on the forearms and spreading to the lower extremities, shoulder, and back. The rash has been present for 4 days. The patient also mentions a dry cough and mild itching on the chest. O: Laboratory examination revealed a WBC count of 16.7  103/L (normal: 103/L) and an AEC of 1600 cells/L. Biopsy of the lesions in the posterior right arm showed dermal edema and subepidermal vesicle with fibrin and irregular brown pigmentation in the epidermis. Coccidioidal serology indicated weakly reactive ID-IgM and ID-IgG with a CF antibody titer of less than 1:2. Chest X-ray showed bilateral infiltrates worsening on the left lower lobe. A: The primary diagnosis is a maculopapular rash with respiratory involvement. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of rash, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and laboratory findings. P: The patient is advised to rest, stay hydrated, and take over-the-counter fever reducers and antihistamines to manage fever and itching. If symptoms worsen or do not improve after 2 weeks, the patient is advised to return for further evaluation.

S: The patient reports experiencing a popping sensation followed by heat and pressure at the base of the skull, which began at age five, occurring when suddenly rotating the head. The patient experiences numbness in the back of the tongue and difficulty speaking for approximately 15 seconds. The sensations occur approximately five to 10 times a year, with a reduction in frequency as the patient gets older. The sensations occur more frequently during competitive fencing and military training. The patient denies any significant past medical, surgical, or developmental issues during birth. O: Physical and neurologic examinations including cranial nerve exam were normal. MRI of the cervical spine revealed slight dysplastic enlargement of the anterior arch of the C1 vertebrae, mild degenerative changes of the atlantoaxial junction, and a lower end of normal spinal canal caliber. No abnormal bone spurring or hypoglossal canal abnormalities were noted. A: The primary diagnosis is a traumatic brain injury (TBI) likely secondary to traumatic brain injury, likely secondary to traumatic brain injury. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of traumatic brain injury, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The management plan includes continued monitoring of the patient's neurological status and symptom progression. The patient is advised to return for a follow-up if symptoms worsen or new symptoms appear. Further consultations with a neurologist and a neurologist may be necessary depending on the patient's response to the treatment.

S: The patient is a 33-year-old male with no comorbidities, presenting with a chief complaint of a fever of 39.5°C, paresthesia in the feet, difficulty walking and speaking, and a fall from his own height on June 28th. He reports difficulty walking and speaking, difficulty walking and speaking, and persistent muscular pain. O: Initial laboratory tests showed hemoglobin at 14.0 g/dL, creatinine at 0.72 mg/dL, and other normal levels. Serology confirmed Zika virus IgG antibodies. On June 30th, the patient developed acute respiratory insufficiency type II, necessitating sedate and mechanical ventilation with a pressure controlled mode (PCV). Cerebrospinal fluid showed increased protein levels (191mg/dL) with a normal cell count, consistent with Guillain-Barré syndrome. Blood cultures for bacteria, fungi, and serological tests for toxoplasmosis, herpes, varicella, and HIV were negative. During his stay in the ICU, 0.4g/kg intravenous immunoglobulin was administered for 5 days, and septic shock of undetermined focus was treated with vasoactive amines and intravenous antimicrobial agents. A: The primary diagnosis is Guillain-Barré syndrome, complicated by acute respiratory insufficiency type II and septic shock of undetermined focus. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of acute respiratory insufficiency, but these are less likely given the positive serology results. P: Continue monitoring the patient's response to treatment and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Maintain orotracheal intubation until the beginning of the weaning process, and monitor the patient's neurological status closely. Educate the patient on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and adherence to follow-up appointments. Consider referral to a neurologist for further evaluation and management of Guillain-Barré syndrome.

S: The patient reports feeling alright, but is nervous about the surgery. The patient has a history of uncontrolled hypertension, leading to the discovery of an infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) with dissection extending distally involving both common iliac arteries. O: The patient underwent an endovascular treatment with the Endologix AFX2 bifurcated AAA endograft system, which was successfully implanted without complications. The stent-graft was patent at the 12-month follow-up without evidence of endoleak. A: The primary diagnosis is a 3.2cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm with dissection extending distally involving both common iliac arteries. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the successful endovascular treatment. P: The patient is advised to continue monitoring blood pressure and manage hypertension. Regular follow-up appointments are scheduled to monitor the aneurysm and aneurysm. The patient is advised to maintain a healthy lifestyle and prepare for prostate surgery.

S: The patient reports experiencing central vision loss in the right eye for approximately 2 weeks. The patient denies any previous medical issues or family history of eye problems. O: Initial best-corrected visual acuity was 1.2 OU with no refractive error. Funduscopic examination revealed a wedge-shaped dark reddish lesion at the macula in the right eye but no abnormal findings in the left eye. SLO infrared imaging showed a dark area corresponding to the dark reddish lesion in the right eye. EDI-OCT showed loss or disruption of the interdigitation zone (IZ) at the macula in the right eye but normal findings in the left eye. Fluorescein angiography showed hypofluorescence corresponding to the lesion in both eyes, while indocyanine green angiography showed initial geographic hypofluorescence corresponding to the AMN lesion in both eyes, but the finding became obscured at the late phase. Fundus autofluorescence (FAF) showed faint hypo-autofluorescence corresponding to the lesion in both eyes. Humphrey threshold 10–2 perimetry showed decreased central sensitivity corresponding to the lesion. A: The primary diagnosis is AMN in the right eye, evidenced by the presence of a wedge-shaped dark reddish lesion at the macula in the right eye and disruption of the IZ at the fovea in the left eye. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of central vision loss, but these are less likely given the imaging findings. P: The patient was initially diagnosed with AMN in the right eye, which was ruled out based on imaging and clinical findings. The treatment plan included monitoring the patient's condition without specific treatment, with close monitoring of the lesion's progression and recovery of the macular structure. The patient is advised to return immediately if any changes in vision occur. Regular follow-ups will be scheduled to monitor the condition and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient reports experiencing flatulence and epigastric discomfort over the past few months. The patient denies any history of illness, family history of illness, smoking, alcohol use, or medication use. O: On admission, the patient was afebrile with normal neurological examination. Blood pressure was 126/84 mmHg, pulses were 75-80 beats/minute, and temperature was 36.8 °C. Laboratory tests showed elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate, C-reactive protein, and lactate dehydrogenase levels, indicating inflammation and tissue necrosis. CT scan showed a large mass measuring approximately 24 cm in its greatest dimension (23.7 cm  16.5 cm  11.5 cm), compressing the right hepatic lobe and inferior vena cava. Functional adrenal work-up including serum aldosterone, potassium, renin, adrenocorticotrophic hormone levels, dexamethasone suppression test, and 24-hour urinary metanephrine levels were within normal limits. Fine-needle core biopsy confirmed adrenal cortical carcinoma (ACC). Metastatic work-ups of the head and chest and bone scans were negative for metastases. Postoperative pathology confirmed ACC. A: The primary diagnosis is adrenal cortical carcinoma (ACC) of the right adrenal gland, confirmed by biopsy and metastatic work-up. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of adrenal cancer, but these are less likely given the imaging and biopsy results. P: The patient underwent a laparotomy to remove the tumor with its own capsule. No further adjuvant treatment is necessary at this time. The patient is advised to contact healthcare providers if any concerns or questions arise during the postoperative course. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's recovery and adjust treatment as necessary.

S: George Smith, a landscaper, presents with numbness and tingling in his fingers and pain in his left wrist. He reports the pain at night, primarily in the thumb and pointer finger, and in the fifth finger. He also experiences numbness in the left hand, particularly at night. He has a history of rheumatoid arthritis in his right hand. He drinks a beer or two on Fridays and Saturdays on weekends. O: Physical examination reveals weakness in the left hand, particularly in the thumb and pointer finger, with a lesser grip strength on the right side. He also experiences jolt or zing in his finger tips. He has a bilateral positive tinel's sign. A: The primary diagnosis is bilateral carpal tunnel syndrome, likely exacerbated by repetitive activities such as landscaping. Differential diagnoses include rheumatoid arthritis and rheumatoid arthritis, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and history. P: The treatment plan includes activity modification for carpal tunnel syndrome. The patient will be given a wrist splint to wear, ibuprofen 6 hundred mg every 6 hours, and a wrist splint to wear. A: The primary diagnosis is bilateral carpal tunnel syndrome, likely exacerbated by repetitive activities such as landscaping. The patient has a history of rheumatoid arthritis and rheumatoid arthritis. P: The management plan includes activity modification for carpal tunnel syndrome. The patient will be given a wrist splint to wear, ibuprofen 6 hundred mg every 6 hours, and a wrist splint to wear. A wrist splint will be prescribed, and a wrist splint will be prescribed. A follow-up appointment in two weeks is scheduled to assess the need for further diagnostic testing or surgical intervention. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms or concerns before the end of the consultation.

S: The patient, a 6-month-old female, presented with symptoms of vomiting and diarrhea. She was diagnosed with sepsis and metabolic disease. O: Initial tests showed anemia, neutropenia, and thrombocytopenia. Serum vitamin B12 was normal, but serum homocysteine was elevated at 53 mol/L. Megaloblastic changes and vacuolization were noted in bone marrow aspiration. Immunological evaluation revealed hypogammaglobulinemia with low levels of antibodies, but lymphocyte subsets were normal. A c.1106+1516_1222+1231del mutation was identified, causing a premature stop four codons into the new reading frame. A: The primary diagnosis is sepsis, metabolic disease, and a genetic deficiency of TC. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of hematological issues, but these are less likely given the genetic findings and clinical presentation. P: Initiated treatment with intramuscular vitamin B12 and oral folic acid to address hematological issues. The patient has shown improvement in hematological response with the treatment, but a speech deficit was noted during the 2-year follow-up. Continued monitoring of the patient's progress and additional support will be provided as needed.

S: The patient is a 76-year-old with a history of well-controlled hypertension and coronary artery disease. He reports progressive shortness of breath for the past two weeks, worsening. O: Vital signs include blood pressure at 238/146 mm Hg, heart rate at 75 bpm, and oxygen saturation at 80%. Physical examination revealed pulsus paradoxus, distant heart sounds without murmurs or gallops, marked jugular venous distension, diminished breath sounds at the bases, and mild bilateral lower extremity pitting edema. EKG showed low voltage, chest radiograph showed an enlarged cardiac silhouette and bilateral moderate pleural effusions. Echocardiogram indicated a moderate to large pericardial effusion with tamponade physiology. Percardiocentesis removed 1200 cc of bloody fluid. Right heart catheterization indicated severe elevated right-sided pressures and equalization of right atrial, right ventricular, and pulmonary capillary wedge pressures with diminished cardiac output. Follow-up echocardiogram showed resolution of the pericardial effusion. Fluid cytology, culture, LDH, serum antinuclear antibodies (ANA), serum complement, ESR, CRP, anti-double-stranded DNA (dsDNA), and anti-Smith antibody tests were negative for malignant cells. A: The primary diagnosis is a pericardial effusion with tamponade physiology. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of pericardial effusions, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The patient underwent a labetalol drip to manage blood pressure. Follow-up echocardiogram showed resolution of the pericardial effusion. Further diagnostic workup including fluid cytology, culture, LDH, serum antinuclear antibodies, serum complement, ESR, CRP, anti-double-stranded DNA, and anti-Smith antibody tests were conducted. The patient will continue to be monitored for any signs of recurrence or worsening of the pericardial effusion. Education regarding the nature of the pericardial effusion and its implications will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance with the treatment plan.

S: The patient, with a history of nonischemic cardiomyopathy, ESRD, deceased donor kidney transplantation, ehrlichiosis, cryptococcal pneumonia, and histoplasmosis, reports a history of syncope, subarachnoid hemorrhage, volume overload, and cryptogenic encephalopathy. The patient has a history of nonischemic cardiomyopathy, transplant vasculopathy, ESRD, deceased donor kidney transplantation, ehrlichiosis, cryptococcal pneumonia, and histoplasmosis. O: In 2013, the patient underwent dual chamber pacemaker placement with a Medtronic ADDRL1 pacemaker and two leads, one in the ventricular position and another in the right atrial appendage, but the active fixation lead was unstable. Three years later, undersensing was discovered on the atrial channel due to a gradual P wave amplitude decrease from 4.7 mV at implant to about 0.4 mV, leading to asynchronous ventricular pacing and failure to recognize atrial arrhythmias. Chest X-ray showed no change in lead position. The patient was admitted for volume overload three years later due to undersensing and occluded left subclavian vein. A: The primary diagnosis is cryptogenic encephalopathy, likely related to subclinical cirrhosis. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of atrial arrhythmias, but these are less likely given the patient's history and clinical presentation. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic with appropriate management. P: Continue monitoring the patient's condition closely and report any concerning symptoms to the healthcare team. Regular follow-up appointments should be scheduled to monitor the patient's condition and adjust the pacemaker as necessary. Educate the patient on the importance of reporting any concerning symptoms to the healthcare team. Consider referral to a cardiologist for further evaluation and management of atrial arrhythmias.

S: The patient, a long-term smoker with a history of smoking 10 cigarettes daily for 45 years, reports recent liver dysfunction. He has a history of a choledochoduodenostomy 38 years ago for a bile duct stone and an extensive small intestine excision 32 years ago due to strangulation ileus. He has been on home parenteral nutrition for over 30 years and has been on long-term intravenous hyperalimentation. O: Physical examination revealed a scar from the midline incision but no tenderness. Abdominal examination revealed a palpable mass in the abdomen. Laboratory findings showed elevated AST 55 IU/L, ALT 57 IU/L, LDH 317 IU/L, GTP 445 IU/L, and ALP 1067 IU/L. Tumor markers were slightly elevated with CEA 11 ng/ml and CA19-9 37 U/ml. Liver infection and hepatitis B and C tests were negative. Abdominal ultrasonography revealed a papillary mass of 40  30 mm slightly brighter in the left hepatic duct and dilated distal left intrahepatic bile duct. Abdominal enhanced CT showed a mass of 40  30 mm in the left hepatic duct and a lymph node of 12 mm in the hepatic hilar region. 18F-fluorodeoxyglucose-PET showed abnormal accumulation in the left bile duct and lymph node. A: The primary diagnosis is a liver and bile duct malignancy, likely secondary to a choledochoduodenostomy or a bile duct malignancy. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of liver malignancy, but these are less likely given the elevated tumor markers and imaging findings. P: Plan to conduct further evaluation of the liver and bile duct malignancy. Consider referral to a hepatologist for further evaluation and management of liver and bile duct malignancy. Educate the patient on the importance of regular follow-ups to monitor for any recurrence or complications. Consider referral

S: The patient, a 12-year-old female, presents with an unerupted permanent right maxillary central incisor. She reports low self-esteem and has been constantly bullied at school due to her unesthetic smile. The patient has no history of medical illness and no history of trauma to her teeth or jaws. O: The patient's medical history includes physical health and no history of medical illness. No history of trauma to her teeth or jaws is reported. A: The primary diagnosis is an unerupted permanent right maxillary central incisor. The patient's condition is characterized by low self-esteem and bullying. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of low self-esteem, but these are less likely given the patient's medical history and the absence of trauma to her teeth or jaws. P: Plan to schedule a follow-up appointment with a dental specialist to explore treatment options to improve the patient's smile and improve self-esteem. The patient is advised to reassure the family about the treatment options and to reach out with any further questions or concerns.

S: The patient is a 54-year-old male with a history of stage 1 squamous cell carcinoma diagnosed 3 years ago. He reports a local recurrence two years post-surgery, necessitating a definitive upper alveolectomy and a hard palate resection from the midline to the right posterior molar. He has no history of radiation or adjuvant therapy post-second alveolectomy. O: The patient underwent a partial right upper alveolectomy and obturator reconstruction three years ago. Post-surgery, he developed a local recurrence and required a definitive upper alveolectomy. The second surgery involved a hard palate resection from the midline to the right posterior molar, including bone removal. No radiation or adjuvant therapy was administered post-second alveolectomy. A: The primary diagnosis is stage 1 squamous cell carcinoma with complications including local recurrence and a local recurrence post-surgery. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of squamous cell carcinomas, but these are less likely given the patient's history and surgical history. P: The plan includes discussing reconstructive options such as an osteocutaneous radial forearm or fibula flap based on the final intraoperative defect size. The patient is advised to discuss these options with the surgeon during his scheduled appointment. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's progress and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. The patient is encouraged to reach out with any questions or concerns post-surgery.

S: The patient reports experiencing occasional pulling pain in the left side since May, along with nausea and a low-grade fever. O: Physical examination revealed a cyst in the spleen. Kasoni and ELISA tests for Human Cystic echinococcosis were negative. The patient was admitted for surgery on June 13. The spleen measured 20 x 10 cm, with the lower pole palpable in the mesogastrium. Blood and urine tests were within normal limits except for the erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) of 29 mm/h, and thrombocytopenia with platelet values of 315 thousand/l. CT scan of the abdominal organs showed a 20 x 10 cm spleen with clear, even contours and a homogeneous structure, and a 7.5 x 7.5 x 5 cm cyst with clear smooth contours, uniform content, and no septa or additional inclusions. No color Doppler mapping was noted in the cyst walls. A: The primary diagnosis is a cyst of the spleen, confirmed by imaging and clinical findings. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of splenic pain and fever, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The patient will be admitted for surgery on June 13 to perform a percutaneous puncture and MWA of the splenic cyst. The procedure will involve intravenous anesthesia with Propofol 150 mg and Phentanylum 0.2 mg. The catheter will be used to perform the procedure. Post-operative care will include monitoring for any complications or complications, and the patient will be educated on the procedure and post-operative care to ensure understanding and compliance. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor recovery and manage any complications.

S: The patient is a 62-year-old male with a history of sigmoidectomy for sigmoid colon cancer. He reports multiple liver metastases, including S3, S4, S6, and S8. He underwent eight cycles of adjuvant chemotherapy with 5-fluorouracil, oxaliplatin (FOLFOX), and panitumumab. Post-chemotherapy, he experienced partial response with a 44% reduction in the sum of target lesions. The liver metastases were resectable 15 months post-sigmoidectomy. He underwent left hepatic trisectionectomy, partial posterior segmentectomy, and partial right hepatic vein resection. Post-surgery, hepatic lesion showed a confluent multinodular growth with varying edematous and sclerotic areas. O: Histopathological examination post-sigmoidectomy revealed adenocarcinoma, type 2, por1>tub2, with a wild-type KRAS status. Post-chemotherapy, abdominal computed tomography showed remarkable shrinkage of liver tumors with a partial response of 44%. Follow-up abdominal CT showed remarkable shrinkage with a 44% reduction in target lesions. Post-chemotherapy, the liver metastases were resectable with slight reductions in tumor sizes, a 10% reduction in target lesions, and stable disease with slight reductions in tumor sizes and a 10% reduction in the sum of target lesions. Gross examination of the hepatic lesion showed confluent multinodular growth with varying edematous and sclerotic areas. A: The primary diagnosis is adenocarcinoma of the liver, type 2, por1>tub2, with a wild-type KRAS status. The patient underwent multiple surgeries including left hepatic trisectionectomy, partial posterior segmentectomy, partial right hepatic vein resection, and percutaneous transhepatic portal vein embolization therapy. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of liver cancer, but the prognosis depends on the response to treatment and response to therapy. P: The patient is advised to continue monitoring his condition and follow up

S: The patient reports swelling around the upper left second molar and bone exposure in the left buccal region. The patient has a history of excisional biopsy for osteoma. The patient denies any special medical or family history. O: Clinical examination revealed maxillary bone exposure without pain. CT scan showed a diffuse radiopaque lesion around the alveolar cortical bone surface of the maxilla, spanning from the first molar to the second molar. Biopsies showed necrotic bone without atypia. Post-surgery, the lesion enlarged, and MRI showed heterogeneous contrast-enhanced masses and hypointense areas corresponding to mineralized areas. Histopathological assessment indicated dense atypical spindle cell proliferation and focal cartilage formation with mild atypia. Immunohistochemical staining showed diffuse expression of -catenin and -smooth muscle actin in the atypical spindle cells. A: The primary diagnosis is a diffuse radiopaque lesion in the left buccal region of the maxilla, likely a recurrence of osteoma. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of osteoma, but these are less likely given the imaging and histopathological findings. P: The management plan will include discussing treatment options based on the patient's previous surgeries and the current state of the lesion. The patient will be closely monitored for any signs of recurrence or complications, and a follow-up appointment will be scheduled to assess treatment efficacy and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Patient education regarding the nature of the disease, treatment options, and potential side effects will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient reports a bulging in the right eye for the past 8 months, with a lot of tearing up. The patient has a family history of breast cancer, high blood pressure, and type 2 diabetes, but no family history of endocrine issues. The patient has a regular menstrual cycle since age 12, and has a child without complications. O: The patient is admitted to the Endocrinology Department for further evaluation and treatment. A thorough examination will be conducted, and tests will be conducted to determine the cause of the exophthalmia and epiphora. The patient is advised to bring personal belongings and medications currently in use. A: The primary diagnosis is exophthalmia and epiphora in the right eye, likely secondary to a family history of breast cancer and type 2 diabetes. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of exophthalmia and epiphora, but these are less likely given the patient's family history. P: The patient will be admitted to the Endocrinology Department for further evaluation and treatment. The treatment plan will be based on the results of the tests and the patient's current medications. The patient is advised to bring personal belongings and medications currently in use. The medical team will manage the rest of the treatment plan.

S: The patient is a 23-year-old male from Cameroon presenting with acute-onset, right-sided scrotal pain and swelling. He reports no prior sexual activity or other symptoms such as penile discharge, hematuria, fevers, night sweats, weight loss, or cough. He was diagnosed with acute epididymitis and treated with ceftriaxone and doxycycline, which resolved the symptoms but recurred five months post-treatment. O: Urinalysis showed pyuria. Naat was negative for Neisseria gonorrhoeae and Chlamydia trachomatis. Repeat ultrasound showed persistent epididymitis. Repeat urinalysis and gonorrhea and chlamydia NAAT were also negative. Contrastd CT of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis revealed a complex right-sided scrotal fluid collection, an enlarged heterogeneous prostate, an enlarged juxtaesophageal lymph node, and right lung apical nodular scarring. A unilateral orchiectomy was performed due to age and concerns about malignancy. Post-orchiectomy, the epididymis was enlarged (6.0  1.7  1.5 cm) with caseating necrosis and miliary deposits, and a large scrotal abscess. Histologic sections showed diffuse necrotizing granulomas with giant cell formation in the scrotum, testis, and epididymis. A: The primary diagnosis is acute epididymitis with complications including scrotal fluid collection, heterogeneous prostate, juxtaesophageal lymph node, and right lung apical nodular scarring. Differential diagnoses considered included TB but were ruled out based on imaging and histologic findings. P: The management plan includes scheduling follow-up appointments to monitor recovery and manage any pain or discomfort during the healing process. The patient is advised to follow all prescribed treatment plans and report any changes in symptoms. Further consultations with oncology and hematology are planned to manage the scrotal abscess and manage

S: The patient reports severe headaches and visual loss, along with primary amenorrhoea and galactorrhoea. The patient also mentions a history of primary amenorrhoea and galactorrhoea. O: MRI findings revealed an apoplectic suprasellar tumor with high prolactin levels at 10,919 miU/L. The patient underwent endoscopic trans-sphenoidal surgery (ETSS) to address the tumor, which was successful. The patient's vision returned to normal after 6 years, and prolactin levels were normal. Histology confirmed pituitary apoplexy with expression of prolactin in a diffuse pattern, and the Ki67 proliferation index was low. A: The primary diagnosis is apoplectic suprasellar tumor with secondary symptoms of primary amenorrhoea and galactorrhoea. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of suprasellar tumors, but these are less likely given the histological findings and histological findings. P: The patient underwent endoscopic trans-sphenoidal surgery (ETSS) to address the tumor. Post-operatively, the patient's prolactin levels were normal, and the Ki67 proliferation index was low. The patient is advised to continue regular check-ups to monitor for any recurrence of the tumor. Further consultations with a nephrologist and a pulmonologist are recommended to manage the tumor and prevent further recurrence.

S: The patient reports feeling fatigued for the past 2 months and unintentionally losing 60 pounds in weight over the past 2 months. O: Laboratory findings include AIHA, C3 positivity, elevated immunoglobulin (Ig)G, elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), low haptoglobin, elevated reticulocyte count, elevated RDW-CV (red blood cell distribution width-corpuscular volume), positive direct Coombs test, thrombocytopenia, and proteinuria. CT scan of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis with contrast revealed a compression fracture of the L1 vertebral body. Bone marrow biopsy of the left posterior superior iliac spine showed plasma cell myeloma with 80% of marrow elements. Flow cytometry showed monoclonal plasma cells with cytoplasmic kappa light chain restriction and characteristics like CD19 neg, CD20 neg, CD38 bri, CD45 dim to neg, CD56 neg, CD138 mod, and cKappa mod. Serum protein electrophoresis confirmed monoclonal gammopathy with IgG-K. Quantitative IgG was 7468 with very low IgA and IgM, markedly elevated Kappa free light chain of 1879, and elevated -2-microglobulin of 6.99. Cytogenetics were normal. A: The primary diagnosis is ES, evidenced by imaging, lab results, and clinical presentation. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of ES, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: Initiated treatment with high-dose methylprednisolone 500 mg intravenous for 2 days, followed by oral prednisone taper. The patient was started on high-dose methylprednisolone 500 mg intravenous for 2 days, followed by an oral prednisone taper. Continued monitoring of reticulocyte count and IgG-K status is necessary. Regular follow-ups with a nephrologist and a pulmonologist are recommended to manage the ES. Patient education on the nature of the disease, treatment expectations, and potential side effects will be provided to ensure understanding and

S: The patient reports a severe breathy voice and a cough, accompanied by difficulty breathing and a strange voice. The patient has a history of laryngeal burns sustained during a house fire. O: Physical examination revealed laryngeal edema but airway was secure. The laryngeal movement was restricted during phonation. Laryngoscopic examinations revealed vibrations of the vocal folds, a non-vibrating portion, and micro-vibrations in the vocal folds. Acoustic analysis showed decreased CPP, low-to-high frequency spectral ratio (L/H spectral ratio), and mean CPP F0. A: The primary diagnosis is laryngeal burns, likely secondary to traumatic trauma. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of laryngeal edema, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The management plan will include addressing the damage to the larynx and improving voice quality. The patient will receive counseling for post-traumatic stress management. The patient will be educated on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and addressing post-traumatic stress. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor progress and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient, a book binder, reports experiencing sensory disturbance, numbness, and severe neuropathic pain in the index finger, which has been present for 2 weeks. The patient also mentions hypoesthesia in the thumb, index, middle, and little fingers. O: Physical examination revealed a wound scar near the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint of the ulnar side of the index finger. Sensory examination showed redness in the index finger, indicating loss of protective sensation. Tinel's sign was consistent with the wound. Visual analog scale was 1 to 10, with a visual analog scale of 10 being the worst pain. No radiological findings were found suggesting a fracture. Significant restriction in the range of motion of the index finger was noted: metacarpophalangeal joint: 0°/70°, proximal interphalangeal joint: 0°/40°, and DIP joint: 0°/60°. Total active range of motion (TAM) was 63%. Sensory nerve conduction study (NCS) will be conducted to further understand the extent of the injury. A: The primary diagnosis is severe neuropathic pain in the index finger, likely exacerbated by the injury. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of neuropathic pain, but these are less likely given the imaging results and clinical presentation. P: The management plan will include a sensory nerve conduction study (NCS) to assess the extent of the injury. The patient will continue to be monitored for any changes in symptoms or deterioration in the affected area. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess progress and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. The patient will be educated on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and adherence to follow-up appointments.

S: The patient is a 14-year-old male with a history of obesity, presenting with pain and limited range of motion following a fall from 3 stairs. He reports limiting range of motion and difficulty bear weight on the left lower limb post-fall. O: Physical examination revealed profound swollen and bruised left knee with tenderness over the tibial tuberosity and lateral joint line, unable to actively move the knee joint, and painful passive range of motion. X-ray radiographs and CT scan revealed a Watson-Jones type IIIB avulsion fracture of the tibial tuberosity apophysis. A: The primary diagnosis is a Watson-Jones type IIIB avulsion fracture of the tibial tuberosity apophysis, with a step of the articular surface more than 2 mm extending to the posterior-lateral epiphyseal part of the proximal tibia, also known as the lateral tibial plateau. Differential diagnoses could include compartment syndrome, neurological, or vascular injury. P: The patient will be admitted to the hospital for operative management. A tourniquet will be used to avoid excessive bleeding. The leg will be prepped and draped according to the standard orthopedic protocol. The procedure will involve an anterolateral approach of the knee with an incision starting from the lateral upper border of the patella to 10 cm down, and the deep fascia will be opened anterior to the iliotibial tract to access the fracture line. A reduction clamp will be used to reduce the articular step and ensure proper alignment. Post-operative care will include follow-up care and rehabilitation to help the patient recover.

S: The patient reports a postsurgical linear hairless scar near the hairline, described as a long, straight hairless line, approximately 20 cm long and 1 cm wide. The patient has a history of forehead reduction surgery about a year ago. O: The scar is described as a long, straight hairless line, approximately 20 cm long and 1 cm wide. The procedure involves harvesting 700 follicular units (FUs) from the occipital area and transplanting them at a density of 35 FUs per square centimeter into the scarred area. Postoperative follow-up shows a graft survival rate of approximately 80%, with significant improvement in the patient and observer scales of the Patient and Observer Scar Assessment Scale (POSAS) scores. A: The primary diagnosis is a postsurgical linear hairless scar with a postsurgical linear hairless scar. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of hair loss, but these are less likely given the patient's history and current findings. P: The patient will be scheduled for a consultation with a hair transplant specialist to discuss the specific case and determine the best approach for the hair transplantation procedure. The consultation will focus on the patient and observer scales to assess the scalp and determine the best approach. The patient is advised to reach out with any further questions or concerns during the consultation.

S: The patient, with a history of hypertension, amlodipine, furosemide, primary open angle glaucoma, and Timolol 0.5%, presented with persistent untreated conjunctivitis in the right eye. The patient has a history of ectropion surgery on the right lower lid lateral tarsal strip five years ago, bilateral cataract surgery with IOL implantation, and a later YAG-laser capsulotomy. The patient also has aponeurotic ptosis in the left eye. O: Clinical examination revealed best-corrected distance visual acuity (BCDVA) in the right eye at 0.7 logMAR (20/100), intraocular pressure at 20 mmHg in the right eye and 15 mmHg in the left eye. Slit-lamp examination showed conjunctival hyperemia and inferior brownish non-granulomatous endothelial precipitates. Corneal fluorescein staining was negative, and no pathological findings were noted in the posterior segment. A: The primary diagnosis is persistent untreated conjunctivitis in the right eye, likely exacerbated by Aspergillus niger infection. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of conjunctivitis, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and imaging findings. P: The management plan includes empirical treatment with Ganciclovir gel 1.5 mg/g 3 times daily, followed by a corneal scraping to assess for fungal keratitis. The patient is currently on topical voriconazole 1% 4 times a day and moxifloxacin 0.3% 6 times a day, with a Tyndall effect of positive. A corneal scraping is planned to address the fungal keratitis. A: The primary diagnosis is persistent untreated conjunctivitis in the right eye, likely exacerbated by Aspergillus niger infection. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of conjunctivitis, but these are less likely given the culture results. P: The management plan includes modifying the treatment regimen to 2 mg/ml topical voriconazole 1% 4 times a day and mox

S: The patient is a previously well 12-year-old female patient who has been transferred to THP from a private hospital. She reports a 5-day history of fever, melena, haematemesis, and hemomaturia with passage of blood clots. She denies abdominal pain or other warning signs of dengue. O: Physical examination reveals the patient to be ill, but adequately hydrated with a GCS of 15/15, blood pressure of 125/75 mmHg, pulse rate of 90 beats per minute, and capillary refilling time of less than 2 seconds. Respiratory examination shows clear lungs and soft, non-tender abdomen. NS1 and IgM tests are positive, and dengue PCR reveals a serotype of DEN 2. Ultrasound of the abdomen shows no plasma leaking. Liver enzymes are mildly elevated with AST at 87 u/L and ALT at 56 u/L. Clotting profile is normal. Complete blood count shows hemoglobin at 7 g/dl and platelet count at 17  109/L. Transfusion of 1 pint of blood and 4 units of platelets resolved symptoms within a few days. A: Primary diagnosis of primary dengue fever with bleeding manifestations. Differential diagnosis initially included other causes of fever and hemoglobin deficits, but these were ruled out based on imaging and clinical findings. P: The patient underwent transfusion with 1 pint of blood and 4 units of platelets to improve hemoglobin levels. She is advised to rest, stay hydrated, and take prescribed medications as directed. Follow-up will include monitoring blood counts and liver enzymes to ensure they return to normal levels. The patient is encouraged to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately.

S: The patient, with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia, presents with symptoms of angina pectoris for the past 9 months. O: Initial electrocardiogram revealed ST-segment depression in anteroseptal leads and pathological Q waves in inferior wall leads. Echocardiography showed normal left ventricle cavity size with good systolic function and no regional wall motion abnormalities. Left ventricular ejection fraction is 57%. Coronary angiography revealed severe stenosis in the proximal left anterior descending artery (LAD) and a CTO in the proximal right coronary artery (RCA). J-CTO score (3; re-try lesion, blunt stump type, presence of calcification, occlusion length 20 mm) and PROGRESS CTO score (2; proximal cap ambiguity and absence of “interventional” collaterals). A 3.5 mm  18 mm biodegradable polymer drug-eluting stent was used for severe stenosis in the LAD artery and a CTO in the RCA. The RCA revascularization was complicated by severe corkscrew type tortuosity and small collateral size. A: The primary diagnosis is severe stenosis in the proximal left anterior descending artery (LAD) and a CTO in the proximal right coronary artery (RCA). Differential diagnoses could include other causes of coronary artery blockages, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The management plan includes exploring alternative treatment options to address the RCA blockage. The patient is advised to continue taking medications and maintain a heart-healthy lifestyle. Further consultations with cardiology and vascular surgeons are planned to discuss the case and develop a comprehensive treatment plan.

S: The patient, a former marathoner in the 30s, reports difficulty breathing during exercise since the 60s. He has a history of running marathons in the 30s. O: Recent electrocardiograms in the 40s revealed a complete left bundle branch block. Echocardiography revealed an enlarged RCA (10 mm) and a vessel with blood flow into the pulmonary artery (PA). Left ventricular ejection fraction was 60%, and mild mitral regurgitation was noted. Coronary CT indicated the LCA arose from the dorsal side of the PA, and both coronary arteries were markedly dilated and tortuous. Cardiac catheterization showed a pulmonary/systemic blood flow ratio of 1.4, and pulmonary artery pressure was 39/19/28 mmHg. Adenosine-loading myocardial scintigraphy indicated ischemia in the left anterior descending branch. A: The primary diagnosis is a complete left bundle branch block in the pulmonary artery, complicated by ischemia in the left anterior descending branch. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of pulmonary embolism, but these are less likely given the imaging and surgical findings. P: The patient underwent successful surgical intervention with a median sternotomy and a cardiopulmonary bypass from the superior and inferior vena cava to the ascending aorta. Post-operative care includes close monitoring of cardiac function and recovery. Regular follow-up appointments are scheduled to assess recovery and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. The patient is advised to maintain regular medical follow-ups to monitor for any recurrence or complications.

S: The patient reports experiencing shortness of breath and a fever over 38 °C for 2 weeks. The patient has a history of left pneumonia diagnosed by CT and has been referred for further evaluation. O: The patient's Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group (ECOG) performance status score was 2, and Hugh-Jones classification was IV. Rhonchi were evident in the anterior chest. Laboratory studies indicated an increased inflammatory response but tumor markers were within normal limits. Chest X-ray showed an infiltrative shadow in the lower left lung field. CT imaging showed a solid left main bronchial tumor with carinal involvement and carinal destruction. Rigid bronchoscopy confirmed the tumor occluded the left main bronchus and showed tumor hemorrhage. Pathological examination showed three typical histology types (cribriform, tubular, solid pattern), and tracheobronchial adenoid cystic carcinoma was diagnosed. A: The primary diagnosis is tracheobronchial adenoid cystic carcinoma of the left main stem bronchus. Differential diagnosis initially included obstructive pneumonia, which was ruled out based on imaging and biopsy results. P: The patient underwent rigid bronchoscopic treatment with significant improvement in general condition and cardiopulmonary function. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the progression of the tumor and adjust treatment as necessary. The patient will be educated on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and adherence to follow-up appointments. Referral to oncology for further evaluation and management of tracheobronchial adenoid cystic carcinoma is recommended.

S: The patient, a male, presented with a chief complaint of fatigue, muscle aches, nausea, skin rash, and blurry left eye for approximately a month. He denies experiencing double vision, pain with eye movements, flashing lights, floaters, or changes in color vision. He has no past ocular or medical history, family history of ocular or autoimmune diseases, or recent sick contacts or travel. He has been taking non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs. O: Physical examination revealed a malar rash and violet raised papules on the elbows and knees, worsening with sunlight exposure. Arterial pressure was 115/70 mmHg. Visual acuity test showed the right eye at 20/20 and the left eye at 20/100. Intraocular pressure was normal in both eyes. Extraocular movements were conjugate and full, with no subjective red desaturation. Conjunctiva was white without dilated conjunctival vessels, and the cornea was clear. Anterior chamber showed no cell or flare bilaterally. SS-OCT showed light central macular edema in the right eye and severe central macular edema in the left eye, with serous subretinal fluid. A: The primary diagnosis is chronic ocular vascular engorgement (CWS) with complications including bilateral retinal vascular engorgement, scattered foci of inner retinal whitening, and superficial hemorrhages in both eyes. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of macular edema, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: Plan to conduct further diagnostic tests and consultations to determine the best course of treatment. The patient will be educated on the importance of monitoring symptoms and adherence to the treatment plan. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess progress and adjust treatment as necessary.

S: The patient, a housewife with a history of hearing impairment and presbyacusis, presented with a medical prescription for a MRI-PET exam to investigate the nature of the musical hallucinations. The patient reports the MH began six months ago during a stressful period when her husband was experiencing health issues. She denies any neurological illnesses, neurodegenerative disorders, or psychopathological conditions. She describes the MH as occurring daily, mainly in the afternoon, with no specific emotional attachment or memories associated with the songs. She denies any auditory hallucinations. She has been using bilateral mobile acoustic prostheses for hearing impairment and presbyacusis. O: Clinical interview and neurological evaluation reveal the MH occurs daily, mainly in the afternoon, with no significant disturbances in sleep or activities. The MH are familiar Neapolitan, English, and French songs, with 3-4 current songs with no special preference and no emotional attachment or memories associated with them. The MH is slightly weakened when listening to radio or TV. The patient has been using bilateral mobile acoustic prostheses. A: The primary diagnosis is epileptic musical hallucinations, likely triggered by a stress-related condition, given the patient's history of hearing impairment and presbyacusis. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of MH, but these are less likely given the patient's history and clinical presentation. P: The management plan includes a MRI-PET exam to further investigate the nature of the MH. The patient will be informed about the procedure and consent to use of bilateral mobile acoustic prostheses for hearing impairment and presbyacusis. Written informed consent will be required to proceed with the study. A follow-up appointment will be scheduled to assess the effectiveness of the prostheses and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient, a student, presented with multiple episodes of vomiting three days ago, reduced urine output, and shortness of breath for the past couple of days. The patient reported consuming amlodipine 90 tablets of 10 mg each. O: Physical examination revealed consciousness, oriented, and afebrile. Vital signs included a blood pressure of 70/50 mm Hg, pulse rate of 108/min, and tachypnea with an oxygen saturation of 85% on room air. Physical examination revealed engorged neck veins and bilateral pedal edema. Blood tests indicated acute kidney injury (AKI) with a serum creatinine of 1.8. Arterial blood gas analysis indicated Type I respiratory failure. ECG showed sinus tachycardia, and chest roentgenogram confirmed bilateral pleural effusion. Diagnostic pleural tap showed a transudative picture. Blood culture and urine culture were sterile, and serum pro-calcitonin level was normal. A: The primary diagnosis is acute kidney injury (AKI) with a serum creatinine of 1.8, Type I respiratory failure, and sinus tachycardia. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of acute kidney injury, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The patient was resuscitated with IV fluid bolus, oxygen inhalation, and dual inotropes (noradrenaline and dopamine). The inotropes were stepped up, and empirical antibiotics were added. The patient showed dramatic improvement with tapering of inotropes and restoration of urine output within 4 hours. The patient was discharged in 3 days with stable vitals. A: The primary diagnosis is acute kidney injury with complications including acute kidney injury and Type I respiratory failure.
