The patient's suicide attempt was complicated by the consuming of amlodipine. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the improvement in renal function and symptomatic improvement. P: The patient will be discharged in 3 days with stable vitals. The patient is advised to follow up in the psychiatry outpatient department to address the underlying issues leading to the suicide attempt. Further consultations with a nephrologist and a pulmonologist are recommended to

S: The patient, with a history of Tetralogy of Fallot repair with a Dacron Patch over a large ventricular septal defect, reports a 2-month history of fever, weight loss, and left-sided abdominal pain. Recently, the patient experienced right-sided pneumonia treated with intravenous ceftriaxone, suspected infective endocarditis, and added gentamicin. The patient also experienced persistent fevers of 40°C. O: Physical examination revealed grade IV clubbing without cyanosis and no peripheral stigmata of infective endocarditis. Chest X-ray showed left mid and right lower lung zone infiltrates, and ultrasound of the upper abdomen showed an ill-defined splenic lesion without internal vascularity. Blood cultures were negative. Echocardiogram showed vegetation on the VSD patch, dehiscence, a large VSD, and moderate right ventricular outflow obstruction. CT abdomen with contrast revealed multiple liver, splenic, and lung abscesses, an infarcted left kidney, and a thrombus at the bifurcation of the aorta secondary to the septic embolic phenomenon. Postoperative echocardiogram showed mild left ventricular dysfunction and moderately reduced right ventricle function. The Dacron Patch was sent for bacterial, mycobacterial, and mycology testing. A: The primary diagnosis is a septic embolic phenomenon secondary to a Tetralogy of Fallot repair with a Dacron Patch over a large ventricular septal defect. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of septic embolic phenomena, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The patient underwent a redo-sternotomy, removal of the vegetations from the right ventricular outflow tract site, removal of the Dacron Patch, and complete repair of the Tetralogy of Fallot. Postoperative echocardiogram showed mild left ventricular dysfunction and moderately reduced right ventricle function. The Dacron Patch was sent for bacterial, mycobacterial, and mycology testing. The patient is advised to monitor symptoms and report any new or worsening symptoms immediately. Regular follow-ups are essential to monitor recovery and adjust

S: The patient reports a history of bilateral headaches for over 10 years, which have become more progressive over the past year. The patient denies any other symptoms such as fever, nausea, vomiting, altered consciousness, sensory or movement disorders, visual disturbances, facial palsy, aphasia, incontinence, or convulsions. O: Vital signs and neurologic examinations were normal. Laboratory examinations were unremarkable. MRI revealed a dilated posterior horn of the right lateral ventricle with a well-delineated oval mass measuring 1.3  1.2  1.0 cm, hypointense on T1-weight images, hyperintense on T2-weight and FLAIR images, and no enhancement following contrast administration. A stereotactic neuronavigator-guided ventriculoscopic procedure was performed. Postoperative care included general anesthesia, successful intubation, and a 3-cm incision and a small burr hole. A: The primary diagnosis is an abnormal brain mass, likely causing the patient's progressive headaches. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of headaches, but these are less likely given the imaging and surgical findings. P: The patient underwent a stereotactic neuronavigator-guided ventriculoscopic procedure to address the abnormal brain mass. Postoperative care includes regular follow-ups to monitor recovery and detect any new or worsening symptoms. The patient is advised to report any new or worsening symptoms immediately. Further consultations with neurosurgery may be necessary if symptoms persist or worsen.

S: The patient reports coughing up blood and spent childhood in northern Iran raising sheep. Symptoms began a few days after admission, leading to respiratory distress and hypoxia. The patient underwent an urgent lobectomy and was suctioned clear cystic fluid from the endotracheal tube during intubation. O: Initial chest CT scan revealed a 9 by 11 cm right lower lobe cyst, measuring 9 by 11 cm. Repeat CT scan showed air within the pulmonary cyst with a floating wavy membrane at the air-fluid level, indicative of the camalote. Histopathology confirmed echinococcal scolices. Preoperative ecchinococcal enzyme-linked immunosorbent IgG antibody assay was negative, but positive postoperatively with a positive ecchinococcal enzyme-linked immunosorbent IgG antibody at 7.15 IV. A: The primary diagnosis is echinococcal scolices in the right lower lobe of the right lower lobe. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of respiratory distress and hypoxia, but these are less likely given the imaging and histopathology results. P: The patient will be prescribed a 4-week course of albendazole to ensure full recovery. The patient is advised to adhere strictly to the medication regimen and report any concerns or questions immediately. Further consultations with a pulmonologist and a pulmonologist are recommended to manage the echinococcal scolices and manage any complications.

S: The patient, a female with a history of left-sided ductal breast cancer treated with neoadjuvant chemotherapy, partial mastectomy, axillary lymph node dissection, and radiation therapy in 1999, presents with sudden onset of fever, shivers, and a suspected infection. She reports a history of erysipelas in the left upper arm since 1999, treated with compression stockings, ACE inhibitors, and beta-blockers. She has a known systolic murmur, but echocardiographs in 2011 and 2017 were normal. She has a history of six episodes of erysipelas in the left upper arm, treated with a partial mastectomy and ACE inhibitors. O: The patient's current symptoms include a swollen, painful, and sharply demarcated erythema measuring 7  15 cm in the lymphoedematous area of the left upper arm, with no local portal of bacterial entry. Blood cultures from three of these episodes showed growth of a bacterium belonging to the S. mitis group, sensitive to clindamycin. A: The primary diagnosis is erysipelas in the left upper arm, likely secondary to a bacterial infection, given the patient's history of erysipelas and the presence of erythema in the left upper arm. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of erysipelas, but these are less likely given the patient's history and current symptoms. P: Initiate treatment with appropriate antibiotics and possibly a bacterium from the S. mitis group. Monitor the patient's response to treatment and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Schedule follow-up appointments to review the results and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Educate the patient on the importance of adhering to the treatment regimen and follow-up schedules.

S: The patient, referred for evaluation of back pain and worsening left lower extremity pain, reports a history of a fall from standing height a few months ago, accompanied by low back pain and a month later, left leg pain. The patient denies any history of lumbar epidural or intrathecal injections for the pain, fever, or difficulty passing urine. The patient has a history of mild hypertension, no history of malignancy, and no use of anticoagulant drugs. O: Physical examination revealed full power and symmetrical reflexes in both lower extremities, but a patchy reduction in sensation in the left lower limb. A left L5 nerve root block was administered only for 3 days. Lumbar MRI without gadolinium showed a posterior mass at L4/5 on T1-weighted images, isointense with hyperintense areas in the center and hypointense in the periphery. A second MRI with gadolinium showed a newly isointense mass in the anterior part of the previously identified lesion, with no significant enhancement with gadolinium-based contrast. A: The primary diagnosis is a spinal tumor, likely a spinal tumor, given the imaging findings and imaging findings. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of back pain and lower extremity pain, but these are less likely given the imaging results and imaging findings. P: The management plan includes continued monitoring of symptoms and considering additional imaging or treatment options if necessary. The patient will be educated on the importance of reporting any new symptoms or changes in condition. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess progress and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient is a 21-year-old African American male with a history of schizophrenia, presenting with fever and tachycardia. He reports frequent hospitalizations due to nonadherence with his home medications. He denies any pain, vomiting, diarrhea, loss of consciousness, or seizures. He has been on various antipsychotics since his diagnosis at age 19, including haloperidol, olanzapine, and risperidone. O: On admission, vital signs showed a temperature of 102.4 degrees Fahrenheit, BP of 115/81 mmHg, HR of 114 bpm, and oxygen saturation of 97% on room air. Physical examination showed mild dehydration, no skin rash, jugular venous distension, basal crepitation, or pedal edema. Cardiac auscultative findings were normal except for a tachycardic heart rate, apex beat in the 5th intercostal space, midclavicular line, normal heart sounds, S1 and S2, and warm peripheral extremities with a normal capillary refill. A: The primary diagnosis is a tachycardic heart rate secondary to a psychiatric history of schizophrenia. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of tachycardia, but these are less likely given the patient's history and clinical presentation. P: Continue monitoring the patient's condition closely and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Maintain current antipsychotic dosages and monitor for side effects. Educate the patient on the importance of adhering to the prescribed medications to prevent further complications and hospitalizations. Schedule follow-up appointments to reassess the patient's condition and adjust treatment as necessary.

S: The patient, with a history of profound intellectual disability, schizophrenia, posttraumatic stress disorder, Parkinson's disease, gastroesophageal reflux disease, and seizure disorder, presented with feverishness, rapid heartbeat, nausea, and vomiting for the past three days. The patient was brought in from an assisted living facility. O: On admission, vital signs showed a temperature of 102.5F, pulse 123 bpm, respiratory rate 40 breaths per minute, O2 saturation 96% on room air, and blood pressure 154/84 mm/Hg. Imaging showed no acute cardiopulmonary disease, sinus tachycardia with possible right atrium enlargement and ventricle hypertrophy. Laboratory tests showed a segmented neutrophil count of 92.8%, absolute neutrophil count of 9.19 k/cmm, hemoglobin 12.8, hematocrit 38.0%, atrial blood gas unremarkable, lactic acid 1.96 mmol/L, procalcitonin 0.32 ng/ml, sodium 149, chloride 114, BUN 37 mg/dL, AST 136, and ALT 43. Urinalysis showed trace blood, urine ketones 40 mg/dL. Urine culture was negative post 48 hours, blood cultures from admission were negative post five days, influenza screen and viral PCR were negative. A: The primary diagnosis is sepsis of unknown origin, with differential diagnoses including acute cardiopulmonary disease, pulmonary etiologies, and gastrointestinal disorders. The patient's history of profound intellectual disability, schizophrenia, posttraumatic stress disorder, Parkinson's disease, gastroesophageal reflux disease, and seizure disorder complicates the diagnosis. P: The patient was started on antibiotic therapy with vancomycin, levofloxacin, and piperacillin/tazobactam. Fluid resuscitation was provided. The patient is currently on paliperidone 3mg daily and haloperidol 2mg daily. Close monitoring of the patient's response to treatment will be necessary, with adjustments to the treatment plan as necessary. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately.

S: The patient, with a family history of seizures, generalized epilepsy, and a family history of high blood lactate levels and easy fatigability, reports a history of generalized epilepsy treated with valproic acid (VPA). The patient also has a family history of high blood lactate levels and easy fatigability. The patient has a history of diabetes, ketoacidosis, and generalized epilepsy, which has been well-controlled using valproic acid. O: Initial blood glucose levels were elevated at 12.5 mmol/L and 9.4 mmol/L, respectively. Urine tests for glucose and ketones were positive with 3+ and 2+ ratings. Arterial blood gas analysis showed elevated lactate levels (9.4 mmol/L) and low pH (7.23), with a HbA1c level of 14.60%. Neurological examination revealed external ophthalmoplegia, mild limb weakness, and pyramidal signs. Fasting plasma insulin and post-prandial insulin values were 112.54, 298.03, and 73, respectively. A: The primary diagnosis is diabetes, ketoacidosis, and generalized epilepsy, complicated by severe respiratory acidosis and respiratory failure type II. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of tachycardia, but these are less likely given the patient's family history and clinical presentation. P: Continue monitoring the patient's condition with regular follow-up appointments to assess treatment efficacy and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Educate the patient on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and adhering to follow-up appointments. Consider referral to a neurologist for further evaluation and management of diabetes, ketoacidosis, and generalized epilepsy.

S: The patient, a young child, presented with new-onset hypertension following a right heminephrectomy for neuroblastoma. The patient was intubated and performed CPR for 20 minutes until restoration of spontaneous circulation. He was treated with cortisone as suspected transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI). The patient's heart rate was 160 times/min, blood pressure was 150/111 mmHg without vasoactive drugs, and he had a tidal volume of 30ml with a pH of 6.7, PO2 of 56mmHg, PCO2 of 28mmHg, lactate of 16 mmol/l, and BE of -30. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of acute lung injury, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation. P: The patient was transferred to the ICU for respiratory support and further treatment. He was managed with cortisone as suspected transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI). He was treated with cortisone for transfusion-related acute lung injury, and a critical care ultrasound was performed to better understand the patient's condition. Continuous monitoring and supportive care are necessary to manage his condition and prevent complications.

Differential diagnoses could include other causes of atrial fibrillation and atrial fibrillation, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. The patient will be educated on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and

Differential diagnoses could include other causes of hypoglycemia, but these are less likely given the patient's history and clinical presentation. P: The management plan includes scheduling additional tests to confirm the diagnosis and rule out FHH. The patient is advised to continue taking calcium and vitamin D3 supplements, iron, cobalamine, multivitamins, and thiazide diuretics. Referral to a nephrologist for further evaluation and management of primary PHPT is recommended. The patient is advised to adhere strictly to diet and follow prescribed medications.

S: The patient, a clerical worker, reports recent discomfort in the area of the previous thymic cyst resection performed 10 years ago. The patient denies any significant medical issues and is not taking any medications. The patient has no significant family history of cancer or other illnesses. O: Physical examination and laboratory tests including tumor markers are within normal limits. A solid nodule with a multilocular lesion was found at the site of the previous surgery, measuring 30 x 30 x 15 mm. Previous CT scans showed a thymic cyst and a small nodule in the cranial section of the cyst, which was resected 10 years ago. MRI showed the solid component of the lesion iso-intense on T1WI and T2WI, with the cystic component iso-intense on T1WI and highly intense on T2WI, with no evidence of invasion to surrounding organs. A trans-sternal radical thymectomy was performed at the left inferior pole of the thymus, with the tumor size 3.7  2.5  1.0 cm, composed of small nodules and abundant lymphoid stroma. A: The primary diagnosis is a malignant thymoma or thymic carcinoma of the thymus, with a differential diagnosis of thymoma or thymic carcinoma. The prognosis depends on the response to the trans-sternal radical thymectomy. P: The patient underwent a trans-sternal radical thymectomy, which was performed at the left inferior pole of the thymus, with no evidence of invasion to surrounding organs. Post-operative care will include monitoring for any signs of recurrence or complications. The patient is advised to contact healthcare providers if any further questions or concerns arise.

S: The patient, referred for suspicion of polymyositis-dermatomyositis, reports a history of high creatine phosphokinase levels, muscle weakness, and exertional dyspnea since a stillbirth at 21 weeks of gestation. She has a history of a glucose metabolism disorder diagnosed in the first trimester and has been on insulin therapy. She also mentions exertional dyspnea worsening at 8 weeks of gestation. O: Physical examination revealed elevated serum muscle enzymes (CK 3875 U/L, aldolase 29.5 U/L, myoglobin 440 ng/mL), myalgia, muscle weakness, and arthritis. Electromyogram showed myogenic change and an inflammatory reaction, positive for anti-Jo1 antibodies, and decreased ambulatory SpO2 to 84% at room atmosphere. Blood tests indicated elevated interstitial lung disease marker levels (KL-6: 1572.0 U/mL; SPD: 195.5 ng/mL). Chest radiograph, chest-computed tomography, and respiratory function tests showed ground-glass opacity with a partial honeycomb lung throughout the entire lung field and restrictive respiratory. A: The primary diagnosis is polymyositis-dermatomyositis, evidenced by elevated serum muscle enzymes (CK 3875 U/L, aldolase 29.5 U/L, myoglobin 440 ng/mL), myalgia, muscle weakness, and arthritis. Differential diagnoses could include autoimmune myositis or myopathy, but these are less likely given the elevated anti-Jo1 antibodies. P: The management plan will include medication and monitoring of lung function. Close monitoring of the patient's pregnancy and obstetrician will be necessary to ensure optimal outcomes for both the patient and her baby. Further diagnostic tests will be conducted to assess lung disease markers and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. The patient will be educated on the importance of adhering to the treatment regimen and adherence to the treatment plan.

S: The patient reports a painless mobile lump in the right axilla, initially noticed 6 months ago, which has been progressively worsening over the last 2 months. The patient denies any other masses in the breasts or elsewhere on the body. O: Physical examination of the right axilla revealed a 5  5 cm ill-defined mobile mass with smooth surface and no overlying skin changes. Peripheral neurovascular examination was unremarkable except for a mild decrease in superficial touch sensation in the right little and ring fingers. Staging studies including MRI of the axilla, CT angiogram, chest, abdomen, and pelvis, and bone scans showed no evidence of metastasis. MRI of the axilla showed a well-defined oval-shaped heterogeneous soft tissue mass in close proximity to the axillary artery, measuring 3  3.3 cm in axial diameter and 4  4 cm craniocaudally, isointense on T1 and slightly hyperintense on T2, with vivid enhancement post-gadolinium administration. CT angiogram showed mild mass compression at the axillary/brachial arteries transition, but peripheral vessels were patent. A: The primary diagnosis is monophasic synovial sarcoma of the right axilla, confirmed by imaging and histopathological findings. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of breast cancer, but imaging and histopathological findings support the primary diagnosis. P: The management plan includes mass excision of the mass and any other affected tissue, preserving nearby blood vessels and nerves. The patient will be monitored for any changes in symptoms or concerns. Post-operative care will involve monitoring for any new symptoms or changes in the patient's condition. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately.

S: The patient reports a history of diffuse abdominal pain and vomiting. The patient denies any previous abdominal surgery. O: Physical examination revealed abdominal distension, muscle rigidity, and absent peristalsis. Groin swelling was normal. Bowel decompression was performed via a nasogastric tube. Plain x-ray of the abdomen showed multiple dilated loops of small intestines. CT scan identified a herniation of the ileum between the internal and external obturator muscles, with signs of incarceration. Emergency diagnostic laparoscopy was performed, and the trapped ileum segment was bluntly reduced. Postoperative management included fast tract rehabilitation, physical therapy, and mobilisation. ICG fluorescence angiography indicated irreversible ischaemia. A: The primary diagnosis is a herniation of the ileum between the internal and external obturator muscles, with signs of incarceration. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of small bowel obstruction, but imaging and surgical findings support the primary diagnosis. P: The patient underwent emergency diagnostic laparoscopy and resection of the hernia. Postoperative management included fast tract rehabilitation, physical therapy, and mobilisation. The patient was discharged on postoperative day seven postoperatively.

S: The patient, referred for hypertension, moon face, buffalo hump, severe muscle wasting, and hair growth on the face, reports experiencing high blood pressure, a rounder face, fatty bump on the back of the neck, weakness in muscles, and hair growth on the face. The patient has undergone transsphenoidal surgery for a pituitary adenoma in May 2007. Post-surgery, the patient's blood pressure returned to normal, and PC and ACTH levels improved. Recently, the patient experienced weakness and weight gain. O: Hormonal analysis confirmed ACTH-dependent Cushing's syndrome. MRI confirmed a pituitary adenoma. Histological examination confirmed a microadenoma. Post-surgery, the patient's PC and ACTH levels were normal. Thyroid function evaluation showed low FT4 levels, a TSH of 1.3 mIU/L, and positive TPO Ab (212 IU/mL, normal 1–50 IU/mL). Ultrasound imaging of the thyroid gland revealed a diffuse dyshomogeneous pattern. A: The primary diagnosis is Hashimoto thyroiditis, evidenced by low FT4 levels, TSH of 1.3 mIU/L, and positive TPO Ab. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of thyroid dysfunction, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The patient has been started on levothyroxine 50 mcg once a day to improve thyroid function and alleviate symptoms. Continued monitoring of thyroid function and thyroid function is necessary, with adjustments to treatment as necessary. The patient will continue to be educated on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and regular follow-up appointments to monitor progress and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient is a 57-year-old male, diabetic and hypertensive, with a family history of ischemic heart disease, presenting with chest burning after meals and occasional chest heaviness at rest. He reports a dry cough for four to five days. O: Clinical examination revealed blood pressure at 138/84 mmHg, heart rate at 76 bpm, and oxygen saturation at 98% on room air. Cardiac auscultation revealed S1 and S2 with no added heart sounds. Chest examination showed normal vesicular breathing. Systemic examination was normal. Baseline ECG showed normal sinus rhythm with LBBB. Blood work including complete blood count, creatinine, and electrolytes were within normal limits. Troponin I was within normal ranges and negative for any issues. A myocardial perfusion scan with dipyradimole was performed. Stress SPECT imaging with 760 MBq of IV Tc-99m tetrofosmin was performed. A: The primary diagnosis is ischemic heart disease with complications including ischemia and a recurrent dry cough. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of chest burning and chest heaviness, but these are less likely given the imaging results. P: The patient was referred for a myocardial perfusion scan with dipyradimole to assess for ischemia. Stress SPECT imaging was performed with 0.56 mg/kg of IV dipyradimole followed by IV 270 MBq of Tc-99m tetrofosmin. The patient will be monitored for any signs of ischemia or complications from the stress SPECT imaging. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to review the results and discuss any necessary follow-up requirements.

S: The patient is a 28-year-old woman with a 28-day menstrual cycle and a FSH level of 5.1 U/L. She was diagnosed with carcinoma of the left breast in 2010, and has undergone targeted sequencing of cancer tissue. She has agreed to undergo ovarian tissue cryopreservation as a fertility preservation method due to time constraints. O: Postoperative pathology revealed poorly differentiated invasive ductal high-grade carcinoma with negative sentinel node biopsy. The cancer is classified as pT2 pN0 M0 G3 stage IIA by TNM classification. Targeted sequencing of cancer tissue showed no cancer-related variants or mutations in BRCA1, BRCA2, PTEN, STK11, CDH1, CHEK2, BRIP1, ATM, PALB2, NF1, and TP53 genes. Laparoscopy revealed two ovarian pieces, sized 1.5  1.0 cm, containing ovarian cortex and medullar part, manually dissected from medullary tissue in HEPES-buffered IVF culture media. The cortical part of the tissue was cut into smaller pieces, measuring 1-2 mm  3-5 mm, with a thickness of 1-2 mm, and cryopreservation was performed with human serum albumin (HSA, 25 mg/ml). A: The primary diagnosis is poorly differentiated invasive ductal high-grade carcinoma of the left breast, staged as pT2 pN0 M0 G3 stage IIA by TNM classification. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of ovarian cancer, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and biopsy results. P: The patient underwent ovarian tissue cryopreservation as a fertility preservation method due to the time constraint and potential for premature ovarian insufficiency and loss of menstrual cycle activity. She has been advised to continue regular check-ups and follow-up appointments to monitor her health and fertility status. Further consultations with oncology and genetics may be necessary depending on the results of the cryopreservation procedure.

S: The patient, with a history of coughing for 5 and 9 years, presents with a new diagnosis of a multicystic mass in the left lung, initially suspected to be a bronchial cyst. Recently, a health check revealed an abnormal shadow on a radiograph. O: Recent chest CT scan using the Revolution EVO machine revealed a multicystic mass with a diameter of 35 mm in the left lung, located between the S1+2 and S6 segments. Bronchoscopy showed three bronchi branching from the left main bronchus. Three-dimensional (3D) CT with multiplanar reconstruction showed one of the bronchi displaced, passing to the dorsal side of the left main pulmonary artery. A: The primary diagnosis is a multicystic mass in the left lung, likely a bronchial cyst. Differential diagnosis initially included benign disease, but surgical resection was performed to confirm the diagnosis. P: The management plan includes surgical resection of the multicystic mass, followed by additional surgery for mediastinal lymph node dissection if the mass is malignant. The patient will be kept in contact with the healthcare team to discuss the results of the surgery once they are available.

S: The patient is a 40-year-old obese African American female presenting with a history of cardiac arrest, hypotension, intubation, nonresponsive to noxious stimuli, and minimally reactive pupils. She has been ingesting Epsom salt for weight loss. The patient denies any history of drug abuse or recent physical trauma. O: Upon examination, the patient was hypotensive, intubated, nonresponsive to noxious stimuli, and minimally reactive pupils. Initial blood work indicated hypermagnesemia with a blood magnesium level of 9.7 mg/dL, lactic acidosis (AG metabolic acidosis), mild liver enzyme elevation, and a negative urinary drug screen. A 12 Lead ECG ruled out acute coronary syndrome, and a normal sinus rhythm with a prolonged QT. Glasgow Coma Scale was 3 upon presentation. ECG indicated a first-degree AV block, a PR interval of 220 milliseconds, QRS interval of 120 milliseconds, and nonspecific intraventricular block. Brain CT scan showed no acute intracranial process. Serum creatinine was normal at 0.9 mg/dL. Urinary output was consistently normal between 1350-1600 milliliters. A: The primary diagnosis is acute coronary syndrome, stroke, and toxic ingestion of magnesium sulfate. Differential diagnoses include acute coronary syndrome, stroke, and toxic ingestion of magnesium sulfate. The patient's neurological status is stable with no evidence of acute coronary syndrome or stroke. P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition, supportive therapy without dialysis, and regular monitoring of vital signs, blood work, and overall recovery. The family will be educated on the importance of adherence to the treatment plan and the importance of regular follow-up.

S: The patient reports experiencing rapid heartbeat. The patient has a history of mild hyperthyroidism. O: Laboratory evaluation revealed mild hyperthyroidism. Thyroid ultrasound revealed a multinodular goiter in the thyroid. Thyroid scintiscan confirmed a toxic multinodular goiter with a 2 cm hyperfunctioning left nodule and a 15 mm non-hyperfunctioning nodule in the right lobe with benign features (Thy 2). Serum calcitonin levels were borderline elevated at 13.2 pg/ml. A total thyroidectomy was performed, revealing struma with CCH and medullary multifocal microcarcinoma, with a maximum diameter of 6 mm in the left lobe. A: The primary diagnosis is a toxic multinodular goiter with associated dysphagia and hyperthyroidism. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of hyperthyroidism and dysphagia, but these are less likely given the imaging and histological findings. P: The patient underwent a total thyroidectomy to remove the thyroid gland. Post-surgery, the patient will continue to be monitored for symptoms and complications. The management plan includes regular follow-up appointments to monitor for any recurrence of the toxic multinodular goiter and manage any complications.

S: The patient, a 14-month-old male, presents with a chief complaint of fever and fatigue. He has a history of oculocutaneous albinism, sickle cell disease, and siblings with the sickle cell trait. He was born at term with a birth weight of 3000 g and had neonatal jaundice, which resolved on its own. He has been on the recommended vaccination schedule according to the expanded program of immunization in the DRC. The patient is wide awake with good contact and interaction, with generalized pallor, subicteric conjunctivae, and irises are bluish gray and translucent, appearing red with nystagmus. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and management of the sickle cell disease. P: Continue monitoring the patient's fever and fatigue. Maintain the recommended vaccination schedule and seek treatment for febrile episodes such as malaria or typhoid fever. Educate the parent on the importance of reporting any worsening symptoms or concerns immediately. Schedule follow-up appointments to monitor the patient's condition and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient is a 42-year-old female in her 34th week of pregnancy, admitted due to premature rupture of membranes. She reports a negative past medical history. O: On admission, the patient's arterial blood pressure was 110/70 mmHg, and temperature was normal. Laboratory tests showed leukocytosis with 12,430 cells/mmc and severe microcytic hypochromic anemia (Hb 6.9 mg/dL, Hct 25.2%, MCV 70.8 fL, MCHC 27.4 g/dL). Post-transfusion, Hb levels increased to 9.3 mg/dL, but arterial blood pressure increased to 165/90 mmHg. Neurologic examination revealed lethargic status with mild right hemiparesis. Brain MRI showed multiple cortical and subcortical bilateral areas with hyperintense signals in T2, DWI, and Flair sequences, without contrast-enhancement. A: The primary diagnosis is chronic microcytic hypochromic anemia secondary to multiple uterine myomas. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of uterine myomas, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and imaging findings. P: The patient underwent a caesarian section and was treated with IV diazepam for a generalized tonic-clonic seizure. Neurologic examination revealed lethargic status, mild right hemiparesis, and multiple cortical and subcortical bilateral areas with hyperintense signals in T2, DWI, and Flair sequences. The patient was transferred to the Neurology Department for further evaluation and treatment. A: The primary diagnosis is chronic microcytic hypochromic anemia secondary to multiple uterine myomas. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of uterine myomas, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and imaging findings. The prognosis is guarded due to the complexity of the anemia and the patient's history of multiple uterine myomas. P: The patient was transferred to the Neurology Department for further evaluation and treatment. Continued monitoring of blood pressure and neurological status is necessary, with adjustments to treatment as necessary based on the patient's response to the

S: The patient, admitted with complaints of shortness of breath, hemoptysis for three days, palpitations, fever, and weight loss for two months, reports difficulty breathing, coughing up blood, heart palpitations, fever, and weight loss. O: Physical examination revealed malnutrition and anemia with a blood pressure of 130/80 mm Hg, pulse 103 bpm, and oxygen saturation 84% on pulse-oximeter. Respiratory examination revealed markedly reduced air entry in the right upper zone, bilateral basal coarse crepitations, and a 2-3/6 systolic ejection murmur. Chest X-ray indicated a boot-shaped heart with cavitation and fibrosis in the right upper lobe, resulting in a collapsed right upper lobe. Echocardiographic study showed an enlarged and hypertrophied right ventricle, a right-to-left shunt across the large ventricular septal defect, mild overriding of the aorta, pulmonary stenosis, valvular as well as infundibular, and a right pulmonary artery of 8 mm. Sputum examination for acid-fast bacilli was positive in two of the three-morning sputum samples, and GeneXpert MTB/RIF test was positive. A: The primary diagnosis is multi-drug-resistant pulmonary tuberculosis with complications including tetralogy of Fallot and multi-drug-resistant pulmonary tuberculosis. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of pulmonary tuberculosis, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The patient has been started on anti-tuberculous therapy (ATT) with second-line agents including injectable amikacin and oral medications including levofloxacin, cycloserine, ethionamide, and pyrazinamide. The daily doses have been adjusted based on weight. Close monitoring of the patient's response to the treatment plan is necessary, with adjustments to the treatment regimen as necessary. The patient is advised to maintain regular follow-ups and report any new symptoms or concerns.

S: The patient, with a history of hypertension and chronic back pain, presents with new symptoms of chest pain and shortness of breath. O: Physical examination revealed a 7.2 cm aneurysm in the ascending aorta with a Stanford classification type A dissection. The procedure involves axillary cannulation via the right subclavian artery with side graft anastomosis. The patient's primary care physician advised the patient to attend for further evaluation. O: Physical examination revealed a 7.2 cm aneurysm in the ascending aorta with a Stanford classification type A dissection. The procedure involved arterial cannulation using axillary cannulation via the right subclavian artery with side graft anastomosis. Post-operative findings included changes in the right radial AL tracing and pulse oximeter waveform due to partially clamping the right subclavian artery. A: The primary diagnosis is a 7.2 cm aneurysm in the ascending aorta with a Stanford classification type A dissection. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of chest pain and shortness of breath, but these are less likely given the imaging and surgical findings. P: The procedure will involve arterial cannulation via the right subclavian artery with side graft anastomosis. The patient will be prepared for the procedure with nicardipine and esmolol infusions, axillary cannulation via the right subclavian artery with side graft anastomosis, and a left radial arterial line, pulse oximeter, and noninvasive blood pressure cuff. Post-operative care will include monitoring of arterial pressures and adjusting the cannula as necessary. The patient will be educated on the procedure and post-operative care to ensure understanding and compliance. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor recovery and adjust the cannula as necessary.

S: The patient, a 7-year-old male, reports a 3-year history of seizures. He has been on sodium valproate, clonazepam, and topiramate for seizure management. O: MRI showed no lesions. Scalp EEG showed sharp waves mainly over bilateral parietal-occipital-posterior temporal regions. The patient's seizure frequency was 9.41  5.30 times per day. The patient underwent six blocks of tDCS treatment at 2 mA, with a seizure frequency of 7.68  5.38 times per day and a seizure frequency of 9.11  5.49 times per day. During the first 19 days of the second follow-up, the seizure frequency was 9.11  5.49 times per day. The patient remained seizure-free for 6 months. A: The primary diagnosis is seizure encephalopathy (ES), evidenced by the scalp EEG and seizure frequency. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of seizure encephalopathy, but these are less likely given the imaging and EEG findings. P: The patient underwent six blocks of tDCS treatment at 2 mA, with a seizure frequency of 7.68  5.38 times per day and a seizure frequency of 9.11  5.49 times per day. The patient has been seizure-free for 6 months, indicating a positive response to the treatment. Regular monitoring of seizure frequency and seizure frequency is recommended. The patient is advised to contact healthcare providers if any changes in seizure behavior or symptoms occur.

S: The patient reports progressive visual impairment in both eyes. O: Initial best corrected visual acuity (BCVA) was 0.3 in the right eye and 0.2 in the left eye. Slit-lamp examination revealed a clear cornea, calm anterior chamber, and transparent lens in both eyes, with no deposits in the corneal limbus of either eye. Optometry discs were normal on fundus examination. Extensive shiny white-yellow deposits were noted in the posterior pole and mid-peripheral retina. An OCT in 2014 showed a central macular thickness of 194 m in the right eye and 198 m in the left eye, with hyperreflective intraretinal spots and plaque-like deposits at the RPE-Bruch's membrane junction, intraaretinal cystic spaces, outer retinal tubulation, choriocapillaris atrophy, and enhanced visibility of large choroidal vessels in enhanced depth imaging mode. SS-OCT in 2018 showed a relative reduction in intraretinal hyperreflective spots and hyperreflective plaque-like deposits at the RPE-Bruch's membrane. A: The primary diagnosis is BCD, evidenced by the presence of hyperreflective intraretinal spots and plaque-like deposits at the RPE-Bruch's membrane junction, choriocapillaris atrophy, and choroidal hyperreflective foci around the choroidal vessels. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of intraretinal hyperretinal spots and plaque-like deposits, but these are less likely given the imaging findings and clinical presentation. P: The management plan includes scheduling follow-up appointments to monitor the patient's condition and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. The patient will be educated on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and adherence to follow-up appointments. Referral to a neurologist for further evaluation and management of BCD is recommended.

S: The patient is an 82-year-old African American female with a history of hypertension and a laparotomy 20 years ago. She reports nonspecific lower abdominal pain for a long time. She has not seen a doctor in 10 years and has never had a colonoscopy. Recently, she experienced unintentional weight loss. O: Physical examination revealed cachectic and dehydration, mild right lower quadrant tenderness, microcytic hypochromic anemia, and positive leukocyte esterase. Liver function tests were normal. Chest X-ray showed cardiomegaly. Abdominal ultrasound revealed mild ascites and a dilated common bile duct to 1 cm. EGD and colonoscopy were scheduled. CEA was 12.2 ng/ml (normal less than 3 ng/ml). Hemoglobin dropped to 6.2 gm/dL, requiring blood transfusions. Echocardiography revealed mitral stenosis and severe pulmonary hypertension, with normal ejection fraction. A urine culture grew klebsiella. A: The primary diagnosis is acute respiratory failure secondary to klebsiella infection. Differential diagnoses could include gastrointestinal malignancy, but these are less likely given the elevated CEA. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the improvement in respiratory status and the presence of klebsiella. P: The patient was admitted for dehydration, failure to thrive, and further work-up for possible gastrointestinal malignancy. She underwent EGD and colonoscopy with gastroenterology. She was transferred to the Medical Intensive Care Unit (MICU) for acute respiratory failure. She was started on IV antibiotics for possible pneumonia. Echocardiography revealed mitral stenosis and severe pulmonary hypertension, but ejection fraction was normal. A urine culture grew klebsiella. A: The primary diagnosis is acute respiratory failure secondary to klebsiella infection. Differential diagnoses could include gastrointestinal malignancy, given the elevated CEA and the patient's critical health status. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the improvement in respiratory status. P: Continue monitoring the patient's condition closely and discuss further

S: The patient, a hypertensive patient, presented with moderately severe headaches for four days, followed by a sudden severe headache yesterday. The patient reported vomiting but denied any history of trauma, fever, seizures, weakness of limbs, or loss of consciousness. The patient is a hypertensive patient with irregular medication use but no diabetes or addictions. O: On examination, the patient's Glasgow Coma Scale score was 15 and the patient was graded as World Federation of Neurosurgical Societies grade I. A CT scan of the brain revealed subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) in the left sylvian fissure and interhemispheric fissure, a Modified Fisher grade 1 hemorrhage. A CT cerebral angiogram showed a bilobed anterior communicating artery aneurysm measuring 8x7x5 mm, with no other aneurysms or vascular malformations. Intraoperative findings included a controlled rupture during permanent clipping with a blood loss of 20 ml, without papaverine. Postoperatively, the patient was extubated on the table and fully conscious. Postoperatively, the patient noticed ptosis in the right eye, which progressed to complete right-sided oculomotor nerve paralysis. A: The primary diagnosis is a Modified Fisher grade 1 hemorrhage of the left sylvian fissure and interhemispheric fissure, complicated by a bilobed anterior communicating artery aneurysm. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of cerebral hemorrhage, but these are less likely given the imaging and surgical findings. P: The patient underwent a right pterional craniotomy and clipping of the aneurysm, which was uneventful. Postoperatively, the patient was extubated and fully conscious. The patient will continue to be monitored for any signs of recurrence or complications from the aneurysm. Further management will include monitoring for any recurrence or complications from the aneurysm. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess recovery and manage any complications.

S: The patient reports a three-day history of diarrhoea, pain, vomiting, and nausea. The pain is mainly in the centre area of the abdomen, under the belly button, and sometimes accompanied by a bit of nausea. The last time the patient vomited was this morning, this morning, but the pain has not worsened. The patient has a history of vomiting, which has been exacerbated by a recent consuming of fruit. The patient has a history of asthma, and has not noticed any chest pain. O: The patient's inhaler has run out. The patient has a foreigner with a new inhaler, which is a foreigner. The patient's inhaler is a foreigner, and has a new one. The patient has a history of vomiting, which has been exacerbated by a recent consuming of fruit. The patient's tummy pain is likely exacerbated by a recent consuming of fruit. The patient's tummy pain is exacerbated by a recent consuming of fruit, which has been causing the pain. The patient's tummy pain is likely exacerbated by a recent consuming of fruit. A: The primary diagnosis is gastroenteritis, a tummy infection. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of tummy pain, but these are less likely given the patient's history and symptoms. The prognosis depends on the severity of the tummy infection and the patient's response to treatment. P: The management plan includes a visit to the GP in real life, in person, to check for any worsening of symptoms. The patient will be advised to drink lots of water and fluids, and to check for fevers if they start. The patient will be advised to stay home for the time being until symptoms improve. Further consultations with a gastroenterologist may be necessary if symptoms persist or worsen.

S: The patient, a 13-year-old male with a history of ASD, developmental delay, hypotonia, constipation, and ASD, reports a history of grade five vesicoureteral reflux, dysplastic kidney, absence seizures at 3 months and 9 years, delayed myelination, and delayed myelination. He has a history of delayed developmental milestones, anxiety, and Oppositional Defiant Disorder (ODD) diagnosed at 11 years of age. He has been on resperidone since diagnosis of ASD. O: The patient's birth weight is 6 lb, 14 oz, and his EEG at 9 months was normal. Brain MRI at two and a half years showed hypoplastic olfactory nerves, a Klippel-Feil anomaly, and incomplete myelin maturation in the inferior frontal lobes and temporal tips. Growth parameters were at or below the third percentile, hypotonic, and severe constipation. Clinical genetic assessments at 3 and 5 years did not identify a specific genetic diagnosis. Clinical CMA, fragile X testing, and metabolic testing were normal. A: The primary diagnosis is Wiedemann-Steiner Syndrome (WSS), based on the patient's clinical features and genetic findings. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of developmental delay and hypotonia, but these are less likely given the genetic findings and clinical characteristics. P: Continue current medications and behavioral therapy as needed. Maintain current medications and monitor for any new symptoms or changes in the patient's condition. Educate the patient on the importance of adherence to the treatment plan and regular follow-ups. Consider referral to a geneticist for further evaluation and management of Wiedemann-Steiner Syndrome.

S: The patient, a male with a history of severe neurodevelopmental delays and epilepsy, presents with irritability and gastroesophageal reflux at age three months. He was diagnosed with severe partial refractory epilepsy and tetraplegic cerebral palsy at age four months. The patient has not developed language, eye-to-eye contact, or basic motor and social milestones. O: Cytogenetic and metabolic panels including mucopolysaccharidosis, organic acids, amino acids, long chain polyunsaturated fatty acids, and muscle biopsy were normal. EEG records showed immature rhythms but no paroxysmal events in the last two years. Serial MRI studies revealed a static cortico-subcortical atrophic pattern with marked asymmetry. Genetic analysis of the LIS, PTAFR, PAFAH1B2, PAFAH1B3, FGF8, and PAX2 genes were unremarkable. A: The primary diagnosis is severe partial refractory epilepsy and tetraplegic cerebral palsy. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of neurodevelopmental delays and epilepsy, but these are less likely given the genetic findings. The prognosis depends on the management of the neurodevelopmental delays and the progression of the neurological symptoms. P: The management plan includes regular monitoring of the patient's condition and management of symptoms. Genetic testing will be conducted to explore potential genetic causes of the neurological symptoms. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's condition and adjust treatment as necessary. The patient will be educated on the importance of adherence to the treatment plan and the importance of regular follow-up care.

S: The patient, diagnosed with locally advanced rectal carcinoma infiltrating the dental line and lymph node metastases, presents with defecation, constipation, and tumor-related anemia. The patient denies any significant preexisting diseases or family history of cancer. The patient denies any significant preexisting diseases or significant family history of cancer. O: CT scan and proctoscopy revealed locally advanced rectal carcinoma infiltrating the dental line with lymph node metastases. Histological examination of a biopsy confirmed poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma with a large cell NEC component, confirmed by strong diffuse staining for synaptophysin and CD56. Chromogranin A was negative, and the Ki67 index was greater than 80%. CT scan showed more than ten metastases in both lobes of the liver. The TNM stage is cT3cN1cM1. A: The primary diagnosis is locally advanced rectal carcinoma with lymph node metastases. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of rectal cancer, but these are less likely given the imaging and histological findings. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and response to treatment. P: The treatment plan includes starting cisplatin (CDDP 20 mg/m2 on days 1–5, every 4 weeks) and irinotecan (IRI 50 mg/m2/day on days 1/8/15, every 4 weeks) with conventionally fractionated pelvic radiotherapy up to 50.4 Gy to alleviate pain. The patient is advised to follow the treatment timeline and report any new symptoms or side effects. Regular follow-ups will be scheduled to monitor the patient's response to treatment and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient, a male with a history of hypertension, bronchial carcinoid tumor post-lobectomy 15 years ago, occupational asbestos exposure with calcified pleural plaques, and low-risk prostate adenocarcinoma diagnosed 12 years ago, presents with one-month fatigue, weakness, poor oral intake, 10 lbs. unintentional weight loss, and periodic confusion by his wife. He reports a history of right ankle soreness, fevers/chills, urinary symptoms, muscle aches, pain, nausea/vomiting, and additional unintentional weight loss. Family history includes lung cancer, heavy smoker, and a deceased daughter with spinal cord astrocytoma. O: Physical examination was non-contributory. Laboratory findings showed normocytic anemia (hemoglobin 13.2 g/dL), hypercalcemia (14.6 mg/dL), and acute kidney injury (creatinine 1.7 mg/dL). Electrocardiogram showed sinus rhythm without abnormal waveforms or intervals. CT of the abdomen and pelvis, skeletal survey, nuclear medicine bone scan, and serum protein electrophoresis/serum-free light chains analysis were normal except for mild "nonspecific" splenomegaly to 14 cm and calcified mediastinal lymph nodes. A: The primary diagnosis is hypercalcemia secondary to asbestos exposure. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of splenomegaly and calcified mediastinal lymph nodes. The prognosis depends on the management of the splenomegaly and calcified mediastinal lymph nodes. P: The management plan includes intravenous fluids, furosemide, calcitonin, and pamidronate to manage hypercalcemia. The patient is advised to monitor the condition closely and report any new or worsening symptoms. Regular follow-ups will be scheduled to monitor the patient's condition and adjust treatment as necessary. The patient is encouraged to reach out with any questions or concerns.

S: The patient reports experiencing nasal obstruction and hyposmia on the left side for the past 6 months. The patient has tried over-the-counter medications without relief. The patient denies any history of maxillo-facial surgery or trauma, and no family history of congenital anomalies. O: Clinical examination revealed a bump along the floor of the left nasal cavity. Radiograph of the paranasal sinus and nasal cavity showed a radiopaque focus in the left nasal cavity. CT scan of the paranasal sinuses showed a tooth-like bony structure with a pulp cavity in the hard palate extending into the left inferior nasal cavity and a deviated nasal septum with convexity to the left, similar to a smaller canine. Orthopantomogram and 3D CT scan confirmed the presence of a supernumerary tooth in the left nasal cavity. Mild mucosal thickening was noted in the bilateral maxillary and sphenoid sinuses, with no tooth-like structures on the right side. A: The primary diagnosis is a supernumerary tooth in the left nasal cavity. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of nasal obstruction and hyposmia, but these are less likely given the imaging findings and normal intraoral dentition. P: The management plan includes performing endoscopic removal of the ectopic intranasal tooth to address the nasal obstruction and hyposmia symptoms. The patient will be monitored for any signs of infection or complications, and follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess recovery and adjust treatment as necessary.

S: The patient reports an erythematous rash on the left cheek, which occurs immediately upon eating, disappearing within 30 minutes. The patient has a history of facial and chest trauma, a mandibular fracture, and a right lower lobe collapse. The patient underwent maxillofacial surgery for the mandibular fracture at age 3. O: Physical examination revealed no systemic abnormalities or eczema. However, when consuming candy, facial flushing was noted on the left cheek, stretching from the temporal region to the corner of the mouth, with no associated lip or tongue swelling or difficulty breathing. Skin prick testing on an extended panel was negative, ruling out an allergic reaction. A: The primary diagnosis is Frey's syndrome, a non-allergic condition characterized by facial flushing and facial nerve involvement. Differential diagnosis initially included allergic reactions, which were ruled out by skin prick testing. P: The patient is advised to avoid the foods that trigger the rash and avoid foods that trigger the rash. Follow-up with a paediatrician is recommended to monitor for any new symptoms or changes in symptoms. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms immediately.

S: The patient, a 12-year-old male, presents with moderate mental retardation, microcephalus, and gait impairment. There are no perinatal deleterious events mentioned in the patient's historic reports. The parent reports persistent developmental delays and persistent microcephalus. The patient has a history of complex obsessive-compulsive behavior over the age of fifteen. O: Physical examination revealed a slight ataxic gait with little knee flexion during follow-up. Genetic analysis of EN2 markers showed no alterations in genes. A: The primary diagnosis is moderate mental retardation, microcephalus, and gait impairment. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of developmental delays, but these are less likely given the genetic findings. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and the management of the genetic anomalies. P: Continue monitoring the patient's condition closely. Maintain current medications and monitor for any changes in the genetic profile. Educate the parent on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and adherence to follow-up appointments. Consider referral to a geneticist for further evaluation and management of the genetic anomalies.

S: The patient reports feeling okay post-surgery with a history of squamous cell carcinoma, stage III, in the right mandible. The patient denies experiencing pain around the TMJ during mandibular function and reports no issues with the bite on the left side. O: Postoperative imaging revealed an anterior dislocation of the right condyle, with the miniplates at the connection between the fibula and the ascending ramus failing. Panoramic radiographs 1 year and 3 months post-surgery showed an anterior dislocation of the right condyle, with a failure of the miniplates at the bottom gonial angle area and a broken superior miniplate. A: The primary diagnosis is squamous cell carcinoma, stage III, in the right mandible. The patient's postoperative findings include an anterior dislocation of the right condyle, likely due to a failure of the miniplates at the connection between the fibula and the ascending ramus, leading to severe displacement. P: The management plan includes scheduling another surgery to replace the broken miniplates and restore stability to the connection between the fibula and the ascending ramus. This will prevent further displacement and complications. The patient is advised to reach out with any further questions or concerns during recovery.

S: The patient reports a persistent cough and multiple cervical lymphadenopathy in December 2016. The patient underwent VDLP induction chemotherapy and CAM chemotherapy, followed by allo-HSCT in July 2017. Post-transplant, the patient experienced abdominal pain, diarrhea, and a rash, characterized by acute grade three GVHD. O: The patient's CD34+ cell count was 8.33  106/kg, and MNC count was 10.15  108/kg. Post-transplant, the patient developed acute grade three GVHD, treated with methylprednisolone, cyclosporine, mesenchymal cells, and fever. BK DNA levels were 4.07  1010/ml on August 7, 2017, and 1.05  1010/ml on August 7, 2017. Chest CT showed diffuse ground-glass opacities, and abdominal CT showed enlargement of the spleen. Tracheoscopy revealed CMV-DNA at 3  106 in BALF and 6. A: The primary diagnosis is Ann-Arbor stage III lymphoma with complications including acute grade three GVHD and chronic lymphadenopathy. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of lymphoma, but these are less likely given the patient's history and clinical presentation. P: Continue monitoring the patient's response to treatment and adjust the treatment plan as necessary based on the patient's response to treatment. Regular follow-ups with oncology, oncology, and oncology are recommended to assess the progression of the disease and manage any complications. Educate the patient on the importance of adhering to the treatment regimen and follow-up appointments to monitor the patient's response to treatment and manage any complications.

S: The patient is a 67-year-old female with a history of severe aortic stenosis (AS) treated with ventricular septal defect repair at age 10, mitral valve replacement at age 57, and redo mitral valve replacement for a stenotic prosthetic mitral valve. She reports progressive dyspnea six years post-replacement, necessitating urgent redo mitral valve replacement. She has end-stage renal disease and requires haemodialysis. O: Recent transthoracic echocardiography revealed a degenerated bicuspid aortic valve with a peak velocity of 5.2 m/s, peak gradient of 108 mmHg, mean gradient of 68 mmHg, and an area of 0.43 cm2. The mitral valve prosthesis is functioning normally. Invasive coronary angiography showed normal coronary arteries. The aortic annulus measures 17 mm, maximum diameter 24 mm, perimeter 69 mm, and area 355 mm2. Common femoral arteries measure 6 mm bilaterally. The rim between the mitral valve prosthesis and the aortic annulus measures 10 mm, indicating an adequate landing zone for the TAVI valve. A: The primary diagnosis is severe aortic stenosis with complications including a degenerated bicuspid aortic valve and aortic valve embolization risk. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of aortic valve embolization, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation. P: The management plan includes performing Transcatheter Aortic Valve Implantation (TAVI) due to previous mitral and redo mitral valve replacements. The procedure will involve cannulating the right femoral artery and introducing a 14 French E-sheath between valve sizes 23 mm and 26 mm Sapien S3 valves. The valve will be crossed retrogradely using an Amplatz Left1 diagnostic catheter. The patient will be kept informed throughout the procedure and any questions or concerns will be addressed.

S: The patient is a 6-year-old boy presenting with limited forearm rotation and elbow flexion, which began 2 months ago. He reports a history of a fracture in his arm and a neglected Monteggia fracture. He underwent an open reduction of the radial head and an osteotomy of the ulna, followed by a cast on his arm. He reports an uneventful recovery. O: The patient's X-ray revealed a consolidated fracture of the ulna with an associated radial head dislocation, also known as a neglected Monteggia fracture. Post-operatively, the patient underwent an open reduction of the radial head and an osteotomy of the ulna, followed by a cast on the arm. The patient has been treated with a LCP combined with a cast. A: The primary diagnosis is a neglected Monteggia fracture of the ulna with associated radial head dislocation. The patient's recovery has been uneventful, with no complications reported. P: Continue monitoring the patient's recovery with regular follow-ups to assess healing and adjust treatment as necessary. Encourage the patient to report any pain or discomfort immediately. Educate the patient on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and reporting any new symptoms.

S: The patient is a 70-year-old female with a history of post-menopausal bleeding and a small nodule in the right posterolateral vaginal wall. She reports no prior hypersensitivity reactions. She has a history of post-menopausal bleeding and a right periclitoral mass 4 months post-menopausal bleeding. O: Biopsy revealed a 9 mm invasive melanoma in the right posterolateral vaginal wall. Wide local excision confirmed negative margins. positron emission tomography/CT scan showed focal uptake in the mass area with no regional or distant metastases. Excision revealed atypical epithelioid cells with melanin synthesis, consistent with malignant melanoma. Breslow depth was 9 mm with 3 mitoses/mm2, a positive deep margin, and no lymphatic invasion. A: The primary diagnosis is malignant melanoma with a history of invasive melanoma and atypical epithelioid cells. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of malignant melanoma, but these are less likely given the imaging and biopsy results. The prognosis is guarded due to the high risk of morbidity with additional surgery and concurrent chemotherapy. P: The management plan includes intensified-modulated radiation therapy (IMRT) to the vulva and vagina. Close monitoring of the patient's response to treatment will be necessary, with adjustments to the treatment plan as necessary. The patient will be educated on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and adherence to the treatment regimen.

S: The patient, with a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and coronary artery disease, presented with anorexia, shaking chills, diaphoresis, hematuria, productive cough, and a fever up to 103°F. The patient reported feeling weak, without appetite, severe chills, sweating, blood in urine, and a cough with mucus. The patient has a history of high-grade papillary noninvasive urothelial carcinoma of the bladder, stage TaN0M0, treated with intravesical BCG therapy. O: Upon admission, the patient appeared fatigued, acutely ill, with a temperature of 103°F, respiratory rate 24, blood pressure 160/80, pulse 84, and pulse oximetry 97% on 2 L nasal canula. Examination revealed bilateral crackles at the lung bases, benign abdomen, and no costovertebral angle tenderness. Laboratory results showed a white blood cell count of 3.6  109/L, hemoglobin 14.4 g/dL, platelet count 98  109/L, alkaline phosphatase 251 U/L, alanine transaminase 71 U/L, and aspartate transaminase 92 U/L. Liver function tests showed alkaline phosphatase 251 U/L, alanine transaminase 71 U/L, and aspartate transaminase 92 U/L. Urinalysis showed moderate blood, 3–10 RBC/hpf, and 0–5 WBC/hpf. A: The primary diagnosis is recurrent high-grade papillary noninvasive urothelial carcinoma of the bladder, stage TaN0M0. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of acute respiratory distress, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and laboratory results. The prognosis depends on the response to BCG therapy and response to treatment. P: Continue close monitoring of the patient's condition with regular follow-ups to assess for any recurrence or complications. Educate the patient on the importance of adherence to the treatment regimen and

S: The patient, a 62-year-old female, reports a history of breast cancer treated with mastectomy at 48 years old, chemotherapy with paclitaxel, doxifluridine, and hormonal therapy with tamoxifen. She has a history of bone metastasis in the vertebra, liver metastasis, and atypical femoral fractures (AFFs) in both proximal femurs. She has been on bone-modifying agents for 8 years and has experienced temporary right hip pain but persistent left hip pain. She also experienced a left displaced femoral subtrochanteric fracture after falling at 63 years old. O: The patient's Ki67 was 10%, and 27 out of 28 lymph nodes were positive. Bone scintigraphy revealed atypical femoral fractures (AFFs) in both proximal femurs, with no signs of metastatic lesions. Bone scintigraphy showed a beak on the lateral side of the fracture area with cortical bone sclerosis. A: The primary diagnosis is atypical femoral fractures (AFFs) in both proximal femurs, with a history of long-term use of bone-modifying agents. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of bone metastasis, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation. P: The management plan will focus on addressing the AFFs and monitoring breast cancer and metastases. The patient will be educated on the importance of adherence to the treatment regimen and potential side effects of the treatment. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess treatment efficacy and manage any complications. Referral to a nephrologist for ongoing management of bone metastasis and a nephrologist for bone metastasis management will be arranged.

S: The patient, with a history of severe aortic stenosis, bioprosthetic aortic valve placement 4 years ago, hypertension, and coronary artery disease, presented with dull, aching new-onset low back pain for the past 2 weeks. The patient reported a history of severe aortic stenosis, hypertension, and coronary artery disease. O: Physical examination revealed positive tenderness over the lower lumbar spine. Vital signs included a fever of 38.7°C, heart rate of 96/min, blood pressure of 130/90 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation of 96% on room air. Tenderness was noted over the lower lumbar vertebra without deformity, skin lesions, or focal neurological deficits. A new holosystolic murmur was noted at the mitral area. Laboratory tests showed a white blood cell count of 4.33  103/L, hemoglobin/hematocrit of 6.8 g/dL/20.6%, thrombocytopenic with a platelet count of 100  103/L, renal and liver function tests normal, and elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein at 107 mm/h and 205 mg/L, respectively. MRI of the spine revealed a lumbar epidural abscess, vertebral osteomyelitis, discitis, and bacteremia with C hominis. CT–guided needle biopsy of L4-L5 was positive for C hominis. Transesophageal echocardiogram showed small vegetation on the mitral valve with mild regurgitation. A: The primary diagnosis is a lumbar epidural abscess, vertebral osteomyelitis, discitis, and bacteremia with C hominis. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of lumbar spine pain, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: Initiated treatment with intravenous ceftriaxone 2 g once daily for 6 weeks to manage the infection. Post-treatment, the patient was discharged with instructions to reassess the condition and return to the clinic for further evaluation and management. The patient

S: The patient is a 67-year-old Hispanic female presenting with stage II B (T4aN0M0) melanoma of the clitoris. She reports a pigmented vulvar lesion over her clitoris that occasionally bleeded over the past month. She has a history of hypothyroidism, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and gastritis. She underwent a total hysterectomy and a left breast lumpectomy in 2015 to remove a benign cyst. She has a history of hypothyroidism, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and gastritis. O: Initial pathology revealed a malignant melanoma with a thickness of 8.0 mm invading the reticular dermis, with no ulceration, lymphovascular, or perineural invasion, and no microsatellites. Marginals were free of involvement. Staged PET scan was negative for metastasis. Lymphoscintigraphy and biopsy of the left inguinal sentinel lymph node were negative for metastatic melanoma, confirmed by immunohistochemical stains for Malan-A and S-100. Physical examination showed no signs of recurrence. Pap test was negative. A: The primary diagnosis is stage II B (T4aN0M0) melanoma of the clitoris, with a history of metastatic melanoma and lymph node involvement. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of metastatic melanoma, but these are less likely given the positive pathology and negative imaging results. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and response to treatment. P: The patient will continue under observation with a clinical trial of high-dose interferon for one year. She will be referred to gynecology for further evaluation and management. Regular follow-ups will be scheduled to monitor her condition and detect any recurrence. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms or worsening of symptoms immediately.

S: The patient reports experiencing chest and back pain, originating from the shoulder to the chest and back. The pain moves from the shoulder to the chest and back. O: On examination, the patient's vital signs were stable with clear consciousness. Blood pressure was 160/87 mmHg, heart rate was 109 bpm, and GCS score was E4V5M6. An enhanced CT scan revealed an aortic dissection with an intramural hematoma. Extravasation and pseudoaneurysm were not observed. Post-operative CT showed a decrease in the thickness of the intraluminal hematoma. A: The primary diagnosis is an aortic dissection with an intramural hematoma. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of chest and back pain, but these were ruled out by imaging and surgical findings. P: The patient underwent conservative therapy including blood pressure control with a target of systolic pressure below 140 mmHg, bed rest for 14 days, and close observation using enhanced and plain CT on hospital days 1, 3, 5, 9, and 14. Postoperatively, the patient was discharged walking to his home on postoperative day 14, which was hospital day 30. Follow-up CT showed a decrease in the thickness of the intraluminal hematoma. The patient is advised to continue follow-up and report any concerns or questions.

S: The patient reports progressive dyspnea and chest pain for the past 2 weeks. The patient has a history of high-grade invasive urothelial carcinoma of the bladder treated with neoadjuvant chemotherapy and radical cystectomy, which led to complete pathologic remission. O: Physical examination revealed a heart rate of 136 bpm, blood pressure of 122/74 mm Hg, respiratory rate of 18 breaths/min, and O2 saturation of 98% on room air. Physical findings included an irregularly irregular heart rhythm, distention of the jugular veins, and Kussmaul's sign. Bibasilar crackles were noted on lung auscultation. Laboratory tests showed creatinine at 1.42 (baseline 1.08), an INR of 3.6 (high for warfarin), complete blood counts, and electrolytes. Electrocardiogram indicated atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular rate and electrical alternans. Chest radiograph showed enlargement of the cardiac silhouette. Bedside transthoracic echocardiogram indicated a large pericardial effusion with diastolic compression of the right ventricle, suggestive of cardiac tamponade, and mild left ventricular systolic dysfunction. Post-procedure, 700 ml of turbid, dark, bloody pericardial fluid was successfully removed. Pericardial fluid cytology and pericardial biopsy were positive for malignancy, consistent with metastatic urothelial carcinoma. CT scan of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis showed no evidence of metastatic disease elsewhere. A: The primary diagnosis is metastatic urothelial carcinoma of the bladder with complications including cardiac tamponade and left ventricular systolic dysfunction. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of cardiac tamponade and cardiac tamponade, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The patient underwent an emergent subxiphoid pericardial window to remove the fluid causing the tamponade. Post-procedure, the patient will continue to be monitored for any new symptoms or changes in cardiac function. Regular follow-ups will be scheduled

S: The patient, a non-smoker with a history of De Quervain's tenosynovitis of the left hand, presented with right-sided chest pain following a session of acupuncture and cupping (ba guan). The patient reported no trauma to the chest but experienced difficulty breathing due to the pain. The patient denies fever, cough, runny nose, or sore throat. O: Physical examination revealed the patient to be afebrile, with a blood pressure of 99/63 mmHg, heart rate of 96 bpm, respiratory rate of 22 bpm, and oxygen saturation of 100% on room air. The patient was alert, comfortable, and able to speak in full sentences. The back showed multiple cupping and needling marks, and the abdomen was soft and non-tender with no pedal edema. Initial investigations included a normal complete blood count and metabolic panel. Electrocardiogram showed a normal sinus rhythm with no acute ST segment or T wave changes. Chest radiograph revealed a right-sided pneumothorax with an apical-cupola distance of 3.6 cm. A: The primary diagnosis is a right-sided pneumothorax with a 3.6 cm apical-cupola distance, likely exacerbated by acupuncture and cupping. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of chest pain and respiratory distress, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The patient has been placed on a non-rebreather mask with a FiO2 to improve breathing. Close monitoring of the patient's condition will be necessary, with adjustments to the treatment plan as necessary based on the patient's response to the treatment. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately. Further treatment may be considered if symptoms persist or worsen.

S: The patient, a two-year-old male, presented to the pediatric emergency department for a possible foreign body ingestion. The mother reported finding the child with the packaging for 10 button batteries two hours prior to the visit. The child has not shown any symptoms since then. O: Physical examination was within normal limits. Radiographs revealed six foreign bodies within the child's stomach and one distally, suggestive of ingested batteries. A: The primary diagnosis is a foreign body ingestion, likely ingested by the child. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of foreign body ingestion, but these are less likely given the radiograph findings. P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the child's condition and a procedure to safely remove the batteries. The mother is advised to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the child's condition and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient, with a history of malignant melanoma in the nasal cavity, reports feeling fatigue, nausea, and sweating. He has been previously treated for hypothyroidism secondary to Hashimoto's disease and type 2 diabetes mellitus with insulin injection therapy. He has been managing his diabetes with insulin injections. O: On admission, the patient was febrile with a temperature of 38.0°C, tachycardic, agitated, and acutely anxious but still conscious. Glasgow Coma Scale score was 14/15. Blood pressure decreased to 70/50 mmHg. Physical examination revealed a diffuse goiter without exophthalmoses, jugular venous distension, and peripheral edema. The abdomen was soft and non-tender, and skin was warm and wet. An electrocardiogram showed marked tachycardia with atrial fibrillation, but the chest radiograph was normal. Laboratory tests showed low TSH, free triiodothyronine (FT3) at 31.7 pg/ml, free thyroxine (FT4) at 3.43 ng/dl, and elevated thyroglobulin. A: The primary diagnosis is severe thyrotoxicosis with complications including severe thyrotoxicosis and poor blood glucose control. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of thyrotoxicosis, but these are less likely given the imaging and laboratory findings. P: The management plan includes close monitoring of thyrotoxicosis and blood glucose levels. Regular follow-ups are necessary to monitor the patient's condition and adjust medications as necessary. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms or changes in his condition immediately. Further consultations with a nephrologist and a cardiologist are recommended to manage his condition and improve quality of life.

S: The patient, referred to the out-patient clinic, reports generalized erythroderma with mild infiltration and whitish fine scales on the body.
