The patient has been under regular dermatological care for 28 years, with no significant side effects from phototherapy and oral acitretin. The patient has a history of psoriasis and is unaware of any family members affected by PRP. O: Physical examination reveals generalized erythroderma with mild infiltration and whitish fine scales. Clinical and histological findings indicate an atypical PRP phenotype. Direct sequencing of the CARD14 coding regions revealed three heterozygous missense variants: c.1641G/C p.Arg547Ser in exon 14, c.2044C/T and p.Arg682Trp in exon 17, and c.2458C/T p.Arg820Trp in exon 20. A splice site variant in homozygous form c.676-6G/A was six nucleotides away from the 5′ end of exon 7. Pathogenicity prediction tools indicated the p.Arg682Trp missense variant as pathogenic. A: The primary diagnosis is atypical PRP phenotype, evidenced by clinical and histological findings. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of erythroderma, but these are less likely given the clinical and histological findings. P: The management plan includes continued monitoring of the patient's condition and exploring alternative therapies to manage symptoms. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms or changes in symptoms immediately. Further consultations with dermatology and psoriasis specialists are recommended to address the underlying cause of PRP.

S: The patient, with a history of multiple myeloma, hyperlipidemia, and hypertension, presents with worsening chest pain, shortness of breath, orthopnea, and a single episode of losing consciousness during exertion over the past two days. The patient also reports an episode of syncope in the last two days. The patient denies any previous symptoms of dizziness, sweating, or other autonomic symptoms. No fever, chills, nausea, vomiting, or abdominal pain were reported. O: Physical examination revealed alertness and no acute distress. Heart rate was 84 bpm, blood pressure 120/70 mmHg, respiration rate 28 breaths per minute, and peripheral capillary oxygen saturation 98%. Physical examination revealed elevated jugular venous pressure and a systolic ejection murmur. Respiratory exam showed bilateral inspiratory crackle. Laboratory tests showed normal white blood cell count, normal hemoglobin, and normal electrolytes. Pro-brain natriuretic peptide (BNP) was elevated at 1425 pg/mL (normal range 1–100 pg/mL). Chest radiography showed pulmonary edema in the lower lung field of both lungs with Kerley-B lines. EKG showed a right bundle branch block with low voltage in the limb leads and no ST-T ischemic change. Echocardiogram revealed increased left ventricular wall thickness, hyperdynamic function with an ejection fraction of 75%, paradoxical motion of the interventricular septum with LVOT obstruction due to systolic anterior motion (SAM), and moderate mitral and tricuspid regurgitation. Genetic testing for HOCM mutations was negative. A: The primary diagnosis is a comorbid cardiac disorder with a history of multiple myeloma, hyperlipidemia, and hypertension. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of cardiac symptoms, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The management plan will include a referral to a cardiologist for further evaluation and management of cardiac issues. The patient will be educated on the importance of adherence to the treatment plan and the importance of follow-up care. Referral to

S: The patient reports feeling weak and dizzy for the past week and has lost over 20 lbs over the past year. The patient has a history of anemia. O: Physical examination revealed reddish annular spots on the right lower extremities. Blood pressure was 169/72 mmHg, pulse 102 bpm, respiratory rate 18 breaths/minute, temperature 98.3 F, and pulse ox 100% on room air. Laboratory tests showed a serum anion gap of 21.5, delta/delta ratio of 0.74, and a positive urine anion gap of 36 and urine pH greater than 6. Urine osmolar gap (UOG) was 95.43 mOsm/kg. Bone marrow biopsy indicated markedly hypercellular bone marrow with 70% B-lymphoblast, positive for TdT, PAX5, CD79a, and CD10. Peripheral blood smear showed only a few target cells. CT scan of the abdomen showed bilateral kidney enlargements. A: The primary diagnosis is distal renal involvement (RTA) with associated metabolic acidosis and renal involvement. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of renal involvement, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The management plan includes fluid replacement and sodium bicarbonate for metabolic acidosis. Treatment options will include fluid replacement and sodium bicarbonate for lactic acidosis. Monitoring of renal function and lactic acidosis will be conducted. The patient will be educated on the importance of adherence to the treatment plan and the importance of follow-up appointments.

S: The patient is a 78-year-old African-American male with a history of chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL), hyperuricemia with chronic gouty arthropathy, and chronic kidney disease (CKD) stage 3. He presented with shortness of breath and fatigue for one day. He has a history of initial treatment with bendamustine and was started on ibrutinib 420 mg and allopurinol 300 mg daily. He also reports significant fatigue associated with a dry nonproductive cough. O: On examination, the patient was febrile with a temperature of 101.6 degrees Fahrenheit but otherwise asymptomatic. Blood and urine cultures were obtained, and levofloxacin was started empirically. Laboratory findings included worsening hyperuricemia with uric acid level of 13.0 mg/dl, and a single dose of intravenous rasburicase 3 mg. CT angiogram showed a left lower lobe infiltrate. Laboratory findings included drop-in hemoglobin (4.9 mg/dL), indirect hyperbilirubinemia (7.2 mg/dL), low haptoglobin (10 mg/dL), and elevated lactate dehydrogenase (1611 IU/L). A: The primary diagnosis is chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL), hyperuricemia with chronic gouty arthropathy, and chronic kidney disease (CKD) stage 3. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of acute respiratory distress and fatigue. The prognosis depends on the management of CLL, hyperuricemia, and chronic kidney disease. P: The management plan includes close monitoring of symptoms and laboratory results to determine the best course of treatment. The patient is advised to follow up with his primary oncologist and nephrologist to manage CLL, hyperuricemia, and chronic kidney disease. Further consultations with oncology and nephrology are recommended to manage CLL, hyperuricemia, and chronic kidney disease. The patient is encouraged to reach out with any concerns or questions.

S: The patient, a 4-year-old male, reports severe speech delay, motor delay, and hypotonia. He has a history of agenesis of the splenium of the corpus callosum, measuring 49 cm (-1 SD) and height of 98 cm (0 SD). He has facial features including hypertelorism, a prominent nasal tip, a bulbous nose, a small mouth, and both retro- and micrognathia. O: The patient's OFC is 49 cm (-1 SD) and height is 98 cm (0 SD). He has a missense variant in the ZBTB18 gene, predicted to be deleterious with a SIFT score of 0 and a Polyphen score of 0.991. A total of 25 patients with pathogenic variants in ZBTB18 showed developmental delay in varying degrees with prominent speech delay. Out of 15 MRI scans, 9 showed corpus callosum abnormalities. Clinical evaluation of congenital anomalies in 13 patients showed dysmorphic facial features, epilepsy in 5 patients, hypotonia in 7 patients, and dystonia in 2 patients. A: The primary diagnosis is a genetic syndrome characterized by a genetic variant of the ZBTB18 gene, likely related to the ZBTB18 gene. Differential diagnoses could include other genetic disorders or genetic disorders, but these are less likely given the genetic findings and clinical presentation. P: The management plan includes regular follow-ups with a neurologist, speech therapist, and physical therapist to monitor growth, development, neurological function, and congenital anomalies. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately. Further genetic counseling may be considered if symptoms persist or worsen.

S: The patient, admitted with a gunshot injury on the upper left side of the chest, was in shock and hypoxemic upon admission. He was treated with resuscitation and a chest tube. He reports a brachial plexus injury and impaired sensation in the upper left limb. O: The patient's Glasgow coma scale score was 14. Hematologic examination revealed a non-expanding and non-pulsatile chest hematoma. CT angiogram of the chest revealed a 5 x 5-mm pseudo-aneurysm in the third part of the axillary artery, proximal to the posterior origin of the circumflex humeral artery, and a well-defined regional hematoma adjacent to the artery. Diagnostic angiography confirmed the CT findings and contrast extraversion. A 6 x 50 mm VIABAHN®-covered stent was placed over the injury site, and a 6x100-mm non-compliable balloon was inflated through the stent. Completion angiography confirmed the exclusion of the pseudo-aneurysm and patent blood flow. A: The primary diagnosis is a gunshot injury on the upper left side of the chest, complicated by a non-expanding and non-pulsatile chest hematoma and a well-defined regional hematoma. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of chest hematomas, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation. P: The patient underwent successful surgical intervention with a 6 x 50 mm VIABAHN®-covered stent and a 6x100-mm non-compliable balloon. He will be discharged three days post-procedure. The patient is advised to follow all take-home instructions and schedule a follow-up appointment with the healthcare provider to monitor recovery and manage any complications.

S: The patient, with a history of spinal cord tumor surgically removed 4 years ago, reports spastic paraplegia, becoming bed-bound, and a chronic pressure sore at the labia majora. Three days prior to the anaphylaxis episode, the patient reported vaginal spotting. The patient experienced mild vaginal pruritus and developed generalized hives, swollen eyelids, and hypotensive syncope within 30 minutes. The patient has a history of minimal pruritus after direct skin contact with latex gloves during a bed bath procedure 1 month prior to the anaphylaxis episode. The patient has a history of fruit allergy since the age of 50, including bananas, longans, and jackfruit, which caused pruritus of the lips, urticarial rashes, and angioedema. O: The pelvic examination revealed severe anaphylaxis. The patient was administered intravenous fluid and intramuscular epinephrine without biphasic reactions. A: The primary diagnosis is severe anaphylaxis secondary to the use of latex in NRL gloves and CHX during the pelvic examination. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of vaginal spotting, but these are less likely given the patient's history and clinical presentation. P: The management plan includes discontinuation of NRL gloves and CHX in future procedures and examinations. The patient is advised to report any new or worsening symptoms immediately. Regular follow-ups will be scheduled to monitor the patient's condition and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. The patient is advised to report any new or worsening symptoms immediately.

S: The patient is a 19-year-old male referred for compulsory Greek military service, presenting with a solitary right kidney. He reports no symptoms or problems during the initial physical examination. He denies any history of trauma or surgeries, and has no significant medical history related to hereditary or acquired diseases. O: Physical examination revealed no scars on the trunk or external genitalia. Whole blood count and urinalysis were within normal limits. Abdominopelvic CT and MRI of the pelvis showed a large lobulated multicystic lesion of the left seminal vesicle without enhancement on contrast-enhanced images, and a saccular dilated ectopic ureter opening into the left cystic seminal vesicle with a length of approximately 16 cm. MRI with a Siemens Magnetom Avanto (1.5 Tesla) MRI unit showed a large lobulated multicystic lesion in the anatomic region of the left seminal vesicle measuring approximately 7.2 cm  6.1 cm. A: The primary diagnosis is a large cystic lesion in the left seminal vesicle and an extended ectopic ureter. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of venous obstruction, but these are less likely given the imaging results and imaging findings. P: The management plan includes regular follow-ups to monitor the lesion and ureter, with instructions for the patient to report any new symptoms or issues immediately. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately. Further consultations with a nephrologist and a nephrologist may be necessary depending on the progression of the lesion and ureter.

S: The patient reports a recent itchy eruption that started 3 weeks ago on the upper to mid-back and along the "V" of the neck. The patient has been on a strict diet for the past month. O: Physical examination revealed an itchy eruption on the upper to mid-back and along the "V" of the neck. The patient's skin was examined. A: The primary diagnosis is a recurrent itchy eruption, likely related to a recent diet change. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of skin irritation, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The management plan includes gradual reintroduction of some of the eliminated foods. The patient is advised to apply an over-the-counter hydrocortisone cream twice daily to the affected areas and schedule a follow-up appointment in two weeks to monitor the response to the treatment. The patient is advised to call the office if the itching worsens or does not improve.

S: The patient reports a month-long history of diarrhea and a cough, described as watery and productive with yellowish mucus, shortness of breath, and weight loss. The patient denies any history of hemoptysis or abdominal pain, recent contact with sick patients, or use of drugs. O: Physical examination shows the patient is conscious, oriented, and alert. No respiratory distress, pallor, cyanosis, grade 3 lower limb edema, decreased air entry on the left side, inspiratory crackles, or other systemic examinations. Blood tests show WBC 14.2  109/L, hemoglobin 7.1 g/dl, platelets 660  109/L, albumin 18 g/L, ESR 89 mm/h, CRP 74 mg/L, and normal sinus rhythm on ECG. Chest x-ray reveals a cavity on the left side with pleural effusion. CT scan reveals left upper lobe air space consolidation with secretion in the left upper main bronchus, a cavity lesion measuring 3  4  3 cm, bilateral pleural effusion, and a large left inferior subpleural cavity-like abscess measuring 11  10  12 cm invading pleural and splenic areas, communicating with the posterior fundus of the stomach, causing upper pole splenic infarction. Bronchoscopy and biopsy indicate thick mucus in the left bronchus. BAL culture and sensitivity were negative, but biopsy was positive for mucormycosis. Upper GI endoscopy revealed spleen invading the fundus of the stomach. A: The primary diagnosis is a pleural effusion with associated pleural and splenic infarction. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of pleural and splenic infarction, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The management plan includes surgical management including a left thoracotomy and left upper lobectomy to remove the affected lung tissue. The patient will be monitored for any signs of infection or recurrence of symptoms. The patient will be educated

S: The patient, with a history of epilepsy, reports a history of a previous Generalized Tonic-Clonic (GTC) seizure that occurred 10 days ago and a subsequent one a few days later. The patient recalls the seizure, which was treated with 2 mg of lorazepam intravenously. Post-seizure, the patient experienced dyspnea and hypoxic, necessitating intubation for hypoxic respiratory failure. O: Initial chest radiograph showed diffuse bilateral infiltrates and pink frothy sputum in the endotracheal tube, suggestive of aspiration pneumonitis. Chest radiograph post-intubation showed diffuse bilateral infiltrates and pink frothy sputum in the endotracheal tube. Brain CT scan showed no acute intracranial abnormality. Continuous EEG indicated diffuse background slowing and occasional bifrontal spike and wave discharges, suggestive of frontal lobe epilepsy. Bedside nasopharyngolaryngoscopy showed no upper airway source of bleeding. Repeat chest radiograph showed rapid resolution of bilateral infiltrates and PaO2:FiO2 >200 mm Hg. Blood, urine, and sputum cultures, influenza, and respiratory syncytial virus polymerase chain reaction tests were negative. A: The primary diagnosis is Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS) with complications including frontal lobe epilepsy. Differential diagnoses initially included aspiration pneumonitis, but these were ruled out by imaging and clinical findings. P: The patient was started on ampicillin/sulbactam for aspiration pneumonia. The treatment plan included discontinuation of antibiotics and inhaled epoprostenol. The patient will continue to be monitored in the MICU and on lung protective ventilation. Regular follow-ups with a neurologist are recommended to manage epilepsy and prevent complications.

S: The patient is a 67-year-old male with a history of hypertension, diabetes mellitus type 2, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, presenting with sudden and severe left flank pain, which began while watching TV at home. He reports discomfort and pain. He denies any recent trauma or use of anticoagulation medications. O: Vital signs include a temperature of 37.5°C, pulse 107 bpm, respiratory rate 18 breaths per minute, blood pressure 104/62 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation 97% on room air. Physical examination reveals severe tenderness in the left flank. Laboratory findings include creatinine at 1.6, hemoglobin at 9.7, and lactate at 4.5. CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis revealed a large acute retroperitoneal hematoma extending into the left suprarenal fossa and left hemi pelvis, displacing the left renal parenchyma. Hemoglobin decreased to 8.4 after transfusion of 2 units of packed red blood cells. Interventional radiology confirmed multiple bilateral renal artery aneurysms and active extravasation from the L2 segmental artery trunk. ANA was positive with a titer of 1:80 and a nucleolar pattern. P-ANCA, c-ANCA, and hepatitis serologies were negative. A: The primary diagnosis is polyarteritis nodosa (PAN), evidenced by elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate >140, C-reactive protein at 13.7, and low C4 with normal C3. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of acute renal artery aneurysms and active extravasation from the L2 segmental artery trunk, but these are less likely given the imaging and laboratory findings. P: The patient has been started on prednisone 60 mg daily to manage the bleeding. The patient has been embolized to secure the bleeding and has been started on prednisone 60 mg daily. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's response to treatment and manage any complications. Education regarding the nature of the disease, treatment options, and potential complications will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient reports experiencing swelling and pain in the left ankle for about a year. The patient has a history of pulmonary TB and intracranial TB, which improved with anti-TB drugs. O: Physical examination revealed hyperplasia of synovial tissue, pale areas, regional congestion, scattered fibrous protein, and necrotic tissue, but the residual cartilage remains stable. Arthroscopy confirmed ankle TB with hyperplasia of synovial tissue, pale areas, regional congestion, scattered fibrous protein, and necrotic tissue. Post-operative AOFAS score was 93 points. A: The primary diagnosis is ankle TB, evidenced by hyperplasia of synovial tissue, pale areas, regional congestion, scattered fibrous protein, and necrotic tissue, with stable residual cartilage. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of ankle pain, but these were ruled out by arthroscopy and imaging. P: The patient underwent arthroscopic debridement to remove the scarring tissue and improve motor function. Post-procedure, the patient's AOFAS score improved to 93 points. The patient is advised to monitor the ankle and report any further pain or swelling. Regular follow-up appointments are scheduled to monitor the patient's condition and adjust treatment as necessary.

S: The patient, with a history of chronic hepatitis B, reports progressive dysphagia starting a few weeks ago, primarily with solid foods. The patient has been experiencing holocranial headaches, falls with dizziness, nausea, and photophobia for the past 3 to 6 weeks. O: The patient's barium swallow test indicated esophageal dysmotility. Abdominal ultrasound showed no acute findings. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy revealed a nodule in the distal esophagus and a large, friable, ulcerated mass along the gastric cardia. Biopsies confirmed adenocarcinoma, intestinal type, with neoplastic glands infiltrating muscularis mucosae. positron emission tomography and computed tomography scans confirmed the gastric mass and two fluorodeoxyglucose avid lymph nodes. MRI of the head showed three peripherally enhancing lesions with surrounding edema in the right cerebral hemisphere, with the largest lesion in the right temporoparietal lobes, resulting in mass effect with midline shift. A: The primary diagnosis is gastrointestinal adenocarcinoma with neoplastic glands infiltrating muscularis mucosae. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of intestinal adenocarcinoma, but these are less likely given the biopsy results. The prognosis is guarded due to the aggressive nature of the tumor and the patient's history of chronic hepatitis B. P: The patient underwent neoadjuvant chemotherapy with epirubicin, oxaliplatin, capecitabine, total gastrectomy with esophagojejunal anastomosis, followed by total gastrectomy with esophagojejunal anastomosis. Post-surgery, the patient will undergo gamma knife radiosurgery for the resection cavity and remaining two metastases, which were enlarged on MRI. Close monitoring of the patient's condition will be necessary, with adjustments to the treatment plan as necessary

S: The patient is a 47-year-old male with a history of severe thoracic trauma in a forklift accident 14 hours ago, resulting in severe thoracic trauma and hemoptysis. He reports no specific past medical history. O: Physical examination post-accident revealed pulse oxygen at 80%, subcutaneous emphysema in the neck and chest, no breathing in the left lung, and moist rales in the right lung. CT scan showed left-side pneumothorax, right-side pneumo-hemothorax, bilateral traumatic wet lung, multiple rib fractures, and a left main bronchial rupture. Bronchoscopy indicated a left main bronchial rupture. APACHE II score was 25, indicating a 51% predicted odds of mortality. Blood gas revealed respiratory acidosis and metabolic acidosis, with both conditions exacerbating. Chest x-rays were taken before pneumonectomy and post-ECMO withdrawal. A: The primary diagnosis is severe thoracic trauma with complications including subcutaneous emphysema, left-side pneumothorax, right-side pneumo-hemothorax, bilateral traumatic wet lung, multiple rib fractures, and left main bronchial rupture. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of thoracic trauma, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The patient was treated with bilateral closed thoracic drainage, fluid infusion, and immobilization of the chest wall. The patient was transferred to the Department of Thoracic Surgery (ECMO) due to his critical condition. He was initiated with ECMO without delay due to his critical condition. Continuous monitoring of vital signs and respiratory status is essential. Further consultations with a pulmonologist and a nephrologist are recommended to manage his condition effectively. Education on signs of respiratory distress and when to seek immediate care was provided.

S: 70-year-old male presents with pain and swelling around the ankle, particularly on the left side. He has a long-standing history of symptomatic varicose veins on his left leg. He denies any comorbidities or other medical conditions, including dyslipidemia and arterial hypertension. He is currently on simvastatin and lisinopril. O: Physical examination revealed varicose veins in the knee and lower leg mediodorsally, with perimalleolar edema on the left side. Duplex ultrasound examination revealed an insufficient left GSV with a long-lasting reflux from the SFJ down to the ankle, measuring 10mm in the thigh. A 10x10x8 mm isoechogenic mass with a hyperechogenic component was detected in an eccentric dilated segment of the GSV, adherent to the terminal valve and vein wall, adhering to the terminal valve and vein wall. No color Doppler signals were detected within the structure. The deep venous system of the left leg is patent and sufficient without postthrombotic sequelae. A: The primary diagnosis is focal thrombosis of the left leg, evidenced by the presence of a 10x10x8 mm isoechogenic mass in an eccentric dilated segment of the GSV, adhering to the terminal valve and vein wall. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of varicose vein thrombosis, but these are less likely given the imaging and imaging findings. P: Initiate thromboembolic prophylaxis with Rivaroxaban 10mg once daily to prevent complications. Arrange for an accelerated EVLA of the GSV to treat the varicose veins and exclude the thrombotic mass. Continue monitoring the patient's condition closely. Schedule follow-up appointments to assess recovery and manage any complications.

S: The patient reports persistent skin tags on the nipples, which have been present for a long time. The patient has a history of hypothyroidism, epilepsy, and learning difficulties. O: Clinical examination revealed bilateral, pedunculated, polypoid, and fleshy lesions on both nipple-areolar complexes, measuring 60x55x35mm and 25x25x25mm. Microscopic findings showed dermal proliferations of bland spindle-shaped cells with elongated wavy dark nuclei, with no atypia, pleomorphism, necrosis, or mitotic activity. The spindle cell proliferation is close to a mammary duct but includes smooth muscle fibers in close proximity to mammary ducts. Immunohistochemistry (IHC) showed neural differentiation of spindle cells with immunopositivity for S100 and neurofilament, negative for cytokeratins (AE1/3 and p63). Large amounts of smooth muscle bundles were dispersed within the lesion. Desmin and smooth muscle myosin on IHC showed the florid component of associated smooth muscle. A: The primary diagnosis is neurofibroma in the nipple, with differential diagnoses including breast parenchyma and breast parenchyma. The presence of spindle cell lesions and the presence of smooth muscle bundles suggest a reactive process in response to neurofibroma. P: The patient is advised to monitor the condition closely and follow up with a healthcare provider for any changes or concerns. Regular follow-ups with a nipple nephrologist are recommended to monitor the condition and manage any potential complications. The patient is encouraged to maintain a healthy lifestyle and maintain regular medical check-ups.

S: The patient reports severe headaches, difficulty speaking, weird twitching, and weakness all over. The patient has a 3-year-old son with a febrile exanthema positive for EV-71. O: Neurological examination revealed motor aphasia, right facial paralysis, tetraparesis, and hyperreflexia. Brain MRI showed left frontal cortical thickening in FLAIR images, hyperintense in DWI, with leptomeningeal enhancement, and spinal cord MRI showed cervical and lumbosacral lesions. CSF test indicated pleocytosis but negative enterovirus PCR. Enterovirus RNA was detected in stool sample. A: The primary diagnosis is EV-71-induced encephalopathy with associated neurological symptoms including motor aphasia, right facial paralysis, tetraparesis, and hyperreflexia. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of encephalopathy, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: Initiated plasmapheresis (PEX) therapy 72 hours post-onset of neurological symptoms, achieving clinical improvement within 24 hours. Five PEX sessions were performed every other day, with no complications observed. The patient was asymptomatic at 3- and 12-month follow-ups, with a modified Rankin Scale score of 0, indicating full recovery. The patient is advised to monitor for any new symptoms or changes in health.

S: The patient, who underwent curative laparoscopic ileocecal resection for cecum cancer, reports a history of moderately differentiated tubular adenocarcinoma without K-RAS mutation, T3 N1, stage IIIB. Post-surgery, the patient experienced peritoneal and bilateral ovarian metastases. The patient underwent CRS (CC-0) and HIPEC after 5 months of adjuvant chemotherapy, with a PCI score of 5/39. Five months post-CC-0 and HIPEC, liver metastasis to segment 6 was detected, with no other metastasis or dissemination detected. Postoperative management included systemic chemotherapy with FOLFOX and bevacizumab, with a reduction in liver metastasis and no other metastasis or dissemination. Postoperative complications included a posterior sectionectomy of the liver, which involved a total blood loss of 233 mL, and adhesion of the liver surface to the diaphragm and stomach. A: The primary diagnosis is moderately differentiated tubular adenocarcinoma with liver metastasis to segment 6. The patient's PCI score was 5/39 post-CC-0 and HIPEC, with a positive PCI score of 5/39 post-CC-0 and HIPEC. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of adenocarcinoma, but the prognosis is favorable given the absence of adjuvant chemotherapy. P: The patient underwent a posterior sectionectomy of the liver with a total blood loss of 233 mL. Postoperative management includes close monitoring of the patient's health, with regular follow-ups to assess for any recurrence or complications. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately.

S: The patient, a male with a history of Hodgkin lymphoma diagnosed at age 16, presents with neck pain. He reports no recent radiation to the face. He has a history of Hodgkin lymphoma treated with chemotherapy and radiation in 1998, which targeted lymph nodes in the neck, axilla, and behind the sternum. He has no significant past surgical or family history of breast or thyroid cancer. He quit smoking after 10 years and does not use drugs or alcohol. O: Neck CT revealed a subcutaneous mass over the mid-clavicle, a breast mass, and multiple nodules in the thyroid gland. The largest nodule measures 1.5  1.6  2.0 cm, and the breast mass measures 2.6  4.0  4.9 cm. Physical examination showed the patient to be well developed and well nourished. The respiratory, abdominal, musculoskeletal, and cardiovascular systems are normal. A: The primary diagnosis is a subcutaneous mass over the mid-clavicle, a breast mass, and multiple nodules in the thyroid gland. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of neck pain, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and management of the tumor. P: The patient will be monitored in breast and thyroid clinics for any signs of recurrence or complications. The surgical oncologist will discuss the case and determine the best course of action. The patient is advised to follow up with the breast and thyroid clinics and report any new symptoms or concerns immediately. Further consultations with oncology and a nephrologist may be necessary depending on the outcome of the consultation.

S: The patient reports a pruritic rash on the trunk and both upper and lower extremities, which has been uncomfortable. The patient has a history of mild spongiosis with an underlying superficial and deep perivascular infiltrate. The patient has tried various treatments including topical halobetasol, tacrolimus, oral antihistamines, prednisone, and mycophenolate mofetil, which were ineffective. O: Physical examination revealed lichenified papules throughout the trunk and extremities, mostly on the back. Biopsies of the rash showed mild spongiosis with an underlying superficial and deep perivascular infiltrate. Treatments initially included topical halobetasol, tacrolimus, oral antihistamines, prednisone, and mycophenolate mofetil, but these were ineffective. Dupilumab at standard dosing improved the patient's rash and pruritus, with minimal residual post-inflammatory hyperpigmented macules. However, the patient's initial pruritic rash returned after 1 year due to insurance issues. A: The primary diagnosis is mild spongiosis with an underlying superficial and deep perivascular infiltrate. Differential diagnoses initially included other causes of rash and pruritus, but these were ruled out based on biopsy results. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic following the successful reintroduction of dupilumab. P: Continue current regimen of dupilumab and monitor for any recurrence of rash or pruritus. Regular follow-up appointments should be scheduled to monitor the patient's condition and response to treatment. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately.

S: The patient, an 8-year-old female, presented with severe abdominal colic, vomiting, constipation, and fatigue. She was prescribed a nasal spray liquid twice daily for 10 days. O: Initial venous blood lead level was 91 g/dL. Laboratory tests showed elevated creatine kinase at 747 U/L, creatine kinase isoenzyme MB at 14.8 ng/mL, AST at 119 U/L, and ALT at 390 U/L. Radiography of the abdomen showed shadows of stool and gas, increased density, and shadows of stool and gas. Radiopaque particles on abdominal x-ray showed no lead. A: The primary diagnosis is rhinitis, complicated by rhinitis and rhinitis. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of rhinitis, but these are less likely given the imaging and lab results. P: The management plan includes administering folium sennae as a cathartic to eliminate lead from the intestine. The chelation regimen will be identical to the previous treatment, with a white blood cell count monitoring after 2 days. Chelation therapy will continue with an intravenous infusion of CaNa2EDTA to achieve a BLL of 36 g/dL at the end of 5 days. The patient is advised to reach out with any questions or concerns.

S: The patient is a 44-year-old immigrant male with a history of neurocysticercosis treated with a craniotomy in Mexico. He reports new onset of bilateral parotid masses, which he believes represent cysticercosis lesions. He has a history of neurocysticercosis treated with a craniotomy in Mexico. He was vaccinated against tuberculosis, and his work-up for systemic tuberculosis was negative. O: CT scan of the neck with i.v. contrast revealed bilateral parotid masses with a dominant, ring-enhancing, hypodense lesion in the left superficial parotid gland, measuring 3.0  2.9 cm. Left superficial parotidectomy was performed, and pathological analysis confirmed a squamous epithelium-lined cyst with lymphoepithelial complexes. Serological studies confirmed an HIV infection. A: The primary diagnosis is a lymphoepithelial cyst in the left superficial parotid gland, likely a cysticercosis lesions. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of parotid masses, but these are less likely given the imaging and pathological findings. P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition with appropriate medications and lifestyle modifications. The patient is advised to maintain regular check-ups and maintain close monitoring of his health. Further consultations with a nephrologist and a pulmonologist are recommended to manage his condition.

S: The patient, with a history of pulmonary sarcoidosis, hypertension, premature ventricular contractions (PVCs), hypertension, and obesity, presents with sudden difficulty seeing out of the right eye and difficulty remembering names and events. The patient recalls previous tests including a 12-lead electrocardiogram showing incidental PVCs, 12% PVC burden over 24 hours, and a transthoracic echocardiogram revealing hypokinesis of the left inferior ventricular wall with an ejection fraction of 35%. Cardiac catheterization showed no significant coronary vessels blockages. Cardiac MRI indicated sarcoid infiltrates on T2-weighted images, and pulmonary node biopsy indicated noncaseating granulomas. Initial CT scan was negative. A: The primary diagnosis is cardiac sarcoidosis with complications including alexia and right homonymous hemianopia. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of sarcoidosis, but these are less likely given the imaging results and clinical presentation. P: The management plan includes close monitoring of symptoms and follow-up with brain MRI to further investigate the cause of the symptoms. The patient will be educated on the importance of reporting any new symptoms or changes in condition. Referral to a cardiologist for further evaluation and management of cardiac sarcoidosis is recommended.

S: The patient reports no significant changes in uterine fibrosis over the past 5 years, but a 7 cm hypodense lesion near the gallbladder was found. The patient denies any abdominal pain or discomfort. O: Abdominal computed tomography revealed no significant changes in fibrosis size or internal density over the past 5 years. Ultrasound and MRI revealed a well-defined, non-calcified tumor between the gallbladder and liver, and a hyperintense tumor with delayed enhancement on arterial and portal venous phases, followed by a delayed washout on the hepatocyte phase. Laboratory tests including carcinoembryonic antigen, cancer antigen 19-9, alpha-fetoprotein, and squamous cell carcinoma antigen were within normal limits. A laparoscopic partial hepatectomy and lymphadenectomy were planned, but the tumor was enucleated with cholecystectomy. The tumor was moderately attached to the liver at the fundus of the gallbladder. A: The primary diagnosis is a benign gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST) of the gallbladder, likely originating from the liver or gallbladder. Differential diagnosis initially included gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST), but these were ruled out based on imaging and clinical findings. P: The patient underwent a laparoscopic partial hepatectomy with gallbladder resection and Lymphadenectomy among the hepatoduodenal ligament. Post-operative management included tumor enucleation with cholecystectomy, with the surgical margins of the cystic duct negative for tumor cells. The liver parenchyma en bloc was partially resected to ensure no tumor tissue was present. The patient is advised to report any concerns or symptoms immediately. Regular follow-up appointments are scheduled to monitor recovery and manage any complications.

S: The patient, a 16-year-old with a history of epileptic seizures since age 16, reports a history of bilateral tonic clonic seizures at age 16, followed by focal hyperkinetic seizures with mild impairment of awareness and no secondary generalization. The patient has been on lacosamide 600 mg/day, levetiracetam 3000 mg/day, and valproic acid 1000 mg/day. O: Brain MRI revealed increased T2 and FLAIR signal intensity in the right frontal lobe, possibly due to gray matter heterotopias or FCD. Long-term video-EEG with surface electrodes recorded five seizures with durations from 16 to 30 seconds. Histopathological findings of the resected brain specimen revealed MOGHE, a specific type of brain tissue abnormality associated with epilepsy. A: The primary diagnosis is epileptic seizure syndrome (MOGHE), evidenced by increased T2 and FLAIR signal intensity in the right frontal lobe. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of epilepsy, but these are less likely given the imaging findings and histopathological findings. P: The patient underwent a long-term video-EEG with surface electrodes for three days, followed by implantation of subdural grids and strips, depth electrodes, and a tailored resection of the right frontal lobe. Postoperative data showed two years of seizure freedom. Histopathological findings identified MOGHE as a specific brain tissue abnormality. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately. Regular follow-up appointments are scheduled to monitor the patient's condition and adjust treatment as necessary.

S: The patient, previously diagnosed with lung adenocarcinoma and treated with right lower lobectomy, reports a history of postoperative recurrence of lung adenocarcinoma with multiple metastasis in both lungs. The patient has no history of asthma, atopy, drug allergy, new medications, or cigarette smoking. Post-treatment with nivolumab, the patient developed a cough and developed pulmonary infiltrates in both lungs. O: The patient's tumor proportion score was less than 1% post-lobectomy. Postoperative chemotherapy included platinum-based chemotherapy and nivolumab. Chest CT showed pulmonary infiltrates in both lungs. Levofloxacin was administered for 12 days. Bronchoalveolar lavage from the right upper lobe showed a significant increase in total cell count with 27.1% eosinophils and 8.3% lymphocytes. No pathogenic bacterial organism was cultured. A: The primary diagnosis is recurrent lung adenocarcinoma with multiple metastasis in both lungs. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of lung cancer, but these are less likely given the patient's history and clinical presentation. P: The patient was suspended from nivolumab and started on oral prednisolone, tapered 5 mg weekly. The patient has shown rapid improvement in symptoms and radiological findings, consistent with AEP. The patient is advised to continue monitoring symptoms and follow up with the healthcare team for further support and treatment as needed.

S: The patient reported progressive discomfort and swelling in the left knee. The patient underwent a resection of a benign diffuse-type thrombocytopenia (TGCT) and developed rapid recurrence within weeks. Post-amputation, the patient developed painless inguinal lymphadenopathy, malaise, dyspnea on exertion, nonproductive cough, and night sweats. A chest CT revealed a left-sided pleural mass, confirmed as metastatic malignant TGCT by biopsy. PET-CT revealed several pulmonary nodules, a focal hypermetabolic lesion in the L3 vertebral body, and a rapidly progressing pleural lesion. Systemic treatment with imatinib showed mixed response, but a new hypermetabolic component invaded the chest wall. The patient developed symptomatic progression within one week and entered hospice care. The patient passed away 3 years after initial diagnosis, 2 years after malignant TGCT, and 13 months after developing metastatic disease. O: The patient's resection of a benign diffuse-type thrombocytopenia was performed. Pathology confirmed multifocal malignant transformation of TGCT. Post-operative complications included painless inguinal lymphadenopathy, malaise, dyspnea on exertion, nonproductive cough, and night sweats. Chest CT showed a left-sided pleural mass, confirmed as metastatic malignant TGCT by biopsy. PET-CT revealed several pulmonary nodules, a focal hypermetabolic lesion in the L3 vertebral body, and a rapidly progressing pleural lesion. Systemic treatment with imatinib showed mixed response, but a new hypermetabolic component invaded the chest wall. A: The primary diagnosis was metastatic malignant thrombocytopenia with complications including pulmonary nodules, a focal hypermetabolic lesion in the L3 vertebral body, and a rapidly progressing pleural lesion. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of metastatic thrombocytopenia, but the prognosis was guarded due to the aggressive nature of the recurrent tumor. P: The patient was treated with systemic treatment with imatini

S: The patient, a 1-year-old male, presented with a chief complaint of abnormal head circumference, truncal hypotonia, and decreased muscle tone in the trunk area. The parent reports delayed motor and speech development. O: The patient's occipitofrontal circumference (OFC) is 43.5 cm, approximately 2.8 standard deviations below the average. Physical examination revealed truncal hypotonia. An EEG and MRI showed a short and hypoplastic corpus callosum that affects the splenium more than the rostrum. Facial features include an upward slant, a small and somewhat sloping forehead, depressed nasal bridge, small and upturned nose tip and nostrils, an elongated philtrum, and a thin upper lip. Genetic tests revealed a de novo nonsense variant: Chr1(GRCh37):g.244217655G>A, NM_205768.2(ZBTB18): c.579G>A (p.(Trp193*)). A: The primary diagnosis is microcephaly, evidenced by the truncal hypotonia and facial features. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of truncal hypotonia, but these are less likely given the genetic findings. P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's development with a genetic counselor and a neurologist. Genetic counseling will be necessary to guide the treatment plan. The patient will be educated on the importance of follow-up appointments and the importance of adherence to the treatment plan. Referral to a genetic counselor and a neurologist is recommended for further evaluation and management.

S: The patient reports a 7-month history of mucopurulent and hemorrhagic discharge from the left eye, which started suddenly after a walk in the park. The owner denies any abnormalities in the right eye. O: The patient's left eye has been experiencing mucopurulent and hemorrhagic discharge. An ultrasound will be performed to assess the nasolacrimal system. The dog will be manually restrained and placed in sternal recumbence. Ultrasound gel will be applied to the skin and transducer surface, and B-mode scanning will be performed in sagittal and cross-sectional planes. A: The primary diagnosis is unilateral dacryocystitis of the tear sac, likely exacerbated by the presence of foreign bodies or abnormalities in the lacrimal sac. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of nasolacrimal system inflammation, but these are less likely given the ultrasound findings. P: The management plan includes performing an ultrasound to assess the nasolacrimal system, specifically the nasolacrimal system, to determine the cause of the inflammation and discharge. The patient will be anesthetized and removed if a foreign body is found. A: The primary diagnosis is unilateral dacryocystitis of the tear sac, likely exacerbated by the presence of foreign bodies or abnormalities in the lacrimal sac. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of nasolacrimal system inflammation, but these are less likely given the ultrasound findings. P: The management plan will include anesthesia to remove the foreign body and anesthetize the dog. The patient will be scheduled for an ultrasound later this week to assess the effectiveness of the treatment. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the dog's response to treatment and adjust the plan as necessary.

S: The patient is a 9-year-old female with a history of osteosarcoma of the left tibia and a solitary metastasis in the L3 vertebrae, diagnosed in January 2016. She underwent a below knee amputation and L3 corpectomy with posterior spinal fusion and instrumentation from L1 to L5 with decompression laminectomy at L2-3, and L3-4 through a posterior and left thoracoabdominal approach in March 2016. She was started on second line drugs, including ifosfamide and etoposide, and has been ambulating with a below knee prosthesis. Previous implants were well in place. O: Physical examination revealed no neurological deficits. Physical examination showed no neurological deficits. MRI and ultrasound guided fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) of right paraspinal psoas tissue confirmed recurrent osteoblastic osteosarcoma on December 2016. Imaging tests including radiographs, CT, bone scan, PET scan, and MRI with contrast enhancement confirmed a single metastatic site. A: The primary diagnosis is recurrent osteoblastic osteosarcoma of the L3 vertebrae with a recurrent metastasis in the L3 vertebrae. Differential diagnoses could include other bone tumors, but imaging and clinical findings support the primary diagnosis. The prognosis depends on the successful surgical resection of the osteoblastic osteosarcoma. P: The management plan includes a complex en bloc resection of L2, L3, and L4 with removal of deep spinal implants, anterior and posterior spinal fusion, and instrumentation. The patient and her family will be educated about the risks of surgery and the importance of follow-up care. The patient will be monitored closely for any signs of complications and will be educated on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan.

S: The patient reports feeling tired for the past 3 days, experiencing a fever for 2 days, abnormally talkative behavior, and a limp for a day. Additionally, the patient has noticed black spots on the palms and soles, and a blackened left second finger and left fifth toe. O: Vital signs include a temperature of 39.8 °C, heart rate of 130 beats/min, blood pressure of 100/71 mmHg, respiratory rate of 18 breaths/min, and oxygen saturation of 98% on room air. The patient is oriented but oddly garrulous. Mouth and throat examinations reveal no hemorrhages in the palpebral conjunctiva, but petechial hemorrhages on the uvula and posterior pharynx suggestive of streptococcal pharyngitis. No cardiac murmurs are heard. The left second finger and left fifth toe are black, and petechiae on the right palm are present. The dorsum of the left foot is erythematous, warm, and swollen. Laboratory findings include disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) with elevated white blood cell count and elevated C-reactive protein. Blood cultures grew Streptococcus pyogenes. Follow-up examination revealed vegetation on the mitral valve and mitral regurgitation (MR). Echocardiography revealed vegetation on the mitral valve and mitral regurgitation. A: The primary diagnosis is a skin and soft tissue infection causing bacteremia and DIC. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of skin and soft tissue infection, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and laboratory findings. P: Initiate IV ampicillin/sulbactam and clindamycin. Switch to ampicillin and continue clindamycin. Monitor mental status closely and consider further treatment options based on susceptibility testing results. Educate the patient on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and adherence to follow-up appointments.

S: The patient, a male with a history of dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans (DFSP), presented with a long-standing swelling on the left lower leg, which progressively increased in size. He reported a history of recurrence of dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans (DFSP) after a wide local excision and subsequent recurrence in the left lower limb stump. The patient has been coping with walking using a prosthetic limb, which has been difficult at first. O: The patient underwent a wide local excision and a re-excision, followed by a second recurrence in the left lower limb stump two years post-DFSP, with no distant metastases. A re-biopsy confirmed DFSP without fibrosarcomatous transformation and immunohistochemistry positive for CD34, focally positive for actin, and negative for desmin and S100 protein. Chest X-ray and abdominal ultrasound were negative. A 15 x 12 cm mobile mass on the left lower limb stump and two palpable, firm, and fixed lesions on the posterior torso were noted, with the largest measuring 9 x 7 cm. A: The primary diagnosis is recurrent dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans (DFSP) with a secondary recurrence in the left lower limb stump. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of dermatofibrosarcoma, but these are less likely given the negative metastatic workup. The prognosis is guarded due to the recurrence of DFSP and the presence of multiple lesions on the posterior torso. P: The patient was treated with palliative radiotherapy to relieve pain in the left lower limb stump and to enable the use of the prosthetic limb. The treatment plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition and reassessment of the treatment plan as necessary. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms or changes in symptoms immediately. Further consultations with oncology and radiation oncology are planned to further evaluate the recurrence of DFSP.

S: The patient, diagnosed with bifocal invasive ductal breast cancer in 2006, underwent mastectomy, chemotherapy, and radiotherapy. She reports severe dorsal pain recently. She has been on tamoxifen for five years. O: An MRI of the spine revealed diffuse medullary metastatic disease in the spine, filling the perimedullary subdural space at T2-T3 and molding the posterior medulla. Leptomeningeal metastatic spread was noted as small nodular foci, sticking to the spinal cord and dorsal roots, without intramedullary metastatic spread or CSF blockage. Bone deposits were found in the right pedicle of T4 and the vertebral body of T7, with no brain or intramedullary metastatic disease. A: The primary diagnosis is diffuse medullary metastatic disease in the spine, likely exacerbated by radiation therapy. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of metastatic cancers, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The treatment plan includes a 30Gy radiotherapy treatment to reduce the volume of the metastatic sleeve at the thoracic level, allowing partial improvement in symptoms and reducing the dose of analgesic drugs. The patient will be monitored in a pain management unit and will be prescribed hormonotherapy, consisting of anastrozole, an aromatase inhibitor. Follow-up will include monitoring in a pain management unit and consultation in a pain management unit. The patient will be educated on the importance of follow-up and compliance with the treatment plan.

S: Matthew Smith, a 67-year-old male, reports a recent injury to his right shoulder, which he describes as a traumatic event. He has a history of appendicitis and an appendectomy three four years ago. He denies fever, chills, fever, headache, or passing out. He has a history of appendicitis, appendectomy, and other orthopedic injuries. O: Vital signs are stable with a blood pressure of 128 over 776 mmHg, heart rate of 802 bpm, and oxygenation of 95% on room air. Physical examination reveals no fever, numbness, tingling in fingers, and difficulty with arm strength. The patient is right-handed with a right-hand acromioclavicular joint fracture. No fever or chills were reported. A: The primary diagnosis is an acute acromioclavicular joint fracture of the right shoulder. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of shoulder pain, but these are less likely given the imaging results. The prognosis depends on the extent of the fracture and the patient's response to treatment. P: The patient will be placed in a sling for pain management. He will be prescribed meloxicam 15 mg once a day, and a cat scan of the right shoulder will be ordered to assess the joint's condition. Physical therapy will be recommended to strengthen the shoulder to prevent further fractures. The patient will be advised to avoid tackle football for a while, and he will be advised to avoid playing taggle football for a while.

S: The patient, a 3-month-old female with a history of congenital heart defect (CHD), presented with central cyanosis and significant inconsolable agitation. The episode lasted about 15 minutes. The parent reports no audible murmurs, and the patient's oxygen saturation was between 48 and 66%. The patient was born to non-consanguineous afro-Caribbean parents and diagnosed antenatally with tetralogy of Fallot, followed by intrauterine growth restriction in the third trimester. O: Physical examination revealed no murmurs. Initial oxygen saturation was between 48 and 66%. Knee-to-chest positioning, intravenous fluid, and morphine administration were initiated. The episode lasted about 15 minutes. Genetic analysis showed a normal karyotype with no 22q11 deletion. Initial oxygen saturation was around 95% on room air, and a grade 4/6 ejection systolic murmur was noted. Post-treatment with oral beta blockers, oxygen saturation stabilized between 85 and 90% on room air without further hypoxic spells. Despite treatment with posture adjustment, morphine use, fluid boluses, and incremental increase in beta blockade (up to 2 mg/kg/dose), the patient's baseline oxygen saturation dropped from 85 to 70%, and oxygen saturation during a cyanotic spell was as low as 40%. Echocardiography confirmed the pre-natal diagnosis of tetralogy of Fallot. A: The primary diagnosis is tetralogy of Fallot, complicated by recurrent cyanotic spells and a recurrent cyanotic spell. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of cyanosis, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation. P: Continue monitoring the patient's condition closely with regular follow-up appointments and consider further treatments to manage symptoms. Educate the parent on the importance of adherence to the treatment plan and monitoring for any new symptoms. Consider referral to a pediatric cardiologist for further evaluation and management of Fallot.

S: The patient reports a 4-month history of constant abdominal pain and weight loss. The pain has recently started in the left inguinal area. O: Physical examinations were within normal limits. Abdominal CT scan showed retroperitoneal enlarged lymph nodes without other pathological findings. Biopsy through the laparoscopic approach was nonspecific adenitis. Abdominal CT scan showed a large left retroperitoneal fluid collection causing slight left hydronephrosis and retroperitoneal lymph node enlargement in the interaortocaval, precaval, and right common iliac artery territories. Percutaneous drainage of the fluid collection was performed using a 21-gauge Chiba needle and an 8.5F pigtail drainage catheter. 1100 mL of milky liquid was drained. Imaging showed perfect opacification of the lymphatic afferent and efferent vessels of the punctured lymph node and contrast leakage at the fourth lumbar spine. A: The primary diagnosis is cisterna chyli injury secondary to retroperitoneal surgery. Differential diagnoses initially included lymphoproliferative disease and nonspecific adenitis. The prognosis depends on the successful surgical management of the chyli injury. P: The patient underwent percutaneous drainage of the chyli collection, which was performed under local anesthesia with 10 mL of 2% mepivacaine and an 8.5F pigtail drainage catheter. The patient will continue to be monitored for any complications and will be educated on the procedure and expected outcomes. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess recovery and manage any complications.

S: Patient A reports a two-month history of difficulty speaking, moving properly, and self-care. The disease began with positive psychotic symptoms like bizarre delusions and auditory hallucinations over a 14-month period, then deteriorated to negative symptoms and catatonia. The patient denies echolalia, echopraxia, negativism, waxy flexibility, mitmachen, or ambitendency. Family consulted faith healers for spiritual treatment, which did not improve symptoms. O: Patient A is diagnosed with catatonic schizophrenia according to the International Classification of Diseases and Related Health Problems (ICD-10). Treatment includes aripiprazole (15 mg a day) and lorazepam (1 mg thrice a day) for catatonic schizophrenia. The patient is advised to start eating, going to the toilet, and eventually speaking. Psychometric tools such as the Positive and Negative Syndrome Scale (PANSS) and the Brief Psychiatric Rating Scale (BPRS) will be used to measure response to the treatment. A: The primary diagnosis is catatonic schizophrenia, based on the ICD-10 classification. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of psychotic disorders, but these are less likely given the patient's history and clinical presentation. P: Initiate treatment with aripiprazole (15 mg a day) and lorazepam (1 mg thrice a day). Monitor the patient's response to the treatment closely, with adjustments to the treatment as necessary based on the patient's response to the therapy. Regular follow-ups are scheduled to assess treatment efficacy and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Educate the patient on the importance of reporting any new symptoms or concerns immediately.

S: The patient, a 12-year-old male, presented with bleeding per rectum and mild abdominal pain for the past 3 days following a blunt abdominal trauma while playing football. The patient denies any relevant medical, surgical, family, or psychosocial history. O: Physical examination revealed tenderness and bowel sounds. FAST showed mild intraperitoneal fluid in the pelvis. CT scan showed mild pelvic hemoperitoneum without definite solid or hollow visceral injury. On admission, the patient's heart rate was 86 bpm and blood pressure was 100/70 mmHg. Hemoglobin was 9.6 gm/dl. On day 3, hemoglobin dropped to 6.1 gm/dl despite receiving 2 units of packed red blood cells. Mild fever was 37.8 °C, tachycardia was 140 bpm, and blood pressure dropped to 70/40 mmHg. On day 3, hemoglobin dropped to 6.1 gm/dl. Colonoscopy revealed altered blood within the whole colon and terminal ileum without a definite bleeding site. A: The primary diagnosis is recurrent bleeding per rectum and mild abdominal pain, likely secondary to a blunt abdominal trauma. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of abdominal bleeding, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation. P: The patient was admitted to the general ward for serial abdominal observation. He was resuscitated with intravenously administered crystalloid fluids and 2 units of packed red blood cells. A laparotomy was performed to further investigate the bleeding site. The patient was advised to report any new symptoms immediately. Further diagnostic and therapeutic management will be necessary based on the patient's progress.

S: The patient is a 45-year-old English teacher presenting with right knee pain persisting for about a year, worsening eight months ago. He reports severe anterior knee pain when climbing stairs or squatting, and a cystic mass in the posterior aspect of the knee joint. He denies any specific trauma or injury. O: Physical examination revealed mild swelling and effusion in the right knee, painful crepitation, moderate tenderness, and a large, non-tender cystic mass in the posterior aspect of the right knee joint. Crepitation was noted in the left knee, but no pain on the left side. The right infrapatellar region is larger and firm, and passive full knee range of motion is possible, but painful. Radiographic examination revealed a large ossicle beneath the patellar tendon and inside the infrapatellar fat pad in the right knee, and a similar-sized ossicle in the left knee, partially fused to the hypertrophied tibial tuberosity. MRI findings showed a 3.8 x 1.3 x 3.0 cm well-circumscribed ossicle near the tibial tubercle. Inflammatory changes in synovium, infrapatellar fat pad, and patellar tendon were noted. A reactive bone marrow edema was noted at the anterior aspect of the tibial condyle. A: The primary diagnosis is a recurrent right knee pain, likely exacerbated by a recurrent cystic mass in the posterior aspect of the knee joint. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of knee pain, but imaging and clinical findings support the primary diagnosis. P: The management plan will include medication, additional therapy, or surgery based on the patient's symptoms and imaging findings. Regular follow-ups will be scheduled to monitor the patient's progress and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. The patient will be educated on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and adherence to follow-up appointments. Referral to a neurologist for further evaluation and management of the recurrent cystic mass is recommended.

S: The patient, a clothing industry worker, reports mild muscle and bone pain in both lower limbs since childhood, which does not interfere with daily life. The patient has a history of developmental dysplasia of the hip during infancy. The patient denies any history of rickets, fractures, or dental problems. The patient denies smoking, alcohol abuse, or drug use. The patient has a family history of breast cancer and Hashimoto's thyroiditis. O: Vital signs include a body temperature of 37.0 °C, blood pressure of 115/80 mmHg, pulse of 101 beats/min, height of 150.3 cm, and body weight of 44 kg. Physical examination revealed spontaneous pain in the right femur and left crus, no tenderness or pain with percussion, no palpebral conjunctiva, bulbar conjunctiva, and no thyroid palpable. Neurological examinations including muscle strength tests, deep tendon reflexes, and esthesia were normal except for spontaneous pain in bilateral legs. Complete blood count was 41.4% and hemoglobin was 13.8. A: The primary diagnosis is low serum ALP levels, likely exacerbated by a family history of breast cancer and Hashimoto's thyroiditis. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of low serum ALP levels, but these are less likely given the family history. P: Continue monitoring serum ALP levels and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Educate the patient on the importance of reporting any new symptoms or changes in the patient's condition. Schedule follow-up appointments to reassess the patient's condition and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient, with a history of 16 nonmelanoma skin cancers, actinic keratoses, seborrheic dermatitis, stasis dermatitis, and tinea pedis, presents for a total body skin check. He reports a history of sleep apnea treated with two liters of oxygen via continuous positive airway pressure each night. He has a history of thyroid issues, cardiac conditions, congestive heart failure, coronary atherosclerosis, hyperlipidemia, hypertension, paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, sick sinus syndrome, and chronic kidney disease. He is currently on amlodipine, carvedilol, febuxostat, ferrous sulfate, finasteride, folic acid, furosemide, levoxyl, pravastatin, tamsulosin, and warfarin. O: Physical examination reveals keratotic plaques on the scalp, face, and arms, actinic keratoses with liquid nitrogen cryotherapy, elongation of the lateral aspect of the cuticle on both great toes, curling of the cuticles on the lateral and medial views of both great toes, and curling of the cuticles on the lateral and medial views of both great toes. A: The primary diagnosis is actinic keratoses with keratotic plaques and elongation of the lateral aspect of the cuticle. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of keratotic plaques, but these are less likely given the patient's medical history and clinical presentation. P: The management plan includes liquid nitrogen cryotherapy for actinic keratoses and a pedicure to address the keratotic plaques. The patient will be scheduled for the pedicure at the earliest convenience. The plan includes scheduling the pedicure at the patient's convenience, which will be scheduled at the earliest convenience. The patient is advised to contact the healthcare provider if any questions or concerns arise.

S: The patient reports feeling weak, experiencing generalized abdominal pain, nausea, and intractable vomiting for a week, with multiple episodes of loose, non-bloody bowel movements. The patient denies fevers, chills, hematochezia, melena, voiding difficulty, dysuria, hematuria, or flank pain. The patient has not experienced fevers, chills, hematochezia, melena, voiding difficulty, dysuria, hematuria, or flank pain in the past 18 years. O: Physical examination reveals a temperature of 36.8°C, heart rate 69 bpm, respiratory rate 16 br/min, blood pressure 147/102 mmHg, and oxygen saturation 100% on room air. Diaphoretic and moderate distress. Abdominal tenderness is normoactive, and costovertebral angle tenderness and Murphy sign are negative. Laboratory findings include a white blood cell count of 6100 K/mcl, hemoglobin 5.9 g/dL, hematocrit 18%, and platelet count 240,000 K/mcl. Basic metabolic panel shows sodium 130 mmol/L, potassium 4.7 mmol/L, chloride 95 mmol/L, CO2 24 mmol/L, BUN >150 mg/dL, creatinine 26.9 mg/dL, anion gap 21, glucose 87 mg/dL, and serum calcium 6.5 mg/dL. Liver function studies and lipase are within normal limits. Fecal occult blood test (FOBT) is negative. Anemia workup shows normal iron levels, low total iron binding capacity (TIBC), high ferritin, normal B12, and low reticulocyte count. Arterial blood gas pH 7.35 and pCO2 32 mmHg. A: The primary diagnosis is a gastrointestinal or renal inflammatory disorder, likely exacerbated by gastrointestinal or renal conditions. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of abdominal pain and nausea, but these are less likely given the laboratory results and clinical presentation. P: Plan to schedule an appointment for a specialist to conduct further diagnostic tests and possibly consult a nephrologist for further evaluation and management.

S: The patient, a recent immigrant from Honduras, reports a history of generalized tonic-clonic seizures for about five years and a recent seizure episode in Honduras three years ago, which has been seizure-free since then. The patient has a history of nonadherence to antiepilepsy medications and has not been on routine medications as an outpatient. The patient has a history of nonadherence to antiepilepsy medications. O: Initial CT scan of the brain showed no remarkable findings. Initial treatment included IV levetiracetam 1000 mg and oral levetiracetam 500 mg twice daily. MRI and EEG were noncontributory. Physical examination and review of systems were noncontributory. MRI indicated a 5 mm ring-enhancing lesion in the posterior right frontal lobe of the cerebral cortex with surrounding vasogenic edema, suggestive of an infective neurocysticercosis lesion. CT scan and EEG were normal. Positive serological antibody test utilizing a western blot assay for cysticercosis immunoglobulin G antibody confirmed parenchymal neurocysticercosis. A: The primary diagnosis is parenchymal neurocysticercosis, likely exacerbated by a parasitic infection in the brain. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of seizures such as ischemic brain injury or a vascular or ischemic insult, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation. P: Initiate treatment with IV levetiracetam 1000 mg and oral levetiracetam 500 mg twice daily. Monitor the patient's response to treatment and adjust as necessary. Educate the patient on the importance of adhering to the treatment regimen and follow-up appointments. Encourage the patient to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately.

S: The patient reports a three-week history of a dry cough. The patient denies any similar past medical history. O: Chest imaging revealed a mass in the anterior mediastinum. Repeat chest X-ray revealed a right-sided para-pericardial mass in the anterior mediastinum, significant decrease in the size of the right middle lobe opacity, and no other focal opacities. Cardiac silhouette was unremarkable. Chest CT scan showed a cystic mass. Intraoperative findings included significant adhesion of the right lung to the anterior chest wall surrounding the cyst. Intraoperative findings included significant adhesion of the right lung to the anterior chest wall, a thick cyst in the anterior segment of the right upper lobe, and cheese-like material. A: The primary diagnosis is a cystic mass in the anterior mediastinum. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of pulmonary embolism, but these are less likely given the imaging and surgical findings. P: The patient underwent a right thoracoscopic approach to remove the cyst. Postoperative recovery was uneventful, with retrieved specimens measuring 64.4 g of lung tissue measuring 14.5 x 6.0 x 3.0 cm and a mass on the pleural surface measuring 6.0 x 5.0 x 2.5 cm containing soft yellow material. Postoperative care will include monitoring for any complications or complications from the surgery. The patient will be educated on signs of complications and advised to report any new symptoms immediately.

S: The patient, referred for progressive weakness and arthralgia involving the proximal part of the superior limbs, reports a 3-month history of weakness, joint pain, intermittent fever, weight loss, and a 6-month history of skin rashes. The patient has not received any therapy for these symptoms. O: On admission, the patient's temperature was 37.4°C. Physical examination revealed significant hepatomegaly and mucocutaneous lichenoid papules on the dorsal surface of the hands, typical of Gottron papules. Jugular venous pressure was raised, heart sounds were normal, and chest was clear to auscultation. Blood pressure was 90/60 mmHg, heart rate was 82 bpm, respiratory rate was 16 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation was 98%. Blood tests showed high alanine transaminase at 78 IU/l, creatine phosphokinase at 736 UI/l, positive Rose-Waaler test, positive anti-Jo1 antibody, and high NT-proBNP levels at 3150 ng/l. Electromyography indicated small, short, polyphasic actions potentials with early recruitment motor unit action potentials indicative of membrane irritability. Right quadriceps femoris biopsy indicated B cells inflammatory infiltrated involving perivascular spaces and interfascicular septae. Musculoskeletal magnetic resonance indicated generalized muscular edema, atrophy, and adipose infiltration. A: The primary diagnosis is DM, evidenced by elevated alanine transaminase, high creatine phosphokinase, positive Rose-Waaler test, positive anti-Jo1 antibody, and high NT-proBNP levels. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of muscle weakness and arthralgia, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: Initiate corticosteroids therapy, specifically 1 mg/kg/day of oral prednisolone and methotrexate (15 mg) to manage symptoms and slow the progression of the disease. Educate the patient on the importance of adh

S: The patient, with a history of non-muscle invasive UC, hypertension, and type 2 diabetes mellitus, presents with swelling and pain in the right anterior mandible for approximately 3 weeks. The patient has tried amoxicillin and cephalexin for pain and swelling. O: Radiograph revealed a radiolucent lesion in the right anterior mandible. Incisional biopsy confirmed metastatic UC with a positive GATA-3 immunostain. Cystoscopy showed a 3-cm anterior bladder wall tumor near the bladder neck, a 1- to 2-cm left anterior wall tumor, and a 1-cm right anterior wall tumor. TURBT showed noninvasive high-grade papillary UC with multiple foci, classified as high-risk. Postinduction TURBT was negative for tumor, and cytology and fluorescent in situ hybridization studies were negative. The patient was placed on surveillance with cystoscopy, cytology, and FISH analysis every 3 months for 2 years, and then every 6 months. A CT Urogram 18 months post-TURBT was performed 18 months post-TURBT. A: The primary diagnosis is metastatic UC with complications including scrotal swelling and fever. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of scrotal swelling and fever. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and response to therapy. P: The management plan will include discussing the patient's current condition with a multidisciplinary team including oncology, oncology, and endocrinology. The patient will be educated on the nature of the disease, treatment options, and potential side effects. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's progress and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Referral to a nephrologist for ongoing management and a pulmonologist for specialized care will be arranged.

S: The patient, an 18-month-old female, presented with snoring and mouth breathing during sleep, sleep apnea, weak aspiration, and nasal leakage when drinking fluids. She was admitted to Shanghai Children's Hospital for further evaluation and management. O: Physical examination revealed a wide fissure splitting from the palate vertical anterior cleft to 1/3 of the hard palate, no congestion in the pharyngeal mucosa, and the uvula in the middle. Bilateral tonsils showed hypertrophy without exudation. The epiglottis and bilateral pear-like nest were not clear. CT scan showed a convex mass convex to the pharyngeal cavity measuring 27 mm  21 mm  26 mm, convex to the pharyngeal cavity, with no abnormalities in the nasopharyngeal bone or soft tissue. Postoperative histological examination showed a well-demarcated mature brain tissue with scattered sand-like particles. A: The primary diagnosis is an incomplete cleft palate with soft palate vascularized space-occupying lesions involving the left posterior wall of the nasopharynx, likely a fibrous hemangioma. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of snoring and mouth breathing, but these are less likely given the imaging and histological findings. P: The patient underwent palatal lump resection and cleft palate repair under general anesthesia. Postoperative care included symptomatic treatment for infection and nasal feeding. Histological examination post-surgery showed a well-demarcated mature brain tissue with scattered sand-like particles. The patient is advised to monitor recovery and follow up regularly to ensure stable and well-managed condition.

S: The patient reports persistent, tolerable headache, nausea, and vomiting for the past day. The headache is described as blunt in the right temporal region. The patient has a three-year history of hypertension and is currently on antihypertensive drugs. The patient denies any psychosocial or familial hereditary history. O: Neurological examination is normal. Laboratory tests including serum C-reactive protein, erythrocyte sedimentation rate, thyroid and sex hormone levels are within normal limits. Serum anti-MPO and P-ANCA are weakly positive. Other markers including antinuclear, anti-SSA, anti-SSB, anti-dsDNA, anti-Sm, anti-RNP, anti-Scl-70, anti-RP3, anti-GBM, and anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies, and antibodies to neuro-paraneoplastic syndromes, neuromyelitis optica, myelin basic protein, and myelin oligodendrocyte glycoprotein are negative. Lumbar puncture showed elevated intracranial pressure at 240 mmH2O. CSF analysis showed normal protein, glucose, cell count, and negative pathogens. MRI of the brain revealed multifocal white matter hyperintensity (WMH) lesions, cortico-subcortical, on T2, and fluid attenuated inversion recovery (FLAIR) associated mass effect. Suceptibility-weighted imaging (SWI) showed multiple cerebral microbleeds in cortical and subcortical areas. MRS was normal, and both angiography and venogram were normal.
