A: The primary diagnosis is a brain tumor, likely exacerbated by the patient's hypertension and antihypertensive drug use. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of headache and nausea, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition with regular follow-ups to assess the progression of the tumor and the presence of brain lesions. Further diagnostic tests may be considered if the patient's symptoms persist or worsen. The patient will be educated on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and adherence to the treatment plan. Referral to

S: The patient, diagnosed with astrocytoma a few weeks ago, reports new onset seizures and has been on levetiracetam but experienced break-through seizures. The patient has been on Lamotrigine for seizure control but has experienced a rash, right upper quadrant abdominal pain, and fever for four days without nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, or joint pains. The patient is a stay-at-home mother of one child, and has not traveled out of the city in the last 18 months. O: Physical examination reveals mild distress with a temperature of 38 degrees Celsius, pulse 110 per minute, respiratory rate 18 breaths per minute, blood pressure 124/77 mm Hg in the right upper limb in the supine position, and oxygen saturation 98% on room air. A reticulated macular erythematous rash on the upper extremities and trunk is noted, with no localized swelling, lymphadenopathy, or icterus. Head and neck examinations are within normal limits. Abdominal exam shows right upper quadrant tenderness. Laboratory findings include eosinophil count of 4 x 105/ml, elevated white cell count, ALT 1231 units/L, AST 1026 units/L, and alkaline phosphatase 362 units/L. Ultrasound of the abdomen and MRI of the cholangiopancreatography confirm the diagnosis. A: The primary diagnosis is astrocytoma with complications including a rash, right upper quadrant abdominal pain, and fever. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of abdominal pain and fever, but these are less likely given the imaging and lab results. P: The management plan will include discontinuation of Lamotrigine as DRESS. The patient will be closely monitored for symptoms and response to treatment, with adjustments to the treatment plan as necessary. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess the effectiveness of the treatment and adjust the plan as necessary. The patient will be educated on the signs of worsening symptoms and advised to report any new symptoms immediately.

S: The patient, a 4-month-old female Simmental calf, presented with polymelia, a single rudimentary limb in the thoracic spine. The calf was alert and in good body condition. The respiratory frequency was slightly increased at 34 breaths per minute, likely due to excitement. O: Clinical examination revealed an otherwise healthy animal with an adequate state of physiologic development. Haematology and blood chemistry tests were normal. The thoracic part of the spine was scoliotic and lordotic. CT scans showed significant overlapping of anatomical structures. Premedication included intramuscular xylazine hydrochloride (0.1 mg/kg) and IV butorphanol tartrate (0.05 mg/kg), followed by IV ketamine hydrochloride (3 mg/kg) and isoflurane (AttaneTM Isoflurane) delivered in 100% oxygen under pressure-controlled mechanical ventilation. Pulse oximetry, side stream capnography, ECG, and oscillometric blood pressure were monitored. CT in sternal recumbency was performed, and anesthesia and recovery were smooth. A: The primary diagnosis is polymelia in the thoracic spine, likely originating from the thoracic spine. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of thoracic spine abnormalities, but imaging and clinical findings support the primary diagnosis. P: The management plan includes further treatment options including surgical interventions to address the polymelia. The patient will be monitored for signs of infection or complications, and further surgical interventions may be considered if necessary. The patient will be educated on signs of infection and the importance of follow-up care. Referral to a veterinary surgeon for further evaluation and management of the polymelia is recommended.

S: The patient is a 7-year-old boy with congenital bilateral sensorineural deafness and a failed right cochlear implant. He reports no discomfort during the MRI. O: During the MRI, the airway was secured with a 5.5 mm internal-diameter uncuffed ETT. Intraoperative neurophysiology monitoring includes brainstem auditory sensory evoked potentials, brainstem mapping of CN IX, X, XI, XII, and their motor nuclei, and corticobulbar tract motor-evoked potential (MEP). The patient's airway was secured with a 5.5 mm internal-diameter uncuffed ETT. A 32 mm by 29 mm laryngeal electrode was used for CN X monitoring. The depth of the ETT corresponding to the laryngeal inlet was 6 cm at vocal cords (15 cm at lips). A new #5.5 uncuffed ETT with laryngeal electrodes was prepared and re-intubated. The tracheal tube was stabilized with rolled up gauzes. Total Intravenous Anesthesia (TIVA) includes propofol (Paedsfusor Target Control Infusion), target plasma concentration (3.5–5.0 mcg/ml) and remifentanil (0.08–0.3 mcg/kg/min). Post-surgery, the patient will be closely monitored for recovery and required follow-up care. A: The primary diagnosis is congenital bilateral sensorineural deafness with complications including a failed right cochlear implant. The patient's condition is complicated by congenital bilateral sensorineural deafness and a failure of the right cochlear implant. P: The patient underwent successful ABI insertion with the use of a 32 mm by 29 mm laryngeal electrode for CN X monitoring and re-intubation. Post-operative care will include close monitoring of recovery and follow-up care. The patient will be educated on the importance of adhering to the postoperative care instructions and adherence to follow-up care. Referral to a pediatric neurology

S: The patient, diagnosed with unilateral breast cancer, reports no prior abdominoplasty and is unaware of bilateral DIEP flaps. The patient has a history of an infection at the left breast, treated with antibiotics, local debridement, and wound care. O: The patient underwent a second-stage procedure six months post-first procedure, which included bilateral fat grafting with 150 mL of fat to each breast and nipple reconstruction. The prognosis depends on the success of the autologous breast reconstruction and the patient's response to the second-stage procedure. P: The patient will undergo autologous breast reconstruction using the patient's own tissue. Postoperative care will include microvascular anastomosis, microvascular anastomosis, and nipple reconstruction. Postoperative care will include antibiotics, local debridement, and wound care. The patient is advised to continue monitoring and follow up with the medical team to ensure the best possible outcome.

S: The patient, a gravida 4, para 1, abort 3, reports experiencing pelvic pain and enlarged ovaries, with a 5-day history of left lower quadrant abdominal pain. The patient denies nausea, vomiting, dysuria, or diarrhea. The patient's last menstrual period was 2 weeks ago. O: Physical examination revealed palpable, cystic, solid masses on both sides in the lower quadrant. Laboratory tests showed a white blood cell count of 22.9  109/L, granulocyte rate of 80.6%, and normal -hCG level. Transient fever was 37.9 °C. Ultrasound imaging and computed tomography showed enlarged ovaries with multiple follicles. Serum hormone levels were normal: FSH 2.38 IU/L, E2, 46.85 pg/mL, P 0.35 ng/mL, T 0.54 ng/mL, LH  0.2 IU/L, PRL 7.44 ng/mL, DHEA 497.5 g/dL, UFC 165.24 g, CA125 365.7 U/mL. Adrenal ultrasound, serum thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH)/free thyroxine (FT4), thyroxine (T4), and hypothalamic-pituitary MRD showed no abnormalities. A: The primary diagnosis is enlarged ovaries with a history of PCOS, complicated by atypical symptoms and atypical symptoms. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of pelvic pain and abdominal pain, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The management plan includes close monitoring of symptoms and reporting any changes or worsening of the condition. The patient will be scheduled for a follow-up appointment to discuss the results of further tests and determine the best course of treatment. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms or worsening of the condition immediately. Further diagnostic tests may be necessary to confirm the diagnosis and guide treatment.

S: The patient is a 55-year-old male presenting with critical left lower limb ischemia and a great toe ulceration. He reports severe pain and numbness in the left leg and a great toe ulceration. He denies any symptoms of critical limb ischemia during the clinical evaluation. He experienced sudden pain and numbness in the right foot and short distance calf claudication after discharge. O: CT angiogram revealed a Trans-Atlantic Inter-Society Consensus (TASC) A lesion in the left superficial femoral artery with patent run-off vessels. A confirmatory angiogram showed satisfactory results with patent run-off vessels. During the left retrograde SFA angioplasty, continuous bleeding was noted. Manual compression was applied for 10 minutes. Post-procedure, pedal pulses were palpable. Physical examination confirmed an unremarkable access site, palpable femoral and popliteal pulses, but absent pedal pulses. Lower limb CT angiogram indicated a metallic artifact in the distal popliteal artery, consistent with VCD embolisation. Endovascular retrieval of the closure device was unsuccessful, leading to severe spasm of the popliteal artery. Surgical exploration of the distal popliteal artery and tibioperoneal trunk revealed a thrombus in the explored arteries with the closure device occluding the TPT bifurcation. A: The primary diagnosis is a trans-Atlantic Inter-Society Consensus (TASC) A lesion in the left superficial femoral artery with patent run-off vessels. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of ischemia, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic following successful surgical intervention. P: The patient is advised to continue anti-platelet therapy and statins. Regular follow-ups are necessary to monitor recovery and manage any complications. The patient is advised to maintain medication and follow up regularly to monitor recovery and manage any complications. Further consultations with a cardiologist and a neurologist are recommended to manage the TASC A lesion and

S: The patient, a six-year-old male, reports experiencing hypotonia since birth. He has a history of kyphosis, a curvature of the spine, normal cognitive function, and no history of seizures. O: The patient's CK and aldolase levels were elevated at 6304 U/l and 44 U/l, respectively. Muscle biopsy and immunohistochemistry (IHC) tests at five months showed dystrophic changes. MRI of the brain at six months was normal. Genetic testing for the LAMA2 gene was recommended. A: The primary diagnosis is merosin deficiency, likely a genetic condition based on clinical and biochemical findings. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of hypotonia, but these are less likely given the clinical and biochemical findings. P: The management plan includes obtaining a genetic test for the LAMA2 gene to confirm the diagnosis. The patient will continue to be monitored for symptoms and cognitive function, with no history of seizures. The family will be educated on the importance of monitoring symptoms and reporting any concerns. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's condition and adjust treatment as necessary.

S: The patient, born in Sierra Leone, presented with a 3-month history of personality changes, sleepiness, walking with a shuffling gait, and fatigue. Initially treated with intravenous acyclovir and ceftriaxone, the patient experienced a generalized tonic-clonic seizure and was intubated and admitted to the intensive therapy unit (ITU). During treatment, the patient experienced a generalized tonic-clonic seizure and was unresponsive, necessitating intubation and admission to the intensive therapy unit. O: Physical examination revealed right side lateral gaze palsy, rigidity, and bradykinesia. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) showed a white cell count of 250, 100% mononuclear, and a protein level of 0.57 g/l with a normal CSF/serum glucose ratio. Serology for herpes virus and syphilis serology was negative. Laboratory tests showed high voltage gated potassium channel-complex antibodies and moderate N-methyl-D-aspartate antibodies. Initial treatment with intravenous acyclovir and ceftriaxone was ineffective. During ITU, bone marrow trephine microscopy revealed Trypomastigotes of T. brucei in peripheral blood. Repeat CSF tests showed a positive T.b. gambiense IFAT at 1:32 and serum IFAT at 1:3200. T2W FLAIR MRI showed bilateral supratentorial deep white matter high signal intensity, extending to the cerebellum and brain stem, and the mesial temporal lobe structures. On day 9, CSF test showed no evidence of trypanosomes. A: The primary diagnosis is Stage 2 West African trypanosomiasis with complications including a generalized tonic-clonic seizure and unresponsiveness. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of cerebral palsy, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and laboratory findings. P: Continue monitoring the patient's response to treatment and adjust as necessary. Regular follow-ups are necessary to assess the effectiveness of the treatment and adjust as necessary. S: The patient reports progressive visual loss in both eyes for a week, headaches, nausea, and vomiting for the past two months. The patient denies any prolonged fever, chronic cough, weight loss, or loss of appetite. The patient's father has pulmonary tuberculosis treated with anti-tuberculosis therapy two years ago. O: Best corrected visual acuity is 3/60 in the right eye and 4/60 in the left eye. Optic nerve function tests show impaired optic nerve function in both eyes, including light brightness, contrast sensitivity, and color vision, with a relative afferent pupillary defect in the right eye. Contrast test reveals generalized haziness with dense central scotoma in bilateral vision. Fundoscopy examination reveals bilateral papilledema, swollen optic discs with peripapillary flame-shaped hemorrhages and macular exudates, but no vitritis or panuveitis. Vital signs are stable, afebrile, and no signs of meningism or localizing signs. Respiratory examination shows crepitation in the right lung. Other cranial nerves examinations are unremarkable. Baseline blood investigations show elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (79 mm/h) and C-reactive protein (23 mg/l). Human immunodeficiency virus antibody test was negative. Mantoux test was positive with a 16 mm area of induration. Sputum microscopic examination identified acid-fast bacilli and chest radiograph showed cavitations at the right lower zone. CT scan confirmed tuberculosis. A: The primary diagnosis is tuberculosis, evidenced by imaging and clinical findings. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of visual impairment, but these are less likely given the imaging findings and clinical presentation. P: Initiate treatment for tuberculosis with close monitoring of the patient's response to treatment. Regular follow-ups are necessary to monitor the patient's response to treatment and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Educate the patient on the importance of reporting any new symptoms or changes in condition. Consider referral to a neurologist for further evaluation and management of tuber

S: The patient, a child, presented for an assessment in preparation for orthognathic surgery. He reports a 1.5 cm diameter exophytic midline tongue lesion, which has not changed since childhood. O: Physical examination revealed a 1.5 cm diameter exophytic midline tongue lesion, smooth, regular, and soft to palpation. MRI of the tongue revealed a 1.5 cm protuberant mass arising from the dorsal aspect of the tongue at the approximate junction of the oral component and base. Histological examination confirmed the lesion as a leiomyomatous hamartoma, characterized by fibrovascular connective tissue, smooth-muscle bundles, skeletal muscle fibers, adipose tissue, salivary tissue, blood vessels, lymphoid tissue, peripheral nerves, and ganglion cells. Microscopy showed circumscribed nodules covered by stratified squamous epithelium and interlacing cords of eosinophilic spindle-shaped cells consistent with smooth muscle within the lamina propria. Histological examination confirmed the lesion as a benign leiomyomatous hamartoma, with no nuclear atypia, cellular pleomorphism, mitosis, or necrosis. A: The primary diagnosis is a benign leiomyomatous hamartoma of the lamina propria, characterized by fibrovascular connective tissue, smooth-muscle bundles, skeletal muscle fibers, adipose tissue, salivary tissue, blood vessels, lymphoid tissue, peripheral nerves, and ganglion cells. The lesion is benign, and the patient is advised to monitor it in future check-ups. P: The management plan includes surgical removal of the lesion and further histological examination to confirm the diagnosis. The patient will be monitored in future check-ups to ensure no complications arise from the lesion. The patient will be educated on the nature of the lesion and the importance of follow-up care.

S: The patient, with a history of ankylosing spondylitis for the past 10 years, reports feeling fatigued. He denies fever, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, confusion, or headaches. He has been on certolizumab pegol treatment for ankylosing spondylitis for 6 months, starting with 400 mg and 200 mg every 2 weeks. He denies recent travel, illicit drug use, quinine-containing drugs, or untreated water. O: Current complete blood count shows hemoglobin at 14.4 g/dL, hematocrit at 52%, leucocyte count at 8900/mm3, and platelet count at 415000/mm3. Monthly evaluations were normal until 5 months into the treatment. Biochemical analysis indicates significant elevation in lactate dehydrogenase at 5680 U/L, total bilirubin at 2.2 mg/dL, direct bilirubin at 0.32 mg/dL, and haptoglobulin at 28 mg/dL. Renal functions are normal, and no proteinuria is noted. Peripheral blood smear shows schistocytes in about 20% of erythrocytes per field. A: The primary diagnosis is thrombotic microangiopathy secondary to certolizumab pegol treatment. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of ankylosing spondylitis, but these are less likely given the clinical and laboratory findings. P: Initiate plasma exchange and 1 mg/kg/day of methylprednisolone to address thrombotic microangiopathy. Collect samples for ADAMTS13 evaluation before plasmapheresis. Continue daily plasma exchange and corticosteroid treatment. Monitor renal function and proteinuria closely. Educate the patient on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and reporting any new symptoms or concerns.

S: The patient, a 2.5-year-old male with a BMI of 17.7, presents with complete hearing loss since birth, aphasia, and a history of bilious vomiting, failure to thrive, and severe constipation. He has a family history of Hirschsprung's disease, confirmed by a rectal biopsy and end-colostomy at the descending colon. O: Vital signs include a heart rate of 85 bpm, blood pressure of 110/85 mmHg, and respiratory rate of 18/min. Physical examination reveals blue homochromatic irises with a normal visual response, coarse hair texture, pallor of nails, and a slightly broad high nasal root, and segmental depigmentation on the forehead and left forearm. The patient has a white hair patch (poliosis) in the frontal hair distribution since birth, which diminished upon cutting the hair. He has a history of bilious vomiting, failure to thrive, and severe constipation at six months. Auditory brainstem response indicates bilateral sensorineural hearing loss. A: The primary diagnosis is Hirschsprung's disease with associated aphasia and bilateral sensorineural hearing loss. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of hearing loss, but these are less likely given the family history. The prognosis depends on the management of Hirschsprung's disease and the management of aphasia. P: Continue monitoring the patient's progress and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Educate the mother on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and monitoring for any complications. Schedule follow-up appointments to assess progress and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient, a 52-year-old smoker with a history of bilateral cryptorchidism, presents with intermittent hematuria with clotting for the past 2 weeks. He denies any other complaints. O: Physical examination shows no localized tenderness or palpable mass in the lumbar fossae. The prostate is painless and without suspect lesions. Laboratory tests include hemoglobin at 13 g/dl, platelet level, homeostasis, and renal function. Urine analysis shows red blood cells but is sterile. Prostate-specific antigen level is 1.09 ng/ml. Ultrasound and CT scans reveal an enlarged hypoechoic mass on the upper pole of the right kidney with a dilated ureter and a hypovascularized intraluminal papillary tumor in the right lumbar ureter. Urine analysis shows red blood cells but is sterile. CT and MRI confirm the right ureteral duplicity with a destroyed upper pole, a 20 mm endoluminal tumor at the L4–L5 disc, partially calcified, and highly enhancing, with conserved secretory and excretory functions, and a left ureteral bifidity without parenchymal lesions. Cystoscopy under anesthesia was normal. The two meatuses were of normal seat. A: The primary diagnosis is a tumor in the right lumbar ureter, complicated by a tumorous ureter orifice. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of hematuria and clotting, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: Plan to discuss further treatment options based on the tumor's location and kidney function. Monitor renal function closely and consider surgical intervention if necessary. Educate the patient on the importance of smoking cessation and the importance of regular follow-up appointments. Consider referral to a nephrologist for further evaluation and management.

S: The patient, a 20 pack-year smoker, presented with dyspnea and a small-volume hemoptysis that started 2 weeks ago. The patient reported feeling weak but did not lose weight. The patient has a history of pre-eclampsia during two pregnancies but no history of toxic chemicals or changes in smoking habits. O: On admission, clinical examination revealed apyrexia, hypertension (BP 184/105 mmHg), pulse rate 96 beats/minute, and skin pallor. Chest X-ray revealed bilateral infiltrates. Thoracic CT scan indicated diffuse and bilateral ground-glass opacification. Laboratory findings showed normocytic normochromic anemia with hemoglobin at 7 g/dL, normal platelet and leucocyte counts, and creatinine level increased from 50 mol/L in June 2011 to 614 mol/L, indicating acute renal failure. Bronchoscopy revealed hematic traces with a Golde score of 197, negative bacterial cultures, and negative serologic tests for auto-antibodies, ANCA, and anti-GBM antibodies. Hemolytic complement fractions were normal with C3 at 1.22 g/L and C4 at 0.28 g/L. Renal biopsy indicated fibrinoid necrosis in 10 of 29 glomeruli (34.5%), glomerulosclerosis in 30% of glomeruli, and cellular glomerular crescents in 28%. Immunofluorescence analysis confirmed linear deposition of IgG, consistent with Goodpasture Syndrome. A: The primary diagnosis is Goodpasture Syndrome, a rare autoimmune disease affecting the kidneys and lungs. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of hemoptysis, but these are less likely given the patient's history and clinical presentation. P: The patient underwent daily plasmapheresis as part of a treatment plan. Continued monitoring of the patient's condition is necessary, with adjustments to the treatment regimen as necessary based on the patient's response to the treatment. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's condition and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. The patient is advised to

S: The patient, previously treated with a retrograde expandable Fixion® nail, presented with a history of chronic heel pain for the past two and a half years. The patient denied consenting to the removal of the nail, which was initially considered necessary but was later deemed necessary due to the prominence at the bottom end of the nail. O: The patient underwent an extraction of the nail using the standard extraction technique, but the nail fractured at the junction of the valve and fins, leading to the abandonment of the procedure. The nail remains asymptomatic, and the patient is currently asymptomatic. A: The primary diagnosis is a multifragmentary Pilon fracture, likely secondary to the prominence at the bottom end of the nail. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of heel pain, but these are less likely given the patient's history and current symptoms. P: The management plan includes removing the nail remnant unless it becomes symptomatic. The patient is advised to maintain the nail remnant unless it becomes symptomatic. Regular follow-up visits are scheduled to monitor the condition and ensure stability. The patient is advised to maintain regular follow-up visits to monitor for any recurrence or complications.

S: The patient reports feeling nervous about the surgical procedure. He has a history of acute appendicitis treated with curative antimicrobial treatment 2 months ago. He denies any abdominal pain or discomfort. O: Physical examination revealed multiple neurofibromas and café-au-lait spots on the skin. Laboratory analysis showed normal levels for hemoglobin, white blood cell count, platelets, serum total protein, serum albumin, total bilirubin, aspartate aminotransferase, alanine aminotransferase, lactic acid dehydrogenase, and C-reactive protein. Tumor markers including carcinoembryonic antigen and carbohydrate antigen 19-9 were normal. Contrast-enhanced CT and colonoscopy showed thickened appendiceal mucosa projecting to the cecum without abscess or jellylike liquid. Histopathological examination of the appendix showed atypical mucinous epithelial cells with multiple neurofibromas in the muscle layer, submucosa, and mucosa, and micro plexiform neurofibromas in the neuroplexus of the appendix. Immunohistochemical examination was positive for S100 protein. A: The primary diagnosis is chronic appendicitis with chronic appendiceal inflammation and appendiceal neoplasms. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of appendicitis, but these are less likely given the imaging and histopathological findings. P: Plan to proceed with laparoscopic cecectomy to remove the affected appendix. Post-operative care will include monitoring for potential complications and discussing further treatment options if necessary. The patient will be educated on the importance of adhering to the surgical plan and post-operative recovery to prevent future complications.

S: The patient is a 40-year-old African-American male with a history of neurosarcoidosis involving the hypothalamus and pituitary, presenting with altered mental status. He reports feeling lethargic, unable to respond to people when they talk to him. O: On examination, the patient was responsive to verbal stimuli but was hypothermic with a temperature of 32°C and hypernatremic with a sodium level of 176 mEq/L. ECG showed sinus bradycardia at 41 bpm, first-degree AV block at PR interval of 280 ms, premature atrial contractions, prolonged QRS at 160 ms, and QT intervals with a QTc of 584 ms. Osborn waves were noted in the precordial lateral leads. Intravenous fluid management and administration of intranasal desmopressin improved serum sodium levels and mental status. A: The primary diagnosis is neurosarcoidosis involving the hypothalamus and pituitary, complicated by AV block and Osborn waves. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of hypothermia and hypernatremic symptoms, but these are less likely given the ECG findings and clinical presentation. P: The patient was admitted to the intensive care unit with careful intravenous fluid management and administration of intranasal desmopressin, which improved serum sodium levels and mental status. The treatment plan includes continuation of corticosteroids, testosterone, levothyroxine, and desmopressin. The patient is expected to be discharged ten days post-procedure. Follow-up with the healthcare team is recommended for further evaluation and management.

S: The patient, a 76-year-old male with no pathological history, presented with a 5-day evolution fever, abdominal distension, and a palpable mass in the hypogastrium. He reported feeling weak and experiencing faster heartbeats. O: Initial resuscitation was initiated with 2000 ml of physiological solution and antibiotic therapy with Metronidazole and Ceftriaxone. Exploration revealed an indurated and mobile formation in the hypogastrium without signs of peritoneal irritation. Blood analysis indicated leukocytosis with immature cells and increased CRP with normal lactate levels. Abdominal CT scan showed a large supra-bladder pelvic mass of 12 cm with central necrosis and hydro-aerial level. Hepatic intra-portal gas was noted. Pigtail drainage was placed, and noradrenaline was administered at 0.15 g/kg/min. Post-operative recovery was well-received, with a complete drained intra-tumoral abscess. Anatomopathological examination of the tumor revealed mesenchymal proliferation on the intestinal wall without mucosa infiltration. A: The primary diagnosis is a large tumor of the jejunum with associated intestinal perforation. Differential diagnosis initially included other causes of intestinal perforation, but these were ruled out by culture and biopsy. P: The patient underwent urgent surgical intervention with intestinal resection and mechanical anastomosis. Post-operative recovery was well-received, and the patient was discharged after 13 days. The prognosis is guarded due to the aggressive nature of the tumor and the patient's condition.

S: The patient, a 16-year-old male, reports experiencing headaches since age 10 and has been experiencing them since age 16. He has a history of headaches since age 10, and his mother has a similar condition. He also mentions his mother with prominent calcification in the bilateral globus pallidus, caudate nuclei, thalamus, dentate nuclei, and subcortical white matter. O: Physical examination revealed spotty calcification in the bilateral globus pallidus and caudate nuclei, with mild calcification in the thalamus, subcortical white matter, and dentate nuclei. CT images showed spotty calcification in the bilateral globus pallidus and caudate nuclei, with mild calcification in the thalamus, subcortical white matter, and dentate nuclei. DNA analysis confirmed the patient's third brother with the same variant, but his eldest brother did not present with the variant. The patient's younger sister is currently in a nursing institution due to mental retardation. A: The primary diagnosis is a genetic disorder with a differential diagnosis of a neurological disorder, specifically a genetic disorder, given the genetic findings and the patient's family history. The differential diagnosis includes other causes of headaches, but the primary diagnosis is a genetic disorder. P: Continue regular neurological checkups to monitor the patient's condition and symptoms. Educate the patient on the importance of reporting any new symptoms or worsening of symptoms. Schedule regular follow-up appointments to monitor the patient's condition and symptoms. Encourage the patient to report any changes or worsening of symptoms immediately.

S: The patient, with a history of two cervical surgeries in 1987 and 2003, reports experiencing fatigue, chills, headaches, nausea, asymmetric arthralgia, malar rash post-sun exposure, and a fluctuating rash in the trunk area since 2005. The patient has a history of arthritis of the left shoulder and left ankle, livedo reticularis, and an erythematous cutaneous rash in the thorax, with no infection foci. The patient has experienced a fluctuating course from 2005 to 2007, with symptoms of dysphagia, halitosis, and "sputum" production of a purulent aspect. O: Physical examination revealed arthritis of the left shoulder and left ankle, livedo reticularis, and an erythematous cutaneous rash in the thorax. Laboratory tests showed thrombocytosis of 485,000 cells/mm3, elevated CRP of 75 mg/dl, and an ESR of 40 mm/h. Autoantibodies were negative, and complement levels were within normal limits. SPECT indicated spondylitis in the cervical spine (C4-C6), an inflammatory process in the nasopharynx, an increase in the prevertebral space of > 2 cm, and free air in this area. Esophagogram with hyd was performed. A: The primary diagnosis is spondylitis in the cervical spine, evidenced by elevated CRP, ESR, and thrombocytosis. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of arthralgia, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. The prognosis depends on the management of the spondylitis and the progression of symptoms. P: The management plan will include further diagnostic tests including a CT scan of the cervical spine to assess for spondylitis. The patient will be educated on the importance of regular follow-up with the rheumatologist and other specialists to manage symptoms effectively. Referral to a rheumatologist for further evaluation and management of spondylitis is recommended. Patient education on the importance of adherence to follow-up appointments will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient, with a history of well-controlled type II diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia, presented with left lower quadrant abdominal pain for the past 3 days, rated 6/10, radiating to the left lower back. Additionally, the patient experienced a high-grade fever of 103°F, nausea, and vomiting. The patient denies any history of urinary tract infections or renal stones. O: Vital signs include blood pressure 172/86 mmHg, heart rate 94 bpm, and temperature 102°F. BMI 46.61 kg/m2. Physical examination revealed tenderness in the left lower quadrant and left flank. Urinalysis indicated pyuria, bacteriuria, and nitrites. Hemoglobin A1C was 7.5% (59 mmol/mol). CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis showed a 4-5 mm obstructive left distal ureteral stone with mild hydroureteronephrosis. A: The primary diagnosis is obstructing nephrolithiasis complicated by pyelonephritis, complicated by obstructing nephrolithiasis and pyelonephritis. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of nephrolithiasis and pyelonephritis, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The patient was initially treated with intravenous ceftriaxone 1 gram every 24 hours, followed by cystoscopy with retrograde pyelography and placement of a left 6-French  24 cm double-J ureteral stent. The patient was discharged home with cefdinir 300 mg twice a day for 14 days and tamsulosin 0.4 mg daily for 30 days. Urine cultures from the left renal pelvis and bladder showed no growth. A: The primary diagnosis is obstructing nephrolithiasis complicated by pyelonephritis, complicated by obstructing nephrolithiasis and pyelonephritis. The

S: The patient is a 31-year-old female presenting with a recurrent itchy eruption on her mid- to lower back, lateral chest wall, and nape of her neck, which has been recurrent for a long time. She reports the eruptions occur during fasting during Ramadan or travel to North America. She denies any recent medical issues. O: The patient's symptoms are recurrent, with a net-like pigmentation after itching resolves. The eruptions are associated with fasting during Ramadan or travel to North America. A: The primary diagnosis is a recurrent itchy eruption on the mid- to lower back, lateral chest wall, and nape of her neck, likely exacerbated by fasting and travel. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of itchy eruptions, but these are less likely given the patient's history of fasting and travel. The prognosis depends on the severity of the eruptions and response to treatment. P: The management plan includes maintaining moisturized skin and avoiding irritants that could exacerbate the itching. Stress management is recommended to reduce flare-ups. Adjusting fasting practices during Ramadan or travel plans to reduce the likelihood of eruptions is recommended. The patient is advised to monitor the affected areas and report any worsening or new symptoms immediately. Regular follow-up appointments are scheduled to assess the effectiveness of the treatment and adjust the plan as necessary.

S: Ms. C., previously diagnosed with uveal melanoma in 2014, reports regular check-ups. She has a history of angiomyolipoma of the kidney, uterine leiomyoma, obstructive sleep apnea, enthesopathy in the hip, Achilles tendinitis, and arthritis, treated with a bone graft, estradiol-norethindrone, and trazodone. She is allergic to gabapentin and has no family history of inflammatory bowel disease or GI malignancy. She began ipilimumab 3 mg/kg on April 29th, with new onset paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, treated with metoprolol and apixiban. She also experienced epigastric pain and symptoms of gastric reflux, unresponsive to high dose proton pump inhibitors. O: Past medical history includes angiomyolipoma of the kidney, uterine leiomyoma, obstructive sleep apnea, and enthesopathy in the hip, Achilles tendinitis, and arthritis. She is currently on estradiol-norethindrone and trazodone. She has a history of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation treated with metoprolol and apixiban, with new onset of epigastric pain and symptoms of gastric reflux. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy and flexible sigmoidoscopy revealed normal esophageal, gastric, and duodenal mucosa but lymphocytic inflammation surrounding pigmented cells. Gastric biopsies showed lymphocytic inflammation surrounding pigmented cells. A: The primary diagnosis is uveal melanoma with liver metastases. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of gastrointestinal malignancies, but these are less likely given the patient's history and imaging findings. The prognosis depends on the response to ipilimumab and response to treatment. P: Continue current regimen of estradiol-norethindrone and

S: The patient, previously diagnosed with Felty syndrome at age 64, reports a history of chronic disease, rheumatoid arthritis, neutropenia, and an enlarged spleen. The patient has a history of splenectomy at 67 years old, which led to refractory anemia and myelodysplastic syndrome. The patient has undergone multiple treatments including erythropoietin support, adjusted-dose lenalidomide, adjusted-dose lenalidomide, and one cycle of azacitidine, which was discontinued after a BM examination showed no morphologic support for residual MDS. O: BM core biopsy and aspiration revealed hypercellular marrow with trilineage dysplasia, moderate reticulin fibrosis, and 2% blasts. Flow cytometry indicated changes consistent with MDS, with decreased side scatter in granulocytes, absence of hematogones, and aberrant myeloid blasts with increased CD13 and CD34, decreased CD38, and a normal diploid karyotype. Dendritic cells with a CD123bright, CD4+, HLA-DR+, CD56 immunophenotype were 0.2% of all analyzed cells. Cytogenetic studies showed a normal diploid karyotype. A: The primary diagnosis is refractory anemia with associated myelodysplastic syndrome and myelodysplastic syndrome. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of refractory anemia and myelodysplastic syndrome, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The management plan will include a team of specialists to discuss the case with a multidisciplinary team to determine the best course of action to manage anemia and MDS. The patient will be kept informed and provided with all necessary information and support. Referral to a rheumatologist for further evaluation and management of MDS is recommended.

S: The patient is a 76-year-old Asian male with a 55-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus, presenting with right intermittent claudication for 3 years. He reports a history of diabetic retinopathy treated with insulin for the past 3 years. O: Vascular examination revealed a right femoral bruit and diminished right popliteal pulse, suggesting a right femoral lesion. Right ABI measured by volume plethysmograph was 1.28 (normal range: 1.00–1.40), while the left ABI was elevated at 1.55 (>1.40), indicating incompressible infrapopliteal arteries at the left ankle. An angiography confirmed a severe stenotic lesion at the origin of the right superficial femoral artery, with no occlusive arterial disease in the left extremity. Fluoroscopic and computed tomography revealed severe calcification of infrapopliteal arteries at the right ankle and bilateral infrapopliteal arteries. A: The primary diagnosis is a severe stenotic lesion at the origin of the right superficial femoral artery, with no occlusive arterial disease in the left extremity. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of right ankle claudication, but these are less likely given the imaging and angiography results. P: The patient was started on a supervised exercise training program for 6 months, followed by regular walking 2 hours a day. The supervised exercise training program was discontinued due to severe calcification of infrapopliteal arteries at the right ankle and bilateral infrapopliteal arteries. A: The primary diagnosis is a severe stenotic lesion at the origin of the right superficial femoral artery, with no occlusive arterial disease in the left extremity. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of right ankle claudication, but these are less likely given the imaging and angiography results.
