S: The patient, a male with a history of viral gastroenteritis treated with antibiotics, presents with nausea, vomiting, and bloody diarrhea persisting for five days. He reports poor oral intake and increased weakness. He recalls eating meatloaf three days prior to the onset of symptoms. O: Vital signs are stable with dry mucous membranes. Laboratory tests reveal hemoglobin at 12 g/dl (reduced from 15.4 two months ago), platelet count at 47 x 103/mL (lower than 161 two months ago), sodium at 119 mmol/L, potassium at 4.4 mmol/L, creatinine at 6.7 mg/dl (baseline creatinine was 1.0 mg/dl), and blood urea nitrogen at 99 mg/dL. Urinalysis shows mildly increased schistocytes, normochromic normocytic erythrocytes, marked thrombocytopenia, elevated reticulocyte count at 3.08%, lactic acid dehydrogenase at 480 IU/L, normal bilirubin levels, haptoglobin at 163 mg/dL, and free hemoglobin at 115 mg/dL. A: The primary diagnosis is a urinary tract infection caused by Enterococcus faecalis. Differential diagnoses include atypical hemolytic uremic syndrome (TMA) and thrombotic microangiopathy (ADAMTS13 activity at 92%). The patient's symptoms and laboratory findings suggest a urinary tract infection. P: Initiate ampicillin treatment for TMA. Monitor the patient's condition closely and report any new-onset thrombocytopenia, anemia, or acute kidney injury. Schedule a follow-up appointment with the primary care physician and report any recent hospital visits and lab results. Educate the patient on the importance of reporting new symptoms and adherence to the treatment plan.

S: The patient is a 27-year-old female with no past medical or surgical history, presenting with fever, altered consciousness, and hypotension. She reports a rash on her face for the last year, which has not resolved. She denies any contact with sick people or recent travel. O: Physical examination revealed typical physical signs of dermatomyositis, including a heliotrope rash on her face. Laboratory findings include hemoglobin at 8.5 g/dl, hematocrit at 0.28, RBCs at 3.30x1012/L, platelet count at 40,000/ul, LDH at 814 IU/L, total bilirubin at 2.2mg/dl, PT at 16 sec, aPTT at 38 sec, BUN at 42 mg/dL, and creatinine at 3.5 mg/dL. Spinal tap, urinalysis, and blood cultures were negative, indicating an autoimmune etiology of dermatomyositis. A: The primary diagnosis is dermatomyositis, characterized by fever, altered state of consciousness, renal failure, anemia, and thrombocytopenia. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of dermatomyositis, but these are less likely given the laboratory results and clinical presentation. P: The patient has been started on plasmapheresis to address the autoimmune etiology of dermatomyositis. The treatment plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition and adjustments to the treatment plan as necessary. The patient will be educated on the importance of adhering to the treatment regimen and regular follow-up appointments to assess treatment efficacy and manage any complications.

S: The patient, a current smoker with a history of asthma and atrial fibrillation, presented with sudden, intense back pain. The pain was initially suspected to be aortic dissection, which was ruled out by imaging and non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs. The patient denies any current medications and has a corgi dog that has bitten and scratched her. O: On admission, the patient's body temperature was 37.5 °C, blood pressure 127/48 mmHg, heart rate 84 bpm, and oxygen saturation 95% in ambient air without accelerated respiration. Laboratory tests showed a white blood cell count of 13,360 cells/mm3, platelet count 17.0  104/L, serum creatinine 0.66 mg/dL, and C-reactive protein 18.5 mg/dL. Enhanced CT and plane MRI of the spine was undiagnosed, but Gram-negative bacilli were detected in blood cultures. A: The primary diagnosis is spinal epidural abscess or vertebral osteomyelitis/discitis, complicated by Gram-negative bacilli. Differential diagnoses initially included aortic dissection and aortic involvement, which were ruled out based on imaging and lab results. P: The patient was started on intravenous meropenem 1 g every 8 hours as a provisional diagnosis of spinal epidural abscess or vertebral osteomyelitis/discitis. The drug susceptibility was confirmed by the Vitek2 system. The patient is advised to avoid further dog bites or scratches to prevent further complications. Regular follow-ups will be scheduled to monitor the patient's response to the treatment and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient, a pregnant woman, reported experiencing high blood pressure and petechiae during pregnancy. She recalls the symptoms of high blood pressure and petechiae during pregnancy. She was diagnosed with an acute pregnancy-onset TTP episode, characterized by low platelet count, anemia, and other blood cell issues. She underwent plasma exchange and corticosteroids, which normalized platelet count after 6 days of treatment. She also experienced Escherichia coli-induced sepsis, leading to discontinuation of plasma exchange treatment. O: The patient's thrombocytopenia was 5 x 109 platelets/L, hemolytic anemia was 7.0 g/dL, schistocytes were 7-10 out of every 1,000 red blood cells, and lactate dehydrogenase levels were increased to 454 U/L. Direct Coombs test was negative. MRI of the brain revealed old ischemic lesions in both cerebral hemispheres, likely from an ischemic event 7 months prior. The patient developed Escherichia coli-induced sepsis, necessitating restarting plasma exchange treatment. ADAMTS13 was fully characterized in both plasma and molecular levels. A: The primary diagnosis is acute pregnancy-onset TTP episode, complicated by severe intrauterine growth restriction, ischemic lesions, and Escherichia coli-induced sepsis. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of ischemic lesions, but these are less likely given the clinical and molecular findings. The prognosis is guarded due to the severity of the ischemic lesions and the patient's history of severe intrauterine growth restriction. P: Continue regular follow-up appointments to monitor the patient's health and detect any new symptoms. Educate the patient on signs of infection or recurrence of TTP and encourage immediate reporting of any new symptoms. Encourage the patient to report any new symptoms immediately.

S: The patient, referred in December 2017 for acute liver failure of unknown origin, reports no pre-existing medical conditions, exposure to drugs, promiscuity, or autoimmune disorders. Initially, the patient was experiencing fatigue and indolent jaundice. O: Physical examination revealed distinct jaundice and hepatic encephalopathy grade I. Laboratory findings included massively elevated transaminases (ALT 4645 U/l, AST 4956 U/l), cholestatic liver enzymes (AP 216 U/l, -GT 91 U/l), total bilirubin 14.8 mg/dl, INR 2.39, and factor V activity less than 35%. Laboratory tests for autoimmune hepatitis, viral hepatitis (A-E), Wilson's disease, and hemochromatosis were unremarkable. A: The primary diagnosis is cryptogenic acute liver failure, evidenced by elevated transaminases, cholestatic liver enzymes, and liver synthesis parameters. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of liver dysfunction, but these are less likely given the laboratory findings and clinical presentation. P: The treatment plan includes supportive treatment with vitamin K, ursodeoxycholic acid, and lactulose. The patient's liver maximum capacity (LiMAx) test showed significant impairment of enzymatic liver function at 147 g/h/kg, below the normal range of over 315 g/h/kg. The patient is currently on non-acetaminophen-induced acute liver failure, which has deteriorated. A: The primary diagnosis is cryptogenic acute liver failure, evidenced by elevated transaminases, cholestatic liver enzymes, and liver synthesis parameters. The patient's clinical presentation and laboratory findings support the diagnosis of cryptogenic acute liver failure. P: Continue supportive treatment with vitamin K, ursodeoxycholic acid, and lactulose. Monitor liver function closely and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Educate the patient on the importance of adhering to the treatment regimen and adherence to the treatment plan. Schedule follow-up appointments to assess progress and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient is a 56-year-old mother of 3, presenting with multiple neck lumps for 4 months, general vague abdominal pain, loss of appetite, and lower back pain. She denies any significant medical, family, or psychosocial history. O: Clinical examination revealed multiple enlarged cervical lymph nodes, firm to hard in consistency, a 2x2 cm firm lump on the lower pole of the left thyroid lobe, and enlarged right inguinal lymph nodes. Abdominal, rectal, and breast examinations were normal. The uterine cervix felt hard and unhealthy, and spinal tenderness was noted. Neurological examination of the lower limbs was normal. Basic blood investigations, liver profile, and renal functions were within normal limits. Ultrasound of the abdomen and neck showed no abnormalities. CT scan of the neck, chest, abdomen, and pelvis revealed a mass in the uterine cervix, multiple enlarged lymph nodes in various areas, low-density nodules in the thyroid gland, a mixed density mass lesion in the lower pole of the left thyroid lobe, and an anterior wedge fracture of the L2 vertebra. Biopsies from the uterine cervix and endometrial curettage indicated moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma. Excision biopsy of one left cervical lymph node showed metastatic deposits of moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma. Ultrasound-guided fine needle aspiration cytology was performed on the thyroid. A: The primary diagnosis is moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of the uterine cervix, likely a recurrence of the uterine cervix. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of cervical cancer, but these are less likely given the imaging and biopsy results. P: The management plan includes a comprehensive treatment plan including surgery, radiation therapy, chemotherapy, or combination of these. The patient will be educated on the nature of the disease, treatment options, and the importance of adhering to the treatment plan. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the progression of the disease and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient is a 61-year-old male with a history of alcohol abuse and presumed cirrhosis, presenting with a chief complaint of weakness and drooping of the right side of his face. O: Vital signs include low blood pressure and lower body temperature. Diagnostic paracentesis showed 9,787 nucleated cells per microliter with abundant intra- and extra-cellular bacteria. Point-of-care ultrasound revealed air bubbles and debris through ascites and intraperitoneal A-lines, indicative of pneumoperitoneum. A portable abdominal radiograph was suspicious for free air. Post-surgery, a ruptured gastric ulcer and ischemia were noted in the distal ileum and cecum, but no frank necrosis was noted. A: The primary diagnosis is pneumoperitoneum secondary to a ruptured gastric ulcer and ischemia in the distal ileum and cecum. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of drooping of the face, but these are less likely given the imaging and surgical findings. P: The patient underwent surgical intervention for a ruptured gastric ulcer and ischemia, with no frank necrosis noted. Post-operative care will include monitoring for recovery and adherence to follow-up care. The patient will be educated on signs of infection and advised to report any new symptoms immediately. Referral to a gastroenterologist for further evaluation and management of the gastric ulcer and ischemia is planned.

S: The patient, a male with a history of hypertension and diabetes, presents with a painless swelling on the right side of the neck, below the jaw, for the past two weeks. He reports no fever or other symptoms. O: Physical examination revealed a 6 x 5 cm right submandibular swelling with normal overlying skin, non-tender, mobile, and firm in consistency. Intraoral examination showed pus at the Wharton's duct orifice, but no sialolith. Preoperative blood investigations, electrocardiography, and chest radiographs were normal. CT scan of the neck showed opacity in the right submandibular gland and duct. Postoperative findings included induration of the right submandibular gland and a firm bulge along the submandibular duct, with the largest stone being 25 mm. Histopathology confirmed severe acute-on-chronic sialadenitis with multiple calculi. A: The primary diagnosis is severe acute-on-chronic sialadenitis with multiple calculi. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of neck swelling and opacity, but these are less likely given the imaging and histopathology results. P: The patient underwent an excision of the right submandibular gland under general anesthesia, which was performed successfully. Postoperative recovery has been uneventful, with the largest stone being 25 mm. The patient will continue to be monitored for recovery and any further treatment options. Further treatment options may be considered if necessary.

S: The patient, a long-term user of an electrical heating pad for 12 months, reports generalized pain, which has not been identified. The patient has been using the heating pad for at least six consecutive hours for several months without burning or discomfort. O: Physical examination revealed reticulated, ill-defined, reddish-brown patches on the back. The lesions are due to chronic heat exposure from the heating pad. A follow-up visit 18 months later showed resolution of the lesions. A: The primary diagnosis is chronic heat exposure from the heating pad, likely due to chronic heat exposure. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of skin lesions, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: Discontinued the heating pad and avoided heat sources. Scheduled a follow-up visit in a few months to monitor the progress of the skin. Scheduled a follow-up in 18 months to monitor the progress of the skin. A: The primary diagnosis is chronic heat exposure from the heating pad, likely due to chronic heat exposure. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of skin lesions, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: Discontinued the heating pad and avoided heat sources. Scheduled a follow-up visit in a few months to monitor the progress of the skin. The patient was advised to discontinue the heating pad to prevent further damage to the skin. Follow-up visits 18 months later showed resolution of the lesions. The patient is encouraged to reach out with any further concerns or need assistance in managing pain.

S: The patient, with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and stroke, presents with muscle weakness for the past two months and a remote exposure to statins. O: Physical examination revealed 2/5 strength on the left side and 4/5 on the right. Laboratory tests showed elevated CK at 28,885 U/L (normal range: 0-60 U/L). MRI showed extensive proximal muscle edema. Biopsy of the vastus medialis showed necrotizing features without inflammation. HMG CoA antibodies were strongly positive. Initial treatment included IV methylprednisolone followed by PDN 60 mg/day. MRI showed extensive proximal muscle edema and necrotizing features without inflammation. Treatment included IVIG for 5 days, MMF 1 g/day, rituximab (3 g/day), prednisone (60 mg/day), and two doses of IVIG as bridge therapy. Three months post-presentation, CK levels were still elevated at 3,178 U/L, and TAC 4 mg/day was added to MMF (3 g/day) and PDN 40 mg/day. Labs normalized after TAC 4 mg/day and tapered PDN dose. Eight months post-TAC, weakness improved markedly, and labs normalized. A: The primary diagnosis is necrotizing myositis with complications including muscle weakness and recurrent CK levels. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of muscle weakness, but these are less likely given the imaging and lab results. P: Continue monitoring the patient's condition closely with regular follow-up visits to assess for any recurrence or recurrence of muscle weakness. Maintain current regimen of tacrolimus and MMF. Educate the patient on the importance of adhering to the treatment regimen and adherence to follow-up appointments. Encourage the patient to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately.

S: The patient reports intermittent abdominal pain and diarrhea for 3 months, characterized by mucoid-runny diarrhea 3-4 times daily and visceral pain around the belly button. The pain usually resolves after diarrhea. The patient has a history of gastrointestinal hemorrhage 10 years ago but no surgeries or drug use. O: Physical examination revealed fever 36 °C, pulse 82/min, arterial blood pressure 130/80 mmHg, abdominal distention, increased bowel sounds, and deep palpation. Laboratory findings included a white blood cell count of 14,000/uL, C-reactive protein at 185 mg/L, and erythrocyte sedimentation rate at 60 mm/h. Stool microscopy showed many leukocytes, no parasitic organisms, and no specific microorganisms. Abdominal ultrasonography (USG) showed inflammation of intestinal loops, omental inflammatory thickening, and a 7x5x4 cm fluid collection in the pericaecal area. CT scan revealed a hyperdense area of 12x16 mm in a heterogeneous structure within the anterior mesenteric fat tissue at the ileocecal valve level. A: The primary diagnosis is plastron appendicitis, likely secondary to gastrointestinal bleeding, given the clinical presentation and imaging findings. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of abdominal pain and abdominal pain, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The patient has been hydrated with empiric cefixime 1x100 mg and metronidazole 3x500 mg, with drainage of purulent fluid, antibiotics, and hydration. The patient is advised to continue with the prescribed medications and hydration as needed. Regular follow-ups will be scheduled to monitor the patient's response to treatment and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient is a 46-year-old woman with a history of anaplastic oligoastrocytoma treated with radiation therapy and currently on temozolomide. She presents with cough and palpitations. O: Vital signs on admission include blood pressure 115/83 mm Hg, heart rate 117 beats/min, body temperature 36.5°C, and SpO2 96% with an O2 2 L/min cannula. 12-lead electrocardiogram shows sinus tachycardia and SIQIII TIII with negative T in V1–3. Ultrasound cardiogram shows distended right ventricle, D-shape (+), moderate tricuspid valve regurgitation, and moderate to severe pulmonary hypertension with a maximum pressure gradient of 59 mm Hg. Chest X-ray shows distended pulmonary arteries and interstitial lung infiltrate. Emergency CT scan shows nodular opacities with a tree-in-bud pattern, and abdominal CT shows a slightly distended gastric wall with lymphadenopathies. Laboratory findings include decreased platelets (71  103/L), activated partial thromboplastin time (30.7 seconds), prothrombin time-international normalized ratio (1.19), fibrinogen 100 mg/dL, and increased D-dimer (20.08 g/mL). No signs of infection were detected with a white blood count of 7450/L, C-reactive protein 0.24 mg/dL, and d-glucan below 2.4 pg/mL. A: The primary diagnosis is temozolomide-induced interstitial pneumonia complicated by disseminated intravascular coagulation and right heart failure. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of interstitial pneumonia, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: Initiate steroid pulse therapy with methylprednisolone 1 g/d, recombinant thrombomodulin and continuous heparin infusion to manage hypercoagulability. Monitor the patient's response to treatment and adjust as necessary. Educate the patient on the importance of reporting any new symptoms or concerns during her stay.

S: The patient, with a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus, presented with a coma and shock. The patient denied any previous hospital visits or medication use. O: On admission, the patient's consciousness level was at a Glasgow Coma Scale score of 3/15 (E1V1M1), blood pressure 80/40 mm Hg, pulse rate 130 bpm, and temperature 37.3°C. Laboratory findings included neutropenia (640/L), elevated C-reactive protein (12.73 mg/dL), blood glucose (237 mg/dL), and hemoglobin A1c (12.1%). CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis revealed diffuse gas collection within the urinary bladder wall. A: The primary diagnosis is a coma and shock secondary to Escherichia coli infection, likely secondary to a gas-forming infection. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of coma and shock, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and laboratory findings. P: The patient was treated with meropenem hydrate and a vasopressor, and was placed on a respirator and catheterized for better management. The family was advised to be aware of the risks associated with the infection and to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately. Further consultations with a nephrologist and a pulmonologist were planned to manage the infection and manage complications.

S: The patient, with a history of tobacco smoking and a history of NSCLC (T1bN3M0 stage IIIB) diagnosed a year ago, reports progressively worsening abdominal pain and constipation. O: Vital signs and measurements were unremarkable. Physical examination was primarily benign. Laboratory findings showed an elevated carcinoembryonic antigen at 4.2 ng/dL. CT scan showed severe colonic stool burden and a soft tissue left upper lobe lung mass consistent with NSCLC. A single large soft tissue mass with possible mucosal invasion was found in the rectosigmoid colon. Surgical intervention included colostomy, ileocecectomy, anastomosis, and rectosigmoid mass resection with tissue sampling. Biopsies from the rectosigmoid mass showed positive for high-grade NSCLC and metastatic poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma of lung origin. Hematoxylin and eosin staining showed extensive necrosis, focal mucosal involvement, and negative for regional lymph node carcinoma. Colic glandular cells surrounded by atypical cells were normal. Immunohistochemical stains for CK7, TTF-1, Napsin-A, and epithelial specific antigen/EpCAM were performed. A: The primary diagnosis is high-grade NSCLC with metastatic poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma of lung origin. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of lung malignancies, but these are less likely given the imaging and biopsy results. P: The patient will be closely monitored for any new or worsening symptoms. Further treatment options will be discussed based on the results of the immunohistochemical stains. The patient is advised to report any new or worsening symptoms immediately. Regular follow-ups with the oncologist are recommended to monitor for any new or worsening symptoms.

S: The patient, a 5-year-old male Jack Russell Terrier, presented with sudden onset of weakness and reluctance to move from his basket. The dog is primarily an indoor pet, with a history of vaccinations against distemper, parvovirosis, leptospirosis, Rubarth disease, parainfluenza, and rabies. The owner lives in Belgium and occasionally removes ticks from his skin. O: The dog's hematology and biochemistry profile were unremarkable. Serological examinations for Toxoplasma gondii and Borrelia species were negative, but Lyme serology was positive with a titer of 1:1024. A: The primary diagnosis is Lyme disease in the dog, with a differential diagnosis of other causes of weakness and reluctance. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the positive Lyme serology. P: The management plan includes a course of doxycycline 5 mg/kg orally twice a day for 30 days. The dog will be monitored for improvement within three days post-treatment. The owner is advised to report any new symptoms or concerns during the treatment period. Regular follow-ups will be scheduled to monitor the dog's response to the treatment and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient, a male, presented with a 5-day history of frequent vomiting, moderate to severe headache, and giddiness, accompanied by weakness on the right side of the body and altered sensorium. He reports a recent episode of generalized tonic-clonic seizures. He denies any history of major illness or drug treatments and no addictions. O: Vital signs were afebrile with a pulse of 86/minute and blood pressure of 126/74 mmHg. Neurological examination revealed drowsiness, poorly-controlled verbal commands, hypertonia, grade III power in the right upper limb and lower limb, mildly exaggerated deep tendon reflexes, and positive Babinski sign on the right side. Blood examination revealed macrocytic anemia with hemoglobin at 11.4 g/dl, MCV at 110 fl, macrocytes and macro-ovalocytes with hypersegmented neutrophils, low serum cobalamin at 68 pg/ml, normal folate levels, and negative anti-intrinsic factor antibodies. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) was normal. Immunological profile including ANA, ANCA, lupus anticoagulant, and antiphospholipid antibodies was negative. A: The primary diagnosis is neurological deficits, likely exacerbated by low cobalamin levels. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of neurological deficits, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and laboratory findings. P: Plan to conduct further investigations to determine the exact cause of the neurological deficits and plan a treatment strategy based on the clinical findings. Continue monitoring the patient's neurological status and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Educate the patient on the importance of reporting any new symptoms or concerns immediately.

S: The patient reports noticing a firm palpable mass close to the supernumerary nipple on the right side, which has been present for several months. The patient denies any other symptoms. O: Initial bilateral mammogram and ultrasound revealed normal breast tissue but a small, hypoechoic, well-defined mass on the right side, measuring approximately 10 mm in diameter. Clinical examination revealed inversion of the supernumerary nipple on the right side and a palpable firm mass underneath it. Ultrasound-guided needle core biopsy with a 16G needle identified elongated epithelial islands composed of cubic cells, surrounded by dense fibrous stroma. Pathology indicated elongated epithelial islands composed of cubic cells, with a small centrally located lumen and focally identifiable cuticles. Microscopically, the tumor measured 13 mm in diameter, localized in the deep part of the dermis and underlying subcutaneous tissue, with solid trabecular and glandular imitating formations and focal cysts, with solid trabecular and glandular imitating formations and focal cysts. Foreign body giant cells were noted. A: The primary diagnosis is a B3-lesion of the supernumerary nipple, characterized by elongated epithelial islands, dense fibrous stroma, and a B3-lesion with uncertain malignant potential. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of breast cancer, but these are less likely given the imaging and biopsy results. P: The patient underwent successful resection of the tumor with a 5 mm rim of normal tissue. Regular follow-ups are scheduled to monitor the patient's condition and detect any recurrence. The patient is advised to contact healthcare providers if any concerns or changes in health are noted.

S: The patient is a 54-year-old divorced Caucasian male, lead singer of a local rock band, presenting with severe headache and lower extremity numbness following a cocaine binge. He reports no prior psychiatric history or hospitalizations. He has a history of cocaine use for approximately 20 years, primarily prior to stage performances. He denies vegetative depressive symptoms or suicidal thoughts. He has been diagnosed with an adjustment disorder and has been sent home with good family support. O: Initial MRI of the brain showed two small foci of increased signal intensity within the subcortical white matter of the left frontal lobe and bilateral foci of infarct on the right side of the pons, consistent with an embolic phenomenon. MRI findings suggest an embolic phenomenon. The patient has been experiencing significant crying spells over the course of two weeks, denying feeling depressed and suicidal. The patient has been referred to a mental health center for evaluation of uncontrollable crying spells. A: The primary diagnosis is an embolic phenomenon, likely exacerbated by cocaine use. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of anxiety and depression, but these are less likely given the MRI findings and clinical presentation. The prognosis is guarded due to the severity of the embolic phenomenon and the patient's history of cocaine use. P: The management plan will include a comprehensive treatment plan to address depression and anxiety, with adjustments to the treatment plan as necessary based on the patient's symptoms and history. Regular follow-ups will be scheduled to monitor the patient's progress and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Referral to a psychiatric specialist for further evaluation and management of the embolic phenomenon is recommended.

S: The patient reports daily vertigo, worsening with sudden head movements, nausea, vomiting, and difficulty sustaining balance in confined spaces. The patient has a history of meningitis at age 2 and no family history of vertigo, epilepsy, hearing loss, or familial cancer syndromes. The patient denies experiencing headaches. O: Neurologic and audiometric examination revealed perceptive high tone loss in the right ear. MRI of the cerebellum and cerebellopontine angle was normal. MRI results were normal. A follow-up MRI showed persistent perceptive high tone loss in the right ear. Follow-up MRI with thin slices through the cerebellum and cerebellopontine angle and series after contrast administration showed no pathology. A: The primary diagnosis is benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV), with differential diagnoses including other causes of vertigo and balance disorders. The patient's history of meningitis and family history of vertigo and epilepsy are consistent with BPPV. P: Continue monitoring the patient's symptoms and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Provide home exercises to alleviate symptoms and monitor for any changes in symptoms. Educate the patient on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and reporting any new symptoms immediately. Consider referral to a neurologist for further evaluation and management of BPPV.

S: The patient, a recent return from a trip to Lagos, Nigeria, reports feeling unwell with episodes of syncope starting six days after returning. The symptoms began three days after returning, with fevers and sweats multiple times daily. The patient denies headache, neck stiffness, sore throat, or respiratory symptoms. The patient has a history of malaria prevention, which was administered within the last year. The patient has no significant past medical history or current medications. O: Physical examination reveals a temperature of 100.8°, pulse 117 bpm, blood pressure 127/78, respirations 18 per minute unlaborated, and O2 saturation 98% on room air. A: The primary diagnosis is syncope secondary to a recent trip to Lagos, Nigeria. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of syncope, but these are less likely given the patient's history and current symptoms. The prognosis depends on the response to the treatment plan and response to the treatment. P: The management plan includes initiation of a multidisciplinary team approach to address the syncope and identify the underlying cause. The patient is advised to follow the prescribed medications and follow-up requirements to monitor the effectiveness of the treatment and manage any complications. Further consultations with a rheumatologist and a nephrologist are recommended to address the underlying cause of syncope.

S: The patient reports swelling in the suprapubic area and difficulty in passing urine for the last 4 months. The patient also mentions constipation for the past 2 months without fever, vomiting, hematuria, or bleeding per rectum. O: Physical examination revealed a smooth, firm, slightly tender, nonmobile lump in the suprapubic region, approximately 5 cm above the pubic symphysis. The lower limit of the lump was not palpable. Digital rectal examination showed a smooth spherical mass outside the rectal wall, but rectal mucosa was normal. Blood tests showed hemoglobin at 12.4 g/dl, total leucocyte count at 8900/mm3, platelet count at 2.54 lakh/mm, blood urea at 33 mg/dl, serum creatinine at 1.12 mg/dl, and normal serum electrolytes. Liver function tests were normal with serum bilirubin at 0.75 mg/dl, S.G.O.T. at 16 U/L, S.G.P.T. at 36 U/L, and alkaline phosphatase at 88 U/L. Urine examination showed pus cells (5-6/hpf), but urine culture was sterile. Chest X-ray and ECG were normal. Ultrasound indicated a cystic mass in the pelvis, suggestive of a hydatid cyst with bilateral hydroureteronephrosis, moderate hydronephrosis on the right side, and mild hydronephrosis on the left side. A: The primary diagnosis is a hydatid cyst with bilateral hydroureteronephrosis. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of urinary tract infection and urinary tract obstruction. The prognosis depends on the management of the hydatid cyst and the hydronephrosis. P: The management plan includes referral to a nephrologist for further evaluation and management of the hydatid cyst and hydronephrosis. The patient is advised to monitor symptoms and report any changes or worsening of the condition. Further consultations with a nephrologist may be necessary depending on the

S: The patient reports constipation. The patient has a history of cT3N1M0 stage IIIa rectal cancer, diagnosed as cT3N1M0 stage IIIa. O: Colonoscopy revealed a circumferential tumor in the lower rectum 60 mm from the anal verge. Biopsy indicated moderately differentiated tubular adenocarcinoma. CT scan showed a 6.3-cm bulky middle to lower rectal tumor and multiple enlarged regional lymph nodes without distant metastasis. Emergency CT scan and colonoscopy showed a clinical partial response (cPR) to neoadjuvant therapy (NAT) according to the New Response Evaluation Criteria in Solid Tumors: Revised RECIST Guideline (version 1.1). Colonoscopy revealed an obstruction at the lower rectum, with smooth stenosis and growth of fibrous tissue. A self-expanding metallic stent (SEMS) was placed, and the tumor was successfully removed. A: The primary diagnosis is cT3N1M0 stage IIIa rectal cancer, stage IIIa. The patient's response to neoadjuvant therapy and successful surgical intervention were noted. P: The patient underwent successful surgical intervention with a self-expanding metallic stent (Niti-S Colonic Stent) and a laparoscopic low anterior resection with diverting ileostomy. Post-surgery, the patient will continue to be monitored for recovery and potential complications. Further treatment options may be considered if symptoms persist or worsen.

S: The patient, referred to the emergency otorhinolaryngology department, reports a history of progressive dysphagia, dysphonia, and dyspnea over the past year. The patient also mentions difficulty swallowing, hoarse voice, and shortness of breath. O: Clinical examination revealed a large mass in the oropharynx, measuring 80 x 55 mm, with firm, tenderness and no fluctuation. Cervical lymph nodes were not palpable. Rescue tracheotomy was performed. MRI revealed a voluminous process infiltrating the entire posterior tongue, heterogeneous on T1 and T2 tissue signal, and infiltrating the uvula and tonsils without associated cervical lymph nodes. Biopsy of the tongue revealed tumoral proliferation with distinct plasmacytic differentiation. Immunohistochemistry was positive for CD138 and monoclonal expression of Lambda chains. Whole-body MRI showed a lesional process in the lower metaphysis of the right femur, with polylobed contours and an intermediate signal in T1 with a central zone in hypersignal. Laboratory workup showed a 7.5 g/dl normocytic anemia, accelerated sedimentation rate, normal calcemia, and renal function. Serum electrophoresis showed lambda chains, and Beta2 microglobulin was slightly elevated. A: The primary diagnosis is a voluminous process infiltrating the posterior tongue, characterized by tumoral proliferation and monoclonal expression of Lambda chains. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of dysphagia and dyspnea, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The management plan will include surgical intervention, radiation, and/or chemotherapy, with close monitoring of the patient's progress. The patient will be educated on the importance of follow-up appointments to assess treatment efficacy and manage any complications. Referral to a nephrologist and a pulmonologist for further evaluation and management of the lesion is recommended. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's progress and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The owner reports that the 3-day-old male Boxer puppy, a 3-day-old male Boxer puppy, has been active and continuously suckling but has not gained weight. The owner also noticed nasal discharge after suckling. O: Physical examination revealed a moderately wide midline defect in the hard palate and a caudally divergent defect in the soft palate, classified as - - H S H - -. No other congenital diseases or signs of pneumonia were detected. The puppy was offered milk replacer by Royal Canin, which he suckled immediately but showed nasal discharge and occasional sneezing. A: The primary diagnosis is a cleft palate, classified as - - H S H - -, with no other congenital diseases or signs of pneumonia. Differential diagnoses could include other congenital diseases or atypical facial growth. P: The owner is advised to raise the puppy at the Clinic for Obstetrics, Gynecology, and Andrology of Large and Small Animals with Ambulatory Service of the Justus-Liebig University in Germany to monitor his progress and manage his weight gain. Regular follow-ups will be scheduled to monitor his progress and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient reported experiencing pain, redness, and hyperemia in the right eye following cigarette ash exposure a week prior to referred. The patient experienced no improvement after two weeks of outpatient treatment. O: Initial corneal scraping was negative. Initial treatment included levofloxacin eye drops, cefminox sodium, and voriconazole. Post-treatment, the patient experienced exudation in the anterior chamber two days post-surgery, which was resolved with intracameral fluconazole injection. The mycelial growth was identified as P. insidiosum, with three protein peaks identified as 2094.01, 4834.62. A: The primary diagnosis is a fungal infection of the right eye with complications including exudation and mycelial growth. Differential diagnoses could include other fungal infections or bacterial infections. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and management of the infection. P: The management plan included levofloxacin eye drops, cefminox sodium, and voriconazole. Post-surgery, the patient was treated with intracameral fluconazole and enucleation. The patient is advised to continue follow-up care and report any new symptoms or concerns immediately. Further consultations with a neurologist and a pulmonologist are recommended to manage the infection and manage any complications.

S: The patient, a female, presented to the emergency department following a drowning incident at the sea. She reported feeling weak and disoriented. O: Upon arrival, the patient was hemodynamically unstable with a blood pressure of 100/55 mmHg, heart rate of 135 bpm, and breath rate of 25 bpm. She was afebrile with a temperature of 36.7 C. Laboratory findings showed hemodynamic instability with hematocrit at 23% and hemoglobin at 7.3 g/dL. Fluid resuscitation and transfusion of 2 blood units were performed. Abdominal ultrasonography showed free intra-abdominal fluid. Chest X-ray was negative for tympanic abdomen or pneumoperitoneum. Exploratory laparotomy identified the bleeding from vessels originating from the lesser curvature of the stomach, which were successfully ligated. A: The primary diagnosis was a drowning incident at the sea, complicated by hemodynamic instability and afebrile state. Differential diagnoses initially included tympanic abdomen or pneumoperitoneum, which were ruled out by imaging and clinical findings. P: The patient underwent fluid resuscitation and transfusion of 2 blood units. Postoperatively, the patient was discharged on the 12th postoperative day. The patient is advised to maintain regular follow-ups to monitor for any recurrence or complications. The patient is advised to maintain a healthy lifestyle and report any new symptoms immediately.

S: The patient, a cashier at a fast food restaurant, presented with lethargy and extreme exhaustion following a fall on the floor of the restroom. He reported feeling weak and tired. He also experienced mild flu-like symptoms, a low-grade fever, and multiple episodes of nonbilious vomiting for the past 3 days. He denies any recent changes in medications or exposure to toxic substances. He has a history of high-functioning autism, works as a cashier at a fast food restaurant, and has been on methylphenidate and sertraline for years without any recent changes. O: On examination, vital signs were temperature 98.2°F, blood pressure 140/71 mm Hg, heart rate 136 bpm, respiratory rate 38/min, and oxygen saturation 96% on ambient air. Glasgow Coma Scale score was 10/15, indicating impairment in mental state. Mucous membranes were dry, skin cold to touch with decreased turgor, deep and labored breathing, clear chest to auscultation, and gastrointestinal and cardiovascular examinations were unremarkable. A: The primary diagnosis is syncope, likely secondary to a fall on the floor of the restroom, given the patient's history of autism and the presence of a Glasgow Coma Scale score of 10/15. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of mental impairment, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and laboratory findings. P: The management plan includes continued monitoring of vital signs, supportive care, and hydration. The patient is advised to maintain hydration and rest as much as possible, and to report any worsening symptoms immediately. Regular follow-ups will be scheduled to assess progress and adjust treatment as necessary. The patient is encouraged to report any new symptoms or worsening symptoms immediately.

S: The patient is a 38-year-old nulliparous woman presenting with right lower abdominal pain. She reports that the pain has been bothersome. O: Physical examination revealed a non-echogenic cyst in the right flank. Abdominal ultrasound revealed a non-echogenic cyst in the right flank. CT scan with intravenous and oral contrast confirmed a right lower abdominal cystic formation measuring 38 by 33 millimeters and density of 24 Hounsfield units. Gynecological examination showed a normal cervix in speculo, a mobile uterus with normal adnexa, and an intrauterine device in the uterine cavity, a normal left ovary, but the right adnex could not be visualized. Explorative laparoscopy revealed normal appendix, cecum deep in the right fossa, and internal genitals showed a unicornuate uterus and a normal left fallopian tube and ovary, infrahepatically, with the right fallopian tube and ovary positioned upon the psoas muscle and crossed over by the right ureter. A: The primary diagnosis is a right lower abdominal cyst with associated abnormal position of the right adnexa. Differential diagnoses considered included enteric duplication cyst, mesenterial cyst, peritoneal inclusion cyst, and appendiceal mucocele. The prognosis depends on the management of the cyst and the patient's response to treatment. P: The management plan will include referral to a rudimentary uterus for further evaluation and management. The patient will be educated on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and following up with a nephrologist to monitor her condition and manage any complications. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor her condition and adjust treatment as necessary.

S: The patient, a smoker with a history of hypertension and neurodermatitis, presents with symptoms of anxiety, depressed mood, anger, loss of drive, anhedonia, and insomnia. The patient reports persistent left-thoracic chest pain for 2 hours, hyperventilation, symmetric leg tingling, and heaviness, which resolved 30 minutes before admission. The patient denies any past episodes of dyspnea or disturbances of consciousness. O: Physical examination and ECG were unremarkable. Troponin T level was significantly elevated at 243 ng/ml (normal 14 ng/ml). Cardiac catheterization showed severe reduction in left ventricular function with typical apical ballooning. Coronary heart disease was ruled out. N-terminal (NT)-pro-brain natriuretic peptide (BNP) levels were elevated at 307.0 pg/ml. A: The primary diagnosis is Takotsubo cardiomyopathy, a temporary heart condition likely triggered by stress. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of chest pain, but these are less likely given the elevated troponin T level. P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition, adjustment of medications, and regular follow-ups with the healthcare team to address any new or worsening symptoms. The patient is advised to report any new or worsening symptoms immediately. Further consultations with a cardiologist and a neurologist are recommended to manage stress and manage mental health concerns.

S: The patient, a male with a history of laparoscopic cholecystectomy, ischemic brain stroke, and paraplegia, presents with a chief complaint of hematemesis persisting for 7 days. He reports three episodes of non-bloody emesis before the hematemesis, weight loss, epigastric pain, and post-prandial vomiting for about a year. He has a history of a laparoscopic cholecystectomy, ischemic brain stroke, and paraplegia due to a lumbar herniated disc. O: Physical examination revealed cachexia, extremely weak with a blood pressure of 90/40 mmHg, heart rate of 110 beats/min, respiratory rate of 22/min, and oral temperature of 36.8. EGD revealed a linear clean base ulcer in the lower third of the esophagus, Mallory Weiss syndrome, and a submucosal lesion in the bulb area of the duodenum. Endoscopic ultrasonography identified an anechoic lesion measuring 45x55 mm, adjacent to the duodenal wall, with intact duodenal wall layers. CT scans of the abdomen and pelvis showed multiple cortical cysts in both kidneys, pressing on the duodenum. A: The primary diagnosis is Mallory Weiss syndrome, likely exacerbated by repeated vomiting. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of hematemesis, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: Initiate conservative treatment with crystalloid fluids and intravenous pantoprazole. Monitor the patient's condition closely and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Educate the patient on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and adhering to follow-up appointments.

S: The patient reports intractable pruritus, scaling, dry skin, and generalized eczematous lesions resistant to atopic dermatitis therapy. The patient has a history of desquamative skin lesions treated with emollients, topical steroids, and tacrolimus creams for severe atopic dermatitis. The patient denies any family history of skin disorders. O: Physical examination revealed dry skin, erythematous scaly patches on the abdomen, face, and extremities, but eczematous lesions were not typical of atopic dermatitis. Biochemical tests, serum folate, iron, vitamin B12, and zinc levels were normal. Urinary amino acid analysis, immunoglobulins (IgA, IgG, IgM, and IgG), complements (C3, C4), and lymphocyte subset counts (CD3, CD4, CD8, CD14, CD19, CD56) were normal. All antibody tests including anti-gliadin IgA, IgG, anti-endomysium IgA, ANA, anti-dsDNA, and anti-HIV were negative. Thyroid hormone levels and thyroid autoantibodies were within normal ranges. A: The primary diagnosis is severe atopic dermatitis with complications including erythroderma, Ichthyosis linearis circumflexa, and elevated serum total IgE levels. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of erythroderma and eczematous lesions, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and laboratory results. P: The management plan includes exploring alternative treatments for atopic dermatitis and consultation with a dermatologist for further evaluation and management. The patient is advised to continue avoiding allergens such as eggs and cow's milk and maintain a current skincare routine. Further consultations with a dermatologist may be necessary to further explore the nature of the condition and potential treatment options. The patient is encouraged to contact the clinic if any questions or concerns arise.

S: The patient reports experiencing left-sided mastodynia and has a history of an excisional biopsy of a fibroadenoma in the left breast. The patient has a history of an excisional biopsy of a fibroadenoma in the left breast. O: MRI revealed a 7 mm enhancing stellate lesion at 9 o'clock in the right breast, with a homogeneously low signal on T1-weighted images and rapid early enhancement with plateau kinetics on dynamic contrast imaging. No diffusion restriction was observed. Mammography of the right breast showed a focal asymmetric density with spiculated margins in the superolateral quadrant, with no associated microcalcifications or suspicious lesions elsewhere. Second-look ultrasound showed a small oval hypoechoic mass, approximately 4 mm, with partially obscured borders. Core needle biopsy confirmed BI-RADS 4b lesion. Histological analysis of the lesion showed an infiltrative stromal process with interlacing bundles of fibroblast and myofibroblast, suggestive of a desmoid tumor, with no nuclear atypia or mitosis. A: The primary diagnosis is fibromatosis of the right breast, confirmed by MRI findings and histological analysis. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of breast cancer, but these are less likely given the imaging findings and histological findings. P: The patient underwent a wide excision of the tumor, which confirmed the diagnosis of fibromatosis. Post-operative care included monitoring for any signs of recurrence or complications. The patient was advised to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately. Further consultations with oncology and a nephrologist were recommended to manage her condition and prevent further complications.

S: The patient is a 26-year-old primigravida woman presenting with a chief complaint of labor and postpartum hemorrhage. She reports severe dyspnea right after the transfusion. She was admitted to the obstetrics department for emergency caesarean section and experienced severe postpartum hemorrhage with a blood loss of 2 L. She was treated with sulprostone, intravenous fluids, and a blood transfusion. She experienced severe left ventricular dysfunction with an estimated ejection fraction of only 15%, moderate wall motility in the basal septal region, and no signs of ischaemia or coagulopathy, ruled out by amniotic fluid embolism. She was intubated and transferred to the ICU for further treatment. Follow-up echocardiography showed normalization of left ventricular function with normal ventricular dimensions within a few days. The patient returned to the cardiologist a few years later with a desire to become pregnant again, and her left ventricular function has remained normal to date. O: The patient underwent emergency caesarean section with severe postpartum hemorrhage and severe left ventricular dysfunction with an estimated ejection fraction of only 15%. Chest X-rays showed congestion and echocardiography revealed severe left ventricular dysfunction with an estimated ejection fraction of only 15%, moderate wall motility in the basal septal region, and no signs of ischaemia or coagulopathy. Follow-up echocardiography showed normalization of left ventricular function with normal ventricular dimensions within a few days. A: The primary diagnosis is acute heart failure secondary to takotsubo cardiomyopathy, evidenced by echocardiographic images of akinesia affecting the whole ventricle except the basal segments, and rapid recovery of ejection fraction. Differential diagnoses initially included PPCM, which was ruled out based on imaging and clinical presentation. P: The patient was treated with sulprostone, intravenous fluids, and a blood transfusion. She was intubated and transferred to the ICU for further treatment. She was treated with conventional heart failure medication. Follow-up echocardiography showed normalization of left ventricular function with normal ventricular dimensions within

S: The patient reports a slow-growing, ulcerated skin mass on the front, inner part of the left lower leg, which has been present for 2 years. The mass is approximately 5 by 6 cm in size, with skin surface ulceration, purulent drainage, and a foul smell. The patient denies any significant medical history or other issues. O: Blood tests are within normal limits. White blood cell count, hemoglobin, and platelet levels are within normal limits. Biopsy of the lesion was performed at Butaro Cancer Centre of Excellence in Rwanda. The lesion was infiltrated by intermediate to large immature cells with irregular nuclei, dispersed chromatin, distinct small nucleoli, and scanty cytoplasm, with frequent mitotic figures. Pathology at Brigham and Women's Hospital confirmed positive lesional cells for CD45, terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase, PAX5, CD3, CD20, myeloperoxidase, and lysozyme. Additional immunostains were positive for CD2, CD33, CD4, CD56, CD123, and TCL1. The immunophenotype was inconclusive. A: The primary diagnosis is a slow-growing, ulcerated skin mass on the front, inner part of the left lower leg, likely secondary to a wound superinfection. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of skin lesions, but these are less likely given the immunophenotype. P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the lesion and follow-up with additional tests or treatments recommended by the healthcare team. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately. Further consultations with a dermatologist and a dermatologist are recommended to further explore the diagnosis and treatment options.

S: The patient is a 4-year-old female with a history of EA and a distal tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF). She reports a history of over 20 esophageal dilatations, five esophageal stent placements, and a tracheostomy at an outside hospital. She has undergone over 20 esophageal dilatations, five esophageal stent placements, and a tracheostomy at an outside hospital. She has experienced dysphagia with solid food one year post-surgery, which led to a tracheoplasty and gastric interposition using the gastric pull-up procedure. O: Initial bronchoscopic and esophagoscopic examination under general anesthesia revealed a tracheoesophageal fistula at the upper esophagus. Endoscopy revealed a large tracheoesophageal fistula, likely iatrogenic after stent placement with a cuffed tracheostomy tube, causing erosion of adjacent tracheoesophageal walls. Post-operative findings included a mucosal bridge at the level of the gastroesophageal anastomosis, which was divided under endoscopic vision using a 6 mm flexible endoscope and a 5 mm miniature stapler from JustRight Surgical. No intra- or postoperative complications were reported. A: The primary diagnosis is a distal tracheoesophageal fistula with associated iatrogenic tracheoesophageal fistula. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of tracheoesophageal fistulas, but these are less likely given the imaging and surgical findings. The prognosis is guarded due to the complexity of the tracheoesophageal fistula. P: Continue monitoring the patient's progress with regular follow-ups to assess for any recurrence of the tracheoesophageal fistula or complications. Educate the patient

S: The patient reports no specific symptoms but has been admitted for surgical treatment of a mediastinal tumor detected on a chest roentgenogram. The patient expresses concern about the procedure and the potential for Horner syndrome transiently. O: The patient's chest CT revealed a mediastinal tumor in the right thoracic outlet, adjacent to the right subclavian vein and right brachiocephalic artery. Preoperative diagnosis is undetermined, but it is suspected to be a benign neurinoma with a possibility of malignancy. During surgery, the patient will be placed in a left semi-lateral decubitus position, with access ports placed at the 5th intercostal space on the middle axillary line, the 3rd intercostal space on the middle axillary line, and the 5th intercostal space on the anterior axillary line. Postoperative management includes VATS, which will be used to dissect the caudal side using VATS. The patient will be discharged 6 days postoperatively for schwannoma, which will be completely resected. A: The primary diagnosis is a mediastinal tumor in the right thoracic outlet, adjacent to the right subclavian vein and right brachiocephalic artery. The patient's preoperative diagnosis is a benign neurinoma with a possibility of malignancy. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the patient's risk of Horner syndrome, which should resolve naturally. P: The patient will be discharged 6 days postoperatively for schwannoma, which will be completely resected. Postoperative care will include close monitoring of recovery and monitoring for Horner syndrome. The patient will be educated on the importance of follow-up care and the importance of adherence to follow-up appointments.

S: The patient is a 55-year-old obese patient with a history of hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, dyslipidemia, and arthritis. He has a history of multiple median and transverse abdominal scar incisions and recurrence of an enormous incisional hernia in the right iliac fossa. He reports persistent vomiting over several months. He denies any history of tobacco or alcohol intoxications. O: The patient's preoperative upper fibroscopy revealed 2 cm of BE without dysplasia on the biopsy. The multidisciplinary team performed sleeve gastrectomy, incisional hernia repair, gastric leak, and abdominal dermolipectomy. Postoperative complications included gastric leak and cutaneous dehiscence, complicated by cutaneous dehiscence. A supraumbilical incisional hernia was repaired successfully using a preaponeurotic subcutaneous polypropylene mesh. Upper digestive tract opacification showed a lacunar image on the lower esophagus. Endoscopic ultrasound revealed a supra-cardial pediculate hypoechoic lesion of 2 cm without peritumoral lymph nodes. Biopsy confirmed well-differentiated intra-epithelial adenocarcinoma in BE with safe surgical margins and no lymphatic embolus or perineural sheathing. A: The primary diagnosis is well-differentiated intra-epithelial adenocarcinoma in BE with no lymphatic embolus or perineural sheathing, classified as pT1 with negative HER2 expression. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of gastrointestinal malignancies, but these are less likely given the biopsy results. P: Continue monitoring the patient's condition closely with regular follow-ups to assess the progression of the disease and manage any complications. Educate the patient on signs of worsening symptoms and encourage immediate reporting of any new symptoms. Consider referral to a gastroenterologist for further evaluation and management of the adenocarcinoma.

S: The patient reports worsening abdominal pain and distention over the past 4 days. The patient denies any past medical or surgical history. O: Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination revealed generalized abdominal tenderness and guarding of the abdomen. Laboratory tests showed an abnormally elevated white blood cell count of 24,900/mm3. Abdominal x-ray showed multiple air fluid levels. CT scan showed dilated small bowel loops with ischemia. Laparoscopy revealed a severe ischemic distal ileal segment, complicated by severe small bowel dilatation. During the laparotomy, approximately 20 cm of the distal ileum was herniated and twisted along its mesentery. An ileocecectomy with a side to side primary anastomosis using a 75 GIA stapler was performed. Postoperative course was uneventful, and the patient was discharged on the 8th postoperative day. A: The primary diagnosis is a small intestinal obstruction secondary to ischemic distal ileal segment. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of abdominal pain and distention, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation. P: The patient underwent an ileocecectomy with a side to side primary anastomosis using a 75 GIA stapler. Postoperative care includes regular follow-ups to monitor recovery and manage any complications. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately.

S: The patient is a 35-year-old female presenting with worsening abdominal pain following an extreme conditioning competition two days ago. She reports no improvement in pain and muscle swelling following treatment with Tenoxicam and advised to take bed rest and drink plenty of water. She denies any history of diseases. O: The patient's serum creatinine (CK) level was 43,322 U/L, which was elevated to 77,590 U/L. Kidney function was normal with blood urea, creatinine, sodium, and potassium levels. Liver enzymes were elevated with an AST of 477 U/L and an ALT of 74 U/L. The patient was diagnosed with rhabdomyolysis. A: The primary diagnosis is rhabdomyolysis, evidenced by elevated serum creatinine and liver enzymes. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of rhabdomyolysis, but these are less likely given the clinical and laboratory findings. P: The management plan includes aggressive intravenous fluid resuscitation. The patient will be discharged on the fourth day of hospitalization with instructions to avoid intense exercise. Follow-up examinations will monitor serum CK levels on the 10th day and on the 25th day. The patient is advised to avoid intense exercise and report any worsening symptoms. Family members have been informed of the treatment plan and consent was given for the use of clinical and personal data in research.

S: The patient, a 2-month-old female, presented for consultation with a lump on her left thigh, which has been growing progressively since birth. The parent reports no other abnormalities. O: Clinical examination revealed a 25/10 mm nodule on the antero-internal side of the left thigh, firm, mobile, and within the deep layers, with normal overlying skin. Initial X-ray and ultrasound showed a pre-femoral soft tissue mass at 30/13 mm, with a nonhomogeneous structure, hypoechoic areas, calcifications, and a weak Doppler signal. Abdominal ultrasound was normal. MRI indicated a mass of 19.33/15.19/34 mm with nonspecific vascular involvement. A: The primary diagnosis is a schwannoma of the left saphenous nerve, likely a schwannoma of the left saphenous nerve. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of fetal distress, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The management plan includes elective surgery to remove the mass. An italic S-shaped incision will be performed from the crural arch distally extended for approximately 6 cm, measuring approximately 4 cm  1.5 cm  1.5 cm. The patient will be educated on the procedure and expected recovery process. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor recovery and manage any complications.

S: The patient, with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, diabetes mellitus type 2, and obesity, presents with recent hip pain following a fall. The patient reports no dislocation or fracture of the hip. O: Radiograph of the hip showed no dislocation or fracture. Physical examination revealed proximal muscle weakness greater in the lower extremities, with no skin rashes, lymphadenopathy, joints inflammation, and pedal edema. EKG showed normal sinus rhythm with no ST-T changes. Blood work showed elevated CPK (9767), CKMB (101.50), and aldolase (60) levels, and LFT derangement (AST-302 and ALT404). Other lab findings were negative for ANA, anti-Jo antibody, and antimitochondrial antibody. Thyroid function tests were normal. The patient is currently on atorvastatin 80 mg, replacing simvastatin for better hyperlipidemia control. A: The primary diagnosis is statin-induced necrotizing autoimmune myopathy, consistent with necrotizing autoimmune myositis. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of muscle weakness, but these are less likely given the positive ELISA results. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the progression of proximal muscle weakness and the presence of necrotizing autoimmune myopathy. P: The management plan includes discontinuation of atorvastatin and close monitoring in the medical clinic. Prednisone therapy will be started at 1 mg/kg per day and tapered over the next three months to improve muscle strength and mobility. The patient will be educated on the importance of adhering to the treatment regimen and regular follow-ups to monitor for any recurrence or complications.

S: The patient is a 19-year-old multigravid female, presenting for a routine antenatal transabdominal ultrasound at 16 weeks gestation. She reports no family history of twins, no history of abortion or miscarriage, and no history of chronic diseases. She has a history of receiving Anti-D after the delivery of her first child. She denies any history of abortion or miscarriage. O: The patient's height is 165 cm, weight is 63 kg, and she is neither anaemic nor hypertensive. She has no history of abortion or miscarriage. The last menstrual date is unknown. Colour Doppler study shows two aortic arches emerging from the single functional heart. A: The primary diagnosis is conjoined twins with aortic arches, likely contributing to the pregnancy's malformation. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of conjoined twins, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation. P: The management plan includes a referral to a nephrologist for further evaluation and management. The patient and her husband will decide on the continuation of the pregnancy or termination of the pregnancy. Further evaluation and investigation will be necessary if the twins survive. The patient and her husband will be educated on the importance of avoiding pregnancy and the potential complications of conjoined twins.

S: The patient is a 78-year-old Japanese woman, gravida 10, para 2, with a 10-year history of uterine prolapse and a 10-year history of uterine prolapse. She reports recent bleeding from an ulcerated lesion on the surface of her prolapsed uterus for the past month. O: Physical examination revealed severe uterine prolapse with complete eversion of the posterior vaginal fornix and an ulcerated lesion measuring 3 cm in diameter and a deep-seated induration on the completely prolapsed uterus. Biopsy of a mass in the vaginal wall indicated keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma. Magnetic resonance imaging showed a mass with a depth of 1.6 cm, but no invasion to adjacent tissues. Fluorodeoxyglucose positron emission tomography/CT showed no metastases to lymph nodes or other organs. A: The primary diagnosis is stage IV keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma of the uterine cervix, classified as stage I vaginal cancer. The patient's advanced age and arrhythmias, including paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia and paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, make it ineligible for surgery under general anesthesia and chemotherapy. P: The management plan includes radiation therapy alone, with no potential for insertion of a probe or tandem. The patient is advised to follow up regularly with the healthcare team to monitor her condition and manage side effects of radiation therapy.

S: The patient is a 74-year-old female presenting with a chief complaint of intermittent fever for over a month, a weight loss of 18 kilograms over the past half year, and a dry cough. She denies recent travel. O: Physical examination revealed a temperature of 37.3°C, heart rate of 101 beats/min, respiratory rate of 16 breaths/min, and blood pressure of 142/54 mmHg. Pulmonary examination showed accessory muscles use and bilaterally diffuse rales. Abdominal examination showed a palpable spleen contour without muscle guarding or rebounding pain. Laboratory findings included a total leukocyte count of 19,900 cells per L, platelet count of 133,000 per L, alkaline phosphate of 481 U/L, serum total bilirubin of 3.2 mg/dL, and lactate dehydrogenase of 311 U/L. Serum transaminases, INR, and aPTT were within normal limits. Chest X-ray and CT scan indicated pulmonary tuberculosis with miliary tuberculosis. On the 3rd day of hospitalization, progressive orthopnea and paradoxical respiration were noted, and oxyhemoglobin saturation was 83% in room air. Serial laboratory examinations revealed leukocytosis with left shifting, INR > 10 ratio, aPTT > 100 seconds, and fibrinogen levels below the detectable limit. A: The primary diagnosis is pulmonary tuberculosis with miliary tuberculosis, complicated by progressive orthopnea and paradoxical respiration. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of respiratory distress and pulmonary symptoms, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The patient was transferred to the respiratory intensive care unit for resuscitation. She is currently in the respiratory intensive care unit for resuscitation. She will continue to be monitored in the RICU for resuscitation and will be educated on the importance of reporting any new symptoms or concerns. Regular follow-ups will be scheduled to assess treatment efficacy and adjust as necessary.

S: The patient reports a severe electrical burn from a power line, resulting in 32% total body surface area third-degree injuries to the left knee. The left knee was treated with three skin grafting procedures and a spatial external fixator (SEF) placed 24 days post-injury. Post-SEF placement, two additional skin grafting procedures were performed, and a bony prominence resection was performed. No significant complications were reported during the treatment. A: The primary diagnosis is a severe electrical burn from a power line, with a secondary injury to the left knee. The patient underwent three skin grafting procedures and a spatial external fixator placed 24 days post-injury, followed by two additional skin grafting procedures and a bony prominence resection. No significant complications were noted during the treatment. P: The management plan includes scheduling an appointment with a physical therapist and an occupational therapist to assess the patient's current condition and create a plan for ongoing recovery. The patient is advised to schedule an appointment with a physical therapist and an occupational therapist to assess the condition and create a plan for ongoing recovery.

S: The patient reports experiencing fatigue for the past 10 days, shortness of breath post-activity, cough, sore throat, and low-grade fever. The patient has a history of root canal therapy 2 months ago. O: Physical examination revealed a heart rate of 96 bpm, body temperature of 36.7 °C, hemoglobin at 36 g/L, mean corpuscular volume of 78.9 fL, red blood cell count at 1.42  1012/L, and reticulocyte count at 2.52%. Urinalysis indicated urobilinogen positivity with 4+, and urine red blood cells at 3 cells/L. Laboratory tests showed lactic dehydrogenase at 594 U/L, serum total bilirubin at 27.3 mol/L, and serum indirect bilirubin at 20.45 mol/L. Serum autoantibodies were ANA at 188.35 IU/ml, dsDNA at 186.42 IU/ml, AnuA at 27.01 IU/ml, anti-SSA antibody positive, anti-cardiolipin antibodies (aCL) IgG and IgM positive, anti-2-glycoprotein-I antibodies positive, and Coombs test at 4+. A: The patient is diagnosed with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), based on the clinical presentation and autoantibodies. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of low hemoglobin, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and autoantibodies. P: The patient has been started on dexamethasone 10 mg daily. Follow-up appointments are necessary to monitor the patient's response to treatment and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately.

S: The patient is an 85-year-old woman with a history of pseudoexfoliative glaucoma, presenting with decreased vision in the right eye for approximately 4 months. She reports a vision of 20/60 in the right eye for the past 4 months. Recently, she has experienced a central scotoma in the right eye. O: Initial OCT revealed a macular hole (MH) in the right eye, which spontaneously closed after one month, achieving best-corrected visual acuity (BCVA) of 20/50. Subsequent OCTs indicated a reopening of the macular hole and intraretinal cystic spaces. A second OCT showed reopening of the macular hole, with intraretinal cystic spaces. A: The primary diagnosis is a central scotoma in the right eye, complicated by a macular hole reopening and intraretinal cystic spaces. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of macular hole reopening and intraretinal cystic spaces. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the reopening of the macular hole and minimal subretinal fluid. P: The management plan includes continuing monitoring the patient's condition with regular follow-ups. The patient will be educated on the signs of reopening and the importance of adherence to follow-up appointments. Referral to a neurologist for further evaluation and management of the central scotoma is recommended.

S: Patient 3, a male, presented with hoarseness and difficulty swallowing for a few weeks. He reported feeling well for the past 4 years following his diagnosis and treatment. O: Initial CT scan revealed a 3.8 cm left thyroid tumor with superior mediastinal and tracheal involvements, staged as pT4bN0M0. Post-surgery, the patient underwent a total thyroidectomy and central neck dissection, followed by postsurgical chemotherapy with docetaxel at 120 mg/m2 and cisplatin at 30 mg/m2, followed by intensity modulated radiotherapy with 70 Gy at 2.5 Gy per fraction. A: The primary diagnosis is a thyroid tumor with superior mediastinal and tracheal involvements, staged as pT4bN0M0. The patient's condition has progressed well over the past 4 years. P: The management plan includes a total thyroidectomy and central neck dissection, postsurgical chemotherapy with docetaxel at 120 mg/m2 and cisplatin at 30 mg/m2, and intensity modulated radiotherapy with 70 Gy at 2.5 Gy per fraction. The patient is advised to continue regular check-ups to monitor for any signs of recurrence or complications. Further consultations with oncology and oncology are recommended to manage the patient's condition and manage any complications.

S: The patient, a sixth-pregnant woman, presented for delivery at the 37th week of gestation. She reports a history of two children, three abortions, and one previous cesarean section delivery. She has a history of multiple abortions and has a history of multiple cesarean sections. O: Preoperative blood tests showed hemoglobin at 10.8 g/dL, PT at 10.5 seconds, aPTT at 29 seconds, international normalized ratio at 2.3, and platelet count at 385x109/L. Transabdominal sonography and MRI showed total placenta previa and myometrial invasion to the urinary bladder at the anterior wall of the uterus. Postoperative findings included a 5-6 cm area of tissue loss at the anterior wall of the uterus, bleeding from the cervix and posterior wall of the bladder, and a 5-6 cm area of tissue loss at the anterior wall of the uterus. Pelvic packing was applied for 20 minutes, sutured with 1.0 polyglactine sutures, and a Sengstaken-Blakemore balloon catheter was placed. Bilateral uterine and hypogastric artery ligations were planned due to the hemorrhage, with the left external iliac artery accidentally held and bonded as the left hypogastric artery. The patient lost approximately 2000 cc of blood due to intraoperative hemorrhage, measured by adding 1650 cc blood in the aspirator and counting gauzes. A: The primary diagnosis is total placenta previa and myometrial invasion to the urinary bladder at the anterior wall of the uterus. Differential diagnoses could include complications from hysterectomy or other surgical interventions. The prognosis is guarded due to the complexity of the hemorrhage and the patient's history of multiple abortions. P: The patient underwent successful ligation of the uterine and hypogastric arteries. She was given erythrocyte suspension (3 units preoperatively and 4 unites postoperatively) and fresh frozen plasma to manage blood loss. Postoperative care included erythrocyte suspension (3 units preoperatively and 4 unites postoperatively) and fresh frozen plasma.

S: The patient, a 35-year smoker, reports progressive deterioration in renal function following immunotherapy with nivolumab for lung cancer.
