Differential diagnoses could include other causes of renal impairment, but these are less likely given the patient's history and clinical presentation. The prognosis is guarded due to the progression of renal function and the severity of the disease. P: Continue monitoring renal function and discuss potential treatment options. Continue current immunotherapy regimen with nivolumab. Maintain current regimen of 3 mg/kg every 2 weeks and monitor renal function closely. Educate the patient on

S: The patient, with a history of acromegaly and a transsphenoidal pituitary resection three weeks ago, presents with severe, intermittent, throbbing headache and clear nasal discharge following the removal of a nasal splint. The headache worsens when standing up or coughing, but is managed with lying down and taking acetaminophen. O: Physical examination and neurological examination were normal. Vital signs were normal. CT scan of the head showed multiple air loculi in the basal cisterns, lateral, third, and fourth ventricles, and numerous air-filled spaces scattered in the brain. No mass effect or midline shift was observed. A repeat CT scan showed mild increased diffuse PNC with intracranial air loculi in the parafalcine region, anterior horn of the left ventricle, posterior fossa, and left middle fossa, and an increased amount of air in the posterior fossa causing a mass effect on the pons. A: The primary diagnosis is diffuse PNC with associated pons mass effect. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of pons mass effect, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The management plan includes initial management with rest in the Fowler position at 30°, avoidance of Valsalva maneuvers, and a transsphenoidal endoscopic exploration of the sphenoid and sellar floor, septoplasty, and packing of the sphenoid sinus with an abdominal fat graft and a lumbar drain. Post-procedure, the patient will be discharged on day 10 of hospitalization with instructions to monitor symptoms and report any new symptoms. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's condition and adjust treatment as necessary.

S: The patient, currently on chemotherapy for acute myeloid leukemia (AML), reports a terrible reaction to pentamidine treatment. Symptoms include severe abdominal pain, emesis, diarrhea, lightheadedness, and almost fainting. The patient initially started IV pentamidine after developing a nonocclusive thrombus involving the celiac trunk, proximal hepatic, and splenic arteries. Post-treatment, the patient experienced intense abdominal pain, hypotension, and poor perfusion. Intramuscular epinephrine was positive. Abdominal X-ray showed non-obstructive gas patterns with small bowel wall thickening. Abdominal CT scan showed colonic wall thickening with surrounding inflammatory changes and ischemic colitis. MR enterography revealed patchy transmural ischemic colitis without local thrombosis or emboli. The patient continues IV pentamidine treatments every two weeks, with immediate symptoms including abdominal pain, emesis, pruritus, diarrhea, and headaches. A: The primary diagnosis is ischemic colitis secondary to pentamidine therapy, complicated by a nonocclusive thrombus and ischemic colitis. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of ischemic colitis, but these are less likely given the imaging and pathology results. P: Continue IV pentamidine therapy every two weeks, adjusting the desensitization protocol as needed. Monitor platelet levels closely and report any new symptoms or worsening of existing symptoms. Educate the patient on the importance of reporting new symptoms or worsening of existing symptoms. Encourage the patient to report any new symptoms or worsening of existing symptoms immediately.

S: The patient reports blurry and distorted vision in the left eye. The patient has a history of choroidal melanoma, diagnosed as choroidal melanoma. O: Histopathology confirmed choroidal melanoma. Surveillance imaging showed hepatic lesions in the liver in January 2016, with the largest lesion measuring 7.1  5.8 cm (M1b). Liver biopsy confirmed metastatic uveal melanoma (MUM). Initial treatment included nivolumab (1 mg/kg) and ipilimumab (3 mg/kg) every 2 weeks, followed by TACE treatments every 4 weeks. In November 2016, MRI showed a marked decrease in the size and number of metastatic liver lesions. Maintenance nivolumab (240 mg every 3 weeks) was started in January 2017. A: The primary diagnosis is metastatic uveal melanoma, confirmed by histopathology and liver biopsy. The prognosis is guarded due to the progression of the disease. P: Continue monitoring the patient's condition with regular check-ups and imaging. Maintain current regimen of nivolumab and TACE treatments every 8 weeks. Educate the patient on the importance of reporting any new symptoms or concerns immediately.

S: The patient reports a chronic right-sided headache, foul discharge from the nose, and a stuffed nose. The patient has a history of maxillary osteomyelitis in 2009, complicated by multiple interventions and a complex mediofacial resection. The patient also has depression and type two diabetes mellitus managed with peroral therapy. O: Nasal endoscopy and CT revealed a huge pathologic cavity, characterized by communication between the oral cavity, right maxillary sinus, and nasal cavity, and a minor communication with the right orbit. Biopsy specimens under general anesthesia showed severe but unspecific changes in nasal epithelium, reserve cell hyperplasia, epithelial erosions, ulcers, squamous cell metaplasia with acanthosis, abundant keratinization, squamous cell metaplasia of the submucosa, granulation tissue, fibrosis, chronic inflammatory infiltrate with lymphocytes, plasma cells, and absent giant cells. The interstitium was severely affected by zones of granulation tissue, fibrosis, and chronic inflammatory infiltrate with lymphocytes and plasma cells. A: The primary diagnosis is empty nose syndrome (ENS), based on clinical, endoscopic, radiologic, and histomorphologic findings. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of nasal epithelium abnormalities, but these are less likely given the clinical and imaging findings. P: The management plan includes continued monitoring of the patient's condition and managing symptoms. The patient is advised to maintain regular follow-up appointments to monitor the condition and adjust treatment as necessary. Further consultations with a nephrologist and a pulmonologist are recommended to address the underlying conditions.

S: The patient, a 16-year-old with a history of electrical burns at age 16 and 6 months old, reports a history of 48% TBSA third-degree injuries and severe right elbow injury. The patient underwent six skin grafting procedures prior to SEF placement, which was kept on for six weeks and placed using the Smith Nephew Richards system with 5.0-mm Shantz pins and rods. The patient also underwent two additional surgeries post-SEF placement, including ulnar nerve transposition, heterotopic ossification removal, contracture release with arthrofibrosis excision, and a flap to cover the soft tissue deficit. O: The patient's PT/OT notes showed a final ROM of 20°–90° in the extension and flexion arc, supination of 25° and pronation of 85°, and motor strength of 4-/5. Previous surgeries included ulnar nerve transposition, heterotopic ossification removal, contracture release with arthrofibrosis excision, and a flap to cover the soft tissue deficit. A 13-month follow-up showed a final ROM of 20°–90° in the extension and flexion arc, supination of 25° and pronation of 85°, and motor strength of 4-/5. A: The primary diagnosis is TBSA third-degree injuries with complications including heterotopic ossification, cubital tunnel syndrome, and elbow stiffness. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of elbow stiffness, but these are less likely given the patient's history and imaging results. P: Continue regular physical therapy and follow-up with a physical therapist to monitor the patient's recovery and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Educate the patient on the importance of adhering to follow-up appointments and adherence to the treatment plan. Encourage the patient to report any new or worsening symptoms immediately.

S: The patient reports experiencing nocturia, which is bothersome. O: Initial blood tests showed elevated PSA levels at 76.2 ng/mL. Digital rectal examination revealed induration in the prostate. Pelvic MRI showed extensive high signal in diffusion-weighted imaging (DWI) and fluorodeoxyglucose-positron emission tomography/CT. PET/CT showed multiple spine and pelvic bone and para-aortic and pelvic lymph node metastases. Post-treatment, PSA levels risen to 2.33 ng/mL, indicating castration-resistant prostate cancer (CRPC). Histopathological examinations of the prostate and vertebra showed 10 of 12 cores with viable prostate cancer cells. A: The primary diagnosis is castration-resistant prostate cancer (CRPC), confirmed by histopathological examinations and histopathological findings. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of metastatic prostate cancer, but these are less likely given the imaging and histopathological findings. P: The patient was started on androgen deprivation therapy (ADT) without prostate needle biopsy, including degarelix and bicalutamide. After 15 months of treatment, PSA levels risen to 2.33 ng/mL, indicating castration-resistant prostate cancer (CRPC). A CT, bone scan, and WB-MRI were performed to assess disease status. Histopathological examinations of the prostate and vertebra showed 10 of 12 cores with viable prostate cancer cells. A CT-guided needle biopsy from the osteoblastic lesion of the second lumbar vertebra will be performed to further assess the condition.

S: The patient, a 70-year-old female, reports frequent dizziness since age 70, accompanied by memory and thinking difficulties. She also mentions a decrease in movement speed recently due to mild bradykinesia. O: The patient's mini-mental state examination (MMSE) score was 23, indicating mild cognitive impairment. Neurological examination revealed mild bradykinesia in movements. Brain CT scan showed calcified areas in various regions of the brain, including bilateral globus pallidus, caudate nuclei, pulvinar thalami, dentate nuclei, and subcortical and periventricular regions. A: The primary diagnosis is mild cognitive impairment with associated mild bradykinesia and mild cognitive impairment. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of brain calcifications, but these are less likely given the imaging findings and imaging findings. P: The management plan includes regular check-ups and close monitoring of the patient's condition. The patient will be educated on the importance of regular follow-ups and medication adherence. Referral to a neurologist for further evaluation and management of the calcifications is recommended. The patient is encouraged to reach out with any questions or concerns during the consultation.

S: The patient reports dull, aching generalized abdominal pain persisting for eight months, worsening after meals, nausea, and reduced appetite. The pain wakes the patient from sleep every few days. The patient has a history of hypertension, four surgeries in the last 10 years, and no recent weight loss. The patient has a BMI of 38. O: Physical examination is unremarkable. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy revealed a nonobstructing, nonbleeding cratered ulcer in the posterior wall of the gastric body. Biopsies indicated moderate-poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma. PET scan showed increased uptake in two regions: one in the medial gastric fundus (maximum SUV=14.2) and a second near the cecum (maximum SUV=18.6), with abnormal circumferential thickening and pericolonic inflammatory changes involving the cecum with numerous small lymph nodes in the right lower quadrant (largest lymph node=12 mm  18 mm). Colonoscopy revealed a fungating, partially obstructing, nonbleeding, circumferential mass in the cecum. Blood tests showed anemia with a hemoglobin level of 9.3, but other tests were unremarkable. Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) level was 0.819 preoperatively. A: The primary diagnosis is synchronous gastric and colon cancer, characterized by a nonobstructing, nonbleeding cratered ulcer in the posterior wall of the gastric body, moderate-poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma, and anemia with a hemoglobin level of 9.3. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of gastric and colon cancers, but these are less likely given the imaging and biopsy results. P: The management plan includes scheduling a surgical resection of the synchronous gastric and colon cancer, which is surgically resectable. The patient will be monitored for signs of recurrence or complications, and follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess recovery and manage any complications. Education on the signs of recurrence and when to seek immediate care will be provided.

S: The patient, a male, presented with a history of accidentally taking two celphos tablets about 7 hours ago. He reports shortness of breath and passing cola-colored urine. O: Vital signs include blood pressure 76/54 mm Hg, pulse 114/minute, respiratory rate 24/minute, oxygen saturation 86% in ambient air, and Glasgow Coma Scale (15/15). Oxygen was administered at 4-5 L/minute. Glasgow Coma Scale was 15/15, with no focal neurological signs. Laboratory tests showed lactic acidosis on arterial blood gas analysis. A: The primary diagnosis is unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, likely secondary to celphos use. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of hemolytic anemia, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and laboratory results. P: The patient was moved to the intensive care unit for management. Management included central venous pressure guided intravenous fluids, ionotropes, and magnesium sulfate injections. On day two, the patient experienced shortness of breath and passing cola-colored urine. Further tests revealed macrocytosis and anisopoikilocytosis without schistocytes or red blood cell fragments. Serum lactate dehydrogenase was 1900 U/L, haptoglobin was 11 mg/dL, and direct Coomb's test was negative. Partial thromboplastin time and prothrombin time were normal. Urine showed hemosiderin, but microscopy was normal. Ultrasonography of the abdomen was normal. A: The primary diagnosis is unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, likely secondary to celphos use. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of hemolytic anemia, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and laboratory results. P: The management plan includes transferring the patient to the ICU for intensive care. Management will include central venous pressure guided intravenous fluids, ionotropes, and magnesium sulfate injections. The patient will be monitored in the ICU for hemogram and biochemistry, with a focus on preventing worsening hemolysis. The patient will be advised to avoid medications that may worsen hemolysis. Follow-up appointments will be

S: The patient, with no past medical history, presented with sudden, severe abdominal pain, weight loss, and painless jaundice. The patient reported a significant weight loss and yellowing of the skin and eyes. O: Physical examination revealed scleral icterus. Laboratory tests showed liver enzymes dysfunction (alanine transaminase 144 U/L, aspartate aminotransferase 122 U/L, alkaline phosphatase 331 IU/L), conjugated hyperbilirubinemia (5.4 mg/dl), and a marginal increase in total protein to 9 g/dl. Immunoglobulins assay showed an increase in IgG total (15.1 g/dl), IgG subclass analysis (155 mg/dl), and normal tumor marker screen for cancer antigen 19-9. Imaging showed lymph node enlargement close to the celiac plexus origin and minimal calcification of the pancreatic head. Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) showed a distal stricture in the common bile duct (CBD), relieved with stenting, and histopathology suggested primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC). Endoscopic ultrasound was unremarkable. A: The primary diagnosis is autoimmune pancreatitis with complications including sclerosing cholangitis and primary sclerosing cholangitis. Differential diagnoses were considered but ruled out based on imaging and tumor marker screen. P: The patient was treated with steroid therapy and has been on thyroxine for hypothyroidism and Hashimoto's. Follow-up will be scheduled for four to six months to monitor progress and adjust treatment as necessary. The patient will be educated on the importance of follow-up and the importance of adherence to the treatment plan.

S: The patient reports a history of a distal pancreatectomy and splenectomy to treat a pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor. Postoperatively, the patient developed a pancreatic fluid leak from the tail of the pancreas, which was resolved with the removal of an abdominal drain. Post-surgery, a CT scan showed an increase in the size of the rim enhancing fluid collection around the tail of the pancreas. An ERCP confirmed a leak from the tail of the pancreas. An endoscopic pancreatic sphincterotomy and placement of a 5 Fr x 13 cm pancreatic duct stent with internal barbs were performed. An EUS showed a well-demarcated, hypoechoic, heterogeneous collection adjacent to the tail of the pancreas, approximately 6.5 cm in the largest dimension. A 15 mm x 10 mm LAMS was placed under endosonographic guidance from the stomach, and a large amount of pus was drained. A: The primary diagnosis is a pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor with complications including a pancreatic fluid leak and a pancreatic duct leak. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of pancreatic fluid leaks, but these are less likely given the imaging and surgical findings. P: The patient underwent an endoscopic pancreatic sphincterotomy and placement of a 5 Fr x 13 cm pancreatic duct stent with internal barbs. Post-procedure, a 15 mm x 10 mm LAMS was placed under endosonographic guidance from the stomach, and a large amount of pus was drained. A: The primary diagnosis is a pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor with complications including a pancreatic duct leak and a pancreatic duct leak. The prognosis is guarded due to the complexity of the pancreatic duct leak and the patient's neurological status. P: Continue monitoring the patient's progress closely and provide supportive care. Regular follow-ups are necessary to assess the effectiveness of the stent and manage any complications. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms or changes in health immediately. S: The patient reports experiencing low blood pressure, chest pain, and difficulty breathing for the past three days. O: Initial Doppler sonography revealed acute deep vein thrombosis (DVT), characterized by severe right ventricular dysfunction and enlargement in the right ventricle. Echocardiography showed severe right ventricular dysfunction and enlargement, with a high systolic pulmonary artery pressure (SPAP) of 70 mmHg. A: The primary diagnosis is acute deep vein thrombosis (DVT), evidenced by severe right ventricular dysfunction and enlargement in the right ventricle. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of DVT, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The management plan includes administering reteplase to manage DVT and improve heart function. The patient is advised to monitor symptoms closely and schedule a follow-up appointment in a few weeks to monitor progress. Lifestyle changes and medications may be recommended to prevent future DVT episodes. The patient is encouraged to contact healthcare providers if any concerns arise.

S: The patient, with a history of poorly controlled diabetes, presented with vomiting blood and disorientation, nausea, and epigastralgia for the past 2 days. O: Vital signs were in shock, with no response to rehydration. Laboratory findings showed a blood glucose level of 470 mg/dL (normal range: 135-170 mg/dL), arterial blood gas pH of 7.2, PCO2 of 25.2 mmHg, HCO3 of 9.9 mEq/L, and PO2 of 169 mmHg with an anion gap of 24.3 mEq/L. Positive urinary ketones and glucose. Intubation and emergency endoscopy revealed black pigmentation in the entire esophageal mucosa. CT scan showed circumferential edematous thickening of the esophageal wall with slight pleural effusion, but no perforation or free air in the mediastinum. Emergency thoracoscopy indicated significant pleural effusion with pus and perforation of the esophagus. A: The primary diagnosis is acute esophageal necrosis (AEN) with complications including acute pleural effusion and free air in the mediastinum. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of esophageal necrosis, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The patient was started on antibiotics, glycemic control, a proton pump inhibitor, and plasmapheresis. The patient was extubated on day 5, but remained in fever. Emergency thoracoscopy was performed, revealing significant pleural effusion with pus and perforation of the esophagus. A: The primary diagnosis is acute esophageal necrosis (AEN) with complications including acute pleural effusion and free air in the mediastinum. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of acute esophageal necrosis, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The patient was started on antibiotics, glycemic control, a proton pump inhibitor, and plasmapheresis. The patient was extubated on day 5

S: The patient, a 6-year-old non-pregnant huacaya alpaca mare, presented with respiratory symptoms lasting about 6 weeks, accompanied by forced breathing but no fever, and recent weight loss. The alpaca was previously treated with medication but did not improve symptoms. O: Clinical examination revealed the alpaca to be alert and nervous, with a body mass of 53 kg, a body condition score of 1 out of 5, and a rectal temperature of 38.3 °C. Heart rate was 72 bpm, and respiratory rate was 60 breaths per minute. Lab results showed neutrophilia at 9.37  109/l (normal 3.4–9.1  109/l), low potassium at 3.64 mmol/l (normal 4–5.2 mmol/l), and low magnesium at 0.71 mmol/l (normal 0.71 mmol/l). A: The primary diagnosis is a left shift alpaca with respiratory symptoms and weight loss. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of respiratory symptoms, but these are less likely given the clinical findings and lab results. P: The management plan will include further diagnostic tests including a complete blood cell count and blood chemistry panel to further explore the cause of the alpaca's respiratory symptoms and weight loss. The alpaca will be closely monitored for any signs of infection or recurrence of respiratory symptoms. The patient will be educated on the importance of adherence to the treatment plan and the importance of regular follow-ups. Referral to a veterinarian for further evaluation and management of the alpaca's condition is recommended.

S: The patient, a 39-year-old male, presented with progressive dyspnea, reduced physical activity, and periodic cardiac arrhythmia. He has a history of acroparesthesia, heat intolerance, severe abdominal pain, gastrointestinal abnormalities, and bronchial asthma diagnosed in childhood. He has been followed by a nephrologist for recurrent pyelonephritis, acute urinary tract infections, subnephrotic proteinuria (1 g/L), and edema in the lower limbs. O: Physical examination revealed normal sinus rhythm, short PR interval, signs of left ventricular hypertrophy, secondary repolarization abnormalities, and asymmetric myocardial hypertrophy in the LV apex and lateral wall without LV outflow tract obstruction. Two-dimensional strain analysis showed a reduced global longitudinal strain (GLS14%), particularly reduced in the posterolateral wall (peak systolic strain8%), with normal diastolic function. Cardiac MRI showed asymmetric myocardial hypertrophy in the apex and lateral wall, with no signs of renal failure. Brain MRI on T2/FLAIR showed white matter hyperintensities lesions. A: The primary diagnosis is Fabry disease, likely secondary to a recurrent pyelonephritis, acute urinary tract infections, subnephrotic proteinuria, and edema in the lower limbs. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of asymmetric myocardial hypertrophy, but these are less likely given the imaging findings and clinical presentation. P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition with regular follow-ups with nephrology and cardiology. The patient is advised to maintain a healthy lifestyle and follow up with healthcare providers as needed. Further diagnostic workups will be conducted to further evaluate the cause of the myocardial hypertrophy and potential fibrotic alterations. Education regarding the nature of Fabry disease and the importance of adherence to follow-up appointments will be provided.

S: The patient is a 53-year-old female presenting with right wrist pain and swelling following a fall. She reports blister formation on her right forearm two days post-splinting. She has no previous medical history. O: Plain X-ray examination revealed a distal radius fracture accompanied by dorsal displacement of the distal bone fragment (AO classification: type A2). A: The primary diagnosis is a distal radius fracture with dorsal displacement of the distal bone fragment. The patient's skin condition is poor, necessitating conservative treatment with a splint or cast. P: The management plan includes minimally invasive locking plate osteosynthesis using the Henry approach using a 10 mm incision starting from 15 mm proximal to the radial styloid process, 9 days post-injury. Postoperative care will include immobilization in a bulky dressing without an arm splint until tissue swelling has decreased. The pronator quadratus will be incised transversely at its distal portion and dissected off the periosteum using a periosteal elevator preserving its ulnar and radial insertions. A: The primary diagnosis is a distal radius fracture with dorsal displacement of the distal bone fragment. The patient's skin condition is poor, necessitating conservative treatment with a splint or cast. P: The management plan includes minimally invasive locking plate osteosynthesis using a volar locking plate. Postoperative care will include immobilization in a bulky dressing without an arm splint until tissue swelling has decreased. The pronator quadratus will be incised transversely at its distal portion and dissected off the periosteum using a periosteal elevator preserving its ulnar and radial insertions. The patient will be educated on the procedure and expected outcomes to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient, with a history of arthritis and a history of right total hip arthroplasty, reports a history of laparoscopic cholecystectomy for acute cholecystitis and complications including choledocholithiasis. The patient experienced right hip pain and difficulty moving the hip or leg. O: On admission, the patient was febrile with a temperature of 102.7 F. Physical examination revealed a well-healed right lateral hip incision with no erythema or drainage. Laboratory tests including WBC, hemoglobin, hematocrit, basic metabolic profile, and liver function tests were within normal limits. A 3 cm hepatic abscess was identified on a CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis and MRI of the right hip, with a large air- and fluid-filled collection. A: The primary diagnosis is an iliopsoas abscess, periprosthetic infection, and hepatic abscess. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of acute cholecystitis, but these are less likely given the imaging and laboratory findings. P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition with regular follow-ups to assess for any recurrence or complications. The patient will be educated on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and adherence to follow-up appointments. Referral to a hepatologist for further evaluation and management of the hepatic abscess is recommended.

S: The patient, a housewife with a history of TOT surgery 2 years ago, presents with urinary incontinence, dysuria, and urine leakage during sexual intercourse. She reports persistent symptoms of urinary incontinence and has been using duloxetine 80 mg daily for 3 months. She denies any history of alcohol consumption or tobacco smoking. She has two deliveries: one vaginal birth and one cesarean delivery. O: On admission, the patient's temperature was 36.6 °C, pulse 82 beats/minute, and blood pressure 110/65 mmHg. She was fully conscious and responsive. Psychologically, she appeared depressed. Physical examination revealed no abdominal tenderness or anatomic anomalies, no murmurs or arrhythmias, respiratory frequency 14/minute, and no wheezing or rales. Neurological examination showed normal muscle strength and tone, normal ulnar, patellar, and Achilles reflexes (2+). Urogynecological examination showed SUI without urogenital prolapse. Laboratory tests showed total white blood cell count 6.9  103/mm3, hemoglobin 12.1 g/dL, alanine aminotransferase 38 u/l, aspartate aminotransferase 35 u/l, C-reactive protein 1.1 mg/l, and creatinine 0.6 mg/dl. Serological tests for HbsAg, HCV, and HIV were negative. Urine analysis showed microscopic hematuria and sterile urine culture. A: The primary diagnosis is urinary incontinence secondary to TOT surgery, complicated by SUI. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of urinary incontinence, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and laboratory findings. P: Continue current regimen of duloxetine 80 mg daily for 3 months. Schedule a follow-up appointment to assess progress and discuss potential adjustments in treatment. Educate the patient on the importance of reporting any new symptoms or changes in her condition. Encourage her to report any new symptoms immediately.

S: The patient, with a history of severe peripheral vascular disease, right hip disarticulation, and paraplegia, reports a stage IV pressure ulcer on the left greater trochanter leading to osteomyelitis. The patient underwent limited resection of the greater trochanter with complications including an invasive infection in the hip and acetabulum, which led to the development of osteomyelitis. O: Intraoperative findings revealed a grossly necrotic femoral head with a large open wound over the greater trochanter. Cultures from the Girdlestone procedure grew Staphylococcus epidermidis. The wound was treated with a Cleanse Choice NPWTi-d and delayed primary closure over closed suction drains. Postoperatively, the patient was discharged seven days post-procedure on ceftriaxone and vancomycin, and was not readmitted in the first 30 days postoperatively. The incision has healed completely but remains persistent low volume drainage via a surgical drain at five months postoperatively. A: The primary diagnosis is osteomyelitis secondary to a stage IV pressure ulcer on the left greater trochanter, complicated by an invasive infection in the hip and acetabulum. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of osteomyelitis, but these are less likely given the culture results. P: The patient underwent a Girdlestone procedure to manage the osteomyelitis. Postoperatively, the patient was discharged seven days post-procedure with ceftriaxone and vancomycin, and was not readmitted in the first 30 days postoperatively. The incision has healed completely but remains persistent low volume drainage via a surgical drain at five months postoperatively. The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition with regular follow-ups to assess for any recurrence or complications.

S: The patient reports experiencing seizures and is concerned about them. The patient has a history of astrocytoma grade II glioma diagnosed in May 2010, treated with partial surgical resection and chemotherapy with TMZ. The patient experienced anorexia, insomnia, depression, and a second seizure requiring hospitalization in May 2015. O: Initial MRI showed intra-axial expansive and infiltrative lesions in the anterior half of the right temporal lobe, extending from the pole to the Sylvian fissure superiorly and to the right parahippocampal gyrus posteriorly and medially. MRI findings included discrete extension of signal alteration areas in the subinsular regions. The patient underwent partial surgical resection and chemotherapy with TMZ at a dose of 2,000 mg, with cycles every 28 days for 5 days, with no tumor regrowth. In 2015, the tumor size increased. In June 2015, a follow-up MRI showed exacerbation and an ultra-precocious phenomenon of PSD with increased edema and inflammatory disease, characterized by extensive contrast enhancement and tissue hypoperfusion. A: The primary diagnosis is astrocytoma grade II glioma with a history of astrocytoma grade II. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of glioma, but the MRI findings support the primary diagnosis. The prognosis is guarded due to the recurrence of seizures and the progression of glioma. P: Continue monitoring the patient's condition closely and adjust the treatment plan as necessary to manage symptoms and control tumor growth. Regular follow-ups with neuro-oncology are recommended to monitor the patient's condition and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Educate the patient on the importance of reporting new symptoms or changes in their condition.

S: The patient reports experiencing left-sided testicular pain for about a month, a dry cough, fever, weakness, tiredness, and decreased appetite over the last four days. The patient has a history of insulin-requiring type 2 diabetes mellitus, arterial hypertension, stage 3 chronic renal disease, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. O: Physical examination revealed febrileness and tachycardia. Left testicular edema and pain on epididymal palpation were noted. Laboratory tests showed neutrophilic leukocytosis (24.2 x103/uL WBC and 87% neutrophils), thickening of the bronchial walls, increased white blood cells, and Gram-negative bacteria. Testicular ultrasound revealed an abscess in the tail of the left epididymis. Follow-up chest X-ray showed multiple bilateral nodular lesions and left pleural effusion. Blood and urine cultures were positive for K. pneumoniae, sensitive to penicillin, quinolone, and carbapenem. Chest CT confirmed multiple bilateral nodules with halo sign and reversed halo sign. A: The primary diagnosis is SPE secondary to epididymitis, evidenced by the presence of multiple bilateral nodular lesions and left pleural effusion. Differential diagnoses initially included other causes of testicular pain and edema, but these were ruled out based on imaging and clinical findings. P: The patient was suspended from oral doxycycline therapy and started intravenous ciprofloxacin. The treatment plan includes continued monitoring of respiratory symptoms and metabolic control, with adjustments to the treatment plan as necessary. The patient will continue to be monitored in the intermediate-care unit for hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state. Further consultations with a pulmonologist and a nephrologist are recommended to manage the patient's condition and manage any complications.

S: The patient reports experiencing pelvic and abdominal pain following a serious car accident. The patient denies any issues with voiding. O: Clinical examination revealed pelvic instability and blood loss from the urethra. An urgent contrast-enhanced CT scan showed a small liver laceration and an unstable pelvic fracture. Kidneys were normal, and the bladder was empty. Urine was not visible on abdominal ultrasound. Follow-up abdominopelvic CT scan 14 hours post-admission showed a nearly empty and upwards displaced bladder with contrast extravasation into the peritoneal cavity. Laboratory tests indicated severe electrolyte imbalance, elevated creatinine, and anemia. A: The primary diagnosis is a severe car accident with complications including pelvic instability, blood loss from the urethra, and a bladder laceration. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of pelvic instability, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The patient underwent hemofiltration and a laparotomy to drain urine and a large laceration in the bladder dome. Post-admission, hemofiltration was performed, followed by laparotomy, where copious amounts of urine were drained and a large laceration was found in the bladder dome. The patient will continue to be closely monitored in an academic hospital with dedicated trauma facilities. Further treatment options will be discussed with the multidisciplinary trauma team to manage the patient's condition and prevent further complications.

S: The patient, an eight-year-old female, presented with massive ascites over the past two months, accompanied by fatigue, abdominal distention, and weight loss of 10-15 pounds over the past two months. The patient denies any significant medical history. O: Vital signs were normal at a tertiary care hospital, but the abdomen was distended. No signs of peritonitis or perforation were noted. Bowel sounds were normal. Laboratory tests showed hemoglobin at 14.6 g/dL with low red cell indices, iron deficiency anemia, low serum iron, and platelet count at 641,000/micro liter. Peripheral smear showed hypochromia, anisocytosis, microcytosis, few reactive lymphocytes, and increased platelets. C-reactive protein was 24.27 mg/L. Liver function tests and coagulation profile were normal. Ascitic tap was positive for red blood cells with a total lymphocyte count of 122/cumm, protein 2.6 g/dL, and lactate dehydrogenase 156. Serum-ascites albumin gradient was less than 1.1 g/dL. Chest X-ray and Mycobacterium tuberculosis DNA by PCR were negative. CT scan showed gross ascites with omental thickening and nodularity. A: The primary diagnosis is severe ascites secondary to iron deficiency anemia. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of ascites, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. The prognosis depends on the response to further diagnostic tests and treatment options. P: The management plan includes continuation of supportive care and monitoring of symptoms. The patient is advised to continue supportive care and report any new symptoms or worsening of symptoms immediately. Further diagnostic tests may be considered based on the results of the Chest X-ray and Mycobacterium tuberculosis DNA by PCR. The patient is advised to continue supportive care and monitor symptoms closely. Referral to a pediatric hematologist for further evaluation and management of ascites is recommended.

S: The patient, a child-Pugh stage C patient, presented with general malaise and septic shock-like symptoms. He reported being on renal dialysis for the past 2 years. He denies any type of cancer, chemo or corticosteroid therapy, autoimmune diseases, or alcohol consumption. He was previously diagnosed with end-stage hepatic failure (Child-Pugh stage C) and treated for anorexia, hypotension, and hypoglycemia. He denies any alcohol consumption. O: On examination, the patient was in Japan Coma Scale I-3 (Glasgow Coma Scale E3V1M5), with severe hypotension. Laboratory tests indicated high serum C-reactive protein, increased direct bilirubin, extremely high hyaluronic acid, type IV collagen, reduced total protein and albumin levels, reduced prothrombin time, and markedly low choline esterase activity. Complement system tests showed reduced 50% hemolytic complement (CH50) and C3 levels, with normal C4 levels. Abdominal computed tomography showed pleural effusion and small ascites. Cell counts were 272/L, negative for culture. On day 4, blood culture yielded Cryptococcus. A: The primary diagnosis is decompensated liver dysfunction, complicated by pleural effusion and small ascites. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of liver dysfunction, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and laboratory findings. P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition, treatment for liver dysfunction, infection, and other symptoms. The patient will be educated on the importance of adherence to the treatment plan and the importance of regular follow-ups. Further consultations with a hepatologist and a hematologist may be necessary depending on the response to treatment.

S: The patient, diagnosed with refractory AML, has been admitted for treatment. He reports feeling anxious about the treatment process but expresses concern about the side effects of chemotherapy. O: The patient's current hemoglobin level is 9.5 g/dl (normal range: 13.8-17.2 g/dl for men, 15.1-17.2 g/dl for women), and platelet count is 20,000 per microliter (normal range: 0-60 g/dl). Urinalysis results are normal. Blood cultures of the central line and peripheral veins show Staphylococcus epidermidis. CT scan of the paranasal sinuses revealed sinusitis with hyperdense opacification. A CT scan of the paranasal sinuses revealed sinusitis with hyperdense opacification. A skin lesion biopsy was performed to determine the cause of endophthalmitis in the left eye. A: The primary diagnosis is refractory AML with complications including catheter-related infection and thrombocytopenia. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of thrombocytopenia, but these are less likely given the culture results. The prognosis depends on the response to chemotherapy and response to treatment. P: The patient will be closely monitored for fever and neutropenia. Antibiotic lock therapy will be started, followed by systemic antibiotics. Skin lesion biopsy will be performed if painful, erythematous macular and papular lesions resembling ecthyma gangrenosum are noted. Intravitreal AMB will be added to systemic antifungal therapy to treat endophthalmitis. The patient will be educated on the importance of reporting new symptoms or concerns.

S: The patient is a 20-year-old female with a history of amoxicillin allergy and a recent pregnancy test. She reports a persistent, persistent tummy ache at the bottom of her abdomen, which started a few days ago. She has a history of vaginal bleeding, constipation, and a recent cesarean section. She has been using Implanon for one year and has a history of constipation. She has been at work for the past few days, and has been at home. She has been drinking a lot but has not been up that high before. She has a history of allergies, amoxicillin allergy, and a recent pregnancy test. O: The patient's abdomen is below the belly button. She has been constipated for a week, and has been constipated for a week. She has a history of vaginal bleeding, constipation, and a recent pregnancy test. She has been at work for a month, and has been at home for a year. She has a history of amoxicillin allergy and a recent pregnancy test. She has been drinking a lot but has not been up that high before. She has a history of a pregnancy test a month ago. A: The primary diagnosis is a recurrent vaginal bleeding, likely exacerbated by the use of Implanon. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of vaginal bleeding and constipation, but these are less likely given the patient's history and current symptoms. The prognosis is guarded due to the severity of the symptoms and the potential for complications. P: The management plan includes scheduling a face to face examination in a clinic to conduct an abdominal examination, and advising the patient on the importance of avoiding alcohol and other substances. The patient is advised to call the support line if the pain worsens or if she is not holding any fluids down. She will be referred to a nephrologist for further evaluation and management. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's response to treatment and adjust the plan as necessary.

SZ.F reports a 4 cm lump in the neck, which has been bothering him. Blood tests were recently unremarkable. Fine needle aspiration cytology indicated a lymphoproliferative disorder. Neck CT scans showed a 33x25 mm hypodense, homogenous mass in the neck with other smaller lymph nodes in the surrounding area. Open surgical biopsy identified necrotic tissue with a fibrotic capsule, Vimentin-positive connective tissue components, vessels, and fragments of skeletal muscle. Silver impregnation showed a residual reticular sinusoidal structure. CD-20 and CD-68 immunohistochemistry indicated histiocytes and residual lymphoid cells, and Ki-67 reaction showed a 10% proliferation index of CD-20 positive lymphocytes. Subtotal lymph node infarction was diagnosed as subtotal lymph node infarction without malignancy. A 17 mm cystic mass was found in the incision area. A: The primary diagnosis is subtotal lymph node infarction without malignancy, a non-cancerous condition. Differential diagnosis initially included lymph node infarction, which was ruled out based on biopsy results. P: The patient underwent surgical removal of the cystic mass. The final histologic diagnosis is a lymph node infarction without malignancy. The patient is under control with no signs of cancer or malignancy.

S: The patient reports difficulty breathing and discomfort in the chest. The patient has a history of Ebstein's anomaly, causing severe right atrial and right ventricular dilatation, right moderate ventricular dysfunction, and severe tricuspid regurgitation. The patient has a history of HIV immunodeficiency, leading to a history of cerebral infection and Kaposi's Sarcoma. O: The patient's test results indicate severe right atrial and right ventricular dilatation, right moderate ventricular dysfunction, and severe tricuspid regurgitation. The patient has a history of HIV immunodeficiency, contributing to the patient's risk of infections. A: The primary diagnosis is Ebstein's anomaly, complicated by severe right atrial and right ventricular dilatation, right moderate ventricular dysfunction, and severe tricuspid regurgitation. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of heart failure, but these are less likely given the patient's history of HIV immunodeficiency and HIV immunodeficiency. P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's heart condition and HIV immunodeficiency with appropriate medications. The patient is advised to maintain a balanced diet, exercise as tolerated, and avoid smoking and excessive alcohol consumption. Regular follow-up appointments are scheduled to assess progress and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. The patient is encouraged to report any worsening symptoms or new issues immediately.

S: The patient, diagnosed with severe HEMA in early childhood, reports a low factor VIII activity of less than 0.001% and a brother with severe HEMA. The patient has a history of HIV-1 and hepatitis C infection, treated with blood transfusions, and has been considered an HIV long-term non-progressor (LTNP). O: The patient's factor VIII activity was less than 0.001%, and the patient's brother also developed inhibitors during treatment with factor VIII. Blood samples were taken in EDTA tubes and isolated peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs) over ficoll gradient. Magnetic purification of CD4 T cells was performed using an allprep DNA/RNA mini kit from Qiagen. Whole exome sequencing (WES) was performed using Kapa H. A: The primary diagnosis is severe HEMA, with a history of HIV-1 and hepatitis C infection. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of HEMA, but these are less likely given the patient's history of HIV-1 and hepatitis C infection. P: The management plan includes analyzing the results of WES to determine the phenotype of the HEMA causative mutation and potential HIV LTNP phenotype. The patient will be educated on the importance of adherence to the treatment regimen and the importance of monitoring for potential complications. Further follow-up or treatment will be based on the results.

S: The patient reports being asymptomatic with a history of metastatic breast cancer treated with mastectomy and systemic chemotherapy. The patient denies experiencing abdominal pain or fever. The patient has been on lapatinib, capecitabine, zoledronic acid, and steroids for cerebral oedema. O: Recent restaging total-body CT scan revealed moderate pneumatosis in the mesentery and pericolic fat, with intramural gas along the caecum and ascending colon. No other worrisome findings were noted. The patient has been on lapatinib, capecitabine, zoledronic acid, and steroids for cerebral oedema. A: The primary diagnosis is metastatic breast cancer with complications including pneumatosis and intramural gas in the mesentery and pericolic fat. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of pneumatosis, but these are less likely given the absence of other significant findings and the absence of symptoms. P: The management plan includes conservative surveillance with clinical and radiological surveillance to monitor the pneumatosis. The patient is currently asymptomatic with no symptoms of pain or fever. Follow-up imaging tests will be conducted to track the pneumatosis. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately.

S: The patient is 37 weeks into her first pregnancy, referred for obstetric ultrasonography. She reports no significant clinical history during her pregnancy. She has a history of unremarkable clinical history. O: The patient underwent a routine obstetric sonographic examination at 22 weeks gestation, which showed no abnormalities. Ultrasonography results showed a well-developed foetal, with no noticeable abnormalities. A: The primary diagnosis is a well-developed foetal, with no abnormalities noted during the ultrasound. The prognosis is good with no immediate complications. P: The patient is advised to continue regular check-ups and monitoring for the remainder of her pregnancy. The patient is advised to report any changes or concerns immediately. Regular follow-up appointments are scheduled to monitor the development of the foetal.

S: The patient presented with a moderately severe frontal headache, characterized by non-radiating pain. The patient reported a non-radiating pain. O: Initial Brain MRI showed multiple discrete regions of abnormal signal and mild swelling involving white matter and overlying cortex. Susceptibility-weighted imaging (SWI) indicated numerous cortical lobar microbleeds throughout both cerebral hemispheres. Repeat MRI showed resolution of parenchymal abnormalities but new regions containing peripheral microbleeds. Amyloid-PET using 18F-florbetapir showed moderate widespread amyloid deposition. CSF analysis showed reduced amyloid-beta 1–42 and high-normal total tau. Formal neuropsychological testing suggested mild compromise in frontal functioning. Follow-up MRI showed almost complete resolution of parenchymal abnormalities but persisting lobar microbleeds. A: The primary diagnosis is a mild frontal headache with associated atypical amyloid deposition and persistent lobar microbleeds. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of frontal headaches, but these are less likely given the imaging findings and clinical presentation. P: The patient was treated with 5 days of intravenous methylprednisolone (1 g daily) followed by an oral taper from prednisolone 60 mg over 8 weeks. Post-treatment, the patient remains asymptomatic 24 months post-symptom onset. Regular follow-ups are scheduled to monitor the patient's condition and detect any new symptoms. The patient is advised to reach out with any concerns or new symptoms immediately.

S: The patient, with a history of synthetic cannabinoid use for approximately five years, presents with strange symptoms including peeing blood and nosebleeds, and a red eye. The patient also mentions adding rodenticides to synthetic cannabinoids to make them stronger. O: Physical examination reveals stable vital signs, right conjunctival hemorrhage in the eye, active epistaxis in the left nostril, and blood-tinged urine. Laboratory tests indicate a prothrombin time greater than 106 seconds, and a partial thromboplastin time of 79.5 seconds. International normalized ratio (INR) is not determinable. A: The primary diagnosis is acute chemical-induced coagulopathy, likely exacerbated by synthetic cannabinoid use. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of coagulopathy, but these are less likely given the laboratory results and clinical presentation. P: Initiate intravenous vitamin K1 50 mg and notify the poison control center. Continue two doses of oral vitamin K1 50 mg over the next two days until PT normalizes. Educate the patient on the importance of monitoring symptoms and adhering to the treatment plan. Encourage the patient to reach out with any concerns or questions.

S: The patient, a 53-month-old female, reports progressive bilateral breast enlargement and accelerated growth since 9 months old. She denies any vaginal bleeding or developed pubic or axillary hair. She has no history of vaginal bleeding or hair growth. O: Physical examination reveals a well-looking girl with normal blood pressure, a weight of 17 kg, height of 108 cm, mid-parental height of 175 cm, and predicted adult height of 167 cm. Tanner staging is A1, P1, and B3. She has a reddish mucoid vagina with no clitoromegaly, acne, hirsutism, or palpable abdominal mass. Laboratory tests reveal a bone age of 8 years, elevated basal luteinizing hormone at 3.1 mIU/L, elevated estradiol E2 at 29,000 pg/ml, and dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate at 90 ng/mL. Early morning cortisol is normal at 16 ng/mL. Abdominal ultrasound and CT scan reveal a 25  22 mm well-defined rounded focal lesion at the right adrenal gland with homogeneous attenuation. A: The primary diagnosis is a progressive bilateral breast enlargement and accelerated growth, likely secondary to a genetic condition, given the patient's history and imaging findings. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of vaginal bleeding and hair growth, but these are less likely given the imaging findings. P: Plan to discuss the case with a specialist to determine the best course of action. Continue monitoring the patient's symptoms and regular follow-ups. Educate the patient on the importance of reporting any new symptoms or changes in her condition. Consider referral to a nephrologist for further evaluation and management.

S: The patient is an 80-year-old male presenting with progressive dysphagia for the past 8 months. He reports difficulty swallowing and feels like a foreign body stuck in his throat. He denies any pain during swallowing or changes in voice. O: Physical examination revealed no obvious pathology and no palpable mass in the neck. Indirect laryngoscopy showed a protrusion in the posterior hypopharyngeal wall, unremarkable endolarynx exam, and normal vocal cord mobility. Neurological examination was normal. CT scan of the cervical spine showed extensive flowing anterior osteophytes from C5 to D1, with a level of compression at C5-C6. A: The primary diagnosis is progressive dysphagia, likely exacerbated by underlying osteophytes. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of dysphagia, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: Discharge with a prescription for anti-inflammatory drugs and recommendations for dietary changes. The patient is advised to avoid solid food to alleviate discomfort. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor progress and adjust treatment as necessary.

S: The patient reports a history of a motor vehicle accident with basilar skull fractures, subarachnoid hemorrhage, and an epidural hemomatoma, treated conservatively with conservative treatment. The patient also experiences mild blurred vision, double vision, and occasional headaches for over a week. The patient denies any history of diabetes, hypertension, pneumonia, tuberculosis, or other infectious diseases. No fever, sickness, surgery, loss of appetite, or weight loss. The patient is a non-smoker and denies any allergies to medications. O: Physical examination reveals visual acuity of 6/5 in the right eye and 17 mmHg in the left eye. Physical examination shows slight hyperaemia in the right eye, no eyelid swelling, exophthalmos, ptosis, visual decrease, and no limitation in extraocular muscle movement. The left eye exhibits eyelid swelling, mild ptosis, exophthalmos, chemosis, and corkscrew hyperaemia centred on the cornea. Abduction and elevation of the left eye are -1, while movement on adduction and depression are normal. The left anterior chamber is slightly shallow. A: The primary diagnosis is a recurrent ocular condition with complications including ocular hyperaemia and hyperaemia in the left eye. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of ocular hyperaemia, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The management plan will include close monitoring of the patient's condition with regular follow-ups to assess treatment efficacy and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. The patient will be educated on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and adherence to follow-up appointments. Referral to a neurologist for further evaluation and management of ocular hyperaemia and a pulmonologist for ocular hyperaemia is recommended. Patient education regarding the nature of the condition, treatment options, and expected outcomes will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient is a 20-year-old male with no known co-morbid conditions, presenting with a three-week history of low-grade fever and weakness in one of his limbs, worsening over time, and for the last five days, feeling out of it. He has had contact with pets recently. O: Physical examination revealed a blood pressure of 125/80, pulse of 95 per minute, respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute, and temperature of 39°C. Neurological examination showed a Glasgow coma scale of 13/15 (E4, M5, V4). Physical examination revealed increased tone in the right lower limb, normal limb bulk, decreased power in the right upper and lower limbs, 1/5 power in the right upper and lower limbs, up-going plantar reflexes, and reactive pupils. Laboratory tests including complete blood count, urea, creatinine, electrolytes, liver function tests, calcium, magnesium, and albumin were within normal limits. Lumbar puncture showed a protein level of 46mg/dl (normal range 20-40mg/dl), glucose of 72mg/dl (60% of plasma glucose), 6 red blood cells, and 5 white blood cells. Blood culture, CSF culture, and PCR tests were negative. MRI of the brain revealed multiple ring-enhancing lesions in the white and grey matter, surrounded by vasogenic edema. AFB smear and MTB DNA tests were negative. C3 and C4 levels were within normal limits. A: The primary diagnosis is a coma of the brain, likely exacerbated by exposure to pets. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of brain abnormalities, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: Plan to closely monitor the patient's condition with regular follow-ups to rule out hypocomplementemia. Consider referral to a neurologist for further evaluation and management. Educate the patient on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and avoiding contact with pets. Consider referral to a neurologist for further evaluation and management.

S: The patient reports two generalized tonic-clonic seizures within one month. The patient has a history of choroid plexus papilloma treated with posterior fossa resection and cadaveric dural patch in 1980, with no family history of brain hemorrhage or cognitive impairment. O: Clinical examination revealed longstanding right arm mild pyramidal weakness and ataxia, and a slightly unsteady gait. Brain MRI showed patchy T2 hyperintensities bilaterally throughout the cerebral white matter, and 5 punctate foci of restricted diffusion at the gray–white matter interface. Electroencephalography indicated intermittent left anterior centrotemporal theta/delta activity, drowsiness, hyperventilation, and occasional sharp slow waves. Follow-up brain MRI showed multifocal abnormal cortical signal and swelling on T2-weighted sequences, particularly in the left frontal region, with leptomeningeal enhancement and recent subarachnoid hemorrhage, and new punctate foci of restricted diffusion. Gradient-recalled T2*-weighted sequences showed left parietal superficial siderosis and peripheral microbleeds. Lumbar puncture showed 680 red blood cells and elevated protein levels at 0.99 g/l. A: The primary diagnosis is primary central nervous system vasculitis, likely secondary to the patient's history of choroid plexus papilloma treated with posterior fossa resection and cadaveric dural patch. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of cerebral hemorrhage or other neurological disorders. P: Initiated treatment with levetiracetam 500 mg daily for 5 days, followed by oral prednisolone 50 mg for 3 months. Initiated treatment with intravenous methylprednisolone 500 mg daily for 5 days, followed by oral prednisolone 50 mg for 3 months. Continued monitoring of neurological status and response to treatment will be necessary. Family education regarding the nature of the condition, treatment options, and potential complications will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient is a 41-year-old white woman, gravida 3, para 0, presenting with symptoms of dizziness, impaired vision, facial edema, and increasing edema in her lower legs since yesterday. She reports a history of gestational hypertension, gestational hypertension, magnesium 40 mg 1-1-1, and progesterone 100 mg 2-0-2 since the onset of this pregnancy. She has been on alpha-methyl-dopa 250 mg 1-2-1, magnesium 40 mg 1-1-1, and progesterone 100 mg 2-0-2 since the onset of this pregnancy. O: The patient's blood pressure is elevated at 175/105 mmHg. She has been on alpha-methyl-dopa 250 mg 1-2-1, magnesium 40 mg 1-1-1, and progesterone 100 mg 2-0-2 since the onset of this pregnancy. She has been on magnesium 40 mg 1-1-1 and progesterone 100 mg 2-0-2 since the onset of this pregnancy. She has a history of gestational hypertension, assisted reproductive technologies, and a second miscarriage, with no pathologies for APS, lupus erythematosus, and thrombophilia. An ultrasound of the genital organs revealed a tumor at the posterior wall of the uterus, likely a fibroma. Follow-up ultrasounds showed two viable embryos. A: The primary diagnosis is a fibroma at the posterior wall of the uterus, likely a fibroma. Differential diagnoses include APS, lupus erythematosus, and thrombophilia, which were ruled out. The prognosis is guarded due to the fibroma and the presence of viable embryos. P: Continue monitoring the patient's pregnancy closely with regular ultrasound examinations to assess the well-being of the embryos. Educate the patient on the importance of medication adherence and reporting any new symptoms immediately. Schedule regular ultrasound examinations to monitor the health of the embryos. Encourage the patient to report any new symptoms immediately.

S: The patient, with a history of urothelial bladder cancer and a former smoker, presents with chest pain during exertion, described as pressure, worsening when active and resolving when resting. The patient denies sweating or palpitations. O: Physical examination revealed inferior wall ischemic changes. Exercise stress test indicated inferior wall ischemic changes. An elective angiogram showed inferior wall ischemic changes. ECG showed sinus rhythm with a right bundle branch block, but no ST segment or T wave changes indicative of ischemia. Lab tests including troponin, lipid profiles, and fasting blood glucose were within normal limits. Coronary angiogram through the right femoral artery revealed anomalous origin of the left circumflex artery and the right coronary artery from a shared ostium, with 80% stenosis in the middle and distal segments, and 70% stenosis in the right posterior descending artery. The left anterior descending artery was found anterior to the shared ostium of the right coronary artery and left circumflex artery. A: The primary diagnosis is coronary artery stenosis secondary to an anomalous origin of the left circumflex artery and the right coronary artery. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of coronary artery stenosis, but these are less likely given the imaging findings and clinical presentation. P: Aborted the procedure to perform a cardiac multidetector computed tomography (MDCT) to further study the anatomy of the coronary arteries. The patient will be monitored for any signs of ischemia or ischemic changes. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess progress and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient is a 75-year-old female with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and atrial fibrillation, presenting with acute, severe, sharp, constant left hip pain for two weeks, worsening, sharp, and constant, radiating to the left thigh. She reports no improvement in her overall clinical status. O: Physical examination revealed external rotation of the left lower extremity, tenderness, and coldness to palpation, and a 3-cm decubitus ulcer around the heel. Laboratory tests showed elevated potassium at 7.2, creatinine at 13.34 mg/dL, blood urea nitrogen at 103, white blood cell counts at 51,200/mcl, platelet count at 585, lactic acid at 7.2, erythrocyte sedimentation rate at 97, and C-reactive protein at 23. Electrocardiogram showed generalized hyperacute T waves. Urine culture for Escherichia coli was positive, and blood cultures showed Gram-positive rods. Left hip arthroscopy identified another source of infection, but no synovial fluid was yielded. Blood cultures were negative for growth. A: The primary diagnosis is septic shock secondary to urinary tract infection with suspected blood culture contamination. Differential diagnoses initially included septic shock secondary to urinary tract infection, which was ruled out based on negative blood cultures. P: The patient was started on vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam for empiric coverage. She has been started on vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam for empiric coverage. She is currently on vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam for empiric coverage. Follow-up in the ICU will continue to monitor her condition and adjust treatment as necessary. The patient is advised to adhere strictly to her medication regimen and follow up appointments to monitor her condition and adjust treatment as necessary.

S: The patient reports experiencing anxiety and depressive symptoms, which began after taking too much acetaminophen in 2012. The symptoms began after taking too much acetaminophen in 2012. The patient has a history of incomplete Broca's aphasia and dysprosody, which affects speech ability. The patient denies any family or personal history of psychiatric diseases, and has a family history of hypertension. O: The patient's medical history includes an ischemic stroke two years prior to the symptoms, resulting in incomplete Broca's aphasia and dysprosody. The patient's family history includes bilingualism in Italian and French, and a work as a writer and translator. Cerebral MRI revealed diffuse white matter high-signal hyper-intensity in the left posteroinferior portion of the frontal lobe, anterior to the motor cortex. A: The primary diagnosis is speech impairment and anxiety and depressive symptoms, likely exacerbated by acetaminophen use. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of speech impairment, but these are less likely given the patient's history and clinical presentation. P: The management plan will include speech therapy, medication, and counseling to address both speech impairment and anxiety and depressive symptoms. The patient will be monitored in the psychiatric unit for progress and adjustments to the treatment plan as necessary. The patient will be educated on the importance of adherence to the treatment plan and the importance of reporting any new symptoms or concerns immediately.

S: The patient, with a history of rheumatic heart disease and an episode of IE three years ago, presented with complaints of low-grade intermittent fever and progressive shortness of breath for the past two months. The patient was a non-smoker, uses intravenous drugs, and was previously unemployed due to health issues. O: Physical examination revealed a low-grade fever of 99 °F, tachycardia with 110 bpm, hypotension at 90/60 mm Hg, mild pallor, and bilateral pitting ankle edema. Chest auscultation revealed a displaced apex beat, pan-systolic murmur radiating to the axilla, bilateral basal crepitation, massive cardiomegaly with interstitial edema, and bilateral mild pleural effusion. Chest X-ray indicated massive cardiomegaly with interstitial edema and bilateral mild pleural effusion. 2D-Echocardiography showed a dilated left ventricle, severe aortic and mitral regurgitation, reduced ejection fraction to 30%, and a deformed calcified mitral valve with large 1417 mm vegetation on the aortic valve, grade 3 mitral and aortic regurgitation. Laboratory tests showed mild anemia and a normal biochemical profile. Over the past two days, the patient developed high-grade fever, neutrophil leukocytosis (15.5109 l1), and markedly elevated C-reactive protein levels (96 mg dl1). A: The primary diagnosis is an infectious etiology of a rheumatic heart disease with complications including aortic and mitral regurgitation, deformed calcified mitral valve, and grade 3 mitral and aortic regurgitation. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of etiology, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: Initiated empirical antimicrobial treatment with Ceftriaxone 2 g IV once daily, Gentamicin 60 mg IV 8 hourly, and Vancomycin 120 mg 8 hourly. Close monitoring of the patient's response to the treatment will

S: The patient reports a recent diagnosis of a left frontal tumor, diagnosed as IDH1-mutated codeleted oligodendroglioma, WHO grade III, with a Ki67 proliferation rate of 25%. The tumor was surgically removed with an en bloc resection, resulting in loss of white matter tissue on the medial/inferior side. O: MRI showed minimal contrast enhancement. Histopathological examination confirmed IDH1-mutated codeleted oligodendroglioma, classified as WHO grade III, with a Ki67 proliferation rate of 25%. PET scan identified 15 ROIs with 9 ROIs in the hot spot (ROI1), five ROIs with medium uptake (ROI2), and one ROI3 with lower MET uptake located in the tumor periphery. Histological analysis showed strong correlation between MET uptake and IDH1, with a r value of 0.85 and a p-value of less than 0.0001. No significant correlation between MET uptake and tumor perfusion or other histological markers was noted. A: The primary diagnosis is IDH1-mutated codeleted oligodendroglioma, WHO grade III, with a Ki67 proliferation rate of 25%. Differential diagnoses could include other types of brain tumors, but histopathology and imaging support the primary diagnosis. P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's progress and recommending further treatments if necessary. The patient is advised to attend all follow-up appointments to ensure the best possible outcome. Further treatment options may be considered based on the patient's response to treatment and response to treatment.

S: The patient, referred to the department of neurology, reports progressive cognitive decline over the past 12 months, including loss of weight, nausea, gait disturbance, and tremor. The patient has a history of dull holocephalic headache diagnosed in May last year, treated with duloxetine. The patient also experiences postural instability and falls when turning around. O: Initial MRI of the brain revealed a tension-type headache and a depressive disorder. Second examination in February 2012 showed bilateral white matter lesions and an old lacunar lesion at the left striatum. Neurocognitive testing in May 2012 showed severe decline in attention, memory, and executive functions, corresponding to subcortical dementia. The patient's weight was reported at 47 kg, with a weight loss of 20 kg over the past year. The patient's gait has been insecure, with postural instability, and falls when turning around. The patient's voice has become quiet, and muscle tone has been mildly elevated with a slight hesitancy, or "Gegenhalten." The patient also experiences mild bradykinesia. A: The primary diagnosis is subcortical dementia, evidenced by the patient's history of vascular encephalopathy and recent weight loss. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of cognitive decline, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and management of the vascular encephalopathy. P: The management plan will include a comprehensive review of the patient's neurological status and potential adjustments to the treatment plan. The patient will be educated on the importance of reporting any significant changes in symptoms and adherence to the treatment plan. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's progress and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Referral to a neurology specialist for further evaluation and management of subcortical dementia is recommended.

S: The patient, who underwent open REYGB six years ago, presents with crampy abdominal pain, intermittent vomiting, and obstipation. The patient denies fever or changes in bowel habits. O: Physical examination revealed abdominal tenderness. Abdominal CT scan revealed a dilatation of the biliopancreatic limb of the REYGB and an intussusception of the small bowel through the jejunojejunostomy. Exploratory laparoscopy was performed to reduce the intussusception and check the viability of the bowel loops. No bowel resection was deemed necessary. A: The primary diagnosis is intussusception of the small bowel through the jejunojejunostomy. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of abdominal pain and inability to pass stool. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the successful surgical resolution of the intussusception and the viability of the bowel loops. P: The patient underwent successful exploratory laparoscopy to reduce the intussusception and assess the viability of the bowel loops. Post-operative care includes monitoring for bowel function and discharge within two days. The patient will be kept under observation and discharged home once normalization is achieved.

S: The patient, with a history of morbid obesity and Roux-en-Y gastric bypass surgery, reports experiencing dyspnea on exertion and intermittent substernal chest pain for the past two months. The symptoms have worsened post-bariatric surgery, affecting the patient's BMI from 100 pounds to 24 pounds. The patient denies any tobacco abuse, excessive alcohol consumption, or drug use. O: Physical examination revealed resting bradycardia with a heart rate of 55 BPM and blood pressure of 89/54, with a BMI of 24, considered normal. EKG showed non-specific ST wave changes. High sensitivity troponin I was within normal limits (0.017). EKG exercise stress test using the Bruce protocol showed a heart rate of 68 at rest, 81 at stage I, and 133 METs at stage III. The patient achieved a target heart rate until stage IV of exercise. A: The primary diagnosis is post-surgical dyspnea secondary to Roux-en-Y gastric bypass surgery. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of post-surgical dyspnea, but these are less likely given the EKG findings and family history of coronary artery disease. The prognosis depends on the progression of the disease and response to treatment. P: The management plan will include referral to a cardiologist for further evaluation and management. The patient will be educated on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and adherence to follow-up appointments. Referral to a cardiologist for further evaluation and management of cardiac issues is recommended. Patient education regarding the importance of follow-up and compliance with the treatment plan will be provided.

S: The patient, with a history of atrial fibrillation, hypertension, dyslipidemia, and benign prostatic hypertrophy, presents with testicular swelling and pain for the past four days. The patient reports persistent back pain and a recent fall at home three weeks ago. The patient has a history of multiple urological procedures for ureterolithiasis and nephrolithiasis, iatrogenic urinary incontinence, and an indwelling Foley catheter insertion. O: Physical examination revealed an abscess on the inner gluteal fold of the perineal region spontaneously draining serosanguinous output, erythematous and indurated left scrotum, mild tenderness to palpation, and no crepitus in the thighs or scrotum. Recent CT scan of the spine revealed a recent L1 vertebral compression fracture with sclerosis and slightly ill-defined margins, lumbar spine compression fractures at T12, L3, and L4, and multiple multilevel degenerative changes in the lumbar spine. The patient has a long-concealed history of atrial fibrillation, hypertension, dyslipidemia, and benign prostatic hypertrophy. A: The primary diagnosis is Fournier's gangrene with associated scrotal wound drainage. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of scrotal wound drainage, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation. P: The management plan includes admission for management of the scrotal wound. Urology and general surgery evaluations will be conducted, with a low suspicion for Fournier's gangrene. Urological procedures for ureterolithiasis and nephrolithiasis are currently under consideration. The patient has undergone multiple urological procedures including bilateral ureteroscopy, stone removal, stricturotomy, and placement of ureteral stents to prevent hydronephrosis progression. Recent CT scans show a recent L1 vertebral compression fracture with sclerosis and slightly ill-defined margins, lumbar spine compression fractures at T12, L3, and L4, and multilevel degenerative changes in the lumbar

S: The patient, with a history of tobacco use, hypertension, transient ischemic attack, and osteoarthritis, presents with a first-time fall due to syncope. He reports no focal neurological deficits, additional heart sounds, or murmurs. O: Physical examination revealed no focal neurological deficits, additional heart sounds, or murmurs. Electrocardiogram showed 2-mm ST elevation in the lateral leads I and aVL and a reciprocal 1-mm ST depression in the inferior leads II, III, and aVF. Initial troponin T level was 0.81 ng/dL, significantly elevated over the reference range of less than 0.03 ng/dL. Coronary angiography indicated non-obstructive coronary artery disease. Left ventriculogram showed an ejection fraction of 30% with poor anteroapical and distal inferior wall hypokinesis. Blood work indicated troponin 0.50 ng/dL, total creatine kinase (329 units/L), and creatine kinase-muscle/brain (CK-MB) 27 ng/mL. Lipid panel showed total cholesterol 140 mg/dL, LDL 60 mg/dL, and HDL 73 mg/dL. Transthoracic echocardiogram confirmed apical ballooning and akinesis, typical of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy. A: The primary diagnosis is Takotsubo cardiomyopathy with complications including apical ballooning and akinesis.
