Differential diagnoses could include other causes of cardiomyopathy, but these are less likely given the elevated troponin and creatine kinase levels. P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition with adjustments in medications as necessary. The patient is advised to manage his risk factors such as tobacco use and hypertension, including smoking cessation. Regular follow-ups with his primary care physician are recommended to discuss the results and further treatments. The patient is advised to manage his risk factors such as smoking cessation and hypertension.

S: The patient reports experiencing chest pain and hoarseness. He has a history of a traffic accident 3 months ago, involving fractures in the femur, radius, ribs, and sternum. He underwent internal fixation of his femur and radius. O: Physical examination was normal. CT scan revealed a ruptured aortic arch with a pseudoaneurysm measuring 20 mm in the posteroinferior aspect of the aortic arch, involving the posterior wall of the innominate artery and the origin of the left common carotid artery, and a 40 mm x 48 mm x 30 mm pseudoaneurysm in the upper mediastinum, with a distance from the junction of the aortic sinus and ascending aorta to the rupture is 7.9 cm. Postoperative thoracic and abdominal CT angiography showed no leak of contrast agent and smooth reconstruction of blood vessels. A: The primary diagnosis is a ruptured aortic arch with a pseudoaneurysm, likely secondary to a traffic accident. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of chest pain and hoarseness, but these are less likely given the imaging and surgical findings. P: The patient underwent a hybrid surgery involving debranching and thoracic endovascular aortic repair (TEVAR) to reduce the risk of cardiopulmonary bypass or cardiac arrest under deep hypothermia. Postoperative follow-up care will include monitoring for any signs of infection or recurrence of symptoms. The patient is advised to reach out with any questions or concerns during recovery.

S: The patient, previously diagnosed with cT3N2M0 stage IIIA luminal-HER2 type breast cancer, underwent preoperative chemotherapy and axillary lymph node dissection in 2013, followed by weekly PTX. Post-mastectomy, the patient received trastuzumab and LHRH-a with tamoxifen, but did not undergo post-mastectomy radiotherapy. Post-surgery, the patient achieved a complete radiological response and non-pathological values for CA15-3 and NCC-ST-439. The patient started the first-line treatment for metastatic breast cancer (MBC) with docetaxel, pertuzumab, and trastuzumab, with a loading dose of 75 mg/m2 of docetaxel on day 1, 840 mg of pertuzumab on day 1, 420 mg on day 1, 8 mg/kg on day 1, and 6 mg/kg on day 1 of trastuzumab. The patient achieved a complete radiological response and non-pathological values for CA15-3 and NCC-ST-439. The patient stopped maintenance therapy in October 2017, and the last follow-up was in August 2018. The patient has survived for 10 months post-termination of anti-HER2 therapy. O: The patient underwent preoperative chemotherapy with epirubicin plus cyclophosphamide, followed by weekly PTX. Post-mastectomy, the patient received trastuzumab and LHRH-a with tamoxifen, followed by irradiation to the chest wall and internal mammary lymph node region, and maintenance therapy with pertuzumab plus trastuzumab for approximately 18 months. The last follow-up was in August 2018, with the patient surviving for 10 months post-termination of anti-HER2 therapy. A: The primary diagnosis is metastatic breast cancer with a history of cT3N2M0 stage IIIA luminal-HER2 type breast cancer. The patient's response to initial chemotherapy and subsequent treatment is consistent with the progression of the disease. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of metastatic breast cancer, but the prognosis depends on the response to the current treatment regimen. P: Continue regular follow-

S: The patient, a newborn born at term from spontaneous delivery, was admitted for ineffective breastfeeding and failure to thrive. The pregnancy was uneventful except for a delayed intrauterine growth restriction detected during the last month. The parent reports normal external genitalia and skin pigmentation except for mild pigmentation of the external genitalia. O: The newborn was born at term with a delayed intrauterine growth restriction detected during the last month. Blood tests revealed severe hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, hypochloremia, metabolic acidosis with increased lactate, and urinary sodium loss. Endocrinological tests indicated low plasmatic aldosterone levels, significantly increased renin, elevated ACTH, and normal plasmatic cortisol. The neonatal screening for 17-OH-progesterone was within normal limits. Cerebral ultrasounds and cerebral MRI were both normal. ECG and chest X-rays were normal. Abdominal MRI showed normal size of the adrenal glands. A: The primary diagnosis is severe hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, hypochloremia, metabolic acidosis with increased lactate, and urinary sodium loss. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of electrolyte imbalances, but these are less likely given the clinical and hormonal findings. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the successful treatment and normalization of clinical and hormonal conditions. P: The management plan includes continued electrolyte replacement, intravenous and oral, and Fludrocortisone therapy (50 g/die) and salt integration. Regular blood tests are necessary to monitor the electrolyte levels. The patient will continue Fludrocortisone therapy as prescribed. The parent is advised to contact healthcare providers if any concerns or questions arise.

S: The patient, with a history of gastric cancer surgery, presented for a gastroscopy due to eating obstruction. The patient reported experiencing nausea, vomiting, severe pain in the chest and lower back, and compression pain in the neck. O: The patient's recent esophagus CT scan was normal. Laboratory analysis showed serum RBC 4.7cell/L, Hgb 138 g/L, HCT 42.8%, and endoscopic jejunal tube placement under the gastroscope. Post-procedure, the patient experienced severe pain in the chest and lower back, severe pain in the chest and lower back, and compression pain in the neck. Emergency CT scan showed extensive subcutaneous emphysema in the chest and back, a large amount of emphysema in the mediastinum, a small amount of left pleural effusion, and no pneumothorax. Postoperative findings included a long strip rupture in the esophagus, 28–34 cm away from the incisors, with blood stasis and hemostatic clip placement. Esophageal angiography showed no contrast agent leakage or exacerbation of emphysema. A: The primary diagnosis is spontaneous esophageal rupture secondary to gastric cancer surgery. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of esophageal obstruction, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation. P: The patient underwent endoscopic jejunal tube placement under the gastroscope and started parenteral nutrition. Postoperative care includes fasting and anti-infection treatment, with esophageal angiography showing no contrast agent leakage or exacerbation of emphysema. The patient is advised to follow postoperative care instructions, including fasting and anti-infection treatment. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor recovery and manage any complications.

S: The patient, a homeless individual, presented with upper extremity swelling and pain in the left arm, treated for cellulitis in the left leg, which was later confirmed as CLL. The patient left against medical advice before further tests could be conducted, despite the patient's lack of insurance or money and living on a road crossing opposite the hospital. O: Physical examination revealed swollen, red, and tender left upper extremity and swollen lower extremity without redness or tenderness. Laboratory findings included a WBC of 256 with 87.5% atypical lymphocytes, hemoglobin of 13.4 g/dl, platelet count of 166 x 109/L, and significant electrolytes at 5.4 meq/L. Peripheral blood smear showed smudge cells and enlarged lymph nodes. Flow cytometry confirmed CLL with monoclonal B cells. Over the course of hospital stay, potassium levels have been as high as 8 meq/L, but the patient remains asymptomatic. A: The primary diagnosis is CLL with monoclonal B cells. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of swelling and tenderness, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. The prognosis is guarded given the stable potassium levels and the patient's asymptomatic nature. P: The management plan includes continued monitoring of the patient's condition with regular follow-ups to assess the progression of the disease and manage any complications. The patient is advised to adhere strictly to the treatment regimen and follow up regularly to monitor for any recurrence or new symptoms. Further consultations with a nephrologist and a cardiologist are recommended to manage the condition effectively.

S: The patient, a 9-year-old female with a history of bilateral glaucoma since 3 years of age, has been prescribed 50 mL of Sholl solution and anti-acidosis capsules three times daily, and eye drops containing a -blocker and carbonic anhydrase inhibitor. She has a history of oligohydramnios during pregnancy and was born prematurely with intrauterine growth retardation. The patient's mother reports no family history of inherited diseases, cataract, or pRTA. O: The patient's weight and height are below the 3rd percentile, and she exhibits intellectual disability. Laboratory tests show sodium at 139 mmol/L, potassium at 3.1 mmol/L, chloride at 110 mmol/L, blood urea nitrogen at 12 mg/dL, and creatinine at 0.9 mg/dL. Blood gas analysis shows a pH of 7.22, HCO3 at 11 mmol/L, and PCO2 at 29 mmHg. Urinalysis shows a pH of 5, no protein, glucose, and normal urinary excretion of amino acids. Urinary 2-microglobulin level is 110 g/L. The patient has pRTA without Fanconi syndrome, thyroid hormones, IGF-I, and IGFBP3 levels. Renal ultrasound at age 9 shows a 9-mm diameter parenchymal stone in the right kidney. Brain MR imaging shows no intracranial calcification. A: The primary diagnosis is pRTA without Fanconi syndrome, with differential diagnoses including other causes of glaucoma and pRTA. The patient's short stature and abnormal thyroid hormone levels are consistent with pRTA. The absence of Fanconi syndrome and the presence of a parenchymal stone in the right kidney are consistent with pRTA. P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition with regular follow-ups and imaging studies to ensure stable health. The patient's condition will be closely monitored, with adjustments to the treatment plan as necessary based on the patient's response to the treatment and any new symptoms. The patient's mother is advised to maintain regular

S: The patient, a known case of viral perimyocarditis treated four months ago, presented with progressive dyspnea, mild exertion, edema in the lower extremities, paresthesia, and pain. The patient reported a history of new onset heart failure with a reduced ventricular ejection fraction four months ago. O: Vital signs include afebrile, tachycardiac with a heart rate of 110s BPM, tachypneic with a respiratory rate of 20s Br/min, pulse oximetry 93% on room air, normal temperature 110/70 mmHg, and oxygen saturation 93% in ambient air. Physical examination revealed jugular venous distention, diffuse bilateral crackles, bilateral pitting lower extremity edema up to the knee, reduced femoral and dorsalis pedis pulses, and jugular venous distention. Laboratory findings include neutrophil-predominant leukocytosis (WBC 19 x 103 mcL), elevated brain natriuretic peptide (2506 pg/mL), troponin-I (0.48 ng/mL), D-dimer (6.6 g/mL), erythrocyte sedimentation rate (110 mm/Hr), and C-reactive protein (12.7 mg/dL). Transthoracic echocardiogram showed severe global hypokinesis, moderate-to-severe systolic dysfunction, paradoxical septal motion, and multiple biventricular pedunculated mobile echodensities (1-2 centimeters in size), and a trace of pericardial effusion. Contrast-enhanced CT study for pulmonary embolism revealed a right lobar pulmonary embolus and bilateral small pleural effusions. Lower extremity computed tomography angiogram showed occlusion of the superficial femoral, popliteal, posterior tibial, peroneal, and anterior tibial arteries. A: The primary diagnosis is pulmonary embolism secondary to viral perimyocarditis. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of

S: The patient reports experiencing vision loss in both eyes for the last 5 days, which began suddenly, accompanied by severe headache on the right side and jaw pain. O: Neuro-Ophthalmological examination revealed alertness and orientedness, with visual acuities indicating no light perception in both eyes, dilated pupils, and no reaction to light. Slit lamp examination revealed punctate cataract. Funduscopic examination revealed diffused swollen optic disc with pallid "chalky white" appearance, atrophy around the optic disc in both eyes, and full extra-ocular motility in both eyes. Laboratory tests showed slightly decreased RBC and Hb levels, normal platelet count, elevated ESR, and CRP levels. Color duplex ultrasonography (CDUS) showed decreased posterior ciliary artery, central retinal artery, and ophthalmic artery in both eyes. CDUS of the bilateral superficial temporal arteries showed inflammation of the vessel wall as a hypo-echoic concentric ring. orbital fat-suppression T1-weighted MRI with contrast showed enhancement of the optic nerve sheath in the left eye, but no inflammatory or mass occupation lesions. MRA results were unremarkable. Right temporal artery biopsy revealed occlusion of the luminal owing to inflammation. A: The primary diagnosis is occlusion of the luminal artery due to inflammation and occlusion in the temporal arteries. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of ocular inflammation, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The management plan will include referral to an ophthalmologist for further evaluation and management of the occlusion of the luminal artery. The patient will be educated on the signs of occlusion and the importance of follow-up appointments to monitor progress and manage any complications. Referral to an ophthalmologist for further evaluation and management of the occlusion of the luminal artery is recommended.

S: The patient is a 44-year-old male with a history of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) treated with induction chemotherapy (IC) on day 0. He reports experiencing bone marrow suppression with fever and septic shock on day 10, followed by recurrent fever and hemiplegia on day 25. He also experienced hemiplegia and hemiconvulsions on the right limb. O: On day 10, the patient experienced bone marrow suppression with fever and septic shock. Peripheral blood cultures from day 10 to day 28 were negative. CT scans of the brain showed a hyperdense lesion with surrounding edema, suspected as cerebral infarction in the right parietal lobe and small hypodense areas in the left and right parietal lobes. MRA of the brain showed no abnormalities. CT scans of the lung showed multiple hyperdense lesions on day 18. A: The primary diagnosis is acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) with complications including bone marrow suppression, fever, and septic shock. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of acute lymphoblastic leukemia, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: Continue current antifungal and antibacterial treatments with voriconazole and imipenem. Schedule follow-up appointments with the healthcare team to monitor for any new symptoms or changes in his condition. Educate the patient on the importance of reporting any new symptoms immediately.

S: The patient reports sudden onset left upper limb dyspraxia and confusion. The patient has a history of hemochromatosis and a distant history of meningococcal meningitis. O: MRI of the brain revealed a large right parietal lesion. CT and PET scans revealed left upper and lower lobe lung lesions, a solitary liver lesion, and a base of skull lesion. Histopathology confirmed BRAF/NRAS wild-type metastatic melanoma. Follow-up MRI brain results showed intracranial recurrence but stable extracranial disease. A redo craniotomy was performed, complicated by a cerebral abscess and ventriculitis. Cultures confirmed corynebacterium acnes. Cardiac MRI confirmed ICI-induced pericarditis with associated pericardial effusion. Cardiac MRI confirmed ICI-induced pericarditis with associated pericardial effusion. A: The primary diagnosis is BRAF/NRAS wild-type metastatic melanoma with complications including intracranial recurrence and stable extracranial disease. Differential diagnosis initially included myocarditis, which was ruled out by imaging and culture results. P: The patient was started on IV Cephalothin for 12 weeks, followed by aggressive diuresis, colchicine 500 mcg daily, and ibuprofen 500 mg three times daily. The patient was monitored with weekly echocardiograms to manage the pericardial effusion. The patient has been discontinued immunotherapy due to the pericardial effusion. A: The primary diagnosis is BRAF/NRAS wild-type metastatic melanoma with complications including intracranial recurrence and ventriculitis. The prognosis is guarded due to the severity of the pericardial effusion. P: Continue monitoring the patient's condition closely with regular echocardiograms to assess for any signs of recurrence or complications. Maintain current immunotherapy regimen and monitor the patient's response to treatment. Educate the patient on the importance of reporting any new symptoms or concerns immediately. Consider referral to a cardiologist for further evaluation

S: The patient is a 69-year-old male with a history of well-controlled hypertension, chronic kidney disease stage III, and a right solitary kidney from a left-sided nephrectomy for atrophic kidney from ureteropelvic junction obstruction. He presents with worsening shortness of breath for the past week, which he has not experienced before. He reports no recent fever, night sweats, cough, hemoptysis, or chest pain. He is currently on atenolol, allopurinol, and atorvastatin. O: Physical examination revealed decreased tactile fremitus and dullness upon percussion with reduced breath sounds on the right side. Chest X-ray indicated a large right-sided pleural effusion. Ultrasound-guided thoracentesis removed 1.5 liters of turbid orange fluid, which was sent for chemical analysis and cytology. The patient improved symptomatically overnight, but returned within a week with recurrent right-sided pleural effusion, bloating, and acute kidney injury. CT scan showed right-sided hydroureteronephrosis extending down to the uretero-vesicular junction and an irregular bladder wall thickening concerning for a primary bladder tumor. A: The primary diagnosis is recurrent right-sided pleural effusion, bloating, and acute kidney injury. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of pleural effusion, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation. The prognosis depends on the cytology results and response to treatment. P: The management plan will include a referral to a nephrologist for further evaluation and management of the pleural effusion. The patient will be educated on the importance of adherence to prescribed medications and follow-up appointments to monitor for any recurrence or complications. Referral to a nephrologist for further evaluation and management of the pleural effusion and a nephrologist for a primary bladder tumor is recommended. Patient education regarding the importance of smoking cessation and the importance of adherence to prescribed medications will be provided.

S: The patient, a gardener, reports a five-hour history of bitten by a snake, which was identified as a Merrem's hump-nosed viper. The patient has been feeling well until now. The patient has no recent substance or alcohol use. O: Physical examination reveals mild swelling and tenderness on the right foot with two fang marks below the right lateral malleolus. The patient's heart rate is 106 bpm, blood pressure is 95/60 mmHg on a supine position, mild postural dizziness, and increased thirst. Blood clotting test (WBCT20) is 20 min, and the INR is 1.05. A: The primary diagnosis is a Merrem's hump-nosed viper bite, complicated by a generalized tonic-clonic seizure, which lasted for 30 minutes. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of swelling and epigastric pain, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation. P: Initiated oral fluids intake of 0.6 L and intravenous infusion of 0.9% saline at a rate of 100 ml/hour, a total of 3 L over 24 hours, and a tetanus toxoid and oral cloxacillin 500 mg every 6 hours. The patient was started on oral fluids and intravenous infusion of 0.9% saline at a rate of 100 ml/hour, with a total of 3 L over 24 hours. A: The primary diagnosis is a Merrem's hump-nosed viper bite, complicated by a generalized tonic-clonic seizure. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of swelling and epigastric pain. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and management of the seizure. P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's seizure and monitoring for any recurrence or complications. The patient will be educated on the signs of seizure recurrence and the importance of compliance with the treatment regimen. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's response to treatment and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient is a 77-year-old ambulatory man with a history of hypertension, sarcoidosis, complete atrioventricular block status post-pacemaker implantation, chronic kidney disease due to FSGS, and right facial nerve paralysis. He reports sporadic gait and right face numbness. He has a history of sarcoidosis diagnosed 14 years ago, treated with a biopsy of a tumor in front of the right tibia, and no immunosuppressive treatment for FSGS. Recently, he experienced sudden dysarthria and left limbs weakness. O: The patient's serum creatinine level was 1.2 mg/dL, and proteinuria was 0.4 g per day. Renal biopsy revealed sclerotic glomeruli and residual glomeruli with segmental sclerosing lesions, diagnosed as primary FSGS. Post-pacemaker implantation, he experienced palpitations and complete atrioventricular block, with no significant stenosis of the coronary arteries. Subsequent symptoms included sudden dysarthria and left limbs weakness. Perfusion CT with iodinated contrast and CT angiography showed no ischemic lesions or occlusion of major cerebral arteries. A transient ischemic attack (TIA) was suspected three hours post-onset. A: The primary diagnosis is primary FSGS with complications including sarcoidosis, complete atrioventricular block, and right facial nerve paralysis. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of numbness and sarcoidosis. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and response to treatment. P: Continue monitoring the patient's symptoms and adjust the treatment plan as necessary based on the patient's response to treatment and imaging findings. Educate the patient on signs of worsening symptoms and encourage immediate reporting of any new symptoms. Schedule follow-up appointments to assess progress and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Ensure compliance with the treatment regimen and follow-up appointments.

S: The patient, a 4-year-old female, presented with a chief complaint of fever and swelling in her right leg. She has a history of Takayasu arteritis diagnosed at age two. She has been resistant to standard therapy with prednisolone and tocilizumab, and no monitoring of plasma concentrations was conducted. O: Initial treatment with IFX was 5 mg/kg, followed by 10 mg/kg on day 10. Initial CRP levels decreased from 8.7 mg/dL to 1.6 mg/dL, but increased again on day 23 to 9.0 mg/dL. Blood IgG levels were lower than the standard, leading to a decrease in immunoglobulin levels. Plasma IFX levels decreased from 23.6 g/mL on day 10 to 2.5 g/mL on day 23. LC-MS/MS with nano-surface and molecular-orientation limited proteolysis measured trough IFX levels. A: The primary diagnosis is Takayasu arteritis, complicated by exacerbated inflammation and necrosis of the right leg. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of inflammation and necrosis, but these are less likely given the clinical course and IFX levels. P: The management plan includes adjusting the dosages and intervals of IFX administrations based on trough IFX levels. The patient will continue to receive IFX biweekly at 8 mg/kg per administration, with a goal of gradually increasing plasma IFX levels and decreasing CRP levels to around 2 mg/dL within 40 days. The patient is advised to reach out with any further concerns or changes in her condition. Regular follow-ups will be scheduled to monitor her condition and adjust treatment as necessary.

S: The patient, with a history of diabetes, hypertension, and kidney disease, presents for renal replacement therapy. He reports a radiocephalic arteriovenous fistula in the left upper extremity. O: During the surgical creation of the fistula in the left wrist, a large cystic formation enmeshed in the radial artery was encountered, with no clear borders between the cyst and artery but a strong local pulse. Surgical intervention involved resection of the cystic segment and preservation of the radial artery, with slight adhesions between the vessel and cyst. Histopathological analysis confirmed a cystic lesion of the arterial wall. A follow-up echo-Doppler 1 year post-surgery showed no signs of artery degeneration. A: The primary diagnosis is a radiocephalic arteriovenous fistula in the left upper extremity for hemodialysis. The successful creation of the fistula and the presence of a cystic lesion in the arterial wall are consistent with the successful surgical approach. P: The patient is currently under continuous monitoring with a multidisciplinary team to monitor the fistula's function and function. The patient is advised to attend all follow-up appointments and report any changes or concerns to the medical team. Further consultations with a vascular surgeon and a hematologist are recommended to manage the fistula and manage any complications.

S: The patient is a 64-year-old woman with a history of right breast cancer treated four years ago with BCS and axillary lymph node dissection, endocrine therapy, and radiation therapy. She reports no recurrence for six years and three months. O: Physical examination revealed a 27  13 mm mass in the outer lower lesion of the right breast, markedly thickened surrounding skin. Mapping biopsies showed no tumor invasion in all five sites 2 cm from the edge of the nodule. A total mastectomy with extensive skin resection (30  22 cm) and a wide skin graft were performed. Pathological diagnosis confirmed angiosarcoma, measuring 45  40  20 mm. Postoperative chemotherapy included weekly paclitaxel at 80 mg/m2 for six cycles. A: The primary diagnosis is angiosarcoma of the right breast, based on biopsy results. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of breast cancer, but these are less likely given the biopsy results. P: The patient underwent a total mastectomy with extensive skin resection and a wide skin graft. Postoperative chemotherapy included weekly paclitaxel at 80 mg/m2 for six cycles. The patient has shown excellent progress with no recurrence for six years and three months. Further consultations with oncology and oncology are recommended to manage her condition and manage her cancer effectively.

S: The patient, a 3-year-old female, presented with asymptomatic proteinuria discovered during a urinary screening test in Japan at age 3. She reports frequent urination and excessive thirst, with a urine output of 3L in one day. She also mentions frequent urination and excessive thirst. She has a history of nephrotic syndrome without systemic edema at age 8 years. O: The patient's urine protein to creatinine ratio (UPCR) was 1.0-1.5 g/gCr. Ultrasonography showed normal echogenicity in both kidneys. Urine protein to creatinine ratio (UPCR) was 11.5 g/gCr, serum albumin was 2.1 g/dL, serum creatinine was 0.97 mg/dL, and eGFR was 46.8 mL/min/1.73m2. Urine specific gravity was 1.008, and urinary beta 2-microglobulin increased to 9,269 g/L. Kidney biopsy indicated segmental or global sclerosis with cellular lesions, swollen, vacuolated, and proliferative glomerular epithelial cells in Bowman's space, partially collapsed glomerular capillaries, occluded by swollen endothelial cells, and karyorrhexis. No neurological manifestations were reported. Brain MRI and electroencephalogram were normal. Developmental milestones included holding the head up at 4 months, sitting at 8 months, pulling up to stand at 9 months, and speaking single words at 1 year. A: The primary diagnosis is segmental or global sclerosis with associated glomerular epithelial lesions and cellular lesions. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of glomerular sclerosis, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and response to treatment. P: Continue monitoring the patient's renal function and renal function closely. Consider referral to a nephrologist for further evaluation and management of glomerular epithelial lesions. Educate the patient on the importance of reporting new symptoms or changes in health. Schedule regular follow-up appointments to monitor renal function

S: The patient is a 3-year-old boy with a history of left-sided pneumonia diagnosed at a regional hospital and started on Ampicillin. He reports worsening respiratory distress, necessitating transfer to the pediatric intensive care unit (PICU). O: During the PICU, the patient developed acute respiratory failure and required endotracheal intubation and invasive ventilation. Chest X-ray revealed an effusion and pneumothorax on the left side, necessitating the placement of two chest drains. Chest CT showed severe necrotizing pneumonia of the left lung with destruction of lung parenchyma and formation of a large abscess cavity in the lower lobe, and consolidation of the right lung. Oxygen saturation was 75-80%, and arterial blood gas pH was 7.28, paO2 = 38 mmHg, and paCO2 = 127 mmHg. A: The primary diagnosis is severe ARDS (PaO2/FiO2 = 38 mmHg, oxygenation index = 52.6), indicating severe ARDS. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of acute respiratory distress, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The management plan includes venovenous extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (VV-ECMO) on day 19 of mechanical ventilation. The initial ECMO settings will be adjusted based on blood flow and RPM. The patient will be monitored closely for any changes in oxygen saturation or respiratory status. Regular follow-ups will be scheduled to assess progress and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient is a 10-year-old right-handed boy presenting with a 3-year history of sudden, spontaneous seizures, characterized by shouting, right eye crossed, drooling, and a seizure lasting 4-5 minutes. The second episode occurred 10 days later, 10 days after starting oxcarbazepine. The seizure frequency has increased from once a month to 4 times a day, even with oral administration of oxcarbazepine. The patient denies any history of perinatal hypoxia, febrile convulsions, brain injury, or family history of epilepsy. O: Physical examination shows stable vital signs, normal neurological examination, and normal blood routine, biochemical tests, infection immunoassay, blood coagulation tests, and urinalysis. Electrocardiogram and chest radiography are normal. Video observation and neurologic interview reveal a fearful facial expression and screaming before the seizure, accompanied by a fearful facial expression and screaming. A: The primary diagnosis is ictal fear, likely exacerbated by a seizure, given the patient's history of seizures and ictal fear. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of seizures, but these are less likely given the patient's history and clinical presentation. P: The management plan will include adjustment of the medication regimen to manage seizures and ictal fear. The patient will be monitored for response to the new medication regimen and potential side effects. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess the effectiveness of the new medication and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. The patient is advised to reach out with any concerns or questions regarding his seizure management.

S: The patient is a 29-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 0, presenting with abdominal pain in the lower part of her abdomen at 32+2 weeks of gestation. She reports a history of threatened premature delivery treated with phloroglucinol and dexamethasone, which led to continuous abdominal distension. She was diagnosed with threatened premature delivery, treated with phloroglucinol and dexamethasone, and was treated with phloroglucinol for tocolysis and dexamethasone for lung maturation. O: Initial ultrasound showed MC triplet gestation with a difference in fetal weight estimates. Umbilical cord was once around the neck. Umbilical artery Doppler and non-stress test showed no unusual symptoms. Ultrasound examination on the fourth day showed two fetuses with a weight estimated for 33 weeks and the other for 32 weeks. Non-stress test indicated slight abnormality. Fetal heartbeats stopped at 4:30 am on the fifth day, indicating fetal distension. The three deceased fetuses were delivered via caesarean section with a weight of 1700, 2100, and 1800 grams. External examination revealed thin and pale fetuses A and C, heavy and red fetuses B, and anaemia in the placenta. Placental villi showed differences in anaemia. A: The primary diagnosis is threatened premature delivery with complications including fetal heartbeats and anaemia in the placenta. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of placental abnormalities, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The management plan includes scheduling a follow-up appointment with the obstetrician to discuss further concerns and monitor recovery. The patient will be educated on signs of complications and advised on the importance of follow-up care. Referral to a fetal obstetrician for further evaluation and management is recommended.

S: Patient 54, a 12-year-old male with a history of cutaneous bleeding and a mild reduction in platelet count, presents with a mild reduction in platelet count at 101  109/L. He reports occasional easy bruising. The patient has a history of a stop-loss variant in the GATA1 gene, c.1240T>C, p.*414Arg+41, causing a loss of the wild type stop codon, leading to the extension of the protein by 41 amino acids. The patient also experiences easy bruising. O: The patient's platelet count is at 101  109/L. A stop-loss variant in the GATA1 gene, c.1240T>C, p.*414Arg+41, causes a loss of the wild type stop codon, leading to the extension of the protein by 41 amino acids. A rare X-linked blood group called Lu(a-b-) phenotype indicates a marked decrease in the expression of Lutheran glycoprotein on the erythrocyte cell surface. Serological analysis using flow cytometry has not been conducted in the patient's case. Giant occasional macrothrombocytes have not been observed in routine histological examination. A: The primary diagnosis is a stop-loss variant in the GATA1 gene, c.1240T>C, p.*414Arg+41, causing a loss of the wild type stop codon, leading to the extension of the protein by 41 amino acids. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of bruising or other hematological abnormalities. The absence of giant macrothrombocytes in the patient's case and the presence of a Lu(a-b-) phenotype suggest a complex genetic disorder. P: Continue regular monitoring of the patient's platelet count and symptoms. Educate the patient and family about the importance of avoiding potential injury or bleeding. Regular follow-ups are necessary to monitor the patient's condition and detect any changes in his condition. Encourage the patient to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately.

S: The patient is a 56-year-old married, retired Caucasian male with a 6-year history of Parkinson's Disease (PD). He reports a history of right-handed tremor and bradykinesia seven years prior to his presentation. He has been treated with various dopaminergic medications, including carbidopa-levodopa, but he developed worsening left-handed tremor and bradykinesia, necessitating restarting treatment with DBS. He also experienced changes in behavior including apathy, poor communication skills in social settings, and uncharacteristic hypersexuality, anger, and impulsivity. He attempted suicide by carbon monoxide poisoning a month prior to his presentation. O: The patient's oxygen saturation was 94%, and his carboxyhemoglobin level was 49.3 (normal less than 2). A: The primary diagnosis is Parkinson's Disease with complications including apathy, poor communication skills in social settings, and uncharacteristic hypersexuality, anger, and impulsivity. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of tremor and bradykinesia, but these are less likely given the current findings. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the ongoing management of Parkinson's Disease. P: Continue monitoring the patient's medication and DBS settings closely. Address any mental health concerns promptly. Educate the patient and family about the importance of reporting any changes in symptoms or behavior to the healthcare team. Schedule follow-up appointments to assess progress and adjust treatment as necessary.

S: The patient, referred to the Child Neuropsychiatry Unit of the Polyclinic Hospital of Bari, reports a history of mucohemorragic diarrhea, tenesmus, and abdominal pain since age 12, exacerbated by frequent bathroom use over the past 10 days. The patient has experienced new symptoms including irritability, decreased sleep, disorganized behavior, and inflated self-esteem. The patient also experiences grossly disorganized behavior, conceptual disorganization, auditory and visual hallucinations, delusion, suspiciousness, hostility, social and emotional withdrawal, and somatic concerns. O: The patient's medical history includes a diagnosis of Ulcerative Colitis, treated with conventional therapies including mesalazine, prednisone, metronidazole, azathioprine, infliximab, and adalimumab. The patient has no history of obstetric complications, neurological or psychiatric diseases, substance abuse, and normal early childhood neurodevelopmental milestones and IQ. The patient's electroencephalogram shows slow waves with isolated spikes in the right temporal and parietal regions. A: The primary diagnosis is Ulcerative Colitis with complications including grossly disorganized behavior, conceptual disorganization, auditory and visual hallucinations, delusion, suspiciousness, hostility, social and emotional withdrawal, and somatic concerns. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of irritability, but these are less likely given the patient's history and current findings. P: Continue monitoring the patient's symptoms and adjust the treatment plan as necessary based on the patient's response to thalidomide. Consider referral to a pediatric neurologist for further evaluation and management of Ulcerative Colitis. Educate the patient on the importance of reporting any new symptoms or changes in symptoms. Schedule regular follow-up appointments to monitor the patient's progress and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: 39-year-old gravida one para zero woman presents with progressive, severe abdominal pain for the past 10 days, moderate vaginal bleeding for a few months, intermittent nausea, and vomiting. She was previously diagnosed with an intrauterine pregnancy with an estimated gestational age of nine weeks and zero days. O: On examination, the patient was tachycardic with a heart rate of 131 bpm and normotensive at 116/84 mmHg. Physical examination revealed tenderness to palpation of the abdomen with rebound and guarding. Laboratory findings included moderate anemia (hemoglobin 9.2 g/dL), leukocytosis (13,200 wBC/m2), and mild elevations in alanine aminotransferase (76 u/L) and aspartate aminotransferase (53 u/L). A limited POCUS identified a 16-week fetus measuring 163 bpm with a heart rate of 163 bpm. Oligohydramnios was noted. A formal ultrasound confirmed a ruptured left tubal ectopic pregnancy. A left-sided salpingo-oophorectomy was performed, requiring four units of packed red blood cells. A: The primary diagnosis is a ruptured left tubal ectopic pregnancy with complications including uterine rupture and a ruptured left tubal ectopic pregnancy. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of abdominal pain and bleeding, but these are less likely given the imaging and lab results. P: The patient underwent a left-sided salpingo-oophorectomy with four units of packed red blood cells. She was discharged on post-operative day two with instructions to seek immediate medical attention if any further pain, bleeding, or other concerning symptoms arise. Further consultations with obstetrics are recommended to monitor recovery and manage any complications.

S: The patient, with a history of Barrett's esophagus and high-grade dysplasia, reports difficulty swallowing and occasional chest pain. O: Endoscopic evaluation revealed a large hiatal hernia and an approximate 3 cm segment of Barrett's esophagus. A focal area of ulceration was removed via EMR. Microscopic evaluation of the specimen revealed focal high-grade dysplasia adjacent to squamous epithelium in the middle portion of the tissue, with cavernous and ectatic venous channels in the deeper aspect of the tissue. Abdominal examination revealed abnormal cell growth in the middle portion of the tissue, irregularities in blood vessels, and minor salivary glands with cystification in the ducts. A: The primary diagnosis is Barrett's esophagus with associated high-grade dysplasia and ulceration. Differential diagnosis initially included invasive carcinoma, which was ruled out based on biopsy results. P: The patient underwent radiofrequency ablation to manage abnormal cell growth and alleviate symptoms. The patient is advised to continue monitoring symptoms and follow up regularly to ensure no further complications arise. Further consultations with oncology and gastroenterology are recommended to manage the condition and prevent further complications.

S: The patient reports experiencing memory loss, gait disorder, and urinary incontinence. The patient denies any history of hypertension, diabetes, or bad personal habits. O: Neurological examination revealed consciousness and response to questions. MMSE score was 16. Strength in extremities showed normal strength with exaggerated deep tendon reflexes. Babinski's signs were positive. Cerebrospinal fluid pressure was below 120 mmH2O, and biochemical analysis was normal. Brain imaging showed ventricular dilation with an Evan index greater than 0.3, periventricular and deep white matter changes. Barthel index of ADL and FAQ scores were 20 and 26, respectively. The patient is suffering from severe dementia, slight gait disturbance, and urinary incontinence. A: The primary diagnosis is CAA, based on the clinical presentation and imaging findings. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of cognitive impairment such as Alzheimer's disease or Parkinson's disease, but these are less likely given the imaging findings and clinical presentation. P: The management plan includes supportive care with daily activities and close monitoring of symptoms. The patient will be educated on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and lifestyle modifications to manage CAA effectively. Referral to a neurologist for further evaluation and management of CAA is recommended. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's progress and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient reports experiencing pain and discomfort, including pleurisy, arthritis, and proteinuria. The patient has a history of Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE), characterized by pleurisy, arthritis, and proteinuria. The patient has been treated for tuberculosis, tuberculosis, and bacterial endocarditis. The patient also has a history of persistent fever and Pp65 antigenemia. O: The patient's test results indicate Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE). The patient's symptoms of pleurisy, arthritis, and proteinuria are consistent with SLE. Lab results indicate positive antinuclear antibodies (ANA), anti-double stranded DNA (anti-dsDNA), anti-Sm, and complement consumption. Purulent pleural fluid and elevated ADA levels were noted. Tuberculosis was treated with ganciclovir, followed by bacterial endocarditis and Pp65 antigenemia. Gallium scintigraphy showed endocardial uptake and transesophageal echocardiogram revealed mitral valve perforation. A: The primary diagnosis is Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE), complicated by bacterial endocarditis and mitral valve perforation. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of pleurisy, arthritis, and proteinuria, but these are less likely given the positive test results. P: The management plan includes referral to a cardiac surgeon for further evaluation and management of the mitral valve injury. The patient will be educated on the importance of adhering to the treatment regimen and adherence to follow-up appointments. Referral to a cardiac surgeon for further evaluation and management of the mitral valve injury is planned.

S: The patient, with a history of gastroesophageal reflux and deep vein thrombosis with pulmonary embolism, presented with a sudden development of a severe headache just before Nissen fundoplication surgery. O: Initial non-contrasted head CT revealed a right-sided caudate intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) with ventricular extension but without hydrocephalus. ICH score was 1, and coagulation labs were within normal limits. On arrival, the patient declined, requiring intubation, and subsequent imaging showed worsening of the ICH with intraventricular hemorrhage and associated hydrocephalus. Glasgow Coma Scale score was 7t, and ICH score increased to 2. Vascular imaging was negative for underlying malformations. A repeat CT head six hours post-EVD placement showed a collapsed ventricle due to cerebrospinal fluid drainage, progression of perihematoma edema, and midline shift. A: The primary diagnosis is right-sided caudate intracerebral hemorrhage with ventricular extension and hydrocephalus, complicated by a collapsed ventricle and perihematoma edema. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of cerebral hemorrhage, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation. P: The patient was placed in the ICU for ICH evacuation, followed by a 5 cm curvilinear right frontal incision behind the hairline, followed by a 4 cm craniotomy. The procedure involved a 5 cm curvilinear right frontal incision followed by a 4 cm craniotomy, identifying the posterior aspect of the right frontal superior sulcus and using stereotactic trans-sulcal introduction of a 75 mm sheath and obturator. The inferior depth of the hematoma was evacuated with gentle irrigation and suction, and a small opening into the right lateral ventricle was identified. A straight rigid endoscope was used for further examination and treatment. The patient will continue to be closely monitored in the ICU and receive appropriate treatment. Further imaging and assessments will be scheduled to assess recovery and manage any complications.

S: The patient, in the late 30s, presents with new proteinuria. He reports a history of SLE with positive anti-nuclear antibodies, anti-Smith antibodies (1:160), anti-double-stranded deoxyribonucleic acid (anti-dsDNA) antibodies (> 1:640), anti-ribonucleoprotein (anti-RNP) antibodies, lupus anticoagulant, immunoglobulin M (IgM) anti-cardiolipin antibodies, hypocomplementemia (C3  40, normal: 90 - 165 mg/dl; C4  8, normal: 10 - 40 mg/dl), rheumatoid factor (50 IU/mL), elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), arthritis, lymphopenia, and thrombocytopenia. O: Recent spot urine protein/creatinine ratio is 1,059 mg/g, normal creatinine at 0.6 mg/dl, negative antibodies of perinuclear (p)-ANCA, cytoplasmic (c)-ANCA, atypical p-ANCA, focal, mild necrotizing crescentic glomerulonephritis, non-specific 1+ linear staining of the glomerular basement membrane, rare 1+ granular mesangial staining for IgG, IgM, kappa, and negative immunoglobulin A (IgA), C3, C1q, and lambda. Renal biopsy revealed focal, mild necrotizing crescentic glomerulonephritis, non-specific 1+ linear staining of the glomerular basement membrane, and rare 1+ granular mesangial staining for IgG, IgM, kappa, but negative immunoglobulin A (IgA), C3, C1q, and lambda. A: The primary diagnosis is pauci-immune focal necrotizing/extracapillary proliferative glomerulonephritis with a secondary diagnosis of class II lupus nephritis. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of glomeruloneph

S: The patient reports transient episodes of amnesia and independent short-duration loss of awareness with oral automatism. The patient has a history of early-stage Alzheimer's Disease (AD) concomitant with temporal lobe epilepsy. O: Brain MRI revealed a cavernous malformation (CM) in the right amygdala. A seven-day scalp video-EEG at the epilepsy center did not capture interictal epileptiform discharges, impaired awareness seizures, or oral automatisms. Neuropsychological examinations showed verbal memory at 79, visual memory at 68, and total memory at 72. Trail making test (TMT)-A took 1 min 27 s, and TMT-B took 3 min 37 s. Intraoperatively, the SE recording from the right parahippocampal area showed frequent epileptiform discharges. A: The primary diagnosis is epileptic amnesia (EA) in the right amygdala, complicated by a cavernous malformation in the right amygdala. Differential diagnoses initially included interictal epileptiform discharges, impaired awareness seizures, or oral automatisms. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the successful removal of the CM. P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's progress and recovery, with appropriate medications and follow-up appointments. The patient will continue to be managed with appropriate medications and follow-up appointments. Further consultations with neurology and a neurologist may be necessary depending on the patient's response to the treatment plan.

S: The patient, previously diagnosed with IPF 5 years ago, reports experiencing respiratory distress during exertion and a dry cough without treatment. O: Physical examination revealed bilateral fine crackles in the lungs. CT scan showed new ground-glass opacity over a broad range of bilateral lung fields. Laboratory tests showed a high level of pertussis toxin antibodies at 147 EU/mL on day 1 of admission, indicating an infection. Post-treatment, the patient's PT level decreased to 52 EU/mL. A: The primary diagnosis is AE-IPF, evidenced by poor blood oxygen concentration and new ground-glass opacity findings. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of respiratory distress, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The patient will be started on long-term oxygen therapy (LTOT) to manage respiratory issues. The patient will be discharged to the home once stable and comfortable with the therapy. Regular follow-ups will be scheduled to monitor the patient's progress and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. The patient is encouraged to reach out with any questions or concerns.

S: The patient is a 70-year-old Caucasian male with a history of long-standing ischemic cardiomyopathy, heart failure, reduced ejection fraction (EF 40% and grade I diastolic dysfunction), chronic kidney disease stage III B, and hypertension. He presents with acute onset non-radiating exertional chest pressure, orthopnea, and shortness of breath. He has been treated for an acute exacerbation of heart failure (New York Heart Association Class III) eight months ago. O: Physical examination revealed 2+ bilateral pitting pedal edema and diffuse crackles on lung auscultation. Initial tests showed elevated N-terminal-pro hormone B-type natriuretic peptide (NT-proBNP) levels (>4000 pg/mL) but low suspicion of acute coronary syndrome (ACS) due to unchanged ECG findings and stable cardiac enzyme levels. Chest x-ray showed signs of pulmonary edema and prominent cardiomegaly. Initial treatment with IV diuresis was successful, but he returned five days post-discharge with chest pain and similar non-radiating chest pressure. A transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) indicated further reduction in LV systolic function with EF 30-35%, with an akinetic apex. A: The primary diagnosis is worsening heart failure with a history of ischemic cardiomyopathy and reduced ejection fraction. Differential diagnoses could include acute coronary syndrome (ACS) or other causes of heart failure, but these are less likely given the elevated NT-proBNP levels and stable cardiac enzyme levels. P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's heart function and adjustment of the treatment plan as necessary. The patient is advised to follow up with outpatient appointments and report any new or worsening symptoms immediately. Further diagnostic workup will be necessary to assess the progression of heart failure and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient reports experiencing shaking head movements for approximately a month, which began shortly after starting hydroxychloroquine for seropositive rheumatoid arthritis in December 2012. The patient denies smoking, alcohol, or illicit drug use and maintains physical fitness by dancing once or twice a week. The patient denies smoking, alcohol, or illicit drug use. Family history is non-compliance. O: Vital signs show blood pressure at 135/72 mmHg, temperature at 97.7 Fahrenheit (38.6 Celsius), and BMI at 41.05 kg/m2. Neurological examination reveals intact cranial nerves 2-12, sensation to pinprick, vibration, and joint position, with reflexes 2+ at all tendons and strength 5/5 in all extremities. Gait is ataxic, choreiform movements affecting head, upper extremities, and lower extremities, dysmetria with finger-to-nose testing, normal heart rate and rhythm, and a holosystolic murmur in the aortic region. Pulmonary, abdominal, and integumentary exams are unremarkable. A: The primary diagnosis is hydroxychloroquine-induced shaking head movements, likely exacerbated by hydroxychloroquine use. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of shaking head movements, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The management plan includes discussing the possibility of a recurrence of shaking head movements with the rheumatologist. The patient is advised to discuss the possibility of a recurrence of shaking head movements with the rheumatologist. Further consultations with a rheumatologist may be necessary if symptoms persist or worsen. The patient is encouraged to reach out with any further concerns or if the shaking head movements persist.

S: The patient, a 79-year-old male, presented with a history of non-ulcerated melanoma on the left cheek in 2014, presenting with a BT of 2.4 mm. He reported a positive SNB, leading to a left neck dissection. He developed paracardiac nodes, adrenal, lung, and multiple large subcutaneous metastatic deposits within months. He was started on IMM-101 as a named-patient program, which stabilized his condition. He was treated with pembrolizumab and achieved a complete response (CR) for 18 months. O: The patient's BT was 2.4 mm, and a positive SNB led to a left neck dissection. Subcutaneous lesions began to shrink within 4 days of the first infusion. A restaging CT scan showed a PR of more than 50% as per RECIST1.1 criteria. A: The primary diagnosis is metastatic melanoma of the left cheek, presenting with a complete response (CR) of 18 months. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of metastatic melanomas, but these are less likely given the patient's history and response to pembrolizumab. P: Continue pembrolizumab therapy as recommended by the medical team. Monitor the patient's condition closely and report any new symptoms or changes in condition. Educate the patient on the importance of adherence to the treatment regimen and follow-up appointments to assess treatment efficacy and manage any side effects.

S: The patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian female with multiple comorbidities including seropositive rheumatoid arthritis, common variable immunodeficiency, hypertension, hypothyroidism, and osteoporosis. She was diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis in 2013 and developed cutaneous vasculitis in May 2015. She initially treated with mycophenolate, hydroxychloroquine, and prednisone, which was tapered off, leading to worsening joint symptoms and synovitis. She switched to methotrexate six months later due to hair loss and inadequate disease control. She started abatacept 10 mg/kg intravenous infusion with concurrent therapy of leflunomide, hydroxychloroquine, and prednisone, which resolved her lesions. At four-month follow-up, she showed a satisfactory response to abatacept, hydroxychloroquine, and prednisone. She is currently on abatacept, hydroxychloroquine, and leflunomide. O: The patient underwent abatacept 10 mg/kg intravenous infusion with concurrent therapy of leflunomide, hydroxychloroquine, and prednisone, which resolved her lesions. She has been on abatacept, hydroxychloroquine, and leflunomide for the past four months. A: The primary diagnosis is cutaneous vasculitis secondary to rheumatoid arthritis with complications including cutaneous vasculitis and cutaneous vasculitis. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of cutaneous vasculitis, but these are less likely given the patient's comorbidities. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the successful response to abatacept, hydroxychloroquine, and prednisone. P: Continue current medications including abatacept, hydroxychloroquine, and leflunomide. Regular follow-up appointments are necessary to monitor the patient's response to therapy and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms or changes in her condition immediately. Further consultations with rheum

S: The patient, previously treated with oseltamivir for fever, mild cough, and nasal discharge, reports worsening respiratory distress, fatigue, low activity, and breathing difficulty. The patient has no history of recurrent bacterial infections or growth failure. O: Physical examination revealed significant respiratory distress and consciousness disturbance (Glasgow Coma Scale, E4V3M4). Vital signs included a body temperature of 38.0°C, blood pressure of 126/77 mmHg, heart rate of 155 beats/min, respiratory rate of 60 breaths/min, and oxygen saturation of 90% at room air. Physical examination revealed reduced right breath sounds, an end-inspiratory crackle in the right upper lung, red, cracked lips, strawberry tongue, trunk, and bilateral feet erythema. Laboratory findings included a WBC of 20,000/L with 95.1% neutrophils, hemoglobin of 14.0 g/dL, platelet count of 22.7  104/L, elevated C-reactive protein at 20.54 mg/dl, procalcitonin at 45.23 ng/mL, LDH at 512 U/L, ferritin at 261 ng/mL, and soluble interleukin-2 receptor (sIL-2R) at 6,176 U/mL. IL-1 was 1.3 pg/mL, IL-6 was 233 pg/mL, IL-10 was 67 mg/mL, and TNF- was 2.6 pg/mL. A: The primary diagnosis is influenza A infection with a significant inflammatory response likely exacerbated by the influenza A infection. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of respiratory distress and respiratory distress, but these are less likely given the elevated inflammatory markers and elevated cytokines. P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition with adjustments in treatment as necessary. The patient will be educated on the importance of adhering to the treatment regimen and attending follow-up appointments to monitor recovery and adjust treatment as necessary. Further consultations with infectious disease specialists and possibly a nephrologist may be necessary depending on the patient's response to the treatment.

S: The patient, diagnosed with Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML) in December 2020, reports experiencing fatigue, weakness, and more frequent sick episodes. The patient recalls feeling tired and weak, and experiencing more frequent sick episodes. The patient has been on an induction therapy regimen of venetoclax and azacitidine, starting with 100 mg daily, 200 mg daily, 400 mg daily, and 75 mg/m2 daily for 7 days. The patient has achieved complete remission (CR) after one course of VA, but progressive disease with 67% blasts in the bone marrow was observed during the second course. The patient has been on a new regimen combining chidamide, venetoclax, and azacitidine for 21 days, and has achieved complete remission after one course. O: The patient's bone marrow examination revealed a hypercellular marrow with 32% myeloid blasts. A molecular panel identified aberrations in the RUNX1 gene, but the karyotype was normal. The patient was started on an induction therapy regimen of venetoclax and azacitidine, which led to complete remission. The patient has been on a new regimen combining chidamide, venetoclax, and azacitidine for 21 days, which achieved complete remission after one course. A: The primary diagnosis is Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML) with complications including progressive disease with 67% blasts in the bone marrow. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of bone marrow cancers, but these are less likely given the clinical and molecular findings. The prognosis is guarded due to the progressive nature of the disease and the absence of severe adverse events during the treatment process. P: Continue monitoring the patient's response to VA and azacitidine. Maintain current regimen of chidamide, venetoclax, and azacitidine. Regular follow-up appointments are scheduled to assess the patient's response to treatment and adjust the regimen as necessary. Educate the patient on the importance of reporting any new symptoms or concerns immediately.

S: The patient, a muscular teenager, presents with persistent abdominal pain, fever, and dark-colored urine for several months. He was previously diagnosed with acute glomerulonephritis and inflammatory bowel disease with anemia of chronic disease, intestinal lymphoma, vasculitis, and leukemia. The patient has a history of infectious colitis and IgA nephropathy. O: Initial CBC showed normal pancytopenia with a white blood cell count of 8.8  109/L, hemoglobin of 110 g/dL, and platelet count of 155  109/L. Laboratory studies indicated anemia and thrombocytopenia. Urinalysis showed too many red blood cells. Abdominal CT showed thickening of the small bowel, cecum, and ascending colon. Initial differential diagnosis included acute glomerulonephritis, inflammatory bowel disease with anemia of chronic disease, intestinal lymphoma, vasculitis, and leukemia. Clostridium difficile was detected in stool. The patient was treated with metronidazole and discharged. During the second presentation, severe abdominal pain, fever, and reappearance of dark-colored urine were noted. The patient's weight is 84th percentile, height is 95th percentile, and BMI is 95th percentile. A: The primary diagnosis is acute glomerulonephritis, inflammatory bowel disease with anemia of chronic disease, intestinal lymphoma, vasculitis, and leukemia. Differential diagnoses include infectious colitis and IgA nephropathy. The patient's symptoms and laboratory findings support the diagnosis of infectious colitis and IgA nephropathy. P: The management plan will include referral to a nephrologist for further evaluation and management. The patient will be educated on the signs of worsening symptoms and advised to report any new symptoms immediately. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's response to treatment and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient, with a history of hypertension, oromandibular dystonia treated with Botox, and recent gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), presents with a chief complaint of numbness in the left chin, approximately the size of a fingertip. The patient reports significant difficulty swallowing solids for three weeks but no liquids. O: Initial upper endoscopy revealed LA Class D esophagitis with ulceration in the distal esophagus, and biopsies indicated inflamed glandular mucosa with at least high-grade dysplasia. CT scan showed a right mandibular angle fracture and coronoid fracture. The patient was discharged on a liquid diet with Augmentin, Peridex, and close follow-up. CT scan showed a right mandibular angle fracture and coronoid fracture. A second upper endoscopy confirmed moderately differentiated esophageal adenocarcinoma of the distal esophagus. PET/CT revealed a large, hypermetabolic distal esophageal mass consistent with esophageal adenocarcinoma. A: The primary diagnosis is Stage IV esophageal cancer of the distal esophagus. Differential diagnosis initially included Barrett's esophagus secondary to GERD, which was ruled out based on imaging and biopsy results. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and response to treatment. P: The management plan will include a liquid diet with Augmentin, Peridex, and close follow-up. The patient will be educated on the nature of the disease, treatment options, and potential side effects. Regular follow-ups will be scheduled to monitor the patient's response to treatment and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Patient education regarding the nature of the disease, treatment options, and expected outcomes will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient reports being diagnosed with squamous cell carcinoma in the left mandible. He underwent neck dissection and resections. He reports gradual relief of trismus and no pain around the TMJ during mandibular function. He has no issues with his bite, such as an open bite from the right mandibular incisor to the right posterior region during mastication. O: Postoperative follow-up radiographs show an anterior dislocation of the left condyle and narrowing of the left posterior interocclusal space. Postoperative radiographs indicate an anterior dislocation of the left condyle and a displacement between the anterior part of the fibula segment and the mandible. The miniplates at the connection between the fibula and the mandible have failed, with widening of the inferior border. A: The primary diagnosis is squamous cell carcinoma in the left mandible, complicated by an anterior dislocation of the left condyle and narrowing of the left posterior interocclusal space. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of trismus and pain, but these are less likely given the imaging and surgical findings. P: The management plan includes scheduling a follow-up appointment to discuss reinforcement and additional fixation options to address the complications and ensure smooth recovery. The patient is advised to reach out with any further concerns or questions during the follow-up.

S: The patient reports worsening chronic lower back pain for the past three weeks and chills for two days. The patient denies any recent fevers, dental treatments, respiratory infections, or gastrointestinal complaints. O: Physical examination shows the patient is not acutely ill. Vital signs include blood pressure 130/93 mmHg, pulse 120 bpm, and auricular temperature 37.5°C. Laboratory findings include a holosystolic heart murmur in the apical region without spinal percussion tenderness or focal neurological deficits. Hemoglobin 11.0 g/dL (normal 14-18 g/dL), normal white blood cell count, elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate 46 mm/h, and C-reactive protein 45 mg/L (normal 45 mg/L). Transthoracic and transesophageal echocardiograms show mitral valve insufficiency based on a prolapse but no vegetation or other signs of infectious endocarditis. Dukes criteria were not met. A: The primary diagnosis is a Gram-positive coccus, Granulicatella adiacens, likely contributing to the patient's Crohn's disease. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of Crohn's disease, but these are less likely given the culture results. P: The patient was started on penicillin 12 * 106 U/24 h and gentamicin 3 mg/kg/24 h intravenously for suspected endocarditis. The dose of penicillin has been reduced to 6 * 106 U/24 h. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms or worsening of current symptoms. Regular follow-ups are scheduled to monitor the patient's condition and adjust treatment as necessary.

S: The patient, previously diagnosed with avascular necrosis in the left hip, panniculitis, diffuse systemic sclerosis, and pulmonary fibrosis, reports recent symptoms of gross hematuria and dysuria. The patient denies experiencing fever, suprapubic or flank pain, or loss of appetite. O: Clinical examination revealed diffuse skin thickening from the underlying disease. Urinalysis showed more than 100 red blood cells and leukocytes/L, but urine culture was negative for organisms. Kidney function was normal. Ultrasonography of the kidney, ureter, and bladder system showed normal kidneys and turbid urine in the urinary bladder. Cystoscopy revealed a white-yellowish plaque in the bladder. Hematoxylin and eosin stain showed sheets of large macrophages with granular eosinophilic cytoplasm and mixed inflammatory cells infiltration. Von Kossa stain showed Michaelis–Gutmann bodies. Latest urinalysis showed 5-10 leukocytes/L and 1-2 red blood cells/L. A: The primary diagnosis is a recurrent infection of the left hip, panniculitis, diffuse systemic sclerosis, and pulmonary fibrosis. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of hematuria and dysuria, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The patient has been started on ciprofloxacin 500 mg orally twice daily for 2 weeks to manage the infection. The prophylactic dose of trimethoprim–sulfamethoxazole and prednisolone and methotrexate is currently in place. The patient has not experienced any hematuria or dysuria post-treatment. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's response to the treatment and adjust the plan as necessary.

S: The patient reports persistent oral Candida infections since age 8 months, which have been recurring since age 8. The patient has a history of a heterozygous de novo T385M missense mutation in the STAT1 gene, a GOF mutation, associated with increased susceptibility to Candida infections. The patient has tried multiple drug treatments including fluconazole, nystatin, ketoconazole, and miconazole, which only provide partial improvement. Recently, the patient presented with severe oral candidiasis, requiring polyvalent IgG mouthwash for 12 days. O: The patient's current medications include fluconazole, nystatin, ketoconazole, and miconazole, which have been ineffective. The patient has been treated with nystatin and ketoconazole, which did not alleviate the symptoms. A: The primary diagnosis is severe oral candidiasis, complicated by a heterozygous de novo T385M missense mutation in the STAT1 gene. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of oral candidiasis, but these are less likely given the patient's history and current symptoms. P: The patient is advised to continue using polyvalent IgG mouthwash for 12 days to manage severe oral candidiasis. Follow-up appointments are necessary to monitor the patient's response to the treatment and adjust the plan as necessary. The patient is encouraged to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately.

S: The patient, previously diagnosed with ulcerative colitis, presented with progressive shortness of breath for 3 days. He denies experiencing fever, abdominal pain, diarrhea, bloody stool, or tenesmus. He has been on mesalazine 2 g per day for 2 years and 8 months. O: Vital signs showed blood pressure 131/79mm Hg, pulse 80 bpm, respiratory rate 28/min, and body temperature 36.0°C. Physical examination revealed coarse breathing sounds with bilateral crackles. Laboratory findings included a white blood cell count of 10,600/L with 79% neutrophils, hemoglobin 9.7 g/dL, platelet count 464,000/L, elevated C-reactive protein (79.7 mg/L), mildly impaired renal function with blood urea nitrogen 21.2 mg/dL, creatinine 1.23 mg/dL, and normal alanine aminotransferase 13. ECG showed normal sinus rhythm and echocardiography with a left ventricular ejection fraction of 77%. Chest radiography indicated increased infiltration with patchy consolidations in both lungs and lower lobe predominance. CT scan showed diffuse peribronchial and subpleural consolidations in bilateral lungs with minimal interstitial thickening. A: The primary diagnosis is community-acquired pneumonia with complications including cryptogenic organizing pneumonia, acute interstitial pneumonia, and metastasis. Differential diagnoses initially included cryptogenic organizing pneumonia, acute interstitial pneumonia, and metastasis. P: The patient was admitted to the chest ward with suspected community-acquired pneumonia, which was managed with antibiotics. The patient was treated with noninvasive ventilator support (bi-level positive airway pressure). The plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition and adjustment of treatment as necessary. Regular follow-ups are essential to monitor the patient's condition and adjust treatment as necessary.

S: The patient, previously diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus over 10 years ago, reports a history of glimepiride and metformin, which he recently discontinued. He reports recent cognitive decline, which has worsened. He has been a frequent visitor to the clinic for exenatide-LAR injections, which have reduced his HbA1c levels to 7.1%. O: The patient's body weight is 41.7 kg with a BMI of 20.1 kg/m2, liver function with an AST of 24 IU/mL, and renal function with creatinine of 0.68 mg/dL. Hemoglobin A1c levels have increased to 10.2% within 6 months. The patient has been on 2 mg of exenatide-LAR once weekly to manage hypoglycemia. Hemoglobin A1c levels have increased to 10.2% after 4 months, and hemoglobin A1c levels have decreased to 7.1%. The patient has been visiting the clinic weekly for exenatide-LAR injections. A: The primary diagnosis is type 2 diabetes mellitus with complications including hypoglycemia and hypoglycemia. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of hypoglycemia, but these are less likely given the patient's history and current clinical presentation. P: The management plan includes discontinuing glimepiride and metformin. The patient will continue with exenatide-LAR injections to manage hypoglycemia and improve blood glucose control. The patient will be educated on the importance of adherence to the treatment regimen and the importance of regular follow-ups. Referral to a nephrologist for ongoing management of type 2 diabetes mellitus and a cardiologist for diabetes management is recommended. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's condition and adjust treatment as necessary.

S: The patient reports feeling down and anxious for the past 3 years, worsening memory and coordination issues. The patient has a history of dementia and a family history of panic disorder. O: Neurologic examination revealed mild cerebellar ataxia. CT scan showed marked calcification in various areas of the brain, including bilateral globus pallidus, caudate nuclei, pulvinar thalami, and dentate nuclei. The patient's father had dementia, and his son has been treated for panic disorder since his teenage years. A: The primary diagnosis is mild cerebellar ataxia, likely related to the patient's family history of dementia and panic disorder. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of cerebellar ataxia, but these are less likely given the imaging findings and family history. P: The management plan will include close monitoring of the patient's mental health and cognitive function. Regular follow-ups will be necessary to adjust the treatment plan as necessary. The patient and family will be educated on the importance of adherence to the treatment plan and regular monitoring of mental health and cognitive function.

S: The patient, a male with a history of right limb weakness for 1 year, reported no other symptoms and generally okay overall condition. He was admitted with a history of right arm and leg weakness for about a year. O: Neuroimaging revealed a noncalcified homogeneously enhancing mass with peripheral signal hyperintensity around the ventricles, edema, and multiple damaged parts. Serum LDH level was elevated at 375 U/L, and CSF protein concentration was high at 625 mg/L. The patient's IELSG score was 4, placing him in the high-risk group. A: The primary diagnosis is a brain tumor with a secondary involvement of deep brain structures. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of brain tumors, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. The prognosis is guarded due to the high-risk nature of the tumor and the patient's condition. P: The treatment plan included starting HD-MTX at 3.5 g/m2, chemotherapy with cytarabine, surgery, and consolidation whole-brain radiotherapy at 40 Gy. Post-treatment, the patient was expected to achieve a partial response (PR) post-treatment, achieving significant reduction in the brain mass. The family was informed about the patient's death 8 months post-diagnosis. The patient's condition was managed with close monitoring and supportive care.

S: The patient, with a history of primary antiphospholipid syndrome diagnosed 2 years ago, underwent an allograft transplant due to end-stage renal failure secondary to hypertension and primary antiphospholipid syndrome. Postoperatively, the patient developed a renal hematoma measuring 13 cm  7 cm, extending up to the right subhepatic area and down into the pelvis, displacing the bladder to the left. Three weeks post-surgery, the patient experienced reduced urine output, progressive abdominal distension, pain, and fever, accompanied by swelling, pain, and decreased urine output. O: Postoperative ultrasonography revealed a renal hematoma measuring 13 cm  7 cm. CT scan showed a homogenous fluid collection posterior to the allograft, extending up to the right subhepatic area and down into the pelvis, displacing the bladder to the left. Serum creatinine and urine output normalized over the next few days. Urethral catheter and ureteric stent were removed, and warfarin was restarted prior to discharge. Ultrasonography revealed a large perigraft collection. Resuscitation and urgent exploration revealed a large urinoma posterior to the kidney, suspected anastomotic leak, necessitating a passive external drain.
