Surgical exploration revealed an allograft vascular pedicle in the inferolateral aspect of the graft and a completely sloughed off allograft ureter. Free flow of urine from the graft was noted, and the ipsilateral native ureter was divided close to the native renal pelvis and approximated to the graft extraperitoneally. A: The primary diagnosis is an allograft transplant due to end-stage renal failure secondary to hypertension and primary antiphospholipid syndrome. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of renal failure, but these are less likely given the imaging and surgical findings. P: The patient underwent surgical exploration and definitive reconstruction of the allograft ureter. Postoperatively, the patient is advised to closely monitor renal function and follow up with the healthcare team regularly. The patient is advised to report any unusual symptoms or changes in urine output immediately. Regular follow-ups with the healthcare team

S: The patient is an 85-year-old woman presenting with pain in her right leg following a minor trauma from falling down while walking. She has a history of right total hip arthroplasty 18 years ago due to rapidly destructive coxopathy and a revision arthroplasty 9 years ago due to loosening of the femoral stem. She has been taking alendronate for over five years. O: Radiographs reveal localized thickening of the lateral femoral cortical bone and a complete transverse fracture with internal spikes and a third bone fragment with similar findings as the atypical femoral fracture identified as a Vancouver type B1 periprosthetic fracture. Radiographs taken five months prior to hospitalization showed cortical bone thinning near the tip of the stable femoral stem and transverse lucency on the outside. Post-surgery, the patient was allowed to do non-weight-bearing exercises. Three months post-surgery, she reported no pain. A: The primary diagnosis is a Vancouver type B1 periprosthetic fracture of the femoral cortical bone, likely causing the fracture. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of femoral fractures, but these are less likely given the radiograph results. P: The management plan includes open reduction and internal fixation using a locking plate with cable grip. Post-surgery, the patient will discontinue alendronate use and prescribe weekly subcutaneous injections of 56.5 g teriparatide and LIPUS. The patient will continue to be allowed to do non-weight-bearing exercises. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor recovery and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. The patient will continue to be monitored for any signs of displacement or loosening of the implants.

S: The patient is a 65-year-old woman with no significant medical history, referred for surgical reconstructive therapy. She reports a peri-implantitis lesion around her mandibular left distal implant. She expresses slight discomfort but no significant medical history. O: The patient underwent open-flap debridement of the infected implant surface with sodium bicarbonate air powder abrasion. During the procedure, rapid onset swelling was noted on the left cheek and in the periorbital space. Intraoral examination showed no swelling or crepitus in the mandibular region, but air was entrapped into the upper and middle loose spaces of the face. Intraoral examination showed no swelling or crepitus in the mandibular region. A: The primary diagnosis is a peri-implantitis lesion around the mandibular left distal implant. The patient's history of rapid onset swelling and periorbital ptosis suggest a complex surgical process. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of peri-implantitis, but these are less likely given the patient's history and imaging results. P: The management plan includes surgical reconstructive therapy to address the peri-implantitis lesion around the implant. The patient will be monitored for any signs of recurrence or complications. She will be educated on signs of infection and advised to report any new symptoms immediately. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess the effectiveness of the treatment and adjust the plan as necessary.

S: The patient, the youngest sibling of the two patients, reports experiencing anxiety and stomach issues. The patient has a history of generalized anxiety disorder and gastritis, and a family history of an offspring with cleft lip. O: Genetic screening will be conducted to confirm the presence of a specific CDH1 gene mutation in the patient's siblings. Initial CT scan of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis and EGD biopsy will be performed. The patient will undergo a prophylactic total gastrectomy with Roux-en-Y esophagojejunostomy and j-tube placement. Post-operative recovery will be post-operative day 7, with the patient expected to recover without major complications and be discharged on post-operative day 7. The patient developed symptomatic gallstones during outpatient recovery, and a third time was admitted for elective cholecystectomy. A: The primary diagnosis is a CDH1 gene mutation associated with a high risk of stomach cancer. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of stomach cancer, but these are less likely given the patient's family history. P: The management plan includes a prophylactic total gastrectomy with Roux-en-Y esophagojejunostomy and j-tube placement. The patient will be discharged on post-operative day 7, with abdominal pain and nutrition managed. The prophylactic bilateral mastectomy is recommended due to the increased incidence of lobular breast cancer in women with CDH1 mutations. The patient has been advised to continue regular follow-ups with the clinic to monitor for any signs of disease or complications.

S: The patient, previously diagnosed with prostatic adenocarcinoma in 2015, underwent radical prostatectomy and lymph node dissection two months post-diagnosis. The patient reports no prior knowledge of CLL/SLL. O: The patient's complete blood count showed a white blood cell count of 12.5  109/L, positive for CD20, CD5 (dim), CD23, and BCL2, and negative for CD3, CD10, and cyclin D1. The interfollicular areas were composed of T-lymphocytes expressing CD3, CD5 (bright), CD43, and BCL2. Flow cytometry indicated 26% immunophenotypes: CD20 (+), CD5 (+), CD19 (+), CD22 (+), CD23 (partial +), CD79b (+), CD200 (+) with surface immunoglobulin lambda light chain restriction. Conventional cytogenetic analysis showed a complex karyotype. FISH screen for CLL/SLL showed del(11q) and del(13q), with IGH hypermutation of the variable region. Peripheral blood WBC doubling time was estimated at 6 months, indicating low-stage CLL/SLL. Mutational analysis using next-generation sequencing 51-gene panel for hematologic neoplasms showed mutations in ATM and MDM2. A: The primary diagnosis is CLL/SLL, characterized by the follicular pattern of CLL/SLL. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of hematologic neoplasms, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and immunophenotypic findings. P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition with regular follow-up appointments to assess treatment efficacy and response to treatment. The patient is advised to maintain regular follow-up appointments and report any new symptoms or concerns immediately. Further treatment options may be considered based on the progression of the disease and response to treatment.

S: The patient, a 49-year-old with a history of hepatitis B and C, interferon therapy, diabetes, and hemodialysis for diabetic renal failure, was referred for surgical treatment of two hepatic tumors. He reports a history of a blood transfusion at age 6 during surgery for a traumatic left femoral fracture, hepatitis B and C viral infection at age 30, and interferon therapy at age 33. He has a history of diabetes and started hemodialysis for diabetic renal failure at age 49. O: Physical examination revealed a soft, flat abdomen without ascites, and no liver or spleen palpable in the subcostal area. Laboratory findings included platelet and white blood cell counts of 4.0  104/L and 2000/L, hemoglobin, albumin, and total bilirubin levels of 12.0 g/dL, 3.8 g/dL, and 0.4 mg/dL. Aspartate and alanine aminotransferase, alkaline phosphatase, and gamma-glutamyl transpeptidase concentrations were 27 U/L, 27 U/L, 199 U/L, and 29 U/L, respectively. Prothrombin time was 66.5%, Child–Pugh grade was A, and indocyanine green retention rate was 4.9%. Hepatitis B virus antigen and hepatitis C antibody were positive. Serum alpha-fetoprotein was elevated at 126.0 ng/mL, but protein induced by the vitamin K antagonist was within normal reference limits at 18.0 mAU/mL. Pre-contrast CT scans revealed two hypoattenuating hepatic lesions, measuring less than or equal to 1.0 cm in diameter, located in segments 3 and 7 of the liver. A: The primary diagnosis is two hypoattenuating hepatic lesions in the liver segments 3 and 7 of the liver. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of hepatic lesions, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The management plan includes surgical intervention for the hepatic tumors

S: The patient reports a history of sexual intercourse in the female superior position where the penis bent sharply against the partner's thigh. The patient experienced a 'snap' in the left side of the penis, severe pain, discoloration, and deformation, followed by severe pain, discoloration, and deformation. The penis swelled, and bruising tracked down into the scrotum. The patient has been able to void normally and has no blood in urine. O: Physical examination revealed grossly deformed penis with swelling and deviation to the right. Dipstick urinalysis showed no microscopic hematuria. axial CT scan showed a unilateral 0.8cm x 1.4cm tear in the left lateral tunica albuginea with an adjacent hematoma, causing the penile shaft to deviate to the right side. A: The primary diagnosis is a unilateral 0.8cm x 1.4cm tear in the left lateral tunica albuginea with an adjacent hematoma, causing the penile shaft to deviate to the right side. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of penile swelling and deformity, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The patient will be transferred to the operating room for surgical exploration, evacuation of the hematoma, and repair of the ruptured tunica albuginea using absorbable sutures. Post-operative care will include monitoring for signs of infection or recurrence of the injury. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled in 3 months to assess healing and erection progress.

S: The patient reports a swollen and red right eye, which started during a 10-day trip to South Africa two days after visiting False Bay. The patient has a blank past medical history and was treated with oral azithromycin 500 mg for 3 days and topical dexamethasone/tobramycin eye drops. The symptoms flared up 14 days later when skiing in Switzerland. The patient returned to his home country a few days ago and consulted the eye clinic. O: The patient's symptoms and history suggest a persistent case of conjunctivitis. The patient is advised to continue with the topical dexamethasone/tobramycin eye drops and to follow up for a follow-up appointment. A: The primary diagnosis is persistent conjunctivitis, likely secondary to a recent trip to South Africa. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of conjunctivitis, but these are less likely given the patient's history and current symptoms. P: The management plan includes continuation of the topical dexamethasone/tobramycin eye drops and a different oral medication to address the infection. The patient is advised to follow the instructions on the label and complete the full course of treatment. The patient is advised to return for a follow-up appointment if symptoms worsen or if symptoms do not improve within the timeframe. The patient is encouraged to reach out with any questions or concerns.

S: Proband D reports recurrent jaundice for 8 years and splenomegaly for more than 6 years. He has a history of cholecystectomy and splenectomy for HS complicated with jaundice and cholelithiasis. O: Physical examination revealed cutaneous and icteric sclera and a palpable spleen 60 mm below the costal margin. Laboratory tests showed elevated serum total bilirubin (TBIL) at 73.1 mol/l, direct bilirubin (DBIL) at 7.3 mol/l, hemoglobin at 125 g/l, reticulocytes at 0.334  1012/l, MCV at 85.7 fl, MCH at 28.4 pg, and MCHC at 332 g/l. Spherocytes account for 13.6% of RBCs. Abdominal ultrasonography indicated cholelithiasis. Serum hepatitis B virus surface antigen test was positive, but liver biopsy showed no signs of cirrhosis. A: The primary diagnosis is cholecystectomy complicated with jaundice and cholelithiasis, complicated by HS complicated with jaundice and cholelithiasis. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of splenomegaly, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The management plan includes a similar approach with cholecystectomy and splenectomy to address HS complicated with jaundice and cholelithiasis. The patient will be referred to a hepatologist for further evaluation and management. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor progress and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient is a 53-year-old woman with a history of posterior, stage IIB NSCLC in the left upper lobe, treated with neoadjuvant carboplatin, pemetrexed, and radiotherapy. She reports severe left back pain, left axillary numbness, and paresthesia. O: Physical examination revealed severe left back pain and left axillary numbness and paresthesia. MRI studies showed no direct tumor invasion of the left brachial plexus or subclavian vessels. A posterior approach, image-guided T2 and T3 osteotomy, and transthoracic en bloc resection of the thoracic tumor were recommended. Post-operative care instructions were provided to ensure a smooth recovery. A: The primary diagnosis is posterior, stage IIB NSCLC in the left upper lobe. The patient's symptoms of severe left back pain and left axillary numbness and paresthesia are likely exacerbated by the tumor's attachment and infiltration. P: The management plan includes a posterior approach, image-guided T2 and T3 osteotomy, and transthoracic en bloc resection of the thoracic tumor. Post-operative care instructions will be provided to ensure a smooth recovery. The patient will be educated on the procedure and expected outcomes to ensure understanding and compliance. Follow-up care instructions will be provided post-operatively to ensure a smooth recovery.

S: The patient, a female with no personal history of thyroid disease, presented for a thyroid ultrasound examination. She reports no personal history of thyroid disease. O: The patient's BMI is 33 kg/m2 and other lab results are normal. Bidimensional ultrasonography (DUS 2) with high frequency probes (13 - 15 MHz) identified a highly suspicious micro-focus in the left thyroid lobe with a radial shape, markedly hypoechoic echostructure, and irregular margins measuring 0.3 cm. An ADF test showed clear flow through newly formed tortuous vessels at the periphery of the specific micro-focus. Fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) was performed under ultrasound guidance. Histological examination post-surgery showed proliferation of well-differentiated epithelial cells forming a papillary structure, surrounded by blood vessels with irregular borders, and infiltrating the thyroid parenchyma, with no relation to the thyroid capsule and no vascular or lymphatic invasion. Final TNM 8th eds. staging is pT1, pN0. A: The primary diagnosis is papillary thyroid carcinoma, based on histological findings and histological findings. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of thyroid cancer, but these are less likely given the imaging and histological findings. P: The patient underwent a Total Extracapsular Thyroidectomy (TT) procedure, which was performed under ultrasound guidance. The patient will undergo close monitoring and follow-up care to monitor for any recurrence or complications. Education regarding the nature of the tumor and its prognosis will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient presented with colic pain in the lower left abdomen, with no fever or hematuria. The patient has a history of bilateral hysteroscopic fallopian tube embolization in 2009 for interventional birth control, presenting with a small amount of clear vaginal discharge starting 3-5 days before her period and ending on the last day of her period. O: Emergency CT scan revealed a thick-walled cystic mass, approximately 2.1 x 1.5 cm in size, in the region of the left adnexa, with a dilated left ureter and severe hydronephrosis on the left kidney with a very thin cortex. Gynecologic ultrasound and hysteroscopy were normal. CT retrograde ureterogram indicated a uretero-fallopian fistula with extravasation of contrast media into the uterus, confirming the presence of a uretero-fallopian fistula. A: The primary diagnosis is a uretero-fallopian fistula in the left kidney, likely secondary to a bilateral hysteroscopic fallopian tube embolization in 2009. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of uretero-fallopian fistulas, but imaging and hysteroscopy confirmed the presence of a uretero-fallopian fistula. P: The patient underwent a left nephrectomy to remove the proximal ureter and the distal part of the left ureter. Postoperative recovery was uneventful, and no vaginal discharge was observed. The patient will continue to be monitored for any signs of infection or recurrence of symptoms. Further consultations with a urology specialist and a gynecologist are recommended to manage the uretero-fallopian fistula.

S: The patient, previously diagnosed with SLE three years ago, reports skin lesions, alopecia, ANA positive, anti-Sm, anti-dsDNA, and complement consumption. Recently, the patient experienced a fever, mental disorientation, and hallucinations. The patient has been empirically treated with antibiotics, but a screening for CMV infection was positive but had low pp65 antigenemia. O: The patient's recent admission revealed lupus nephritis with nephrotic range proteinuria, dysmorphic hematuria, and a positive direct Coombs test. The patient was empirically treated with endovenous corticosteroids and cyclophosphamide. The patient has been feeling much better since the last admission, with symptoms of fever, disorientation, and hallucinations resolved. A: The primary diagnosis is lupus nephritis with complications including nephrotic range proteinuria, dysmorphic hematuria, and a positive direct Coombs test. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of lupus nephritis, but these are less likely given the low pp65 antigenemia. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the improvement in symptoms and the low pp65 antigenemia levels. P: Continue monitoring the patient's symptoms closely. Regular follow-ups are necessary to monitor the progression of lupus nephritis and detect any recurrence. Educate the patient on the importance of reporting any new symptoms or changes in symptoms. Encourage the patient to report any new symptoms immediately.

S: The patient is a 48-year-old male presenting with intraventricular hemorrhage, presenting with severe headaches, dizziness, vomiting, and weakness and disorientation. He reports feeling better overall following a combined STA-MCA bypass and EDAS surgery. O: The patient underwent a combined STA-MCA bypass and EDAS surgery. Post-surgery, the patient experienced less frequent headaches and dizziness and no vomiting. Follow-up DSA showed almost occluded direct bypass but satisfactory revascularization at a Matsushima level 3, with abundant dural neoangiogenesis. CTP indicated improved perfusion at the temporal region. A: The primary diagnosis is intraventricular hemorrhage with complications including severe headaches, dizziness, and vomiting. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of intraventricular hemorrhage, but these are less likely given the imaging and surgical findings. P: The patient is advised to follow post-surgery care instructions, including medication as prescribed, regular follow-up appointments, and a healthy lifestyle to support recovery. The patient is advised to report any changes in symptoms or concerns immediately. Further consultations with a cardiologist and a vascular surgeon are recommended to manage the vascular issues and prevent further complications.

S: The patient is a 48-year-old female presenting with recurrent abdominal pain in her back for the last eight months and recurrent jaundice in the last three months. She was previously diagnosed with hepatitis at a district hospital. O: Physical examination revealed slight jaundice at the sclera and skin, but the abdomen was within normal limits. Chest examination showed no remarkable findings. Laboratory tests showed elevated blood sugar levels, normal serum amylase, renal function tests, and Liver Function Tests (LFT's). Chest X-Ray and ECG were normal. Radiogram indicated opacities and dilatation in the biliary tract and pancreatic duct, and MRCP indicated a radiolucent stone in the distal of the common bile duct and pancreatic duct. A: The primary diagnosis is obstructive jaundice with chronic pancreatitis, evidenced by the radiolucent stone in the distal of the common bile duct and pancreatic duct. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of obstructive jaundice and pancreatitis, but these are less likely given the imaging and laboratory findings. P: The management plan will include medication, lifestyle changes, or surgery to remove the stone and improve symptoms. The patient will be closely monitored for any changes in her condition and will be educated on the importance of reporting any new symptoms or concerns. Further consultations with a hepatologist and a hepatologist may be necessary depending on her response to treatment.

S: The patient reports intermittent fever and joint pain. The patient has a history of B-lymphoblastic lymphoma (BLL) with hypodiploidity. O: Physical examination revealed a white blood cell count of 6,880/L with 2% lymphoblasts, moderate thrombocytopenia, and a platelet count of 6.4 x 104/L. Transaminase levels were normal, but lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) was high at 1315 U/L. Blood coagulation test was slightly abnormal. Bone marrow aspiration showed 56.2% lymphoblasts with immature nuclei, high N/C ratio, and positive PAS staining. Blood cytometry showed positive CD19, CD20, CD22, c-CD79, CD38, CD99, HLA-DR, and weak positivity for CD10. Gene rearrangement was not detected. A: The primary diagnosis is B-lymphoblastic lymphoma (BLL) with hypodiploidity. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of lymphoma, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The patient is scheduled for multidrug chemotherapy followed by high-dose chemotherapy with allo-HSCT. The chemotherapy regimen includes steroid, Vincristine, anthracyclines, and L-asparagenase. Post-induction chemotherapy, the patient achieved complete clinical remission on day 33. During intensification courses, minimal residual disease-polymeric chain reaction (MRD-PCR) targeting IgH was not detected. The patient will be transferred to our hospital for further treatment.

S: The patient is an 8.2-year-old boy with a history of partial secondary generalized epilepsy with atypical absences. He reports difficulty focusing, inability to stay still for long, difficulty learning, and understanding. He also experiences strange episodes where he zones out and does not remember anything. O: Physical examinations were normal, but he has moderate mental retardation with language delay. EEG showed abnormal discharges of slow waves and spikes, and bi-temporally localized waves. MRI showed cortico-subcortical atrophy and corpus callosum hypoplasia. Genetic studies revealed a 116-base deletion in the EN2 gene and abnormalities in the transcription of the gene. High definition karyotype and metabolic panel were normal. Genetic studies indicated a 116-base deletion in the EN2 gene and abnormalities in the transcription of the gene. No alterations in LIS1, PTAFR, PAFAH1B2, PAFAH1B3, FGF8, or PAX2 genes were found. A: The primary diagnosis is mild mental retardation with language delay and epilepsy. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of epilepsy, but these are less likely given the genetic findings. The prognosis is guarded due to the genetic findings and the presence of a 116-base deletion in the EN2 gene. P: The patient is advised to continue taking valproic acid as prescribed and attend regular follow-up appointments to monitor his condition and adjust treatment as necessary. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms or worsening of his condition immediately. Further genetic counseling may be considered if new symptoms or worsening of his condition occur.

S: The patient, a lifelong non-smoker with no family history of skin lesions or cancer, presents with a painful right foot fifth digit wound, first noticed 2 months ago. The lesion was initially diagnosed as a diabetic foot ulcer, which has not fully healed. The patient reports minimal improvement with local wound care, but the lesion has developed into two painful papules. The patient has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, asthma, and dementia. The patient denies any family history of skin lesions or cancer. O: The patient's last recorded hemoglobin A1c test was 6.1%. Clinical examination revealed palpable pedal pulses with triphasic flow to the bilateral dorsalis pedis artery and posterior tibialis artery, right hallux toe pressure of 126 mmHg and left hallux toe pressure of 184 mmHg, diminished protective sensation (2 out of 4 sites bilaterally) with a 10-g 5.07 Semmes-Weinstein monofilament. A: The primary diagnosis is a painful right foot fifth digit wound with complications including a granulomatous mass on the medial aspect of the right fifth digit. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of granulomatous mass, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. The prognosis depends on the management of the granulomatous mass and the progression of the wound. P: Continue regular monthly follow-ups at the wound center to monitor the patient's condition and manage any complications. Educate the patient on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and adhering to follow-up schedules. Consider referral to a nephrologist for further evaluation and management of the granulomatous mass. Ensure the patient understands the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and adhering to follow-up schedules.

S: The patient reports experiencing nausea, vomiting, and a significant amount of pain in the chest and stomach for the past few weeks following an atrial fibrillation catheter ablation. The pain improves with sitting. The patient has a history of an inflammatory syndrome with CRP levels from 57 mg/L to 441 mg/L in 48 hours. O: Recent lab tests revealed an inflammatory syndrome with CRP levels from 57 mg/L to 441 mg/L in 48 hours. Chest CT angiography revealed a massive hydropneumopericardium with white arrows. Gastroscopy identified a transparietal ulcer with purulent content on the anterior face of the esophagus approximately 30 centimeters below dental arches, and an ulcer just in front of the posterior wall of the left atrial appendage. A: The primary diagnosis is Oesophageal-pericardial fistula (OPF) secondary to atrial fibrillation catheter ablation. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of acute chest pain, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The management plan includes surgical pericardial drainage and esophageal stenting to cover the ulcer. The treatment will involve minimally invasive techniques, including surgical pericardial drainage and esophageal stenting. The patient will be educated on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and adherence to the treatment plan. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor progress and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient, a male with a family history of cardiac disease and liver cirrhosis, presented with decreased renal function. He reported a history of renal insufficiency with a serum creatinine level of 1.15 mg/dL three years ago, elevated to 1.31 mg/dL last year, and urine protein of 2.0 g/gCr last year. He has been treated with valsartan, which has worsened his condition. O: On admission, the patient's blood pressure was 110/60 mmHg, pulse rate was 84/min, and body temperature was 36.2°C. Recent urinalysis showed 2+ proteinuria, 2+ occult blood, and no glycosuria. Urinary sediment showed no granular or red blood cell casts. Proteinuria was 1.31 g/gCr. Blood examination revealed renal insufficiency with a creatinine level of 1.94 mg/dL and an estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) of 21.0 mL/min/1.73 m2. Immunological data showed mild elevation of immunoglobulin G (IgG) with decreased IgA and IgM levels, and anti-nuclear antibodies were detected. A: The primary diagnosis is renal insufficiency with a history of interstitial fibrosis and tubular atrophy. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of renal insufficiency, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: Continue monitoring renal function and adjust treatment as necessary based on the patient's response to valsartan. Educate the patient on the importance of adherence to the treatment regimen and monitoring for any recurrence of symptoms. Consider referral to a nephrologist for further evaluation and management of renal insufficiency.

S: The patient reports a history of keloid scars on both shoulders from a Bacillus Calmette–Guérin vaccination. The scar on the right shoulder has been swollen and painful for 3 months. The lesion on the right shoulder has been recurrently swollen and has spread to surrounding keloid scar tissue. O: Physical examination reveals a 9  7 cm keloid scar on the right shoulder and a 2  1.5 cm ruptured lesion on the right shoulder. Histopathological examination reveals a large laminated keratin-filled cyst in the dermis, surrounded by a dense collagenous keloid scar. Histopathological examination reveals a large laminated keratin-filled cyst in the dermis with stratified squamous epithelium and granular layer, consistent with an epidermoid cyst (EC). The adjacent dermis contains characteristic broad, eosinophilic, and homogeneous keloidal collagen bundles. A: The primary diagnosis is an epidermoid cyst in the right shoulder, with complications including wound dehiscence and scar widening. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of keloid scars, but histopathological findings and histopathological findings support the diagnosis. P: The management plan includes surgical excisation of the keloid tissue and repair of the wound using subdermal 3-0 PDS and interrupted 5-0 Ethilone sutures. Postoperative care will include removal of stitches 14 days post-surgery and Steri-Strip skin closures for 1 month to prevent wound dehiscence and scar widening. Mepiform and compression garments will be used for 5 months to prevent recurrence of the epidermoid cyst or keloid overgrowth. A 1-year follow-up period will be scheduled to monitor recovery and ensure no recurrences or keloid overgrowth. The patient is advised to reach out with any concerns or questions during recovery.

S: The patient, with a history of esophageal dysmotility, gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), lymphocytic colitis, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), essential hypertension (HTN), hyperlipidemia, neuropathy, and depression, presents with substernal pleuritic chest pain and lightheadedness starting a couple of hours post-outpatient upper and lower endoscopy. The patient denies any known allergies and has a family history of heart disease, stroke, myocardial infarction, and cerebrovascular accident. The patient has been on oxybutynin, omeprazole, amlodipine, bupropion, escitalopram, topiramate, tramadol, and fenofibric acid for various conditions including urinary symptoms, GERD, HTN, depression, neuropathy, pain, and HLD. The patient has had three endoscopies for epigastric abdominal pain, periumbilical abdominal pain, and chronic diarrhea. O: The patient's current medications include oxybutynin, omeprazole, amlodipine, bupropion, escitalopram, topiramate, tramadol, and fenofibric acid. The most recent upper and lower endoscopy took 5 minutes, and the lower endoscopy took 25 minutes. A: The primary diagnosis is GERD with complications including substernal pleuritic chest pain and lightheadedness. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of pleuritic chest pain and lightheadedness, but these are less likely given the patient's history and current symptoms. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and management of the underlying conditions. P: Continue monitoring the patient's condition with regular follow-ups in the emergency room. Educate the patient on the importance of adherence to prescribed medications and follow-up appointments. Consider referral to a gastroenterologist for further evaluation and management of GERD, HTN, depression, neuropathy, pain, and HLD. Consider referral to a gastroenterologist for further evaluation and management of underlying conditions. Ensure compliance with the treatment plan and

S: The patient reports recurrent acute pyelonephritis for the past 4 years, without symptoms of polyuria, polydipsia, muscular cramps, carpopedal spasms, or generalized seizures. The patient denies any symptoms of polyuria, polydipsia, muscular cramps, carpopedal spasms, or generalized seizures. The patient's family history includes two cousins, 56 and 53, with no significant medical history. The patient's only sibling died from renal failure at age 25. O: Physical examination shows the patient's height at 160 cm and weight at 55 kg, with a BMI of 21.48 kg/m2. Laboratory tests show impaired renal function with a SCr of 250 mol/L and an EPI-eGFR of 21.1 ml/min/1.73m2. Hypocalcemia with a calcium level of 1.42 mmol/l, below the normal range of 2.11–2.52. Serum parathyroid hormone levels are normal at 65.59 pg/ml, and 25OH-Vitamin D levels are normal at 26 ng/ml. Serum magnesium is slightly low at 0.60 mmol/l, and 24-hour urinary calcium is 3.9 mmol/1.73m2. Urine acidification function is normal at pH  5.3, and serum bicarbonate level is nearly normal at HCO3 22 mmol/l. Renal ultrasound imaging reveals bilateral nephrocalcinosis and parenchymal renal calculi. Ophthalmologic examination is normal. A: The primary diagnosis is recurrent acute pyelonephritis with impaired renal function and hypocalcemia. Differential diagnoses include distal renal tubular acidosis and renal tubular acidosis, which are ruled out by normal urine acidification function and bicarbonate levels. The patient's family history of renal failure and the presence of nephrocalcinosis and parenchymal renal calculi raise concerns for potential renal involvement. P: The management plan will include close monitoring of calcium, magnesium, and renal function. The patient will be educated on the importance of regular follow-ups to assess treatment efficacy

S: The patient reports experiencing epigastric pain and throat discomfort. The patient has a history of multiple medications including esomeprazole, rebamipide, sitagliptin, candesartan, ezetimibe, mirabegron, levocetirizine, zolpidem, and a lactobacillus preparation for reflux esophagitis, diabetes, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, urticaria, and insomnia, and a flurbiprofen poultice for chronic lumbar pain. The patient has a history of allergies to multiple medications, including antibiotics, treated for H. pylori 2 years ago, which failed eradication. O: Physical examination showed no abdominal abnormalities. Laboratory findings showed elevated total cholesterol at 254 mg/dL, triglyceride at 130 mg/dL, hemoglobin A1c at 7.7%, and immunoglobulin E at 598 IU/mL (normal range 0-170 IU/mL). Gastrin levels were not measured. H. pylori IgG antibody was positive. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy revealed multiple white spots in the gastric fornix, body, and antrum, with small, round, white deposits similar to substances observed in other cases. Biopsied specimens indicated cystic dilation of the gastric fundal gland, approximately 600 m in diameter, with parietal cell protrusions and dilated glands forming microcysts. A: The primary diagnosis is H. pylori infection, likely contributing to the patient's symptoms of epigastric pain and throat discomfort. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of gastric pain and throat discomfort, but these are less likely given the positive H. pylori IgG antibody. P: The management plan will include discussing a treatment plan to address the H. pylori infection and manage other conditions. The patient will be educated on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan to prevent further complications. Referral to a gastroenterologist for further evaluation and management of H. pylori infection is recommended. Patient education regarding the importance of adh

S: The patient is an 80-year-old male with a history of diabetes mellitus type 2, atrial fibrillation, cerebrovascular disease, polymyalgia rheumatica, and osteoporosis. He reports a recent hematoma on his right thigh following a minor trauma. He has a regular prescription of metformin, warfarin, and prednisolone. O: Clinical examination revealed splenomegaly at inspiration. Blood tests showed hemoglobin at 10.3 g/dL (normal 13.4–17.0), platelet count at 2000  109/L, white blood cell count at 23  109/L, and lactate dehydrogenase at 366 U/L (normal 115–255 U/L). Microscopy of the peripheral blood smear showed a leukoerythroblastic picture with nucleated erythrocytes, promyelocytes, and myelocytes, but no blasts. Bone marrow smear showed increased cellularity with increased megakaryocytes and 4% myeloblasts, and BM biopsy confirmed focal bundles of reticulin fibers and proliferation of megakaryocytes with classic atypia and reduced myelopoiesis. Mutational analysis was positive for the JAK2V617F mutation with an allele burden of 0.6%. RT-qPCR detecting most common BCR-ABL1 fusions was negative. A: The primary diagnosis is primary myelofibrosis (PMF), characterized by megakaryocytic proliferation, reticulin fibrosis, and JAK2 mutation. Differential diagnoses could include other myeloid malignancies, but these are less likely given the patient's genetic profile. P: The management plan will include a treatment plan focusing on managing primary myelofibrosis, including medications, blood transfusions, or other therapies as needed. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's condition and adjust treatment as necessary. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms or changes in his condition immediately.

S: The patient reports experiencing headaches and nausea over the past months. The patient denies any comorbidities, surgeries, or medications, alcohol, tobacco, or drug use. There is no family history of similar tumors. O: CT and MRI scans revealed an ill-defined tumor measuring 39  37  29 mm in the anterior-posterior, transverse, and cranial-caudal dimensions. The lesion was slightly hypointense on CT with poor contrast enhancement. MRI showed hyperintensity on FLAIR sequence and T2-weighted imaging, while hypointensity on T1-weighted imaging. No obstructive hydrocephalus was noted in the right cerebellar hemisphere. Neurological examinations showed no sensorimotor deficits, cranial nerve deficits, or abnormal reflex responses. Standing and walking abilities were normal without unstableness. Blood pressure, pulse, temperature, and laboratory findings (complete blood count, liver function, renal function, and C-reactive protein) were within normal limits. A: The primary diagnosis is a benign tumor of the anterior-posterior, transverse, and cranial-caudal dimensions. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of headaches and nausea, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The management plan includes surgical removal of the tumor under general anesthesia with a right-sided suboccipital craniotomy under general anesthesia. Postoperative care will involve monitoring recovery and ensuring positive surgical outcomes. The patient will be kept informed and provided with guidance on follow-up requirements.

S: The patient reports experiencing numbness and tingling sensation in the legs, which has become difficult for walking. The patient has a history of bariatric surgery, a laparoscopic gastric sleeve procedure in January 2017, which was discharged without complications. The patient also mentions experiencing pain, memory impairment, and dizziness, but denies any other symptoms. O: Physical examination reveals the patient is pale, in pain, and dehydrated, with conscious, oriented, and alertness. Hemodynamic stability and afebrile. Motor functions include decreased lower limb tone, slight decreased power, absent reflexes, decreased sensation up to the knees, and decreased sensation up to the upper limbs. Laboratory tests include complete blood count, erythrocyte sedimentation rate, and C-reactive protein. Vitamin B12 and selenium levels are normal, but vitamin D and B1 levels are low. Copper level is normal, but potassium is decreased. Serum protein electrophoresis indicates hypoalbuminemia. A: The primary diagnosis is nutritional deficiencies, particularly vitamin D and B1, contributing to the patient's symptoms. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of numbness and weakness, but these are less likely given the laboratory results and clinical presentation. P: The management plan includes prescribing vitamin D and B1 supplements, monitoring potassium levels, and performing a lumbar puncture to further investigate the patient's symptoms. The patient is advised to report any worsening symptoms or new symptoms immediately. Further consultations with a neurologist and a pulmonologist are recommended to address nutritional deficiencies and improve quality of life.

S: The patient, a young male, reports difficulty holding a cup of coffee and difficulty swallowing during episodes. He has a history of stroke and mini-strokes in his family, including a father who underwent a neck surgery. He has no history of diabetes, blood pressure, or cholesterol issues. He is on aspirin seventy five mg once a day due to a reading on the internet. He lives with his wife and is allergic to penicillin. O: The patient has a history of stroke, mini-strokes, and transient ischemic attacks. He has a family history of stroke. He is currently on aspirin seventy five mg once a day. He is currently working in plastic surgery. He has a history of stroke and mini-strokes in his family. He is currently on a TIA clinic for a stroke referral. He is currently on aspirin seventy five mg once a day. He is currently on a TIA clinic. A: The primary diagnosis is a stroke with complications including TIA and transient ischemic attacks. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of ischemic episodes, but these are less likely given the patient's family history. The prognosis is guarded due to the urgency of the emergency. P: The management plan includes referral to a stroke clinic, a TIA clinic, and a referral to a mini-stroke clinic. The patient will be referred to a TIA clinic if symptoms persist or are prolonged. If a mini-stroke is prolonged, he may need to attend A and E. The patient is advised to contact the hospital if there is a delay or if a mini-stroke is prolonged.

S: The patient is a 14-year-old male presenting with dizziness since yesterday, accompanied by non-bloody, nonbilious, projectile vomiting, abdominal pain, and diarrhea. He reports similar symptoms one and a half months ago following a bicycle fall, which resolved after a while. His parents had a nonconsanguineous marriage and his father suffered a premature cardiovascular death at age 35. O: On examination, the patient was hemodynamically stable. Neurological evaluation was normal without complaints of weakness, positive Babinski sign, or sensory involvement. An anthropometric review revealed an increased arm length more than height. Neurological assessment indicated upper motor neuron facial nerve palsy, evident from right-sided hemiparesis. MRI indicated bilateral cerebellar non-hemorrhagic infarcts. Respiratory distress, pooling of secretions, hoarseness of voice, and deviation of the uvula to the right side with an absent gag reflex were noted. Antinuclear antibody assessment was negative. A: The primary diagnosis is medullary component with ninth and tenth nerve involvement. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of vertigo, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation. P: The patient was moved to the pediatric intensive care unit for further evaluation and management. The management plan includes close monitoring in the pediatric intensive care unit, close monitoring of neurological status, and close monitoring of neurological status. The patient and family will be kept informed of any changes or developments in his condition.

S: The patient reports a 4-day history of high-grade fever, vomiting, and refusal to feed, with a recent onset of irritability. The patient has a history of an oral antibiotic used for 24 hours, which was ineffective. O: On admission, the patient's general condition was irritable but overall good. The patient's body weight was 11 kg, heart rate was 101 beats/min, body temperature was 38 °C, oxygen saturation was 98% in room air, and blood pressure was 90/50 mmHg. Cardiorespiratory and abdominal examinations were normal, and no skin rash was noted. Laboratory tests showed elevated WBC counts at 14,090/mmc with 75.7% neutrophils, and CRP at 5.76 mg/dl. Electrolytes, renal function, and coagulation tests were within normal limits. Lumbar puncture revealed clear cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) with 840 cells/mmc with neutrophilic predominance, glucose at 38 and protein at 44 mg/dl. A: The primary diagnosis is a bacterial infection, likely secondary to an oral antibiotic, given the elevated WBC counts and CRP levels. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of irritability, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The patient was started on ceftriaxone 100 mg/kg/day in a single dose, followed by intravenous antiviral therapy with acyclovir (30 mg/kg/day in 3 doses). The treatment plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition and adjustment of the treatment as necessary. The patient is advised to report any changes in symptoms or concerns immediately.

S: The patient, with a history of hypertension, poorly controlled diabetes, and nephrolithiasis, presents with a chief complaint of right-sided abdominal pain, fevers, nausea, vomiting, and difficulty peeing. O: Vital signs include right-sided abdominal pain, fevers, nausea, vomiting, and difficulty peeing. CBC and serum chemistry panel showed leukocytosis of 13,740/L and creatinine of 1.06 mg/dL. Urinalysis was positive for ketones, proteinuria, urobilin, nitrite, leukocyte esterase, 146 RBC per HPF, over 182 WBC per HPF, and many bacteria. Urine culture was positive for Escherichia coli. CT scan revealed an 8 mm right obstructive proximal ureteral stone and bilateral nonobstructive stones. Intraoperative urine culture confirmed E. coli, and piperacillin-tazobactam was started. Four days post-surgery, the patient underwent uncomplicated URS-LL, involving a rigid cystoscope, flexible grasper, and a flexible ureteroscope. Laser lithotripsy was performed to obliterate the stone into small fragments. Postoperative course was uneventful, and the patient was discharged later that day. A: The primary diagnosis is a right obstructive proximal ureteral stone, complicated by Escherichia coli. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of urinary tract infections, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The patient underwent URS-LL, which was performed using a rigid cystoscope and a flexible grasper. Postoperative care included monitoring for any recurrence of symptoms or complications. The patient is advised to follow up with their primary care physician and report any new symptoms immediately. Further consultations with a nephrologist and a pulmonologist are recommended to manage hypertension and diabetes.

S: The patient, with a history of a left ankle fracture treated with open reduction and internal fixation in 1990, reports chronic pain and a history of total ankle replacement in November 2016. Post-total ankle replacement, the patient developed a wound, which was treated with amoxicillin and clavulanic acid, followed by removal of hardware, placement of a Palacos® cement spacer with vancomycin and tobramycin, and a split-thickness skin graft. Post-procedure, the wound reopened 15 months later, with a plastic surgery clinic performed deep wound debridement, closure with flap advancement, and allograft superficial peroneal nerve reconstruction. Cultures grew Candida auris in moderate amounts after 2 days on Blood and MacConkey agar plates. A: The primary diagnosis is Candida auris infection secondary to a left ankle fracture treated with total ankle replacement. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of chronic pain, but these are less likely given the culture results. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the successful closure of the wound. P: The management plan includes continued monitoring of the wound and potential treatment for Candida auris infection. The patient is advised to continue attending wound care and follow-up appointments as scheduled. Further diagnostic tests will be conducted to confirm the diagnosis and address the infection. Further consultations with a nephrologist and a pulmonologist are recommended to manage the infection.

S: The patient, referred to Sina Hospital for abdominal pain, reports a history of bowel resection 10 years ago for bowel stenosis due to obstruction. O: Abdominal auscultation revealed a bruit. Laboratory tests and a computed tomography scan were normal. Angiography showed a large fistula between the vessels and an aneurysmal superior mesenteric vein. A coil embolization was performed, involving a 7-F guiding catheter and a 5-mm balloon catheter. Final angiography showed successful embolization without visualization of the fistula or aneurysmal vein. A: The primary diagnosis is an arteriovenous fistula in the superior mesenteric vein, complicated by an arteriovenous fistula. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of abdominal pain, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The patient underwent coil embolization to treat the arteriovenous fistula. Post-operative care will include monitoring for any complications and providing additional treatment as needed. The patient will be educated on the importance of follow-up and compliance with the treatment plan.

S: The patient is a 27-year-old male with a history of schizophrenia, currently on clozapine. He reports experiencing painful erythema and tense skin blisters on his upper limbs after exposure to sunlight for a few hours. These blisters eventually formed larger, fluid-filled bullae filled with serous fluid. He was on vacation and did not use sun protection. He also noticed small, red bumps or irritated skin on the axillae and back, likely due to heat exposure. He has no sunburns before starting clozapine. O: The patient's skin issues are related to clozapine and excessive sunlight exposure. Painkillers and supportive treatment are currently administered. A: The primary diagnosis is clozapine-induced skin blisters and miliaria rubra, likely due to heat exposure. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of skin blisters and miliaria rubra, but these are less likely given the patient's history of schizophrenia. P: The management plan includes pain killers and supportive treatment for miliaria rubra. The patient will be monitored for response to treatment and expected recovery in 2 weeks. The patient is advised to use sun protection and avoid excessive sun exposure. Further consultations with a dermatologist and a dermatologist may be necessary depending on the response to treatment.

S: The patient, a male, presented with general fatigue, loss of appetite, jaundice, and yellowish skin and eyes. He reported feeling tired and not having much of an appetite. O: Laboratory tests revealed elevated total bilirubin at 7.7 mg/dL (normal range: 0.6-1.2 mg/dL). Endoscopy revealed a 10-mm tumor in the Vater's papilla. Endoscopic retrograde biliary drainage (ERBD) reduced total bilirubin to 1.9 mg/dL. Endoscopic ultrasonography indicated invasion of the pancreatic parenchyma. CT scan showed a hypovascular mass at Vater's papilla. Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) and carbohydrate antigen 19-9 levels were not elevated (CEA 1.9 ng/ml, CA19-9 31.5 U/ml). Microscopic examination revealed spindle cells constructing sarcomatous tissue proliferated with intricate infiltration and growth of tubular adenocarcinoma. A: The primary diagnosis is a pancreatic adenocarcinoma of Vater's papilla. The patient underwent a subtotal stomach-preserving pancreaticoduodenectomy (SSPPD) with D2 lymph node dissection. Postoperative complications included a postoperative pancreatic fistula (grade B), managed with persistent drainage. P: The patient underwent a subtotal stomach-preserving pancreaticoduodenectomy (SSPPD) with D2 lymph node dissection. Postoperative management included persistent drainage and management of the pancreatic fistula. The patient was discharged on the 30th postoperative day with instructions to monitor for any further evaluations or treatments. The patient is advised to maintain regular follow-up appointments and report any new symptoms or concerns.

S: The patient, with a history of cholecystectomy in 2010, depression, and IBS-D, presents with sharp epigastric pain radiating to the back, nausea, and diarrhea. The patient denies any family history of pancreatitis, alcohol consumption, or smoking. The patient is currently on eluxadoline, bupropion, and oral contraceptive pills. O: Vital signs include blood pressure 123/78 mm Hg, heart rate 110 beats/minute, sinus tachycardia, respiratory rate 18/minute, and oxygen saturation 100% on room air. Physical examination reveals epigastric tenderness but no organomegaly. Previous diagnoses included acute pancreatitis with a lipase level of 1067 U/L, no abnormalities on CT scan, and a reduced dose of eluxadoline 75 mg BID three weeks prior to the first episode of pancreatitis. MRCP showed normal ductal anatomy and absence of stones or tumors. IgG4 level was normal. A: The primary diagnosis is acute pancreatitis with a differential diagnosis of pancreatitis, given the patient's history of cholecystectomy and IBS-D. The differential diagnosis includes other causes of acute pancreatitis, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation. P: Continue monitoring the patient's vital signs and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Educate the patient on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and adherence to the medication regimen. Schedule follow-up appointments to assess the effectiveness of the treatment and adjust as necessary. Ensure compliance with the medication regimen and follow-up appointments.

S: LD is a right-handed 26-year-old male with a history of heroin addiction for about a year. He reports significant health issues post-anoxic coma, including significant inertia, lack of drive, and complete loss of self-activation. He denies spontaneous complaints but admits to a history of depressive symptoms and mild compulsive counting and checking. He also experiences a forelimb dystonic syndrome, predominantly in the left arm, characterized by fist posture, hyperextended toes, preserved motor strength, and brisk reflexes with a bilateral Babinski sign. O: Neurological examination revealed major impairment in speech, aprosodic, hypophonic, and characterized by accelerated articulation, with bilateral hyperreflexia. Psychiatric evaluation indicated low anxiety and a marked flattened affect. Non-significant depressive symptoms and mild compulsive counting and checking were noted. A forelimb dystonic syndrome was noted, predominantly in the left arm, with a fist posture and hyperextended toes, preserved motor strength, but brisk reflexes with a bilateral Babinski sign, dystonia, and an intense akinetic syndrome without rigidity. A: The primary diagnosis is a forelimb dystonic syndrome, likely exacerbated by heroin addiction, given the underlying neurological deficits and psychiatric findings. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of dystonic syndromes, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The management plan includes regular follow-up appointments to monitor the condition and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms or worsening of existing symptoms immediately. Further consultations with neurology and psychiatry may be necessary to address the forelimb dystonic syndrome.

S: The patient, with a history of chronic kidney disease of unknown etiology for 6 years, presented with sudden neurological impairment while walking down the street. He described his mental status as stuporous and unresponsive to external stimuli. O: Vital signs and capillary glucose levels were elevated at 20 mg/dl, increasing to 42 mg/dl after a 50 ml infusion of 50% dextrose. Physical examination revealed somnolentness and paleness with slight oedema in both legs. During an infusion of 20% dextrose, a new episode of symptomatic hypoglycemia was observed, with an infusion rate of 10.416 ml/hr. Blood samples showed abnormal findings. CT axial tomography with double contrast showed no abnormal findings. Treatments included ascending doses of diazoxide up to 600 mg/day, low doses of octreotide, and a suspension of octreotide at 0.4 mcg/kg/h. A: The primary diagnosis is hypoglycemia secondary to chronic kidney disease, complicated by symptomatic hypoglycemia and hypoglycemia. Differential diagnoses could include insulinoma, but imaging and clinical findings support the primary diagnosis. P: Continue monitoring the patient's condition closely with regular follow-ups in the internal medicine department and a nephrology clinic. Educate the patient on signs of hypoglycemia and encourage immediate reporting of any new symptoms or concerns. Encourage the patient to report any new symptoms immediately.

S: The patient, a female in her late seventies, reports feeling unwell and has no significant medical history. She has a history of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) and has undergone a left partial hepatectomy. O: CT scan revealed an isovascular nodule in the left liver lobe. Laboratory data showed mildly elevated CRP at 0.39 mg/dL (normal range: 0.1-1.2 mg/dL), and hemoglobin decreased at 8.9 g/dL (normal range: 0.6-1.2 g/dL). Microscopic examination revealed an unencapsulated, ill-defined, and expansive nodule with solid proliferation of atypical epithelial cells, small-to-medium-sized cells, enlarged hyperchromatic nuclei, and scant cytoplasm, with no intracytoplasmic mucin or prominent fibrous stroma. Immunohistochemistry was positive for CK7, CK8/CK18, and CK19/CD56, but negative for Hepatocyte. A: The primary diagnosis is primary cholangiolocellular carcinoma intermediate type (CHC-INT), based on clinical findings and immunohistochemistry results. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of hepatocellular carcinoma, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The patient underwent a left partial hepatectomy to remove the tumor. Post-operative care will include regular follow-ups every few months for the first year to monitor for any recurrence or new symptoms. The patient is advised to contact healthcare providers if any concerns or symptoms arise.

S: The patient, diagnosed with adenoid cystic carcinoma in the left main bronchus, reports experiencing difficulty breathing and occasional chest pain. O: Bronchoscopy confirmed the extent of the tumor. Bronchoscopy revealed the tumor's submucosal vascularity and margin on the bronchial mucosa. Imaging studies using LCI and WLI showed a clearer view of the tumor's submucosal vascularity and margin. A: The primary diagnosis is adenoid cystic carcinoma in the left main bronchus. The patient's symptoms of difficulty breathing and chest pain are related to the tumor's submucosal vascularity and margin. P: The management plan includes performing a left pneumonectomy to remove the affected lung. Post-operative care will include close monitoring of the patient's recovery and adjustment to breathing with one lung. The surgery is scheduled for tomorrow morning. The patient will be educated on the procedure and expected post-operative care to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient reports vesicular lesions on the right forearm, treated initially with topical steroid therapy and parenteral ceftriaxone, 1 g/day, but deterioration has occurred. The patient has been treated with topical steroid therapy and parenteral ceftriaxone, 1 g/day, but has deteriorated. The patient has a history of a similar case at the Spallanzani Institute, Case 1, where a similar case was reported. O: On admission, the patient's symptoms were noted, including bilateral oedema of the upper extremity up to the shoulders, ulcerated and necrotising skin lesions covered by black eschars. The patient was treated with intravenous meropenem (1 g every 3 h), daptomycin (350 mg every 24 h), and clindamycin (600 mg every 6 h). Cultures of swabs and ulcers were negative, but PCR for B. anthracis DNA from margin eschar fragments was positive. A: The primary diagnosis is vesicular lesions on the right forearm, likely secondary to a similar case at the Spallanzani Institute. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of vesicular lesions, but these are less likely given the patient's history of exposure to anthrax. P: The management plan includes discontinuation of previous antibiotic therapy and starting intravenous ciprofloxacin (400 mg twice/day). The patient will be discharged after two weeks of hospitalization and will be prescribed oral ciprofloxacin (500 mg twice/day) for an additional 7 days. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's response to treatment and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient, a pediatric dentist, presented with a referral for further management of pulp necrosis in the lower right second premolar (tooth 45), secondary to the fractured tubercle of dens evaginatus. The patient reported lingering pain following cold and thermal stimuli, which was diagnosed as irreversible pulpitis and treated with root canal therapy. The patient has a plaque score of 30%, and the upper dental arch is well-aligned. O: General oral examination revealed mild gingivitis with a BPE score of 1 in all sextants. The patient's plaque score is at 30%, indicating room for improvement. An occlusal glass ionomer dressing was found in the access cavity. Cold and electric pulp sensibility testings showed positive responses for all fully erupted premolars, indicating tooth vitality except for tooth 45. The periapical radiograph of tooth 45 showed an immature root with convergent open apex and small periapical radiolucency, and the pulp space is an even width from the coronal to the apical portion. A: The primary diagnosis is pulp necrosis secondary to fractured dens evaginatus and symptomatic apical periodontitis. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of pulp necrosis, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The management plan includes isolation of tooth 45 with a rubber dam after infiltration of local anaesthetic solution containing 2% lidocaine. The patient is advised to maintain regular oral hygiene and report any new symptoms or concerns immediately. Further consultations with a nephrologist and a pulmonologist are recommended to manage the condition and prevent further complications.

S: The patient is a 6.5-year-old girl presenting with painless thickening in her PIP joints for the past two months. She denies fever, trauma, or rash. She has a history of pneumonia and normocytic anemia. She was born with a weight of 3700 g and has a history of pneumonia and normocytic anemia. O: Physical examination reveals symmetric thickening of the DIPs and PIPs in both hands without joint effusion, tenderness, or stress pain. Joints have normal range of motion, no evidence of tenosynovitis, and no muscle wasting. Skin is clear, and no nail changes. Height is 110 cm (10th percentile), and weight is 19 kg (30th percentile). Radiographs show short distal phalanges with bilateral swelling of soft tissue around the DIPs and PIPs. Foot and pelvis radiographs are normal. Spine radiograph shows shortening of the intervertebral spaces D 4–5-6 and D 10–11-12. Laboratory tests show slightly elevated eosinophilia at 2.2 K/microL (normal  0.7 K/microL; 24.2%). CRP and erythrocyte sedimentation rate are normal. Biochemistry, CPK, complement levels, Rheumatic factor, and serum lipid profile are within normal limits. Antinuclear antibody (ANA) was negative. Ophthalmological evaluation showed no evidence of uveitis. A: The primary diagnosis is a recurrent PIP joint infection, likely exacerbated by a history of pneumonia and normocytic anemia. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of joint inflammation and swelling, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: Continue close monitoring of the patient's condition with regular follow-up appointments to assess any changes or progression of symptoms. Educate the patient on the importance of reporting any new symptoms or concerns before the follow-up appointment. Consider referral to a pediatric rheumatologist for further evaluation and management of her condition.

S: The patient, with a history of angina, coronary artery disease (CAD), transient ischemic attack (TIA), hyperlipidemia, and gastric bypass, presents with chest pain. He reports no past issues with general anesthesia using sevoflurane or desflurane. O: Genetic screening identified a variant in the RYR1 gene associated with Malignant Hyperthermia (MH). There are over 400 variants in the RYR1 gene, but only 48 are known to cause MH. The patient is enrolled in the Geisinger MyCode program, which offers whole exome genetic screening. A: The primary diagnosis is Malignant Hyperthermia (MH) with a genetic variant in the RYR1 gene. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of chest pain, but the genetic findings support the diagnosis. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the patient's history of MH and the presence of a genetic variant. P: The management plan includes preparing the anesthesia workstation with a new circuit, CO2 absorbent, charcoal filters, and removal of the vaporizers. The perfusionist will be informed to treat the patient as MH positive and not to add volatile anesthetics to the circuit during CPB. The patient will be treated as an MH positive case during surgery, with precautions including rocuronium and maintaining anesthesia with fentanyl, midazolam, and propofol. A bispectral index monitor will be applied throughout the surgery to monitor the depth of anesthesia. A: The primary diagnosis is Malignant Hyperthermia with a genetic variant in the RYR1 gene. The patient's history of MH and the presence of a genetic variant complicate the management of MH. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the patient's history of MH and the presence of a genetic variant. P: The management plan includes preparing the anesthesia workstation with a new circuit, CO2 absorbent, charcoal filters, and removal of the vaporizers. The patient will be advised to treat as MH positive and not to add volatile anesthetics to the circuit during CPB. Postoperative care will include platelets and cryoprecipitate to manage coagulopathy. The patient will be closely

S: The patient, with a history of hypertension managed with medication, presents with sudden severe right shoulder and flank pain, numbness in the right hand, and no prior subjective symptoms. The patient reports no prior symptoms prior to today. O: The patient was intubated and transferred to the emergency department by air ambulance helicopter 6 hours post-symptom onset. Laboratory findings include a pH of 7.174, partial pressure of carbon dioxide of 62.4 mmHg, partial pressure of oxygen of 94.3 mmHg, and a base deficit of -7.4, with end-expiratory pressure at 10 cm H2O and a fraction of inspired oxygen of 0.5. Chest CT showed infiltration in the right upper lobe, spreading to the right middle and lower lobe, and left hilar area. Peripheral blood was collected for laboratory analysis. Blood cell count, coagulation, and biochemistry were normal except for a slight elevation in serum creatinine level. A: The primary diagnosis is acute respiratory failure secondary to hypertension, complicated by acute respiratory failure. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of acute respiratory failure, but these are less likely given the imaging and laboratory findings. P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition with close monitoring of vital signs and respiratory status. The patient will be educated on the importance of reporting any new symptoms or changes in condition. Regular follow-ups will be scheduled to assess the effectiveness of the treatment and adjust the plan as necessary. Patient education regarding the nature of the condition, treatment expectations, and expected outcomes will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient is a 46-year-old male with a history of obstructive sleep apnea diagnosed 3 years ago. He reports feeling tired due to sleep deprivation. He has refused consent for awake fiberoptic intubation under sedation. O: Airway inspection revealed a short neck with a circumference of 51 cm, limited extension due to thick fat with a Mallampatti score of . Vital signs before anesthesia induction showed Bp 142/79 mmHg, HR 88 bpm, SpO2 96%, and RR 22 bpm. Midazolam 3 mg and sufentanil 10 g intravenously to reach a BIS of 62 for sedation. Subsequent administration of 100 mg of intravenous propofol to maintain SpO2 at 100%. A: The primary diagnosis is obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) with complications including a short neck with a Mallampatti score of . Differential diagnoses could include other causes of obstructive sleep apnea, but these are less likely given the patient's history of OSA. P: The management plan includes gastric volume reduction surgery to reduce body weight under general anesthesia, tracheal intubation with fiberoptic intubation, and a laryngeal mask airway (LMA). The patient will be administered Midazolam 3 mg and sufentanil 10 g intravenously to reach a BIS of 62 for sedation, and 100 mg of intravenous propofol to maintain SpO2 at 100%. Mask pressurized ventilation will be performed to maintain SpO2 at 100%. A WEI Nasal Jet Tube (WNJ) will be placed in case of further difficulties. The patient will be educated on the importance of adherence to the surgical plan and the importance of follow-up.

S: The patient, with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, diabetes mellitus type II, coronary artery disease, and chronic kidney disease stage IV, presents with yellowish discoloration of skin and urine for the past 2 weeks. The patient denies fever, abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, melena, hematochezia, or acholic stools. O: Vital signs include blood pressure 133/60 mmHg, heart rate 75 bpm, respiratory rate 23 breaths per minute, temperature 97.7°F, and oxygen saturation 98% in room air. Laboratory findings include hemoglobin 11 g/dl, white blood cell count 3,800 cell/mm3, platelet count 214,000/mm3, elevated ALT 326 IU/L, direct bilirubin 1.8 mg/dl, ALP 1,219 IU/L, and lipase 250 IU/L. Renal function tests are within normal limits at 1.72 mg/dl. Recent upper and lower endoscopy showed mild antral gastropathy. CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis revealed stable pelvic adenopathy with the largest lymph node measuring 4 cm. A: The primary diagnosis is acute liver injury secondary to elevated liver enzymes and bilirubin levels. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of biliary dilation and biliary distension, but these are less likely given the imaging and laboratory findings. P: The management plan includes further investigation into the cause of the elevated liver enzymes and bilirubin levels, monitoring renal function and other health conditions, and close monitoring of liver function and other health conditions. The patient will be closely monitored in the emergency department with regular follow-ups to assess treatment efficacy and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Referral to a nephrologist for further evaluation and management of liver dysfunction is recommended.

S: The patient reports a significant receding of gums on one of the teeth, which is not very good. O: Clinical examination revealed deep Miller Class III gum recession on the buccal aspect of tooth #2, with the root apex exposed, and degree 3 Muhlemann mobility associated with tooth extrusion. Probing examination revealed pockets of 6 mm on the buccal and palatal mesial aspect and 5 mm on the buccal and palatal distal aspect. Radiographs indicated advanced vertical bone loss on the mesial and distal aspects of the tooth, with an apical lesion and mild root resorption. Thermal pulp tests indicated necrotic pulp, indicating no longer vital. Occlusion and occlusal trauma were noted. A: The primary diagnosis is a periodontal-endodontic lesion in tooth #2. The patient's symptoms and imaging findings support the diagnosis. The prognosis depends on the extent of the disease and the management of the dental issue. P: The management plan includes mechanical therapy, scaling, root planing, antimicrobial drugs, and endodontic treatment. The patient will be prescribed oral hygiene instructions, and a lateral positioned flap will be used to cover the gum recession and augment the keratinized tissue around tooth #2. The corrective phase of the treatment will focus on covering the gum recession, augmenting the keratinized tissue around tooth #2, and correcting the occlusion with orthodontic treatment. The patient is advised to reach out with any questions or concerns during the treatment process.

S: The patient is a 12-year-old male Miniature Pinscher dog presenting with a history of generalized nodules and a ventral umbilical hernia. The nodules were disseminated, worsening over a period of 2 months, with a gradual increase in size. The owner reports no improvement in the condition with oral prednisolone and antibiotics. O: Physical examination revealed no enlargement of peripheral lymph nodes on palpation and no other abnormalities on hematologic or serum biochemical examination. Dermatological examination revealed generalized ulcerative nodules, erosion, erythema, and hyperpigmentation in the dorsum, ventrum, neck, and perianal region. Six mm punch skin biopsies of the nodular lesions showed immunohistopathological findings including neutrophils and phagocytized cocci bacteria, and fine needle aspiration biopsy indicated a cluster of intermediate to large lymphocytes with multinuclear cells, proliferation of numerous round cells, and mitotic figures in the epidermis and dermis. Immunohistochemical staining confirmed CD3 positive round cells, confirming T cell origin. A: The primary diagnosis is CETL, based on histopathological findings and histopathological findings. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of skin lesions, but these are less likely given the histopathological findings and histopathological findings. P: The management plan includes initial treatment with retinoic acid (1.5 mg/kg, PO, once daily; Roaccutane; La Roche Pharma, Basel, Switzerland) and IFN- (2  106 IU/m2, SC, every other day; Roferon-A; La Roche Pharma, Basel, Switzerland). The treatment plan will continue for 2 months, with close monitoring of the dog's condition and adjustments to the treatment plan as necessary. The patient will be educated on the importance of follow-up and compliance with the treatment regimen to prevent further complications.

S: The patient, a female, delivered through cesarean, reports feeling good but is worried about her health. She experienced a presyncopal episode, shortness of breath, and grunting a few days ago, which resolved after a few minutes. O: At delivery, the patient's appearance, pulse, grimace, activity, and respiration were normal. APGAR score was normal at 5 minutes. Echocardiogram revealed a tumor in the right ventricle. Echocardiogram showed a systolic murmur. A subsequent echocardiogram showed cyclic complete obstruction of the right ventricular outflow tract. MRI revealed a mobile and large mass in the right ventricle measuring 13 mm  9 mm, attached to the baso septum and moved to the pulmonary trunk during systole. Pulmonary artery flow measurements indicated pulmonary insufficiency. MRI showed a mobile and large mass in the right ventricle measuring 13 mm  9 mm, attached to the baso septum, and moved to the pulmonary trunk during systole. Global kinetics of the left ventricle were homogeneous compared to a slight dilation in the right ventricle. A: The primary diagnosis is a tumor in the right ventricle, complicated by pulmonary insufficiency and pulmonary insufficiency. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of pulmonary insufficiency, but these are less likely given the imaging findings and imaging findings. P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's heart function and potential treatment options to address the tumor and its effects on heart function. The patient will be educated on signs of worsening heart failure and advised to report any new symptoms immediately. Referral to a pediatric cardiologist for further evaluation and management of the tumor is recommended.

S: The patient, with a history of migraine headaches, presents with a four-month history of constant motion throughout the day and while lying down. The symptoms subside when driving a car or riding a bicycle, but they recur as soon as they stop. The patient has experienced vertigo three years ago, which resolved after positional exercises. The patient denies headaches, nausea, vomiting, tinnitus, or falls related to the imbalance. O: Physical and neurological examinations are normal. MRI, video-nystagmography, oculomotor testing, positional testing, and audiogram are normal. A: The primary diagnosis is Mal de Débarquement syndrome, characterized by a persistent feeling of imbalance, likely secondary to prolonged motion. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of migraine headaches, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The patient is advised to be patient and allow the body time to adjust. Follow-up examinations are scheduled to monitor the patient's response to treatment and adjust as necessary.
