The patient is advised to return for a follow-up examination if symptoms worsen or new symptoms develop.

S: The patient, a newborn girl, was born via elective Cesarean section at 39 weeks, 4 days, with a history of fibular hypoplasia, tibial campomelia, and oligodactyly. The mother reports no history of prenatal complications. O: Physical examination revealed shortening and anterolateral bowing of the left lower limb at the distal third of the tibia, curved lower part of the left leg, and oligosyndactyly of both feet. The baby has only three toes on the left foot and four on the right foot, with absent fourth and fifth rays on the left and fifth ray absent on the right. Hip ultrasound showed no congenital hip dysplasia. Radiographic examination confirmed the hypoplasia of the left fibula, absence of two rays on the left foot and one ray on the right foot, and anterolateral bowing and shortening of the left tibia. Both femora were normal. A: The primary diagnosis is fibular hypoplasia, tibial campomelia, and oligodactyly. The absence of congenital hip dysplasia and the presence of oligosyndactyly suggest a complex etiology. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of fibular hypoplasia and tibial campomelia. P: The management plan includes regular follow-ups to monitor the baby's progress and address any potential complications. The mother is advised to consult with a pediatric neurologist for further evaluation and management of fibular hypoplasia and tibial campomelia. Further consultations with a pediatric neurologist may be necessary depending on the patient's response to treatment.

S: The patient is a 38-year-old woman with a 16-year history of ulcerative colitis treated with mesalazine and infliximab. She reports no specific symptoms. O: Initial colonoscopy revealed multiple random biopsies from the transverse colon to the rectum, suggestive of rectal cancer. Follow-up colonoscopy showed absence of the haustra between the transverse colon and rectum. Histopathological examination of multiple random biopsy specimens indicated dysplasia with p53 overexpression in the rectum. Laparoscopic proctocolectomy and D2 lymphadenectomy with TaTME were performed. Transanal surgery involved mobilization of the colon from the ileocecal region to the rectum, laparoscopy-guided dissection of blood vessels, and mobilization of the rectum in the TME plane. Circumferential mucosectomy with preservation of the anal sphincter muscle was performed. A purse-string suture was used to close the rectal lumen to prevent mucus leakage and cancer cell dissemination. A: The primary diagnosis is rectal cancer with complications including dysplasia with p53 overexpression in the rectum. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of colon cancer, but these are less likely given the imaging and histopathological findings. P: The patient underwent a laparoscopic proctocolectomy and D2 lymphadenectomy with TaTME. Post-operative care includes regular follow-up appointments to monitor recovery and detect any new symptoms. The patient is advised to report any unusual symptoms immediately. Further consultations with oncology and oncology are recommended to manage her condition and manage her ulcerative colitis.

S: The patient reports intermittent abdominal pain for the past 10 days, located in the lower right abdomen, close to the inguinal region. O: Clinical examination revealed tenderness in the right iliac fossa. Blood tests showed no signs of inflammation. Ultrasound examination revealed a direct inguinal hernia protruding anteromedially and inferiorly to the inferior epigastric vessels and a small tubular structure compatible with the appendix. The appendix diameter is at the upper normal range, and the surrounding fat is hyperechoic. A CT scan confirmed Amyand's hernia with signs of inflammation. A: The primary diagnosis is Amyand's hernia with signs of inflammation. Differential diagnoses could include incarceration or acute appendicitis, but the CT scan confirms the presence of Amyand's hernia. P: The patient will be referred to a specialist for further evaluation and possible surgical intervention. The patient is advised to monitor symptoms closely and seek immediate medical attention if they worsen. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess the effectiveness of the surgical intervention and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient reports a painful mass in the right groin that has been growing for the past 2 days. The patient denies any recent nausea, emesis, diarrhea, or constipation. O: Vital signs are normal, and the patient is afebrile. Physical examination revealed a bulging tender mass in the right groin consistent with a femoral hernia, non-reducible. Laboratory tests showed elevated WBC count at 13,500/L and CRP at 34 mg/L. CT of the abdomen-pelvis showed the top of an inflamed appendix within the femoral sac and a small fluid collection in the femoral canal area. A: The primary diagnosis is a De Garengeot's hernia of the right groin. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of groin pain, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The patient will be transferred to the operating room for surgical intervention using Lockwood's infrainguinal approach. Preoperative antibiotics, cefuroxime 1500 mg, metronidazole 500 mg, will be administered. Postoperative care will include close monitoring of wound healing and wound closure. The patient will be discharged 7 days postoperatively, and follow-up will be scheduled to ensure wound healing and complete wound closure. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately.

S: The patient is a 39-year-old Caucasian male with ESRD, presenting for evaluation and exchange of a malfunctioning internal jugular hemodialysis catheter. He reports previous SVC stricture issues and underwent four previous SVC venoplasties. O: Initial manual dissection was performed to withdraw the dialysis catheter and conducted a central venogram to assess the proximal venous structures for possible stenosis or occlusion. Venograms revealed high-grade SVC stenosis near the cavoatrial junction, multiple collateral veins filling in the vicinity of the heart, and an anomalous small cardiac vein draining directly into the SVC. Additional venograms showed two vascular structures following the contour of the right heart border and base of the heart, refluxed contrast within the azygos vein, and refluxed contrast within the azygos vein. Coronary arteriogram showed no evidence of fistulous communication between the SVC and the coronary arterial system. Delayed views during the arteriogram showed contrast enhancement of the previously identified abnormal vessel, confirming anomalous venous drainage of the right heart. Repeat venograms showed direct communication with the superior vena cava and early filling of the coronary sinus. A: The primary diagnosis is arteriovenous fistula involving the right coronary artery and the SVC, complicated by a possible arteriovenous fistula. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of vascular stenosis and occlusion, but these are less likely given the imaging and venogram findings. P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition with regular follow-ups to assess for any recurrence or complications. The patient will be educated on the importance of compliance with the treatment plan and the importance of follow-up appointments. Referral to a cardiologist for further evaluation and management of the arteriovenous fistula is recommended.

S: The patient, with a history of Posner-Schlossman syndrome in the left eye recurred 20 years ago, reports persistent attacks of high IOP and AU in the left eye for 4 months in 2016. The patient has a history of Posner-Schlossman syndrome in the left eye, which recurred several times 20 years ago. O: The patient's maximum IOP was 36 mmHg and best-corrected visual acuity (BCVA) was 20/25 with deep anterior chamber, fine pupillary light reflex, and a few anterior chamber inflammations. Examinations revealed significant thinned retinal nerve fiber layer (RNFL) at superior and nasal side corresponding to visual field defects in the inferior temple quadrant for the infected eye. On admission in September, BCVA was 20/25 for the right eye and 20/200 for the left eye, IOP was 18 mmHg and 40 mmHg, respectively. The left eye features included cornea edema with bullous keratopathy, fine white keratic precipitates (KPs), deep anterior chamber, 2+ flare counts in aqueous, patched iris atrophy, visual field defects, and glaucomatous optic nerve defects. Serum IgG for CMV was positive with 1800 copies/ml. CMV-DNA in the aqueous sample was positive with 1800 copies/ml. A: The primary diagnosis is recurrent Posner-Schlossman syndrome in the left eye, complicated by CMV-DNA infection. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of IOP and visual field defects, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and imaging findings. P: The patient was treated with systemic antiviral therapy (ganciclovir 5 mg/kg twice a day intravenously for a week, followed by once a day for another week), topical 0.15% ganciclovir gel four times daily, and 1% prednisolone acetate eye drops. Regular follow-up appointments are recommended to monitor IOP, inflammation, and visual field defects. The patient is advised to maintain regular eye pressure and visual acuity to prevent further damage to the eye.

S: The patient reports experiencing swelling in the neck. The patient denies any other symptoms. O: Initial blood tests showed a leukocyte count of 49.1 X 109/L with 90% lymphocytes. Immunophenotyping test was positive for CD20, CD5, and CD23 surface antigens. The patient has been diagnosed with CLL (Rai IV) based on immunophenotyping results. Previous treatments with fludarabicin and rituximab were ineffective, leading to a repeat cycle of treatment with cyclophosphamide and prednisone. Cultured peripheral blood lymphocytes in RPMI-1640 medium were stimulated with phorbol-12-myristate-13-acetate and pokeweed mitogen, and metaphase cells were obtained. FISH analysis was performed using a combination of the 13q14.3-deletion probe and the RB1 probe. A: The primary diagnosis is CLL (Rai IV), a type of cancer that affects the blood and bone marrow. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of lymphoma, but these are less likely given the immunophenotyping results. P: The treatment plan includes chemotherapy with cyclophosphamide, adriamycin, vincristine, and prednisone. The patient will be monitored closely for response to therapy and will be educated on the importance of adhering to the treatment regimen and follow-up appointments. Further consultations with oncology and oncology are recommended to manage the disease and manage any complications.

S: The patient reports a history of a dislocated IOL in the left eye due to noninfectious chronic uveitis and persistent cystoid macular edema. The patient underwent vitrectomy in August 2010, followed by a sclerally-fixated IOL with a knotless zigzag-shaped intrascleral suture. Post-surgery, the patient experienced blurry vision and discomfort. O: Initial best-corrected visual acuity (BCVA) in the left eye was 20/100. Ozurdex® was injected into the left eye, causing diffuse corneal edema. Thirteen days post-implantation, the patient experienced blurry vision and discomfort. Post-surgery, the patient's BCVA was 20/200. Anterior segment examination showed diffuse corneal edema and a stable, well-positioned, sclerally-fixated IOL. Descemet membrane endothelial keratoplasty (DMEK) procedure was performed six months later, followed by rebubbling procedures due to a partially detached graft. A: The primary diagnosis is a dislocated IOL in the left eye with complications including noninfectious chronic uveitis and persistent cystoid macular edema. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of uveitis-related macular edema, but these are less likely given the patient's history and imaging results. P: Continue monitoring the patient's vision and adjust the treatment plan as necessary based on the patient's progress and any new symptoms. Regular follow-ups with ophthalmology and ophthalmology are recommended to monitor the patient's condition and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Educate the patient on the importance of reporting any changes in vision or concerns immediately.

S: The patient reports a spiking fever of 39–40 °C, dry cough, night sweats, and fatigue for 2 months. The patient has a history of mild anemia diagnosed with an upper respiratory tract infection treated with Cefprozil. Recently, the patient has noticed a growing mass on the right side of the neck, which has been painful but has not experienced arthralgia, rash, or weight loss. The patient has no relevant family history. O: Physical examination revealed scattered rales on the right lung, splenomegaly, and enlarged lymph nodes in the right cervical region. Laboratory tests showed peripheral pancytopenia (WBC 2.28*109/L, HGB 87 g/L, PLT 71*109/L), elevated liver enzymes (ALT 192 U/L, AST 139 U/L, LDH 554 U/L), and hyperferritinaemia (Fer 4090 ng/ml). Natural killer cell activity was reduced. Haemophagocytosis was found in the bone marrow aspirate. Serological investigations for common pathogens and autoimmune diseases were negative. Chest CT scan revealed bilateral nodules and right pleural effusion. Gram staining, acid-fast staining, and mycobacterial culture of the sputum were negative. Ultrasound-guided puncture on the right cervical lymph nodes identified M. intracellulare. A: The primary diagnosis is an infection caused by M. intracellulare, evidenced by the presence of acid-fast bacilli and nucleic acid probes. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of acute respiratory distress, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and laboratory findings. P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's response to Cefprozil and regular follow-ups to assess treatment efficacy and manage any complications. The patient will be educated on the importance of reporting any new symptoms or changes in health. Referral to a hematologist for further evaluation and management of M. intracellulare is recommended.

S: The patient reports a worsening headache for the past 3 days, characterized by constant pressure on the back of the head. The pain is not pulsatile. The patient has a history of hypertension diagnosed 10 years ago, treated with antihypertensive drugs but does not regularly use them. The patient has a history of hypertension diagnosed 10 years ago, treated with antihypertensive drugs but does not regularly use them. O: Physical examination revealed a blood pressure of 150/100 mmHg, with other vital signs within normal limits. Tenderness and inflammation at the occiput region were noted, with a Visual Analogue Scale (VAS) of 6-7, but no signs of tenderness or inflammation were noted. A: The primary diagnosis is high blood pressure, likely exacerbated by the patient's hypertension. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of high blood pressure, but these are less likely given the patient's history of hypertension. P: The management plan includes regular monitoring of the patient's blood pressure and other vital signs. The patient should return for a follow-up appointment if the headache persists or worsens. The patient is advised to take antihypertensive medication regularly to manage hypertension. Further consultations with a neurologist or a pulmonologist may be necessary depending on the patient's response to the medication.

S: Mrs. Patient 2, a female, presents for a follow-up regarding her treatment for WM and the IgMkappa paraprotein. She reports no new symptoms or changes in her health. O: Recent lab results include capillary zone electrophoresis, gel electrophoresis, capillary zone electrophoresis, urine immunofixation, IgMkappa paraprotein, serum-free light chain ratio, total IgG 35.1 g/L, suppressed IgA, IgMkappa paraprotein, IgG1 subtype, and other IgG subtypes. Bone marrow results include lymphoma cells CD5, CD20+, CD79a+, CD10+, CD23+, CD56+, and CD138+. A: Primary diagnosis of lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma/WM with associated IgM/kappa paraprotein. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of lymphoma, but these are less likely given the imaging and biopsy results. P: Continue monitoring the patient's condition closely with regular follow-ups to assess treatment efficacy and response to treatment. Educate the patient on the importance of reporting any new symptoms or concerns immediately. Consider referral to a hematologist for further evaluation and management of lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma/WM.

S: The patient reports chronic abdominal and right inguinal pain persisting for a while, with no history of surgery or trauma. The patient is currently on amlodipine 10 mg for hypertension. O: Physical examination revealed blood pressure at 135/95 mm Hg, heart rate at 62 bpm, and body temperature at 36.8°C. Laboratory tests showed leukocyte count at 7300/mm3, c-reactive protein at 2.7 mg/dL, potassium at 3.8 mmol/dL, aspartate aminotransferase at 34 U/L, and alanine aminotransferase at 205 U/L. Intravenous contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CECT) scan showed a calcified mass measuring 60x52 mm, located between the right internal iliac artery and urinary bladder. Tru-cut biopsy was undiagnostic. Post-surgery, the frozen section pathological examination confirmed the mass as a pelvic hydatid cyst. A: The primary diagnosis is a pelvic hydatid cyst in the right internal iliac artery. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of abdominal pain, but these are less likely given the imaging and pathological findings. P: The patient underwent an explorative laparotomy with a vertical midline incision to excise the mass, which was successfully excised. Post-operative care will include a liquid diet and regular follow-ups to monitor recovery and manage any complications. Albendazole 200 mg/day will be prescribed as part of the treatment plan. The patient is advised to adhere strictly to the treatment plan and follow-up schedules to manage any potential complications.

S: The patient, an 8-year-old male, presents with a large black hairy skin patch on his face since birth, covering the left periorbital area, forehead, cheek, and nose. He denies any neurological symptoms or medications and is not taking any medications. There is no family history of similar lesions or skin cancer. O: Physical examination reveals a pigmented patch measuring approximately 13 cm in its greatest dimension on the left periorbital area, covering nearly half of the face. No increase in size, color, pain, itching, or discharge has been noted since birth. There are no other similar lesions on the body, no other satellite lesions, and no associated congenital anomalies. A: The primary diagnosis is a large black hairy skin patch on the face of the left periorbital area, covering the left periorbital area, forehead, cheek, and nose. Differential diagnoses could include other skin lesions or other skin cancers, but these are less likely given the skin patch's size and color. The prognosis is guarded due to the nature of the lesion and the absence of congenital anomalies. P: The management plan includes providing support and counseling for the patient to cope with the lesion and discuss the available treatment options and follow-up requirements. The patient will be educated on the importance of adherence to the treatment plan and the importance of follow-up appointments. Referral to a dermatologist for further evaluation and management of the lesion is recommended.

S: The patient, referred for treatment of rectal rectal mucinous adenocarcinoma (SMT) detected during a checkup at another hospital, reported no symptoms during the checkup. O: Digital examination of the anus and rectum revealed a 20-mm elastic hard tumor on the right and ventral sides of the anal canal, 2 to 3 cm proximal to the anal verge. Laboratory tests showed no elevated carcinoembryonic antigen or cancer antigen 19-9. Colonoscopy identified a 20-mm SMT in the anal canal. Abdominal CT and MRI scans showed a 20-mm cystic tumor on the right side of the lower rectum with no lymph node or distant metastases. Follow-up CT and MRI scans 14 months post-surgery showed a new cystic lesion near the site of the removed tumor. Pathological examination confirmed the tumor as a mucinous adenocarcinoma of the lower rectum with a possible remnant tumor at the local site. Anal sphincter-preserving intersphincteric resection (ISR) with partial resection of the external sphincter and prophylactic lymph node dissection were performed. Immunohistochemical analysis was positive for CK7. A: The primary diagnosis is rectal rectal mucinous adenocarcinoma of the lower rectum with a possible remnant tumor at the local site. Differential diagnosis initially included benign cysts, which were ruled out by imaging and clinical findings. P: The patient underwent trans-sacral resection of the SMT and ISR with partial resection of the external sphincter and prophylactic lymph node dissection. Post-surgery, the patient underwent anal sphincter-preserving intersphincteric resection with partial resection of the external sphincter and prophylactic lymph node dissection. Post-surgery, the patient will continue to be closely monitored and provided with appropriate follow-up care to ensure the best possible outcome. Additional support and guidance will be provided to manage any side effects or complications.

S: The patient, a 40 pack-year smoker, reports a 10-day history of dry cough, dyspnea, and fatigue. He has a history of HIV treated with combination anti-retroviral therapy, undetectable viral loads, and a CD4 count of >500/mm3. He has a history of prostate resection for hypertrophy, left total knee replacement, and spinal stenosis. He has a 40 pack-year smoking history, minimal alcohol intake, and no illicit substance history. O: Vital signs include a respiratory rate of 18 per minute, saturations of 93% on 2 L of nasal prong oxygen, heart rate of 75 bpm, and blood pressure of 104/60 mmHg. Physical examination reveals reduced air entry with bibasal crackles. Laboratory findings include hemoglobin of 115 g/L, neutrophils 8.19  109/L, lymphocytes 0.49  109/L, eosinophils 0.17  109/L, and platelets 390  109/L. Chest film shows diffuse bilateral infiltrates, with urea of 25.4 mg/dL, and C-reactive protein of 148 mg/L. Arterial blood gas test indicates type 1 respiratory failure. A: The primary diagnosis is pneumonia, likely exacerbated by the patient's history of HIV and recent surgical interventions. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of respiratory failure, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The patient was started on ceftriaxone, azithromycin, and oxygen, followed by intravenous fluids. The patient was monitored closely for any changes in symptoms or overall condition. Adjustments to the treatment plan will be made based on the patient's response to the treatment and any new symptoms. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms or changes in his condition immediately.

S: The patient, a 3-year-old boy, presented with a 5-day history of respiratory distress and retching. He reported difficulty breathing and retching. O: Initial chest X-ray showed a left-sided tension pneumothorax with mediastinal shift and suspicion of bowel loops in the left lower hemithorax. On admission, the patient showed severe dyspnea, temperature of 39.5°C, and tachycardia of 200/min. Thoracic CT scan confirmed a left-sided enterothorax with mediastinal shift. Diagnostic laparoscopy identified a left-sided Bochdalek hernia with herniation of the small intestine, spleen, and stomach into the chest. Bile-stained fluid was found in the thorax and abdomen. A gastric perforation was identified at the lesser curvature. A conversion to laparotomy was performed to close the gastric perforation and repair the diaphragmatic hernia. A: The primary diagnosis is a left-sided Bochdalek hernia with herniation of the small intestine, spleen, and stomach into the chest. Differential diagnoses considered included bowel loops in the left lower hemithorax. The prognosis is good with a successful surgical intervention. P: The patient underwent a conversion to laparotomy to close the gastric perforation and repair the diaphragmatic hernia. Postoperatively, the boy was discharged with a long-term recovery of gastroparesis. The family is advised to continue monitoring the boy's progress and report any new symptoms or concerns.

S: The patient reports a five-week history of right-sided chest pain, right upper quadrant abdominal pain, and associated shortness of breath. The patient has a history of a fall at work approximately five weeks ago, leading to the progression of right-sided chest pain. The patient denies any prior medical, social, or renal disease. O: On examination, the patient was tachycardic with a pulse rate of 104 beats/minute, blood pressure of 121/76 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 100% on room air. Cardiac examination was unremarkable. The patient was tender over the lower four right ribs, clear to auscultation with no rales or rhonchi, and the abdomen was soft and non-tender with no organomegaly or peripheral edema. Chest X-ray indicated a pleural lesion in the right hemothorax. CT scan showed an expansile lytic lesion corresponding to the pleural lesion. Skeletal survey revealed multiple lesions on the skull, pelvic bone, and proximal right femur. Laboratory tests showed normocytic anemia with hemoglobin at 113 g/L, MCV at 83.6 fL, and 3+ rouleaux formation on peripheral blood smear. White cell and platelet count were normal. Corrected calcium level was 4.43 mmol/L, creatinine was 621 mol, and urea was 23.6 mmol/L. Urine microscopy was positive for protein but negative for blood. Serum protein electrophoresis showed total protein at 114 g/L with high gamma globulin at 47. A: The primary diagnosis is a pleural lesion in the right hemothorax, likely secondary to a underlying inflammatory or inflammatory process. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of right-sided chest pain and anemia, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: Plan to conduct further diagnostic tests and consult with a nephrologist for further evaluation and management of the lytic lesions and anemia. Plan to monitor the patient's symptoms and report any changes. Schedule follow-up appointments to

S: The patient, with a history of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, hypertension, irritable bowel syndrome, and anxiety disorder, reports a long-standing history of dry skin, abnormal menstrual periods, menorrhagia with irregular menses, and increasing polymenorrhea for several months. Recently, the patient has experienced chronic diarrhea alternating with constipation, a recent weight gain of 20 lbs, and a recent development of galactorrhea and breast enlargement and tenderness. The patient also reports a 1-day history of transient blurry vision, apraxia, aphasia, chest tightness, or increased anxiety. The patient denies any pain or swelling in the neck, recent viral infections, excessive iodine intake, exposure to iodinated contrast agents, lithium, amiodarone, prolonged steroid use, skin tags, changes in appearance, or changes in ring or shoe size. The patient has a family history of hyperthyroidism but no other pituitary disorders. O: Physical examination shows a BMI of 41. The patient's thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH) level is >150 mIU/mL (normal 0.5-5.5 mIU/mL), low free thyroxine (FT4) level (0.4 ng/dL), and elevated prolactin (29.4 ng/mL). MRI of the pituitary gland revealed an enlarged pituitary gland measuring 14x12 mm abutting the optic chiasm. A: The primary diagnosis is a pituitary disorder, likely exacerbated by hormonal imbalances and pituitary enlargement. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of pituitary enlargement, but these are less likely given the MRI findings. The prognosis depends on the extent of the pituitary enlargement and the patient's response to treatment. P: Plan to closely monitor the patient's symptoms and conduct further diagnostic tests to determine the cause of hormonal imbalances and pituitary enlargement. Educate the patient on the importance of adherence to prescribed medications and lifestyle modifications to manage weight and overall health. Schedule follow-up appointments to monitor the patient's response

S: The patient is a 74-year-old male with a history of end-stage liver disease, receiving an orthotopic liver transplant in March 2018, which led to improvement in hepatic encephalopathy and synthetic function. He also experienced acute kidney injury shortly before the transplantation due to suspected hepatorenal syndrome. He has been dialysis dependent prior to the transplantation and has been on an outpatient regimen of dialysis every Monday, Wednesday, and Friday. He has been diagnosed with ESBL Klebesiella oxytoca and a polymicrobial bacteremia due to a catheter related infection. He reports a tremor in his voice, weakness, confusion, and forgetfulness, and a change in his personality. O: The patient's blood cultures in August 2018 grew Citrobacter, Stenotrophomonas ESBL, and ESBL Klebesiella oxytoca. He was prescribed ertapenem for the infection, which led to a tremor in voice, weakness, confusion, and forgetfulness. He was hospitalized for emergent measurement of tacrolimus levels at 5.3 ng/mL, which was within normal limits and at the goal for the liver transplant. A: The primary diagnosis is ertapenem neurotoxicity, likely related to a catheter-related infection. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of hepatic encephalopathy and hepatorenal syndrome, but these are less likely given the culture results. The prognosis is guarded due to the complexity of his condition and the potential for neurotoxicity. P: Discontinued ertapenem due to suspected neurotoxicity. Continued hemodialysis on Mondays, Wednesdays, and Fridays. Monitor tacrolimus levels closely and adjust treatment as necessary. Educate the patient on the importance of reporting any new symptoms or concerns immediately. Schedule regular follow-up appointments to assess progress and adjust treatment as necessary.

S: The patient reports experiencing unusual symptoms in the left eye following strabismus surgery. The patient has a history of concomitant exotropia and has undergone strabismus surgery. O: Surgical exploration revealed thin purulent fluid in the subconjunctival cyst with no capsules, necrotic soft tissue, and a broken end of the medial rectus firmly attached to the sclera surface with a surgical design of 5 mm posterior insertion. Initial muscle suture was intact but loose. Postoperative bacterial and fungal cultures were positive for methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA). Postoperative bacterial culture was positive for MRSA. A: The primary diagnosis is a subconjunctival cyst in the left eye. The patient's history of strabismus surgery and recent surgical findings support this diagnosis. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of subconjunctival cysts, but these are less likely given the surgical findings and pathological findings. P: The management plan included surgical exploration and removal of the medial rectus and muscle suture. The patient was administered vancomycin (0.25 g, q8h) via intravenous drip, local antibiotics, and corticosteroid eye drops from Tobradex, made by Alcon. Postoperative follow-up showed complete recovery of the conjunctival incision and restoration of right binocular alignment. The patient is advised to report any concerns in the future.

S: The patient reports experiencing fever, diarrhoea, and reduced consciousness over a 12-hour duration. The patient also mentions myalgia, arthralgia, and a frontal headache. The patient denies any photophobia, phonophobia, skin rash, fits, cough, urinary symptoms, or bleeding manifestations. The patient has a history of mild intermittent bronchial asthma. O: On examination, the patient was febrile with a temperature of 101.3 °F and drowsy with a Glasgow coma scale of 11/15. Neurological examination showed no skin rashes, lymphadenopathy, or focal signs. Fundoscopic examination showed a pulse rate of 112 bpm, blood pressure of 100/60 mmHg, and respiratory rate of 14/min. Laboratory tests showed white blood cells at 6  109/L, neutrophils at 59%, hemoglobin at 14.3 g/dL, platelet count at 74  109/L, erythrocyte sedimentation rate at 13 mm in the first hour, C-reactive protein at 63 mg/l, normal serum electrolytes, mild impaired renal function, elevated liver enzymes with alanine aminotransferase at 303 U/l, aspartate aminotransferase at 482 U/l, total bilirubin at 10.6 mol/L, and normal urine analysis and coagulation profile. Non-contrast CT scan showed cerebral oedema. A: The primary diagnosis is cerebral oedema secondary to bronchial asthma. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of bronchial asthma, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and management of the oedema. P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition with regular follow-ups to assess treatment efficacy and manage any complications. The patient is advised to report any worsening symptoms or concerns immediately. Further consultations with a nephrologist and a pulmonologist may be considered if symptoms worsen or if symptoms worsen.

S: The patient, referred for an orthodontic consultation, reports experiencing a bit of crowded teeth and a suspicion of cavities. O: Physical examination reveals Class I canine occlusion on both sides, increased overjet, moderate crowding in the anterior segments in both the upper jaw and lower jaw, and a tipped lower-left first molar in the space of the second deciduous molar. Clinical examination reveals severe caries affecting the second deciduous molars in the upper jaw and an ectopic eruption of the first permanent molars. Radiographic examination reveals total submerged molar on the right side. A: The primary diagnosis is Class I canine occlusion, increased overjet, and moderate crowding in the anterior segments in both the upper jaw and lower jaw, with severe caries affecting the second deciduous molars in the upper jaw and an ectopic eruption of the first permanent molars. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of crowded teeth, but these are less likely given the clinical and radiologic findings. P: The management plan includes the extraction of the submerged molar (8.5) to prevent impaction of the permanent successor. A minimally invasive approach for the space regaining procedure involves a band with a double buccal tube on the permanent molar and a .014-inch round NiTi wire compressing between the first permanent molar and the first deciduous molar. The procedure will involve a minimally invasive approach with a .014-inch round NiTi wire. The patient will be provided with detailed instructions for preparation and post-procedure care.

S: The patient, a male, presented with sudden weakness and dizziness. He reported feeling weak and dizzy upon arrival to the emergency department. O: On examination, the patient was obtunded with a Glasgow Coma Score of 3 and a blood sugar level of 33 mg/dL. EZ-IO® device was used to place a 45 mm IO needle into the left proximal tibia and administered dextrose at a concentration of 50%. Upon arrival, the patient was hypoglycemic and unresponsive. Upon intubation, two 50 mL doses of D50 were administered through the IO needle. POCUS showed absence of flow in the IO space during the injection of normal saline. The left lower extremity was cool and mottled, with firm compartments and decreased peripheral pulses, and deep posterior compartment pressure was 85 mmHg. Radiograph revealed punctured both the anterior and posterior cortex of the tibia, extending 2 mm beyond the posterior cortex. A: The primary diagnosis is compartment syndrome secondary to IO needle placement. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of hypoglycemia or vascular injury, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The patient underwent a four-compartment fasciotomy to alleviate compartment syndrome. Post-operative care included intubation and medication administration. The patient is advised to follow up with an orthopedic surgeon for further evaluation and management of compartment syndrome. Further evaluation and management of compartment syndrome is necessary.

S: The patient, a 7-year history of Basedow's disease treated with thiamazole, reports a 9-day history of high fever, palpitations, and a dry cough. The patient denies any sore throat, cervical pain, dyspnea, or stomachache. The patient has a history of childhood asthma treated with thiamazole, and has lost 20 kg in the past 6 months and chronic mild diarrhea. The patient smokes a pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years but denies alcohol consumption. O: Physical examination reveals an anxious, febrile state with a temperature of 39.1 °C, blood pressure of 129/77 mmHg, pulse of 131 bpm, respiratory rate of 34 breaths per minute, oxygen saturation of 97% on room air, and an exophthalmos. Physical examination reveals a soft, diffusely enlarged thyroid gland with no skin redness or warmth. Cardiovascular examination shows tachycardia, clear lungs, hyperactive bowel sounds, and non-tender abdomen. Neurological examination is normal. Lab results indicate leukocytosis with 11,360 WBC /L, neutrophils at 78.6%, hyperthyroidism with TSH  0.021 IU/mL, F-T3 > 30.00 pg/mL, F-T4 at 8.88 ng/mL, and TSH receptor antibody 42.2 IU/L. CRP level is 5.07 mg/L. A: The primary diagnosis is Basedow's disease, likely exacerbated by the discontinuation of thiamazole. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of fever, palpitations, and dry cough, but these are less likely given the laboratory results and clinical presentation. P: Restart thiamazole medication and schedule regular follow-up appointments to monitor the patient's condition and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Adjust the treatment plan as necessary to manage symptoms and improve overall health. Educate the patient on the importance of adherence to the treatment plan and adherence to follow-up appointments.

S: The patient, a 51-year-old with a history of liver injury and cervical and mediastinal lymphadenopathy, reports a 7-10 day history of fevers over 38°C, occurring every 14-20 days for the past 2 months, and a skin rash that occurs every 14-20 days. The patient also mentions a productive cough for several days. The patient has been treated with antipyretics and anti-allergy drugs, but has not received immunosuppressive therapy. O: The patient's blood cell counts are normal, with elevated aspartate aminotransferase (AST 79 IU/L), alanine aminotransferase (ALT 51 IU/L), and lactate dehydrogenase (LDH 471 IU/L) levels, while alkaline phosphatase (ALP 152 IU/L) and -glutamyl transpeptidase (-GTP 24 IU/L) levels are normal. CRP is 2.86 mg/dL, and ferritin is markedly elevated (4731 ng/mL). Screen tests for hepatitis B and C were conducted. A: The primary diagnosis is hepatitis B and C, complicated by a persistent fever over 38°C and a skin rash. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of hepatitis B and C, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and laboratory findings. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and response to treatment. P: Continue monitoring the patient's condition closely with regular follow-ups to assess for any recurrence or new symptoms. Consider referral to a hepatologist for further evaluation and management of hepatitis B and C. Educate the patient on the importance of adherence to prescribed medications and follow-up appointments to monitor the progression of symptoms and adjust treatment as necessary. Consider referral to a hepatologist for further evaluation and management of hepatitis B and C.

S: The patient, a male with a history of epilepsy, presented to the emergency room with confusion and reduced awareness following a pub fight. He reports no psychiatric history but has a history of epilepsy, which he discontinued a while ago. O: Physical examination, neurological examination, brain CAT, and cerebrospinal fluid findings were unremarkable. Blood analysis showed slight signs of leukocytosis. EEG showed general slowing without epilepsy traces. Valproic acid was restarted at 1500mg daily. Urine toxicology confirmed a decrease in leukocytosis, increased CK to 521 U/L, and increased CRP to 16.2 mg/L. Brain MRI was unremarkable. Two days post-admission, Valproic acid blood levels were 54 mg/L, and EEG remains unchanged. A: The primary diagnosis is epilepsy with a history of tonic-clonic and generalized seizure. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of epilepsy, but these are less likely given the current findings. The prognosis depends on the response to the current treatment regimen and response to the current medication regimen. P: The patient was started on Valproic acid at 1500mg daily, with a dose of 2x1000mg/d, and the EEG remains unchanged. The patient is advised to continue taking antiepileptic drugs regularly to prevent future seizures. Regular follow-ups will be scheduled to monitor the patient's condition and adjust treatment as necessary. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms or changes in his condition immediately.

S: The patient, a 1-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus, presented with persistent left epigastric dull pain, chills, and febrile symptoms. The pain began without clear cause and has been persistent for a while. The patient has lost 10 kg in 6 months unintentionally. The patient has been on anti-infection therapy for abdominal pain relief, which has been reversible. O: Physical examination revealed no distended abdomen, normoactive bowel sounds, rebound tenderness, tenderness in the left upper quadrant, and no palpable mass. Laboratory tests showed a white blood cell count of 17.37  109 cells/L, neutrophils 93.9%, lymphocytes 3.1%, monocytes 3.0%, eosinophils 0.00%, and basophils 0.00%. Platelet count was 289  109 cells/L. Liver function tests, alpha-fetoprotein, carcinoembryonic antigen, carbohydrate antigen 19–9, and highly sensitive C-reactive protein were normal. Upper abdominal contrast-enhanced CT indicated diffuse hepatic disease, spleen abscess with inflammatory exudate, spleen calcification, chronic inflammation of the inferior lobe of the left lung, a small amount of fluid in the left chest, and thickening of the gastric fundus. Histological examination of biopsies showed spleen enlargement, fibrosis, and necrosis. A: The primary diagnosis is recurrent left epigastric dull pain, likely secondary to a hepatic infection, given the patient's history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and recent weight loss. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of hepatic disease, but these are less likely given the imaging and histological findings. P: The patient underwent laparoscopic exploration and splenectomy to address the spleen enlargement, fibrosis, and necrosis. The patient is advised to continue regular follow-ups with the healthcare team and maintain a healthy lifestyle to manage type 2 diabetes. Education on the importance of medication adherence and regular monitoring of symptoms is crucial. Referral to a gastroenterologist

S: The patient reports experiencing abdominal distention and pain for the past 5 hours, worsening, and vomiting twice. The patient has a history of acute pancreatitis (AP) treated with hyperlipidemia in May this year, which was discontinued due to hyperlipidemia. The patient has been on a high-fat diet for the past 3 months, and has had fatty food about 7 hours ago. O: The patient's upper abdominal CT scan shows severe acute pancreatitis (AP) and multiple organ dysfunction syndrome (heart, liver, and kidney). The patient's Ranson score is 4, Balthazar CT grade is D, APACHE II score is 17, and SOFA score is 9, indicating severe acute pancreatitis (SAP) and multiple organ dysfunction syndrome (heart, liver, and kidney). Upper abdominal CT, liver, kidney, and heart function, electrolyte levels, Ranson score is 4, Balthazar CT grade is D, APACHE II score is 17, and SOFA score is 9, indicating severe acute pancreatitis (SAP) and multiple organ dysfunction syndrome (heart, liver, and kidney). A: The primary diagnosis is severe acute pancreatitis (SAP) with multiple organ dysfunction syndrome (heart, liver, and kidney). Differential diagnoses could include other causes of acute pancreatitis, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: Initiate positive expansion, gastrointestinal decompression, and nutritional support. Continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT) will be initiated on the second day. Intraperitoneal puncture and drainage will be administered under ultrasound guidance. Eight root drainage tubes will be placed, two of which will be pulled out on the 11th day. Jejunal nutrition will be administered for 16 days post-admission. The patient's temperature will return to normal around day 19. The treatment plan includes monitoring the patient's vital signs and dietary modifications to prevent further complications.

S: The patient, a male, presented with a chief complaint of a cervical nodule. He reported no neurological symptoms. He has a history of dermatological surgery in the right cervical area, which required intensive care. O: Color Doppler ultrasonography revealed a large nodule posterior to the left carotid bifurcation and a ligature of the right common carotid artery. Arteriography identified a hypervascularized glomus tumor with a maximum diameter of 5 cm, located posterior to the left carotid bifurcation, fed by the ascending pharyngeal artery, and an occlusion of the right carotid artery and a 4 mm saccular aneurysm involving the left ophthalmic artery. A: The primary diagnosis is a hypervascularized glomus tumor with contralateral carotid occlusion and a hypervascularized glomus tumor. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of cervical nodules, but these are less likely given the imaging findings and imaging findings. P: The treatment plan includes preoperative embolization of the tumor using an Onyx® copolymer embolic agent 2 days prior to surgery. The procedure will involve a pressure cooker technique using a femoral artery puncture and selective catheterization of the left common carotid artery. The Apollo® microcatheter will be used to inject Onyx® until arterial reflux is identified on fluoroscopy. The patient will be educated on the procedure and expected outcomes to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient reports a 3-year history of spontaneous, oppressive pain on the left side of the face, described as oppressive. The pain is intermittent, radiating to the left temporal and orbital region, characterized by anxiety, agitation, and difficulty sleeping. The patient has been prescribed various medications including analgesics, antibiotics, steroids, and antidepressants, which have not been effective. The patient has a history of extraction of a decayed upper third molar and restoration of a carious tooth. O: Clinical examination revealed sharp, localized pain in the hamular region, characterized by an elongated hamular process with a knife-edge bony projection, with normal overlying palatal mucosa. Anesthetic injection (1 ml of 2% lidocaine) was administered. Oral examination showed deep dentinal caries with respect to 18 and pulp stones with respect to 16 on the right side. Blood tests were conducted to rule out cranial arteritis and autoimmune disorders such as Sjogren's syndrome. A: The primary diagnosis is a hamular process with a knife-edge bony projection, likely causing the pain. Differential diagnoses could include vascular decompression, central pontine dysfunction, skull base, or metastatic tumor. The prognosis depends on the response to the anesthetic and surgical intervention. P: The management plan includes considering surgical intervention to correct the elongated hamular process. Blood tests will be conducted to rule out cranial arteritis and Sjogren's syndrome. The patient will be educated on the importance of adherence to the treatment plan and the importance of follow-up appointments. Referral to a neurologist for further evaluation and management of the hamular process is recommended.

S: The patient, with a history of repaired hypospadias and anal atresia, presents with chronic prostatitis-like complaints for the past three months. O: MRI of the pelvis revealed a large thick-walled cystic lesion in the midline between the prostate and the deformed sacrum, communicating with the prostatic urethra at the verumontanum via a thin neck. No signs of prostatitis were noted on T2w or DCE images. A urethroscopy confirmed the connection between the cystic lesion and the verumontanum, and aspirated fluid was turbid, indicating a chronic infection. Robot-assisted surgical marsupialization of the cyst was performed, resulting in a pelvic abscess and perforation of the bladder wall. A control cystography showed closure of the bladder defect one month later. A: The primary diagnosis is a giant utricle cyst with chronic superinfection, likely causing the patient's symptoms. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of pelvic pain and urinary tract infections, but these are less likely given the imaging and surgical findings. P: The patient underwent a robot-assisted surgical marsupialization of the cyst. Post-surgery, the patient developed a pelvic abscess and perforation of the bladder wall, which were managed conservatively. A control cystography one month post-surgery showed closure of the bladder defect. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor recovery and manage any complications.

S: The patient, previously treated for Helicobacter pylori gastritis, reports experiencing indigestion, heartburn, and bloating for the past six months. O: Upper GI endoscopy revealed a duodenal bulb polyp. Biopsy confirmed a clonal population of malignant B-cells with a CD5+, CD10+, CD20+, CD23- immunophenotype, and over-expression of cyclin D1. A PET and CT scan showed an enlarged inguinal lymph node and a nonenlarged left external iliac lymph node, with no bone or central nervous system involvement. Bone marrow biopsy was normal. A repeat upper endoscopy with endosonographic ultrasound and colonoscopy in November 2014 showed an increase in the duodenal bulb lesion and abnormal mucosa in the ileocecal valve. Biopsy of the ileocecal valve revealed residual MCL. In December 2018, a repeat upper endoscopy with endoscopic ultrasound and a repeat colonoscopy showed normal endoscopic appearance of the duodenal bulb and ileocecal valve. A: The primary diagnosis is metastatic malignant lymphoma (MCL) with a history of Helicobacter pylori gastritis. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of lymphoma, but these are less likely given the imaging and biopsy results. P: The management plan includes close monitoring with regular clinic visits, monthly labs, and surveillance PET/CTs every three months. The patient has been on rituximab, cyclophosphamide, vincristine, and prednisone (R-CVP) for six cycles, with no recurrence of the disease. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms immediately. Regular follow-ups with oncology and oncology are scheduled to monitor the patient's condition and response to treatment.

S: The patient, with a history of epilepsy and asthma, presents with recurrent seizures, requiring a higher level of care. The patient reports two or three episodes of generalized tonic clonic seizure-like activity, which were undocumented. The patient was apneic and cyanotic, and was sedated and intubated for airway protection. The patient has been seizure-free since then. O: Vital signs include elevated blood pressure (170/90 mmHg), heart rate in the 120s, mild leukocytosis, and normal renal function with serum creatinine (scr) of 1.3 mg/dL. Brain CT was unremarkable. Laboratory tests showed mild leukocytosis and normal renal function with serum creatinine (scr) of 1.3 mg/dL. Urine drug screen was negative. On arrival, labs showed mild elevation in serum creatinine at 1.7mg/dL, normal serum electrolytes, and lactic acid. Serum creatine kinase (CK) level was mildly elevated at 297 U/L. On day 2, labs showed worsening acute kidney injury (AKI) with serum creatinine at 4.9 mg/dL, bicarbonate at 18 mEq/L, and phosphorus at 5.4 mg/dL. Urine output was consistent at 40-60 ml/hr. Urine microscopy was performed. A: The primary diagnosis is acute kidney injury secondary to recurrent seizures, likely secondary to underlying epilepsy and asthma. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of acute kidney injury, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and laboratory findings. P: The patient has been started on IV hydration with ringers lactate at 100 ml/hr and antiseizure medications, including IV Midazolam, Levetiracetam, and Lacosamide. The treatment plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition and adjustments to the treatment plan as necessary. Regular follow-ups will be scheduled to monitor the patient's condition and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately.

S: The patient, with a history of hypothyroidism and benign prostatic hyperplasia, presents with a four-month history of dry mouth, generalized weakness, decreased oral intake due to mouth pain, and a 30-pound weight loss in four months. The patient has a family history of Crohn's disease and lupus. O: Physical examination revealed dry oropharyngeal mucosa. Laboratory analysis showed elevated serum calcium at 12.71 mg/dL (normal range: 8.4-10.7 mg/dL), ionized calcium at 1.9 mmoL/L (normal range: 1.10-1.30 mmoL/L), creatinine at 3.81 mg/dL (normal range: 0.7-1.3 mg/dL), parathyroid hormone at 6.5 pg/mL (normal range: 15-65 pg/mL), and erythrocyte sedimentation rate at 55 mm/hr (normal range: 0-15 mm/hr). Laboratory findings include undetectable parathyroid hormone-related peptide (PTHrp), mildly decreased 25-hydroxyvitamin D at 18.1 ng/ml, and elevated 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D at 72 pg/ml. Angiotensin-converting enzyme was elevated at 91 U/L (normal range: 0-15 mm/hr). A: The primary diagnosis is hypercalcemia secondary to nonnecrotizing epithelioid cell granulomas, likely exacerbated by the patient's family history of Crohn's disease and lupus. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of xerostomia, but these are less likely given the imaging and laboratory findings. P: The management plan includes continued monitoring of calcium levels and other lab results. The patient is advised to follow up with the rheumatologist as soon as possible for further evaluation and treatment recommendations. Further consultations with a rheumatologist may be necessary to further evaluate the cause of hypercalcemia and other symptoms. The patient is encouraged to reach out with any concerns or questions in the meantime.

S: The patient, with a long-standing history of persistent atrial fibrillation, reports no palpitations or irregular heartbeat. The patient has a history of arterial hypertension and diabetes mellitus, which are controlled with medication. The patient also mentions microcythemia due to a thalassemic trait. The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation discovered seven years ago, treated with oral anticoagulation with Dabigatran (CHA2DS2-VASC score 2), electrical cardioversion with effectiveness, and Flecainide 100 mg twice daily as an antiarrhythmic therapy. The patient has experienced a recurrence of arrhythmia and has experienced decreased daily activity due to asthenia. O: The patient's electrocardiogram showed a left atrial indexed volume of 36 mL/m2 and a left ventricular ejection fraction of 47%. Echocardiography showed a left atrial indexed volume of 36 mL/m2 and a left ventricular ejection fraction of 47%. An echocardiography showed a left atrial indexed volume of 36 mL/m2 and a left ventricular ejection fraction of 47%. A: The primary diagnosis is recurrent atrial fibrillation with complications including atrial fibrillation and microcythemia. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of atrial fibrillation, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation. P: The management plan includes performing anatomical reconstruction of the right and left atrium using a multi-electrode mapping catheter PentarayTM. The procedure will involve mapping the right atrium to define the inferior and superior vena cava, the His location, and the coronary sinus (A). A decapolar catheter will be inserted in the coronary sinus under 3D EAM guidance, and a decapolar catheter will be inserted in the coronary sinus under 3D EAM guidance. A: The primary diagnosis is recurrent atrial fibrillation with complications including atrial fibrillation and microcythemia. The prognosis depends on the successful surgical intervention and management of the atrial fibrillation. P: The management plan includes scheduling anatomical reconstruction of the right and left atrium using the

S: The patient, with a history of hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, coronary artery disease, and a five-vessel coronary artery bypass grafting, presents with a four-day history of chest pain radiating to the jaw and along the left arm. O: Physical examination revealed shortness of breath. EKG showed old Q waves in the inferior leads and new ST depression in leads I, AVL, V5, and V6. Troponin levels peaked at 15.8. Chest radiograph showed pulmonary edema. Emergency echocardiography indicated partial disruption of the medial papillary muscle with a severely flail posterior MV leaflet and severe MR. Blood pressure was 86/63 mmHg, heart rate was 115 bpm. Emergency echocardiography indicated partial disruption of the medial papillary muscle with a severely flail posterior MV leaflet and severe MR. A: The primary diagnosis is occlusion of the right coronary, left main coronary, and circumflex arteries, with diffuse disease of the grafted vessels to circumflex. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of pulmonary edema, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The patient underwent urgent cardiac catheterization with a 100% occlusion in the right coronary, left main coronary, and circumflex arteries. Emergency echocardiography indicated partial disruption of the medial papillary muscle with a severely flail posterior MV leaflet and severe MR. A transcatheter procedure was performed, and a transseptal puncture with intraoperative transesophageal echocardiography was performed. A transcatheter procedure will be performed on the fifth day of hospitalization. The patient will be closely monitored for any complications and will be educated on the procedure and follow-up requirements.

S: Patient 7, a male, reports experiencing weakness on the left side for approximately 45 minutes. He denies any known underlying diseases. O: Initial NIHSS score was 18, indicating significant neurological deficit. Multimodal CT (MTT) revealed a perfusion delay in the whole right MCA territory, indicating a perfusion delay. Oxygen saturation in the brain was 48.35% and cerebral rSO2 was 64.87%, respectively. A: Primary diagnosis is left hemiparesis, likely secondary to a perfusion delay in the right MCA territory. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of left hemiparesis, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: Initiate Endovascular Therapy (EVT) to restore proper blood flow to the brain and alleviate symptoms. Monitor the patient closely and provide necessary support. Educate the patient on the importance of avoiding strenuous activities and adhering to the treatment plan.

S: The patient reports experiencing fever, headaches, paresthesia, pain in the right arm, and red spots on the skin for the last 30 days. The symptoms have worsened and spread to the lower limbs and trunk within 10 days. The patient has been taking non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) for these symptoms. O: The patient's clinical report includes hypotension, hospital admissions, and discharges. On the 15th day post-skin disease onset, the patient developed thrombocytopenia, liver dysfunction with an INR of 1.45 and Prothrombin Time of 56%, edema in the hands and feet, and hemorrhagic bullous lesions on the skin. Treatment included meropenem and vancomycin for 6 days, intravenous administration of Intravenous Immunoglobulin (Human), 5% (Flebogamma® 5% DIF) at 400 mg/kg/day for 5 days, followed by a repeat antibiotic therapy for 5 days. Platelet levels increased from 43,000 to 201,000, total leukocyte count improved, and edema, necrosis, and erythema reduced. Ten days post-globulin administration, aphasia was observed, indicating a transient acute ischemic stroke. Laboratory analysis confirmed a single anti-CHIKV IgM-positive test. A: The primary diagnosis is a suspected case of CHIKV with complications including thrombocytopenia, liver dysfunction, edema, necrosis, and erythema. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of ischemic stroke, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and laboratory results. P: Continue monitoring the patient's symptoms and adjust the treatment plan as necessary based on the patient's response to therapy. Educate the patient on the importance of reporting any new or worsening symptoms immediately. Schedule follow-up appointments to assess treatment efficacy and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Ensure patient understands the importance of reporting any new or worsening symptoms immediately.

S: The patient, a not a good swimmer, was hospitalized after drowning in cold river water. He was unaware of his condition and was unconscious, with blue lips and nails, and cold skin. The patient regained consciousness within a few minutes. The patient also experienced sleepiness, disorientation, anxiousness, and paleness. O: Initial assessment showed unconsciousness with blue lips and nails, blue lips, and cold skin. First Aid was performed, clearing the airway, mouth to mouth breaths, and chest compression. Initial symptoms included tachypnea with 30 respirations per minute, hypothermia at 35.1°C, and shivering. Upon admission to the JIT, auscultation of the lungs revealed weakened breathing sounds, early and late inspirium cracklings, low tone whistling, arrhythmic cardiac action with tachycardia up to 120 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 100/55. A: The primary diagnosis is a traumatic incident involving a sheep in cold river water. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of respiratory distress or pulmonary embolism, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation. P: The patient was admitted to the JIT with close monitoring of heart, blood pressure, temperature, and pulse oximetry. A nasogastric tube and urinary catheter were placed to manage breathing and cardiac function. A nasogastric tube and urinary catheter were placed to manage cardiac function. A nasogastric tube and urinary catheter were placed to manage cardiac function. A: The primary diagnosis is a traumatic incident involving a sheep in cold river water. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of respiratory distress or pulmonary embolism, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation. The prognosis depends on the response to the treatment and management of the underlying cause. P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition with regular follow-ups to assess recovery and adjust treatment as necessary. The patient is advised to report any new or worsening symptoms immediately. Further consultations with a pulmonologist and possibly a neurologist are recommended to manage respiratory distress and prevent further complications. Education on recognizing symptoms of respiratory distress and when to seek immediate care

S: The patient, admitted to Kasturba Hospital with acute gastroenteritis, reports experiencing loose stools, vomiting, abdominal pain, and fever for a day. He has a history of lupus nephritis class IV and is on a treatment regimen with four cycles of cyclophosphamide, 700 mg every 2 weeks. The patient denies any recent symptoms related to oral candidiasis, upper respiratory tract infections, and leucopenia. O: On admission, the patient described the stools as watery, without mucus or blood. The patient has a history of oral candidiasis, upper respiratory tract infections, and leucopenia. A: The primary diagnosis is acute gastroenteritis with complications including lupus nephritis class IV, oral candidiasis, upper respiratory tract infections, and leucopenia. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of acute gastroenteritis, but these are less likely given the patient's history and current symptoms. P: Continue close monitoring of the patient's acute gastroenteritis with the fifth pulse of cyclophosphamide as scheduled. Maintain hydration and report any new symptoms or changes in symptoms. Educate the patient on the importance of reporting any new symptoms or changes in symptoms.

S: The patient, previously a cesarean section, presents with 8 weeks’ delay of menstruation and increasing pain in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen, and intense reflex sensitivity in the right shoulder for a day. The patient denies any history of endometriosis, pelvic inflammatory disease, tubal surgery, intrauterine device use, or previous ectopic pregnancy. O: Laboratory findings include a quantitative hCG of 3129.94 IU/L and hemoglobin of 10.3 g/dL. TVS examination showed no intrauterine pregnancy, normal bilateral adnexa, and a large amount of free fluid in the abdomen. CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis revealed a 90-mm mixed hypodense mass on the upper surface of the right liver lobe. Diagnostic abdominocentesis showed uncoagulable blood. Laparoscopic surgery revealed significant hemoperitoneum with approximately 1500 ml of blood, a 50 mm corpus luteum cyst on the left ovary, and significant free blood around the perihepatic area and spleen. An active bleeding was discovered from the mass, measuring 80 mm x 50 mm, on the surface of the diaphragm. A: The primary diagnosis is an ectopic pregnancy implanted in the liver, complicated by hemoperitoneum and a 50 mm corpus luteum cyst on the left ovary. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of abdominal pain and weakness, but these are less likely given the imaging and surgical findings. P: The patient was transferred to a tertiary referral center for further management. Post-operative care includes monitoring for hemoperitoneum and hemorrhagic shock, and bipolar electrocoagulation was placed to manage bleeding. The patient will be educated on signs of complications and advised to report any new symptoms immediately. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's condition and adjust treatment as necessary.

S: The patient, with a history of benign prostatic hyperplasia and a 6-year history of an enlarging right inguinal hernia, reports discomfort in the right groin area. The patient denies any other complaints. O: Physical examination revealed a cystic mass on the superior right testicle and a firm, solid mass in the right groin. The testicular mass is fully mobile within the subcutaneous space and minimally tender. A CT scan revealed a partially visualized, heterogenous, and enhancing right inguinal mass. Surgical excisation of the mass was performed, revealing the mass to be located inside the external cord but outside of the internal spermatic fascia, eroded through the aponeurosis of the external oblique muscle. Pathology confirmed the mass as a heterogeneous pattern-less architecture with alternating hypocellular and hypercellular areas, interstitial hyalinization, and intermixed with ropy collagen bands. A: The primary diagnosis is a peripheral nerve sheath tumor or sarcoma of the spermatic cord, likely a peripheral nerve sheath tumor or sarcoma of the spermatic cord. Differential diagnoses could include peripheral nerve sheath tumor or sarcoma of the spermatic cord, but imaging and pathology support the primary diagnosis. P: The patient underwent surgical excisation of the mass from the spermatic cord, which was performed successfully. Post-operative care will include close monitoring of the patient's condition and regular follow-ups to assess for any recurrence or complications. The patient will be educated on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and adherence to follow-up appointments.

S: The patient, a computer scientist, presents with a seven-day history of myalgia, retro-orbital headaches, fatigue, recurrent fever, and nausea. The patient reports increasing difficulty in walking, particularly due to myalgia in the calf region, and an episode of gum bleeding after cleaning teeth. The patient denies recent travel, contact with animals, or recent contact with animals. The patient has a history of a minor knee injury and a skin abrasion two weeks ago. O: On examination, the patient appeared tired with no neurological abnormalities. Physical examination revealed a body temperature of 36.8 °C, pulse 90 bpm, blood pressure 114/75 mmHg, respiratory rate 16 bpm, and oxygen saturation 99%. Lungs and heart auscultation were unremarkable. The abdomen was soft and non-tender. Skin and scleral examination revealed jaundice, slight gum bleeding, and tenderness in the thighs and calves upon pressure. Abdominal ultrasound indicated hepatosplenomegaly without intra- or extrahepatic cholestasis. White-cell count was 9.9 G/L with 87% neutrophils and 3.5% lymphocytes, platelet count was 39 G/L, hemoglobin was 13.3 g/dl, serum sodium level was 123 mmol/l, and potassium was within normal limits. A: The primary diagnosis is hepatosplenomegaly, likely secondary to a hepatosplenomegaly, given the patient's history of a minor knee injury and skin abrasion. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of hepatosplenomegaly, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: Plan to conduct further diagnostic tests to confirm the diagnosis and rule out other causes of hepatosplenomegaly. Continue close monitoring of the patient's condition with regular follow-ups. Educate the patient on the importance of reporting new or worsening symptoms immediately. Consider referral to a hepatologist for further evaluation and management of hepatosplenomegaly.

S: The patient reports a progressive decrease in vision in the left eye over the past six months, with excessive perspiration and sweating. The patient has a history of pituitary gigantism diagnosed at age 16, treated with microsurgical trans sphenoidal surgery and adjuvant radiotherapy in 2011. O: Ophthalmologic examination revealed left ptosis, exophthalmos, and upward/inward limitation on left eye movements. Goldmann's test perimeter showed ipsilateral amaurosis and right hemianopia. Random serum GH level was 0.071 ng/ml (normal 0.003–0.97 ng/mL). Oral Glucose Tolerance Test (OGTT) GH-nadir was 0.13 ng/ml. Insulin-like Growth Factor-1 (IGF-1) was 84.3 ng/ml (normal 64–210 ng/mL). Brain MRI showed a large policystic selar lesion with extensive osteophytic reaction and invasion of the ipsilateral orbital apex, associated with fibrous dysplasia. T2-weighted imaging showed a hypointense and enhancing selar mass lesion with Calcium intensity. A: The primary diagnosis is a large policystic selar lesion in the brain, likely causing the vision problems and other symptoms. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of glaucoma or other glaucoma, but these are less likely given the imaging and MRI findings. P: Refer the patient to a neurologist for further evaluation and management of the lesion. Monitor the patient's symptoms closely and report any changes or worsening of the condition. Refer the patient to a pulmonologist for further evaluation and management. Educate the patient on the importance of reporting any new symptoms or worsening of the condition.

S: The patient, with a history of hypertension and HOCM, presented with sudden onset sharp, non-radiating, left-sided flank pain, nausea, and vomiting. O: On admission, vital signs were unremarkable. Physical examination revealed a Grade III/VI systolic murmur, loudest at the apex, marked tenderness on superficial palpation of the left inferior costal margin, with no rebound tenderness, costovertebral angle tenderness, and no abdominal or flank erythema. Lab results indicated leukocytosis at 13,000 and acute kidney injury with creatinine levels at 1.3 mg/dl (normal 0.7 mg/dl). Urinalysis was positive for hematuria but urine toxicology was negative for illicit substances. CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis showed bilateral segmental hypoperfusion indicative of a bilateral renal infarction, with the left side more affected than the right. EKG showed normal sinus rhythm with no evidence of infarction, ischemia, or atrial fibrillation. Antibodies and levels of protein C, protein S, antithrombin, and Factor V Leiden were within normal limits. Transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) showed hyperdynamic left ventricle systolic function, a moderately dilated left atrium at 54 mm, mild thickening of the anterior and posterior mitral valve leaflets, and a peak subvalvular gradient around 20 mmHg. Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) showed a peak subvalvular gradient around 20 mmHg with no masses or vegetation. A: The primary diagnosis is bilateral renal infarction secondary to a heparin drip. Differential diagnoses could include infection, autoimmune etiology, sickle cell disease, patent foramen ovale, and arrhythmias. The prognosis depends on the response to the heparin drip and management of the renal infarction. P: The patient was started on a heparin drip to manage the bilateral renal infarction. Continued monitoring of the patient's condition is necessary, with adjustments to treatment as necessary based on the patient's response to the

S: The patient, a female with a history of Klippel-Trenaunay Syndrome (KTS), presents with a chief complaint of kyphoscoliosis since birth, uneven growth, a birthmark on her back, and swelling on her left tonsil. She reports discomfort and pain. She has a history of hemangioma on her face and back since birth, laser therapy for facial hemangioma at age 4, and venous varicosities in both lower extremities three years ago. No family history of KTS was reported. O: Radiographs of the spine revealed a Cobb angle of lumbar scoliosis at 105° from Thoracic 11 to Lumbar 4, trunk shift at 10 cm, and kyphosis angle from T8 to L3 at 58°. Physical examination revealed hemihypertrophy of the left face, trunk, and lower limb, port-wine stain on the back, and venous varicosities on both lower limbs. The left leg was 2 cm longer than the right side, and claudication was noted. Neurological examination was intact. Laboratory findings included increased D-Dimer 2.02 mg/L, decreased hemoglobin 105 g/L, decreased 1,25(OH)2D3 6.58 pg/mL, decreased Fe 34.7g/dL, and decreased ferritin 8 ng/mL. A: The primary diagnosis is Klippel-Trenaunay Syndrome (KTS), evidenced by hemihypertrophy of the left face, trunk, and lower limb, port-wine stain on the back, and venous varicosities on both lower limbs. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of kyphoscoliosis, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The management plan will include medication, physical therapy, and possibly surgery for kyphoscoliosis. The patient will be monitored closely for any changes in the lab results and will be educated on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan. Referral to a neurologist for further evaluation and management of KTS is recommended. Patient education regarding the nature of the disease

S: The patient is an 85-year-old male with a history of hypertension and congestive heart failure, presenting with symptoms of dysuria, severe urinary frequency, nocturia, suprapubic pain, fever, and increasing lethargy for the past 3 weeks. He reports no previous abdominal surgeries. O: Urinalysis indicated a urinary tract infection with positive nitrites, proteinuria, and leukocyturia. Urine culture was negative. Blood tests indicated neutrophilia and mild acute renal impairment. Ultrasound examination revealed a heterogenous mass containing gas, anterior to the urinary bladder, measuring 8.5  4.9  6.1 cm. CT scan of the thorax, abdomen, and pelvis with intravenous contrast showed a large, thick-walled mass measuring 8cm superior to the urinary bladder, containing fluid and gas, communicating with the bladder, and in contact with the small bowel, with enlarged lymph node groups in both groins, lateral vesical groups, and the left para-aortic region up to the left renal hilum. A urinary catheter was inserted and drained 'cloudy' urine containing sediment. Cystoscopy was performed to locate the fistula and its relation to the ureteric orifices. A: The primary diagnosis is a urinary tract infection with a fistula, likely a bacterial infection, given the imaging findings and clinical presentation. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of urinary tract infections, but these are less likely given the imaging findings and clinical presentation. P: The patient was started on intravenous Ciprofloxacin, followed by oral antibiotics and urological review. Subsequent treatment included intravenous Co-Amoxiclav therapy. The patient will continue with current therapy and will be closely monitored for any new symptoms or complications. Further consultations with the surgical team will be scheduled to discuss the case and schedule the surgery. The patient is advised to continue with current therapy and report any concerns immediately.

S: The patient, with a history of no known past medical history, presents with sudden right hip pain and progressive difficulty in walking for the past three weeks. The pain worsens with physical activity and mobility, and worsens with rest. The pain also extends to the lower legs. O: Outpatient chest and right hip X-rays revealed multiple lytic lesions suggestive of metastatic disease. Laboratory tests showed hemoglobin at 9 g/dl, creatinine at 2.8 mg/dl, calcium at 13.5 mg/dl, albumin at 2.7 g/dl, total serum protein at 9.6 g/dl, globulin at 7.1 g/dl, and an albumin to globulin ratio of 0.3. Free PSA was 6.9 ng/mL, total PSA was 78.0 ng/mL. Urinalysis showed proteinuria and hematuria. MRI of the spine and bone scan confirmed diffuse metastatic disease. A bilateral orchiectomy was performed without complications. Post-treatment, serum creatinine levels improved, but serum creatinine remains elevated. A: The primary diagnosis is diffuse metastatic disease, complicated by multiple myeloma and metastatic prostate cancer. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of metastatic disease, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The patient underwent a bilateral orchiectomy without complications.
