Post-procedure, the patient was started on steroids for suspected spinal cord compression, and intravenous fluid hydration and zoledronic acid were administered. The treatment plan includes regular monitoring of creatinine levels and adjustment of treatment as necessary. The patient is advised to maintain regular follow-ups with their primary care physician and specialists to manage their condition.

S: The patient is a 32-year-old transgender woman with no prior medical history, presenting with severe pain in the right forearm, redness, and blistering, first noticed 2 weeks ago following a solar branding tattoo on the right forearm. The blistering has been worsening since then. The patient has been prescribed oral clindamycin for a superficial infection of the right forearm full thickness burn, which has not improved. O: Physical examination reveals painful blisters, redness, and swelling of the right forearm and hand, with mild pain when flexing the hand. Vital signs and white blood cell count are within normal limits. A: The primary diagnosis is a superficial infection of the right forearm full thickness burn with associated cellulitis. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of blistering and redness, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation. P: Initiate IV clindamycin 600 mg every 8 hours, followed by bedside debridement in the Burn Unit. Post-operative care includes tangential excision of the wound, and a split-thickness skin autograft placement on the right forearm using the left anterolateral thigh as the donor site. Close monitoring of the patient's progress is essential, with regular follow-ups to assess healing and manage any complications.

S: The patient, a monogamous sexual partner, presented with worsening dyspnea and a nonproductive cough for the past 4 days, fevers, chills, and myalgias. The patient tried acetaminophen and ibuprofen, which did not alleviate symptoms. The patient denies any history of tuberculosis, hematologic disease, or unusual occupational exposures. O: On examination, the patient was tachypneic with over 50 breaths per minute and tachycardic. Chest radiograph revealed increased interstitial markings and alveolar airspace disease. Non-contrast CT of the chest showed diffuse smooth interlobular septal thickening with superimposed areas of ground glass attenuation and peribronchial airspace consolidation. Lab results indicated microcytic anemia, elevated lactate levels (2.9 mmol/L initially, increased to 3.9 mmol/L in 5 hours), mildly elevated procalcitonin (1.91 ng/mL), and LDH (286 u/L). HIV – 1 + 2 antigen + antibody assay was negative. A: The primary diagnosis is acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) with associated noncardiogenic causes of pulmonary edema. Differential diagnoses could include atypical infectious processes such as Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia, alveolar hemorrhage, or drug-induced lung disease. The patient's history of ARDS and immunocompromised status are concerning. P: The patient was admitted to the ICU for close monitoring and treatment. Initial fluids and initial doses of azithromycin and ceftriaxone were administered, followed by initial doses of azithromycin and ceftriaxone. The patient was admitted to the ICU for close monitoring and adjustment of treatment as necessary. Regular follow-ups in the ICU will be scheduled to monitor the patient's condition and adjust treatment as necessary.

S: The patient is a 32-year-old Japanese woman, gravida 4, presenting with a chief complaint of a first-degree perineal laceration on the left side of the external urethral orifice during a term delivery. She reports a two-day history of a fever of 40°C and focal perineal pain. She was discharged on the fifth day post-delivery. O: Physical examination reveals consciousness, hypotension (88/56 mmHg), tachycardia (144 beats/minute), and tachypnea (23 breaths/minute). Body temperature is 40.2°C. Abdominal examination is normal, and pelvic examination shows no tenderness or swelling in the uterus and vagina. Laboratory findings include neutrophilic leukocytosis (WBC 19,600/mm3) with 96.1% neutrophils, 1.2% lymphocytes, and 2.4% monocytes, hypoproteinemia (6.6 g/dl), hypoalbuminemia (3.6 g/dl), and serum electrolyte concentrations (sodium 136 mEq/L, potassium 3.2 mEq/L, chloride 97 mEq/L, calcium 8.2 mg/dl, phosphate 3.7 mg/dl, magnesium 1.5 mg/dl). A: The primary diagnosis is a perineal laceration post-delivery, complicated by neutrophilic leukocytosis, hypoproteinemia, and hypoalbuminemia. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of perineal lacerations, but these are less likely given the laboratory findings and clinical presentation. P: Initiate aggressive intravenous fluid resuscitation and antimicrobial agent therapy with intravenous ceftriaxone (2 g every 12 hours). Perform vaginal, urine, stool, and blood cultures prior to antibiotic administration. Monitor the patient's response to treatment and adjust as necessary. Educate the patient on signs of worsening symptoms and encourage immediate reporting of any new symptoms.

S: The patient is a 53-year-old male with a history of 20 pack-years and occasional alcoholism, presenting with episodes of blood expectoration over the past 9 months. He reports one episode where he coughed up 400 ml of blood, then for 2-3 days, to 100-150 ml. He has a history of bronchial artery embolization for massive hemophilia (LRTI) treated with multiple courses of antibiotics for over 9 months. He denies fever, chest pain, or loss of appetite. O: Physical examination revealed scattered crackles in the left lower lobe area. Chest X-ray showed an inhomogeneous opacity in the left lower zone with a raised left diaphragm. Contrast-enhanced computer tomogram (CECT) indicated a hypodense lesion with irregular margins in the anterior segment of the left lower lobe adjacent to the descending aorta and associated subcarinal lymphadenopathy. Image-guided transthoracic biopsy indicated type 2 alveolar cell hyperplasia with negative immunohistochemistry. Bronchoscopy confirmed a left lower lobe bleed without endoluminal lesion. Bronchial wash was negative for microbiological and cytological studies including AFB stain, geneXpert for MTB complex, and pyogenic culture. CT angiogram showed dilated vascular channels within the lesion without extravasations of contrast and no aortic abnormalities. A: The primary diagnosis is left intrapulmonary vascular lesion, likely a left intrapulmonary vascular lesion. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of hemophilia, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The patient underwent a left lower lobe lobectomy to remove the vascular lesion. Post-operative care includes monitoring for healing and addressing any concerns. The patient is advised to maintain good oral hygiene and reduce alcohol intake to improve overall health. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor healing and address any concerns. The patient is advised to quit smoking and reduce alcohol intake to improve overall health.

S: The patient reports experiencing abdominal pain and left shoulder pain for 6 years. The patient has a history of a large retroperitoneal tumor treated surgically with a 6.8 cm lytic lesion in the coracoid process. Post-surgery, the patient was diagnosed with a metastatic prostate gland tumor (PGL) with liver lesions, bilateral lung lesions, multiple metastatic neck, mediastinal, retroperitoneal lymph nodes, and a left inferior pubic ramus bone metastasis. O: Initial CT scan revealed a large retroperitoneal tumor. Histopathology confirmed a lytic lesion in the coracoid process, treated with 2.5 gray external beam radiotherapy over 13 fractions. MRI scans showed liver lesions, bilateral lung lesions, multiple metastatic neck, mediastinal, retroperitoneal lymph nodes, and a left inferior pubic ramus bone metastasis. Ultrasound guided liver biopsy confirmed a metastatic PGL. Biochemical tests showed elevated plasma NMN, MTY, and CgA. Follow-up CT scans in 2 months showed an increase in liver lesions and recurrence of the retroperitoneal PGL. 68Ga-DOTATATE, 18F-FDG, and 18F-FDOPA PET/CT scans re-demonstrated the liver lesions and re-demonstrated the left hepatic lobe. A: The primary diagnosis is metastatic prostate gland tumor with liver lesions and recurrence of the retroperitoneal PGL. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of metastatic cancers, but imaging and histopathology support the primary diagnosis. P: The patient is currently on PRRT with 177Lu-DOTATATE therapy and external beam radiotherapy to the pubic bone. The current treatment plan includes discontinuation of 177Lu-DOTATATE therapy due to progression. Close monitoring of the patient's condition is essential, with adjustments to the treatment plan as necessary based on the progression of the disease.

S: The patient, a 13-month-old male, was on oral propranolol hydrochloride for a large IH, which has significantly reduced the size of the IH. The mother reports no history of hypoglycemia and is not on any other medications. The patient was unaware of the importance of taking propranolol with food and when to temporarily stop it. O: The patient was in a deep coma with severe hypothermia (34°C), cold sweats, slow heartbeats (60-65 beats/minute), and low blood pressure (85/46 mmHg). The patient was treated with 30 ml of 10% dextrose solution intravenously, followed by 7.5% dextrose for a few hours. A: The primary diagnosis is severe hypoglycemia secondary to propranolol hydrochloride, with complications including severe hypothermia, cold sweats, slow heartbeats, and low blood pressure. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of hypoglycemia, but these are less likely given the patient's history and current findings. P: The management plan includes continued propranolol hydrochloride with food and monitoring for any signs of severe adverse effects. The patient is advised to take propranolol with food and to be aware of when to temporarily stop the medication. The mother is advised to monitor for any signs of severe adverse effects and to report any new symptoms immediately.

S: The patient, previously treated with methampyrone 500 mg orally, developed erythematous skin with severe itching and flaking, followed by bullous exfoliation of the skin. The patient has a history of hypertension and postprimary coronary intervention in 2011. He has been on aspirin 80 mg QD, amlodipine 10 mg QD, and atorvastatin 20 mg QD. O: Physical examination revealed the patient to be conscious and alert but weak. Hemodynamics were stable with a respiration rate of 24x/minutes, body temperature of 37.8°C, and SpO2 of 97–99% while breathing supplementary oxygen with a nasal cannula. Hemodynamics were stable with a respiratory rate of 24x/minutes, body temperature of 37.8°C, and SpO2 of 97–99% while breathing supplementary oxygen with a nasal cannula. Conjunctivitis, turbid corneal ulceration, mouth ulceration, and swollen lips were noted. Generalized skin erythema and irregularly shaped itchy purpuric macules were noted. Nikolsky's sign was elicited, with detachment of the epidermis from lower layers and extension of existing bullae to the clear skin indicated active TEN. The epidermal detachment was over 30% of BSA. The SCORTEN score prognosis was three. A: The primary diagnosis is active TEN with complications including severe itching and flaking. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of skin lesions, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and history. The prognosis is guarded due to the severity of the disease and the severity of the skin changes. P: The patient was started on methylprednisolone 125 mg TID and cyclosporine 50 mg BID, which did not improve the skin lesions. The SCORTEN score was calculated to prognosticate the risk for death from TEN. The patient is advised to continue monitoring his health and follow any recommended medical advice to prevent future complications. Further consultations with a dermatologist and a dermatologist are recommended to manage the TEN and prevent further complications.

S: The patient, a part-time barber, presented with a 2-week history of abdominal distention, bloating, decreased appetite, early satiety, and generalized weakness. The patient has a history of asbestos exposure and significant passive smoking exposure. O: Physical examination revealed a distended abdomen with mild tenderness to deep palpation in all quadrants, no rebound tenderness or guarding, positive fluid wave test, and lower extremity edema. Laboratory workup was unremarkable except for low serum albumin. CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis showed diffuse omental, peritoneal, and mesenteric nodularity with moderate to large ascites. CT chest scan with contrast was negative for primary lung malignancy but showed bilateral pleural plaques. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy and colonoscopy were unremarkable. Tumor markers CEA, PSA, CA 19-9, and AFP were within normal limits. Therapeutic and diagnostic paracentesis yielded 2.5 liters of blood-tinged fluid. Ascitic fluid analysis indicated ascites not associated with portal hypertension. Ultrasound-guided omental biopsy confirmed malignant pleural mesothelioma (MPM), epithelioid subtype. Tumor cells tested positive for calretinin, WT-1, CK5/6, and mesothelia. A: The primary diagnosis is malignant pleural mesothelioma (MPM), epithelioid subtype, confirmed by ultrasound-guided omental biopsy. Differential diagnosis initially included primary lung malignancy but was ruled out based on imaging and tumor markers. P: The management plan includes discussing treatment options for the malignant pleural mesothelioma. The patient will be educated on the nature of the disease, treatment options, and potential side effects. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's response to treatment and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Referral to a pulmonologist for further evaluation and management of the pleural mesothelioma is recommended.

S: The patient, a male with a history of hemoperitoneum from a ruptured ovarian cyst, presented with acute abdominal pain, predominantly in the lower abdomen. He reports severe and sudden pain, predominantly in the lower abdomen. O: The patient's partial thromboplastin time (PTT) was confirmed at 42 seconds (normal range 20-36 seconds). Mixing studies indicated a factor deficiency. Factor X activity was 11%, with other factors normal. Serum protein electrophoresis showed an IgG kappa monoclonal protein of 0.4 g/dL, serum-free kappa 14.5 g/dL, and lambda light chain 72.2 g/dL, respectively. Bone marrow aspiration and biopsy showed 3% kappa-restricted plasma cells. Congo red staining was negative, but rectal biopsy tissue was positive. Immunofluorescent staining confirmed kappa-restricted amyloid protein. The patient developed grade 2 painful sensory neuropathy and achieved a marginal response after 3 cycles of therapy, with FX activity between 10% and 15%. Stem cell collection, high-dose melphalan, autologous stem cell transplantation, and PCC and platelet transfusion were administered during the myelosuppressive period. A: The primary diagnosis is hemoperitoneum from a ruptured ovarian cyst, complicated by amyloidosis and kidney involvement. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of acute abdominal pain, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The patient underwent induction therapy with bortezomib, cyclophosphamide, and dexamethasone regimen (CyborD) to manage amyloidosis. The patient developed grade 2 painful sensory neuropathy, managed with high-dose melphalan, autologous stem cell transplantation, and PCC and platelet transfusion. The patient achieved complete remission with normalized serum lambda light chain levels and corresponding improvement in condition. Continued monitoring and adjustment of treatment will be necessary based on the patient's response to treatment and response to therapy.

S: The patient, an 8-year-old male, presents with pain in his front teeth, particularly when exposed to cold water. He has a history of trauma to his primary teeth, including a fracture in the crown of his upper right primary central incisor repaired with composite resin. He reports no pain after the last treatment but continues to feel pain. O: Physical examination revealed abnormal position of the upper right permanent central incisor and clouding on the labial surface. The patient's VAS was 6 for cold water and 7.5 for air blowing. Post-treatment, the patient's VAS was 4 with cold water and 5 with air. The patient's VAS was 1-2 with cold water and 2-4 with air. Digital analysis showed significant reduction in cloudiness from 27,886 pixels to 7,904 pixels, with a narrow area with a slight brown color. The hypomineralized tooth was mostly cloudy but had a narrow area with a slight brown color. A: The primary diagnosis is a fracture in the crown of the upper right primary central incisor, likely exacerbated by trauma to the primary teeth. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of pain, but imaging and clinical findings support the primary diagnosis. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the improvement in pain and color tone. P: Continue regular follow-up appointments to monitor the patient's response to treatment and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Educate the patient on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and avoiding potential complications. Encourage the patient to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately.

S: The patient is a 33-year-old female, Gravida 3, who was evaluated in the 16th week of pregnancy. She reports feeling not too great. She was diagnosed with infiltrating ductal carcinoma, a grade 3 tumor with increased consistency, irregular margins, and clinically negative axilla. O: Physical examination revealed a tumor in the breast. Biopsy revealed an infiltrating ductal carcinoma with increased consistency, a maximum diameter of 10 cm, and irregular margins. Immunohistochemistry indicated oestrogen receptor-positive (35%), progesterone receptor-positive (85%), HER2/neu-positive (Score 3+), and Ki67 at 37%. Whole-body nuclear magnetic resonance without contrast showed hepatic metastasis in segment V measuring 29 mm and millimetric metastases in the right iliac bone. Genetic testing was negative for BRCA 1 and 2 mutations. Post-delivery, the patient received chemotherapy with epirubicin 90 mg/m2 and cyclophosphamide 600 mg/m2 for four cycles. Post-delivery, the breast lesion reduced by more than 50% and the size and functionality of the hepatic lesion reduced. A: The primary diagnosis is infiltrating ductal carcinoma of the breast, a grade 3 tumor with increased consistency and irregular margins. Differential diagnoses could include other types of breast cancers, but immunohistochemistry and clinical findings support the primary diagnosis. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the aggressive nature of the cancer and the patient's obstetric history. P: Continue current chemotherapy regimen with trastuzumab and docetaxel. Monitor the patient's progress closely and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Schedule regular follow-up appointments to assess treatment efficacy and manage any complications. Educate the patient on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and adhering to follow-up appointments.

S: The patient reports feeling a lump in the neck near the thyroid, near the thyroid. The patient denies any symptoms of difficulty swallowing, pain in the area, or changes in voice. No family history of thyroid or endocrine diseases was reported. O: Initial thyroid function tests were within normal limits. Fine needle biopsy of the left thyroid nodule was performed. The lesion was diagnosed as "suspicious for neoplasm," and a left hemithyroidectomy was performed. Pathology confirmed papillary thyroid carcinoma with extrathyroidal extension. Pathology review was requested, and no metastatic disease was identified. A: The primary diagnosis is papillary thyroid carcinoma with extrathyroidal extension. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of thyroid cancer or metastatic diseases, but these are less likely given the pathology findings. The prognosis is good with ongoing treatment and no evidence of recurrence. P: The patient is referred to our institution for complete thyroidectomy and radioactive iodine therapy. The treatment plan includes continuation of the thyroidectomy and radioactive iodine therapy, monitoring for recurrence and ensuring no evidence of recurrence. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's progress and ensure no recurrence.

S: The patient reports noticing masses in the left axilla and left supraclavicular area. The patient underwent six cycles of chemotherapy for digestive tract tumors but the cancer progressed. The patient also noticed space-occupying lesions in the left breast 15 months later, which were confirmed by a core needle biopsy. O: Initial biopsies identified poorly differentiated carcinoma (PDC) with Villin positive IHC stains (AE1/AE3+, ER–, PR–, HER-2 0, GCDFP-15–, TTF-1–, and PAX8–). Pathology confirmed PDC with IHC stains (AE1/AE3+, ER–, PR–, HER-2 0, GCDFP-15–, TTF-1–, and PAX8–). Follow-up revealed space-occupying lesions in the left breast. Core needle biopsy confirmed invasive breast cancer. A: The primary diagnosis is poorly differentiated carcinoma with Villin positive IHC stains. Differential diagnosis initially included triple-negative breast cancer, which was ruled out by biopsy. The prognosis is guarded given the complex nature of the disease and the patient's history. P: Continue close monitoring of the patient's condition and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Maintain open communication with the healthcare team and report any new symptoms or concerns. Educate the patient on the importance of reporting new symptoms or concerns immediately.

S: The patient is a 62-year-old male with a history of IgG kappa MM, ISS 1, and anemia. He reports anemia with a hemoglobin level of 10.3g/dl and two isolated bone lesions in his spine. He has a history of diabetes mellitus, atopic dermatitis, Bechterew s disease with severe arthrosis of the right hip, wheelchair-dependent, and a history of severe gastrointestinal bleeding episodes due to angiodysplasia in the jejunum and ileum. He denies any family history of bleeding disorders. O: Laboratory findings show 2-microglobulin at 3.2mg/l, M-gradient at 0.26g/dl, 4%, 90% bone marrow infiltration with plasmatic cells, and a serum free light chain ratio of 8.72. Full body examination was unremarkable. CBC tests showed VWF: Ag 12%, VWF: Act  4%, VIII:C 13.6%, aPTT 51s, bleeding time epinephrin > 220sec, and bleeding time ADP. A: The primary diagnosis is IgG kappa MM, ISS 1, and anemia. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of anemia, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and laboratory findings. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and response to treatment. P: Refer the patient to the department of hemostaseology for further diagnostic workup of the bleeding episodes. Plan to monitor the patient's response to treatment and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Educate the patient on the importance of reporting any new symptoms or concerns immediately. Schedule follow-up appointments to assess treatment efficacy and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient, a 5-year-old with a history of VNS implantation three years ago, reports focal seizures starting with a funny feeling, flushing, and head turning to the right. The patient has experienced bilateral convulsive seizures since age 5. The patient has tried multiple antiseizure medications before VNS implantation, which did not improve seizure frequency. O: MRI and EMU evaluations showed no structural brain abnormalities. Initial MEG recording prior to VNS implantation captured epileptiform activity, but the study did not provide localizing information. Subsequent MEG scans using SAM(g2) showed an equivalent right frontal focus on both recordings, which was not revealed by dipole analysis. A: The primary diagnosis is bilateral convulsive seizure with associated epileptiform discharges. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of epileptiform seizures, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. The prognosis depends on the response to the VNS implantation and the management of the epileptiform discharges. P: The management plan will include further evaluation of the epileptiform discharges and potential adjustments to the treatment plan. The patient is advised to continue monitoring seizure frequency and report any changes or concerns to the healthcare team. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess the effectiveness of the treatment and adjust the plan as necessary.

S: The patient, with a history of congenital hydrocephalus and bilateral VP shunt placement, presents with worsening right-sided abdominal distension and pain over the past three weeks, which has been constant and dull, but not related to meals. The patient has been able to pass flatus and has experienced fevers, chills, nausea, vomiting, headache, visual changes, changes in urination, constipation, melena, or bright red blood in stools. The patient has no history of other abdominal surgeries. O: Physical examination reveals the patient to be comfortable, afebrile, with a heart rate of 84 bpm, respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute, blood pressure of 150/80 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 99% on room air. Abdominal exam shows morbid obesity and distension of the right upper and lower abdomen, dull to percussion, minimally tender in the right upper and lower quadrants, and no erythema or skin changes overlying VP shunt reservoirs. Fundoscopic and neurologic examinations are unremarkable. POCUS revealed a large fluid collection with septations in the soft tissue of the right abdominal wall. CT of the abdomen and pelvis with intravenous contrast confirmed an abdominal pseudocyst. A: The primary diagnosis is an abdominal pseudocyst, likely secondary to VP shunt malfunction. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of abdominal distension and pain, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The patient will be scheduled for an urgent outpatient revision of the right VP shunt. The patient is advised to report any worsening symptoms or worsening symptoms immediately. Further consultations with neurosurgery and possibly a nephrologist may be necessary to manage the pseudocyst. The patient is encouraged to report any new symptoms or worsening symptoms immediately.

S: The patient reports a 6-month history of urinary frequency. The patient denies any significant urologic abnormalities or a history of such issues. O: Physical examination revealed no palpable abdominal mass. Laboratory tests showed no specific abnormalities. Abdominal and pelvis CT scans showed a 20  11 cm, well-defined, fatty mass in the abdominal cavity, compressing the bladder. The mass is benign based on its well-demarcated and homogenous features on the CT scan. A: The primary diagnosis is a benign lipoma of the parietal peritoneum, likely causing the patient's urinary frequency. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of abdominal pain, vomiting, anorexia, or bowel disturbances. P: The management plan includes performing a laparoscopic mass excision with preservation of the parietal peritoneum, involving two 11-mm ports, one supra-umbilically in the left lower abdomen and a 5-mm port in the right lower abdomen. The mass will be excised through the marked line with a monopolar instrument, and the peritoneum will be removed completely. Post-operative care will include preservation of the peritoneum, preservation of the peritoneum, and fixation of the peritoneum using a locking material with a closed suction drain. The patient will be discharged without complications on post-operative day 6. A: The primary diagnosis is a benign lipoma of the parietal peritoneum, likely causing the patient's urinary frequency. The prognosis is good with appropriate surgical intervention. P: The patient will undergo a laparoscopic mass excision with preservation of the parietal peritoneum. Post-operative care will include monitoring for any signs of infection or complications. The patient will be educated on the procedure and expected outcomes, and the patient will be discharged without complications on post-operative day 6. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor recovery and manage any complications.

S: The patient is a 5-year-old girl with no prior medical history, presenting with a 2 month history of a right groin mass and a 15-day history of abdominal swelling. She reports occasional umbilical pain, vomiting, and diarrhea. O: Physical examination revealed acute facial features, malnutrition, abdominal swelling, and tenderness. A mass measuring 4  3  2 cm in the right inguinal region was found. Negative Grey Turner and Cullen signs were noted. Routine blood tests showed white blood cells at 2.97  109/L, neutrophils at 47.2%, RBCs at 4.88  109/L, platelets at 714  109/L, and C-reactive protein at 2.06 mg/L. Abdominal enhanced CT scan showed significant dilated pancreatic duct, cystic low-density shadow, massive peritoneal effusion, patchy lymph node enhancement, and intestinal aggregation. Chest CT showed increased lung markings but no signs of TB. Abdominal puncture revealed red and yellow ascites with positive qualitative protein but no acid-fast bacilli. Anti-TB antibody was negative. Purified protein derivative of the tuberculin test and interferon-gamma release assay was negative. No tumor cells were identified in the ascites and no bacterial growth was noted for 48 hours. A: The primary diagnosis is pancreatitis with complications including pancreatitis, peritoneal effusion, and abdominal distension. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of abdominal swelling and abdominal distension, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition with appropriate treatment for pancreatitis and other findings. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor recovery and prevent complications. The patient is advised to reach out with any concerns or questions during treatment.

S: The patient is a 19-year-old male presenting with painless hematuria for 5 days. He denies any family history of cancer. O: General physical examination and systemic examination were normal. Blood workup showed anemia. Renal function and liver functions were within normal limits. Ultrasound revealed a 7 x 5 cm polypoidal mass attached to the anterior wall of the bladder. CT scan of the abdomen showed no lymph node or visceral metastasis. Robot-assisted partial cystectomy and bilateral lymph node dissection till aortic bifurcation were performed, with histopathology suggesting high-grade urothelial carcinoma with six out of seven nodes showing metastasis. Post-operative complications included fever and intestinal obstruction. Repeat CECT abdomen showed soft tissue lesions in both lungs, pleural effusion, multiple liver lesions, and ascites suggestive of disseminated metastasis. Whole-exome sequencing (WES) analysis revealed 558 exonic somatic mutations, including 360 missense, 26 nonsense, and 30 frameshift deletions/insertions. Ten splice site mutations were identified. Thirty mutations were reported in the COSMIC database. A: The primary diagnosis is high-grade urothelial carcinoma of the urinary bladder, with complications including fever, intestinal obstruction, and disseminated metastasis. Differential diagnosis initially included lymph node or visceral metastasis. The prognosis is guarded due to the aggressive nature of the tumor and the aggressive nature of the tumor. P: The patient underwent robot-assisted partial cystectomy and bilateral lymph node dissection till aortic bifurcation. Post-operative management included conservative management of fever and intestinal obstruction. Whole-exome sequencing revealed 558 exonic somatic mutations, including 360 missense, 26 nonsense, and 30 frameshift deletions/insertions, with 10 splice site mutations. The patient succumbed to the disease. A: The primary diagnosis is high-grade urothelial carcinoma of the urinary bladder, with complications including fever and intestinal obstruction. The patient's condition deteriorated, leading to his death. The prognosis is guarde

S: The patient reports feeling unwell and experiencing discomfort under the right rib. O: Blood tests revealed severe leukocytosis (227  109/L), elevated lactate dehydrogenase (969 U/L), and elevated cobalamin (2834 pmol/L). Blood smear showed dominance of myeloid precursor with increased metamyelocytes and rods. Blood smear indicated a dominance of myeloid precursor with increased metamyelocytes and rods. A: The primary diagnosis is Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML), confirmed by blood tests and clinical presentation. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of myeloid leukemia, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and clinical findings. P: Initiated treatment with hydroxyurea combined with interferon. Proceeded with an allogeneic stem cell transplant (allo-SCT) for consolidation treatment. Post-transplant, PCR analysis for BCR-ABL1 transcripts was performed, and an e13a2 transcript of BCR-ABL1 was detected by nested PCR six years post-allo-SCT. Continuous monitoring of the patient's condition is planned, with regular follow-ups to assess progression and manage any potential complications.

S: The patient, a resident of Chiang Klang District, reports a single skin nodule on the left cheek, approximately 1.0 x 1.5 cm, and crusting at the left angle of the mouth. The symptoms began in May 2014. The patient has not traveled abroad recently. O: Histopathological analysis revealed epidermal ulceration with heavy, chronic inflammation of the dermis, and numerous intracellular small round or oval-shaped bodies with the appearance of amastigotes of Leishmania species. A fresh skin biopsy from the nodule was cultured in Schneider's insect medium with 20% foetal bovine serum (FBS) and 50 International Units penicillin/ml, 50 g/ml streptomycin at 25°C. Motile promastigotes were first observed on day 3 of the culture. A: The primary diagnosis is cutaneous leishmaniasis, confirmed by histopathological findings and culture results. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of skin nodules, but these are less likely given the histopathological findings and culture results. P: The treatment plan includes oral amphotericin B at 1 mg/kg/day for 1 day and fluconazole at 200 mg/day for 45 days. The patient is advised to adhere strictly to the prescribed medication regimen and contact healthcare providers if any questions or concerns arise during treatment.

S: The patient, a male, presented with a chief complaint of multi-colored flashes in the right eye for about a week, which have reduced vision. He reports seeing multi-colored flashes and reduced vision. He has a history of a road traffic accident 3 weeks ago, which was uninjured. O: Examination revealed best-corrected visual acuity of 6/12 in the right eye and 6/6 in the left eye, with no anterior chamber or vitreous cells and no vitreous haze. Spectral domain optical coherence tomography (SD-OCT) indicated hyper-reflective sub-retinal changes and small, well-defined creamy white sub-retinal lesions in the superior macular area of the right eye. No other inflammatory or infective pathologies were found. A: The primary diagnosis is commotio retinae secondary to a whiplash injury from the road traffic accident. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of retinal changes, but these are less likely given the imaging findings and negative inflammatory markers. P: The patient was scheduled for a follow-up in six weeks to monitor the patient's progress and manage any further complications. The patient is advised to monitor for any changes in vision and contact healthcare providers if any further issues arise.

S: The patient reports diffuse abdominal pain and high body temperature. He has a history of high blood pressure and type 2 diabetes, currently on ramipril 5 mg twice daily and metformin 500 mg three times daily. He has a history of bile stones in the gallbladder and common bile duct, underwent endoscopic bile stone extraction, laparoscopic cholecystectomy, and choledochotomy. Post-cholecystectomy, he received a daily dose of prulifloxacin 600 mg for 5 days, and a new antibiotic therapy with oral intake of prulifloxacin 600 mg for 5 days. O: Physical examination revealed bilateral lower diaphragmatic excursion and decreased vocal fremitus, with attenuated sounds at the pulmonary bases. Chest and neurological examinations showed bilateral lower diaphragmatic excursion and decreased vocal fremitus, with attenuated sounds at the pulmonary bases. Neurological examination was normal. Pupils were equal, round, reactive to light, visual fields intact, fundi normal, ocular movements intact, muscle bulk and tone normal, and sensation intact. A: The primary diagnosis is bile stones in the gallbladder and common bile duct, likely secondary to a bile infection or a bile duct infection. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of abdominal pain and dyspnea, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation. P: Plan to perform additional diagnostic tests to confirm the diagnosis and rule out other causes of abdominal pain and dyspnea. Continue monitoring the patient's symptoms and adjust treatment as necessary. Educate the patient on the importance of reporting any worsening symptoms immediately. Schedule follow-up appointments to reassess the patient's condition and adjust treatment as necessary.

S: The patient, with a history of long-standing heart failure with multiple hospital admissions over the past year, reports feeling weak and tired, difficulty breathing, and experiencing cardiac racing sometimes. The patient has a history of Chagas cardiomyopathy confirmed by serology, treated with an implantable cardioverter defibrillator for sudden death secondary prevention. The patient was recently admitted to the emergency room with cardiogenic shock (INTERMACS level 2), managed with two inotropes, an intra-aortic balloon pump, and hemodialysis. O: Echocardiography revealed a severely dilated left ventricle with an end-diastolic diameter of 72 millimeters, severely depressed function with an ejection fraction of 18%, and 4+ mitral regurgitation. The right ventricle showed severe dysfunction with 3+ tricuspid regurgitation, tricuspid annular plane systolic excursion 15, and right ventricular systolic pressure of 65 mmHg. Recent right heart catheterization showed low cardiac output with a cardiac index of 0.9 L/min/m2, systolic pulmonary pressure of 70 mmHg, transpulmonary gradient of 16 mmHg, and pulmonary vascular resistance of 6 Wood units. Cardiopulmonary resuscitation measures were effective, but circulation was maintained with escalating doses of vasopressors. A: The primary diagnosis is end-stage heart failure secondary to Chagas cardiomyopathy, complicated by severe cardiac dysfunction and cardiac arrest. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of cardiac dysfunction, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation. The prognosis is guarded due to the severity of the heart failure and the severity of cardiac dysfunction. P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's cardiac function and cardiac status. The patient will be presented at the heart transplant committee for further evaluation and potential listing for a heart transplantation. The patient will be educated on the importance of adherence to the treatment plan and the importance of regular follow-ups. Referral to a cardiologist for further evaluation and management of heart failure is recommended.

S: The patient, twins, reports bilateral trigger thumb and a trigger finger on the opposite hand. Twin 1 has a bilateral trigger thumb and twin 2 has a trigger thumb and a trigger finger on the opposite hand. The patient's younger sister, 4 years and 9 months old, presents with a single trigger thumb. The parent reports no history of trauma to the fingers. No motor or sensory function issues are noted in the affected digits. O: The twins underwent an A1 pulley release with a flexor digitorum superficialis slip release of the affected digit. The parent reports no history of trauma to the fingers. No motor or sensory function issues are noted in the affected digits. A: The primary diagnosis is bilateral trigger thumb and a trigger finger on the opposite hand. The patient's younger sister presents with a single trigger thumb, which is currently managed conservatively. The patient's condition is currently managed conservatively. No history of trauma to the affected digits is reported. A: The primary diagnosis is bilateral trigger thumb and a trigger finger on the opposite hand. The patient's younger sister presents with a single trigger thumb, which is currently managed conservatively. The patient's condition is currently managed conservatively. The patient's motor and sensory function are normal. P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition and regular follow-ups to assess the progression or improvement of the condition. The parent is advised to report any new symptoms or worsening of their condition immediately. The patient is encouraged to report any new symptoms or worsening of their condition.

S: The patient reports a history of alcohol, cannabis, cocaine, and amphetamine use since age 14, affecting behavior. The patient has a history of drug use and anti-social behavior, which has been affecting his behavior. O: Genetic testing revealed polymorphisms of 5-HTTLPR (fragment 44 bp–SS genotype) and COMT (Leu136Leu) in homozygosity. Neuropsychological examination showed no clinical signs of neurological impairment or alcohol dependence. MRI and CT-PET imaging showed a decrease in cortical thickness with larger lateral ventricles, and a statistically significant volumetric asymmetry of the amygdalae, with the right amygdala smaller. A: The primary diagnosis is a personality disorder, likely related to drug use and anti-social behavior. Differential diagnoses could include other genetic disorders, but these are less likely given the genetic findings. P: The patient is advised to understand the nature of the personality disorder and seek appropriate treatment and support. Further consultations with the legal team and healthcare providers are necessary to address the patient's needs and address the potential for anti-social behavior. Further consultations with a neurologist and a psychiatric specialist are recommended to address the personality disorder.

S: The patient, a 25-year history of erratic use of antihypertensives, presents with vomiting for the past four days and difficulty controlling hypertension. He reports lower back pain managed with non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). He has a history of chronic renal insufficiency and a past liver abscess. O: Physical examination revealed the patient to be afebrile but hypertensive with a blood pressure of 180/100 mmHg and a pulse of 160/min. Vital signs were not provided. Respiratory and cardiovascular examinations were normal. Abdominal ultrasound revealed a 10.3 x 9.6 x 6.7 cm heterogeneous cystic lesion in the right lobe of the liver. CT scan of the chest and abdomen showed a 11.3 x 8.0 cm heterogeneous mass in the right adrenal gland, with no lymphadenopathy. Chest and abdomen scans showed lytic lesions in the left acetabulum, sacrum, right and left iliac blades, and the lumbosacral and thoracic spine. Chest scan showed two nodules in the left lung and multiple lytic lesions in the scapula and vertebrae. Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) level was elevated at 1080 IU/L. A: The primary diagnosis is a liver mass with lytic lesions in the right adrenal gland, likely secondary to erratic use of antihypertensives. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of hypertension, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The patient will undergo a 24-hour urine collection test to assess LDH levels and determine a treatment plan. The patient is advised to continue taking antihypertensive medications as prescribed and monitor blood pressure regularly. Further diagnostic tests will be conducted to determine the cause of the liver mass and to rule out ovarian and gastrointestinal pathologies. The patient is advised to continue taking antihypertensive medications as prescribed and monitor blood pressure regularly.

S: The patient reports experiencing dysphagia and significant body weight loss over the past 3 months. The patient has a history of distal gastrectomy for a submucosal tumor 40 years ago, which was performed without lymph node dissection. The patient also has osteoporosis, causing the patient to be bent over. O: On examination, the patient's BMI was calculated at 21.5. Upper gastrointestinal examination revealed the presence of the postoperative stomach in the thoracic cavity via delayed barium passage. Endoscopic examination indicated absence of esophagitis and tumor in the upper digestive tract. Enhanced computed tomography (eCT) revealed a large hiatal hernia involving the entire stomach, compressing the heart in the posterior mediastinum. No cardiac failure was noted, and echocardiography showed preserved right and left gastric arteries and gastroepiploic arteries. A: The primary diagnosis is a large hiatal hernia involving the entire stomach, compressing the heart in the posterior mediastinum. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of dysphagia, but these are less likely given the imaging and preoperative findings. P: The management plan includes elective surgical repair of the hiatal hernia, with a total of five ports placed in the abdomen, and a Nathanson liver retractor inserted to retract the left liver lobe. A laparoscopic approach will be used to address the slight adhesion of the greater omentum under the postoperative scar and the little adhesion with the liver and spleen. The patient is advised to follow preoperative instructions and reach out with any questions or concerns.

S: The patient, a female, reports being ejected from a truck bed during a truck accident, resulting in a hard landing. She has a history of a complex pelvic fracture and a suspected severe urethral injury. She denies any significant past medical history. O: Upon arrival, the patient was tachycardic but normotensive and oxygenating on room air. Physical examination revealed an unstable pelvis. Digital rectal exam showed a foreign body in the rectal vault. Physical examination revealed lacerations on legs and bruising on hips. CT scan revealed an intraperitoneal bladder rupture, a complex pelvic fracture involving the right sacroiliac joint, a shattered right acetabulum, and a complete right femoral neck fracture. The femoral head was lodged in the pelvis. Intraoperative findings included significant hematoma and fecal contamination in the rectum and perirectal space, which communicated with the acetabular fracture. A: The primary diagnosis is a complex pelvic fracture with a suspected severe urethral injury. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of pelvic instability, but imaging and surgical findings support the primary diagnosis. P: The patient underwent an exploratory laparotomy and anoscopy to confirm the location of the femoral head and causing severe disruption to the right lateral rectum. Post-operative management included fecal diversion and further debridement, irrigation, and drainage of the right perirectal space. The patient was transferred to a long-term care facility out of state for long-term care. Post-operative care will include transfer to a long-term care facility out of state for close monitoring and management.

S: The patient, a gravida 7 para 3, reports a history of one normal vaginal delivery and two cesarean sections. The first cesarean was performed due to vulvar herpes simplex infection, followed by an anterior vertical incision and temporary occlusion of internal iliac arteries. The second cesarean section was performed due to placenta previa, requiring an anterior vertical incision and temporary occlusion of internal iliac arteries. Postpartum complications included intractable uterine hemorrhage. Emergency bilateral UAE with gelatin sponge particles and placement of platinum microcoils in the left uterine artery were performed. O: Initial examination revealed a heterogeneous mass with perivascular flow in the cesarean section scar and an endogenic growth of the gestational products measuring 33 x 15 mm embedded in the transverse scar of the first cesarean section and the vertical scar of the second cesarean section. Three-dimensional computerized tomographic angiography showed the gestational products receiving blood supply from the right uterine artery and an aberrant anastomosing left ovarian artery. The main trunk of the left uterine artery is permanently occluded by platinum microcoils. A: The primary diagnosis is an abnormal placentation with complications including intractable uterine hemorrhage and endogenic growth of the gestational products. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of uterine hemorrhage, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition with regular follow-ups. The patient will be educated on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and adherence to follow-up schedules. Referral to a nephrologist for ongoing management of placenta previa and a obstetrician for ongoing management of placenta previa is recommended.

S: The patient, a male with a history of bilateral varicocele, presented with sudden, sharp, painful swelling in the left hemiscrotum, located in the left inguinal region. The swelling started from the inguinal canal and extends through the entire left scrotum. O: Physical examination revealed a soft mass around the left testis and spermatic cord. Laboratory tests were within normal limits. Doppler ultrasonography of the scrotum showed a hematoma extending from the left superficial inguinal ring to the left hemiscrotum, partially surrounding the left testis, with no active bleeding. MRI of the scrotum confirmed the diagnosis of hematoma. A: The primary diagnosis is a hematoma of the left hemiscrotum, confirmed by Doppler ultrasonography and MRI. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of hematomas, but these are less likely given the imaging results. P: The patient was treated conservatively with bed rest, ice packs, antibiotics, and analgesics. The patient was discharged on the third day, and the ecchymosis was noted at the first hospitalization day. A bilateral varicocele repair was performed three months later. The patient is advised to report any further concerns or questions immediately.

S: The patient, with a history of hypertension, abdominal and thoracic aortic aneurysm, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, presents with pain and bruising in the right thigh for the past 6 days. The patient denies any history of abnormal bleeding, family history of bleeding disorders, or use of anticoagulant medications. O: Physical examination revealed a large subcutaneous hematoma on the anterior aspect of the right thigh, extending posteriorly and laterally. Ultrasound for thrombosis was negative, but magnetic resonance imaging showed intramuscular bleeding into the anterior compartment of the right thigh. Laboratory tests showed a low hemoglobin level at 6.8 g/dL. Computed blood count showed a low hemoglobin level at 6.8 g/dL. Colagation profile showed a prolonged activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) of 52.5 seconds, normal prothrombin time, and normal international normalized ratio. Factor VIII assay was low at 2%, with elevated inhibitor levels at 16 Bethesda units (BU). A: The primary diagnosis is acquired hemophilia A (AHA). The patient's history of hemophilia A and recent chemotherapy with cyclophosphamide and rituximab are significant contributing factors. P: The patient was discharged on a prednisone taper and arranged for an outpatient follow-up with hematology. The treatment plan includes discharging the patient on a prednisone taper and arranging an outpatient follow-up with hematology. The patient will continue receiving weekly rituximab cycles to manage his condition.

S: The patient reports experiencing non-radiating and dull epigastric pain for two weeks, along with fever and chills during dialysis sessions. The patient has a history of ESRD, hypertension, atherosclerotic vascular disease, and pending elective coronary artery bypass graft surgery. He has a history of Streptococcus pneumoniae, Enterobacter cloacae bacteremia, and S. maltophilia bacteremia secondary to an infected dialysis catheter. O: Physical examination revealed mild epigastric tenderness but no redness, discharge, or pain around the dialysis catheter on the right chest. Blood and catheter cultures were positive for S. maltophilia. Chest X-ray indicated left lower lobe pneumonia. Initial workup showed elevated troponin and procalcitonin levels, and Chest X-ray indicated left lower lobe pneumonia. Transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) indicated an artifact on an abandoned ICD lead in the right heart, raising concerns for possible vegetation. Blood cultures were positive for S. maltophilia. A transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) was performed to investigate the cardiac source of the infection. A: The primary diagnosis is left lower lobe pneumonia secondary to an infected dialysis catheter. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of epigastric pain and fever, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation. The prognosis is guarded due to the severity of the infection and the patient's history of ESRD. P: The patient was transferred from the dialysis clinic to the emergency room for further evaluation and management. Intravenous levofloxacin therapy was initiated. Cardiology was consulted due to persistent elevation of troponins, suspected secondary to impaired clearance in ESRD. The infected tunneled dialysis catheter was removed on the 2nd day of hospitalization. A transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) is planned to monitor the patient's progress and adjust treatment as necessary. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately.

S: The patient reports a painful mass on the upper part of the right scapula, which has been achy but has been bothersome, affecting daily activities over the past few months. The patient denies any local injuries or recent surgeries on the affected side. The patient has a history of a similar mass on the other side 10 years ago, which was successfully removed. O: Physical examination revealed the mass to be firm, nonmobile, nonpulsatile, and overlying the scapula. The mass is longer in its medial to lateral dimension than craniocaudad, with slight tenderness with deeper palpation. The shoulder shows no signs of rotator cuff weakness or shoulder pain with provocative maneuvers. X-ray and MRI revealed narrowing of the posterior glenohumeral joint space with sclerosis secondary to osteoarthritic changes. The acromiohumeral interval is 8 mm without superior migration of the humeral head. MRI indicated an elongated lesion from the AC joint, tracking medially to superficial and within the trapezius muscle, measuring 2 cm  13 cm  1.8 cm, cystic with peripheral enhancement, and a suspected full-thickness tear of the anterior fibers of the supraspinatus. A: The primary diagnosis is an elongated lesion in the right scapula, likely secondary to osteoarthritic changes. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of scapula pain, but these are less likely given the size and location of the mass. P: The management plan includes referral to a specialist for further evaluation and treatment of the elongated lesion. The patient will be educated on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and avoiding provocative maneuvers. Referral to a neurologist for further evaluation and management of the elongated lesion is recommended. The patient is encouraged to contact healthcare providers if any concerns arise.

S: The patient reports significant pain in the left lower leg and foot following a high energetic accident. The patient has preserved active extension and flexion of the toes, sensibility in the toes and forefoot, and disturbed sensibility to touch and pain at the foot sole. No signs of compartment syndrome were noted. O: Clinical examination revealed multiple fractures including a Gustilo grade IIIB fracture, medial malleolus fracture, Tillaux-Chaput fracture, nutcracker fracture of the cuboid, avulsion fracture of the navicular bone, fractures of the third, fourth, and fifth metatarsal head, a mid-shaft fracture of the third proximal phalanx, and base fractures of the first and second proximal phalanx. Postoperative findings included preserved active extension and flexion of the toes, sensibility in the toes and forefoot, disturbed sensibility to touch, and pain at the foot sole. NIRF imaging was performed using the FluobeamTM imaging head. A: The primary diagnosis is a Gustilo grade IIIB fracture of the medial malleolus fracture, nutcracker fracture of the cuboid, avulsion fracture of the navicular bone, fractures of the third, fourth, and fifth metatarsal head, a mid-shaft fracture of the third proximal phalanx, and base fractures of the first and second proximal phalanx. Differential diagnoses could include compartment syndrome or other causes of fractures. The prognosis is guarded due to the complexity of the fractures and the absence of compartment syndrome. P: The patient underwent a second debridement approximately 2.5 days postoperatively to further clean and treat the affected areas. The plan includes close monitoring of healing and potential additional treatments or surgeries if necessary. The patient is advised to follow up with the medical team and report any changes in symptoms or concerns.

S: The patient reports noticing a growing mass on the forehead, predominantly on the right side of the forehead, following a head injury two weeks ago. The swelling is tender and predominantly on the right side of the forehead. O: Physical examination revealed a two-centimeter, soft, pulsatile mass in the right frontotemporal region. Point-of-care ultrasound with color Doppler showed a dilated vascular structure with pulsatile, bidirectional flow, suggesting a traumatic superficial temporal artery pseudoaneurysm. CT angiography confirmed the diagnosis of a traumatic superficial temporal artery pseudoaneurysm. A: The primary diagnosis is a traumatic superficial temporal artery pseudoaneurysm, likely secondary to a head injury. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of forehead swelling, but these are less likely given the imaging results and imaging results. P: The patient underwent surgical ligation of the pseudoaneurysm. Post-operative care will include monitoring for complications such as infection or recurrence of symptoms. The patient will be educated on the importance of follow-up appointments to monitor recovery and manage any complications. Referral to a vascular surgeon for further evaluation and management of the pseudoaneurysm is recommended.

S: The patient, a male with a history of hypertension, presented with sudden onset of severe abdominal pain, described as sharp and sudden. He denies any history of renal calculus. O: Physical examination revealed a blood pressure of 135/75 mmHg, pulse of 90 bpm, and temperature of 36.5°C. The abdomen was distended and tender to palpitation. Laboratory findings included increased leukocytes (11,400/L), normal serum electrolytes, blood urea nitrogen level of 20 mmol/L, and serum creatinine level of 1.2 mg/dl. Chest X-ray showed no cardiomegaly or abnormal findings. Contrast-enhanced CT scan revealed a large left internal iliac aneurysm (6.5 cm in diameter), with no blood extravasation into the periaortic soft tissue and specific CT signs of an inflammatory aneurysm. Left hydroureteronephrosis and leakage of iodinated urine were noted in the left-side retroperitoneum. A ureteral double-J stent was placed under endoscopic and X-ray fluoroscopic guidance, and endovascular aortic repair (EVAR) was performed under general anesthesia. A: The primary diagnosis is a large left internal iliac aneurysm with a spontaneous ureteral rupture. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of abdominal pain, but imaging and clinical findings support the primary diagnosis. The prognosis is guarded due to the severity of the aneurysm and the patient's history of hypertension. P: The patient underwent endovascular coil deployment within the left IIA and endovascular stent grafting from the left common iliac. Post-operative care will include monitoring for any signs of infection or complications. The patient is advised to attend all follow-up appointments and report any new symptoms or concerns immediately. Further treatment options may be considered based on the patient's response to the treatment and follow-up findings.

S: Mr. Johnson, a 75-pack year smoker and rare alcohol use, presented with a recent asymptomatic mass on the left side of his neck. He reports occasional discomfort but no symptoms of difficulty swallowing or pain in the neck. O: Biopsy confirmed squamous cell carcinoma (SCC). PET/CT scan showed hypermetabolic activity in the right aryepiglottic fold without corresponding CT findings and multiple involved ipsilateral lymph nodes. Triple endoscopy revealed the aryepiglottic fold lesion and tiny lesions in the carina and right/left mainstem bronchi. Biopsies of these lesions confirmed SCC, staining positive for p40 and negative for TTF-1, confirming the tumor's supraglottic origin. A: The primary diagnosis is squamous cell carcinoma of the right supraglottic fold, staged as cT2N2bM1. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of squamous cell carcinomas, but these are less likely given the imaging and biopsy results. P: The patient will be treated with definitive radiation therapy concurrently with weekly cisplatin. IMRT will deliver a total of 70 Gy to the aryepiglottic fold primary lesion, 60 Gy to the ipsilateral neck and larynx, 54 Gy to the contralateral neck, and 50 Gy to most of the tracheobronchial tree. Four-dimensional computed tomography (4DCT) simulation will be used to define the internal target volume, 0.5 cm volumetrically, and 0.5 cm volumetrically. Dosimetric parameters will be used to select organs at risk (OARs). A: The primary diagnosis is squamous cell carcinoma of the right supraglottic fold, staged as cT2N2bM1. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and response to treatment. P: The treatment plan includes definitive radiation therapy concurrently with weekly cisplatin. The patient will be monitored closely for any side effects, including grade 3 esophagitis, weight loss, and hospitalization with aspiration pneumonia. The patient will be educated on the importance of compliance with the treatment regimen and expected outcomes. Regular follow-up appointments

S: The patient, a 4-year-old male, presented with fever, abdominal pain, an enlarged spleen, and hyperleukocytosis. He reported no spleen invasion. O: Physical examination revealed a massive invasion of the bone marrow with 50% myeloid leukemia cells, but no central nervous system invasion. Karyotype analysis confirmed a monosomy of chromosome 7. Biopsy post-induction phase showed dysplastic precursor myeloid cells. Immunophenotypic analysis showed persistent CD34+ CD117+ CD33 blast cells. Hematopoietic Stem Cell Transplant (HSCT) was initiated, and conditioning treatment was initiated. At day -3, peripheral blood flow cytometric analysis showed blast cells (13% of leukocytes; 21 blast cells/L). A: The primary diagnosis is high-risk AML with Myelodysplasia-related changes (AML-MDC). Differential diagnoses could include other forms of myeloid leukemia, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and immunophenotypic analysis. P: The management plan includes continuation of Hematopoietic Stem Cell Transplant (HSCT) with conditioning treatment. The patient will continue to receive high doses of ARA-C (4 g/m2/die) for 5 days prior to the transplant, L-PAM (200 mg/m2), and antithymocyte globulin (6.3 mg/kg/die for three days) to prepare his body for the transplant. Regular monitoring of the patient's condition is necessary, with adjustments to treatment as necessary based on the patient's response to the treatment.

S: The patient, a young female, presented with left elbow pain and swelling for the past 3 days. She reported falling while playing and hurting her elbow. O: Initial X-ray revealed a proximal fracture of the ulna and an associated radial head dislocation. A manipulation and closed reduction was performed, followed by a cast placement. The patient was advised to rest and avoid pressure on the elbow while healing. A follow-up appointment was scheduled to monitor recovery and ensure no complications were reported. A: The primary diagnosis is a Monteggia fracture of the ulna with associated radial head dislocation. The patient underwent successful manipulation and reduction, which was performed successfully. P: The patient underwent a cast placement for at least a few weeks. Post-treatment, the cast was placed, and a follow-up appointment was scheduled to monitor recovery and ensure no complications were reported. The patient is advised to follow up for follow-up appointments to monitor recovery and ensure no complications arise.

S: The patient, with a history of metastatic angiosarcoma treated with doxorubicin and ifosfamide, reports a recent start of Pazopanib at 800 mg per day. Post-treatment, the patient experienced increased total bilirubin to twice the upper limit of normal with minimal elevation of direct bilirubin. The patient has been on Pazopanib for nine months and reports partial remission of the angiosarcoma. O: The patient's pazopanib Cmin is 29.9 mg/L, indicating partial remission. The patient has been on Pazopanib for nine months and has experienced partial remission of the angiosarcoma. A: The primary diagnosis is metastatic angiosarcoma with a history of Gilbert syndrome. The patient's pazopanib treatment has been effective with partial remission of the angiosarcoma. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of metastatic angiosarcoma, but these are less likely given the patient's history of Gilbert syndrome. P: Continue current Pazopanib treatment with regular monitoring of pazopanib Cmin levels. Maintain current regimen of 400 mg per day, 200 mg per day, with a 1-week-on and 1-week-off schedule. Regular follow-ups with oncology and oncology are recommended to monitor the patient's response to the treatment and manage any side effects. Educate the patient on the importance of adherence to the current treatment regimen and follow-up schedules.

S: The patient, a male with a history of CF diagnosed in adulthood, presents with a chief complaint of general unwellness. He reports an increased cough but is mostly non-productive. He has a history of osteoporosis and pancreatic insufficiency. He is currently on maintenance treatment for allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA) with oral anti-fungal therapy and long-term low-dose oral corticosteroids. O: The patient's sputum sample was cultured with blood agar, chocolate agar, Sabouraud agar, Staphylococcus agar, m-Kleb agar, and cepacia selective agar. The sputum sample was cultured with blood agar, chocolate agar, Sabouraud agar, Staphylococcus agar, m-Kleb agar, and cepacia selective agar. The sputum sample was cultured with blood agar, chocolate agar, Sabouraud agar, Staphylococcus agar, m-Kleb agar, and cepacia selective agar. A: The primary diagnosis is CF with a mild drop in lung function and non-epidemic Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of lung dysfunction, but these are less likely given the patient's non-specific symptoms and mild drop in FEV1. P: The management plan includes continued monitoring of the patient's lung function, with adjustments to the treatment plan based on the patient's response to the treatment. A follow-up appointment in 4 weeks is scheduled to reassess the patient's condition and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. The patient's family history of pancreatitis and a family history of pancreatitis are significant contributing factors to the patient's condition.

S: The patient, previously treated with EVAR for an infrarenal aortic aneurysm, reports pain in the abdomen and back, and a pulsating sensation in the stomach area. Recently, the patient has experienced lower back pain. O: Previous treatment with EVAR included a Zenith® LP with a graft diameter of 28 mm and aortic neck dilatation of 30 mm and stent graft migration of 8 mm below the left renal artery. Follow-up CT imaging revealed a type IA EL with aortic neck dilatation of 30 mm and stent graft migration of 8 mm below the left renal artery. The patient underwent a proximal cuff stent graft relining and endoanchor suture using 3D-IF guidance. A: The primary diagnosis is a type IA EL with aortic neck dilatation of 30 mm and stent graft migration of 8 mm below the left renal artery. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of abdominal and back pain, but imaging and surgical findings support the primary diagnosis. P: The patient underwent a proximal cuff stent graft relining and endoanchor suture using 3D-IF guidance. Postoperative care includes regular check-ups and imaging tests to monitor for any new symptoms or discomfort. The patient is advised to maintain a healthy lifestyle, including regular exercise and a balanced diet to prevent future complications. Further consultations with a nephrologist and a pulmonologist are recommended to manage the stent graft and prevent further complications.

S: The patient is a 33-year-old primigravida at 32 weeks gestation, presenting with severe chest pain in the epigastric area, worsening over the past two days. She reports shortness of breath and worsening oliguria. She was previously diagnosed with mild preeclampsia. O: Initial laboratory tests at 03:52 were unremarkable. Platelet count increased from 195 K/uL to "unable to perform count, platelets clumped on slide," AST increased from 183 u/L to 3180 u/L, and ALT increased from 221 u/L to 3495 u/L. Thromboelastogram (TEG) indicated features of coagulopathy. Initial blood pressure was 199/100 mm Hg. A: The primary diagnosis is severe coagulopathy secondary to GERD. Differential diagnoses include thrombocytopenia and thrombocytopenia. The patient's coagulopathy complicates the management of GERD. P: The management plan includes urgent cesarean delivery due to severe coagulopathy. The patient will be started on intravenous magnesium for seizure prophylaxis and treatment for HELLP syndrome. The patient will be monitored for any signs of thrombocytopenia or complications from the cesarean delivery. Education on signs of thrombocytopenia and the importance of fluid intake will be provided. Referral to a cardiologist for further evaluation and management of coagulopathy is recommended.

S: The patient, with a history of ulcerative colitis, steroid-induced diabetes mellitus, deep vein thrombosis in the left thigh, ecchymotic skin lesions, swelling in the left nose, ptosis, and facial nerve palsy, reports experiencing intense intestinal bleeding post-Islamic fasting month, Ramadan. The patient also experienced progressive periorbital ecchymosis, extensive edema of the nasal area, and a nasal ulcer. O: The patient was on azathioprine 50 mg/day and high-dose prednisolone 60 mg/day for 2 months prior to hospital admission. During the treatment, prednisolone caused blood sugar to increase, leading to insulin therapy. The patient developed progressive periorbital ecchymosis, extensive edema of the nasal area, and a nasal ulcer. Eye examination revealed proptosis with a 4+ light reaction, evidence of an afferent pupillary defect, absolute blindness, ophthalmoplegia, and neurological defects of cranial nerves 2, 3, 4, and 6. Laboratory tests showed a fast blood sugar of 302 mg/dL, WBC 9460/l, RBC 3.53106/l, platelets 60103/l, hemoglobin 8.9 g/dl, BUN 35 mg/dL, serum creatinine 2.3 mg/dl, potassium 2.1 mg/dL, body temperature 38°C, blood pressure 120/70 mm/Hg, pulse rate 80/min, and respiratory rate 14/min. A: The primary diagnosis is ulcerative colitis with complications including progressive periorbital ecchymosis, extensive edema of the nasal area, and a nasal ulcer. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of periorbital ecchymosis and ophthalmoplegia. The prognosis depends on the management of the ulcerative colitis and diabetes. P: Continue current medications and monitor blood sugar levels closely. Regular follow-ups with the healthcare team are essential to manage the patient's condition effectively. Educate the patient on the importance of medication adherence

S: The patient reports a significant headache (10/10 intensity), lightheadedness, confusion, and loss of balance since yesterday. The patient denies any significant past medical history. O: Initial CT scan revealed a hyperdense lesion on the right side of the brain at the level of the peri-pontine cistern. MRI scan revealed a 4.1 x 3.3 x 3.2 cm mass in the brain, causing mild tonsillar herniation and a mass effect on the brainstem, with a patchy enhancement. Physical examination showed a positive Babinski sign bilaterally. Physical examination was negative for loss of proprioception and loss of cerebellar function. CT scans of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis identified a right thyroid nodule, no lung mass, and a 2.3 cm renal cyst. A right suboccipital craniotomy was performed on Day 2 of admission to remove the mass in the brain. Intraoperative findings included a positive Babinski sign bilaterally, but negative for loss of proprioception and loss of cerebellar function. A: The primary diagnosis is classic medulloblastoma, World Health Organization grade IV, characterized by densely packed cells. Differential diagnoses could include other neuroepithelial neoplasms, but these are less likely given the imaging findings and clinical presentation. P: The patient underwent a right suboccipital craniotomy on Day 2 of admission to remove the mass in the brain. The intraoperative report will help identify the type of neoplasm and the CD45 marker will be checked to rule out lymphoproliferative disorder. The treatment plan will be discussed with the oncology team and kept informed. The patient will be educated on the importance of early detection of potential complications and the importance of follow-up appointments.

S: The patient reports experiencing gross hematuria for about a year, which has been occurring intermittently. The patient has undergone multiple diagnostic tests including ultrasound, intravenous pyelography, contrast enhancement, and plain CT scans of the kidney, as well as a renal biopsy. O: The patient was admitted to pediatric surgery in November 2002 with a cystourethroscopy revealing urethral mucosa edema, mass, miliary bulging, and bleeding of the membranous urethra. Pathological analysis confirmed submucosal vascular dilatation of the urethra, consistent with UCH. Post-treatment, pingyangmycin was administered under the cystoscope, injected 4 mg of pingyangmycin into the bulge on the urethral membrane. Follow-ups at 1 year, 12 years, and 15 years post-treatment have shown no recurrence of gross hematuria and normal micturition and erectile function. A: The primary diagnosis is UCH with complications including urethral mucosa edema, mass, miliary bulging, and bleeding of the membranous urethra. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of hematuria, but these are less likely given the imaging and pathological findings. P: The patient underwent a cystourethroscopy two weeks post-treatment with pingyangmycin, which was administered 4 mg of pingyangmycin. Post-operative follow-ups at 1 year, 12 years, and 15 years post-treatment have shown no recurrence of gross hematuria and normal micturition and erectile function. The patient is advised to continue monitoring for any recurrence of hematuria and to report any new symptoms immediately.

S: The patient reports experiencing mild dyspnea on exertion. The patient has a history of right upper lobectomy and right S6b wedge resection for synchronous double lung cancer 5 years ago. O: CT scan revealed metachronous double lung tumors in the right lower lobe (S6a and S9) and left diaphragmatic eventration. CT images showed a right S2 tumor and a right S6b peripheral tumor. Chest X-ray confirmed these findings. Pulmonary function test (PFT) was poor with a forced vital capacity (FVC) of 1.54 L, %FVC of 70.0%, FEV1 of 0.92 L, FEV1/FVC of 59.7%, and %FEV1 of 58.6%. A: The primary diagnosis is metachronous double lung tumors in the right lower lobe (S6a and S9) and left diaphragmatic eventration. Differential diagnoses initially included double primary carcinomas, which were ruled out based on imaging and pulmonary function tests. P: The management plan includes Video-Assisted Thoracoscopic Surgery (VATS) diaphragm plication with CO2 insufflation to improve pulmonary function. Post-operative care will include close monitoring of the patient's condition and reassessment of the patient's condition. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess progress and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient, a female, was involved in a car accident, resulting in significant front-end damage and airbag deployment. She reported difficulty breathing but did not recall much. O: Upon arrival at Advocate Christ Medical Center, the patient was unresponsive with a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) of 5. She was intubated for airway protection. She was tachycardic and hypotensive with a heart rate of 143 bpm and blood pressure of 71/46 mmHg. Focused sonography for trauma (FAST) showed no intra-abdominal or pericardial fluid. A left sided hemothorax was noted on chest x-ray. A chest tube was placed with 1200 mL of bloody output. During surgery, a left anterolateral thoracotomy incision was made, with significant blood entering the chest cavity without cardiac tamponade. Cross clamping the pulmonary hilum was attempted, but the bleeding continued. No end tidal CO2 was noted. Cardiac massage was performed, and a 3 cm defect was found in the anterior right atrium. A: The primary diagnosis is a left sided hemothorax secondary to a car accident. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of hemorrhage, but these are less likely given the imaging and surgical findings. P: The patient underwent a left anterolateral thoracotomy incision, with significant blood entry into the chest cavity, no cardiac tamponade, and no end tidal CO2.
