Post-operative management included resuscitation with massive transfusions, cardiac massage, and a left anterolateral thoracotomy incision. The patient's blood loss was over 6 liters. The family was advised to report any concerns or complications immediately.

S: The patient reports experiencing respiratory discomfort. The patient has a history of ALS diagnosed at age 57 and TIV at age 60 due to progressive dyspnea. O: Initial ECG showed negative T waves in V1-V6, and echocardiography indicated decreased wall motion over the entire circumference of the apical region. Blood tests showed increased white blood cells, transaminase, gamma-glutamyl transpeptidase, and C-reactive protein. Abdominal CT indicated wall thickening of the common bile duct, consistent with acute cholangitis. Post-treatment, the patient was successfully treated with antibiotics, revealing the wall motion abnormality and symptoms completely disappeared. A: The primary diagnosis is acute cholangitis, likely secondary to a bile duct infection. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of respiratory discomfort, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The patient was treated with antibiotics for acute cholangitis, which resolved the wall motion abnormality and symptoms. The patient is advised to follow up with their regular doctor to monitor for any recurrence of symptoms. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's response to treatment and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient is a 34-year-old primigravida mother presenting with a chief complaint of anxiety since her first pregnancy. She reports feeling okay but expresses concern about her baby girl's condition. The mother has a history of polyhydramnios diagnosed at 33 weeks of pregnancy, which led to the diagnosis of polyhydramnios. The mother has been aware of the changes in the fetal limbs and biophysical profile. O: The first-trimester morphology scan showed normal results including crown-rump length, visible nasal bone, and normal nuchal translucency value. Double marker for chromosomal aneuploidies (13, 18, and 21) indicated a low-level risk. TORCH IgM and IgG screening showed no acute or recent infection, negative IgM, and high IgG titer. The second-trimester scan at 22 weeks confirmed normal development of a female fetus. At 33 weeks of pregnancy, the amniotic fluid quantity increased, leading to polyhydramnios. The fetal heart rate was significantly altered, with significant decelerations, abnormal fetal movement, and poor muscular tonus. The newborn was delivered prematurely via an emergency C-section at 36 weeks, with an APGAR score of 3. Post-surgery, the newborn's condition deteriorated, requiring assisted mechanical ventilation. A: The primary diagnosis is polyhydramnios with complications including polyhydramnios, minor clubfoot, and altered fetal biophysical profile. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of fetal distress, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. The prognosis is guarded due to the severity of the condition and the potential for respiratory failure. P: The management plan includes continued monitoring of the newborn's vital signs and vital signs, with adjustments to the C-section schedule as necessary. The mother is advised to maintain supportive care and report any new symptoms or concerns immediately. The team will continue to provide the best possible care for the baby, but the mother is advised to maintain a close eye on her baby's condition and ensure she understands the risks and benefits of the C-section.

The prognosis is guarded due to the history of migraines. P: The management plan includes prescribing stronger analgesia or painkillers. The patient is advised to keep a headache diary to monitor for any worsening of headaches. She will be referred to a neurologist for further evaluation and management. S: The patient reports recurrent wheezing and breathlessness during exercise for several months five years ago, with a history of allergic rhinitis. The patient has been on rapid acting 2-agonist and inhaled glucocorticoids, with a positive response to the initial treatment. The patient also reports recurrent petechia on lower limbs over the past three years, with no fever, edema, fatigue, or weight loss. O: Physical examination revealed decreased sensation in the lower extremities. Chest CT, CT angiography (CTA), bronchoscopy, and echocardiography were performed to exclude respiratory tract infection, foreign body aspiration, airway developmental anomalies, cardiovascular diseases, and tumors. Laboratory tests showed elevated serum eosinophil (6.8  109/L, reference 0–0.8  109/L), and immunoglobulin E (IgE 1128 IU/mL, reference 0–165 IU/mL, reference 0–165 IU/mL). Spirometry indicated a  12% increase in predicted FEV1. The patient has been on double inhaled glucocorticosteroid and leukotriene modifier, with gradual decrease in dosage over time. No fever, edema, fatigue, or weight loss were reported. A: The primary diagnosis is asthma with a history of refractory asthma and recurrent petechia on lower limbs. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of numbness, arthralgia, and myalgia, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: Continue monitoring the patient's respiratory status and eosinophil levels closely. Adjust the dosage of the double inhaled glucocorticosteroid and leukotriene modifier as needed. Regular follow-ups with a neurologist and a pulmonologist are recommended to assess the effectiveness of the treatment and manage any recurrence. Educate the patient on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and adherence to the treatment regimen. Consider referral to a pulmonologist for further evaluation and management of asthma.

S: The patient, previously diagnosed with primary MCC on the forearm 3 years ago, reports recurrent, metastatic MCC involving liver, bones, and disseminated lymphadenopathy. The patient has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, coronary artery disease treated with stenting, gastroesophageal reflux, and mild cerebral palsy. The patient has been taking lisinopril, simvastatin, aspirin, omeprazole, and zolpidem for hypertension, hyperlipidemia, coronary artery disease treated with stenting, gastroesophageal reflux, and mild cerebral palsy. O: Physical examination revealed a stable speech impediment. Post-treatment, the patient experienced diffuse muscle aches, urinary retention, abdominal distention, and a sensation of gagging when swallowing. The patient was hospitalized on day 11 post-immunotherapy for supportive care. A CT scan showed air-filled loops of small and large bowels and an increased stool burden within the right colon. A: The primary diagnosis is metastatic MCC with complications including diffuse muscle aches, urinary retention, abdominal distention, and gagging. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of metastatic cancers, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation. The prognosis is guarded due to the severity of the disease and the patient's comorbidities. P: Continue supportive care with oxycodone 5 mg every 4-6 hours. Monitor the patient's response to immunotherapy and adjust treatment as necessary. Educate the patient on signs of worsening symptoms and encourage immediate reporting of any new symptoms. Schedule follow-up appointments to assess treatment efficacy and manage any complications.

S: The patient, a two-month-old male, presented with a left postauricular mass since birth, which has been painless but slowly growing. The parent reported that the mass was initially suspected to be a cystic mass. O: Physical examination revealed a firm 2  2 cm subcutaneous lesion in the postauricular region. MRI showed a 2.3  1.4  2.2 cm solid mass involving the outer table of the right temporal bone and temporoparietal suture with intense peripheral enhancement. Initial resection was performed, but pathology indicated tumor cells at the peripheral margins. Repeat resection with canal wall up mastoidectomy and canal wall up mastoidectomy were performed, resected en bloc and drilled to the inner table of the temporal bone, with significant regrowth of the lesion. Revision mastoidectomy and full-thickness craniectomy were performed, and the mass was excised en bloc, resulting in a full-thickness craniectomy. Postoperative complications included purulence at the incision site, which resolved with intra-washout with neurosurgery. A: The primary diagnosis is a postauricular mass, initially suspected to be a cystic mass. The patient underwent successful surgical excision of the mass, followed by a full-thickness craniectomy. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic with no evidence of disease. P: The patient underwent a full-thickness craniectomy and was discharged home on postoperative day one with no further complications. The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition and regular follow-up appointments to assess for any recurrence or complications. The patient will continue to be educated on signs of infection and the importance of regular follow-up.

S: The patient, diagnosed with metastatic melanoma on the right arm in March 2012, reports feeling unwell after two cycles of treatment with DTIC and carboplatinum. During treatment, the patient experienced a progressive disease and two new asymptomatic MBM were diagnosed. The patient denies any symptoms at that time. O: The patient's melanoma was classified as Clark IV with a Breslow thickness of 2.5 mm. In August 2013, treatment with DTIC and carboplatinum was discontinued due to a progressive disease. In November 2014, Stereotactic Radiotherapy (SRT) was initiated, followed by ipilimumab at 3 mg/kg. In March 2014, two new asymptomatic MBM were diagnosed, and a systemic treatment with fotemustine was initiated in June 2014. Post-surgery, the patient was able to stop taking corticosteroids. Histological analysis confirmed radiation necrosis. A: The primary diagnosis is metastatic melanoma with a Breslow thickness of 2.5 mm. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of metastatic melanoma, but these are less likely given the histological findings. The prognosis is guarded due to the progression of the disease and the presence of radiation necrosis. P: Continue current regimen of pembrolizumab. Monitor the patient's response to treatment and adjust as necessary based on histological findings. Continue monitoring the patient's condition closely and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Educate the patient on the importance of adherence to the treatment regimen and follow-up appointments.

S: The patient, a male with a history of poorly-controlled diabetes type 2, hypertension, dyslipidemia, and obesity, presented with persistent, non-pleuritic, non-radiating, retrosternal chest pain for the past 2 hours. He reported shortness of breath, dizziness, and sweating but no loss of consciousness, cough, palpitations, or swelling of the extremities. He has a history of a similar chest pain a week ago treated with a 325mg dose of Aspirin. O: Vital signs showed a pulse rate of 84 bpm, BP 119/66 mm/Hg, respiration rate 16 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation 98% on room air. Vital signs included a pulse rate of 84 bpm, BP 119/66 mm/Hg, respiration rate 16 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation 98% on room air. Laboratory tests showed elevated troponin at 0.19ng/ml, hemoglobin 14.4g/dl, and platelet count 210  103/ul. EKG indicated deep T wave inversions in leads V1–V6 and inferior limb leads. A: The primary diagnosis is non-ST elevation myocardial infarction, likely secondary to a non-ST elevation myocardial infarction. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of myocardial infarction, but these are less likely given the elevated troponin and EKG findings. P: Initiated a loading dose of Aspirin (325 mg) and Plavix (300 mg) orally, Atorvastatin (80 mg) and Enoxaparin. Close monitoring of the patient's condition is necessary, with adjustments to treatment as necessary based on the patient's response to treatment. Regular follow-ups will be scheduled to assess the effectiveness of the treatment and adjust as necessary.

S: The patient is a 44-year-old Caucasian male who underwent a living unrelated donor kidney transplant. He reports feeling okay overall following the transplant. He has experienced worsening graft function, increasing proteinuria, active urine sediment, and elevated rheumatoid factor (RF 1650 IU/ml). O: Post-transplant, the patient's baseline post-perfusion allograft biopsy was unremarkable. Post-transplant, serum creatinine stabilized to 1.6 to 1.8 mg/dl, and urine protein/creatinine ratio was less than 0.5 g/gram. Six months post-transplant, everolimus was changed to cyclosporine due to arthralgias, and everolimus was reduced to 400 ng/ml. Recent kidney biopsy revealed 18 enlarged glomeruli with diffuse endocapillary proliferative glomerulonephritis, strong (3+) diffuse granular mesangial and capillary wall staining for C4d, IgG, and kappa, with an IgG kappa monoclonal spike (214 mg/dl), serum free kappa light chains 189 mg/L, free lambda light chains 75 mg/L, kappa:lambda ratio 2.5 (normal range 0.26 to 1.65), complements C3 126 (normal range 87–200 mg/dl), and C4 38 (normal range 18–52 mg/dl). A: The primary diagnosis is recurrence of MPGN in the transplanted kidney, evidenced by increased proteinuria, elevated rheumatoid factor, and biopsy findings. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of graft dysfunction, but these are less likely given the biopsy results and clinical presentation. P: The management plan includes close monitoring of kidney function and adjustment of the medication regimen as necessary. Regular follow-up appointments are scheduled to monitor kidney function and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. The patient is advised to adhere strictly to the treatment regimen and adhere to follow-up appointments to ensure optimal outcomes.

S: The patient, diagnosed with seropositive RA in 2015, reports progressive neurological symptoms starting a week ago, including confusion, apathy, difficulty finding words, right-sided weakness, and gait imbalance. The patient has a history of seropositive RA treated with methotrexate, hydroxychloroquine, and low-dose prednisone (10 mg daily). O: Neurological examination revealed decreased attention span, severe expressive aphasia, bilateral postural tremor, right hemiparesis, hypoesthesia, and shuffling and wide-based gait. Clinical evaluation by rheumatology confirmed no synovitis and no extra-articular RA involvement. Gadolinium-enhanced head MRI indicated scattered restricted diffusion and enhancement in the cortex and leptomeninges of the left hemisphere near the vertex, suggestive of meningoencephalitis. CSF analysis showed 6 WBCs, 85% lymphocytes, 15% monocytes, protein concentration of 0.86 g/L (normal 0.15–0.45 g/L), and normal glucose content. CSF bacterial and fungal cultures, cryptococcal antigen, herpes simplex virus, syphilis, serum C-reactive protein was markedly elevated at 135 mg/L (normal 0–5 mg/L). Antinuclear antibodies, anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies, human immunodeficiency virus, anti-onconeural antibodies, methotrexate blood levels, immunoglobin G4-subclass titers, and QuantiFERON-TB testing for Mycobacterium tuberculosis were negative. Serum angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) level was mildly elevated at 66 U/L. A: The primary diagnosis is meningoencephalitis, likely secondary to seropositive RA. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of neurological symptoms, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and response to treatment. P: Continue monitoring neurological symptoms and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Regular follow-ups are necessary to assess the effectiveness of the treatment and adjust as necessary.

S: The patient, a nurse with a history of inguinal hernia, reports no malignancy-related symptoms such as fatigue, unintended weight loss, or changes in bowel habits. The patient denies any malignancy-related symptoms such as fatigue, unintended weight loss, or changes in bowel habits. O: Physical examination revealed a temperature of 36.7°C, blood pressure of 138/78 mm Hg, heart rate of 76 bpm, and oxygen saturation of 98% in room air. Auscultation showed normal heart and lung sounds, and oropharyngeal and abdominal examinations were normal. No periodontal disease was noted. Laboratory tests showed a white blood cell count of 9,430 leucocytes/mm3 with 63% neutrophils, hemoglobin of 153 g/L, and platelet count of 205  109/L. C-reactive protein was elevated at 83 mg/dL (normal 5 mg/dL). RT-PCR test was negative on hospitalization day 1. A thoracic CT scan revealed ground glass opacities. A: The primary diagnosis is a solitary pulmonary nodule in the right mid-lung, likely a primary lung tumor or metastasis of unknown origin. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of lung tumors or metastases, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The management plan will include a referral to a pulmonologist for further evaluation and management of the pulmonary nodule. The patient will be educated on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and follow-up appointments to monitor for any recurrence or new symptoms. Further diagnostic workup will be necessary to assess the extent of the pulmonary nodule and manage any potential complications.

S: The patient is a 19-year-old high school student with a history of ICD-10 F41.2 mixed anxiety and depressive disorder, and symptoms of anorexia nervosa. She reports a history of a private adolescent psychiatric clinic for her anorexia nervosa. She has a history of a father who did not respond positively to her performance but showed disappointment if she did not achieve an A in exams. She has a history of overperforming in school and sports, and has developed an eating disorder. She maintains good relationships with her friends, mother, and siblings. O: The patient's clinical presentation is classified as Anorexia Nervosa in the context of Personality Difficulty, with features of Negative Affectivity, depressivity, shame, anxiety, and Anankastia. The patient's clinical presentation is classified as Personality Difficulty, with Negative Affectivity and Anankastia. A: The primary diagnosis is Anorexia Nervosa, with a history of Negative Affectivity and Anankastia. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of Anorexia Nervosa, but these are less likely given the patient's family history and clinical presentation. P: The management plan will focus on addressing the patient's anxiety, depressive disorder, and anorexia nervosa symptoms. The patient will be educated on the importance of adherence to the treatment plan and adherence to the treatment plan. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's progress and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Referral to a psychiatric clinic for further evaluation and management of Anorexia Nervosa and Anankastia will be arranged.

S: The patient, a male with no significant past medical history, presents with intermittent dysphagia to solids for the past few weeks. He reports feeling food stuck in his substernal area, good appetite, and no weight loss. He denies any family history of stomach or colon malignancy. O: Physical examination shows the patient is well-nourished, no palpable mass or lymph nodes, and no localized tenderness or organomegaly. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) examination reveals a 6 mm nodule at the GEJ and Los Angeles grade A distal esophagitis with mucosal breaks less than 5 mm. Pathology from the GEJ nodule shows squamous mucosa with mucosal ulcer and acute and chronic inflammatory infiltrates. Nests of atypical cohesive cells with clear cytoplasm and mild nuclear pleomorphism are noted in the submucosa. Immunostains indicate atypical clear cell infiltrate involving squamous mucosa, consistent with metastatic RCC. CT scan of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis shows an unremarkable esophagus and no mediastinal lymphadenopathy. A solid-appearing, partially exophytic mass involving the superior left kidney measuring 5.8  5.3 cm, heterogeneous, displacing portions of the upper pole, abutting the inferior aspect of the spleen but with a thin fat plane separating them. A: The primary diagnosis is metastatic RCC with associated acute and chronic inflammatory infiltrates. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of esophagitis, but these are less likely given the imaging and histological findings. P: The management plan includes further evaluation and treatment options for the renal mass. The patient will be educated about the nature of the disease, treatment options, and potential side effects. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the progression of the disease and adjust treatment as necessary. Referral to a nephrologist for further evaluation and management of the renal mass is recommended.

S: The patient reports significant pain in the right leg, lower back, and weight loss of 3 kg. The patient has a history of multiple myeloma (MM), stage II, diagnosed with lumbar spinal canal stenosis and a sacral tumor. O: Lumbar MRI and CT revealed lumbar spinal canal stenosis and a sacral tumor. Laboratory tests showed elevated serum IgG levels (5,436 mg/dL, normal: 800-1,800 mg/dL) and serum beta-2 microglobulin levels (4.1 g/mL, normal: 0-3 g/mL). Serum immunofixation indicated IgG-type M-protein, and the estimated serum-free  and  chain ratio was 21.5 : 1. Microscopic examination and flow cytometric analysis of the bone marrow aspirate showed elevated CD138-positive abnormal plasma cells. Cytogenetic analysis of the bone marrow revealed 46XY, indicating multiple myeloma (MM), stage II. A: The primary diagnosis is multiple myeloma (MM), stage II, with a history of leukocytosis and thrombocytopenia. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of myeloid leukemia or a recurrent recurrent myeloid tumor. P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition and considering alternative treatment options if necessary. The patient is advised to maintain open communication with the healthcare team and report any changes in symptoms. Further consultations with oncology and oncology may be necessary depending on the patient's response to the current treatment regimen.

S: Ms. K, a single, unemployed mother, reports a week-long history of calling out for people who aren't there, seeing things that others can't see, and feeling anxious and not sleeping well at night. She has a history of complex congenital heart disease, including pulmonary atresia, large ventricular septal defect, pulmonary regurgitation, right ventricular hypertension, and failure. She has a history of corrective surgeries for cardiac conditions at ages 6 and 12 years, umbilical herniorrhaphy at 3 years, and clubfoot repair at 2 years. O: Ms. K's physical examination reveals typical features of DiGeorge Syndrome, including a broad flat nose, small ears, thoracolumbar scoliosis, absent long face, hypertelorism, and micrognathia. Physical examination reveals a mediastinal scar and a pansystolic murmur. A: The primary diagnosis is DiGeorge Syndrome, complicated by her complex congenital heart disease, pulmonary atresia, large ventricular septal defect, pulmonary regurgitation, right ventricular hypertension, and failure. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of diGeorge Syndrome, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and imaging findings. The prognosis depends on the management of DiGeorge Syndrome and response to treatment. P: Continue monitoring the patient's condition closely with regular follow-ups to assess treatment efficacy and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Educate Ms. K on the importance of reporting any new symptoms or concerns immediately. Consider referral to a psychiatric hospital for further evaluation and management of DiGeorge Syndrome. Encourage Ms. K to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately.

S: The patient, a 49-year-old female with a history of uterine cancer at age 49, presented for further examination of a left renal tumor in her horseshoe kidney. She reported slight anemia and low liver function. O: Laboratory data showed slight anemia and low liver function. Hb was 12.3 g/dL, AST 52 IU/L, ALT 44 IU/L, and LDH 201 IU/L. Contrast-enhanced CT showed a renal tumor covered with a capsule and buried by nearly 30%. The tumor was supplied by four arteries toward the left kidney. Laparoscopic ports were used, and the tumor was cut with a 1 mm surgical margin. Histopathological examination confirmed clear cell carcinoma (grade 2, INF, v[], pT1a). The patient was discharged 11 days post-surgery. A: The primary diagnosis is clear cell carcinoma (grade 2, INF, v[], pT1a) of the left kidney. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of renal tumors, but imaging and histopathological findings support the primary diagnosis. P: The patient underwent successful surgical removal of the tumor with no urinary tract leakage. Post-operative care included monitoring for any recurrence of the tumor and regular follow-ups to assess for any recurrence. The patient was discharged 11 days post-surgery and is currently free from recurrence for 43 months.

S: The patient reports experiencing objective vertigo, feeling empty, sweating, and palpitations over the past year. The symptoms improve with food intake. The patient denies any family history of endocrine disease. O: On admission, the patient's BMI was 28 kg/m2. Physical examination and biochemical assessments showed no abnormalities. Blood glucose levels were 70 mg/dl, within the normal range of 65-110 mg/dl, with normal plasma cortisol at 8 a.m., negative anti-insulin antibodies, chromogranin A at 69 ng/ml, prolactin at 247 mU/l, gastrin at 12.7 pg/ml, PTH at 6.4 pmol/l, and serum calcium at 8.8 mg/dl. Fasting test was interrupted after 12 hours due to symptomatic hypoglycemia. Plasma glucose levels were 44 mg/dl, 41 mg/dl, insulin 16.3 U/L, and C-peptide at 1.27 nmol/l. Intravenous glucagon was administered intravenously. A: The primary diagnosis is hypoglycemia, evidenced by the patient's symptoms and laboratory findings. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of hypoglycemia, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and laboratory findings. P: The management plan includes a referral to a nephrologist for further evaluation and management of hypoglycemia. The patient is advised to maintain a healthy diet and monitor glucose levels closely. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's glucose levels and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient is a 50-year-old African American female with a history of bilateral breast reduction, iron deficiency anemia, and obesity. She reports recent tenderness in her right breast and keloids developing along the scar from breast reduction, with blue hues. She has been treated with two courses of antibiotics for an infected keloidal scar, with minimal improvement. O: Physical examination revealed a 10 cm diameter keloidal region with edema and cellulitis on the inferior and lateral aspect of the right breast, with no palpable fluctuance, nipple discharge, or adenopathy in the right axilla. Ultrasound indicated marked edema and skin thickening, but no definitive fluid collection or underlying suspicious mass. A right breast partial mastectomy was performed, and pathology confirmed high-grade primary angiosarcoma of the breast with negative margins. Computed tomography of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis showed no gross metastatic disease. A: The primary diagnosis is high-grade primary angiosarcoma of the breast with negative margins. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of breast cancer, but imaging and pathology support the primary diagnosis. P: The patient underwent a right breast partial mastectomy for cosmesis and resection of the infected keloidal area. Postoperative care includes completion mastectomy, adjuvant chemotherapy with gemcitabine and Taxotere, and radiation therapy. The treatment plan includes a completion mastectomy followed by adjuvant chemotherapy with gemcitabine and Taxotere, followed by radiation therapy. The patient is advised to reach out with any questions or concerns during the treatment process.

S: The patient, with a history of left nephrectomy for renal cancer not otherwise specified 36 years ago and radical cystectomy with creation of a right cutaneous ureterostomy for invasive urothelial carcinoma of the bladder 4 years ago, reports feeling okay but is worried about recent check-up. O: Recent CT scan revealed a pancreatic tumor in the head of the pancreas, ventral to the portal vein, with clear, strong enhancement in the arterial phase and a liver tumor in Couinaud's liver segment 7, measuring 22 mm. FDG-PET scan showed no abnormal accumulation in systemic organs. PET scan was negative for both pancreatic and liver tumors. Endoscopic ultrasound-guided fine-needle aspiration for the pancreatic tumor and percutaneous ultrasound-guided biopsy for the liver tumor were positive. Preoperative CT imaging showed type 3A PAP, with the MPD running ventral to the portal vein, and an aberrant parenchyma located cranial to the confluence of the PV and SPV. A: The primary diagnosis is metastasis of clear cell RCC with metastasis to the MPD. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of hepatocellular carcinoma, but these are less likely given the imaging results. P: The management plan includes performing a CP with additional stapler resection and closure of the aberrant parenchyma, which will require a total of three pancreatic transections. The patient is advised to maintain a healthy lifestyle and follow prescribed medication regimens. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to discuss the procedure and the patient's condition.

S: The patient, born at 39 weeks of gestational age via urgent cesarean section due to maternal premature rupture of the membranes, presented with respiratory distress at birth. She developed spontaneous tremors of the upper limbs, axial hypotonia, and apnea episodes. She was treated with phenobarbital and oxygen, respectively. The patient's developmental milestones included head control at 3.5 months, sitting position at 10 months, and non-autonomous standing station at 15 months. The patient experienced psychomotor delay and was above the 98th centile from 8 to 10 months. O: The patient's Apgar scores were 51 and 85, weighing 3550 g, 53 cm in length, and an OFC of 36.5 cm. Brain ultrasound and MRI were normal. EEG showed continuous activity with occasional sharp elements in the right temporo-occipital area. Audiometric and fundus oculi examinations were normal. Developmental milestones included head control at 3.5 months, sitting position at 10 months, and non-autonomous standing station at 15 months. Psychomotor delay and OFC were at the 98th centile until 4 months, then above the 98th centile from 8 to 10 months. Physical examination revealed a broad and rounded forehead, a small nose with saddle root and anteverted nostrils, reverse epicanthus, sparse eyebrows in the medial portion, fetal finger pads, ligamentous hyperlaxity, and a sandal gap with a prominent heel. Direct nucleotide sequencing analysis was negative for lamin A/C, SEPN1, NFIX, and EZH2. A: The primary diagnosis is psychomotor delay with associated psychomotor delay and psychomotor delay. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of developmental delays and developmental delays. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and management of the psychomotor delay. P: Continue monitoring the patient's developmental milestones with regular follow-up appointments to assess progress and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Educate the patient on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and adherence to follow-up appointments. Consider referral to a pediatric neurologist for further evaluation and management of psychomotor delay and macrocephaly.

S: The patient is a 37-year-old homeless male with a history of peripheral vascular disease, type 1 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and depression, presenting with intermittent chest pain and progressive shortness of breath for a few weeks. He admits to recreational marijuana use. O: On admission, the patient's vital signs were stable except for a low saturation on a pulse oximetry of 86% on room air. Physical examination revealed fast breathing and fine crackles in bilateral lung fields. Laboratory tests showed normal complete blood count and basic metabolic panel, positive urine drug screen for opioids, and elevated D-Dimer levels. CT angiography showed extensive miliary densities throughout the bilateral lung fields. Cardiac workup and autoimmune serology were unremarkable. S: The patient, a smoker with no other cardiac risk factors or history of CVD, presented with flushing and urticaria after eating pineapple 15 minutes later, followed by chest pain radiating to the left shoulder, palpitations, and sweating. O: On examination, the patient's blood pressure was 120/70 mmHg and pulse rate was 80 beats per minute. ECG showed no abnormalities. 24-hour Holter test showed ST segment elevation of 2-3 mm in certain leads during two episodes of malaise, chest pain, and palpitations at rest and driving. ventricular bigeminy and nonsustained ventricular tachycardia were noted. S: The patient is a 43-year-old primipara, presenting with severe hypertensive disorder and concerns about her baby. She reports feeling unwell during her pregnancy. The baby will be born without trauma, with endotracheal intubation and surfactant replacement. Ultrasonography shows anemia with a hemoglobin level of 10.8 g/dl, disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), and slight ascites on ultrasonography, suggesting intra-abdominal bleeding. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of hemorrhagic shock, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation. P: Initiate intensive treatment with high-frequency oscillatory ventilation (HFOV), inotropes, steroids, and massive blood and plasma transfusions to address progressive anemia and DIC. Monitor the baby's response to the treatment and adjust as necessary. Consider palliative care if the baby's condition worsens, considering the patient's irreversible worsening clinical condition. Educate the patient and family about the importance of adherence to the treatment plan and considering palliative care options.

S: The patient is a 74-year-old male with a history of recurrent peptic ulcer disease, presenting with symptoms of weakness, low blood pressure, and melena. He reports a history of recurrent peptic ulcer disease. O: Initial GI labs identified arterial hemorrhage from an ulcer in the anterior duodenal bulb. Initial management included upper endoscopy, epinephrine injection therapy, and multiple clip application, which were ineffective. Fluoroscopy identified the bleeding site on fluoroscopy. IR suite mesenteric angiography showed no native GDA. SMA angiogram indicated opacification of a replaced GDA, supplying a large portion of the left lobe of the liver, but no opacification of the right hepatic artery. Active extravasation of contrast into the duodenal lumen was noted. Post-coil embolization angiography showed occlusion of the replaced GDA and patency of the gastroepiploic artery. Liver function panel showed normal limits. A: The primary diagnosis is recurrent peptic ulcer disease, complicated by a recurrent peptic ulcer disease. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of peptic ulcer bleeding, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The patient underwent rapid transfusion protocol to stabilize the bleeding. The liver function panel was normal, and the patient was advised to focus on recovery and follow prescribed treatments. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor liver function and adjust treatment as necessary. The patient is advised to maintain a healthy lifestyle and report any new symptoms or concerns immediately.

S: The patient reports feeling tired, losing appetite, and experiencing dark stools for the past 3 months. O: Clinical examination revealed melena. Digital rectal examination revealed melena. Upper GI endoscopy revealed a large mass in the stomach, arising from the posterior gastric wall, closer to the lesser gastric curvature, with a bleeding mucosal ulcer. Endoscopic biopsies were inconclusive due to only gastric mucosal tissue. Endoscopic ultrasound-guided needle aspiration showed stromal cells. Abdominal CT scan showed a well-defined, intramural mass near the lesser gastric curvature with a small mucosal defect at the superolateral aspect, with intact soft-tissue fat planes and no enlarged or abnormally enhancing lymph nodes. A: The primary diagnosis is a bleeding mucosal ulcer in the stomach, likely causing melena. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of gastric retraction, but these are less likely given the imaging and biopsy results. P: The management plan includes surgical removal of the mass under general anesthesia. The patient will be positioned supine with legs split, insert laparoscopic ports, and conduct diagnostic laparoscopy to check for any peritoneal involvement. Postoperative care will include preoperative transfusions for severe anemia. The patient will be educated about the procedure and expected outcomes, and a follow-up appointment will be scheduled to monitor recovery and manage any complications.

S: The patient, a male with a history of positive purified protein derivative (PPD) diagnosed in 1997, presents with severe low back pain, difficulty walking, and needing a cane. He reports no sensory loss below the knees, urinary incontinence, chills, or fever. He has a history of a mild cold a few weeks ago, denies smoking, intravenous drugs, alcohol use, and travel. O: Physical examination revealed diminished sensation below the knees without sensory level, unsteady gait, Frankel grade of D, hyperreflexic, positive Hoffman's sign bilaterally, intact rectal tone, and no cranial nerve deficits. Vital signs were within normal limits, white blood cell count elevated at 11.2 k/uL with a left shift, and erythrocyte sedimentation rate was 40 mm/h. C-reactive protein, basic metabolic panel, and liver function studies were within normal limits. Full spine MRI revealed three epidural lesions in the thoracic and lumbar spine, centered at the T5 vertebral body and extended from T4-T6, causing spinal cord compression with T2 signal changes. A: The primary diagnosis is epidural lesions in the thoracic and lumbar spine, with differential diagnoses including other causes of back pain and urinary incontinence. The patient's history of PPD and recent cold are consistent with a recurrent inflammatory process. P: The management plan includes referral to a rheumatologist for further evaluation and management of the epidural lesions. The patient is advised to continue monitoring symptoms and report any changes or worsening of the condition. Further consultations with a rheumatologist and possibly a neurosurgery specialist are recommended to address the epidural lesions.

S: The patient is a 19-year-old Hispanic female presenting with mild itching and discomfort on her hands and forearms for about a year. She reports mild itching, worsening with sun exposure. She denies any involvement of her head, trunk, lower extremities, or genitalia. She denies any daily medications or chronic medical issues. O: Physical examination revealed numerous light brown, ovoid papules on the dorsal hands and fingers, and on the dorsal and ventral surfaces of the forearms, with confluence on the lateral dorsal hands. A punch biopsy from the right forearm showed proliferation of small eccrine ductal structures lined by cuboidal cells within a fibrous stroma with an unremarkable epidermis. Laboratory analysis showed normal complete blood count and glycated hemoglobin test at 5.2% (normal is less than 5.7%). A: The primary diagnosis is syringoma of the right forearm, characterized by proliferation of small eccrine ductal structures lined by cuboidal cells, with an unremarkable epidermis. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of syringomas, but these are less likely given the biopsy results. P: Continue monitoring symptoms and report any changes or concerns in the future. Educate the patient on signs of worsening symptoms and encourage her to reach out with any questions or concerns.

S: The patient is a 9-year-old Hispanic male with no significant past medical history, presenting with RLQ abdominal pain for 2 days and a fever for 1 day. S: The patient is a 30-year-old male with a history of active smoking (one pack daily for 10 years), external hemorrhoids, and a history of active smoking and external hemorrhoids. He presents with high blood pressure, complete heart block, and a large thrombus in the abdominal aorta. He denies recent chest pain, palpitations, dyspnea, dizziness, or syncope. O: Vital signs in the ER were elevated at 234/144 and heart rate was 50 beats per minute. ECG showed 3rd-degree heart block and left ventricular hypertrophy with a strain pattern. Physical examination revealed absent arterial pulses except for a weak left radial pulse. Blood work indicated mild renal impairment. CT thoracic aortogram was normal, ruling out coarctation of the aorta. CT coronary angiogram was normal. MRI of the heart was normal. Transthoracic echocardiogram showed moderate hypokinesia of the left ventricle, an ejection fraction of 35-40%, grade 2/4 diastolic dysfunction, and moderate concentric left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH). Kidney ultrasound/Doppler showed increased parenchymal echogenicity. A CT abdominal aortogram revealed a large thrombus in the abdominal aorta, occluding the aorta and common iliac arteries. A: The primary diagnosis is a large thrombus in the abdominal aorta, complicated by high blood pressure, complete heart block, and thrombus in the abdominal aorta. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of high blood pressure, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The management plan includes a comprehensive treatment plan including antihypertensive medication for blood pressure control, and a referral to a cardiology ward for evaluation and management of complete heart block. The patient is advised to adhere strictly to the treatment regimen and attend regular follow-up appointments to monitor his condition and manage any complications. Further consultations with cardiology and a cardiologist are recommended to optimize treatment outcomes.

S: The patient is a 79-year-old woman with a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, and osteoporosis, presenting with fever and leg edema. She reports no recent symptomatic visual impairment. She is currently on multiple daily medications including glimepiride, metformin, olmesartan, alfacalcidol, and pitavastatin. She denies any history of severe hypertension. O: Physical examination revealed bilateral pitting edema in both lower extremities, a body temperature of 37.8 °C, and blood pressure of 177/105 mmHg. Laboratory findings indicated severe thrombocytopenia with a platelet count of 0.9  104/L, elevated serum creatinine at 1.85 mg/dL, and elevated C-reactive protein at 3.90 mg/dL. Serum IL-6 and vascular endothelial growth factor values were within normal limits. ADAMTS13 activity was decreased to 34.4%, and the ADAMTS13 inhibitor was not detected. Urinalysis showed proteinuria with 2.65 g/g creatinine, and microscopic hematuria with 1-4 red blood cells per high-power field. Bone marrow aspiration was dry, indicating bone marrow fibrosis. A: The primary diagnosis is thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP), evidenced by elevated serum creatinine and C-reactive protein levels. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of thrombocytopenia, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and lab findings. P: Initiated hemodialysis to manage the patient's condition. Plan to monitor the patient's response to treatment and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's response to treatment and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Patient education regarding the nature of TTP and the importance of medication adherence will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance

S: The patient, a 25-year-old with a history of Asperger syndrome, hyperlexia, Tourette syndrome, and Wiedemann-Steiner Syndrome (WSS), reports feeling concerned about his health and growth history. He has a history of short stature, hypotonia, Asperger syndrome, hyperlexia, Tourette syndrome, and a de novo KMT2A frameshift variant. He has been diagnosed with Wiedemann-Steiner Syndrome (WSS) at age 25. O: The patient was born at 6 lb, 11 oz, with a history of short stature, hypotonia, Asperger syndrome, hyperlexia, Tourette syndrome, and a de novo KMT2A frameshift variant. The patient has developed good social-communication skills, which contributed to an ADOS-2 score below the clinical cut-off. Speech abnormalities were noted, including borderline cognitive skills, low average adaptive skills, and average language and vocabulary skills. No anxiety, attention, aggression, or emotional regulation were reported. A: The primary diagnosis is Wiedemann-Steiner Syndrome (WSS), a rare genetic disorder affecting growth and developmental delays, cryptorchidism, hypotonia, and autism spectrum disorder (ASD). Differential diagnoses could include other genetic disorders, but the clinical presentation and genetic findings support the diagnosis. P: Continue working on communication and social skills, including seeking support from a therapist or support group. Regular follow-ups with a healthcare professional are recommended to monitor progress and address any concerns. The patient is advised to maintain regular communication and social skills training and to seek support from a therapist or support group.

S: The patient, admitted to the pediatric emergency department, reports continuous abdominal pain, worsening when standing up, accompanied by abdominal distension, nausea, and vomiting. The patient expresses concern about the symptoms and has undergone surgical intervention for intestinal lymphangioma. O: Initial clinical evaluation revealed an intraabdominal, multilocular cystic mass with liquid inside. MRI confirmed a liquid-filled multicystic structure with hypersignal in ponderate sequences T2 and T2 with fat suppression, with a multilocular aspect and moderate contrast snuff at the wall level. Histopathologic evaluation of the surgically removed tumor showed an 8.9 cm length intestinal fragment with a luminal diameter of 0.5-1.2 cm, incorporating multiple cysts with a wall thickness of less than 0.1 cm and a smooth inner and outer surface filled with white-milky content. A: The primary diagnosis is intestinal lymphangioma, evidenced by histopathologic findings and histopathologic findings. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of abdominal pain, but these are less likely given the imaging and histopathologic findings. P: The patient underwent successful surgical removal of the intestinal lymphangioma. Post-operative care will include monitoring for any signs of recurrence or complications. The patient will be educated on signs of complications and advised to report any new symptoms immediately. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess recovery and manage any complications.

S: The patient reports experiencing headaches, nausea, fatigue, and blurred vision for about a month. O: Physical examination and CT scan revealed pericardial inflammation and splenomegaly, an enlargement of the spleen by 2 cm. Ophthalmoscopy on the right eye revealed papillary edema, retinal hemorrhages, and arteriovenous nickings. Laboratory findings included a white blood cell count of 113.2  109/l (77%) blasts, a red blood cell count of 2.53  106/mm3, hemoglobin of 9 g/dl, and a platelet count of 61  109/l. Prothrombine time was 15.1 s, partial thromboplastin time was 25.8 s. Creatinine was 38.7 mol/l, and uric acid was 498.2 mol/l. Post-treatment blood tests showed a white blood cell count of 0.4  109/l, hemoglobin of 9.5 g/dl, and platelet count of 12  109/l, indicating pancytopenia, anemia, and thrombocytopenia. A: The primary diagnosis is Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML), specifically AML-M1. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of splenomegaly, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and laboratory findings. P: Initiated standard treatment for AML with Daunorubicin 60 mg/m2 for 3 days and Cytarabine 200 mg/m2 for 7 days. Post-treatment blood tests showed a white blood cell count of 0.4  109/l, hemoglobin of 9.5 g/dl, and platelet count of 12  109/l, indicating pancytopenia, anemia, and thrombocytopenia. Plan to adjust the treatment plan and explore other options for AML. Close monitoring of the patient's condition and support will be provided.

S: The patient reports feeling more tired, frequent thirst, and urination after a cadaveric kidney transplantation. O: The patient's current immunosuppressive regimen includes tacrolimus, micophenolate mofetil (MMF), and steroids. Histological graft changes include sclerosis, mesangiolysis, ectasia, and microaneurysms in the kidney. Histological graft changes include sclerosis, mesangiolysis, ectasia, and microaneurysms in the kidney. The patient developed moderate hypertension a week post-transplantation, treated with doxazosin and doxazosin. BMI is within normal limits. Initial treatment with repaglinide was poor, leading to poor glycemic control. Insulin was switched to cyclosporine, which led to adequate glycemic levels with an HbA1c of 6.7% (52 mmol/mol). Creatinine serum levels were 1.5 mg/dL, and 24-hour proteinuria was 300 mg. Glycemia was persistently detected during the first six months post-transplantation. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of kidney disease, but these are less likely given the histological findings. The prognosis depends on the management of PTDM and the management of ESRD. S: The patient, a 39-year-old with a history of MS diagnosed at age 39, initially treated with intravenous steroid therapy and interferon beta 1a therapy. Despite discontinuing immunosuppressant therapy due to inability to tolerate it, the patient experienced symptoms of fatigue, difficulty with fine motor skills in hands, and reduced foot sensitivity. MRI examinations revealed Gd as the most present toxic metal in the body. The patient has a history of MS symptoms, which have been resolving with chelation therapy. O: Initial treatment included intravenous steroid therapy, interferon beta 1a therapy, and EDTA chelation therapy. The patient's Gd levels decreased rapidly, but Gadolinium levels decreased significantly after one year of EDTA chelation therapy. The patient's EDSS score was 4 before the chelation therapy and is now 0 three years post-chelation therapy. A: The primary diagnosis is MS with complications including Gd, Cd, and Pb intoxication. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of MS symptoms, but these are less likely given the chelation therapy's effectiveness. P: Continue chelation therapy twice a year to manage MS symptoms and improve overall health. Maintain a healthy diet with a balanced diet of glutathione 250 mg daily and 15 drops of the antioxidant deutrosulfazyme three times a day. Regular follow-ups with a nephrologist are recommended to monitor the patient's condition and adjust treatment as necessary. Educate the patient on the importance of adhering to the treatment regimen and lifestyle modifications to manage MS symptoms effectively.

S: The patient reports experiencing breast pain, abdominal distension, and weakness for approximately a week. The patient denies any significant individual, gynecological, or family medical history. O: Physical examination revealed a high breathing rate of 22 breaths per minute, tachycardia with a heart rate of 110 beats per minute, hypotension with a mean arterial pressure of 55 mmHg, lethargy, swollen and painful breasts, and dilated abdomen with diffuse sensitivity to palpation and dullness on percussion. Laboratory tests indicated neutrophilic leukocytosis (WBC 30,000/L), polymorphonucleocytes at 95%, and thrombocytopenia (platelets 90,000/L). Disseminated intravascular coagulation, increased urea and creatinine levels, increased bilirubin, increased serum glutamic oxaloacetic transaminase, and serum glutamic pyruvic transaminase, and severe lactic and metabolic acidosis. A research laparotomy revealed enlarged and inflamed ovaries, a large amount of ascitic fluid, and an inflamed appendix. The peritoneum was clear and free of abnormalities. A: The primary diagnosis is inflammatory ovaries, pleural effusions, and an inflamed appendix. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of abdominal pain and abdominal distension, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The patient underwent a research laparotomy to investigate the cause of the ovaries, pleural effusions, and an inflamed appendix. Post-operative management includes close monitoring of the patient's condition, regular follow-ups, and supportive care. The patient will be educated on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and adherence to follow-up appointments.

S: The patient, with a history of renal failure and currently on dialysis, presents for a transcatheter aortic valve replacement evaluation. The patient reports a history of renal failure and is currently on dialysis. O: The patient underwent a routine preprocedural TAVR workup assessing the abdominal aortic vasculature for atherosclerotic disease. The patient's BMI is 28. A 25 mL of Isovue 370 was administered at a rate of 4 mL/sec followed by a 40 mL saline chase. The scan showed a greater than two-fold increase in HU of abdominal vessels compared to conventional CT. A 3D volume rendered model of the abdominal vasculature lumen using the 40 keV VMI data was created using thresholding and iodine mapping segmentation tools. A: The primary diagnosis is atherosclerotic disease in the abdominal aortic vasculature, with a significant increase in HU compared to conventional CT. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of atherosclerotic disease, but these are less likely given the imaging results. P: The patient underwent a transcatheter aortic valve replacement evaluation using Isovue 370 at a rate of 4 mL/sec and a 40 mL saline chase. A 3D printed model of the abdominal vasculature lumen was developed using thresholding and iodine mapping segmentation tools. The final 3D printed model of the abdominal vasculature lumen will be discussed with the surgical team to determine the best approach for the transcatheter aortic valve replacement. The patient will be kept informed and guided through the next steps in treatment.

S: The patient, admitted with cervical lymphadenopathy, fever, fatigue, night sweats, and a 15-pound weight loss, reports a history of poorly controlled type II diabetes and chronic pain. The patient is allergic to sulfa drugs and latex. The patient denies travel, drug use, alcohol use, or sexual activity. O: On examination, the patient was febrile with a temperature of 38.6oC, heart rate of 135 beats per minute, respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, and blood pressure of 115/85 mmHg. Laboratory tests revealed marked leukocytosis with eosinophilia, elevated inflammatory markers, uric acid, and lactate dehydrogenase. Blood smear showed reactive lymphocytes, but flow cytometry did not reveal abnormal lymphoid populations. Excisional biopsy of a lymph node showed necrotizing lymphadenitis, immunoblasts, myeloperoxidase-positive histiocytes with crescent-shaped nuclei, and extensive necrosis with karyorrhectic debris. Stains for acid-fast bacteria, fungi, and herpes were negative. A: The primary diagnosis is Epstein-Barr virus-induced lymphadenopathy, likely exacerbated by the patient's history of poorly controlled type II diabetes and chronic pain. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of lymphadenopathy, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and laboratory findings. P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition, considering the potential Epstein-Barr virus infection. Antiviral treatment may be considered if necessary. The patient will be educated on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and avoiding potential complications. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's condition and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient, diagnosed with hepatitis C, presented with pain, nausea, and dark urine in the right upper quadrant. The patient expressed concern about the pain and nausea. O: Physical examination revealed jaundice and tenderness in the right upper quadrant. Laboratory tests showed elevated total bilirubin at 20.2 mg/dl with a direct component of 15.0, normal albumin, INR at 1.0, AST at 55 units per liter, ALT at 43 units per liter, and ALP at 148 units per liter. Ultrasound of the right upper quadrant showed a thickened gallbladder wall but no stones. CT scan of the abdomen indicated early acute cholecystitis and common bile duct dilation of 7 millimeters. Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) showed dilated intrahepatic ducts and occlusion of the CBD due to thick mucus. Cholangiogram showed diffuse moderate dilation of the biliary tree and several filling defects in the CBD. MRI of the abdomen showed intrahepatic biliary dilation but failed to reveal the cause of mucin production. Cold forceps biopsies were performed during cholangioscopy, revealing columnar mucosa with adenomatous changes. A: The primary diagnosis is hepatitis C with complications including acute cholecystitis and common bile duct dilation. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of acute cholecystitis, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The patient was started on intravenous piperacillin/tazobactam 4 grams every six hours to manage the infection. Follow-up ERCP with digital cholangioscopy revealed polypoid frond-like intraductal growth and associated mucin production within segment VIII of the intrahepatic biliary tree. Cold forceps biopsies were performed during cholangioscopy, revealing columnar mucosa with adenomatous changes. A laparoscopic converted to open right hepatectomy was performed to remove the affected tissue. Post-operative care

S: The patient reports a painless right scrotal mass for the past two years, described as elastic and hard, with no translucency. The patient denies any medications for the mass. O: Physical examination revealed normal testis and epididymis. Blood labs and CT scans were unremarkable. Testicular tumor markers (AFP, hCG) were not elevated. Emergent high radical orchiectomy was performed, revealing a testicular tumor with a cystic structure in the right scrotum, measuring 48 x 48 x 42 mm. Pathological examination confirmed squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) from a cyst in the parenchyma of the testis, with a cancer pearl and intraepithelial carcinoma. Postoperative follow-up CT and tumor marker levels were within normal limits at six months post-surgery. A: The primary diagnosis is squamous cell carcinoma of the right scrotum, with a history of uncharacteristic testicular tumors. Differential diagnoses could include other types of testicular tumors, but these are less likely given the clinical and radiological findings. P: The patient underwent an emergent high radical orchiectomy with minimal bleeding and resected tumor with brown pus-like fluid. Postoperative follow-up CT and tumor marker levels are within normal limits at six months post-surgery. The patient is advised to continue monitoring the condition and follow up with any necessary tests or treatments.

S: The patient, with a one-year history of exophthalmia in the left eye, reports no nasal symptoms, no trauma, or systemic disease. The patient underwent a rhinoscopic approach 6 months ago for a marsupialization of an aneurysmal cyst. The patient has been admitted for recidivism of the same lesion. O: Clinical examination shows no visual acuity loss in the left eye. Rhinoscopy revealed a well-defined mass at the level of the left ethmoidal sinus, smooth and pink, with the other side normal. Tomodensitometry showed an oval multiloculated lesion in the ethmoidal cells measuring 392335mm, with multiple stalls and a liquid level realized by blood. The lesion pushes the eye and right internal muscles without invasion, causes grade I exophthalmia, fills the nasal fossa, pushes the septum without a free interface, displaces the ethmoidal roof inward without endocranial invasion, and narrows the optical channel through posterior ethmoid cells invasion. The frontal and sphenoidal sinuses are unaffected. Histopathology of the lesion revealed fusocelular carcinomatous proliferation in the herring bone with calcification, and multinucleated giant cells. A: The primary diagnosis is an oval multiloculated lesion in the left ethmoidal cells, causing grade I exophthalmia and fluid retention in the left maxillary sinus. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of exophthalmia or other ethmoidal cysts. The prognosis depends on the complete removal of the tumor and histopathology results. P: The management plan includes total excision of the tumor, orbital medial wall, and periorbital, using an endoscopic approach. Post-operative histopathology will be conducted to assess the complete removal and potential additional treatment options. The patient will be educated about the procedure, expected outcomes, and the importance of follow-up appointments to monitor recovery and manage any complications.

S: The patient, a ten-year history of chronic lumbar pain, reported violent low back pain and numbness in the left leg starting from the left hip to the foot approximately 4 months ago. The patient has a history of uncontrolled lumbar sprain and difficulty excretion, which led to a referral to a specialist. O: Physical examination revealed tenderness of interspinal areas in the low lumbar and hypesthesia to pinprick in the L5 and S1 dermatomal distribution, with a positive straight leg raising sign. Routine spinal X-rays showed L4 spondylolisthesis and spondylolysis on both sides. CT scan confirmed disc protrusion and lumbar stenosis at L4/5 and L5/S1, compressing the left L5 and S1 root. Post-surgery, a gas pseudocyst was detected compressing the dura sac, ruled out by laboratory studies. Debridement surgery was performed to remove the gas pseudocyst. A: The primary diagnosis is a gas pseudocyst compressing the dura sac, complicated by uncontrolled lumbar sprain and excretion. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of lumbar pain, but these are less likely given the imaging and surgical findings. P: The patient underwent posterior lumbar decompression surgery at L4-S1, internal fixation, and intervertebral fusion at L4/5 and L5/S1. Post-surgery, the patient underwent debridement surgery to remove the gas pseudocyst. The patient is advised to continue monitoring for any new symptoms or worsening pain. Regular follow-up appointments are necessary to monitor the patient's condition and adjust treatment as necessary. The patient is encouraged to report any new symptoms or worsening pain immediately.

S: The patient reports feeling very weak today, despite a low-grade fever yesterday and consuming a lot before bed. The patient denies any recent symptoms of palpitations, hand tremors, abdominal pain, diarrhea, body weight loss, or numbness of limbs. No family history of similar attacks has been reported. O: Physical examination reveals a blood pressure of 121/63 mmHg, body temperature of 36.6 °C, pulse rate of 102 bpm, and respiration rate of 18 breaths per minute. Muscle power is decreased in the lower extremities, but no flaccid paralysis or areflexia. Hormonal profile indicates low thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) levels ( 0.0025 uIU/mL) and elevated free tetraiodothyronine levels. P: Initiate potassium supplementation with potassium chloride infusion. Initiate 20 mEq of KCl in 500 mL of normal saline at a rate of 120 mL/h. Monitor serum potassium levels within 4 hours via KCl replacement. Monitor thyroid function closely and adjust treatment as necessary. Educate the patient on the importance of adherence to the treatment plan and adherence to the treatment schedule.

Patient education regarding the nature of the hematoma and its implications will be provided to ensure understanding and

The mass extending and invading the posterior aspect of the ethmoid air cells, complete opacification of the left nasal cavity and maxillary sinuses, and ostiomeatal complexes have been obliterated by mucosal disease. S: The patient, a driver by occupation, presented with a painful, hard, fixed, and tender lump on the forehead for approximately 3 months, initially thought to be a pimple. The lump has progressively worsened, leading to pain. O: Physical examination revealed a hard, fixed, and tender lump on the forehead. CT scan showed the lesion involving both the outer and inner tables of the frontal bone. Core needle biopsy showed pleomorphic tumor cells with predominantly eosinophilic cytoplasm, prominent nucleoli, and cells arranged in both trabecular and solid patterns. Whole body 18-FDG-PET scan showed a highly avid lesion with a standardized uptake value of 28 in the right lobe of the liver and multiple avid foci involving the liver, lungs, and dorsal vertebrae. AFP level was 6889 ng ml1. Immunohistochemistry was positive for HepPar1 and CD10. Seropositive for HBsAg and negative for HCV. Liver function tests, serum CEA, CA 19-9, coagulation tests, and other routine investigations were within normal limits. A: The primary diagnosis is pleomorphic tumor of the liver, with differential diagnoses including other forms of liver tumors and hepatocellular carcinomas. The patient's HBsAg status has been confirmed, and the presence of avid foci in the liver, lungs, and dorsal vertebrae is concerning. P: The management plan includes discussing treatment options and lifestyle changes to manage the patient's HBsAg status. The patient will be educated on the importance of adherence to the treatment regimen and lifestyle modifications to manage his condition effectively. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's response to treatment and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Referral to a hepatologist for further evaluation and management of the HBsAg status is recommended.

S: The patient, with a history of hepatitis B for 10 years, presents with upper abdominal pain. He has a history of hepatitis B for 10 years. O: MRI revealed a mass in the left outer lobe of the liver, growing outward and invading the diaphragm. Carcinoembryonic antigen was elevated at 10.14 g/L. During surgery, the tumor was 11 cm  9 cm  6 cm, with no lymph node metastases. IHC analysis showed positive CK18 and negative Arg-1, hepatocyte, glypican-3, and CK7. Tumor proportion score (TPS) was  5%, with a frequency of infiltrating CD8+ T cells at 10%. Liver resection margin recurrence and abdominal lymph node metastasis were noted. PET-CT scans showed abnormal hypermetabolic lesions. Whole-exome sequencing (WES) will be applied to the tissue to further understand the condition and plan for further treatment. A: The primary diagnosis is moderately differentiated intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma (ICC) staged at IIIb, staged at IIIb. The patient's history of hepatitis B and hepatitis B complicate the management of the disease. P: The management plan includes a left hemihepatectomy and hepatoduodenal ligament skeletonization to remove the tumor. Post-surgery, whole-exome sequencing (WES) will be applied to the tissue to further understand the condition and plan for further treatment. The patient will be kept informed about the results and treatment options, and a follow-up appointment will be scheduled to monitor the progression of the disease and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient is a 52-year-old with a history of coronary bypass surgery, presenting for a periodic examination of coronary artery disease. He reports feeling okay since the surgery and has no symptoms related to coronary artery disease. O: Physical examination revealed normal heart sounds with normal S1 and S2 sounds without added sounds like S3 or S4, and no murmur on cardiac auscultation. Blood pressure was 132/82 mmHg and heart rate was 72/min. Breathing and swelling were normal. A 12-lead electrocardiogram indicated nonspecific ST changes in precordial leads. Transthoracic echocardiography showed normal systolic contraction in all left ventricular wall segments. No evidence of left ventricular cavity enlargement or hypertrophy was noted. A left ventricular false tendon extending between the apical lateral wall and basal septum was noted. A: The primary diagnosis is coronary artery disease with no evidence of coronary artery disease. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of heart failure, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The patient is advised to continue regular monitoring of heart function and attend regular follow-up appointments to ensure no recurrence of coronary artery disease. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately. Further consultations with a cardiologist may be necessary to assess the underlying cause of the left ventricular false tendon.

The patient will be educated on the importance of adhering to the treatment regimen and adherence to the treatment plan. S: The patient is a 63-year-old male presenting with missing teeth and a desire to replace them with a fixed prosthesis. He reports an incidental finding of a bilateral bifid mandibular canal, which is a rare variation, with only 4 previous references. O: The panoramic radiograph revealed an incidental finding of a bilateral bifid mandibular canal, which is a rare variation, with only 4 previous references. The bifurcation site on the left side is at the height of an imaginary line drawn horizontally along the occlusal plane at the height of the adjacent third molar, and the bifurcation on the right side appears to separate much lower in the mandibular ramus of the mandible. A: The primary diagnosis is a bilateral bifid mandibular canal, which is a rare variation. The differential diagnosis includes other causes of bifurcation in the mandibular canal, but these are less likely given the radiograph findings. The prognosis depends on the placement of the implant in the upper right 1st molar region. P: The management plan will include careful monitoring during the procedure to avoid complications. The patient will be educated on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and the importance of adhering to follow-up appointments. The patient will be educated on the importance of adhering to follow-up appointments and regular dental check-ups.

Serum amyloid P component scintigraphy showed no visceral amyloid uptake, and Technetium labelled 3,3-diphosphono-1,2-propanodicarboxylic acid scan showed no significant abnormalities.
