S: The patient is a 12-year-old boy with a history of hemophilia A, presenting with swelling and pain in multiple joints, intermittent fever for the past 13 days, and a high-grade fever. He reports a high-grade fever, which improves with antipyretics. He has experienced similar joint aches since birth, treated with injections of FVIII and blood transfusions, and non-traumatic episodes of epistaxis and skin bruising since birth. He has a history of circumcised complications with blood clotting. O: On examination, the patient is oriented with a Glasgow coma scale of 15/15, heart rate 88 beats/min, blood pressure 110/80 mmHg, respiratory rate 20 breaths/min, and fever 102°F. No visible bruises are noted. A: The primary diagnosis is hemophilia A, complicated by a high-grade fever and intermittent fever. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of joint aches, but these are less likely given the patient's history of hemophilia A. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and response to antipyretic therapy. P: Continue monitoring the patient's condition closely. Maintain current vaccinations and monitor for any signs of infection or recurrence. Educate the patient on signs of infection and when to seek immediate care. Schedule follow-up appointments to assess treatment efficacy and adjust as necessary. Ensure the patient understands the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and follow-up schedules.

S: The patient reports experiencing abdominal pain for the past 4 days, hypotension, perspiring, and drowsiness. The patient has a history of aggressive, blunt trauma. O: Physical examination revealed tenderness and rebound tenderness to palpation in the abdomen, 2 periumbilical ecchymoses of 2/2 cm, and multiple periumbilical ecchymoses in the left deltoid area and on the lower limbs. Abdominal sonography revealed peritoneal fluid in all spaces with fibrin. Chest X-rays were unremarkable. Laboratory tests showed creatinine at 4.04 mg/dL, urea at 209 mg/dL, mild acidosis with lactate at 21 mmol/L, creatinine-kinase at 1910 U/L, lactate-dehydrogenase at 451 U/L, and ethanol at 34 mg/dL. Laparotomy revealed 2 perforations on the ileum and general peritonitis with pus. Enterectomy and end-ileostomy were performed, followed by multiple intraperitoneal abscesses. Antibiograms from the peritoneal liquid indicated S. putrefaciens, S. cerevisiae, and Candida species susceptible to amikacin, gentamicin, ciprofloxacin, third-generation cephalosporins, and fluconazole. A: The primary diagnosis is septic shock secondary to aggressive blunt trauma, complicated by multiple organ dysfunction syndrome (MODS). Differential diagnoses could include other causes of abdominal pain, but these are less likely given the antibiogram results. P: The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation, inotropic support, and sedation, with a fever of 38.5 oC. The treatment plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition, supportive care, and antibiotic therapy. Further consultations with a nephrologist and a gastroenterologist are recommended to manage the underlying conditions. Patient education on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and follow-up appointments is crucial for managing the patient's condition.

S: Mdm A, a patient with alpha thalassaemia (HbH disease), reports experiencing fever and chills for the past week. She denies any other symptoms or signs of infection. O: Physical examination was unremarkable. Initial investigations revealed pancytopenia with hemoglobin at 7.3 g/dL, white cell count at 1.68  109/L, platelet count at 92  109/L, C-reactive protein at 24, and procalcitonin at 0.14. Renal function, liver enzymes, chest X-ray, and urinalysis were unremarkable. CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis showed hepatosplenomegaly, but no intra-abdominal abscesses. CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis showed hepatosplenomegaly but no intra-abdominal abscesses. Peripheral blood film indicated marked leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, and significant anisopoikilocytosis with microcytosis and target and tear drop cells, consistent with thalassaemia intermedia. Bone marrow examination showed hypocellular marrow with decreased cell trails on the aspirate, marked erythroid hypoplasia with rare giant erythroblasts, inclusion bodies, and increased numbers of macrophages with active haemophagocytosis. A: The primary diagnosis is thalassaemia intermedia, evidenced by pancytopenia, thrombocytopenia, and anisopoikilocytosis. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of pancytopenia, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The management plan includes close monitoring of blood counts and adjustment of treatment as necessary. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms or changes in her condition immediately. Further consultations with a hematologist and a hematologist are recommended to manage her condition effectively.

S: The patient reports experiencing a central scotoma in the right eye for approximately 5 months, which has been bothersome. The patient denies any history of traumatic events, systematic illnesses, or eye disorders in the family. The patient has not noticed any improvement in vision since the last visit. O: The patient's visual acuity was corrected from 8/20 to 10/20, with atypical pigmentary alterations and local serous detachment involving the central fovea through the fundus photo. OCT revealed persistent sub-retinal fluid and FCE. The patient was diagnosed with CSC 2 months ago and treated with half-dose PDT. One month post-treatment, best-corrected visual acuity was 10/20, and the OCT showed complete resolution of the sub-retinal fluid. Sub-macular hemorrhage and a round hypopigmentary site inferior-nasal to the fovea were noted. A: The primary diagnosis is chronic ocular scotoma (CSC) in the right eye, complicated by metamorphosis. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of ocular scotoma, but these are less likely given the patient's history and imaging findings. P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition and potential further treatment options. The patient will be scheduled for a follow-up appointment to reassess the condition and discuss further treatment options. The patient is advised to contact healthcare providers if any concerns or changes in vision occur.

S: The patient, a child, presented with a seizure at home, accompanied by a mother who called an ambulance. The patient reported feeling unwell for the past two to three days, with upper respiratory infection symptoms, cough, and nasal congestion. The patient's mother reported hearing a "thud" and found the patient on the floor shaking and incontinent of the bladder and bowels, lasting about one to two minutes. The patient has a history of hypertension but no family history of seizure disorders. O: On examination, the patient's vital signs were: oral temperature 38° Celsius, heart rate 108 bpm, blood pressure 111/70 mmHg, breathing rate 26 breaths per minute, and oxygenation 97% on room air. Physical examination revealed drowsiness but overall well-developed. Vital signs included an oral temperature of 38° Celsius, heart rate 108 bpm, blood pressure 111/70 mmHg, breathing rate 26 breaths per minute, and oxygenation 97% on room air. A: The primary diagnosis is a seizure secondary to a traumatic event, likely triggered by a traumatic event. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of seizure, but these are less likely given the patient's medical history and family history. The prognosis depends on the severity of the seizure and response to treatment. P: Continue monitoring the patient's vital signs and respiratory status closely. Schedule a follow-up appointment in one week or sooner if symptoms worsen. Educate the patient on the importance of hydration and dietary modifications to prevent further seizure episodes. Encourage the patient to report any new symptoms or changes in condition immediately.

S: The patient, admitted to the ICU after thoracic surgery in 2017, reports feeling weak and tired, experiencing atrial fibrillation, pulmonary edema, and respiratory distress. The patient has undergone multiple surgeries including mitral valve replacement and CABG (coronary artery bypass graft) in 2017, followed by continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT) dialysis in 2010. Postoperatively, the patient developed postoperative kidney failure and required continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT) dialysis. The patient has experienced delirium and fingering the tracheostomy tube. O: The patient's respiratory status improved with a saturation (SaO2) of 95-98% on 3-5L/min of 100% oxygen for up to 7 hours per day. However, the patient developed delirium and fingering the tracheostomy tube, leading to a failed attempt to reinsert the tube. A: The primary diagnosis is postoperative kidney failure with complications including atrial fibrillation, pulmonary edema, and respiratory distress. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of delirium and delirium. The prognosis is guarded due to the complexity of the tracheostomy tube reinsertion and the patient's delirium. P: Continue monitoring the patient's respiratory status and manage symptoms of delirium and fingering the tracheostomy tube. Educate the patient on signs of worsening respiratory symptoms and encourage immediate reporting of any new symptoms. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess the effectiveness of the tracheostomy tube reinsertion and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Encourage the patient to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately.

S: The patient, with a history of tympanoplasty and endoscopic sinus surgery with septoplasty 10 years ago, presents with severe otalgia, a sensation of ear blockage in the left ear, and hearing loss for the past few months. The patient has tried ear wax removal at several ENT clinics, which failed. O: Physical examination revealed the patient to be comfortable and afebrile, with stable vital signs. Otoscopic examination of the left ear showed impacted ear wax covering the tympanic membrane, mild ear wax, and unremarkable tympanic membrane. Oropharynx examination was unremarkable, lymph nodes in the neck were unremarkable, and all cranial nerves were intact. Nasal endoscopy showed no pathologies. Blood tests were within normal limits. Microscope-guided examination of the left ear revealed a thick keratinous plug dilating the external auditory canal with pockets and bone remodeling, circumferential distension with a normal annulus, and intact tympanic membrane. A: The primary diagnosis is keratosis obturans (KO) in the left ear, complicated by a thick keratinous plug dilating the EAC with pockets and bone remodeling. Differential diagnosis initially included impacted ear wax, which was ruled out based on normal blood tests. P: The patient underwent successful removal of the keratinous plug and placed an ear pack with antibiotics in the ear to aid in healing. The patient is advised to keep the ear pack clean and dry, and avoid inserting anything into the ear. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor healing and ensure proper healing. The patient is encouraged to report any new symptoms or changes in symptoms immediately.

S: The patient reports a recurrent, itchy rash persisting for about a year. The rash is spread throughout the body, particularly on extremities and trunk, and on flanks. The rash has red, raised bumps with minimal scaling. O: Physical examination revealed a diffuse rash spread throughout the body, particularly on extremities and trunk, with red, raised bumps with minimal scaling. Biopsy of the left chest revealed a predominantly perivascular inflammatory infiltrate with occasional eosinophils, consistent with Drug Hypersensitivity Reaction (DHR). Direct immunofluorescence test was negative. Treatment options included topical triamcinolone, clobetasol, hydroxyzine, oral prednisone, and dupilumab injections, which resolved dermatitis and pruritus after 4 months of treatment. A: The primary diagnosis is Drug Hypersensitivity Reaction (DHR), evidenced by biopsy findings and clinical presentation. Differential diagnoses could include hypersensitivity dermatitis, contact dermatitis, non-bullous pemphigoid, atopic dermatitis, and Grover disease. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the resolution of symptoms without side effects. P: Continue monitoring the patient's response to the dupilumab injections and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Regular follow-up appointments are scheduled to assess treatment efficacy and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately.

S: The patient is a 19-year-old male presenting with melena once a day for the past week, vomiting, shortness of breath, and palpitations. He reports a history of epistaxis in childhood and increased bleeding tendency in his paternal grandmother. O: Initial complete blood count showed a hemoglobin level of 5.80 g/dL. Lab parameters from admission were not provided. Initial blood count showed a hemoglobin level of 5.80 g/dL, indicating severe anemia according to WHO guidelines. Blood groups were labeled O positive, but serum showed a strongly positive indirect Coomb's test and a negative direct Coomb's test. Extended 11-cell panel antibody testing showed pan-agglutination matched with monoclonal panel cells with anti-Kell, anti-Lub, and anti-Kpb antibodies. Cross match with four O negative and four O positive packed RBCs showed +4 incompatibility. A transfusion reaction workup showed grade 4+ pan agglutination in the serum. A: The primary diagnosis is severe anemia with multiple alloantibodies contributing to gross incompatibility. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of anemia, but these are less likely given the patient's history and laboratory findings. P: The patient was started on one unit of least incompatible packed RBCs after washing with normal saline thrice, and started on the transfusion under strict monitoring. The patient experienced shivering, temperature spikes to 101°F, tachycardia, and hypotension, which were managed with intravenous antihistamine and hydrocortisone. A transfusion reaction workup showed grade 4+ pan agglutination in the serum. A: The primary diagnosis is severe anemia with multiple alloantibodies contributing to gross incompatibility. The patient's history of epistaxis and increased bleeding tendencies suggest a potential complication of multiple alloantibodies. P: The management plan includes close monitoring in the ICU with intravenous desmopressin and intravenous factor VIII. The patient will be closely monitored in the ICU with close monitoring in the ICU to manage his anemia and manage symptoms. Further consultations with

S: The patient is a 55-year-old female with a history of systemic lupus erythematosus and a history of systemic lupus erythematosus, presenting with fatigue and constitutional syndrome lasting for 5 months. She reports no positive physical findings upon physical examination and negative tumour markers and normal liver function tests. O: Extrainstitutional CT revealed multiple focal liver lesions with microcalcifications, occupying all segments of the liver. Extrainstitutional paraclinical tests showed negative tumor markers and normal liver function tests. Contrast MRI with gadopentetate dimeglumine (Magnevist) showed a normal liver size and morphology with multiple focal lesions distributed among all segments of the hepatic parenchyma, with heterogeneous peripheral enhancement and intralesional nodular enhancement. Cholangioresonance sequences were normal. The lesions showed very little contrast uptake in late 5-min sequences, heterogeneous in central and peripheral lesions, and low-intensity lesions in the arterial phase. A: The primary diagnosis is hepatic parenchyma with a history of systemic lupus erythematosus. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of liver lesions, but these are less likely given the imaging findings and clinical presentation. P: The patient will continue to be monitored with regular follow-ups with her healthcare team to manage her lupus and monitor any changes in her symptoms. Further diagnostic tests may be considered if there is no improvement in liver function. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms or changes in her condition immediately.

S: The patient, a 27-year-old Caucasian male and college graduate, presents with obsessive-compulsive symptoms and suicidal thoughts starting a week ago following a nocturnal emission while camping. He reports worsening depression, dysphoria, anxiety, anhedonia, low energy, low motivation, decreased social interest, and poor sleep. He denies hallucinations, delusions, symptoms of mania or hypomania, or use of alcohol or illicit substances. He has a past history of one psychiatric hospitalization but no history of suicidal behavior, physical or sexually aggressive behavior, or drug abuse. O: The patient is admitted to the emergency room for further evaluation and treatment. He has been treated as an outpatient for most of his life, with the exception of one prior psychiatric hospitalization. A: The primary diagnosis is obsessive-compulsive symptoms and suicidal thoughts, likely related to a nocturnal emission. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of obsessive-compulsive symptoms and suicidal thoughts, but these are less likely given the patient's history and current symptoms. The prognosis is guarded due to the severity of the symptoms and the complexity of his past medical history. P: The patient will be admitted to the emergency room for further evaluation and treatment. He will be monitored closely for any changes in his condition or symptoms, and his family will be involved in his care. Referral to a psychiatry specialist and a neurologist is recommended for further evaluation and management. Education regarding the nature of his condition, treatment options, and potential outcomes will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient is a 59-year-old female who reports gradual enlarging swellings under both the right and left scapula, which have been present for eight months, becoming more visible when stretching arms forward or elevating upper extremities. She reports pain in the upper extremities and around her arms. She has a history of neurosurgical procedures for disc extrusion in the cervical and thoracic spine, which were pre-operatively treated with punctures and partial resection of the swelling on the right side five months ago. O: Magnetic resonance imaging on the thoracic wall revealed symmetrical fluid collections in the subscapular regions, measuring 120  37 x 115 mm with a volume of 250 ml, and 120  24 x 90 mm with a volume of 130 ml, between the external intercostal muscles and the heads of the muscle serratus anterior. The fluid collections are moderately heterogeneous with sporadic internal septa, with cystic formations with a slightly distinct signal, and hypersensitive contents in the T1 weighing on the right side, suggestive of chronic post-haemorrhagic changes. Contrast administration showed no significant increase in signal intensity, but moderate reinforcement of the capsule of the fluid collection on the left side showed moderate reinforcement. The axillary lymphatic nodes are of physiological size, and the pulmonary parenchyma is without inflammatory or focal changes. The pleural cavities are without effusion, and the pleura is without hypertrophy. A: The primary diagnosis is chronic post-haemorrhagic changes in the subscapular fluid collections, likely secondary to a recurrent scapula. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of scapula swelling, but imaging and clinical findings support the primary diagnosis. P: The management plan includes scheduling a follow-up appointment to discuss treatment options and monitor the patient's condition. The patient is advised to report any changes in symptoms or concerns immediately. Further consultations with a rheumatologist and a pulmonologist may be considered if symptoms persist or worsen.

S: The patient, with a history of progressive dysphagia for the past 2 months, reports no hoarseness. He has a history of smoking 60 cigarettes daily for 40 years, heavy alcohol consumption for 9 years, and type 2 diabetes diagnosed a year ago. He denies any prior malignant diseases or distant metastases. O: Physical examination revealed no palpable neck and supraclavicular lymph nodes. Blood count and biochemical analysis were normal. Iohexol swallowing test indicated a malignant-appearing structure in the inferior-thoracic region. Endoscopic assessment revealed a lesion of mucosal hyperplasia forming luminal stenosis 36 cm from the incisor teeth, difficult to pass through the gastroscope. Biopsy of the lesion indicated an esophageal MEC. CT scan showed a resected esophagectomy specimen with a fungating tumor measuring 45 and 40 mm in the longitudinal and cross-sectional dimensions. Histopathology confirmed epidermoid cells arranged in nests and keratin pearl formation. Columnar mucus-secreting cells and intermediate cells were forming tube-like structures with invasive growth. Immunohistochemical staining was positive for p-63 and CK5/6. A: The primary diagnosis is an esophageal MEC with associated esophageal hyperplasia and keratin pearl formation. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of esophageal tumors, but these are less likely given the imaging and histopathological findings. P: The patient underwent an esophageal resection with an esophagectomy, 2-field lymphadenectomy (upper abdominal and mediastinum), and esophagogastrostomy through the esophageal bed on the tenth day of hospital admission. Post-surgery, the patient will continue to be monitored for recovery and will be advised to quit smoking and reduce alcohol consumption to improve overall health. Follow-up care will be necessary to monitor recovery and manage any complications.

S: The patient is a female in her late seventies with an aortic aneurysm, currently living alone and independent, with no assistance. She reports a history of percutaneous endovascular aortic repair in 2013. She was admitted for an elective procedure in September 2019, involving the embolization of a type 2 endoleak. Five hours post-procedure, she experienced weakness and numbness in both lower limbs, worsening on the right side. Physical examination revealed a lower motor neurone pattern of weakness over bilateral lower limbs, worsening on the right side. Sensation testing showed normal sensation on the left but impaired sensation for the right from L2 to S1. Lumbar spinal drain was inserted to decompress the spinal cord and allow more arterial flow. A CT aortogram and MRI thoracolumbar spine showed post-interval embolization of bilateral feeding arteries. Onyx material was visible within a branch of the embolized right iliolumbar artery, which extends into the spinal canal at L3 and exits at L2. A: The primary diagnosis is post-interval embolization of bilateral feeding arteries, with complications including spinal cord ischemia and spinal cord ischemia. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of aortic aneurysm, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: Continue monitoring the patient's condition closely with regular follow-ups to assess for any recurrence or new symptoms. Adjust the treatment plan as necessary based on the patient's response to the treatment and any new symptoms. Educate the patient on signs of worsening symptoms and encourage her to report any new symptoms immediately.

S: The patient, a 10-year-old male horse, reported feeling weak and not responding properly, lying on the ground and not moving much. He died approximately 4 hours later, accompanied by two living third-instar dipteran larvae near his head. The patient also noted difficulty breathing the day before the incident but did not notice any discharge. O: The horse's nasal cavity was probed with tweezers and found another four living third-instar larvae. Two larvae were collected for further examination, and the rest were stored in alcohol for morphological study. A: The primary diagnosis is the death of a 10-year-old male horse, likely oestrids, given the presence of larvae and the presence of oestrids. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of oestrids, but these are less likely given the findings and the presence of larvae. P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the horse's respiratory and respiratory status. The larvae will be kept in alcohol for morphological study to further understand the cause of the horse's death. The patient is advised to report any similar symptoms immediately. Further consultations with a veterinary neurologist and a veterinary veterinary specialist are planned to further investigate the cause of the horse's death.

S: 56-year-old male presents with difficulty swallowing, a history of diabetes and high blood pressure, and a history of diabetes and high blood pressure. He has been on metformin 500 mg twice daily for the past four weeks. He has a history of diabetes and high blood pressure. O: Physical examination shows no swelling in the neck, normal thyroid, lymph nodes, masses in the neck, redness, carotid bruit, lung exam clear, heart exam normal, no murmurs on belly, epigastric tenderness, no masses, significant swelling, normal back exam, normal extremity exam, and neurological exam. No nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, or other side effects from metformin. A: The primary diagnosis is difficulty swallowing, likely exacerbated by a stricture of the esophagus. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of esophageal narrowing, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation. P: The management plan includes referral for gastroenterology for a scope of the esophageal narrowing, prilosec for reflux, and prilosec for esophageal narrowing. The patient is advised to chew frequently and maintain a healthy diet. A: The primary diagnosis is a stricture of the esophageal narrowing, likely exacerbated by prilosec. The patient's diabetes and high blood pressure are affecting his health. P: The management plan includes referral for gastroenterology for a scope of the esophageal narrowing, prilosec for reflux, and prilosec for esophageal narrowing. The patient is advised to chew frequently and maintain a healthy diet. The patient is advised to continue the metformin regimen. A: The primary diagnosis is a stricture of the esophageal narrowing, likely exacerbated by prilosec and reflux. The patient's diabetes and high blood pressure are affecting his health. P: The management plan includes referral for gastroenterology for a scope of the esophageal narrowing and prilosec for reflux. The patient

S: The patient is a 91-year-old male presenting with discomfort and pain in the right side, initially suspected to be a right incidental renal tumor. He underwent a laparoscopic renal resection (RN) procedure in December 2016. Postoperatively, he experienced postoperative night delirium, which was managed with haloperidol. He reports feeling alright with the resolution of pain and discomfort. O: The patient underwent a laparoscopic renal resection (RN) procedure in December 2016. Postoperatively, the patient experienced postoperative night delirium, which was managed with haloperidol. The patient was discharged on postoperative day 10. The pathologic diagnosis for the patient is multilocular clear cell renal cell carcinoma (RCC), Fuhrman grade 2, pT1b, with a relatively early stage. A: The primary diagnosis is multilocular clear cell renal cell carcinoma (RCC), Fuhrman grade 2, pT1b, with a relatively early stage. The patient's symptoms and the severity of the disease are consistent with the diagnosis. P: Continue monitoring the patient's condition closely and manage any new symptoms or concerns. Maintain regular follow-up appointments to assess the progression of the disease and manage any complications. Educate the patient on the importance of reporting new symptoms or concerns immediately.

S: The patient, referred for left wrist drop, finger drop, and a tingling sensation over the lateral dorsum of the left hand, reports a history of intoxication 4 days ago, resulting in waking up with symptoms. The patient denies any history of antecedent trauma, injury, infection, or mononeuropathy. O: Neurologic examination revealed weakness (Medical Research Council grade II) in the left wrist and finger extension. Finger abduction appeared weak, but strength improved with passive extension to the neutral position. Wrist and finger flexion were intact. Sensory examination revealed hypoesthesia and tingling sensation over the lateral dorsum of the left hand between the thumb and index finger, extending into the proximal phalanges of the 2nd finger, with reddish skin color and slight edema. Reflexes were normal at the biceps and triceps brachii muscles, but the left brachioradialis reflex was absent. Routine blood analysis showed normal white blood cell count, C-reactive protein, and uric acid levels. Nerve conduction study and electromyography were performed two weeks post-symptom onset. A: The primary diagnosis is compressive radial neuropathy, evidenced by neurological findings and clinical presentation. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of radial nerve weakness, but these are less likely given the clinical findings and normal blood analysis. P: The management plan includes monitoring the patient's condition for approximately two weeks without specific treatment, if improvement in skin color, weakness, and aberrant sensation is noted. The patient is advised to avoid excessive strain on the left arm and wrist. Regular follow-ups will be scheduled to assess progress and adjust treatment as necessary.

S: The patient, an 8-month-old baby boy, presented with a one-month history of a mass on the right elbow, which has been moving his right arm actively without limitations but has been gradually increasing in size. The mother reports no past medical or surgical issues, full-term pregnancy, or complications during pregnancy or delivery. The child's developmental history and family history are normal. O: Physical examination revealed a 3  2  4 cm mobile, soft, nontender mass extending from the right proximal ulnar aspect volar surface crossing the elbow crease proximally without signs of erythema. The full elbow active extension with mild restriction of full flexion is around 15 degrees. Radiograph showed lobular soft tissue swelling. Blood profile including complete blood count, ESR, and CRP was normal. MRI of the right elbow revealed a 3.3  2  4.5 cm lobular juxta articular subcutaneous soft tissue lesion along the medial aspect of the elbow, multiseptated with high T2 signal intensity and a 1.8  1.8  1.5 cm area with low T2 and high T1 signal intensity, with no perilesional edema or joint effusion. Pathology confirmed a multiloculated lymphangioma with no evidence of malignancy. A: The primary diagnosis is an endolymphatic malformation of the right elbow, evidenced by the presence of a multiloculated lymphangioma and the absence of perilesional edema or joint effusion. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of endolymphatic malformations, but these are less likely given the imaging and pathology results. P: The management plan includes a radical excision of the mass under tourniquet control, with careful dissection of the mass from the ulnar, median nerves, and antebrachial muscles. Post-operative care will include monitoring for any signs of malignancy or complications. The patient will be educated on the procedure, post-operative care, and the importance of adhering to post-operative instructions. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor recovery and manage any complications.

S: The patient, a 14-year-old with a history of Hashimoto's hypothyroidism, reports consuming artificial sweeteners for approximately 14 years. The patient has a history of using artificial sweeteners for approximately 14 years. The patient has a significant weight gain of 20 lbs since starting artificial sweeteners. O: Initial TSH was 12.2 mIU/L, free T4 was 0.5 ng/dl, and Anti-TPO Ab was 196 IU/ml. The patient was started on levothyroxine 0.75 mg/day, which normalized TSH levels between 1.23 mIU/L and 2.16 mIU/L over the following three years. The patient also ruled out other autoimmune disorders like Grave's disease and De Quervain thyroiditis, and drug-induced thyroiditis. The patient experienced a significant weight gain of 20 lbs since starting artificial sweeteners. The patient has been clinically euthyroid without any treatment. A: The primary diagnosis is Hashimoto's hypothyroidism with a history of artificial sweeteners. The patient's TSH levels were normalized with levothyroxine 0.75 mg/day, despite a drop in TSH to 0.005 mIU/L. Differential diagnoses included Grave's disease, De Quervain thyroiditis, and drug-induced thyroiditis. P: The patient was started on levothyroxine 0.75 mg/day, which normalized TSH levels. The patient has remained clinically euthyroid without any treatment. The patient is advised to continue monitoring thyroid levels and report any symptoms or changes to their healthcare provider. Regular follow-up visits are necessary to monitor thyroid function and adjust treatment as necessary.

S: The patient, born at term by natural delivery, reports a history of mild learning disabilities, specifically dysgraphia, and recent growth and development. The patient started walking at 13 months and pronounced first words at 11 months, with no developmental delay or intellectual disability. The patient has a history of a neuropsychological evaluation at 9 years old, which showed mild learning disabilities, specifically dysgraphia. The patient has a history of mild learning disabilities, specifically dysgraphia, and has a history of Smith-Magenis syndrome (SMS). O: The patient's birth weight was 3950 g, length 51 cm, and occipital frontal circumference was 34.5 cm, with Apgar scores of 9/9. Birth measurements and Apgar scores were normal. The patient's birth weight was 3950 g, length 51 cm, and occipital frontal circumference was 34.5 cm, with Apgar scores of 9/9. Recent brain MRI and angiography indicated an altered signal near the capsular lenticular structures and the head of the caudate nucleus, suggestive of a hamartoma. A: The primary diagnosis is Smith-Magenis syndrome (SMS) with associated obesity, hyperactivity, dysphagia, sleep disturbance, and minor dysmorphic features. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of developmental delays and intellectual disability, but these are less likely given the imaging findings. P: The management plan includes regular follow-ups with the healthcare provider to monitor growth and development. The patient is advised to maintain a healthy lifestyle to manage obesity and other symptoms. Education on the importance of adherence to follow-up appointments and lifestyle modifications is crucial. Referral to a neurologist for further evaluation and management of SMS is recommended.

S: The patient presented with diffuse abdominal pain and obstipation for the past 24 hours, without vomiting or fever. The patient has a history of a traumatic splenectomy 12 years ago due to a traumatic rupture of the spleen. O: Vital signs were within normal limits, and the patient was afebrile. Physical examination revealed distension and diffuse tenderness in the abdomen. Blood tests showed a high white blood cell count of 23040/mm3, normal hepatic and pancreatic enzymes, and multiple splenic nodules in the left upper quadrant with small bowel distention and air-fluid levels in the jejunum. Exploratory laparotomy identified more than 50 splenic nodules in the left sub-diaphragmatic region, with a splenic tissue on the mesentery of the jejunum, causing external compression and obstruction of the small bowel and colon. Pathologic studies confirmed splenosis, confirming the recurrence of the splenic tissue post-splenectomy. A: The primary diagnosis is splenosis post-splenectomy, evidenced by the recurrence of the splenic tissue. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of abdominal pain and obstipation, but these are less likely given the imaging and pathologic findings. P: The patient underwent exploratory laparotomy to resected the splenic tissues and sent them for pathologic studies. The patient was discharged on the 7th post-operative day and started oral feeding on post-operative day 4. The patient is advised to return for a check-up if symptoms recur or new symptoms arise. The patient is advised to monitor for any recurrence of symptoms and to report any new symptoms immediately.

S: The patient is a frail 86-year-old female presenting with dyspnea on exertion, particularly when exerting. She reports difficulty breathing, particularly when exerting. O: Brain-type natriuretic peptide (BNP) level is elevated at >900. Transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) revealed severe AS (aortic valve area 0.58 cm2 and peak velocity 4.0 m/s), diffuse left ventricular hypertrophy (Maron type III hypertrophic cardiomyopathy), and LVOT obstruction with systolic anterior motion (SAM) of the mitral valve, leading to moderate mitral regurgitation (MR). Valsalva maneuver showed peak velocity of 2.9 m/s and mean pressure gradient of 32 mmHg at the LVOT. Coronary angiography confirmed the first major septal branch perfusing the basal septum. Coronary angiography confirmed the first major septal branch perfusing the basal septum. A: The primary diagnosis is severe aortic valve obstruction with systolic anterior motion (SAM) of the mitral valve, complicated by moderate mitral regurgitation. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of aortic valve obstruction, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation. P: The management plan includes a TAVI to treat severe aortic valve obstruction and LVOT obstruction. The patient will undergo a 23 mm SAPIEN 3 valve implanted via transfemoral approach with general anesthesia and transesophageal echocardiography guidance. Emergent ASA will be performed using a 2 mm over-the-wire balloon and microbubble to stabilize her hemodynamic status. The patient will be educated on the importance of follow-up and compliance with the treatment plan.

S: The patient reports a 24-hour history of nausea and vomiting, followed by acute, moderate right-sided testicular pain, without fever. The patient has a history of transient neutropenia and hepatosplenomegaly, which resolved completely. The patient has a history of cutaneous Parkinson's Disease (PAN) diagnosed at age 5 with a homozygous c.139G > C mutation (p.G47R) of ADA2, and no family history of vasculitis, autoimmunity, or immunodeficiency. O: The patient's recent symptoms and medical history are consistent with DADA2. Genetic testing confirmed a homozygous c.139G > C mutation (p.G47R) of ADA2, and absence of serum ADA2 enzyme activity. The patient's parents are heterozygous for the same mutation, and no family history of vasculitis, autoimmunity, or immunodeficiency was noted. A: The primary diagnosis is DADA2 deficiency, evidenced by the patient's history of transient neutropenia and hepatosplenomegaly. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of cutaneous Parkinson's Disease (PAN), but these are less likely given the genetic findings. P: The management plan includes continued monitoring of DADA2 and monitoring for any new or worsening symptoms. The patient is advised to report any new or worsening symptoms immediately. Regular follow-ups will be scheduled to assess the effectiveness of the treatment and adjust the plan as necessary. The patient is encouraged to report any new or worsening symptoms immediately.

S: The patient, referred for progressive nasal obstruction and recurrent episodes of epistaxis, reports difficulty breathing from one side of the nose and frequent nosebleeds over the past several months. The patient denies any anosmia, nasal discharge, nasal congestion, sneezing, facial pain, or headache. The patient has a history of hypertension and diabetes. O: Rigid endoscopic examination revealed a large, left-sided nasal polypoidal mass with smooth overlying mucosa occluded the whole left nasal cavity. Ear, nose, throat, head, and neck examinations were normal. CT scan of the paranasal sinuses with contrast showed a left anterior lobulated nasal mass at the cartilaginous part of the nasal septum with mild heterogeneous post IV contrast enhancement and bone remodeling, with no extension to the paranasal sinuses and no bone invasion. Intraoperative findings confirmed a semifirm vascular mass attached to the anterior face of the middle turbinate and septum at the same level. Histological examination of the mass showed three fragments of soft to firm tan-gray tissue, positive for vimentin and S100, negative for desmin, NSE, and SMA. Histopathology confirmed schwannoma of the nasal septum. A: The primary diagnosis is schwannoma of the nasal septum, confirmed by histopathology. The patient's history of hypertension and diabetes are significant contributing factors to the recurrence of the nasal mass. P: The patient underwent endonasal endoscopic excision of the nasal cavity mass under general anesthesia, and the pedicle was cauterized. Regular follow-up care will be necessary to monitor for recurrence. The patient will be educated on the signs of infection and the importance of adhering to follow-up appointments.

S: The patient, a 50-year-old with a history of hepatolithiasis and hepatic left lateral segmentectomy, reports no symptoms of dysphagia, epigastric fullness, or gastroesophageal reflux. O: Physical examination was unremarkable. Laboratory tests including carcinoembryonic antigen and carbohydrate antigen 19-9 were normal. Endoscopic endoscopy revealed a sliding hiatal hernia and a 10 mm elevated mass at the EG junction. Endoscopic ultrasonography showed a mass with mixed echogenicity in the esophageal wall partially invading the submucosal layer. Upper gastrointestinal imaging showed an elevated lesion at the EG junction. Biopsy confirmed differentiated tubular adenocarcinoma. CT scans showed no lymph node metastasis or distant metastasis. A: The primary diagnosis is esophageal cancer, specifically cT1bN0M0 cStage I, cT1bN0M0 cStage I. Differential diagnosis initially included lymph node metastasis and distant metastasis. P: The patient underwent a proximal gastrectomy with D1 lymph node dissection and jejunal interposition, removing the affected parts of the esophagus and stomach, and lymph nodes. Post-surgery, the patient will continue to be monitored and provided with follow-up care. The patient is advised to attend all scheduled appointments and contact the healthcare provider if any questions or concerns arise.

S: The patient is a 32-year-old female in her 39th week of pregnancy, presenting with severe dyspnea and chest pain. She reports no similar symptoms or hospitalizations in the past. O: The patient's Apgar index was 3, 6, and 9 at minutes 1, 3, and 5, respectively. The baby weighed 2590 grams at birth, a restriction of the expected weight for 39 weeks of gestation. Ultrasounds showed a reduction in potential foetal growth from the 33rd week without Doppler alteration. Placenta macroscopic examination showed less than 10% of the cotyledons with infarcts. Postoperative course showed a worsening of clinical conditions, resulting in an acute distress syndrome. A: The primary diagnosis is pulmonary embolic disease with complications including pAVM and placental infarcts. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of acute distress syndrome, but these are less likely given the patient's clinical presentation. P: The patient underwent an emergent caesarean section under general anesthesia due to the urgency of the delivery. Postoperative management includes close monitoring of both the patient and the baby's condition. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately. Further consultations with a nephrologist and a pulmonologist are recommended to manage hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia (HHT).

S: The patient is a 19-year-old female who underwent surgical fat grafting to the forehead. She reports a necrotic hairless lesion on her right frontotemporal region, which has been present for over a year. She recalls the procedure, which involved harvesting 4,550 follicular units (FUs) from the occipital scalp using the strip excision method, and transplanting them at a density of 35 FUs/cm2. Postoperatively, the patient scale score improved to 8, and the observer scale score dropped to 7. The patient has noticed improvement in her condition. O: The patient's POSAS scores were 20 and 18 before surgery, respectively. Postoperatively, the patient scale score improved to 8, and the observer scale score dropped to 7. A: The primary diagnosis is a necrotic hairless lesion on the right frontotemporal region, with a history of surgical fat grafting to the forehead. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of hairless lesions, but these are less likely given the patient's history and current findings. P: Continue monitoring the patient's POSAS scores and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess the patient's progress and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately.

S: The patient is a 67-year-old male with a history of permanent atrial fibrillation and triple mechanical prosthetic valve replacements for rheumatic valvular disease. He reports progressive nonischemic cardiomyopathy with a residual left ventricular ejection fraction of 15%. He has declined a subcutaneous implantable cardioverter defibrillator due to his refusal of a subcutaneous implantable cardioverter defibrillator. O: Physical examination revealed significant bradycardia with a heart rate of 35-40 bpm. ECG indicated atrial fibrillation with intermittent rate regularization and variable wide complex QRS morphology, suggesting a high-grade atrioventricular block with variable ventricular escape rhythm. An urgent cardiac resynchronization therapy with a defibrillator (CRT-D) device implantation via the coronary sinus will be performed under aseptic conditions. A: The primary diagnosis is high-grade atrioventricular block with variable ventricular escape rhythm. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of atrial fibrillation, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation. P: The management plan includes urgent cardiac resynchronization therapy with a defibrillator (CRT-D) device implantation via the coronary sinus under aseptic conditions. The procedure will involve extrathoracic subclavian venous punctures using fluoroscopic guidance, occlusive CS-venogram, and an inner catheter (Acuity Pro 7F Inner Guiding Catheter CS-IC130 60 cm, Boston Scientific Corp). The patient will be educated on the procedure and expected outcomes, and a follow-up appointment will be scheduled to monitor progress and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient, a young adult, reports recurrent episodes of rhabdomyolysis since childhood, first occurring at age 22 months old following a respiratory tract infection. The patient has a family history of two siblings who passed away at age 2 and 4, with severe muscle pain, rhabdomyolysis, and myoglobinuria. The patient denies any hypoglycemia or ketosis during the acute illness. The patient has been admitted multiple times with extremely elevated CK levels, including 1,000,000 U/L at age 9, and has been taking aggressive carbohydrate supplementation including nocturnal cornstarch, MCT oil, walnut oil, and Coenzyme Q10, 100-200 mg daily. Serial urine organic acid profile and acylcarnitine profiles are normal. O: The patient's creatine kinase serum concentration was elevated at 250,000 U/L at that time. Postmortem evaluations including skeletal muscle histology and electron microscopy showed no abnormalities. Cardiac evaluation showed dilated cardiomyopathy. The patient has been treated as a possible long chain fatty acid oxidation defect due to family history. Recent investigations have not identified a definite cause of the condition. Serial urine organic acid profile and acylcarnitine profiles are normal. A: The primary diagnosis is recurrent episodes of rhabdomyolysis, likely exacerbated by a family history of long chain fatty acid oxidation defect. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of rhabdomyolysis, but these are less likely given the family history and clinical presentation. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and the management of the underlying cause. P: Continue monitoring the patient's CK levels and cardiac function closely. Maintain aggressive carbohydrate supplementation, restrict fat intake to 40 g/d, use MCT oil and walnut oil, and take Coenzyme Q10 100-200 mg daily. Limit exercise to 20 minutes per day and have a high-calorie drink prior to physical activity. Educate the patient on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and adherence to the treatment regimen. Consider referral to a neurologist for further evaluation and management of rhabdomyolysis.

S: The patient, admitted to the Department of Neurology, reports weakness and clumsiness in the left arm, decreased grip strength, difficulty with pronation, wrist dorsiflection, and forming a ring with the thumb and index finger, and slight brisk left upper extremity reflexes. The patient has a history of long-term oral anticoagulation due to recurrent lower extremity deep vein thrombosis, glaucoma, non-significant aortic valve stenosis, treated hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and non-significant stenosis of the left anterior descendent coronary artery. O: Physical examination showed no abnormalities other than neurological signs. Physical examination revealed wrist drop on the left side, decreased grip strength, difficulty with pronation, wrist dorsiflection, and forming a ring with the thumb and index finger. Left upper extremity reflexes were slightly brisk, with no pathological reflexes or sensory deficits. Laboratory parameters were normal except for a slightly elevated fasting blood glucose level. Cranial CT scan revealed contrast-enhancing, irregularly shaped lesions in the temporal, parietal, and frontal lobes, surrounded by perifocal edema. Carotid duplex ultrasonography showed no focal atherosclerotic plaques, circulatory disturbance, or stenosis on either side. Cranial MRI indicated a tumor in the right precentral gyrus corresponding to the ‘hand knob’, and further similar lesions in the parietal and temporal lobes, and in the left frontal lobe. Neuropsychological examination revealed a deficit in the Luria three-step test. A chest X-ray was conducted. A: The primary diagnosis is a cranial tumor in the right precentral gyrus, likely secondary to the patient's history of recurrent deep vein thrombosis and glaucoma. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of cranial lesions, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The management plan will include a referral to a neurology specialist for further evaluation and management of the cranial

S: The patient, referred to the Pediatric Clinic, reports a history of unilateral left facial palsy, first noticed on the 13th day postpartum. The parent reports a history of low-grade fever 7 days ago and purulent otorrhea 3 days ago. The patient has a history of no pregnancy complications and normal vaginal delivery. O: Physical examination revealed alertness, irritability, ill-appearing, hypotonic facial asymmetry, and hypotonic bilateral tympanic membranes. Laboratory findings included WBC 157000/mm3, Hb 6.2 gr/dL, Hct 18.6%, and platelet 130000/mm3. CSF analysis showed 670 RBC/dL, 630 WBC/dL (70% neutrophils, 30% lymphocytes), protein 14 mg/dL, and glucose 18 mg/dL. CRP was 1+; ESR was 70 mm/h. Peripheral blood smear showed polymorphonuclears (PMNs), myelocytes, basophil count approximately 20% of total cells, large platelets, and mild granulocytic dysplasia. Bone marrow aspiration and biopsy showed HLA DR: 2%, CD2: 3.3%, CD5: 2.8%, CD7: 2.

S: The patient, with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and polycythemia vera, presented with chest pain approximately 40 minutes prior to the ER visit. He reported anterior ST elevations and hemodynamics consistent with shock. O: Emergent angiography revealed 100% occlusion of the left anterior descending artery (LAD) with in-stent thrombosis and angiographic underexpansion of the stents. Catheterization was attempted with a 3.0 and 3.25 noncompliant balloon without resolution of the “waste” in the midportion of the stent. Bivalirudin was administered and passed a Runthrough wire distally, restoring antegrade TIMI 1 flow. Laser with contrast injections at 80/80 (fluency/rate) for about a minute, followed by aggressive dilation with a 2.5 and a 3.0 NC balloon, which expanded the stent. IVUS showed severe concentric calcification and a lumen diameter of 3.75–4.0 mm. A: The primary diagnosis is a PCI of the left anterior descending artery with in-stent thrombosis and angiographic underexpansion. Differential diagnoses initially included anterior ST elevations and shock. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic with appropriate management. P: The patient underwent successful postdilation of the stents with Bivalirudin, Runthrough wire, and aggressive dilation with a 2.5 and a 3.0 NC balloon. The patient is advised to continue monitoring his heart health with regular follow-ups with his cardiologist. Further consultations with a cardiologist may be necessary to manage his hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and polycythemia vera.

S: The patient is a 19-year-old female presenting with a 2-month history of pharyngeal pain, a left neck mass, and fever. She reported a tracheotomy at a local clinic due to airway obstruction caused by a large mass arising from the left parapharyngeal space. O: PET/CT scan revealed a large solid mass in the left parapharyngeal space with compression of the pharyngeal cavity and multiple enlarged lymph nodes in the left neck. Histopathological review confirmed histiocytic sarcoma. Histopathological analysis showed large polygonal cells with epithelioid-to-pleomorphic morphology, abundant eosinophilic to vacuolated or foamy cytoplasm, ovoid to irregularly shaped nuclei, and variably prominent nucleoli. Immunohistochemical markers expressed CD68 and CD163 and partially express S100. Irradiation of the pharyngeal and neck lesions was initiated on day 11 of chemotherapy, reducing the size of the lesions to 5.6 cm x 4.4 cm and 2.9 cm x 2.6 cm. Next-generation sequencing (NGS) of tumor tissue revealed an oncogenic mutation c.2888-1G>T in the MET gene, exon 14, with an allele frequency of 5.58%, and an activated mutation c.361. A: The primary diagnosis is histiocytic sarcoma with complications including airway obstruction and compression of the pharynx. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of histiocytic sarcomas, but histopathological findings support the primary diagnosis. P: Continue close monitoring of the patient's condition with regular follow-ups to assess treatment efficacy and response to treatment. Educate the patient on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and reporting any new symptoms or concerns. Encourage the patient to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately.

S: The patient reports experiencing right axillary swelling. The patient expresses concern about the symptoms and the treatment plan. O: CT imaging identified a space-occupying lesion in the S2 region of the right lung. Histological analysis revealed high-grade cytological atypia with poor intercellular cohesion. Immunohistochemical analysis showed positive pan-cytokeratin, vimentin, and thyroid transcription factor 1, negative for CD45 and CD30, and positive for Programmed cell death ligand 1 in more than 95% of tumor cells. The tumor was evaluated as cT4N2M0, indicating pleomorphic adenocarcinoma of the lung. Post-chemotherapy, the tumor reduced to 70  55  48 mm, reducing to 70  55  48 mm. Laboratory tests showed leukocytosis and thrombocytosis. A: The primary diagnosis is pleomorphic adenocarcinoma of the lung, cT4N2M0, with a partial response to chemotherapy. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of pleomorphic adenocarcinoma, but these are less likely given the imaging and immunohistochemical findings. P: The patient underwent chemotherapy with four courses of nab-paclitaxel plus carboplatin, followed by four courses of 120 mg (3 mg/kg) of nivolumab every 2 weeks. Post-treatment, the tumor reduced to 70  55  48 mm, with no new prodrome or mild noticeable irAEs until the last administration of nivolumab. The patient is advised to monitor symptoms closely and report any new prodrome or mild noticeable irAEs. Regular follow-ups will be scheduled to monitor the patient's response to the treatment and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient is a 77-year-old Japanese woman with a history of end-stage renal disease due to chronic glomerulonephritis, presenting with a chief complaint of a fourth episode of distal end-to-side radial-cephalic autologous AVF in the right forearm, which was created 29 months ago. She reports a history of 21 surgeries related to previous AVFs, including bilateral radiocephalic AVFs twice and percutaneous transluminal angioplasty (PTA) 19 times. O: Physical examination revealed a weak vascular murmur and a thrill in the right forearm. Preoperative ultrasonography showed venous stenosis 0-4 cm from the site of anastomosis, affecting 6 cm of the median cubital vein, with diameters less than 2 mm, and distal and proximal diameters of the lesions approximately 4-6 mm. PTA was performed as a salvage operation. Post-disinfecting the right upper limb, a 5 Fr  3 cm sheath was inserted into the cephalic vein around the middle of the right forearm. Retrograde angiography revealed venous stenosis 0-4 cm from the site of anastomosis. A KyoushaTM NT Peripheral Guidewire and an NSE PTA balloon catheter GDM01 successfully passed through the lesion. A: The primary diagnosis is distal end-to-side radial-cephalic autologous AVF in the right forearm, with complications including venous stenosis and vascular stenosis. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of vascular stenosis, but these are less likely given the imaging and surgical findings. P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition with regular hemodialysis and follow-up care. The patient is advised to maintain a regular hemodialysis schedule and follow any additional healthcare instructions provided by her healthcare team. Further consultations with a vascular surgeon and a hematologist are recommended to manage her chronic glomerulonephritis and manage her chronic glomerulonephritis.

S: The patient reports experiencing acroparesthesias, decreased sweating, exercise intolerance, and frequent episodes of diarrhea and abdominal discomfort. O: Physical examination revealed angiokeratomas on the palms and genitals. GalA test showed decreased enzyme activity at 0.1 nmol/hour/liter (normal >4 nmol/hour/liter). Genetic testing identified a mutation in the GLA gene (c.317T>G (p.L106R)). Laboratory results were unremarkable with a GFR of 104.4 mL/min/m2 (CKD-EPI equation), and 24-hour urinary albumin excretion of 6.00 mg/day. Renal ultrasound and DOPPLER echocardiogram were normal. Plasma Lyso-Gb3 value was 124.5 nmol/L. Relative excretion urinary levels of miR-21, miR-29, miR-192, miR-200, and miR-433 were detected using a reverse transcription reaction with a stem-loop primer. A: The patient is diagnosed with Fabry disease (FD), based on the clinical presentation and genetic findings. The treatment plan includes starting enzyme replacement therapy with agalsidase-beta at a dose of 1 mg/Kg/every other week. The patient is advised to reach out with any questions or concerns immediately.

S: The patient, a 4-day-old baby girl, was referred for genetic evaluation of bilateral asymmetric ectrodactyly. She is the second child of the mother and her husband, both non-consanguineous. She was delivered at term with a birth weight of 2.5 kg and no post-natal complications. The mother reports no previous medical and obstetrics history. The baby was delivered normally at term with no post-natal complications. O: The baby has ectrodactyly involving three limbs: the absence of the third digit on the left hand, the second and third digits on the right hand, and a fixed clubfoot deformity on the right foot with only 2 toes. Radiographs of the upper limbs showed complete absence of the metacarpal bone and phalanges of the third digit in the left hand, and absent metacarpals and phalanges of two digits on the right hand. Right tibial hemimelia was documented in her medical records. Ultrasonography of the abdomen, brain, and bilateral hips were normal. The mother's first child was 2 12 years old at the time of consultation. A: The primary diagnosis is bilateral asymmetric ectrodactyly with associated malformed digits and a fixed clubfoot deformity on the right foot. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of ectrodactyly, but these are less likely given the absence of metacarpal bone and phalanges. The absence of metacarpal bone and phalanges in the left hand and absent metacarpals and phalanges in the right hand are consistent with the primary diagnosis. The absence of facial dysmorphism or facial clefts is noted. The presence of a bi-phalangeal fifth digit on the left hand and a bi-phalangeal fifth digit on the right hand are consistent with the primary diagnosis. P: The management plan includes continued monitoring of the baby's development and management of the ectrodactyly. Referral to a pediatric neurologist for further evaluation and management of the ectrodactyly is recommended. The mother will be educated on the importance of adhering

S: The patient, a 23-year-old male, presented with a 2-day history of fever, headache, sporadic episodes of projectile vomiting, talking irrelevantly, and disorientation. He reports a history of an accidental fall from a two-story building 23 years ago, with a persistent CSF leak from the nose. He has a history of a CSF leak from his nose, treated with complete repair. O: Vital signs on admission included a fever of 39 °C, heart rate of 104 bpm, blood pressure of 130/60 mmHg, respiratory rate of 30/min, and blood glucose of 140 mg/dl. Glasgow Coma Scale score was 9, with motor, eye, and verbal responses indicating a low Glasgow Coma Scale score of 9. A CT scan revealed cystic gliosis changes in the left frontal lobe, communicating with the frontal horn of the ipsilateral lateral ventricle. CSF analysis indicated hypoglycorrachia with less than 20 mg/dl of sugar and blood sugar of 140 mg/dl, elevated protein levels at more than 300 mg/dl, and neutrophil-predominant pleocytosis with total cells of 360/mm3 and 96% polymorphs. Initial peripheral blood WBC count was 14,760 with 85% neutrophils, and serum lactate levels were 5.35 mmol/l. Renal and liver function tests were normal. A: The primary diagnosis is acute pyogenic meningitis with complications including hypoglycorrachia, elevated protein levels, and neutrophil-predominant pleocytosis. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of acute pyogenic meningitis, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The patient was started empirically on antibiotics and antiviral medications, including ceftriaxone 100 mg/kg/day in two divided doses, amoxycillin 100 mg/kg/day in four divided doses, and acyclovir 45 mg/kg/day in three divided doses. Initial peripheral blood WBC count was 14,760 with 85% neutrophils, and serum lactate levels were 5.35 mmol/l. Renal and

S: The patient is a 75-year-old woman presenting with severe bilateral leg edema and epigastralgia. She denies any history of chronic hepatitis or blood transfusions. O: Laboratory tests showed elevated serum aspartate aminotransferase at 48 U/L, mildly decreased serum albumin at 3.6 g/dL, mildly decreased serum (74%), mildly elevated D-dimer at 12.9 g/mL, and mildly elevated fibrin degradation product at 12.6 g/mL. Tumor marker AFP was slightly elevated at 585 ng/mL. CT scan revealed a large tumor in the right liver 21 cm in diameter and another 37 mm in diameter in the right atrium. Transesophageal ultrasound indicated a pedunculated tumor in the right atrium, swinging like a pendulum with heartbeat reaching the tricuspid valve. Thrombectomy of the tumor from the right atrium and inferior vena cava (IVC) was performed successfully. DC defibrillation was initiated, and 100 mg of protamine was administered for neutralization of heparin. The open heart surgery time was 23 minutes. A: The primary diagnosis is a pedunculated tumor in the right atrium, complicated by a symptomatic patient with a high surgical mortality rate. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of liver tumors, but these are less likely given the imaging and surgical findings. P: The patient underwent successful thrombectomy of the tumor from the right atrium and inferior vena cava. Post-operative care includes regular follow-ups to monitor recovery and ensure no complications arise. The patient is advised to maintain a healthy lifestyle and adhere strictly to follow-up schedules to prevent complications.

S: The patient is a 65-year-old female, ASA Class I, with a history of a Neer Type 3 humeral fracture and surgical repair. She reports relief from pain following ESPB surgery, which involved an open reduction and internal fixation via the anterolateral method. She reports no pain score higher than 3 out of 10 during the 24-hour follow-up evaluation. She denies any need for rescue analgesia. O: The patient's total PCA consumption was 240 mg in 24 hours, indicating a high PCA intake. The patient's total PCA consumption was 240 mg in 24 hours. A: The primary diagnosis is a Neer Type 3 humeral fracture with complications including a high PCA intake and a high PCA consumption. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of pain, but these are less likely given the patient's history and clinical presentation. P: Continue monitoring the patient's pain levels and adjust the treatment plan as necessary based on the patient's response to ESPB and PCA consumption. Maintain a low PCA intake and monitor the patient's PCA intake closely. Educate the patient on the importance of reporting any new symptoms or changes in her pain levels. Consider referral to a pain management specialist for further evaluation and management of her humeral fracture.

S: The patient, referred to the hospital, reports poor linear growth and excessive weight gain. The parent reports a healthy, full-term pregnancy with normal newborn screening tests. The child has a history of hypoglycemia, seizures, and midline cranial defects. The parent denies any prior history of hypoglycemia, seizures, or midline cranial defects. The child's neurodevelopment is appropriate for his age. O: The patient's growth chart shows a marked decrease in length percentiles from 73rd to 5th between ages 4 and 7 months, with a length-for-age z-score of -1.66 SD. Physical examination reveals obesity and plethoric moon facies. Laboratory findings include serum cortisol at 14.4 mcg/dL and plasma ACTH at 12 pg/mL. Thyroid function tests are normal. Insulin-like growth factor 1 (IGF-1) is low, insulin-like growth factor binding protein-3 (IGFBP-3) is normal. Midnight serum cortisol concentration is high at 10.4 and 7 mcg/dL, with no suppression of morning serum cortisol (9.8 mcg/dL). 24-hour UFC measurements are not elevated, but leakage around the bladder catheter and low urine creatinine excretion suggest incomplete collection. Pituitary MRI and abdominal ultrasound are normal. A: The primary diagnosis is hepatomegaly, evidenced by elevated serum cortisol and elevated adrenal function. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of hepatomegaly, but these are less likely given the imaging findings. P: Plan to proceed with further diagnostic evaluations to determine the cause of the child's symptoms and determine a suitable treatment plan. Continue monitoring the child's growth and development closely. Educate the parent on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and ensuring compliance with the treatment regimen. Schedule follow-up appointments to assess progress and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient, with a history of TIA and nephrolithiasis, presents with persistent leukocytosis and immature cells on a peripheral smear. The patient reports feeling easily fatigued for a few months but no other symptoms. O: Physical examination revealed persistent leukocytosis (17,500), neutrophil predominance (72%), lymphocytes 10%, monocytes 13%, eosinophils 1%, myelocytes 1%, and blasts 3%. Absolute neutrophil count was 2600 cells/mcL. Mild anemia (hemoglobin 11.6 mg/dl), thrombocytopenia (90000), and metabolic profile within normal limits. Additional tests including ANA, RA factor, ESR, CRP, iron, ferritin, thyroid function tests, vitamin B12, folate, copper serum, and urine immunofixation were normal. Bone marrow biopsy showed hypercellular marrow with 80% cellularity, granulocytic hyperplasia, and trilineage dyspoiesis with less than 5% blasts. FISH was negative for BCR-ABL fusion gene and MDS/AML probes. Cytogenetics analysis was normal with 46,XY. Blood CML PCR quantitative panel was negative for b2a2 and b3a2 transcripts and JAK2V617F mutation. A: The primary diagnosis is low-grade myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS) with a differential diagnosis of CML and MDS. The prognosis depends on the progression of symptoms and response to treatment. P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition with regular follow-ups to assess the progression of symptoms and adjust treatment as necessary. The patient is advised to maintain regular checkups and report any new symptoms immediately. Further treatment options may be considered if symptoms worsen or new symptoms develop.

S: The patient, with a history of partial resection of a left parotid cavernous hemangioma at age 2, external carotid embolization using lyophilized cadaveric dura and gelfoam emboli at age 6, ischemic stroke secondary to internal carotid embolism, right arm weakness, and multiple intracerebral hemorrhages, reports a history of multiple intracerebral hemorrhages, including a left frontal lobe intracerebral hemorrhage, memory impairment, intermittent confusion, and more intracerebral hemorrhages at age 33 and 35. O: Clinical examination revealed longstanding right hemiatrophy and mild right arm pyramidal weakness. Brain MRI showed chronic and recent lobar hematomas, patchy superficial siderosis, and innumerable lobar microbleeds. 18F-Florbetapir amyloid positron emission tomography (PET) indicated widespread moderate cortical amyloid deposition. CSF examination post-last symptomatic intracerebral hemorrhage showed low A1-42 levels at 261 pg/ml (normal range 627-1,322 pg/ml), normal total tau, tau/A ratio, 14-3-3 protein, and S100 levels. Next-generation sequencing for mutations in genes associated with dementia is ongoing. A: The primary diagnosis is multiple intracerebral hemorrhages, likely secondary to ischemic stroke or a complication of a left parotid cavernous hemangioma. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of cerebral hemorrhages, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: Continue monitoring the patient's neurological status closely and report any worsening of symptoms. Consider referral to a neurologist for further evaluation and management. Educate the patient on the importance of reporting any new or worsening symptoms immediately. Schedule regular follow-up appointments to monitor the patient's condition and adjust treatment as necessary.

S: The patient, a male with a history of gastroesophageal reflux disease, hyperlipidemia, and obstructive sleep apnea, presents with a chief complaint of a lesion on the left upper lip, which has been bothersome for a while. He denies any specific cause of the lesion. O: Physical examination revealed a plaque on the upper lip. Biopsy results confirmed squamous cell carcinoma in situ. The patient also noted erosions and altered nail folds in the fingers, suggesting a contributing factor. The lunula of the right thumb is markedly enlarged. A: The primary diagnosis is squamous cell carcinoma in situ, a type of skin cancer. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of skin cancers, but the biopsy results indicate squamous cell carcinoma. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the early detection of the lesion. P: The management plan includes surgical intervention for squamous cell carcinoma in situ and addressing the issues with the nails. The patient will be educated on the nature of the disease, treatment options, and potential side effects. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the disease progression and manage any complications.

S: The patient, a 56-year-old mother and 30-year-old sister, presented with repetitive ventricular ectopic beats. The patient denies any significant symptoms such as syncope or sudden cardiac death in the family. The patient has a history of acute myocarditis one year ago, presenting with chest pain, troponin rise, and T wave inversion in the inferolateral leads on ECG. The patient denies any other relevant symptoms such as syncope or sudden cardiac death. O: The patient's coronary angiogram showed normal coronary arteries. Cardiac magnetic resonance (CMR) indicated a non-dilated left ventricle with low-normal ejection fraction, normal RV dimensions, and function. T2-weighted images showed mid-wall myocardial edema involving the interventricular septum, and mid-wall late gadolinium enhancement. A new CMR study confirmed mildly reduced LV EF without myocardial edema. Post-contrast images showed diffuse circumferential subepicardial late gadolinium enhancement (LGE) involvement of the LV myocardium. Genetic testing and family screening were conducted, excluding a left-dominant variant of arrhythmogenic cardiomyopathy. A: The primary diagnosis is acute myocarditis with complications including a non-dilated left ventricle, mid-wall myocardial edema, and diffuse circumferential subepicardial late gadolinium enhancement. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of myocardial edema and myocardial edema, but these are less likely given the new findings. P: The management plan includes close clinical follow-up and close monitoring of the patient's condition and family's health. Genetic testing and family screening are necessary to exclude a left-dominant variant of arrhythmogenic cardiomyopathy. Close monitoring of the patient's condition and family's health is essential. The patient and family will be educated on the importance of compliance with the treatment plan and follow-up schedules.

S: The patient, with a history of exercise-induced asthma, presents with left-sided chest pain since receiving the second dose of the Moderna vaccine. The pain worsens with deep breaths, accompanied by fever and chills. The patient denies any recent tick bites, upper respiratory symptoms, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea (PND), orthopnea, arthralgias, or rashes. O: Physical examination revealed normal vital signs, normal heart sounds, and no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. No jugular vein distention (JVD) or chest wall tenderness. Lungs were clear upon auscultation. Lower extremities did not exhibit pitting edema. Diagnostic tests showed elevated troponin T at 475ng/L (normal range less than 22ng/L), right axis deviation with left posterior fascicular block, premature atrial contractions (PACs) in trigeminy, and pericardial effusion. CT angiography of the chest was negative for pulmonary embolism. Lyme serology, ANA, respiratory viral panel, and TSH were normal. Leukocytosis was elevated at 11.09 K/ul and absolute neutrophil count was 8.09 K/uL. ESR was elevated at 37mm/hr, and CRP was 11.6mg/L. A: The primary diagnosis is pericardial effusion secondary to the Moderna vaccine. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of acute chest pain, but these are less likely given the elevated troponin T. The prognosis depends on the progression of the infection and response to treatment. P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's symptoms and test results. The patient is advised to rest and stay hydrated, and return to the emergency department if symptoms worsen or new symptoms develop. Further testing or treatment may be considered based on the progression of the infection or new symptoms. The patient is encouraged to report any new symptoms immediately.

S: The patient is a 55-year-old female with a history of numbness of extremities for a month. She was previously admitted to a city hospital due to a suspected intramedullary mass lesion in the medulla oblongata, which was high-risk. She reports worsening intractable hiccough and intractable numbness in her extremities. O: Neurological examination revealed marked deep sensory disturbance in the distal portions of the extremities. MR imaging revealed a circumscribed mass lesion on the medulla oblongata, hyperintense on T2-weighted images, isointense on T1-WI, and enhanced homogeneously with gadolinium-diethylenetriamine penta-acetic acid. Cerebrospinal fluid showed slightly elevated protein levels. ECG indicated a complete atrioventricular block. CT of the neck and chest showed bilateral supraclavicular, hilar, and mediastinal lymphadenopathy. A permanent pacemaker insertion was performed, followed by transbranchial needle aspiration. Pathological examination confirmed a noncaseating granuloma with epithelioid cells, lymphocytes, and rare multinucleated giant cells. A: The primary diagnosis is sarcoidosis, evidenced by imaging and pathological findings. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of numbness, but these are less likely given the imaging and pathological findings. P: The patient was started on oral prednisone therapy at 60 mg/day for 4 weeks, followed by a permanent pacemaker insertion and transbranchial needle aspiration to address the AV block. Post-treatment, the patient was tapered to 20 mg/day over the course of 5 months, with no recurrence of symptoms. The patient is advised to maintain regular follow-up appointments to monitor for any recurrence of symptoms.

S: The patient reports experiencing fever and arthralgia since May, occurring 2 to 3 days prior to menstruation. The symptoms coincide with the start of menstruation. The patient has a history of high fever and arthralgia occurring during the menstrual period. The patient also reports a history of a high fever and arthralgia at the initiation of menstruation in September. O: On admission, vital signs showed a body temperature of 36.8°C, blood pressure of 97/68 mm Hg, heart rate of 97 beats/min, and SpO2 of 98% on room air. Physical examination revealed mild arthralgia in the joints of both shoulders, elbows, and knees, with no signs of peritonitis, pleuritis, or erysipelas-like skin lesions.
