Laboratory tests showed WBC 3600/L (neutrophils 72.8%, lymphocytes 18.9%), Hb 12.0 g/dL (platelets 18.6104/L), CRP 9.53 mg/dL (feritin 51 ng/mL), and SAA 884.5 g/mL (normal range 6.0–138 ng/mL). Serum complement level was normal. Urinalysis showed no abnormalities. Immunologic and serologic tests were negative. A: The primary diagnosis is a recurrent fever and arthralgia, likely triggered by a recurrent infection, given the negative immunologic and serologic findings. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of arthralgia, but these are less likely given the negative immunologic and serologic results. P: Continue monitoring the patient's symptoms and adjust the treatment plan as necessary based on further diagnostic results. Schedule a follow-up appointment in one week or sooner if symptoms worsen. Educate the patient on the importance of reporting any new symptoms or concerns immediately. Consider referral to a rheumatologist for further evaluation and management of arthralgia.

S: The patient is a 77-year-old male with a history of smoldering type ATLL, treated with topical corticosteroids, narrow-band ultraviolet B, oral etretinate, electron radiation therapy, oral prednisolone, and low-dose etoposide, presenting with severe stomatitis. He reports a history of severe stomatitis and has been treated with topical corticosteroids, narrow-band ultraviolet B, and oral etretinate. O: Histopathological examination reveals dense infiltration of small-to-medium-sized pleomorphic lymphoid cells in the dermis with prominent epidermotropism. Histopathological findings include CD3+, CD4+, CD8, CD79a, and CCR4+, with atypical Foxp3+ cells. Blood tests show no hematological parameters or liver function issues. Blood examination shows mild renal dysfunction with BUN 22.7 mg/dL, creatinine 1.06 mg/dL, and eGFR 52.3 mL/min/1.73 m2. A: The primary diagnosis is smoldering type ATLL with complications including severe stomatitis and pleomorphic lymphoid cell infiltration. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of stomatitis, but histopathological findings support the primary diagnosis. P: Initiate mogamulizumab 1.0 mg/kg once weekly for 8 weeks to control the progression of skin lesions. Regular monitoring of renal function and eGFR is necessary. The patient is advised to continue monitoring diabetes and report any new or worsening symptoms. Regular follow-ups are scheduled to assess renal function and response to the treatment.

S: The patient is a 29-year-old male with a history of chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML) in high-risk chronic phase since February 2010. He reports a history of imatinib treatment with a hematological response in the second month but did not achieve cytogenetic response in the 18th month. He switched to dasatinib in March 2013 after verification of lack of cytogenetic response. He experienced a progression to blast crisis of myeloid origin with 72% blasts and a karyotype without growth of metaphases, concomitant infiltrative cutaneous involvement, bone lesions of lytic type, and hypercalcemia. He experienced severe bone pain, inflamed skin, and painful skin. He started nilotinib treatment in March 2017, and underwent induction with 7 + 3 chemotherapy including cytarabine, idarubicin, and bosutinib for 14 days. He experienced infectious complications including invasive fungal infection and bacteremia due to Enterococcus faecium, and symptomatic hypocalcemia due to bisphosphonates. O: The patient's BCR-ABL transcription level increased from 6.3% to 58% in September 2016. Bone marrow study showed 72% blasts and a karyotype without growth of metaphases, concomitant infiltrative cutaneous involvement, bone lesions of lytic type, and hypercalcemia. zoledronic acid was used as an oncological emergency. Induction with 7 + 3 chemotherapy included cytarabine, idarubicin, bosutinib, invasive fungal infection, bacteremia due to Enterococcus faecium, and symptomatic hypocalcemia due to bisphosphonates. A: The primary diagnosis is blast crisis of myeloid origin with complications including invasive fungal infection, bacteremia due to Enterococcus faecium, and symptomatic hypocalcemia due to bisphosphonates. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of bone pain and skin inflammation. The prognosis is guarded due to the complexity of the disease and the patient

S: The patient, a male, presented to the emergency department following a car accident involving a 5-ton water tanker. He reported profuse bleeding due to a perineum injury. He denies any pain in the head or neck. O: On examination, the patient's Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score was 15, with a pulse rate of 80 beats per minute and blood pressure of 90/60 mmHg. X-rays showed no fractures of the skull, cervical spine, and pelvis. Urinary catheterization was performed without difficulty, and abdominal ultrasound showed no internal bleeding. During surgery, the patient was placed in the lithotomy position with anterior displacement of the anus and a circular skin defect surrounding the region, with 1 cm of normal perianal skin left. Digital and proctoscopy examination showed an intact anorectum and surrounding sphincters. Exploration of the wound revealed extensive venous bleeding, with no major arterial tears. A defunctioning sigmoid colostomy was performed without intra-abdominal bleeding. A: The primary diagnosis is a perineum injury secondary to a car accident. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of perineum injury, but these are less likely given the imaging and surgical findings. The prognosis is guarded due to the extensive venous bleeding and absence of major arterial tears. P: The patient underwent a defunctioning sigmoid colostomy with no intra-abdominal bleeding. Post-operative care includes regular follow-up examinations to monitor recovery and manage any complications. The patient is advised to attend these appointments and report any issues or discomfort. Further consultations with a nephrologist and a cardiologist are recommended to manage and manage the perineum injury.

S: The patient is a gravida 1 female with a history of stage I endometriosis, a patent right fallopian tube, and intrauterine synechia for 15 years. She reports irregular menstrual cycles since menarche at age 13, with spotting for approximately 5 days every other month. She denies allergies and is not on any medications. She has a history of a left cornual ectopic pregnancy 16 years ago, which led to exploratory laparotomy with left cornual resection. O: Initial transvaginal ultrasound revealed a 7  5 cm solid homogeneous appearing ovoid mass on the left ovary, suspicious for a granulosa cell tumor. Baseline AMH level was elevated at 14.3, but CA-125 level was normal at 13. A laparoscopic left salpingo-oophorectomy and lysis of adhesions confirmed the tumor as a granulosa cell tumor. Post-surgery, AMH level decreased to 0.64 ng/mL and inhibin B level dropped to 14 pg/mL. Six months post-surgery, she successfully conceived an intra-uterine pregnancy, ending in a first trimester loss. A: The primary diagnosis is a granulosa cell tumor in the left ovary, complicated by a first trimester loss. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of endometriosis, but these are less likely given the imaging and surgical findings. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic with ongoing infertility treatment. P: Continue monitoring the patient's AMH levels and inhibin B levels closely. Continue regular follow-ups with oncology and gynecology to assess for any recurrence or complications. Educate the patient on signs of complications and encourage her to report any new symptoms immediately. Consider referral to a nephrologist for ongoing management of her infertility.

S: The patient, referred by an orthodontist, reports no pain, discomfort, or medical issues. He has a history of successful restoration of cleft lip and palate. O: Extra-oral examination revealed facial asymmetry on the left side, flattening of the nasal bridge, increased intercanthal distance (35 cm), and frontal bossing (54 cm). Multiple skin lesions on arms, right foot, and palmar/plantar pits were noted. Intra-oral examination revealed multiple carious teeth, painless hard swelling in the left mandible, mild pain on percussion in all left mandibular posterior teeth, bilateral radiolucent lesions associated with a partially erupted mandibular second molar teeth, horizontally impacted maxillary right second molar, and congenitally missing second premolars and third molars. Cone Beam Computed Tomography (CBCT) indicated bilateral radiolucent lesions associated with a partially erupted mandibular second molar teeth, horizontally impacted maxillary right second molar, and congenitally missing second premolars and third molars. Skull X-ray revealed calcification of the falx cerebri on the posteroanterior view. A: The primary diagnosis is a calcification of the falx cerebri, likely secondary to a dental accident. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of calcification, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The management plan will include a comprehensive dental evaluation to assess the extent of the calcification and the extent of the calcification. The patient will be educated on the importance of maintaining good oral hygiene and regular dental checkups. Further consultations with an orthodontist will be scheduled to discuss the treatment plan. The patient is advised to maintain good oral hygiene and attend regular dental checkups.

S: The patient, referred by a general dental practitioner, reports noncarious tooth surface loss of permanent maxillary anterior teeth. The patient has a history of hypoglycaemia diagnosed at age two, which causes blood sugar to become low. The patient also has severe asthma, migraine attacks every other day since age 8, vomiting, and nausea. The patient has a history of hospitalization due to asthma and has been on sumatriptan and Migraleve for migraines and domperidone for vomiting. The patient has an allergy to peanuts. O: Clinical examination revealed generalized dental erosion, causing a fracture of the mesial surface of both maxillary central incisors, and several restorations on posterior teeth. The patient was anxious during the first visit, and radiographic examinations were performed during the second visit. A: The primary diagnosis is generalized dental erosion of the permanent maxillary anterior teeth, complicated by severe asthma and migraine attacks. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of dental erosion, but these are less likely given the clinical and radiographic findings. The prognosis depends on the management of the dental erosion and prevention of further damage. P: The management plan will include addressing the patient's dietary habits and addressing dental erosion. The patient will be educated on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and dietary modifications to prevent further damage. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's response to treatment and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Referral to a pediatric neurologist for further evaluation and management of the dental erosion is recommended.

S: The patient, a male infant, was born via cesarean section during the 38th week of pregnancy, with a birth weight of 3300 g. He developed abdominal distension and diarrhea from the 10th day of treatment, which resolved with oral metronidazole and vancomycin. He also developed severe abdominal distension and constipation after 3 weeks of conservative treatment. O: Initial barium enema examination revealed stenosis at the junction of the sigmoid and descending colon, and a distended proximal bowel. Second barium enema examination revealed another stenosis of the right transverse colon, with two segments of stenoses at the junction of the sigmoid and descending colon and a distended proximal bowel. Pathological examination showed fibrosis of lamina propria in the narrow segments. Ganglion cells were normal. Post-operative follow-up showed normal dietary intake and defecation. A: The primary diagnosis is Clostridium difficile infection secondary to stenoses at the junction of the sigmoid and descending colon and right transverse colon. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of abdominal distension and constipation. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the successful surgical intervention and stable growth and development at the 1-year follow-up. P: Continue monitoring the patient's health closely and report any new symptoms or changes in his condition. Regular follow-ups are recommended to assess growth and development. Educate the mother on the importance of reporting any new symptoms or concerns immediately.

S: The patient, recently diagnosed with intra-operative anaphylaxis in the Corpus Callosum, reports difficulty in managing himself and mild cognitive dysfunction. He was initially diagnosed with intra-operative anaphylaxis 4 days ago, which was ruled out due to a short timeline. He has a history of treated hypertension but no other underlying illnesses. He underwent surgical procedures including midazolam, remifentanil, and propofol total intravenous anaesthesia, rocuronium, and cephazolin. He developed intractable hypotension and concomitant bronchospasm, leading to a clinical anaphylactic episode. O: The patient underwent a histo-pathological diagnosis of intra-operative anaphylaxis, which was ruled out due to the short timeline. Post-operative complications included intractable hypotension and concomitant bronchospasm, which led to a clinical anaphylactic episode. The patient was treated with an adrenaline infusion and was admitted to the Intensive Care Unit with an endotracheal tube in situ. No specific allergen testing was available at that time due to the urgency of the patient's condition. A: The primary diagnosis is intra-operative anaphylaxis in the Corpus Callosum. The patient's history of hypertension and previous surgical procedures complicates the management of the anaphylactic episode. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of anaphylaxis, but these are less likely given the patient's history and current findings. P: The patient underwent a histo-pathological diagnosis of intra-operative anaphylaxis, which was ruled out due to the short timeline. He was treated with midazolam, remifentanil, and propofol total intravenous anaesthesia, rocuronium, and cephazolin. He was admitted to the Intensive Care Unit with an endotracheal tube in situ, and re-presented 4 days later for a repeat procedure. Specific allergen testing was unavailable due to the urgency of the patient's condition. The patient was re-presented 4 days later for a repeat procedure. A: The primary

S: The patient, born from a second pregnancy, reports a history of early miscarriage, which threatened spontaneous interruption. The first pregnancy ended in an early miscarriage. The patient was delivered via Cesarean section due to high myopia. The patient's motor and speech development milestones were delayed. At 8 months, he was hospitalized due to hypotonia. At 13 months, a brain MRI showed leukodystrophy, lissencephaly of the left occipital lobe, polymicrogyria of both frontal lobes, secondary ventriculomegaly, and brain atrophic changes with enlargement of sub-arachnoid spaces. Biochemical analysis showed elevated creatine kinase (CK) at 2024 U/L, ALT at 59 U/L, AST at 82 U/L, and LDH at 318 U/L. Electromyographic examination revealed primary muscle involvement. A: The primary diagnosis is cerebral leukodystrophy with associated brain atrophic changes and muscle weakness. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of cerebral leukodystrophy, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and management of the neurological symptoms. P: The management plan includes regular follow-ups to monitor the neurological status and adjust treatment as necessary. The patient is advised to maintain regular check-ups and consult with pediatric neurology for further evaluation and management of cerebral leukodystrophy. Referral to a pediatric neurology specialist for further evaluation and management of cerebral leukodystrophy is recommended.

S: The patient is a 36-year-old male with a history of ketamine use for 6 to 7 years, 2–3 times per week by nasal inhalation, which he discontinued 4 years ago. He reports experiencing dysuria, bladder pain, and a mild burning sensation during urination, particularly around the urethral meatus and perineal region. He initially ignored these symptoms but worsened with worsening symptoms, including decreased voiding amount (50 mL per void) and urge incontinence, painful hematuria, and blood clot formation. O: Urine analysis revealed pyuria with over 100 white blood cells per high-power field. Digital rectal examination showed significant tenderness and swelling of the prostate but no pus-like discharge. Blood tests showed a WBC count of 4870/L without neutrophils or eosinophils, and no marked elevation of serum CRP at 0.25 mg/dL. Temperature was normal, and no signs of toxicity were noted. Blood and urine cultures were taken. A: The primary diagnosis is acute prostatitis, likely exacerbated by ketamine use, given the elevated WBC count and elevated serum CRP. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of urinary tract infections, but these are less likely given the culture results. P: The patient was admitted for advanced antibiotic treatment with ceftriaxone, which was started due to failure of oral antibiotics. The treatment plan includes close monitoring of the patient's response to antibiotics and adjustments to the antibiotics as necessary based on culture results. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms immediately. Further consultations with infectious disease specialists and a nephrologist are planned to assess the effectiveness of the treatment and adjust as necessary.

S: The patient is a 72-year-old Japanese woman with a 10-year history of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (T2DM) and a 10-year history of hypertension and dyslipidemia. She presents with diarrhea and persistent pain in the left lower abdomen for 2 days. She denies smoking, alcohol use, tobacco use, or other history of digestive disease or obstetrics and gynecology-related diseases. O: Physical examination revealed mild tenderness to palpation in the abdomen. Vital signs included blood pressure 150/87 mmHg, heart rate 110 beats/minute, and temperature 36.4 °C. Inflammatory markers were elevated at 20,110/L with 89.0% neutrophils, and CRP 16.12 mg/dL. Anemia and mild hypoalbuminemia were noted. RBC count was 304  104/L, hemoglobin 9.3 g/dL, total protein 6.8 g/dL, and albumin 3.2 g/dL. Liver and renal function were normal. AST was 14 U/L, ALT was 9 U/L, -GTP was 8 U/L, LDH was 202 U/L, creatinine was 0.81 mg/dL, and BUN was within normal limits. A: The primary diagnosis is acute abdominal pain secondary to T2DM with complications including anemia and mild hypoalbuminemia. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of abdominal pain, but these are less likely given the elevated WBC count and elevated CRP. P: Plan to conduct further diagnostic tests to confirm the diagnosis and rule out other causes of abdominal pain. Continue current medications and monitor symptoms closely. Educate the patient on signs of worsening symptoms and encourage immediate reporting of new symptoms. Schedule a follow-up appointment in one week or sooner if symptoms worsen or new symptoms develop.

S: The patient, recently diagnosed with ductal carcinoma in situ, reports noticing a lump in her breast and discomfort. The patient has experienced a lump in her breast and discomfort. O: The patient's imaging report shows a voltage of 30 kV, tube current of 61, and thickness of 46 mm, with 15 projections and an average glandular dose of 1.75. The AGD is 1.75, indicating the amount of radiation received during the mammogram. A: The primary diagnosis is ductal carcinoma in situ, a non-invasive breast cancer with no spread beyond the milk ducts. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of breast cancer, but these are less likely given the imaging results and symptoms. P: The management plan includes discussing treatment options such as surgery, radiation therapy, or hormone therapy based on imaging results and symptoms. The patient will be educated on the importance of follow-up appointments and the importance of adhering to the treatment plan. Further consultations with oncology and oncology may be necessary depending on the patient's overall health, preferences, and specific characteristics of the carcinoma.

S: The patient reports experiencing lower back pain for the last 2 months, radiating to both groins. The patient denies any significant past medical history. O: Vital signs at presentation include BP 120/70 mm Hg, pulse 82 bpm, RR 18/minute, and T 98.9°F. Physical examination and lab work were unremarkable. CT scan revealed a sclerotic and lytic lesion in the T12 vertebra. Chest CT showed multiple bilateral pulmonary nodules and mediastinal and hilar lymphadenopathy. Biopsy confirmed a malignant neoplasm with spindle cells. Immunohistochemical stains were positive for Bcl-2, vimentin, EMA, CD56, CD99, TLE-1, and negative for CD34, CD10, P63, cytokeratin, S100, desmin, and synaptophysin. Interphase FISH was positive for a rearrangement involving the SYT gene (18q11), consistent with synovial sarcoma. Whole-body CT scan was negative. A: The primary diagnosis is metastatic synovial sarcoma with spindle cells and synovial sarcoma. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of metastatic malignancies, but these are less likely given the imaging and biopsy results. P: Refer the patient to a specialized facility for further management of the synovial sarcoma. Refer the patient to a neoplasm specialist for further evaluation and management. Educate the patient on signs of worsening symptoms and ensure compliance with the treatment plan. Refer the patient to a neoplasm specialist for further evaluation and management.

S: Patient 1, a male with a history of hepatic steatosis, obesity, and chronic hepatitis by HCV, reports feeling tired and experiencing abdominal pain. He was diagnosed at age three and discharged with a diagnosis of hepatic steatosis, obesity, and chronic hepatitis by HCV in 2007. He recalls feeling tired and experiencing abdominal pain at the time of his diagnosis. The patient has a history of hepatic steatosis, obesity, and chronic hepatitis by HCV. O: The patient's liver elastometry shows a rapid progression from 4KPa in 2012 to 8KPa in 2017, with liver stiffness worsening from 4KPa in 2012 to 8KPa in 2017. A: The primary diagnosis is hepatic steatosis, obesity, and chronic hepatitis by HCV. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of liver fibrosis, but these are less likely given the patient's history and clinical presentation. P: The management plan includes prescribing DAAs to improve liver health and improve liver function. The patient is advised to adhere strictly to the prescribed dosage and complete the course of treatment. Regular follow-up appointments are scheduled to monitor liver health and manage any new or worsening symptoms. The patient is encouraged to report any new or worsening symptoms immediately.

S: The patient, a deaf individual, reports experiencing tinnitus, anxiety, and depression since childhood. The patient has a history of pneumonia, high fever, and hearing loss. The patient has been using sign language since elementary school, and has not used oral communication since then. The patient has a history of sleep onset disorder, nocturnal awakening, and palpitations. O: The patient's Tinnitus Handicap Inventory score is 94, indicating severe tinnitus. The Self-rating Depression Scale score is 61, indicating a tendency toward depression. State-Trait Anxiety Inventory scores show extremely high anxiety tendencies (State Anxiety score 69 and Trait Anxiety score 67). Imaging tests including a temporal bone CT scan showed no significant abnormalities except for a slight enlargement of the inner ear canals. A: The primary diagnosis is severe tinnitus with associated anxiety and depression. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of tinnitus, but these are less likely given the imaging findings and clinical presentation. The prognosis is guarded due to the severity of the tinnitus and the patient's deaf nature. P: The management plan will include a tailored treatment plan to address tinnitus, anxiety, and depression. Close monitoring of the patient's progress will be necessary, with adjustments to the treatment plan as necessary. The patient will be educated on the importance of adherence to the treatment plan and the importance of follow-up appointments. Referral to a neurologist for further evaluation and management of tinnitus and anxiety is recommended.

S: The patient is a 23-year-old female presenting with a 4-month history of fluctuating weakness in the right upper and lower extremities, a band-like sensation in the trunk, bowel and bladder disturbances, dysphonia, dysphagia, difficulty breathing, and projectile vomiting. She reported experiencing an electric-like sensation on her nape, worsening with neck movement, and progressive weakness to the left lower extremity, requiring assistance for daily activities. She also experienced dysphonia, dysphagia, difficulty breathing, and projectile vomiting. O: On admission, the patient was hemodynamically stable with no spinal deformities. Cranial nerve examination revealed weak gag and shoulder shrug bilaterally. Manual motor testing showed strength 2-3/5 in both upper and left extremities, strength 4/5 in the right lower extremity, hypesthesia at the C4 dermatomal level, dissociated sensory loss, hyper-reflexia in both upper and lower extremities, and paratonic neck. Cranio-spinal MRI indicated a long expansile contrast-enhancing mass involving the entire spinal cord, from the cervical region to the conus medullaris, extending to the lower medulla oblongata. On the 20th hospital day, symptoms progressed to quadriplegia and respiratory failure, followed by healthcare-associated pneumonia and succumbed to septicemia. Autopsy confirmed consolidated lobes of the lungs. A: The primary diagnosis is a spinal cord mass with complications including septicemia and complications from the mass. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of spinal cord weakness and neurological deficits. The prognosis is guarded due to the complexity of the disease and the complexity of the neurological symptoms. P: The patient was started on dexamethasone with minimal relief of symptoms. She was referred to the neurosurgery service for further evaluation and management. Ongoing management included monitoring for complications such as septicemia and pulmonary resection. The patient was referred to the neurosurgery service for further evaluation and management. Family support and education on the nature of the disease and the importance of follow-up care were provided.

S: The patient, a 34-year-old with a history of asthma, hearing loss, and hypertension, presented with progressive shortness of breath. He reported a blood pressure reading of 143/91 mmHg 10 months ago. He has a family history of asthma, hearing loss, and hypertension. O: On admission, the patient's blood pressure was 191/125 mmHg. Physical examination was unremarkable. Urine analysis revealed 25-50 non-dysmorphic RBCs/HPF, 5-10 WBCs/HPF, 100 mg/dl protein, positive leukocyte esterase, and numerous "muddy brown casts." Laboratory tests showed a white blood cell count of 7.2  109/L, hemoglobin 8.9 g/dL, platelet count 73,000/L, BUN 71 mg/dL, and serum creatinine 10.11 mg/dL. Other studies showed AST 34 u/L, ALT 36 u/L, haptoglobin 10 mg/dl, and LDH 2331 u/L. Chest x-ray showed pulmonary congestion and echogenic kidneys on ultrasound. A: The primary diagnosis is pulmonary congestion secondary to hepatitis B, C, HIV, and serum and urine immunoelectrophoresis. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of pulmonary congestion, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and laboratory findings. P: Initiated hemodialysis with a kidney biopsy showing 2 glomeruli. Plan to further analyze the kidney biopsy results and discuss the appropriate treatment plan. Regular follow-ups will be scheduled to monitor the patient's condition and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Patient education regarding the importance of adherence to the treatment plan and regular monitoring of blood pressure is crucial.

S: The patient, with a history of non-insulin dependent diabetes mellitus, presented with a blunt force trauma to the leg. The patient reported significant pain and discomfort. O: Physical examination revealed an isolated closed tibial plateau fracture, Schatzker type 6, with significant swelling of the proximal tibia and two large hemorrhagic fracture blisters anteriorly. No clinical evidence of compartment syndrome was noted. A circumferential wound vac was applied, with decompression of the fracture blisters without removing the overlying epidermis, lined the fracture blister edges with adhesive drapes, and customized a Veraflo sponge. Normal saline was 20 ml with one-minute soak times at two-hour intervals, suction was negative one hundred, 25 mmHg, and preveNA Plus foam was applied circumferentially to the remaining tibia and distal femur. Knee immobilizer was placed, and non-weight bearing precautions were applied. A: The primary diagnosis is a Schatzker type 6 closed tibial plateau fracture with hemorrhagic fracture blisters. The patient's history of non-insulin dependent diabetes mellitus and a history of non-insulin dependent diabetes mellitus complicate the management of the fracture. P: The patient underwent surgical intervention with a circumferential wound vac and preveNA Plus foam. Post-operative care included close monitoring of swelling and skin compromise. The patient was placed on non-weight bearing precautions and was placed on non-weight bearing precautions. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor recovery and adjust treatment as necessary. The patient is advised to maintain regular follow-up appointments and report any new symptoms or concerns.

S: The patient, with a history of high-grade B lymphoma treated with cyclophosphamide and rituximab, and triple intrathecal therapy (MTX, Ara-C, and dexamethasone) as CNS prophylaxis, reports experiencing weakness in the lower limbs ten days post-lumbar puncture, worsening to paraplegia and difficulty controlling bladder. The patient denies any other symptoms. O: Neurological examination revealed absence of deep tendon reflexes in the lower limbs and a sensory level at T1. Cerebrospinal fluid parameters were within normal limits. Nerve conduction studies (NCS) and EMG showed absence of the F wave in both lower limbs with a minimal amplitude decrease and normal latency in CMAP responses, suggestive of lumbosacral polyradiculoneuropathy. Upper limb MRI with gadolinium showed no abnormalities. Lumbosacral MRI with gadolinium showed no abnormalities. A: The primary diagnosis is lumbosacral polyradiculoneuropathy secondary to MTX-it treatment. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of limb weakness and paraplegia, but these are less likely given the imaging results and clinical presentation. P: The patient was started on intravenous methylprednisolone, which did not improve the condition. The patient has been on intravenous methylprednisolone for 6 months, with no improvement in motor amplitudes and moderate denervation in the proximal and distal muscles of the lower limbs. Continued monitoring of the patient's condition is necessary, with adjustments to treatment as necessary based on the patient's response to treatment and response to therapy. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess progress and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient reports a painless, firm, mobile mass in the right cheek, characterized by right facial nerve paralysis, facial numbness, and progressive hearing loss for the past year-and-a-half. The patient also experiences right facial nerve paralysis, facial numbness, and progressive hearing loss for the past year-and-a-half. O: PET-CT scan revealed an FDG-avid 2.2 x 2.0 cm mass centered along the anterolateral aspect of the right masseter muscle without parotid gland involvement. MRI indicated enhancement of the right trigeminal nerve from its origin to Meckel's cave, and enhancement of the right facial nerve from the internal auditory canal to the middle ear. Fine needle aspiration of the mass showed clusters of atypical spindled cells with elongated, irregular nuclei. Histopathologic review confirmed a poorly differentiated MPNST, with no evidence of metastatic tumor in lymph nodes. A: The primary diagnosis is a poorly differentiated MPNST in the right cheek, characterized by a poorly differentiated tumor adjacent to the parotid gland. The patient's symptoms of right facial nerve paralysis, facial numbness, and progressive hearing loss persist for the past year-and-a-half. P: The patient underwent a total right parotidectomy with selective resection of the facial and trigeminal nerves (mandibular division). Histopathologic review confirmed a poorly differentiated MPNST, with no evidence of metastatic tumor in lymph nodes. A: The primary diagnosis is poorly differentiated MPNST in the right cheek, characterized by a poorly differentiated tumor with no evidence of metastatic tumor. The patient's symptoms of right facial nerve paralysis, facial numbness, and progressive hearing loss persist for the past year-and-a-half. P: The patient underwent total right parotidectomy with selective resection of the facial and trigeminal nerves (mandibular division). Post-radiation therapy, the patient will be closely monitored for any new symptoms or changes in the condition. Further interventions may be considered based on the patient's response to initial treatment and response to radiation therapy. Education

S: The patient reports experiencing obstinate constipation for a month and a month ago, accompanied by weakness in the lower limbs and tingling below the chest. Recently, the patient experienced a girdle-like sensation in the right side of the abdomen and worsening weakness in the lower limbs. The patient denies any bladder dysfunction. O: Physical examination revealed sensory impairment of all modalities below Th6 dermatomes on the right side and below Th8 dermatomes on the left side, absent deep tendon reflexes in the right upper and lower limbs, and bilateral Babinski reflexes. Cranial nerve examination identified no abnormalities. Serum anti-aquaporin 4, anti-myelin oligodendrocyte glycoprotein, anti-glycolipid, and anti-neurofascin155 antibodies were negative. Serum anti-lactosylceramide antibody (IgG) was positive. Serum anti-glucoceramide antibody and cerebrospinal fluid anti-lactosylceramide antibody (IgG) were equivocal. CSF analysis showed pleocytosis with 35 cells/L, elevated total protein at 83 mg/dL, myelin basic protein at 818 pg/mL, and IgG index upregulated at 1.54. OCB were positive. Gadolinium-enhanced MRI indicated multiple foci of abnormal signal intensities in the medulla and spinal cord, with no ovoid lesions or Dawson's fingers. Nerve conduction study (NCS) indicated reduced compound muscle action potential (CMAP) amplitudes in bilateral peroneal nerves (0.8 and 0.9 mV, respectively). Conduction block was observed in the right tibial nerve (distal and proximal CMAPs: 10.7 and 1.9 mV). A: The primary diagnosis is obstinate constipation, likely exacerbated by underlying neurological conditions. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of musculoskeletal weakness, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: Continue monitoring symptoms and test results closely. Educate the patient on the importance of reporting any

S: The patient, a 49-year-old with a history of adult Still's disease diagnosed at age 49, presents with abdominal pain. He reports feeling deep tenderness in his abdomen. He has been on oral prednisolone 90 mg/day and cyclosporine 175 mg/day for Still's disease. O: Physical examination revealed deep tenderness in the abdomen. Laboratory tests showed slight leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 9100/L and a moderately elevated C-reactive protein level of 9.3 mg/dL. Blood coagulation factor was within normal limits. CT scan showed a small amount of extra-intestinal free air around the rectum and massive retroperitoneal emphysema between the rectum and the left kidney, with no arterial aneurysm. Postoperative complications included sudden intolerable left flank pain, hemoglobin 7.5 g/dL, slight prolongation of prothrombin time, left retroperitoneal hematoma, extravasation from the left first lumbar arteries, emergency transarterial angiography, and lumbar artery embolization. Postoperative complications included an intra-abdominal abscess and a surgical site infection. A: The primary diagnosis is a rectal perforation, complicated by an intra-abdominal abscess and a surgical site infection. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of abdominal pain, but these are less likely given the imaging and pathological findings. P: The patient underwent an emergency laparotomy to confirm and treat the rectal perforation. Postoperative complications included an intra-abdominal abscess and a surgical site infection. The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition with regular follow-ups to assess recovery and manage any complications. Education on signs of complications and when to seek immediate care was provided.

S: The patient, admitted to the internal department due to thoracic discomfort, vertigo, nausea, and ataxia, reports progressive neurological symptoms including difficulty with balance and coordination, difficulty walking, and inability to eat without help. The patient has a history of hypertension, coronary artery disease, an episode of gastrointestinal bleeding by angiodysplasia in 2015, pulmonary embolism in 2013, persistent diarrhea, vitamin D deficiency despite substitution, and recurrent hypokalemia. The patient is a habitual drinker, consuming two glasses of wine daily. O: Clinical examination revealed remarkable limb and trunk ataxia, rest, postural, and intention tremor, severe dysarthria, nystagmus, and mild cognitive impairment. Current medications include acetylsalicylic acid, pantoprazole 40 mg/d, atorvastatin, spironolactone, opipramol, Ferro Sanol, and ramipril. MRI revealed symmetric hyperintensity in both cerebellar hemispheres. Lumbar puncture was performed to exclude a cerebellar paraneoplastic syndrome and viral or autoimmune encephalitis. Cerebrospinal fluid analysis was normal. Antibodies against NMDA-receptors, AMPA1-receptors, AMPA2-receptors, and autoantibodies against Ma2 and M2, and herpes simplex antibodies (HSV1- and HSV2-DNA) were not detected in the cerebrospinal fluid. CT scan of the thorax and abdomen was unremarkable. A: The primary diagnosis is cerebellar paraneoplastic syndrome with associated neurological symptoms including limb and trunk ataxia, rest, postural, and intention tremor, severe dysarthria, nystagmus, and mild cognitive impairment. Differential diagnoses include cerebellar paraneoplastic syndrome and viral or autoimmune encephalitis. The prognosis depends on the progression of neurological symptoms and response to current medications. P: Continue current medications including Rocephin and aciclovir. Monitor neurological status closely and adjust treatment as necessary. Regular follow-ups

S: The patient, a 21-year-old Somali woman, presented with acute dyspnea, placental abruption, and gross edema following emergency caesarean section at 35 weeks of gestational age. She reported a history of severe PE/HELLP syndrome, which was her first pregnancy. O: The patient's soluble fms-like tyrosine kinase-1/placental growth factor ratio was 211.4. Post-surgery, the patient was transferred to the Intensive Care Unit due to lung edema. Laboratory findings included anemia with hemoglobin at 7.4 g/dL, thrombocytopenia with platelets at 50 G/L, negative coombs test, increased serum lactate dehydrogenase at 690 U/L, increased bilirubin at 2.2 mg/dL, elevated aspartate transaminase at 150 U/L, elevated alanine transaminase at 140 U/L, creatinine at 1.19 mg/dL, and no detectable haptoglobin levels ( 0.09 g/L). Peripheral blood smear showed manifold schistocytes (2.8%) and activated prothrombin time at 38.2 s. The patient's systolic blood pressure was elevated between 160 and 200 mmHg, despite intensive blood pressure lowering medication. A: The primary diagnosis is severe PE/HELLP syndrome secondary to emergency caesarean section, complicated by severe PE/HELLP syndrome. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of acute dyspnea, placental abruption, and lung edema. The prognosis is guarded due to the severe nature of the condition and the presence of manifold schistocytes. P: Initiated plasma exchange therapy (PEX) and glucocorticoid medication, achieving renal retention parameters of 2.09 mg/dL and an estimated glomerular filtration rate of 33 mL/min/1. 73m2. Continued monitoring of renal function and thrombocyte count is necessary, with adjustments to the treatment regimen as necessary. Regular

S: The patient, a male, presented with right lower quadrant abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. He reported feeling nauseous and threw up several times. O: Initial abdominal exam was normal. Abdominal ultrasound and CT scans were unremarkable. Surgical consultation was conducted, and the patient was discharged. A subsequent genital exam revealed testicular torsion, which was managed with a right orchiectomy. A: The primary diagnosis is testicular torsion, likely due to a testicular torsion. Differential diagnosis initially included appendicitis, which was ruled out by surgical evaluation. P: The patient underwent a right orchiectomy to remove the testicle. Post-surgery, the patient was scheduled for a follow-up appointment to monitor recovery and address any concerns. The patient is advised to monitor for signs of infection or unusual pain and return to the emergency department if necessary.

S: The patient, with a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and end-stage renal disease, presents with shortness of breath for three days. He reports a history of COVID-19 vaccination and has received two doses. He is currently on hemodialysis. O: On examination, the patient was hypoxic, saturating 79% on room air. Chest X-ray revealed infiltrates and positive SARS-CoV-2 RNA. Laboratory tests showed stable vital signs, SpO2 of 94-98%, and the patient was afebrile. Laboratory assessments showed stable vital signs, and the patient was weaned to room air with an SpO2 of 94-98%. On Day 1, a right foot wound infection was noted, treated with intravenous vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam, dexamethasone, and remdesivir. The patient was not eligible for baricitinib due to end-stage renal disease. On Day 2, supplemental oxygen was required, and the patient was weaned to room air with an SpO2 of 94-98%. On Day 3, the patient was hypoxic again, treated with 5 L per minute of supplemental oxygen via nasal cannula, dexamethasone, and remdesivir. On Day 17, the patient was re-evaluated with 10 L per minute of supplemental oxygen via high-flow nasal cannula, which escalated to 15 L on a nonrebreather mask. A: The primary diagnosis is COVID-19 with complications including a right foot wound infection and a right foot wound infection. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of hypoxia, but these are less likely given the stable SpO2 and the patient's end-stage renal disease. The prognosis is guarded due to the severity of the infection and the patient's end-stage renal disease. P: Continue supportive care for COVID-19 with supplemental oxygen and dexamethasone and remdesivir. Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Educate the patient and family about the importance of adherence to the treatment plan and monitoring for any complications. Schedule follow-up

S: The patient is an 80-year-old hypertensive and diabetic Saudi male presenting with sudden bilateral painless visual loss five days ago. He reports a history of bilateral temporal headaches on the left side, mild to moderate in severity, stabbing nature, occurring once a week and disappearing after a few seconds. He denies any diplopia, transient visual loss, jaw claudication, myalgia, or other constitutional, motor, or sensory symptoms. O: Physical examination revealed normal blood pressure, heart rate, and temperature. Pupils were dilated to seven millimeters each without reaction to light. Fundoscopy showed normal appearing discs and retina. Motor, sensory, and coordination examinations were normal. CRP was elevated at 132 mg/L and ESR was 40 mm/hr. MRI of the brain revealed a lesion in the right optic nerve, suggestive of acute ischemia. Ophthalmic arteries were not visualized bilaterally by contrast MRA. Biopsied a 2 cm segment of the left temporal artery confirmed giant cell arteritis. A: The primary diagnosis is bilateral Posterior Ischemic Optic Neuropathy (PION) due to giant cell arteritis (GCA). Differential diagnoses could include other causes of optic nerve injury, but these are less likely given the imaging and pathological findings. P: Initiated treatment with intravenous Methylprednisolone 1000 mg for five days and switched to daily prednisolone 60 mg orally. The patient's vision has not improved, but the headache has improved significantly after a few days. Biopsied a 2 cm segment of the left temporal artery confirmed giant cell arteritis. Regular follow-ups are necessary to monitor the patient's condition and adjust treatment as necessary.

S: The patient reports an elevated PSA of 8.98 ng/mL, which was previously negative for prostate cancer three years ago. Recently, the patient has experienced mild lower urinary tract symptoms, with an AUA urinary symptom score of 14. The patient denies any erectile dysfunction issues and has a SHIM score of 25. O: MP-MRI revealed patchy diffuse abnormal signal, suspicious irregularity in the right posterolateral peripheral zone, and hyperplastic nodules in the left anterior transition zone. MRI/TRUS fusion-targeted biopsy indicated GS 4+3 adenocarcinoma in 80% of the specimen cores from the MRI-targeted lesion in the posterior peripheral zone. A: The primary diagnosis is GS 4+3 adenocarcinoma of the prostate gland, with a differential diagnosis of benign prostatic hyperplasia nodularity. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and response to treatment. P: The management plan includes proceeding with prostate SBRT. The patient will be placed on TRUS-guided fiducial markers, followed by a radiation therapy planning CT scan two weeks post-marker insertion. The target volumes for SBRT and SIB will be reviewed. The patient will be kept informed throughout the treatment process and addressed any concerns.

S: The patient's mother reports a difficult gestation period with IUGR and pre-eclampsia and hyperemesis during pregnancy. The patient was born at 38 weeks via cesarean section, weighing 2.49 kg, and required resuscitation at birth. The patient has dysmorphic features including broad forehead, midface hypoplasia with prognathism, depressed nasal bridge, hypertelorism, synophrys, deep set eyes, downslanting palpebral fissures, tongue protrusion, occipital flattening, and small hands. The patient's head circumference was maintained at the 50th percentile, and length/height was consistently below the 5th percentile. MRI at age 3 showed ventricular prominence without hydrocephalus and diminutive geni and corpus callosum. EEG showed moderate generalized slowing and occasional independent left and right lateralized slow waves during sleep, indicating bihemispheric dysfunction, but no epileptiform activity. EKG and echocardiogram were normal. At age 5, the patient was significantly delayed, smiles, and knows 3-5 single words infrequently. Ocular abnormalities include myopic astigmatism in both eyes, intermittent alternating exotropia, high frequency, low amplitude horizontal nystagmus, and high frequency, low amplitude horizontal nystagmus. The patient is unable to cooperate with eye chart testing, but is able to fix and follow objects with each eye. A: The primary diagnosis is a complex genetic disorder with a history of IUGR and ocular abnormalities. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of developmental delays and developmental delays, but these are less likely given the genetic findings. The prognosis is guarded due to the complexity of the genetic profile and the patient's developmental challenges. P: The management plan includes whole exome sequencing to assess the patient's condition and potential treatment options. The patient's mother will be educated on the nature of the condition, potential treatment options, and the importance of follow-up care. Referral to a geneticist for further evaluation and management of the genetic abnormalities is recommended. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's progress and

S: The patient reported experiencing difficulty breathing and chest pressure. The patient expressed concern about the potential risks associated with the surgical intervention. O: Echocardiography revealed an abundant pericardial effusion and a large intrapericardial mass, causing cardiac tamponade. Postoperative histology confirmed the mass as monophasic synovial sarcoma with an SYT-SSX2 transcript. Postoperative echocardiography, cardiac MRI, and CT scans showed no residual tumor. A subsequent echocardiography, cardiac MRI, and CT scan revealed a recurrent pericardial tumor involving both atria and left pulmonary veins. A: The primary diagnosis was monophasic synovial sarcoma with a SYT-SSX2 transcript. The patient's symptoms of tachycardia, dyspnea, and recurrent pericardial tumor were ruled out through histological examination. P: The patient underwent surgical removal of the pericardial tumor. Postoperative chemotherapy included epirubicin and ifosfamide, followed by intensity-modulated radiotherapy for 54 Gy over 25 sessions in 2 months. A subsequent CT scan showed extensive regrowth of the tumor, involving the heart, great vessels, left bronchus, and esophagus, and mediastinal lymphadenopathy. The patient's condition was managed successfully with no further treatment options available. A: The primary diagnosis was monophasic synovial sarcoma with a SYT-SSX2 transcript. The patient's symptoms of tamponade and recurrent pericardial tumor were ruled out through histological examination. The prognosis was guarded due to the recurrent nature of the tumor and the recurrent nature of the tumor. P: The management plan included surgical removal of the pericardial tumor, followed by chemotherapy with cisplatinum and docetaxel for 6 cycles over 4 months, followed by intensity-modulated radiotherapy for 54 Gy over 25 sessions in 2 months. The patient was educated about the nature of the disease, treatment options, and the importance of adherence to the treatment regimen. The family was advised to discuss the patient's condition and

S: The patient reports a painless, slowly growing mass on the hard palate noticed a few weeks ago. The patient denies any significant medical issues or recent medications. There is no family history of similar lesions or significant health problems in immediate family members. O: Physical examination revealed an extraoral area within normal limits. Intraoral examination revealed a large exophytic mass on the right hard palate extending to the soft palate, yellowish in color and soft to palpation, measuring approximately 5  4 cm, oval-shaped. The mass is compressible and smooth with numerous small blood vessels, but does not blanch or feel pulsatile upon palpation. The lesion feels fixed with well-defined margins. A 5 mm incisional punch biopsy confirmed a benign salivary gland tumor with pools of plasmacytoid cells and multiple double-layered ducts, with significant areas of adipose tissue and foci of hyalinization. A: The primary diagnosis is pleomorphic adenoma with a significant adipose tissue component. Differential diagnoses could include other types of salivary gland tumors, but these are less likely given the biopsy results. P: Referred to oral surgery for complete surgical excision of the lesion. Post-operative pathology confirmed the diagnosis of pleomorphic adenoma with a significant adipose tissue component. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's progress and ensure no recurrences.

S: The patient, who had a living donor renal transplant 10 years ago due to glomerulonephritis, reports recent symptoms of swelling in the legs and face, difficulty breathing, and acute heart failure. The patient also mentions severe and difficult to control hypertension. O: Physical examination revealed an audible bruit on the right side of the lower abdomen. Biochemistry results showed a creatinine level of 190 mmol/L (normal range: 0-60 mmol/L) and an eGFR of 27-32. Ultrasound, CT angiography, and catheter angiography showed a very high flow arterial venous fistula within the transplanted organ. The main transplant artery and veins, and all intrarenal branches, are aneurysmal with extreme tortuosity, with a maximum diameter of 12 mm with relative narrowing at the origin, and ectatic and tortuous iliac vessels. A: The primary diagnosis is decompensated heart failure due to high flow arterial venous fistula in the transplanted organ. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of arterial venous fistulas, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The management plan includes elective super selective renal transplant embolization under general anesthesia. The procedure will involve obtaining informed consent and readingmitting the patient for elective super selective renal transplant embolization under general anesthesia. Post-procedure, arterial and venous punctures will be performed to reduce inflow and pressure into the transplant artery. The patient will be educated on the procedure and expected outcomes to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: 70-year-old male with a history of mild paraparesis of the lower limbs, chronic alcoholism, arterial hypertension, inguinal hernia, reflux esophagitis, bougienage of the esophagus due to cardia stenosis, right-sided hip total endoprosthesis, and deep venous thrombosis of the right lower limb, presents with a history of traumatic brain injury, bilateral fronto-basal contusional bleedings, perifocal edema, and blood deposits along the falx and right tentorium. He also reports a series of generalized tonic clonic seizures, respiratory insufficiency, and elevated alcohol levels. He was diagnosed with hypothyroidism, with a TSH level of 6. O: The patient was admitted after a fall of unknown cause, resulting in bilateral fronto-basal contusional bleedings, perifocal edema, and blood deposits along the falx and right tentorium. Subdural hematoma with subarachnoidal fractions was noted along the right fronto-parieto-temporal convexity. An ICP probe was implanted from the left frontal side, and lactic acidosis improved to 14 mmol/L. Alcohol level was elevated to 1.92 g/L upon admission, leading to intravenous vitamin-B1 (300 mg/d) and oxazepam. On hospital day 3, he was transferred to another intensive care unit, with nowake-up and megaloblastic anemia. He was diagnosed with hypothyroidism, with a TSH level of 6. A: The primary diagnosis is traumatic brain injury with complications including bilateral pulmonary embolism and hypothyroidism. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of pulmonary embolism, but these are less likely given the patient's history and imaging findings. P: Continue monitoring the patient's condition closely and manage hypothyroidism. Continue antiepileptic medications, including levetiracetam, midazolam, norepinephrine, clonidine, ketamine, propofol, and

S: The patient, a three-year history of progressive anterior neck swelling and hoarseness of voice, reports a history of cervical lymphadenopathy and a history of intrathyroid thymic carcinoma treated with left hemithyroidectomy. Recently, the patient presents with progressive hoarseness of voice, intermittent haemoptysis, coughing up blood, shortness of breath, and no difficulty swallowing. O: Clinical examination revealed a left supraclavicular mass measuring 2x2 cm and an irregular hard mass on the anterior aspect of the neck measuring 3x4 cm. Indirect laryngoscopy indicated left vocal cord palsy and an intraluminal mass over the posterior tracheal wall, occupying a third of the tracheal lumen. Contrasted computed tomography (CECT) of the neck and thorax revealed a lobulated hypodense soft tissue mass measuring 4.3x3.9x5.2 cm, occupying the left thyroid bed from C7/T1 to T2/T3, displaced the left common carotid artery and internal jugular vein, and more than 80% of tracheal luminal narrowing. A: The primary diagnosis is intrathyroid thymic carcinoma of the left thyroid, complicated by a lobulated hypodense soft tissue mass and tracheal luminal narrowing. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of thyroid cancer, but imaging and clinical findings support the primary diagnosis. P: The management plan includes regular follow-ups to monitor the patient's condition and adjust treatment as necessary. The patient is advised to maintain regular follow-up appointments to monitor the condition and adjust treatment as necessary. Further consultations with a nephrologist and a pulmonologist may be necessary depending on the results of the FNAC. The patient is encouraged to reach out with any further questions or concerns.

S: The patient, with a history of diabetes diagnosed at 7 years old, has been treated with insulin glargine, hypothyroidism, and has had 2 previous ICU admissions due to diabetic ketoacidosis with blood glucose levels exceeding 300 mg/dL. The patient has been adhering well to the treatment regimen. O: Physical examination revealed distended abdomen with diffuse pain without peritoneal irritation. Laboratory tests showed a pH of 7.25, bicarbonate of 10 mEq/dL, BE of -14.9, blood glucose of 153 mg/dL, and positive for ketonemia. Beta subunit of human chorionic gonadotropin levels were 98,928 IU/L. Transvaginal ultrasound revealed a gestational sac with an embryo inside. Treatment included reanimation with parenteral crystalloids at 250 mL/h for 24 hours, isotonic saline solutions, and polyelectrolyte solutions. Total fluid intake was 7,000 mL/24 hours, urinary volume was 2,750 mL/24 hours, and a positive fluid balance of 4,250 mL/24 hours. Continuous insulin infusion was administered at 100 IU in 48 hours. A: The primary diagnosis is normoglycemic diabetic ketoacidosis with complications including menstrual cycle alterations and a gestational sac with an embryo. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of menstrual dysfunction, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The patient was started on continuous insulin infusion with a total of 100 IU in 48 hours. The patient is advised to continue regular treatment and follow-up appointments to monitor for any signs of recurrence or complications. The patient is advised to continue regular insulin glargine therapy and maintain regular follow-up appointments to ensure stable health.

S: The patient, a 10-month-old male, presents with joint, skin, and nutritional issues since birth. He reports mild joint contractures at birth, worsening over time, pain in his wrists, elbows, shoulders, hips, knees, and ankles, and dark brown and black spots on his knuckles, ankles, back, and neck. He has a history of arthrogryposis treated with physical therapy, leading to a femur fracture and persistent protein-losing enteropathy. The patient also has a history of severe malnutrition, weighing only 5 kg, and is constantly irritable. O: Physical examination revealed significant joint contractures in the wrists, knees, hips, and ankles, gingival hyperplasia, generalized sclerodermatous changes in the skin, pearly, erythematous papules, indurated plaques, and multiple coalescent skin-colored, indurated papules involving the perineum. Electrolyte abnormalities include nonanion gap acidosis, hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and hypoalbuminemia. A: The primary diagnosis is severe malnutrition, complicated by chronic joint, skin, and nutritional issues. Differential diagnoses could include arthrogryposis, but these are less likely given the history and clinical presentation. P: The management plan will include close monitoring of the patient's condition, adjustment of treatment as necessary, and regular follow-ups to assess the effectiveness of the treatment and adjust as necessary. The patient will be educated on the importance of adherence to the treatment plan and the importance of regular follow-ups. Referral to a pediatric neurologist for further evaluation and management of his condition is recommended.

S: The patient reports frequent palpitations for the past 3 months, characterized by irregular heartbeats and discomfort. The patient has been on anti-arrhythmic drugs (mexiletine, propafenone, metoprolol) without effective effectiveness. The patient denies any history of cardiovascular disease. O: Physical examination revealed a complete left bundle branch block, inferior frontal axis, and precordial lead transition zone greater than V3, positive QRS in lead I, and a higher R-wave in lead II. 24-hour dynamic ECG showed more than 32,000 PVCs. Electrophysiological evaluation was performed using a LEAD-7000 EP Recording System, filtered at 30-500 Hz and 0.05-500 Hz, respectively. Three-dimensional electromagnetic mapping (CARTO) and ablation were performed using a 7-French saline-irrigated ablation catheter. A: The primary diagnosis is ventricular premature contractions (VP) from the free wall of the RVOT. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of irregular heartbeats, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The management plan includes continued monitoring of the patient's condition and effectiveness of the ablation procedure. The patient is advised to report any further palpitations or discomfort in the future. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess the effectiveness of the ablation procedure and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient, a non-smoker and non-alcoholic, reports progressive swelling in the right leg for the past 10 days and sudden weakness in the left half for the last two days. The swelling is worsening, affecting the right leg, primarily in the upper left limb, with slurring of speech and facial deviation towards the right side. The patient denies chest pain, diaphoresis, shortness of breath, loin pain, nausea, vomiting, decreased urine output, and red colored urine. The patient has a history of recurrent throat infections in childhood, which were treated with no medical treatment. The patient has a history of elevated serum antistreptolysin O (ASO) titer, which was not reported. O: Physical examination reveals blood pressure at 110/70 mm Hg, pulse irregular at 77 bpm, respiratory rate at 16 bpm, and body temperature at 37.1°C orally. The patient is alert, conscious, and cooperative. No appreciable pallor, icterus, clubbing, splinter hemorrhages, rashes, or cyanosis is noted. The first heart sound (S1) is variable in intensity. A: The primary diagnosis is a worsening of RHD and AF, likely due to non-compliance with prescribed medications. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of pulmonary embolism and pulmonary embolism, but these are less likely given the patient's history and current symptoms. P: The management plan includes restarting medications and scheduling a follow-up appointment with a cardiologist for further evaluation and possible intervention. The patient is advised to reassess the effectiveness of the current medications and to report any new symptoms immediately. Further consultations with a cardiologist may be necessary depending on the outcome of the follow-up.

S: The patient, a 26-month-old female, presented with a four-month history of persistent fever, anorexia, and general weakness. She was not responding to antibiotic therapy and had bruises on her abdomen and legs a month prior to admission. She also reported bruises on her abdomen and legs. O: Ultrasonography revealed mild enlargement of the spleen and reduced blood elements. Serological tests were negative. Bone marrow aspiration showed pancytopenia, but amastigotes of the Leishmania parasite were found within bone marrow macrophages. DAT test was positive (>1:3200). A: The primary diagnosis is visceral leishmaniasis, confirmed by positive DAT and positive DAT. Differential diagnoses initially included anemia and leukemia, but these were ruled out based on negative serological tests. P: The patient was started on Amphotericin-B treatment with a dose of 1 mg/kg for 21 days. Post-treatment, the patient's fever disappeared, general condition improved, and blood cell count increased at the next month follow-up. The patient is advised to continue monitoring her condition and report any new symptoms.

S: The patient is a 42-year-old female nonsmoker presenting with an abnormal chest X-ray radiograph revealing a left pulmonary hilar nodule with a 3-cm diameter. She reports no specific medical history. She underwent a bronchoscopic biopsy revealing SCLC (c-T2aN1M0; Stage IIA). MRI and bone scintigraphy were negative. She underwent thoracoscopic lobectomy 3 weeks post-chemotherapy. Post-chemotherapy, her pro-gastrin-releasing peptide (ProGRP) level remained elevated. PET-CT revealed abnormal accumulation in the left ovary and pelvic MRI showed a solid tumor in the left ovary with uneven contrast effect. A: The primary diagnosis is SCLC with a progression to Stage IA. The patient's pro-gastrin-releasing peptide (ProGRP) level has not decreased, leading to a referral to the Obstetrics and Gynecology Department for further evaluation and treatment. P: The management plan includes referral to the Obstetrics and Gynecology Department for further evaluation and treatment. The patient will be educated on the importance of adhering to the treatment regimen and adherence to follow-up appointments. Referral to the Obstetrics and Gynecology Department for further evaluation and treatment planning will be made.

S: The patient, with a history of chronic alcoholism and cirrhosis with a Child score A, reports noticing a growing mass in the mouth and a mass on the left adrenal gland during surveillance cirrhosis controls. O: Physical examination revealed an exophytic lesion of approximately 10 cm on the left mandible. Laboratory tests including serologic tests for hepatitis B and C panels, serum alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) and carcinoembryonic antigen levels were performed. Abdominal MRI and CT scans showed changes in the liver and hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), with abnormal hypermetabolic activity in the mandible, pelvis bones, and adrenal mass suggesting neoplastic lesions. Biopsies of the adrenal and mandible lesions showed morphology and immunohistochemistry consistent with a hepatoid differentiation in carcinoma. A: The primary diagnosis is metastatic hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), with differential diagnoses including adrenocortical carcinoma with hepatoid differentiation. The absence of a liver tumor on imaging raises the possibility of an adrenocortical carcinoma with hepatoid differentiation, a rare tumor with an even rarer presentation. P: The management plan includes hospitalization for laboratory tests and procedures to establish the primary cancer diagnosis. The patient will be monitored for progression, and an exploratory laparoscopy with a liver biopsy will be performed to explore the liver, which may appear cirrhotic and diffusely nodular without a dominant mass. The patient will be educated on the nature of HCC and the importance of follow-up appointments.

S: The patient, admitted for unconsciousness and melena, presented with black, tarry stools upon waking. The patient reported noticing black, tarry stools upon waking. O: On admission, the patient was hemodynamically stable with a hemoglobin level of 12 g/dl (normal range 14-18 g/dl). Upper endoscopy revealed a stomach full of fresh blood without esophageal varices or ulcers. Global aortic angiogram indicated a 2.5 cm saccular aneurysm on the distal third of the splenic artery, with irregular contours. Postostial embolization with microcoils was performed, leading to hemodynamic stabilization. CT scan revealed a distal pancreatic tumor abutting the posterior gastric wall, leading to secondary rupture of a false aneurysm in the gastric cavity. Intravenous contrast material showed no persisting blood extravasation. Biopsies from the margins of the stomach showed invasive pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma. Six days later, blood hemoglobin levels dropped to 7.4 g/dl. A: The primary diagnosis is invasive pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma, complicated by splenic artery erosion and secondary rupture of a false aneurysm. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of gastric artery erosion, but these are less likely given the imaging and histological findings. P: The management plan includes discussing the case with a multidisciplinary team to determine the best course of treatment. The patient will be kept informed throughout the treatment process, with follow-up appointments scheduled to monitor the patient's response to treatment and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient reports a right distal tibial non-union that has deviated into varus deformity following a high-energy, multifragmentary compound fracture in a road traffic accident approximately 4 months ago. The patient underwent a successful stabilization with a retrograde 10 mm x 340 mm expandable nail. Post-operatively, the patient was able to walk comfortably and return to work as a carpet fitter. However, radiological findings suggestive of calcaneal resorption around the neck of the nail were noted 9 months post-insertion. The nail was removed piecemeal through a 6 cm x 2 cm antero-medial tibial window using a Midas Rex® burr. A: The primary diagnosis is a right distal tibial non-union with varus deformity. The patient's history of high-energy, multifragmentary compound fracture and subsequent surgical intervention are consistent with this diagnosis. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of calcaneal resorption, but these are less likely given the imaging and surgical findings. P: The management plan includes regular clinical and radiological follow-ups to monitor the healing of the tibia and ensure proper healing. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms or discomfort immediately. Further consultations with a nephrologist and a nephrologist may be necessary depending on the patient's progress and recovery progress.

S: The patient is a 13-month-old girl who reports a recent injury from a house fire. She has undergone four skin grafting procedures prior to the placement of a micro-SEF system, which was kept on for three weeks. She describes the knee as unstable occasionally. O: Physical examination revealed third-degree injuries on 73% of total body surface area and an open joint injury in the right knee. The SEF was placed 46 days post-injury and was kept on for three weeks. The patient's PT/OT notes showed normal range of motion and motor strength, but post-SEF, the patient experienced joint instability, necessitating eight weeks of knee immobilizer use. A: The primary diagnosis is a severe knee injury post-house fire, complicated by joint instability post-SEF placement. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of knee instability, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation. P: The management plan includes regular follow-up appointments to monitor the patient's progress and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. The patient is advised to adhere strictly to follow-up instructions and report any new symptoms or concerns immediately. Further consultations with a pediatric orthopedic specialist may be considered if the patient's condition worsens.

S: The patient, a 7-year-old male, presents with severe intellectual disability, speech delay, and convulsive seizures. The parent reports no family history of intellectual disability in the family. The patient was initially diagnosed with ALS during infancy, with no specific phenotypic features present. O: Blood samples were extracted using the High Pure PCR template purification kit by Roche. DNA quality and concentration were assessed using an Implen NanoPhotometer. Next-generation sequencing (NGS) of the whole exomes of the son was performed using a NextSeq 500 System with a read length of 2  150 bp and dual indexing. All exomes were sequenced with 160  coverage, with at least 93% of the sequences having a minimum of 20  coverage. A: The primary diagnosis is ALS with phenotypic features and germ-line variants. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of ALS, but these are less likely given the genetic findings. P: The management plan includes continued monitoring of the patient's symptoms and reporting any changes or concerns. Further genetic testing may be necessary depending on the results of the next-generation sequencing. The patient will be educated on the importance of reporting any new symptoms or changes in his condition. Referral to a geneticist for further evaluation and management of ALS is recommended. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's condition and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient reports a 25-year history of increasing vulvar swelling, initially small, but has progressively grew. Recently, the patient experienced dull aching pain approximately 3 months ago, difficulty with micturition, and dysuria, without discharge or bleeding. The patient denies any family history of similar illnesses, smoking tobacco, or alcohol use. O: Physical examination revealed a pulse of 82 bpm, respiratory rate of 18, and temperature of 36°C. The conjunctiva is pink, sclera is non-icteric, and the chest is clear and resonant. Heart sounds are normal with no murmur or gallop. The abdomen is soft and moves with respiration, with no tenderness, guarding, rigidity, palpable mass, or organomegaly. The genitourinary system shows an 18 cm by 12 cm fluctuant, multi-lobulated, mobile, non-tender, right labia majora mass involving the mons pubis and stretching the ventral skin of the urethra, with normal overlying skin and two labial edges fused at their cranial part. Laboratory tests showed hemoglobin at 13 gm/dl, WBC at 6500/mm3, platelet count at 250,000, and blood group B+. Pelvic ultrasound scan showed an atrophied uterus without a pelvic mass. A: The primary diagnosis is a vulvar mass, likely a genitourinary tumor, given the patient's history of genital cutting and sewing. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of vulvar swelling, but these are less likely given the imaging and laboratory results. P: The management plan includes surgical removal of the vulvar mass to alleviate pain and discomfort. The patient will be educated on the procedure, expected outcomes, and potential complications. Post-operative care will include monitoring for any complications and adjusting the treatment plan as necessary. Referral to a nephrologist for further evaluation and management of the vulvar mass is recommended. Patient education regarding the procedure and expected outcomes will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient, referred from the Department of Neurology Outpatient Clinic, presents with complaints of depressed mood, lack of enjoyment of activities, sleep disturbances, poor concentration, and occasional suicidal thoughts. The patient has been using a motorized wheelchair due to the worsening condition, but the current house is not fully wheelchair accessible. The patient has been using a motorized wheelchair due to the worsening condition, and has experienced passive death wishes at least once a week without a suicidal plan or intent. The patient lives alone but has a support system from siblings. O: The patient's labs including hemogram, liver function tests, total protein, vitamin B12, folic acid, T3, T4, and TSH were within normal limits. Beck Depression Inventory score was 23, indicating moderate depression. The patient has started sertraline 50 mg per day, and has been participating in group cognitive behavioral therapy sessions focusing on negative cognitions and aspects of dialectical behavioral therapy. A: The primary diagnosis is major depressive disorder, evidenced by the patient's clinical presentation, laboratory findings, and clinical presentation. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of depressive symptoms, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and laboratory findings. P: The patient has started sertraline 50 mg per day, which is the first time taking medication for depression. The patient has been participating in group cognitive behavioral therapy sessions three times a week, for approximately 12 hours each week. The plan includes continued medication and therapy to manage depression and improve overall well-being. The patient is advised to reach out to the support system and healthcare team if needed for any assistance.

S: The patient reports a severed deformity at the level of the right wrist, extensive soft tissue crush, and an open wrist fracture. The patient denies any special medical history or comorbidities. O: Physical examination revealed a severed deformity at the level of the right wrist, extensive soft tissue crush, and an open wrist fracture. The Mangled Extremity Severity Score (MESS) was 8. Emergency radiographs showed a comminuted fracture of the bones in the right wrist. A wound infection with Enterobacter cloacae was detected in the wound secretion, treated empirically with antibiotics and standardized wound care until no bacterial growth was identified. The amputation stump was repaired with a double-pedicle advancement flap at 4 weeks post-second surgery. A: The primary diagnosis is a comminuted fracture of the bones in the right wrist, with complications including a wound infection with Enterobacter cloacae. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of wrist deformities, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The patient underwent wrist disarticulation, which included designing long volar and short dorsal flaps, clamping, ligating, and dissecting the ulnar and radial arteries, isolating, and dissecting the median, radial, and ulnar nerves, and suturing the flap. Post-operative management included empirical antibiotics and wound care until no bacterial growth was identified. A double-pedicle advancement flap was used to repair the amputation stump. The prosthetic hand was designed and manufactured with the consent of the patient.
