A: The primary diagnosis is a comminuted fracture of the bones in the right wrist, with complications including a wound infection with Enterobacter cloacae. The prognosis is favorable with the creation of a novel 3D-printed prosthetic hand. The prognosis is guarded due to the complexity of the injury and the potential for potential harms. P: The patient underwent wrist disarticulation, which included designing long volar and short dorsal flaps, clamping, ligating, and dissecting the ulnar and radial arteries, isolating

S: The patient, referred by the neurosurgical team, reports hearing music in the head for about a week. The patient underwent surgical evacuation of intraventricular and intracranial haemorrhages, resulting in full recovery. The patient denies experiencing hallucinations, delusions, or other changes in consciousness. The patient also mentions issues with short-term and long-term memory, and frontal lobar impairment. O: Physical examination revealed no neurological deficits. Neurological examination showed no abnormalities. A noncontrast CT brain scan showed no abnormalities. The patient was started on quetiapine 25 mg, gradually titrated to 150 mg. The patient has been symptom-free for one year, and has been symptom-free for one year. A: The primary diagnosis is a traumatic brain injury (TBI) secondary to traumatic brain injury, likely exacerbated by the patient's history of intraventricular and intracranial haemorrhages. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of traumatic brain injury, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and imaging findings. P: The patient was started on quetiapine 25 mg, gradually titrated to 150 mg, and has been symptom-free for one year. The patient is advised to continue the medication as prescribed and report any side effects or recurrence of symptoms immediately. Regular follow-ups are recommended to monitor the patient's response to the medication and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient reports experiencing lumbago and a fever and disturbance of consciousness in the evening. The patient has a history of neoadjuvant and adjuvant chemotherapy and radiation for glioblastoma 6 years ago, but has been able to carry out daily activities independently since then. The patient has no history of pneumonia or pneumococcal vaccination. O: Initial antimicrobial treatment with 4.5 g piperazine/tazobactam every 8 hours was discontinued due to the discovery of pneumococcus in blood culture. Blood tests showed pneumococcus in blood culture, leading to a switch to 2 g ABPC every 6 hours. Lumbar MRI showed abnormal findings in spinal fluid, head MRI, thoracoabdominal contrast CT, and transesophageal echocardiography. MRI on hospital day 9 revealed purulent spondylitis. Antimicrobial drug treatment was administered for 9 weeks to normalize white blood cell count, CRP level, and blood sedimentation rate, and improved CT findings. The patient and his wife tolerated the antimicrobial treatment and have recovered completely. A: The primary diagnosis is purulent spondylitis secondary to pneumococcus infection. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of lumbago, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. The prognosis is good with ongoing antimicrobial treatment and no recurrence of lumbago. P: Continue current regimen of 2 g ABPC every 6 hours. Continue antimicrobial drug therapy for 9 weeks to normalize white blood cell count, CRP, and blood sedimentation rate, and improve CT findings. Continue monitoring the patient's response to antimicrobial treatment and adjust the regimen as necessary. Educate the patient and his wife on the importance of reporting any new symptoms or concerns immediately.

S: The patient, a 12-year-old female, presented with a recent seizure and loss of consciousness. She reported no significant comorbidities before the seizure. O: Physical examination revealed a vascularity-rich tumor 20 mm in diameter in the head of the pancreas. CT scan showed a vascularity-rich tumor 20 mm in diameter in the head of the pancreas. The feeding artery was not clearly demonstrated through angiography and selective arterial calcium injection. The patient's intact parathyroid hormone level was 66.0 pg/ml, slightly elevated, and adjusted serum calcium was 10.3 mg/dL. Parathyroid ultrasound showed no parathyroid tumor. Preoperative examinations were unremarkable. The patient's capillary BG was 80 mg/dL, and the SCGM system was calibrated using a OneTouch® UltraVueTM Blood Glucose Meter. A: The primary diagnosis is insulinoma and hyperparathyroidism in MEN-1. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of pancreatitis, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. The prognosis is guarded due to the aggressive nature of the tumor and the absence of significant comorbidities. P: The management plan includes extended surgical procedures such as pancreatoduodenectomy to address the vascularity-rich tumor. The patient will undergo open abdominal surgery and will be treated with an EnliteTM sensor of the MiniMedTM 620G Diabetes SCGM system. Continuous glucose infusion was initiated during the procedure. The patient will be educated on the importance of adherence to the treatment plan and postoperative care instructions.

S: Phlip, a 13-year-old male, presents with right elbow pain, a history of hypertension and diabetes, and a history of white coat syndrome. He reports pain to palpation of the olecranon area of the posterior elbow, mild pain with flexion and extension, and normal range of motion at the elbow. He denies chest pain or belly pain. He has been taking advil for a few days but forgets about it. He has a low salt diet and is on 500 mg of metformin daily. O: Physical examination shows pain to palpation of the olecranon area of the posterior elbow, mild pain with flexion and extension, and normal range of motion at the elbow. X-ray shows no broken bones, fractures, or bony abnormalities. A: The primary diagnosis is a right elbow contusion, likely exacerbated by a lacrosse stick injury. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of right elbow pain, but these are less likely given the x-ray results. P: The patient is prescribed 8 hundred mg of ibuprofen twice a day to manage swelling and pain, and ice it three times a day for 20 minutes for 20 minutes. He is advised to ice it three times a day for 20 minutes. He is advised to ice it three times a day for 20 minutes. A: The primary diagnosis is a right elbow contusion, likely exacerbated by a lacrosse stick injury. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of right elbow pain, but these are less likely given the x-ray results. P: The patient is advised to continue with lisinopril 20 mg twice daily and ibuprofen twice daily. He is advised to ice it three times a day for 20 minutes. He is advised to ice it three times a day for 20 minutes. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor his condition and adjust the medication as necessary.

S: The patient, a nonsmoker with minimal alcohol intake, presents with a four-day history of generalized abdominal pain postcolonoscopy. He reports nausea and a slightly reduced stoma output. He has a history of asthma and Crohn's disease, settled prior to the colonoscopy. He denies any known drug allergies. He is currently on azathioprine, salbutamol, and beclometasone. He has a history of complicated appendicectomy in 2007, ileostomy in 2010, ileocolonic anastomosis in 2012, major sepsis with abdominal wall breakdown, and abdominal compartment syndrome. O: Physical examination revealed a heart rate of 117 bpm, blood pressure of 128/81 mmHg, respiratory rate 15, and oxygen saturation of 98% on air. Abdominal palpation showed a large mass overlying the hernia to the left of the midline, ballotable with crepitus, tenderness, cough impulse, and a stoma. Chest was clear to auscultation, and GCS was 15/15. Bloods showed a C-reactive protein level of 219 mg/L, significantly elevated over the normal range of 0–5 mg/L. A: The primary diagnosis is a complex hernia with complications including ileostomy, major sepsis, abdominal wall breakdown, and abdominal compartment syndrome. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of abdominal pain and stoma, but these are less likely given the elevated C-reactive protein level. P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition with regular follow-ups to assess the viability of the hernia repair. The patient will be educated on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and adherence to the prescribed medications. Referral to a gastroenterologist for further evaluation and management of the hernia is recommended. Patient education regarding the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and follow-up appointments will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient, recently underwent McKeown minimally invasive esophagectomy (MIE) for middle third esophageal cancer, reports a tough recovery post-operation, including a cervical esophagogastric anastomotic leak, dysphonia, and swallow dysfunction leading to aspiration pneumonia. The patient has experienced acute onset of severe upper abdominal pain, nausea, and dyspnea following a prolonged effort at defecation, described as pale, weak, and experiencing difficulty breathing. O: The patient's histological examination revealed a stage IIIA poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma. Postoperative complications included multiple recurrences in the right paratracheal lymph node, anterior chest wall, and right adrenal gland, with multiple recurrences detected at the 3-month follow-up. Clinical examination revealed pale, bradycardia (35 bpm), hypotension (60/40 mmHg), and tachypnea (26 breaths per minute). Abdominal excavation showed diffuse tenderness and impaired bowel sound, and reduced vesicular breath sounds over the entire left hemithorax. CT scan with contrast showed a giant diaphragmatic hernia. A: The primary diagnosis is stage IIIA poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma with complications including cervical esophagogastric anastomotic leak, dysphonia, and swallow dysfunction. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of squamous cell carcinomas, but imaging and histological findings support the primary diagnosis. The prognosis is guarded due to the complexity of the disease and the patient's coexisting medical conditions. P: The patient will continue to be monitored closely with regular follow-ups in the Oncological Unit and the Oncological Unit. The management plan will include close monitoring of the patient's condition and adjustment of the treatment plan as necessary. The patient is advised to maintain regular follow-up appointments and report any new symptoms or concerns immediately. Further consultations with oncology and oncology may be necessary to manage the hernia and lung complications.

S: The patient is a 24-year-old autistic nonverbal male presenting with increasing lethargy and frequent urination over the past few days. He reports no history of fall, prolonged immobilization, medication overdose, or increased physical activities. O: Upon admission, vital signs were stable. Physical examination revealed confusion, dehydration, and lethargy. Laboratory findings included hypernatremia, high blood glucose levels, elevated serum creatinine at 5.29 mg/dl (normal range 0.61–1.24 mg/dl), low bicarbonate levels at 13 mmol/L (normal range 24–31 mmol/L), hyperphosphatemia, and high anion gap metabolic acidosis. Arterial blood gas analysis showed hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state with a serum osmolality of 395 mmol/kg (normal range 275–295 mmol/kg). Serum acetone was large. Urinalysis indicated ketones, proteinuria, high glucose levels, dark tea-colored urine, and large amounts of urine blood but few red blood cells. CT of the abdomen indicated pancreatitis, with normal amylase and lipase levels. A: The primary diagnosis is diabetes type 2 with complications including pancreatitis, diabetes type 2, and new onset diabetes type 2. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of urinalysis, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The patient was managed aggressively with intravenous normal saline boluses and maintained on maintenance fluid with replacement of electrolytes. He was treated for diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) with a standardized protocol, followed by transitioning to subcutaneous insulin and starting a diabetic diet. A glutamic acid decarboxylase test was negative at less than 5 IU/mL (normal range: 0.0 to 5.0, unit: IU/mL). A: The primary diagnosis is diabetes type 2 with complications including pancreatitis, diabetes type 2, and new onset diabetes type 2. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of urinalysis, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The management plan includes continued monitoring of the patient

S: The patient reported experiencing epigastric pain and bloating in the upper part of the stomach. No history of pancreatitis was reported in the anamnesis. O: Abdominal ultrasonography revealed a 6 x 5 cm cystic lesion without a solid component in the pancreatic tail. Upper abdomen MRI showed a cystic lesion with calcified walls in the pancreatic tail, a 6 x 3 cm hypointense corpus lesion invading the splenic vein, and less contrast uptake. CA 19-9 was elevated at 1012 IU/ml. PET-CT scan showed focally increased FDG metabolization in the pancreas body with a SUVmax of 11.8 without involvement of the cystic lesion localized in the pancreatic tail. Pathology confirmed an intermediate grade ductal pancreatic adenocarcinoma with a clear surgical margin and an Echinococcus granulosus cyst. A: The primary diagnosis is intermediate grade ductal pancreatic adenocarcinoma of the Echinococcus granulosus cyst with a clear surgical margin. Differential diagnoses could include other cystic pancreatic lesions, but imaging and pathology support the primary diagnosis. P: The patient underwent a subtotal pancreatectomy with splenectomy via the left subcostal incision. Postoperative management included discharge on postoperative day 11. The patient is referred to medical oncology for further evaluation and management. Further evaluation and management of the cystic lesion are planned.

S: The patient reports a bilateral Class I canine relationship and left Class I molar relationship in the permanent dentition, with a crossbite of tooth 12. The patient expresses concern about the possibility of adverse staining during treatment, and does not want to use removable orthodontic appliances. O: The patient has been diagnosed with a bilateral Class I canine relationship and left Class I molar relationship in the permanent dentition, with a crossbite of tooth 12. A lingual orthodontic appliance will be used to address the anterior crossbite and retain the case over time. A: The primary diagnosis is a bilateral Class I canine relationship and left Class I molar relationship in the permanent dentition, with a crossbite of tooth 12. Differential diagnoses could include other types of orthodontic treatment, such as ceramic brackets or aligners, but these are less likely given the patient's concerns about adverse staining. P: The treatment plan includes polishing all dental surfaces with pumice powder. An intraoral scan using a 3D intraoral scanner will be performed, and the NemoCast software will determine the shape of each tooth and gum. The bracket placement tool will ensure precise bracket positioning. A virtual transfer tray will be designed using a rapid-prototyping machine. The patient will be kept informed throughout the procedure and kept informed throughout the process.

S: The patient, with a history of hypertension and smoking, presents with a nine-month history of epigastric pain, decreased appetite, and a weight loss of 30 pounds. The patient has a maternal aunt with pancreatic cancer and another aunt with breast cancer. O: Abdominal CT scan revealed a 4 cm x 3.8 cm x 2.6 cm mass encasing the superior mesenteric artery. Hepatic panel results showed elevated alanine transaminase at 160 IU/L, alkaline phosphatase at 256 IU/L, and CA 19-9 at 177 U/mL. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) identified a nodule at the gastroesophageal junction. Endoscopic ultrasound (EUS) revealed an ill-defined, hypoechogenic, lobular area measuring 19.6 mm x 24.7 mm, and a 1 cm nodule at the gastroesophageal junction. Pathology confirmed adenocarcinoma with mucinous features, microsatellite stability, and KRAS amplification. A: The primary diagnosis is a double primary of the pancreas, with differential diagnoses including liver and pancreatic cancer. The prognosis is guarded due to the complexity of the disease and the presence of a nodule at the gastroesophageal junction. P: The patient underwent endoscopic mucosal resection (EMR) of the pancreatic mass. The treatment plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition, including regular follow-ups to assess treatment efficacy and manage any complications. The patient will be educated on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and adherence to follow-up appointments.

S: The patient, admitted in April 2016, reported a 5-day history of high fever and a severe cough. The patient recalls taking cephalothin and azithromycin for inflammatory consolidation with atelectasis. O: On admission, a pulmonary CT indicated fibrinoid formation in the right upper lobe, treated with cephalothin and azithromycin. Post-treatment, the patient experienced hypoxemia and fatigue. Vital signs included a temperature of 38.0°C, heart rate of 135 beats/min, respiration rate of 32 times/min, blood pressure of 90/60 mm Hg, and transcutaneous oxygen saturation of 90% without oxygen. Physical examination revealed fatigue and decreased respiratory sound in the right lung. Routine blood tests showed Hb at 132 g/l, WBC at 12.2  109/L, N at 73.3%, and L at 27.1%. Biochemical examination showed AST at 2,031 U/L, ALT at 1,595 U/L, LDH at 2,673 U/L, creatine kinase-MB at 41 U/L, triglyceride at 1.33 mmol/l, PCT at 1.56 ng/ml, CRP at 38.8 mg/l, and ferritin at 4,355 ng/ml. MP-DNA in BAL fluid was positive with 1  108 copies/ml and MP resistance mutation site 2063/2064. MP-DNA of hydrothorax was also positive at 3.2  105 copies/ml. A: The primary diagnosis is inflammatory consolidation with atelectasis, complicated by severe infection and inflammation. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of acute respiratory distress, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: Continue monitoring the patient's condition closely with regular follow-ups to assess recovery and adjust treatment as necessary. Educate the patient on the importance of adhering to the treatment regimen and adherence to the treatment plan. Consider referral to a pulmonologist for further evaluation and management of the infection. Ensure compliance with the treatment regimen and follow-up appointments.

S: The patient, previously treated for non-ST-elevation myocardial infarction, heart failure with reduced ejection fraction, community-acquired pneumonia, and Staphylococcus hominis mitral valve endocarditis, reports feeling weak and tired but is trying to stay positive. On Day 32 of treatment, the patient experienced whole-body itching and pruritus, followed by an erythematous macular rash on the torso and spread to the extremities, including palms and soles. By Day 33, the desquamating rash covered about 80% of the total body surface area without bullae. The patient experienced desquamation, intense pain to the skin, intermittent fevers, and desquamation. Blood cultures were negative, and serum ALT and AST concentrations were within normal limits. Hemoglobin oxygen saturation by pulse oximetry was above 95% throughout the hospital course. A: The primary diagnosis is non-ST-elevation myocardial infarction, heart failure with reduced ejection fraction, community-acquired pneumonia, and Staphylococcus hominis mitral valve endocarditis. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of skin peeling and fevers, but these are less likely given the elevated lab values and clinical presentation. P: Continue monitoring the patient's condition with intravenous vancomycin. Monitor the patient's blood counts, eosinophilia, erythrocyte sedimentation rate, CRP, and serum creatinine levels closely. Maintain ALT and AST levels within normal limits. Monitor for any pulmonary symptoms such as cough, chest pain, or shortness of breath. Educate the patient on the importance of reporting any new symptoms or concerns. Schedule follow-up appointments to reassess the patient's condition and treatment efficacy.

S: The patient is a 62-year-old male with a history of obstructive jaundice and pancreatitis due to locally advanced pancreatic head cancer treated with endoscopic placement of a biliary and pancreatic stent, followed by chemoradiotherapy with gemcitabine and S-1. He reports sudden onset of severe abdominal pain and slight epigastric pain four months post-treatment. O: Vital signs include blood pressure at 91/67 mmHg, pulse rate at 113/min, and temperature at 37.0 °C. Laboratory tests show elevated leukocytes at 10,100/l, and C-reactive protein at 13.92 mg/dl. CT scan reveals the tip of the pancreatic stent protruding from the pancreatic body, with fluid collection around the pancreas, omental bursa, and Douglas cavum. A: The primary diagnosis is panperitonitis due to perforation of the pancreatic duct. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of panperitonitis, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: Plan to perform an emergency operation to address the panperitonitis. The procedure will involve inserting pancreatic tubes into both sides of the perforated site, suturing between the posterior wall of the stomach and pancreas, and performing percutaneous transgastric drainage. Postoperative recovery will be uneventful, with a transition to internal drainage for recovery. The patient will be monitored for recovery progress and adjustments as necessary.

S: The patient is a 3-year-old boy presenting with severe respiratory distress. He reports a history of pneumothorax on the right chest and a tube thoracostomy. He denies any history of chronic disease or smoking. O: On admission, vital signs were within normal limits except for a high respiratory rate of 45 per minute. Total blood count, liver, and renal function tests were unremarkable. Physical examination revealed a 2x1 cm palpable mass on the right side of the neck. CT scan of the chest revealed bilateral air cysts with a ground glass appearance. Biopsy confirmed Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH) confined to the right salivary gland. Histopathologic features included polymorphonuclear leukocytes and atypical histocytes with oval nucleus and pale granular cytoplasm. Immunohistochemical staining with CD1a and S100 were positive. A chemical pleurodesis with 2 cc of talc through the tube thoracostomy was performed, with no intrapleural analgesics used. Post-surgery, he developed bilateral pneumothorax with subcutaneous emphysema, followed by thoracoscopic bullae excision with pleural decortication. Post-surgery, he was symptom-free for only 1 week. A: The primary diagnosis is Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH) confined to the right salivary gland, complicated by subcutaneous emphysema. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of respiratory distress, but these are less likely given the histopathologic findings and histopathological findings. P: The patient underwent a chemical pleurodesis with 2 cc of talc through the tube thoracostomy, which was performed without intrapleural analgesics. Post-surgical recovery was symptom-free for 1 week. The management plan includes continued monitoring of respiratory status and adjustment of treatment as necessary. The patient will continue to be educated on the importance of adhering to the treatment regimen and adherence to follow-up appointments.

S: The patient reports a small, 1 by 1 cm, inflamed pilar cyst on the left thumb, located proximal to the base of the nail and on the dorsal aspect of the distal phalanx of the left thumb. The lump has been growing slowly. The patient denies any discharge or infection in the area. O: Physical examination revealed a small, 1 by 1 cm lump proximal to the base of the nail and on the dorsal aspect of the distal phalanx of the left thumb. An X-ray of the finger showed no signs of a bony spur. An excision of the lesion under local anesthesia was performed, and the lesion was easily dissected from surrounding tissue. Histopathology confirmed the lump as an inflamed pilar cyst lined by squamous epithelium. A: The primary diagnosis is an inflamed pilar cyst on the left thumb, a type of cystic lesion lined by squamous epithelium. Differential diagnoses considered included mucoid cyst, epidermoid cyst, or squamous cell carcinoma. P: The patient underwent an excision under local anesthesia to remove the lesion. Post-excision, a follow-up appointment in 3 months is scheduled to monitor the area for signs of recurrence. The patient is advised to schedule a follow-up appointment in 3 months to ensure the operative site has healed well and no signs of recurrence.

S: The patient is a 75-year-old male on hemodialysis for end-stage renal disease, presenting with cough, fever, and altered mental status. He reports difficulty breathing and chest pain. O: Vital signs include a temperature of 103°F, pulse of 68, blood pressure of 124/69, respiratory rate of 22, and O2 saturation of 96% on 2 L of O2 by nasal cannula. Physical examination revealed bibasilar crackles. Laboratory tests showed a WBC count of 20,100 cells/mm3, plasma procalcitonin of 1.1 ng/mL, and chest X-ray revealing bibasilar infiltrates. Microscopic examination of the sputum showed profuse polymorphonuclear leukocytes and Gram-positive rods. Sputum culture identified Corynebacteria with rare P. aeruginosa. Blood cultures and viral PCR were negative. A: The primary diagnosis is pneumonia secondary to C. propinquum, based on the presence of Corynebacteria and negative PCR for respiratory viruses. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of lung infection, but these are less likely given the negative PCR results. P: Initiated treatment with vancomycin, cefepime, and metronidazole, based on the presence of Corynebacteria and negative PCR for respiratory viruses. Discontinued cefepime and metronidazole, and continued with vancomycin. The patient will be discharged for a 10-day course of linezolid. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's response to treatment and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient reports discomfort in the groin area. The patient has a normal size penis. O: Physical examination revealed a palpable testis in the left groin and a nonpalpable undescended testis on the right side. MRI findings indicated the left testis in the left hemiscrotum measuring 1.3  0.6 cm with mild hydrocele and another testis on the ipsilateral side within the left inguinal canal. Exploration of the left groin revealed both testes within the same side, with separate vasa deferentia and testicular vessels, but a common cremasteric muscle and tunical covering. A: The primary diagnosis is a bilateral ectopic testis in the left hemiscrotum with associated mild hydrocele. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of ectopic testis in the groin, but these are less likely given the imaging results. P: The management plan includes performing a herniotomy to fix the ectopic testis transseptally to the right hemiscrotum. Post-procedure, the ectopic testis will be fixed transseptally to the right hemiscrotum. The patient will be monitored for any complications and will be provided with follow-up care.

S: The patient reported persistent diarrhea with 4-5 watery stools without blood and mucus and fever up to 39 °C, which appeared 1 year prior to admission. The patient was treated symptomatically and empirically with amoxicillin, ciprofloxacin, and cefuroxime. The symptoms did not completely resolve, and the patient lost 10 kg of weight. The patient denies any medical history of chronic diseases or significant previous travels. O: Physical examination revealed numerous enlarged cervical lymphatic nodes, tenderness to palpation in the left subcostal region, and intensive bowel movements. Laboratory findings indicated an acute inflammatory response with increased CRP, ESR, leukocytosis, monocytosis, neutrocytosis, and thrombocytosis. Bacteria tests for Salmonella, Shigella, Escherichia coli, and Yersinia spp. were negative. Repeated parasitological stool examinations showed numerous Cryptosporidium spp. oocysts, 20-50 oocysts/10 fields (magnification 1000). WBCs and RBCs were elevated, and fecal calprotectin was elevated at 895 g/l. FOBT was positive. Colonoscopy revealed intensive inflammatory mucosal lesions, numerous polyps narrowing the bowel bore, stool-purulent content, and different-shaped ulcers, or cryptitis. CT scans showed extraperitoneum lymphadenopathy and intestine wall inflammation, with mucosa thickening. Histopathologic sections showed incorrect lamina propria architecture with cryptitis. A: The primary diagnosis is acute inflammatory bowel disease with complications including bowel inflammation and infection. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of bowel inflammation, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and laboratory findings. P: The management plan includes continued monitoring of the patient's condition with appropriate antibiotics and supportive care. The patient is advised to maintain good hygiene and report any recurrence of symptoms immediately. Regular follow-up appointments are scheduled to assess treatment efficacy and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms immediately.

S: The patient, an 80-year-old female, reports experiencing bleeding from her prolapsed uterus. She has a history of 3 vaginal births, the last one at age 30, and a last menstruation at age 52. She denies any past or current chronic diseases, addictions, or other health concerns. O: Physical examination revealed a large part of the vagina containing the cervix and a part of the uterine body below the vaginal introits, classified as International Continence Society grade 3. Exophytic infiltrating lesions covered the entire surface of the hypertrophic cervix, spreading to the vaginal fornices. Bimanual vaginal examination revealed a small myoma of 2 cm in diameter in the uterine body, impalpable adnexa, and a tumor in the anal canal. Histopathology of the cervical and anal canal lesion showed moderately differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) with a strong and diffuse immunohistochemical p16 reaction in the neoplastic cells. A: The primary diagnosis is moderately differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) of the cervical specimen, with a strong and diffuse immunohistochemical p16 reaction in the neoplastic cells. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of uterine cancers, but these are less likely given the imaging and histopathological findings. P: The patient was admitted to the department of Obstetrics and Gynaecological Oncology in Dbica, Poland, for further evaluation and management. Further treatment options will be discussed, with close monitoring of the patient's condition. Referral to a nephrologist for further evaluation and management of SCC is recommended. Patient education regarding the nature of the disease, treatment options, and potential side effects will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient reports blurred vision, hyperemia, and pain in the right eye. The patient denies fever, asthenia, anorexia, arthralgia, myalgia, ulcers, abdominal pain, lower back pain, or urinary symptoms. O: The patient's symptoms and lab results indicate bilateral nongranulomatous anterior uveitis without complications. Laboratory findings include elevated C-reactive protein at 2.6 mg/dL (normal range: 0.6-1.2 mg/dL) and erythrocyte sedimentation rate at 96 mm/first hour (normal range: 0-60 mm/first hour). GFR is 48 ml/min/1.73m2, hypokalemia, metabolic acidosis, leukocyturia, glucosuria, hematuria, non-nephrotic proteinuria, and elevated urine 2-microglobulin levels. Other infections ruled out include Hepatitis B and C, toxoplasmosis, brucellosis, Epstein-Barr virus, and CMV. Chest X-ray and ACE levels are normal. Antinuclear antibodies (ANA) and antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA) are negative. Kidney biopsy indicates diffuse mononuclear cell interstitial infiltrates, consistent with acute tubulointerstitial nephritis. A: The primary diagnosis is bilateral nongranulomatous anterior uveitis with complications including hypertension, elevated C-reactive protein, erythrocyte sedimentation rate, hypokalemia, metabolic acidosis, leukocyturia, glucosuria, hematuria, non-nephrotic proteinuria, and elevated urine 2-microglobulin levels. Differential diagnoses include Hepatitis B and C, toxoplasmosis, brucellosis, EBV, and CMV. The patient's kidney biopsy suggests acute tubulointerstitial nephritis. The patient's symptoms and lab findings support the diagnosis of bilateral nongranulomatous anterior uveitis. P: The treatment plan

S: The patient reports experiencing discomfort in the mouth, which is causing pain. The patient has a history of stage II buccal SCC involving the labial commissure. O: Physical examination revealed a growth near the corner of the mouth, causing pain. A thorough examination was performed, revealing a stage II buccal SCC involving the labial commissure. A triangular total thickness flap was drawn along the nasolabial fold, creating a triangular total thickness flap. The inner and outer dimensions of the A-EF skin paddle were 1.8 x 3.0 cm and 1.8 x 2.5 cm, respectively. A 3-month follow-up showed excellent esthetic results for the cheek and lip, orbicularis oris function, and normal speech function. A: The primary diagnosis is stage II buccal SCC involving the labial commissure. The patient's condition is complicated by a local recurrence at 23 months. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic with appropriate surgical intervention. P: The management plan includes surgical removal of the tumor and reconstruction of the affected area under general anesthesia. An A-EF flap will be drawn along the nasolabial fold, creating a triangular total thickness flap. The patient will be monitored for any signs of recurrence and will be educated on the importance of follow-up care and the importance of adherence to follow-up appointments. The patient will be educated on signs of recurrence and encouraged to reach out with any further questions or concerns.

S: The patient reports continuous pain and bleeding from the residual vagina for some time. The patient has a history of a transurethral resection of bladder tumor (TURBT) in 2004, a high-grade UC with adenocarcinomatous differentiation (pT2a, G2>G3). Recently, MRI revealed a tumor in the residual vagina. Biopsy confirmed adenocarcinoma and SCC. CT and bone scintigraphy showed no metastasis. Pathological examination of the tumor showed adenocarcinoma and SCC, positive for CD56, chromogranin A, and synaptophysin, and negative for urothelial carcinoma markers GATA-3, p63, uroplakin, thrombomodulin, and 34E12. MRI confirmed local recurrence and pelvic bone metastasis. Post-surgery, the patient developed ileus and developed multiple lung metastases and local recurrence in the pelvis. A: The primary diagnosis is a recurrent bladder tumor with adenocarcinomatous differentiation (pT2a, G2>G3). Differential diagnoses could include other forms of bladder tumors or metastatic diseases, but the primary diagnosis is a recurrent bladder tumor. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and management of the recurrent bladder tumor. P: The management plan includes continued radiation therapy (52 Gy, 26 fractions) to manage the recurrent bladder tumor. The patient will continue with regular follow-ups to monitor for any recurrence or new symptoms. The patient will be educated on signs of recurrence and advised to report any new symptoms immediately. Referral to oncology for further evaluation and management of recurrent bladder tumors is recommended.

S: The patient, an 8-year-old neutered male miniature Poodle, presented with symptoms of difficulty breathing, difficulty moving around, and severe pain when touched by the neck. The owner reported the dog was hit by a car 4 days ago. O: Initial examination showed the dog was tachypneic and laterally recumbent with a body condition score of 5/9. On palpation of the neck, he vocalized, and pain was assessed at 2/4 on the Canine Acute Pain Scale. Neurologic examination revealed cranial nerve function intact, paresis of the thoracic limbs, plegia of the pelvic limbs, increased muscle tone in the thoracic limbs, decreased conscious proprioception in the thoracic limbs, absent segmental reflexes, and absent panniculus reflex caudal to L1 bilaterally. Blood work indicated elevated alanine aminotransferase (185U/L), normochromic normocytic anemia (hematocrit 35.7%), leukocytosis (15.69K/uL), neutrophilia (10.7K/uL), and monocytosis (2K/uL). A: The primary diagnosis is a T2-T4 injury with cervical disc compression, likely secondary to spinal trauma. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of spinal trauma, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the dog's neurological status and management of pain. Additional diagnostic tests such as MRI or CT scans may be necessary to further understand the extent of the injuries and determine the best course of treatment. The owner is advised to report any changes in his condition and report any new symptoms immediately. Referral to a veterinary specialist for further evaluation and management of spinal injuries is recommended.

S: The patient reports severe neutropenia for the last 6 months, which has not responded to granulocyte-colony stimulating factor at a maximum dose of 20 mcg/kg daily. The patient has a history of recurrent infections of the upper respiratory tract and stomatitis during the first years of life. The patient's birth weight is 3,600 g. Family medical history includes recurrent infections of the upper respiratory tract and stomatitis during the first years of life. O: Physical examination revealed splenomegaly. Ultrasound scan showed a long axis measuring 11.5 cm. Blood count showed profound neutropenia with an absolute neutrophil count of 0.02  109/L, no anemia or thrombocytopenia. Bone marrow examination showed rare myeloid precursors with normal erythroid and megakaryocyte lineages. Bone marrow plasma significantly inhibited growth of progenitor cells. CFU-E/BFU-E count dropped from 88 to 4 when combined with plasma, and CFU-GEMM count from 17 to 9. Anti-neutrophil IgG levels were 171.1 mg/dL. A: The primary diagnosis is autoimmune neutropenia, likely exacerbated by a misdiagnosed form of autoimmune neutropenia. Differential diagnoses considered included Kostmann disease, Shwachman-Diamond syndrome, Fanconi anemia, and paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria. P: The management plan will include exploring alternative treatment options including granulocyte-colony stimulating factor at a maximum dose of 20 mcg/kg daily. Close monitoring of anti-neutrophil IgG levels will be necessary, and the patient will be educated on the importance of reporting new symptoms or concerns. Further diagnostic work-up will be scheduled to assess the effectiveness of the treatment and adjust the plan as necessary.

S: The patient reports a history of spine surgery 15 years ago for a right L4-L5 disc herniation, which initially was moderate but recurred after three years. The patient has experienced severe bilateral L5 sciatalgy with paresthesias, no motor dysfunction, and mictional delay. The patient has undergone multiple intra-foraminal corticosteroid injections and percutaneous radiofrequency denervation at the L4-L5 and L5-S1 facet joints over the last 10 years. O: Recent MRI in July 2014 revealed a disc herniation originating from the L4-L5 disc, perforating the common longitudinal ligament and anterior aspect of the dura, entering thecal sac. The intradural part of the herniation is very large, extending downwards and reaching the upper sacrum. The disc fragment is surrounded by rootlets. The upper part of the disc fragment enters the dura appears compact, with peripheral contrast enhancement after gadolinium injection. The intradural part appears less compact with crumbled appearance, irregular borders, and no contrast enhancement. A: The primary diagnosis is a disc herniation originating from the L4-L5 disc, originating from the L4-L5 disc, involving the common longitudinal ligament and anterior aspect of the dura, entering thecal sac. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of sciatalgy and mictional delay. The prognosis is guarded due to the complexity of the herniation and the presence of rootlets. P: The patient underwent a hemilaminectomy on L4 and L5 on the clinically dominant right side with adjacent hemiflavectomy on L3/4 and L5/S1. Post-operative care includes follow-up appointments to monitor recovery and manage any new or worsening symptoms. Rehabilitation and physical therapy may be recommended to regain strength and mobility. The patient is advised to report any new or worsening symptoms promptly.

S: The patient, diagnosed with papillary serous adenocarcinoma and uterine masses, reports feeling nervous but is okay. He has a history of hypertension, hemorrhoids, morbid obesity with a BMI of 46.8, and a pulmonary embolism three months prior to surgery. He describes his daily activities as moderate to excellent, able to do household chores, cycle three to five miles daily, and climb two flights of stairs. He has no history of anesthetic complications and no family history of anesthetic complications. He is a non-smoker and consumes one alcoholic beverage four times per month. He is allergic to benazepril, ezetimibe, simvastatin, and triamterene, which causes myalgias. O: The patient's current medications include prochlorperazine 10 mg as needed post-chemotherapy, dexamethasone 4 mg for three days post-chemotherapy, rivaroxaban 20 mg daily, enoxaparin 120 mg/0.8 mL solution subcutaneous, hydrochlorothiazide-valsartan 12.5-320 mg daily for essential hypertension control, and hydrochlorothiazide-valsartan 12.5-320 mg daily for essential hypertension control. He is a non-smoker and consumes one alcoholic beverage four times per month. He is allergic to benazepril, ezetimibe, simvastatin, and triamterene, all of which cause myalgias. A: The primary diagnosis is papillary serous adenocarcinoma with uterine masses. The patient's history of hypertension, hemorrhoids, morbid obesity, and pulmonary embolism are significant contributing factors to his condition. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of adenocarcinoma, but these are less likely given the patient's history and current medications. P: The management plan includes an exploratory laparotomy, total abdominal hysterectomy, bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, omentectomy, debulking, and lymph node dis

S: 52-year-old male with a history of hypertension, coronary artery disease, and end-stage renal disease presents with cloudy dialysate and diffuse abdominal pain for approximately 2 hours. He reports a history of community-acquired pneumonia treated with 400-mg oral moxifloxacin daily for 10 days two weeks ago, which has not improved his cough. Recently, he experienced epigastric pain and an intractable cough two days ago without nausea, vomiting, or fever. O: Physical examination revealed epigastric tenderness without guarding or rebound pain. Laboratory studies indicated a white blood cell count of 12,000 cells/mm3 with 87% neutrophils and 8% lymphocytes, hemoglobin 8.0 g/dL, ALT 35 U/L, amylase 19 U/L, total bilirubin 0.56 mg/dL, creatinine 16.7 mg/dL, sodium concentration 133 mEq/L, and potassium concentration 4.2 mEq/L. Chest radiography showed no signs of pneumonia. PD dialysate effluent analysis showed WBC 2/L without polymorphonuclear leukocyte (PMN). Abdominal ultrasonography showed a distended gallbladder with sludge. PD dialysate effluent analysis showed WBC 1783/L without polymorphonuclear leukocyte (PMN) and a distended gallbladder with sludge. On day 2, WBC counts were 1565/L (PMN 71%). A: Primary diagnosis of PD peritonitis, based on PD dialysate effluent analysis and PD dialysate effluent analysis. Differential diagnosis initially included community-acquired pneumonia, which was ruled out based on imaging and lab results. P: Initiated treatment with Cefuroxime and amikacin intraperitoneally to manage diffuse abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. Plan to monitor PD dialysate effluent daily and adjust treatment as necessary. Continue monitoring PD dialysate effluent and adjust treatment as necessary. Educate the patient on the importance of adhering to the treatment

S: The patient is a 43-year-old woman who has a history of thyroidectomy for goiter and endometriosis. She reports severe dysphonia related to scarred vocal folds following a phonosurgery. She has a history of two laryngeal surgeries: suspension laryngoscopy for Reinke edema and cervicotomy with lateral thyrotomy for resection of a right ventricular lesion. She has a history of granuloma excision in the anterior third of the left vocal fold, which did not recur. O: The patient met the inclusion and exclusion criteria for the clinical trial, and she is eligible for a local injection of autologous adipose-derived stromal vascular fraction (ADSVF). Videolaryngostroboscopy revealed a scarred aspect of the vocal folds, particularly an absence of vibration in the middle third. A: The primary diagnosis is severe dysphonia related to scarred vocal folds following a phonosurgery. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of vocal fold dysphonia, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation. The prognosis depends on the response to the local injection and response to the treatment. P: The management plan includes scheduling a local injection of autologous adipose-derived stromal vascular fraction (ADSVF) to address the scarred vocal folds' flexibility and vibration. The patient is advised to continue regular speech therapy and monitor her progress throughout the trial. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess treatment efficacy and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient is a 73-year-old Caucasian woman with a history of hypertension, presenting with intermittent subjective fever, anorexia, weakness, and fatigue for the past 2 weeks. She reports a persistent non-productive cough but no sore throat or rashes. She has been on enalapril for hypertension for 2 weeks, and has a history of left knee pain developed after a hike. She denies any recent sick contacts, sexual partners, or insect/tick bites, and no known exposure to tuberculosis or animals. O: Physical examination reveals the patient to be non-toxic. Vital signs show a temperature of 38.6 °C, heart rate of 96 beats/minute, blood pressure of 130/65 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 99% on room air. No rashes or lymphadenopathy are noted. The thyroid is normal, and no signs of hyperthyroidism are noted. Jugular venous pulse is 2 cm above the sternal angle, heart sounds are normal, and lungs are clear with equal breath sounds bilaterally. The abdomen is soft and non-tender, with no hepatosplenomegaly, jaundice, or asterixis. Knees are normal. A: The primary diagnosis is a recurrent recurrent fever, anorexia, weakness, and fatigue, likely exacerbated by a recent hike. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of fever, anorexia, weakness, and fatigue, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: Plan to conduct further diagnostic tests to confirm the diagnosis and determine the cause of the fever, anorexia, weakness, and fatigue. Schedule a follow-up appointment to review the results and discuss further treatment options. Educate the patient on the importance of adherence to prescribed medications and follow-up appointments. Consider referral to a nephrologist for further evaluation and management.

S: The patient reports experiencing headaches and a visual field deficit in the lower left part of the field. The patient has a history of high blood pressure, smoking, or excessive alcohol consumption. O: CT angiography revealed a left superior carotid-ophthalmic aneurysm measuring 4 x 5 mm. The aneurysm is located in the left superior carotid-ophthalmic artery, measuring 5 mm. A: The primary diagnosis is a left superior carotid-ophthalmic aneurysm, measuring 4 x 5 mm. The aneurysm is small at 5 mm, but it is necessary to monitor its size and manage any risk factors. P: The management plan includes regular check-ups and imaging tests to monitor the aneurysm's growth and manage any potential risk factors. The patient is advised to manage any risk factors such as high blood pressure, smoking, or excessive alcohol consumption. Further consultations with a neurologist may be necessary if symptoms persist or worsen.

S: The patient is a 66-year-old female from an Ashkenazi Jewish family with three successive generations of GD type 1. She reports a history of osteopenia, gallstones, and a family history of colon cancer and GD type 1. She denies any symptoms of bone pains, bone fractures, easy bruising, bleeding, fatigue, or weight loss. She has no significant medical or social history. Family history includes Lynch syndrome, which was noncontributory. O: Physical examination revealed a pulse rate of 42 bpm without hepatosplenomegaly or purpura. Mild cervical dystonia was noted with neck ratcheting to the left with several movements. Complete blood count was within normal limits. -glucosidase activity was reduced at 2 nmol/h/mg (normal range 8–16). Direct gene analysis for the common 9 pathogenic variants in the GBA gene identified a homozygous pathogenic variant in GBA (N370S/N370S). Biomarkers showed elevated activity levels of angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE) at 66 U/L (normal range 9–63 U/L), chitotriosidase (CHITO) at 1603 nmoles/h/ml (normal range 4–120), and lyso-Gb1 at 164 ng/mL (normal range 10 ng/mL). Whole exome sequencing was performed. A: The primary diagnosis is GD type 1, evidenced by the patient's history of osteopenia, gallstones, and family history of colon cancer. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of colon cancer, but these are less likely given the family history. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and response to treatment. P: Plan to monitor the patient's condition closely with regular blood counts and -glucosidase activity levels. Discuss potential treatment options based on the patient's response to treatment. Educate the patient on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and avoiding potential side effects. Schedule follow-up appointments to monitor the patient's condition and adjust treatment as necessary.

S: The patient, with a history of asthma and skin cancer, presented with abnormal shadows on a chest X-ray during an annual check-up. The patient denies any recent trauma. O: Blood tests including hemodynamics, renal, and hepatic function are within normal limits. Electrocardiograms are within normal limits. Chest CT revealed a well-defined tumor approximately 66 X 65 X 45 mm behind the trachea, homogenous with 45 Hounsfield units, with no calcification or fat components. MRI indicated a high signal on T2W1 images, indicating a cystic tumor. The patient was diagnosed as a bronchogenic cyst and underwent cyst excision. Post-operatively, the patient was kept in the hospital for 6 days to wait for normalization of liver function. A: The primary diagnosis is a bronchogenic cyst, a neurogenic tumor, Castleman disease, and malignant lymphoma. Differential diagnoses considered included bronchogenic cyst, neurogenic tumor, Castleman disease, and malignant lymphoma. P: The patient underwent cyst excision, which was performed using a linear stapler. Post-operatively, the patient was discharged 4 years post-operatively. The patient is advised to continue monitoring for any new symptoms or concerns. Regular follow-up appointments are scheduled to monitor the patient's health and adjust treatment as necessary.

S: The patient, an 8-year-old female spayed Dachshund, presented with a sudden, firm, symmetrical painful protrusion in the perineal region, accompanied by one-month history of dysuria and pollakiuria. The owner reports a history of a urinary tract infection treated with amoxicillin-clavulanic acid but did not respond to treatment. The owner also reports tenesmus for the past 2 days. O: Physical examination revealed a 5  4  2 cm firm, painful protrusion on the perineal region, ventral to the anus, and a fluid-filled structure ventral to the rectum and distal colon, without pelvic diaphragm weakness. Serum chemistry and complete blood count were not palpable. CT and vaginoscopy revealed a large, tubular, fluid-filled structure measuring 4 cm in diameter at its widest point and 16.3 cm long, compressing the pelvic canal and caudal abdomen, compressing the colon and rectum dorsally and ventrally, and displacing the bladder within the abdomen to the left of the midline. Mild dilation of renal pelves and proximal ureters was noted. A: The primary diagnosis is a large, tubular, fluid-filled structure in the perineal region, likely exacerbated by pyelonephritis or backpressure from the dilated urinary bladder. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of urinary tract infection, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The management plan includes surgical intervention to address the large, tubular, fluid-filled structure. The owner is advised to closely monitor the dog and report any worsening of the condition. Referral to a veterinary urologist for further evaluation and management is recommended. Regular follow-ups will be scheduled to monitor the condition and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient reports experiencing right hip and lower back pain with radiation to the posterior right thigh, which sometimes goes down the back of the right thigh. The patient denies any numbness, tingling, or weakness in the legs. O: Provocative testing on the right SI joint showed reproducible pain. Radiographic spine survey showed no structural source of low back pain or radiculopathy. Preoperative imaging including MRI showed lumbarization of the S1 vertebra, mammillary bodies in the alar region, and a residual S1-S2 disc. Surgical intervention included SI joint fusion using the iFuse implant System® from SI-Bone, Inc. in Santa Clara, California. The first implant was placed within the S2 body caudal to the residual S1-S2 disc, and the second implant was placed caudal to the first using a double-barrel guide. A: The primary diagnosis is lumbarization of the S1 vertebra, mammillary bodies in the alar region, and a residual S1-S2 disc. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of low back pain or radiculopathy, but imaging and surgical findings support the primary diagnosis. P: The patient underwent successful SI joint fusion using the iFuse implant System® from SI-Bone, Inc. in Santa Clara, California. Postoperative care includes monitoring recovery and providing follow-up care. The patient will continue to be educated on the importance of adhering to follow-up appointments and adherence to follow-up schedules.

S: The patient, admitted on October 28th, 2016, presented with abdominal pain, distension, dark urine, cough, expectoration, chills, and fever. The patient denies any history of hepatobiliary disease, excessive alcohol intake, recent travel, or blood transfusions. O: Physical examination revealed normal vital signs and consciousness. Physical examination showed severe jaundice, no bleeding points, spider angioma, or liver palm. Abdominal examination was flat and soft with no tenderness or rebounding tenderness. Liver and spleen were untouched, and no shifting dullness was noted. Laboratory tests showed WBC 3.54  109/L, NE 61.00%, Hb 119 g/L, PLT 130  109/L, PT 22.9 s, APTT 60.2 s, and PTA 78%. Liver tests showed TBIL 263.62 umol/L, DBIL 211.34 umol/L, IBIL 52.28 umol/L, ALT 747 U/L, AST 986 U/L, gamma-GPT 256 U/L, ALP 184 U/L, TBA 205.85 umol/L, and LDH 346 U/L. Serum IgG was 13.68 g/L, and IgG4 was 298 g/ml. Serologic markers of hepatitis B virus were analyzed. A: The patient presents with severe jaundice, elevated liver enzymes, and abnormal liver function tests. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of liver dysfunction, but these are less likely given the negative serologic markers. P: The management plan includes regular blood tests to monitor liver function and assess any changes in the patient's condition. The patient is advised to monitor symptoms and report any new or worsening symptoms to the healthcare team. Regular follow-ups will be scheduled to monitor liver function and adjust medication as necessary. The patient is encouraged to report any new or worsening symptoms immediately.

S: The patient, a 9-year-old with a history of food allergies, presents with severe eczematous skin lesions persisting even with local and systemic steroids. The patient also experiences recurrent infections with molloscum contagiosum and flat warts on the face, neck, behind the ears, axillary area, and genitalia. The patient has a history of sinusopulmonary infections treated in an outpatient setting, molloscum contagiosum, and flat warts on the face, neck, behind the ears, axillary area, and genitalia. The patient has a history of dental issues related to malocclusion and retention of primary teeth, needing dental intervention, and mucocutaneous candidiasis. Vaccinations were administered according to the Iraq vaccination schedule. At age 9, the patient experienced a slowly growing right jaw mass and toothache without fever, headache, or bone pain. The mass increased in size over several months without changes in the overlying skin. Oral examination revealed a fungating mass related to the right mandible with a bad odor. Chest and abdominal examination showed scattered crepitation and a palpable liver. Growth parameters are below the 3rd centile, but school performance has been good. The patient's parents are first cousins from both maternal and paternal sides. O: Physical examination revealed severe eczematous skin lesions, non-tender right jaw swelling, right submandibular lymph node 2.5 cm, bilateral cervical and axillary lymphadenopathy, and a fungating mass related to the right mandible with a bad odor. Chest and abdominal examination showed scattered crepitation and a palpable liver. Growth parameters are below the 3rd centile, but school performance has been unaffected. A: The primary diagnosis is a fungating mass related to the right mandible with a bad odor. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of eczematous skin lesions, but these are less likely given the patient's history and imaging findings. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the absence of fever, headache, or bone pain. P: The management plan will focus on addressing the fungating

S: The patient reports recurring cervical swelling on the left side, concomitant dysphonia, and dysphagia. The patient has a history of multiple neck surgeries since age 10, including seven under general anesthesia and four tomographic imagings, with a cumulative x-ray exposure of 16 mSv. The patient has undergone multiple interventions including extirpation and drainage of an abscess. O: Computed tomography revealed extensive abscess formation. The patient was hospitalized and treated with draining and intravenous antibiotics. Recent diagnostic work-ups including repetitive computer tomography, MRI, and barium esophagograms showed no fistula or sinus tract. A new barium esophagogram was unremarkable. A subsequent CT of the neck showed accumulation of contrast medium in the superior part of the piriform sinus on the left side. A: The primary diagnosis is a recurrent second branchial cleft cyst, likely secondary to upper respiratory tract infections. Differential diagnosis initially included a second branchial arch cyst, which was ruled out based on pathological findings. P: The management plan includes further diagnostic work-up to determine the underlying cause of the abscess. The patient will be kept informed about the findings and will be monitored for any new symptoms or changes in symptoms. Further diagnostic work-ups will be conducted to further explore the underlying cause of the abscess. The patient will be educated on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and adherence to follow-up appointments.

S: The patient reports a 24-hour history of a motorcycle accident that hit his face on the ground, which he was not wearing a helmet at the time. He denies experiencing loss of consciousness, vomiting, or amnesia post-accident. He has been on medication for diabetes for the past seven years. O: Physical examination revealed swelling and abrasion over the right zygomatic region without subconjunctival hemorrhage, diplopia, or enophthalmos. Ocular movements were normal. Intraoral examination showed normal occlusion, no signs of fracture or mobility of teeth, and a mouth opening of 36 mm. Tenderness in the right zygomaticomaxillary buttress and the right infraorbital rim were noted, with an infraorbital step on the right side. Crepitus was noted in the right zygomaticomaxillary buttress region. CT scan revealed a fracture in the right zygomaticomaxillary buttress region and right infraorbital rim region. A: The primary diagnosis is a fracture in the right zygomaticomaxillary buttress and right infraorbital rim region, likely secondary to a motorcycle accident. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of facial fractures, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The management plan includes open reduction and internal fixation of the fractures in the right zygomaticomaxillary buttress and right infraorbital rim region. The patient will be educated about the procedure and expected outcomes, and follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor recovery and adjust treatment as necessary. Referral to a general physician and a neurosurgeon for further evaluation and management of the fractured facial bones is recommended.

S: The patient reports experiencing chest oppression on effort for a month, characterized by tightness in the chest, particularly when active. The patient has a history of ST-segment depression in leads I, aVL, and V2-4. O: On admission, laboratory tests including creatinine kinase and troponin I levels were within normal limits. Echocardiography showed normal left ventricular contraction and mild to moderate aortic regurgitation. Coronary angiography showed severe stenosis in the ostium of both the left main trunk and the right coronary artery. Quantitative coronary angiography analysis showed % diameter stenosis of the ostial stenosis at 95.0% in the left main trunk and 87.2% in the right coronary artery. Intra-coronary isosorbide dinitrate was administered, but did not dilate the stenosis. Right ankle-brachial indices were 1.08 and 1.03, respectively. Ophthalmologist examination showed no vision impairment. Magnetic resonance angiography showed no significant stenosis of the carotid artery. C-reactive protein, serum amyloid A, and erythrocyte sedimentation rate (1 h) were 2.13 mg/dL. A: The primary diagnosis is coronary artery disease with severe stenosis in the left main trunk and right coronary artery. Differential diagnoses include renal artery stenosis and hypertension, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The patient is currently on beta-blocker, antiplatelet, and statin, with a contrast-enhanced CT scan showing no specific abnormalities of the aorta. The patient is advised to closely monitor symptoms and have regular follow-up appointments to assess progress. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately.

S: The patient reports experiencing hematemesis due to the rupture of esophageal varices and subsequent hemostasis with endoscopic variceal ligation (EVL). The patient has a history of multiple hematemeses due to esophageal variceal rupture, which were treated with hemostasis with endoscopic variceal ligation (EVL). O: Abdominal ultrasonography revealed ascites and color Doppler ultrasonography showed an IAPF between the branch of the left hepatic artery and the umbilical part of the left branch of the portal vein. The right portal venous flow was hepatopetal, and the left portal venous flow was hepatofugal. Contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) showed IAPF in the left lobe, and the umbilical part of the left branch of the portal vein was enhanced simultaneously in the arterial phase. Digital subtraction angiography (DSA) indicated diffuse IAPF and an early filling of the left branch of the portal vein. The patient experienced four more hematemeses due to esophageal variceal rupture, with a total of six EVLs and a second TAE failed to reach complete occlusion due to diffuse collateralization. Serum platelet count was 12.8  104/L, and aspartate transaminase concentration was slightly elevated at 69 IU. A: The primary diagnosis is portal hypertension secondary to IAPF, likely exacerbated by cirrhosis or esophageal varices. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of portal hypertension, but these are less likely given the imaging and lab results. P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition, considering the patient's history of multiple hematemeses and the failure of transcatheter arterial embolization. Additional interventions may be considered to control bleeding and manage liver function. The patient will be educated on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and adherence to follow-up appointments. Referral to a hepatologist for further evaluation and management of portal hypertension and anemia is recommended.

S: The patient presented with a three-day history of palpitations, shortness of breath, pallor, and black tarry stools. The patient expressed concern about the severity of the symptoms and expressed concern about the nature of the symptoms. O: The patient was diagnosed with anemia with a hemoglobin level of 4.4 g/dL. Physical examination and additional blood tests were within normal limits. A CT scan of the abdomen revealed a hypodense mass in the second and third portion of the duodenum, intraluminal with an extraluminal component abutting the uncinate process of the pancreas. Colonoscopy was negative, and an upper endoscopy showed an ulcerated mass in the second and third portion of the duodenum. Biopsy of the mass was inconclusive, showing cellular debris. Postoperative pathology confirmed a duodenal gangliocytic paraganglioma eroding into the pancreas, with all lymph nodes negative for tumor markers. A: The primary diagnosis is duodenal gangliocytic paraganglioma of the pancreas, confirmed by pathology. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of pancreatic adenocarcinoma, but these are less likely given the imaging and biopsy results. P: The patient underwent a pancreaticoduodenectomy, which was successful. Postoperatively, the patient was discharged on postoperative day five, and the tumor was eroding into the pancreas. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately. Regular follow-ups will be scheduled to monitor the patient's condition and manage any complications.

S: The patient is a 67-year-old woman who was hospitalized for cholecystitis and experiencing upper abdominal cramps. She reports severe pain following a laparoscopic cholecystectomy for gallbladder removal. O: During the laparoscopic cholecystectomy, the gallbladder was perforated during an accident. The patient developed severe peritonitis, leading to her death 2 weeks post-surgery. An autopsy and contrast-enhanced PMCT were performed. External forensic examination and conventional autopsy were conducted, and the isolated intestinal tract was prepared for additional examinations. A contrast-enhanced PMCT of the isolated intestinal tract was performed. A: The primary diagnosis is severe peritonitis post-cholecystectomy, complicated by the peritonitis. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of abdominal pain, but these are less likely given the imaging results. P: The patient underwent a laparoscopic cholecystectomy to remove the gallbladder and explore the abdominal cavity. Post-operative care included an autopsy and contrast-enhanced PMCT of the isolated intestinal tract, which was performed using a 40-slice multislice CT system. A urinary catheter was inserted into the upper end and ligated the 2 ends of the intestine. A: The primary diagnosis is severe peritonitis post-cholecystectomy, complicated by the peritonitis. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of abdominal pain, but these are less likely given the imaging results. P: The management plan included an autopsy and contrast-enhanced PMCT of the isolated intestinal tract. The patient's family was informed about the procedure and the importance of reporting any new symptoms immediately. The family will be educated about the procedure and the importance of reporting any new symptoms immediately.

S: The patient, with a history of non-ischemic dilated cardiomyopathy, reports worsening shortness of breath during exercise. The patient has a history of non-ischemic dilated cardiomyopathy. O: Initial treatment with milrinone infusion was ineffective, leading to femoral veno-arterial Extracorporeal Membrane Oxygenation (ECMO) for refractory ventricular tachycardia and worsening cardiogenic shock. ECMO stabilized the patient's condition, but it was not possible to wean off the support. A durable Left Ventricular Assist Device (LVAD) was chosen as a bridge to transplant. Pre-operative echocardiography revealed a severely dilated left ventricle with an ejection fraction of 15%, moderately dilated right ventricle with moderate dysfunction, mildly thickened and calcified aortic valve, moderate aortic insufficiency, and severe, functional regurgitation of both mitral and tricuspid valves. Post-operatively, the patient was weaned from cardiopulmonary bypass after 178 minutes without difficulty. A: The primary diagnosis is severe refractory ventricular tachycardia with worsening cardiogenic shock. The patient underwent successful aortic valve replacement with a 23 mm Intuity valve, tricuspid valve repair with a 30 mm MC3 annuloplasty ring, and HeartWareTM HVAD implant from Medtronic. Post-operatively, the patient was extubated and is currently recovering well. P: Continue monitoring the patient's cardiac status and manage any complications from the LVAD. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess the patient's recovery and adjust treatment as necessary. Educate the patient on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and follow-up appointments to ensure compliance and prevent complications.

S: The patient is a cyclist who experienced a fall during a race, resulting in a fall on the left side and hitting a tree with his right leg. He was wearing a helmet and was not experiencing head or chest trauma. He reported feeling lightheaded and swollen and tender in the right thigh. O: Vital signs showed a blood pressure of 128/69 mmHg, pulse of 65 bpm, no fever, and normal breathing. The right thigh was swollen and tender. ECG indicated lateral ST segment elevation. Troponin I was positive at 0.49ng/mL, and CPK was 617 U/L. Echocardiogram showed normal right and left ventricular function and a trace of pericardial effusion. Coronary angiography indicated a spontaneous coronary artery dissection in the left anterior descending coronary artery. A: The primary diagnosis is a spontaneous coronary artery dissection in the left anterior descending coronary artery. Differential diagnoses initially included cardiac contusion and cardiac arrhythmias, which were ruled out by imaging and clinical findings. P: The patient was started on Aspirin, Clopidogrel, heparin infusion, Lisinopril, and Beta Blocker. Coronary angiography confirmed a spontaneous coronary artery dissection in the left anterior descending coronary artery. A: The primary diagnosis is a spontaneous coronary artery dissection in the left anterior descending coronary artery. The patient's history of caffeine Jello shots and caffeine consumption contribute to heart issues. P: The patient will continue on Aspirin, Clopidogrel, heparin infusion, Lisinopril, and Beta Blocker. Regular follow-ups with the primary care physician and cardiologist are recommended to monitor the patient's condition and manage any complications. The patient is advised to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately. Further diagnostic studies may be necessary based on the findings and the patient's history.

S: The patient, with a history of asthma, reflux disease, diverticulitis, ulcerative colitis, prior left hip replacement, and cholecystectomy, presents with right lower quadrant pain for 3 days, nausea, cough, back pain, nonbloody vomiting, and diarrhea. The patient has a history of a fall 3 weeks ago. O: Vital signs include blood pressure 155/80 mmHg, pulse 74 bpm, respirations 18, and temperature 36.7°C. Abdominal examination reveals soft abdomen with tenderness in the right lower quadrant, no evidence of an inguinal mass or erythema. Lab tests show no leukocytosis. CT scan of the abdomen reveals a right femoral hernia containing an inflamed appendix. Postoperative diagnosis includes a Pantaloon hernia, femoral hernia, and Amyand's hernia containing an early, nonperforated appendicitis. Postoperative complications include Clavien-Dindo grade 1 pain, classified as Clavien-Dindo grade 1. A: The primary diagnosis is a right femoral hernia containing an inflamed appendix, complicated by a Pantaloon hernia, femoral hernia, and Amyand's hernia. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of abdominal pain, but imaging and lab findings support the primary diagnosis. P: The patient will be treated with a laparoscopic appendectomy and McVay hernia repair. Postoperative care will include discharge to the skilled nursing facility where the patient will reside. The patient is advised to attend any necessary follow-up appointments and maintain a healthy lifestyle. The patient is advised to maintain a healthy diet and follow up regularly to monitor for any complications.

S: The patient, with a history of ischemic heart disease and an elective percutaneous coronary intervention four years ago, reports experiencing exercise dyspnea for approximately 2 years, which has been intensifying over the past few weeks. The patient has a history of metabolic syndrome, obesity with a BMI of 33, and gastroesophageal reflux disease. O: The patient was hospitalized for further diagnostic tests including transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) showing a non-dilated left ventricle with a normal systolic ejection fraction of 60%, severe mitral regurgitation (MR), prolapse of the A2 segment, and systolic restriction of the posterior leaflet. Colour Doppler showed a highly distinctive eccentric turbulent jet directed towards the lateral wall and base of the left atrium with an ERO of 0.6cm2 and a regurgitant volume of 60 ml. Coronary angiography indicated hemodynamically significant narrowing in the area of previously implanted drug-eluting stents. A: The primary diagnosis is severe mitral regurgitation with prolapse of the A2 segment and systolic restriction of the posterior leaflet. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of mitral regurgitation, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation. P: The patient underwent mitral valve repair surgery and coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) using a saphenous vein graft to the circumflex artery. Post-operative care will include close monitoring of cardiac function and cardiac function. The patient will be educated on the procedure and post-operative care to ensure understanding and compliance. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess recovery and manage any complications.

S: The patient, admitted with a liver tumor discovered during a PET-CT scan, reports no recent symptoms or discomfort. The patient has a history of hepatitis B virus infection and has been asymptomatic but has not had any medical interventions. O: Serum tumor markers showed no elevated carbohydrase antigen-19-9 (11.2 U/ml), carbohydrase antigen-125 (18.1 U/ml), or carcinoembryonic antigen (1.0 ng/ml). Gastroscopy and colonoscopy were normal. Planned CT scan revealed a 6.0 cm low-density mass in the caudate liver. Enhanced CT showed two components in the mass, with the right tumor enhancement during the arterial phase and delayed washout in the late phase, but the left component appears as a hypovascular lesion. MRI showed low intensity on T1-weighted images and heterogeneously high on T2-weighted images. DWI showed higher intensity than normal liver parenchyma with a high b value of 1000. ADC mean values were 1.19  10 3 mm2/s (right component) and 1.95  10 3 mm2/s (left component). Gadolinium-ethoxybenzyl-diethylene-triaminepentaacetic-acid (Gd-EOB) was used in imaging. A: The primary diagnosis is a liver tumor, likely secondary to hepatitis B virus infection, given the imaging findings and clinical presentation. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of liver tumors, but these are less likely given the imaging findings and clinical presentation. P: The management plan will include discussing the case with a multidisciplinary team including oncology, oncology, and hepatology. The patient will be educated on the nature of the tumor, treatment options, and potential side effects. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's response to treatment and adjust the plan as necessary. The patient is encouraged to reach out with any questions or concerns during the treatment process.

S: The patient reports multiple episodes of dizziness, shortness of breath, and palpitations. The patient denies any history of cardiac arrhythmias, structural heart disease, or ischemic heart disease. The patient has a history of substance use disorder, depression, and substance abuse of hydrocodone dating back to 2007. The patient has drug allergies to amoxicillin and erythromycin. The patient has a history of recreational use of loperamide 400 mg recreationally. O: Physical examination revealed moderate distress with pain from external defibrillations. Vital signs were elevated at over 200 bpm, blood pressure at 157/80 mmHg, and respiratory rate at 24/minute. Pulmonary exam revealed decreased breath sounds bilaterally with symmetrical chest wall expansion. Cardiovascular exam showed tachycardia, no murmurs, and moist mucous membranes without jugular venous distension. Gastrointestinal exam was negative for distention, tenderness, rebound, guarding, hepatomegaly, or splenomegaly.
