Musculoskeletal examination showed warm and well-perfused upper and lower extremities without clubbing, cyanosis, and edema. EKG monitors showed polymorphic VT with a heart rate of 220. A: The primary diagnosis is polymorphic VT with a heart rate of 220. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of ventricular tachycardia, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation. The prognosis depends on the management of the VT and the patient's response to treatment. P: Continue monitoring the patient's cardiac status and substance use disorder. Schedule regular follow-ups with the primary care physician and cardiologist to manage the condition and substance use disorder. Educate the patient on the importance of medication adherence and adherence to follow-up appointments. Encourage the patient to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately.

S: The patient reports experiencing right hip pain for two weeks, described as severe, tenderness in the right hip joint, decreased range of motion, and difficulty walking for gait assessment. The patient has a history of less severe episodes for the last four years. The patient denies fever, skin rash, or acne. O: Physical examination revealed a small lucency in the right greater trochanteric region. X-rays of the pelvis and right thigh showed a small lucency in the right greater trochanteric region. MRI of the right thigh indicated trochanteric bursa effusion and right hip joint synovitis. Initial treatment with NSAIDs and paracetamol was effective for pain management. However, four months later, the patient developed swelling of the right sternoclavicular joint. MRI revealed a patchy area of hyperintensity on T2 and hypointensity on T1 close to the sternoclavicular junction, mild accentuated heterogeneous enhancement, marrow edema, subcutaneous edema, and changes related to cellulitis in the overlying soft tissues. A: The primary diagnosis is SAPHO syndrome, a rare inflammatory condition affecting bones and joints. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of right hip pain, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The patient was started on paracetamol and NSAIDs for pain management. The treatment plan includes continued monitoring of the patient's response to the treatment and adjustments as necessary. The patient is advised to report any worsening symptoms or new symptoms immediately. Further consultations with a neurologist and a rheumatologist are recommended to manage the condition and manage any complications.

S: The patient, a 5-month-old female, presented with difficulty gaining weight, poor feeding, vomiting, and diarrhea. The parent reports a family history of similar issues and a previous child who passed away before. O: Laboratory findings revealed pancytopenia, lymphopenia, hypogammaglobulinemia, low serum vitamin B12 at 136 pg/mL, and low serum homocysteine. CMV PCR test was positive. Bone marrow aspiration showed prominent vacuolization in the myeloid lineage, suggestive of Pearson syndrome, and megaloblastic changes in the myeloid lineage, but molecular analysis did not support the diagnosis of Pearson syndrome. A: The primary diagnosis is severe combined immunodeficiency with a genetic deficiency of transcobalamin (TC). Differential diagnoses could include other forms of immunodeficiency, but these are less likely given the clinical and hematological findings. P: The management plan included intramuscular vitamin B12 and oral folic acid, which were initially administered. The patient was treated with intramuscular vitamin B12 and oral folic acid, which was discontinued due to relapse. The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's progress and adjustment of the treatment plan as necessary. The patient will be closely monitored for any relapse or new symptoms.

S: The patient reports swelling in the left lower leg, presenting with a BMI of 45.2 kg/m2 and type II diabetes, with a hemoglobin A1c of 8.1%. The patient was diagnosed with heart failure in May 2017, treated with a venous duplex and X-ray. The patient has a history of grade 3 obesity with a BMI of 45.2 kg/m2, type II diabetes, and elevated hemoglobin A1c of 8.1%. O: Initial tests showed no deep venous thrombosis and a left bundle branch block. Echocardiography showed a left ventricular ejection fraction of 25% without significant valvular pathology. Renal, liver, and thyroid function tests were within normal limits. Non-reactive for HIV was not anemic. Cardiac MRI indicated dilated cardiomyopathy and an ejection fraction of 21%, and Coronary CT angiogram showed a calcium score of 458. Cardiac catheterization showed cardiomyopathy out of proportion to coronary artery disease with a 30% proximal left anterior descending artery stenosis, 25% proximal and 60% distal left circumflex artery stenosis, and a 65% first obtuse marginal artery lesion. A: The primary diagnosis is heart failure with a history of dilated cardiomyopathy and coronary artery disease. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of heart failure, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic given the resolution of diabetes and improvement in hemoglobin A1c. P: The patient is currently on a whole food plant-based diet and supplemental vitamin B12. Follow-up echocardiography in November 2017 showed a normal left ventricular ejection fraction of 55%. The patient is advised to maintain regular follow-ups with the cardiologist to monitor heart health and adjust medications as necessary. Further consultations with cardiology and diabetes management are recommended to manage diabetes and prevent complications.

S: The patient, with a 21-year history of type 2 diabetes, reports a history of an ulcer on the left heel, numbness on the left lower limb for 6 years, intermittent claudication, and rest pain for about a year. S: The patient, a male with a history of lung cancer in remission following lobectomy and adjuvant chemotherapy, presents with fever, chills, and weakness for the past five days. Blood tests indicated anemia with hemoglobin at 8.7 g/dL, hematocrit at 26.4%, neutropenia with a white blood cell count of 4.71 K/L, thrombocytopenia with a platelet count of 37 K/L, and low haptoglobin at less than 10 mg/dL. S: The patient, with a history of hypertension and type II diabetes, presents with hypertensive and diabetic nephropathy. The liver and right kidney allografts were procured en bloc, and standard liver and kidney back-table reconstruction was performed. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of portal hypertension and splenomegaly, but these are less likely given the imaging and surgical findings. S: The patient, a female with a history of combination hormone therapy for the past 5 years, presented with a vague thickening in the right breast at 1:00, 2 cm from the nipple. She reports a history of postmenopausal breast cancer and a maternal grandmother with postmenopausal breast cancer. O: Initial diagnostic mammogram with tomosynthesis and targeted ultrasound was BI-RADS 1: negative. The breasts were classified as extremely dense. Physical examination showed no dominant masses. MBI with an intravenous injection of 152 MBq (4.1 mCi) Tc-99m sestamibi showed asymmetric, segmentally distributed, marked intensity radiotracer uptake in the upper outer right breast, measuring 5.9 cm in maximum dimension. Second-look ultrasound of the right breast at 1:00 showed an ill-defined hypoechoic area with posterior shadowing. Ultrasound-guided biopsy confirmed pleomorphic ILC, Nottingham grade I (of III), ER/PR positive, HER-2Neu negative, and Ki-67 of the right breast. A: The primary diagnosis is low-grade invasive lobular carcinoma of the right breast, pleomorphic ILC, Nottingham grade I (of III), ER/PR positive, HER-2 Neu negative, and Ki-67 of the right breast. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of breast cancer, but these are less likely given the imaging and biopsy results. P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition with regular follow-ups with the healthcare team. The patient will be educated on the importance of adhering to the treatment plan and adherence to follow-up schedules. Further consultations with oncology and oncology may be necessary depending on the response to treatment.

S: The patient, with a history of dysphagia, difficulty swallowing solid foods, and increased intake of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) medications for a month, reports no improvement with dexlansoprazole. The patient also reports an increased intake of NSAIDs due to joint pain. O: Physical examination was unremarkable. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) revealed abnormal esophageal mucosa with two esophageal webs and gastritis with vague nodularity in the gastric body. Esophageal biopsies showed mild chronic active gastritis, mild focal gastric atrophy, significant subepithelial collagen plate thickening, entrapped inflammatory cells, red blood cells, and small capillaries compatible with collagenous gastritis (CG). Trichrome stain was noted. Serum protein electrophoresis was negative for monoclonal protein, and urine protein electrophoresis showed minor albuminuria. Celiac screen showed anti-transglutaminase IgA at 1.0 U/ml and IgA at 2.36 g/L, respectively. CBC from a year ago was normal with hemoglobin at 145 g/L, platelet at 216  109/L, and WBC at 6.4  109/L. A: The primary diagnosis is collagenous gastritis (CG), evidenced by the presence of inflammatory cells, red blood cells, and small capillaries. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of gastritis, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The management plan includes discontinuation of dexlansoprazole and continuation of dexlansoprazole. The patient will continue on the same dose of dexlansoprazole and will undergo upper and lower endoscopies to rule out other causes of gastritis. A colonoscopy will be conducted to monitor for any further complications. The patient will be educated on the signs of worsening gastritis and the importance of regular follow-up.

S: The patient reports a two-month history of right breast erythema and nipple erosion. The patient has a history of Raynaud's phenomena, arthralgias, alopecia, malar rash, lupus nephritis, and thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura diagnosed 13 years ago, treated with plasmapheresis, cyclophosphamide, mycophenolate mofetil, irbesartan, and maintenance hydroxychloroquine. O: A needle core biopsy identified grade two invasive ductal carcinoma with estrogen receptor 8/8, progesterone receptor 4/8, and negative human epidermal growth factor receptor two via silver in situ hybridization. Stageing workup showed a conglomerated lymph node mass measuring 1.5 cm in the right level I-II axilla without distant metastases (cT4dN1M0 [IIIC]). A subsequent right total mastectomy, sentinel node biopsy with completion of right-sided level I-II axillary dissection, and a prophylactic left-sided mastectomy revealed a 4-cm residual tumor and 3/15 nodes positive for residual disease (ypT4dN1aM0R0). A: The primary diagnosis is grade two invasive ductal carcinoma of the right axilla, with extensive lymphovascular and dermal invasion. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of invasive ductal carcinomas, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation. The prognosis is guarded due to the aggressive nature of the disease and the patient's history of autoimmune disease. P: The management plan includes designing the setup and treatment fields for adjuvant radiotherapy (RT) to minimize lung and cardiac doses. The patient will be educated on the importance of adherence to the treatment regimen and the risks associated with RT. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's response to treatment and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient is a 19-year-old Indian male presenting with abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and weight loss. He has undergone multiple surgeries including left hemicolectomy, colocolic, and jejunojejunal anastomosis. Postoperatively, he developed an anastomotic leak, which required reoperation and mechanical ventilation for pulmonary edema. O: Initial diagnostic tests showed moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma (T2N0M0). Postoperative complications included an anastomotic leak, severe depressed left ventricular function, global hypokinesia in the anteroseptal wall, anterior wall, and intraventricular septum, mild mitral regurgitation, mild tricuspid regurgitation, and no pulmonary artery hypertension. ECG showed sinus tachycardia with a heart rate of 150 bpm, poor R wave progression, and nonspecific ST-T changes. Troponin I level was 1.69 ng/mL, CPK-MB was 5.2 ng/mL, and BNP was 2000 pg/mL. On day 3, hypotension and metabolic acidosis worsened, with chilled peripheries and maximally vasoconstricted urine output. A: The primary diagnosis is moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma (T2N0M0), complicated by anastomotic leak and septic myocarditis. Differential diagnoses considered included acute coronary syndrome and septic myocarditis, but these were ruled out based on imaging and clinical findings. P: The patient has been started on daily aspirin 75 mg, clopidogrel 75 mg, injection fondaparinux 2.5 mg, and injection torsemide 20 mg thrice daily. On day 3, hypotension and metabolic acidosis worsened, with chilled peripheries and maximally vasoconstricted urine output. The plan includes initiation of an IABP, considering cardiogenic shock as the primary cause of his condition. Further treatment options include a revascularization of the left hemicolectomy, colocolic, and jejunojejunal

S: The patient, with a history of hypertension and peptic ulcer disease, presents with progressively worsening headaches and repeated episodes of syncope. O: CT of the head revealed a lobulated pituitary soft tissue mass in the sella turcica region, measuring 1.8 cm x 1.7 cm x 1.4 cm, classified as a macroadenoma, causing displacement of the optic chiasm without sella bony erosion. Visual field testing was normal. Hormonal workup indicated low testosterone at 85 ng/dl and low luteinizing hormone at 1.0 mIU/ml. Other hormone levels including plasma adrenocorticotropic hormone, follicle stimulating hormone, insulin-like growth factor-1, prolactin, and thyroid stimulating hormone were within normal ranges. ENT surgery was performed, and the tumor was completely removed. A: The primary diagnosis is a non-cancerous pituitary macroadenoma in the sella turcica region. The patient underwent successful CT-guided stereotactic endoscopically assisted transsphenoidal resection of the tumor. The patient's symptoms and hormone levels were monitored closely. P: The patient underwent successful CT-guided stereotactic endoscopically assisted transsphenoidal resection of the pituitary macroadenoma. Regular follow-ups and imaging studies will be conducted to monitor the tumor's response to treatment and ensure no recurrence. The patient is advised to maintain regular check-ups and imaging studies to ensure no recurrence of the tumor.

S: The patient, a 5-year-old girl, presented with developmental delays, mild intellectual disability, microcephaly, and a history of recurrent thrombocytopenia and microcephaly. The parent reports that the child has made good progress with intensive combined therapies and has a low normal IQ at 5 years of age. O: Brain MRI revealed two unilateral periventricular nodular heterotopias, with normal brain morphology. Whole exome sequencing revealed a de novo insertion in the last exon of ACTB, c.1101dup, containing 8 amino acids and 4 residues at the far C-terminus of -CYA. A: The primary diagnosis is ACTB-associated syndromic thrombocytopenia (ACTB-AST), characterized by developmental delay, mild intellectual disability, microcephaly, and a history of thrombocytopenia with platelet anisotropy and enlarged platelets. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of developmental delays and microcephaly, but these are less likely given the genetic and physical characteristics. P: Continue the combined therapies and regular checkups to monitor the patient's development. Encourage the parent to report any new symptoms immediately. Encourage the patient to report any new symptoms immediately.

S: The patient, a 78-year-old male, presented with difficulty speaking clearly four years ago. He first noticed this issue four years ago, noticing it four years ago. He also experienced a fever, heart racing, inability to breathe properly, and drowsiness at age 78. He was diagnosed with ALS at age 71 and diagnosed with a urinary tract infection at age 75. He also experienced a fever, heart racing, inability to breathe properly, and drowsiness at age 78. O: During hospitalization, the patient was diagnosed with pyuria, increased white blood cells, and elevated C-reactive protein levels. ECG indicated ST elevation in V1–V5. Echocardiography showed decreased wall motion in the apex of the heart, incongruent with the coronary artery supply region, but basal motion was normal. Echocardiography indicated decreased wall motion in the apex of the heart, incongruent with the coronary artery supply region. A: The primary diagnosis is Takotsubo cardiomyopathy (TTS), characterized by decreased wall motion in the apex of the heart, incongruent with the coronary artery supply region, and normal basal motion. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of dysarthria and breathing difficulties, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The patient was admitted for 11 days for Takotsubo cardiomyopathy and urinary tract infection. He is advised to continue monitoring his health and follow up with his healthcare team to manage his ALS and any potential complications. Education on recognizing symptoms of ALS and the importance of follow-up care is crucial. Referral to a cardiologist for further evaluation and management of ALS and potential complications is recommended.

S: The patient reports severe dyspnea, particularly during mild exertion. The patient has a history of lymphocytic myocarditis, stage III chronic kidney disease, chronic gastritis, and Hashimoto thyroiditis. The patient has a history of high dose ACEI, ß-Blocker, diuretics, and MRA. The patient has a history of progressive left ventricular ejection fraction reduction and LV dilation over the years. The patient has been on high dose ACEI, ß-Blocker, diuretics, and MRA. O: The patient's current medications include high dose ACEI, ß-Blocker, diuretics, and MRA. A transthoracic echocardiogram revealed dilated cardiomyopathy with severe global LV hypokinesia and an ejection fraction of 30%. A 24-hour infusion of calcium sensitizer levosimendan improved basic hemodynamics, indicating a drop in systemic and pulmonary vascular resistance and increased cardiac output. A: The primary diagnosis is dilated cardiomyopathy with severe global LV hypokinesia and an ejection fraction of 30%. Differential diagnoses could include coronary heart disease or recurrence of myocarditis. The prognosis is guarded due to the severity of the dilated cardiomyopathy and the presence of severe global LV hypokinesia. P: Continue monitoring the patient's cardiac function and adjust the treatment plan as necessary based on the patient's response to levosimendan. Regular follow-up appointments are necessary to assess the effectiveness of the treatment and adjust as necessary. Educate the patient on the importance of adherence to the treatment plan and adherence to follow-up appointments.

S: The patient, an 8-year-old female, presented with pain in the left ear, bleeding from the mouth, difficulty swallowing, change in voice, and difficulty breathing for approximately a month. There is no history of trauma to the neck, nasal obstruction, or nosebleeds. O: Clinical examination revealed a large submucosal bulge over the left tonsillar fossa, pushing the uvula to the opposite side, obscuring the oropharyngeal airway, and a pinkish friable mass in the nasopharynx. Nasal endoscopy showed both choanae blocked by a pinkish friable mass. Hematological, liver, and renal function tests were within normal limits. Contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CECT) scan showed a large heterogeneous enhancing soft tissue density mass in the left parapharyngeal space, extending to the oropharynx, laryngopharynx, nasopharynx, prevertebral space, paravertebral region, and superiorly up to the base of the skull, causing displacement of the left carotid artery, complete compression of the internal jugular vein, and significant narrowing of the airway. Biopsy indicated sheets and nests of round-to-oval tumor cells with hyperchromatic nuclei and scant cytoplasm, brisk mitosis, and large areas of tumor necrosis. Immunohistochemical tests were positive for CD99 and negative for SMA, desmin, and chromogranin. Weak PAS positivity was noted. Chest and abdomen CECT showed multiple lung nodules with lytic lesions in the dorsal vertebra, suggestive of metastasis. A: The primary diagnosis is Ewing's sarcoma (EES) of the parapharyngeal space, with lung and skeletal metastasis. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of sarcoma, but these are less likely given the imaging and biopsy results. P: The treatment plan includes chemotherapy with vincristine, doxorubicin, and cyclophosphamide

S: The patient, a recurrent lymph node metastasis with BRAF wild-type melanoma, developed recurrent lymph node metastases and a left occipital MBM in December 2014, treated with Trimix DC vaccination and ipilimumab at 3 mg/kg, followed by pembrolizumab at 2 mg/kg. Cerebral MRI and FDG-PET CT indicated RNB, suggestive of a hypometabolic lesion. The patient is currently in complete remission. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of melanoma, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and imaging findings. The prognosis is good with ongoing management of RNB. P: Continue regular follow-up appointments and report any new symptoms promptly. Educate the patient on signs of recurrence and encourage immediate reporting of any new symptoms. Encourage the patient to maintain regular follow-up appointments and report any new symptoms promptly.

S: The patient is a 75-year-old male former smoker with a 45-pack year history of tobacco abuse, presenting with swelling in the left neck, progressive hoarseness, and difficulty swallowing over the past one to two months. He reports a history of smoking and tobacco abuse. O: Biopsy of the swollen left neck node revealed squamous cell carcinoma, p16 positive. CT and PET-CT scans revealed a 4.5 cm x 7 cm mass involving the left hypopharynx and oropharynx, crossing the midline, causing narrowing of the hypopharyngeal and supraglottic airway, bulky left level II neck lymphadenopathy, and three FDG avid lung nodules. Biopsied one of the lung nodules confirmed metastatic p16 positive squamous cell carcinoma. Follow-up imaging at eight weeks showed progression of the disease with growth of primary and neck masses, ulcerating through the skin, and disease progression in the chest, with growth of previous nodules and new pulmonary nodules. A: The primary diagnosis is metastatic p16 positive squamous cell carcinoma of the neck, complicated by lung nodules. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of squamous cell carcinomas, but imaging and clinical findings support the primary diagnosis. P: The patient underwent a tracheostomy and gastrostomy placement to address airway obstruction and dysphagia. The treatment plan includes QUAD SHOT, delivering 3.7 Gy BID x 2 days (total dose 14.8 Gy) to the gross disease and 3.3 Gy BID x 2 days (13.2 Gy) to microscopic areas at high risk for disease. The patient will be closely monitored for any changes in symptoms or concerns and will be educated on the importance of reporting any new symptoms or concerns.

S: The patient is a 49-year-old obese Hispanic male with a history of granulomatosis with polyangiitis diagnosed in 2010, treated with corticosteroids, plasmapheresis, and cyclophosphamide. He reports frequent ED visits for nosebleeds and ear infections. O: Physical examination revealed saddle nose deformity, distant heart sounds, jugular venous distention, and an arteriovenous fistula bruit. Laboratory findings include normocytic anemia, elevated BUN and Cr levels, hyperkalemia, hypophosphatemia, elevated acute phase reactants, and increased  and  free light chains. Negative c-ANCA, positive p-ANCA, elevated myeloperoxidase antibodies, normal serine protease 3 antibodies, and normal complement levels. EKG shows sinus tachycardia with an S wave in lead I, Q wave in lead III, and electrical alternans. CTA is negative for pulmonary embolism but shows a moderate pericardial effusion and bilateral pulmonary opacities. Echocardiogram confirms tamponade with a solid component in the pericardial tissue. A: The primary diagnosis is tamponade with a solid component in the pericardial tissue. Differential diagnoses include pulmonary embolism and CMV colitis. The prognosis is guarded due to the severity of the tamponade and the rehospitalization of the patient's family member. P: The management plan includes emergent dialysis and a pericardial window to treat the tamponade. The patient will be monitored for recurrence of pulmonary embolism and sepsis from CMV colitis and E. coli. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's response to treatment and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. Education on recognizing symptoms of tamponade and its complications will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient reports a 15 kg weight gain and facial erythema. The patient has a history of prednisone use for orofacial granulomatosis 2 years ago but has not used any corticosteroids since then. The patient denies any hyperandrogenism, virilization, acne, hirsutism, seborrhea, balding, or deepening of the voice. The patient has regular menstrual cycles and is not taking oral contraceptives. O: Physical examination shows a BMI of 22.4 kg/m2, no facial plethora, skin striae, hirsutism, acne, spotty pigmentation, or skin myxomas. Thyroid examination is normal. Laboratory results indicate an 8 a.m. serum cortisol level of 6 g/dl after the 1 mg overnight dexamethasone suppression test (DST), elevated 24-hour urinary free cortisol levels (>510 g/day and >485 g/day, normal 20–90), and suppressed morning plasma adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) at 1 pg/ml. Complete blood count and liver function tests are normal. A: The primary diagnosis is ACTH-independent Cushing's syndrome, evidenced by the patient's symptoms, lab results, and lab results. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of muscle weakness, facial plethora, or other gastrointestinal symptoms. The prognosis depends on the response to treatment and management of the ACTH-independent Cushing's syndrome. P: The management plan will include a low-dose dexamethasone suppression test and a follow-up appointment in 3 months. The patient will be educated on the signs of potential complications and advised on the importance of regular follow-up appointments. Further diagnostic work-ups will be scheduled to assess the effectiveness of the treatment and manage any complications. Referral to a gastroenterologist for further evaluation and management of ACTH-independent Cushing's syndrome will be arranged. Patient education regarding the nature of the condition, treatment options, and potential side effects will be provided to ensure understanding and compliance.

S: The patient, a known case of colonic perforation, abdominal wall hernia with strangulated ileus, and small intestine resection five years ago, presents with hypokalaemia, malnutrition, and decreased renal function. The patient has a history of colonic perforation, abdominal wall hernia with strangulated ileus, and a small intestine resection five years ago. RBC count is 3.34  103/, hemoglobin 11.3 g/dL, hematocrit 33.2%, platelet count 27.9  104/, total bilirubin 1.6 mg/dL, aspartate aminotransferase 48 IU/L, and alanine aminotransferase 37 IU/L. Further consultations with a gastroenterologist and a hematologist are recommended to address the underlying causes of hypokalaemia and malnutrition.

S: The patient is a 12-year-old girl presenting with photophobia and ocular hyperemia for four weeks. She reports no improvement in renal function or recurrent uveitis. O: The patient's blood pressure is normal. She has iron-deficiency anemia, an ESR of 120 mm/first hour, a GRF of 47 ml/min/1.73m2, leukocyturia, glucosuria, hematuria, and non-nephrotic proteinuria. Chest X-ray and kidney ultrasound examinations were normal. Chest X-ray and kidney ultrasound showed no alterations. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic with remission within two months, and uveitis is expected to be in remission within two months. The patient will be started on methotrexate at 10 mg/m2/week. A: The primary diagnosis is bilateral anterior and intermediate uveitis, with differential diagnoses including infectious and autoimmune diseases. The prognosis is cautiously optimistic with appropriate management. P: The patient will be started on mydriatics, topical corticosteroids, and oral deflazacort. She will be in remission within two months of treatment, followed by discontinuation of systemic corticosteroids and starting on methotrexate at 10 mg/m2/week. She will be asymptomatic 18 months post-diagnosis. Regular follow-ups are necessary to monitor her condition and ensure no recurrence of uveitis or recurrent uveitis.

S: The patient reports experiencing breathing difficulties and chest pain. The patient has a history of a large tumor in the left lower lobe of the lung, staged as pT4N0M0, stage IIIB. A: The primary diagnosis is squamous cell carcinoma of the left lower lobe, stage IIIB. The patient underwent a left lower lobectomy and resection of the thoracic wall and diaphragm. The tumor was surgically removed, and histological analysis confirmed the diagnosis of squamous cell carcinoma. P: The patient underwent a left lower lobectomy and resection of the thoracic wall and diaphragm. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's recovery and ensure no signs of cancer recurrence.
