S: The patient, admitted with a five-day history of left chest pain and progressive weakness in the left arm, described the pain as a paroxysmal dull ache worsening post-activity. The patient reported using analgesic poultices as symptomatic treatment for pains but developed dizziness during work the next day. The patient also experienced difficulty breathing without other symptoms. O: Initial examinations showed nebulous and reddish lividity on the back, diffuse ecchymosis on the face, anterior neck, and upper chest, and petechial haemorrhage on the bulbar and palpebral conjunctiva, signs of asphyxia, and cyanosis on the lips, fingernails, and toenails. No bleeding or fractures were noted in the body. Systemic pathological autopsy revealed a 2.5 cm  1.0 cm  1.0 cm neoplasm in the left cervical spinal cord (C3–C5) underneath the spinal nerve root, with a compressed spinal cord visibly sunken. Microscopic examination revealed widespread and recurrent haemorrhage, haemosiderin particle aggregation, and scattered infiltration of lymphocytes within the subarachnoid space of the C3–C5 spinal cord. Tumor cells were long and spindle-shaped, uniform in size, with a fence-shaped, whirlpool, and wavy arrangement, with sporadic Verocay bodies (Antoni type A), haemangiectasis with paralytic congestion, myxoid matrix deposition, and vascular wall hyaline degeneration. A: The primary diagnosis is a neoplasm in the left cervical spinal cord, likely causing the patient's pain, progressive weakness, and asphyxia. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of spinal cord pain and asphyxia, but these are less likely given the imaging and pathological findings. P: The patient was confirmed dead by emergency physicians, and a systemic pathological autopsy was conducted for histopathological examination and judicial poisoning analysis. The family will be educated about the nature of the neoplasm and the

S: The patient is a 48-year-old Sinhalese male with a history of myasthenia gravis diagnosed in May 2016 and treated with thymectomy for thymic hyperplasia in November 2016. He reports progressive dysphagia starting with solids and moving on to liquids for approximately 3 months. He has experienced two episodes of myasthenic crises precipitated by lower respiratory tract infections, which required mechanical ventilatory support. He is currently on pyridostigmine, mycophenolate mofetil, and prednisolone therapy. O: On admission, respiratory parameters and limb muscle power were normal, but iohexol (OmnipaqueTM) was administered under fluoroscopy guidance. However, the contrast material entered the right main bronchus, leading to a transfer to the accident and emergency treatment unit (ETU). The patient's effort of breathing dropped significantly 45 minutes after admission to the ETU, dropping to 10 breaths per minute. Continuous treatment with nebulized salbutamol and metronidazole 500 mg as a stat dose, and endotracheal intubation with 3 mg of midazolam and 10 mg of atracurium was administered. A: The primary diagnosis is myasthenia gravis with complications including respiratory distress due to contrast exposure. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of respiratory distress, but these are less likely given the patient's history and clinical presentation. P: Continue monitoring the patient's respiratory status and adjust treatment as necessary based on the patient's response to treatment and response to treatment. Maintain current medications and monitor for any recurrence or complications. Educate the patient on the importance of compliance with the treatment regimen and follow-up appointments. Consider referral to a neurologist for further evaluation and management of myasthenia gravis.

S: The patient, a smoker of marijuana and tobacco, reports a history of marijuana and tobacco abuse, but denies alcohol excess or illicit drug use. The patient experienced acute thalamomesencephalic stroke leading to a comatose state. The patient has a history of a large tattoo on the left hypochondrium and abdominal flank and smoking marijuana with joints. O: Initial neurological examination revealed right-sided severe ataxic hemiparesis, dysarthria, left palpebral ptosis, mydriasis, divergent strabismus, and fluctuating consciousness with a Glasgow coma scale of 10/15. Blood tests including white blood cells count, hemoglobin, electrolytes, liver, and renal function were normal. Urine toxicology was positive for tetrahydrocannabinol. EKG and chest X-ray findings were normal. Clotting tests showed antithrombin III at 108% (>80%), homocysteine at 7.5 mol ( 12), lupus anticoagulant negative, antinuclear antibodies at 0.3 UM (0.7), and C protein at 117% (70-130). Emergent CT scan showed no gross abnormalities and no evidence of cerebral hemorrhage or encephalitis. A: The primary diagnosis is acute thalamomesencephalic stroke with complications including severe ataxic hemiparesis, dysarthria, left palpebral ptosis, mydriasis, divergent strabismus, and fluctuating consciousness. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of cerebral hemorrhage and encephalitis, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition, supportive care for symptoms, and supportive care for recovery. The patient will be educated on the importance of adherence to prescribed medications and lifestyle modifications to prevent further complications. Referral to a neurologist for further evaluation and management of the coma is recommended. Family support will be provided during this difficult time.

S: The patient is an 84-year-old nursing home resident with a history of type II diabetes mellitus, hypertension, cerebrovascular accident, anoxic brain injury, and a PEG tube and tracheostomy connected to a ventilator. The patient reports feeling uncomfortable and worried. O: On examination, the patient was hypertensive with a blood pressure of 160/74 mmHg, heart rate of 80 bpm, respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, O2 saturation of 100% on 100% FiO2 fraction of inspired oxygen, assist control-volume control + ventilator mode, and a temperature of 37.8°C. Physical examination revealed general edema, crepitus on palpation starting at the forehead, abdomen, pelvis, and upper thighs, and swollen upper arms with crepitus on palpation. The tracheostomy with the tracheal tube was noted with slightly pink secretions and dried blood on gauze surrounding the tube. Chest auscultation showed Hamman's crunch and decreased breath sounds at the right apex. Stat chest X-ray indicated extensive PM associated with subcutaneous emphysema in the neck and right chest wall. A: The primary diagnosis is subcutaneous emphysema with associated subcutaneous emphysema. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of emphysema, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation. P: The patient will be kept in the hospital for close monitoring and treatment to manage the subcutaneous emphysema and other complications. The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition and appropriate treatment for the subcutaneous emphysema. The patient will be educated on the importance of adhering to the ventilator settings and tracheostomy care to prevent further complications. Referral to an otolaryngologist for further evaluation and management of the subcutaneous emphysema is planned.

S: The patient, a five-year-old male, presented with a chief complaint of fever, pallor, rash, two episodes of non-projectile, blood-stained vomitus, and a non-progressive, black lesion over his nose. The mother reported a high-grade, continuous fever up to 103-104°F, with no chills, earache, ear discharge, and limited movement of the left ankle joint four days post-fever. The patient was treated with intravenous antibiotics temporarily, but the joint pain persisted. O: The patient was admitted to the pediatric ward and treated with intravenous antibiotics for two weeks. Labs showed slightly elevated platelet count (451,000/microliter), elevated CRP (22.7mg/L), elevated ESR (42 mm/hr), and a negative ANA. A: The primary diagnosis is oligoarticular juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA), evidenced by elevated platelet count, elevated CRP, elevated ESR, and negative ANA. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of joint pain and fever, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and laboratory findings. P: Initiate treatment with sulfasalazine (30 mg/kg/day, in two divided doses) and naproxen (15 mg/kg/day, in two divided doses). Monitor the patient's symptoms closely and report any new or worsening symptoms. Educate the mother on the importance of reporting any new or worsening symptoms immediately.

S: The patient is a 58-year-old Caucasian male with a 10-year history of ulcerative colitis, presenting with general unwellness, fever, and rigors. He has a history of proctocolectomy with ileal pouch-anal anastomosis, small bowel resections, and a permanent end ileostomy. He reports multiple infections with the Hickman line and has been treated parenterally with a central venous catheter, a Hickman line. He denies significant family or social history. O: Initial vital signs include a heart rate of 108 bpm, respiration rate of 24, SpO2 of 93%, temperature of 38.9° C, blood pressure of 154/94 mmHg, and GCS score of 15/15. Physical examination shows normal heart sounds with no added sounds. The Hickman line is not loose, disconnected, or blocked. The right iliac fossa stoma is in the right iliac fossa, with no signs of swelling, bruising, pain, or bleeding. Blood tests indicate anemia and raised inflammatory markers. A: The primary diagnosis is a stoma in the right iliac fossa, complicated by multiple infections and complications from the Hickman line. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of stoma, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation. P: Initiate treatment with Loperamide, Codeine phosphate, and Omeprazole to reduce stoma output. Monitor the patient's condition closely and adjust treatment as necessary. Educate the patient on signs of infection and when to seek immediate care. Schedule follow-up appointments to monitor the patient's condition and adjust treatment as necessary.

S: The patient presented with sudden onset of sharp, burning right lower extremity pain following use of crack cocaine. The patient denies experiencing chest pain, shortness of breath, abdominal pain, or neurologic symptoms. The patient's past medical history is unremarkable. O: Physical examination revealed the patient to be alert and oriented but in obvious distress. Vital signs were within normal limits except for a blood pressure of 180/100 mmHg. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations were benign with notably equal radial pulses. The right lower extremity was cool to touch without palpable pulses distal to and including the common femoral artery, and the left lower extremity was warm with bounding pulses. Neurologic examination showed normal and symmetric strength in bilateral upper and lower extremities without sensory deficits. Point-of-Care Ultrasound (POCUS) was performed in the emergency department. A large, undulating intimal flap was identified within the abdominal aorta without evidence of a Stanford Type A dissection. A: The primary diagnosis is a Stanford Type B dissection of the abdominal aorta. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of aortic pain, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation. P: The patient underwent a thoracic endovascular aortic repair without complications. Post-operative care will include monitoring blood pressure and monitoring for any signs of recurrence or complications. Follow-up care will be necessary to assess recovery and manage any complications.

S: RC, initially diagnosed with T3N2M0 midrectal cancer, reports feeling okay but feels weak. Post-chemoradiation, RC underwent a laparoscopic low anterior resection with a diverting loop ileostomy, adjuvant chemotherapy, and an elective reversal of the ileostomy nine months postoperatively. Postoperatively, RC experienced persistent small bowel obstruction. Postoperatively, RC experienced multiple adhesions around the previous reversal site, normal-appearing dilated proximal and collapsed distal small bowel, and no localized stricture in the defunctionalized distal ileum. CT imaging and a small bowel series showed a narrowing of the ileum distal to the previous anastomosis. A second exploratory laparotomy revealed persistent collapsed bowel loops distal to the new anastomosis. Pathology of the distal ileum showed submucosal fibrosis with hyalinization of the lamina propria and atherosclerotic changes in adjacent vessels. A: Primary diagnosis is T3N2M0 midrectal cancer with complications including persistent small bowel obstruction and ileocolic anastomosis. Differential diagnosis initially included exclusion colitis and distant metastases, which were ruled out by imaging and surgical findings. P: The patient underwent a second exploratory laparotomy with intraoperative findings of persistent collapsed bowel loops distal to the new anastomosis and ileocolic anastomosis. The patient was discharged on hospital day 38 with instructions to continue monitoring health and follow up with the medical team for any additional care.

S: The patient is a 62-year-old male with a history of Type 2 diabetes, presenting with a non-healing ulcer on his left heel. He reports that the ulcer has been bothersome for a while. O: Initial radiograph of the left calcaneus was unremarkable. MRI results showed a non-displaced insufficiency fracture of the calcaneus without osteomyelitis. A: The primary diagnosis is a non-displaced insufficiency fracture of the calcaneus, with no evidence of osteomyelitis. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of calcaneal ulcers, but these are less likely given the MRI results. P: The treatment plan includes offloading the pressure on the affected area and possibly immobilizing the foot to allow the fracture to heal. Management of Type 2 diabetes will focus on ensuring proper blood flow and healing. The patient is advised to maintain a healthy diet, exercise, and manage blood sugar levels to promote overall health. Regular follow-ups will be scheduled to monitor the patient's progress and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient reports experiencing instability and issues with the left knee for the past 6 months. The patient has a history of a trauma to the knee approximately 6 months ago, which was not treated. O: Physical examination revealed an anterior defect on the left knee with visibility of the intercondylar articulating surfaces of the tibia and femur, and swelling in the anterior aspect of the left distal third thigh. On palpation, the superior part of the patella appears like the superior part of the patella, with the lower pole of the patella close to the left tibial tuberosity. An X-ray confirmed the presence of the superior fragment of the patella in the distal third aspect of the thigh and the lower fragment close to the tibial tuberosity. Postoperative care includes dynamic quadriceps strengthening and active straight-leg-raising exercises, followed by continuous passive motion. A: The primary diagnosis is an anterior defect in the left knee, likely secondary to a trauma. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of knee instability, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The management plan includes surgical intervention with quadricepsplasty and tension band wiring for the patella. Postoperative care will include dynamic quadriceps strengthening and active straight-leg-raising exercises, followed by continuous passive motion. The patient will be monitored closely for recovery progress, with a target range of knee motion from 5 degrees of extension lag to 40 degrees of flexion by 3 months. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess recovery and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

S: The patient reports intermittent distending pain on the right side of the head, near the back, for about a year, which has been worsening over the past 10 days. The patient has not experienced any positive symptoms in the nervous system such as numbness, tingling, or weakness. O: A CT scan showed no abnormal alterations in brain tissue but indicated right fungal sphenoid sinusitis. A transnasal endoscopic sphenoidotomy was performed, and histopathological examination of the tissue identified it as SSFB, a benign fungal infection. A: The primary diagnosis is right fungal sphenoid sinusitis, confirmed by histopathological examination and histopathological examination. The patient underwent successful transnasal endoscopic sphenoidotomy, which confirmed the diagnosis of SSFB. P: The patient underwent successful transnasal endoscopic sphenoidotomy with no need for antifungal therapy. Post-surgery, the patient reported no further recurrence of headaches. The treatment has been successful, and the patient is advised to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately.

S: The patient, with a history of hypertension, coronary artery disease with multiple episodes of cardiac arrest, bipolar disorder, hepatitis C, hysterectomy, and tracheostomy, reports difficulty breathing recently. He has a history of sick sinus syndrome, a condition in which the heart's natural pacemaker is not functioning properly. O: A CT angiogram confirmed an acute TAAD with true and false lumens and a dissection flap extending from the junction of the right- and noncoronary cusps of the aortic valve to the inferior mesenteric artery and left renal artery. During the ICU stay, respiratory failure required intubation and revision of the tracheostomy. The patient also experienced sick sinus syndrome, which led to the implant of a permanent pacemaker to regulate heartbeat. A: The primary diagnosis is acute TAAD with complications including respiratory failure, sick sinus syndrome, and a permanent pacemaker implant. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of cardiac arrest and respiratory failure, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical presentation. P: The patient will be admitted to the CT-ICU for hemodynamic monitoring and IV anti-impulse control. He will be discharged to a rehab facility to continue recovery and regain strength. The patient is advised to follow up with his healthcare team and take prescribed medications as prescribed. Regular follow-ups will be scheduled to monitor his condition and adjust treatment as necessary.

S: The patient, previously diagnosed with intestinal Schistosomiasis in Egypt, presented with absolute constipation, abdominal pain, distention, and vomiting. The patient denied any follow-up investigations to confirm eradication of the disease. O: Physical examination revealed distension, tenderness in the lower part, and absent bowel sounds. Digital rectal examination revealed a collapsed rectum. CT scan showed dilated bowel loops. Exploratory laparotomy revealed localized turbid fluid collection, dilated small and large bowel loops due to paralytic ileus, and a gangrenous appendix. Histopathology confirmed extensive necrosis of the appendix with multiple viable Schistosomal ova. Stool analysis showed no ova. A: The primary diagnosis is intestinal Schistosomiasis with complications including severe necrosis of the appendix and multiple viable Schistosomal ova. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of intestinal obstruction, but these are less likely given the histopathological findings and histopathology results. P: The patient underwent an exploratory laparotomy and appendectomy, followed by lavage and closure. Postoperative antibiotics were administered, and the patient was discharged home after approximately one week. The patient is advised to follow up with the healthcare team as needed and maintain a healthy lifestyle. Further consultations with a gastroenterologist and a nephrologist are recommended to manage the appendix.

S: The patient, admitted to the hospital, presented with fever, joint pain, and abdominal pain. The patient reported no other symptoms. O: Clinical examination revealed anemia, splenomegaly, and leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 19.6  109 /L with 72% lymphoblast. Bone marrow aspiration showed 92% infiltration of lymphoblast cells. Central nervous system (CNS) was not infiltrated by blast cells. Immunophenotyping indicated nTdT, cCD10, CD20, CD22, CD38, and CD45(low) positive, and cCD9, CD19, cCD79, and CD58(interm)-positive cells in 45% of blast cells. Myeloid and T-cell markers were negative. A: The primary diagnosis was leukemia with a history of relapse. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of leukemia, but the clinical presentation and immunophenotyping confirm leukemia. The prognosis is guarded due to the relapse and the presence of chromosomal translocations. P: Initiated a relapse treatment-rescue plan to address the relapse. The patient's family was advised to understand the risks involved and to understand the importance of adherence to the treatment plan. The patient's son passed away due to complications from an opportunistic infection during the relapse treatment.

S: The patient reports a history of a motorcycle accident in July 2016, treated with open reduction and internal fixation with a locking plate and single compression screw, along with a split-thickness skin graft in Bulgaria. The patient has a history of septic pseudarthrosis in the proximal tibia, intramedullary osteomyelitis, and a large abscess zone with contrast agent capturing 30 cm in the dorsal compartment. The patient experiences pain due to the unstable osseous situation, necessitating mobility. O: Initial diagnostics including plain radiographs and pan CT/MRI scan revealed septic pseudarthrosis in the proximal tibia, intramedullary osteomyelitis, necrotic avascular muscle areas, loss of the anterior tibial artery, and a large anterolateral soft tissue defect covered with necrotic split-thickness graft. Laboratory tests showed slightly increased infection parameters with CRP at 2.7 mg/dl and leukocytes at 6.9 G/l. Acinetobacter baumannii (Carbapenem resistant) and Enterobacter cloacae complex (overexpression of AmpC-Betalactamase and fluoroquinolone resistant) were noted in wound smears from the anterolateral defect zone and intramedullary in the proximal tibia to the distal third of the tibial shaft. A: The primary diagnosis is septic pseudarthrosis in the proximal tibia, intramedullary osteomyelitis, necrotic avascular muscle areas, loss of the anterior tibial artery, and a large anterolateral soft tissue defect covered with necrotic split-thickness graft. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of osteomyelitis, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and laboratory findings. P: The management plan includes removal of osteosynthesis material and necrotic split-thickness graft, aggressive extensive osseous debridement, and resection of necrotic muscles of the anterior

S: The owner, a 16-year-old Standard Poodle, presented with a chief complaint of mental status changes over the past year, confusion, less awareness of surroundings, difficulty recognizing human family members, and loss of previously learned abilities. The owner reported a generalized tonic-clonic seizure two days ago, accompanied by poor appetite, lethargy, circling, and signs of ataxia. O: Clinical examination revealed acute right-sided abnormalities including a postural reaction deficit, circling, head and neck turn, left-sided head tilt, positional nystagmus, and ataxia. Neurological examination showed acute right-sided abnormalities, including a postural reaction deficit, circling, head and neck turn, left-sided head tilt, positional nystagmus, and ataxia. Immunohistochemistry was performed, and sections of the brain were stained with hematoxylin and eosin. Immunohistochemistry was performed, and sections of the central nervous system were incubated with primary antibodies anti-APP and anti-GFAP. A: The primary diagnosis is a recurrent neurological disorder, likely a recurrent neurological disorder, given the recurrent neurological symptoms and a poor prognosis. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of neurological symptoms, but these are less likely given the imaging and histological findings. P: The management plan included euthanasia and necropsy. The owner agreed to proceed with the necropsy and necropsy, which will involve euthanasia and necropsy. The owner will be informed about the procedure and the results of the necropsy. Follow-up will be scheduled to discuss the results of the necropsy and the management plan.

S: The patient, a female with a history of confusion, was brought to the emergency department by emergency medical services following a husband's discovery of confusion. She reported feeling weak and disoriented upon arrival. O: Upon arrival, the patient's vital signs were stable with a heart rate of 80 bpm, blood pressure of 78/52 mmHg, respiratory rate of 14 respirations per minute, and temperature of 37.1° Celsius (98.8° Fahrenheit). Bedside glucose level was 170 grams per deciliter (g/dL). A cardiorespiratory monitor was attached, and a liter of crystalloid was infused with a pressure bag. The patient appeared somnolent, arousable, diaphoretic, and pale. Chest and cardiac rhythm were normal. Rectal examination revealed brown stool. Rapid Ultrasound for Shock and Hypotension (RUSH) examination showed moderate free fluid and a well-circumscribed mass adjacent to the uterus. Laboratory analysis showed venous lactate at 2.5 mmol/L, WBC at 11.46 cubic milliliter (K/uL), hemoglobin at 9.0 g/dL, and negative urine human chorionic gonadotropin test. A: The primary diagnosis is suspected hemoperitoneum, likely due to a mass near the uterus. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of abdominal pain or gastrointestinal bleeding, but these are less likely given the imaging and laboratory findings. P: The patient was injected with one liter of crystalloid with a pressure bag. The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition with regular blood products and monitoring of vital signs. The patient will be educated on the nature of hemoperitoneum and the importance of adhering to the treatment plan. Regular follow-ups will be scheduled to monitor the patient's condition and adjust treatment as necessary.

S: The patient, with a history of nonischemic cardiomyopathy, gout with extensive tophi, chronic lymphocytic leukemia on ibrutinib, and venous thromboembolism on rivaroxaban, reports feeling like their ICD was fired the other day. O: Vitals and ICD site are normal. No arrhythmia or shock therapy was noted on device interrogation. Blood cultures grew MSSA in 2 sets. De-escalated antibiotics to cefazolin. Transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) showed no vegetations and drainage of white cheesy material from an elbow tophus, which cultures grew MSSA. Blood cultures were negative after 2 days. A: The primary diagnosis is bacterial infection of the ICD, likely originating from an elbow tophus. Differential diagnoses initially included arrhythmia and shock therapy, but these were ruled out by negative blood cultures. P: The patient was discharged to a skilled nursing facility for 2 weeks of intravenous antibiotics. At the 2-month follow-up, there was no evidence of recurrence of infection at the 2-month follow-up. The patient is advised to continue monitoring his health and reach out if he has any concerns.

S: The patient reports a recent accident with a bark stripping machine at the sawmill, resulting in bilateral grade 3b tibia fractures. The patient has no other injuries or co-morbidities reported. O: Initial surgical intervention included a temporary fixator and appropriate debridement using a Hoffmann Express Stryker® with four half pins and a standard two-bar configuration. The soft tissue defect was equivalent to a Gustilo-Anderson IIIB. The patient was unable to have a flap applied due to a Gustilo-Anderson IIIB soft tissue defect. The first surgery involved frame application, deformation, and closure. The second surgery involved frame removal. The wound was a 270-degree circumferential skin wound from the postero-lateral to the postero-medial aspect of the middle third of the leg, with intact muscle bellies and distally present sensory and motor function. A: The primary diagnosis is bilateral grade 3b tibia fractures with complications including a Gustilo-Anderson IIIB soft tissue defect and a 270-degree circumferential skin wound from the postero-lateral to the postero-medial aspect of the middle third of the leg. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of tibia fractures, but these are less likely given the patient's history and surgical findings. P: The patient underwent a tibial bayonet procedure at the Ilizarov Institute in Kurgan. Sub-muscular elevation was performed, and a standard two-ring/four-half-pin hexapod frame was applied. The wound was a 270-degree circumferential skin wound from the postero-lateral to the postero-medial aspect of the middle third of the leg, with intact muscle bellies and distally present sensory and motor function. Post-operative care instructions will be provided, and the patient is advised to follow all post-operative care instructions and contact the healthcare provider if any concerns or questions arise.

S: The patient, a 2-year-old boy, presented with recurrent hypoglycemia and seizures for over 2 years. The symptoms started at a few days old, accompanied by fever, low calorific intake, or diarrhea. The parent reports that the child has been hospitalized multiple times for these episodes. The patient has a normal IQ and no disturbances in neuro-psycho-motor development. The patient also experienced jaundice on the fourth day post-birth, with total bilirubin at 316.6 mol/L and indirect bilirubin at 303.9 mol/L. Laboratory findings revealed low plasma cortisol and ACTH concentrations, no apparent circadian rhythm of ACTH and cortisol levels, and an ACTH test failed to stimulate cortisol production. Thyroid function tests, kidney function, and electrolytes were normal except for thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH), anterior pituitary hormone concentrations. Blood sugar was normal under non-stress conditions with continuous glucose monitoring. A: The primary diagnosis is recurrent hypoglycemia and seizures, likely secondary to underlying metabolic disorders, given the history of recurrent hypoglycemia and seizures. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of recurrent hypoglycemia and seizures, but these are less likely given the clinical presentation and laboratory findings. P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition with continuous glucose monitoring. The patient will be educated on the importance of reporting any new symptoms or changes in his condition. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor his condition and adjust treatment as necessary. Referral to a pediatric neurologist for further evaluation and management of recurrent hypoglycemia and seizures is recommended.

S: The patient, referred to the hospital, reports persistent vomiting for a few weeks and has become more frequent over the past few weeks. O: Endoscopic upper gastrointestinal imaging revealed a type 3 tumor at the EGJ with a circumference of 56 mm and stenosis. The epicenter is 3 mm from the EGJ on the gastric side. CT scan showed lymph node metastases along the lesser curvature of the stomach and the proximal splenic artery. The patient is diagnosed with a cT4aN2M0, cStage IIIC lesion, indicating spread to nearby lymph nodes but not to distant parts of the body. A: The primary diagnosis is a cT4aN2M0, cStage IIIC lesion, characterized by lymph node metastases. Differential diagnoses could include other types of gastrointestinal tumors, but these are less likely given the imaging and imaging findings. P: The management plan includes discussing the patient's case with a multidisciplinary team to determine the best treatment options. The patient will be closely monitored for response to treatment and expected outcomes. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess treatment efficacy and manage any complications. The patient is advised to reach out with any questions or concerns during the treatment process.

S: The patient reports a persistent cough persisting for a while. The patient has a history of uterine leiomyoma treated 13 years ago with a hysterectomy. O: Chest radiography and CT scan revealed multiple pulmonary bilateral nodules without FDG uptake. CT-guided biopsy of a pulmonary nodule and resected uterine leiomyoma showed identical histopathology of a low-grade, benign, smooth muscle tumor, Benign Metastasizing Leiomyoma (BML). Immunohistochemical profiles were indistinguishable from the primary uterine tumor, with positive SMA, desmin, estrogen, and progesterone receptors and negative HMB-45, CD31, CD34, and EMA. Ki-67 staining showed low mitotic activity, suggesting the tumor cells are not dividing rapidly. Cytogenetic analysis revealed 19q and 22q terminal deletions. A: The primary diagnosis is Benign Metastasizing Leiomyoma (BML), a low-grade, benign, smooth muscle tumor, with negative HMB-45, CD31, CD34, and EMA. Differential diagnosis initially included other uterine leiomyomas, but these were ruled out based on histopathology and cytogenetic analysis. P: The patient underwent surgical castration of the uterine leiomyoma. Post-surgery, the remaining lesions were stable. The patient is advised to maintain regular follow-up appointments to monitor for any recurrence or new symptoms. Further consultations with oncology and oncology are recommended to manage the condition and manage any complications.

S: Andrea is a patient with a history of right knee pain. She reports it occurs intermittently less than once a day, when walking, causing pain. She has a history of a fall, which she describes as causing the whole kneecap to fade. She has been taking farxiga and amlodipine, and lisinopril and hydrochlorothiazide, which are small dosage pills. She has a history of a systolic ejection murmur at the left base, with clear lungs to auscultation bilaterally. The patient has a history of hypertension, which has been ruled out by x-rays. O: Vital signs are: temperature 98.8 °C, pulse 770 bpm, respirations 16 bpm, blood pressure 128/70 mmHg. Heart and lung examinations show a slight 2 over 6 systolic ejection murmur at the left base, with a slight 2 over 6 systolic ejection murmur at the left base. Lungs are clear bilaterally. Right knee exam shows no ecchymosis or edema, effusion, pain to palpation of the left medial knee, decreased range of motion, negative varus and valgus test. Left knee x-ray shows no fracture or bony abnormalities. A: The primary diagnosis is arthritis, with differential diagnoses including hypertension, hypertension, and diabetes mellitus. The patient's symptoms and imaging findings are consistent with the primary diagnosis. P: The management plan includes meloxicam 15 mg daily for arthritis, physical therapy for hypertension, and a hemoglobin a1c to assess the heart murmur. The patient will be scheduled for an echocardiogram to evaluate the heart murmur and diabetes mellitus. A: The primary diagnosis is arthritis, with differential diagnoses including hypertension, hypertension, and diabetes mellitus. The patient's symptoms and imaging findings are consistent with the primary diagnosis. P: The management plan includes meloxicam 15 mg daily for arthritis, physical therapy for hypertension, and physical therapy for hypertension. The patient will continue lisinopril 20 mg daily for hypertension. Hemo

S: The patient is an 11-year-old thin-built, anemic girl presenting with pain in the upper abdomen and recurrent vomiting for a week. She reports disturbances in her behavior and decreased appetite over the past few months. She was previously admitted to another hospital for a similar issue but was treated conservatively. O: Physical examination revealed a nontender lump in the epigastric region, moving with respiration. Laboratory tests indicated microcytic hypochromic anemia. Other parameters were normal. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy (UGIE) identified a large blackish mass in the stomach, mostly hairs. A: The primary diagnosis is trichobezoar, based on the patient's history and imaging findings. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of abdominal pain and vomiting, but these are less likely given the imaging and laboratory findings. P: The management plan includes performing an anterior gastrotomy to remove the large hairball mass. Postoperative care will include a psychiatric consultation to address hair-chewing behavior. The patient will be discharged from the hospital with instructions to return for a follow-up in 6 months to monitor for any recurrence or complications.

S: The patient, who was in a motor vehicle collision, reports feeling slightly better after being fully oriented with a GCS of 15 on arrival. The patient also mentions mild cervical pain and concerns about the condition. O: Initial vital signs were within normal limits. Neurologic examination showed no focal neurological deficits. Brain CT scan, cervical and chest radiography, and FAST examination were unremarkable. Neurologic examination showed no focal neurological deficits. Initial treatment included primary and secondary trauma care, diagnostic studies including Brain CT, cervical and chest radiography, and FAST examination. The patient was readmitted with left hemiplegia two days later, indicating sudden onset of left hemiplegia. Doppler sonography confirmed the occlusion of the right vertebral artery. CT angiography confirmed the occlusion of the right vertebral artery. Warfarin was started at 5 mg per day to reach a target INR of 2-3. atorvastatin 40 mg was prescribed due to dyslipidemia. Physiotherapy for the left extremities improved the patient's left hemiplegia. A: The primary diagnosis is occlusion of the right vertebral artery. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of cervical pain, but these were ruled out by imaging and clinical findings. The prognosis is good with continued warfarin therapy. P: The patient was admitted to the neurology ward and started on heparin 1000 units per hour, titration to maintain a PTT target range of 50-70 seconds, and warfarin at 5 mg per day to reach a target INR of 2-3. atorvastatin 40 mg was prescribed due to dyslipidemia. Physiotherapy for the left extremities was initiated, and the patient was discharged with 5/5 muscle forces. The plan includes continued warfarin after discharge to ensure continued recovery. The patient is advised to reach out with any further questions or concerns.

S: The patient, a child, reports experiencing nyctalopia since childhood and has been experiencing worsening vision since age 20. The patient has tried an ERG examination but was unable to tolerate the examination. O: Examination findings include visual acuity of 20/400 in the right eye and 20/63 in the left eye. Funduscopy revealed bone spicule pigmentation and attenuated retinal vessels. Fundus AF and OCT imaging revealed increased and decreased Autofluorescence in the right eye and a fine pattern of radial lines radiating from the fovea in the left eye. Fundus AF showed increased and decreased Autofluorescence in the right eye, and fine pattern of radial lines radiating from the fovea in the left eye. OCT imaging showed widespread thinning of the photoreceptor layer in both eyes, with foveal sparing in the left eye, and thickening of the inner retina mainly around the optic disc, more evident in the right eye than the left eye. Genetic analysis confirmed a de novo RPGR mutation in the patient's mother. A: The primary diagnosis is Retinitis Pigmentosa (RP), evidenced by Fundus AF and OCT imaging findings. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of RP, but these are less likely given the genetic findings. P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's condition, supportive care, and referral to a low vision specialist to manage the RP. The patient will be educated on the nature of RP and the importance of adhering to the treatment plan. Regular follow-ups will be scheduled to monitor the patient's condition and adjust treatment as necessary.

S: The patient reports bilateral visual impairment for about a year and gradual progressive general fatigue for the past 3 months. The patient denies any history of epileptic seizures. O: Neurological examination revealed blindness in the left eye, half-blindness in the right eye on the ear side, and cognitive dysfunction. Mini Mental State Examination score was 21 out of 30. Fundus examination showed no papilledema. MRI revealed a 77  63  85-mm tumor originating from the pituitary gland, compressing the optic chiasm and bilateral frontal and temporal lobes. Hormone profile showed hyperprolactinemia at 25,270.0 ng/ml (normal range 3.6–12.8 ng/ml). Other pituitary hormones were dysfunction. A: The primary diagnosis is giant prolactinoma (PRLoma) and hypopituitarism. Differential diagnoses could include other forms of pituitary tumors, but these are less likely given the imaging and hormone profile. P: Initiate treatment with 1000 mg/day of levetiracetam. Initiate dopamine agonists (DA) as the initial treatment for PRLoma and hypopituitarism. Monitor hormone levels and adjust treatment as necessary. Educate the patient on the importance of adherence to the treatment plan and follow-up appointments to monitor recovery and manage any complications.

S: The patient reports severe injuries including a left 1st to 12th ribs, right 1st to 6th ribs, and left clavicle, with spine fractures including a displaced T12 spinous process fracture, L1 burst fracture, and L2, 3, and 5 transverse process fractures. The pain in the thorax and back is particularly severe, particularly in the thorax and back. O: The patient has been treated with multimodal analgesia including scheduled acetaminophen 1000 mg 4 times daily, gabapentin 300 mg 3 times daily, hydromorphone patient-controlled analgesia (PCA) with an average 24-hour hydromorphone consumption of 4.7 mg/day, lidocaine patches, and ketamine at 10 mg/hr. An epidural is contraindicated due to traumatic spine fractures. The patient has been on high-flow nasal cannula (HFNC) and intermittent continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) to improve respiratory function. Post-surgical management included intraoperative placement of bilateral ESP catheters targeting the right T5 transverse process. A: The primary diagnosis is traumatic spine fractures with associated traumatic spine fractures. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of thorax and back pain, but these are less likely given the patient's history and clinical presentation. The prognosis is guarded due to the severe nature of the fractures and the need for surgical intervention. P: The patient underwent surgical repair of the L1 burst fracture with T11-L3 posterior spinal instrumentation. Post-surgical management included intraoperative placement of bilateral ESP catheters targeting the right T5 transverse process. The patient was maintained under general anesthesia in the prone position on the operating room table, and a right-sided ESP block was performed using ultrasound guidance with a high-frequency linear ultrasound probe targeting the right T5 transverse process. Continuous monitoring and adjustment of the pain management plan are planned. The patient is advised to report any changes in pain levels or concerns immediately.

S: The patient reports a one-year history of low backache, typical claudication symptoms, left-sided numbness, and paresthesia of the foot, without radicular pain. Recently, the patient experienced progressive reduction in claudication distance, worsening gait, and urinary incontinence following a trivial fall last week. O: Physical examination revealed bilateral high-stepping gait due to foot drop, symmetrical weakness of both L4 and L5 roots (MRC grade 0/5), and partial weakness of the S1 root (MRC grade 3/5). Nondermatomal sensory disturbances and absent deep tendon reflexes were noted in lower limbs. Anal tone was normal, but saddle anesthesia was present. Postvoidal ultrasonogram of the urinary bladder showed a residual urine volume of 250 ml, confirming a neurogenic bladder. Plain radiography of the lumbar spine showed no gross instability and was inconclusive. MRI of the lumbar spine revealed a solitary intraspinal posterior epidural lesion at L2-L3 level, with adjacent epidural fatty hypertrophy contributing to severe canal stenosis (3 mm). The cauda equina is severely compressed and almost not visible. CT scan revealed an osseous lesion attached to the right L2 inferior articular process, causing severe secondary canal stenosis. A: The primary diagnosis is a neurogenic bladder with severe canal stenosis and secondary canal stenosis. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of spinal instability, but these are less likely given the imaging and imaging findings. P: The management plan includes surgical decompression and excision biopsy of the osseous lesion. The patient will be positioned prone on a Relton Hall frame under general anesthesia, with a standard midline posterior approach, exposure of the L2 and L3 lamina, and removal of the spinous process. Post-operative care will include monitoring and supportive care, with follow-up appointments to assess recovery and manage any complications. The patient is advised to reach out with any questions or concerns during the procedure.

S: The guardian of a 2.3-year-old boy from a South American ethnical background presents with microcephalus, complex febrile seizures, and moderate developmental delay. The patient has a history of prenatal exposure to ethanol. O: MRI revealed hyperintense lesions in both corona radiata, more prominent on the right side. Specroscopy indicated a lack of maturity in the frontal lobe, parietal areas, and basal nuclei. EEG studies showed abnormal activity with a generalized slow pattern and theta and delta bursts bilaterally in temporal regions. A: The primary diagnosis is microcephalus, complex febrile seizures, and moderate developmental delay. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of developmental delay, but these are less likely given the genetic findings. P: The management plan includes starting valproic acid to manage seizures and improve cognitive function. The medication has shown adequate response both physiologically and clinically. Genetic testing revealed a deletion of 183 bases (2475-2657 bases, C7 marker), but no alterations in genes LIS1, PTAFR, PAFAH1B2, PAFAH1B3, FGF8, and PAX2. A: The primary diagnosis is microcephalus, complex febrile seizures, and moderate developmental delay. The differential diagnosis includes other causes of developmental delay and developmental delays, but these are less likely given the genetic findings. P: The management plan includes continuation of valproic acid to manage seizures and improve cognitive function. Regular monitoring of the patient's condition is necessary, with adjustments to treatment as necessary based on the patient's response to the treatment. Regular follow-ups will be scheduled to monitor the patient's progress and adjust the treatment plan as necessary. The guardian is advised to report any new symptoms or concerns immediately.

S: The patient is a 42-year-old married woman with two children, presenting with a 4-month history of heartburn, frequent regurgitations, fatigue, and a change in bowel movements, accompanied by 4-5 soft stools daily. She reports a recent unintentional weight loss of 3 kg in a month. She has a history of coeliac disease diagnosed at age 20. O: Physical examination revealed normal IgA levels, negative anti-tTG levels, and antiendomysial antibodies. Ferritin was 33 mg/l, serum folate was lower than 5 nmol/l, hemoglobin was normal, and white blood cells and platelet count was normal. Upper GI endoscopy showed no macroscopic alterations. Biopsies from the gastric antrum, corpus-fundus mucosa, and the bulb and second part of the duodenum indicated Helicobacter Pylori pan-gastritis. Duodenal mucosa showed villous atrophy and increased IEL numbers up to more than 40 IEL/100 EC. A: The primary diagnosis is Helicobacter Pylori pan-gastritis, likely exacerbated by the Helicobacter Pylori infection. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of gastrointestinal symptoms, but these are less likely given the imaging and clinical findings. P: The management plan includes discussing treatment options to manage the Helicobacter Pylori infection and alleviate symptoms. The patient will be educated on the signs of worsening symptoms and the importance of adherence to the treatment plan. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor the patient's condition and adjust treatment as necessary.

S: The patient reports a gradual increase in the lump in the left breast, which has been present for 14 months. The patient denies any history of cancer. O: Physical examination revealed a large, fixed 10 cm mass in the left breast, adherent to the chest without skin invasion, no ulceration, nipple discharge, or retraction, and no palpable lymph nodes. Preoperative unenhanced CT scan showed a well-defined round heterogeneous soft tissue density with hypo dense areas, necrosis, and peripheral and central calcifications, measuring 07 cm  10 cm  11 cm. The tumor is located in the 4th and 5th anterior thoracic rib, with respect for the lung. Core-needle biopsy confirmed chondrosarcoma grade II. Post-operative histopathology confirmed the tumor as a blue-grey mass with a margin of more than 2.0 cm and a defect measuring 23  15 cm on the anterior chest wall. A: The primary diagnosis is chondrosarcoma grade II of the left breast, based on imaging and histopathology. Differential diagnosis initially included other forms of sarcomas. P: The patient underwent successful surgical removal of the tumor. Post-operative care includes extubation one day post-surgery and discharge in 10 days if no complications arise. The patient is advised to follow post-operative care instructions and report any concerns during recovery.
